"

:

"

Australia</a><br
>

<EOS>
color="#800000
"
size="4"><i
>
a
treasure
-
trove
of
literature</i><br
>
<
/font
<EOS>
>
treasure
found
hidden
with
no
evidence
of
ownership</p></td
>

>

>
<
!
<EOS>
--
ad
goes
here
--
>
<
<EOS>
pre
<EOS>
>
   
Title
:
<EOS>
Old
Saint
Paul
's
       
A
Tale
of
the
Plague
and
the
Fire
Author
:
<EOS>
William
Harrison
Ainsworth
    
<EOS>
The
portion
of
the
ensuing
Tale
relating
to
the
Grocer
of
Wood
-
street
,
and
his
manner
of
victualling
his
house
,
and
shutting
up
himself
and
his
family
within
it
during
the
worst
part
of
the
Plague
of
1665
,
is
founded
on
a
narrative
,
which
I
have
followed
pretty
closely
in
most
of
its
details
,
contained
in
a
very
rare
little
volume
,
entitled
,
"
_
Preparations
against
the
Plague
,
both
of
Soul
and
Body
_
,
"
the
authorship
of
which
I
have
no
hesitation
in
assigning
to
DEFOE
.
<EOS>
Indeed
,
I
venture
to
pronounce
it
his
masterpiece
.
<EOS>
It
is
strange
that
this
matchless
performance
should
have
hitherto
escaped
attention
,
and
that
it
should
not
have
been
reprinted
with
some
one
of
the
countless
impressions
of
the
"
_
History
of
the
Plague
of
London
_
,
"
to
which
it
forms
an
almost
necessary
accompaniment
.
<EOS>
The
omission
,
I
trust
,
will
be
repaired
by
Mr.
HAZLITT
the
younger
,
DEFOE
'S
last
and
best
editor
,
in
his
valuable
edition
of
the
works
of
that
great
novelist
and
political
writer
,
now
in
the
course
of
publication
.
<EOS>
It
may
be
added
,
that
a
case
precisely
similar
to
that
of
the
Grocer
,
and
attended
with
the
same
happy
results
,
occurred
during
the
Plague
of
Marseilles
,
in
1720
.
 
<EOS>
For
my
acquaintance
with
this
narrative
,
as
well
as
for
the
suggestion
of
its
application
to
the
present
purpose
,
I
am
indebted
to
my
friend
,
Mr.
JAMES
CROSSLEY
,
of
Manchester
.
 
<EOS>
KENSAL
MANOR
HOUSE
,
HARROW
ROAD
,
<EOS>
_
November
<EOS>
_
30
,
1841
.
    
<EOS>
CONTENTS
.
  
<EOS>
BOOK
<EOS>
THE
FIRST
--
April
,
1665
.
 
<EOS>
1
.
 
<EOS>
The
Grocer
of
Wood
-
street
and
his
Family
.
 
<EOS>
2
.
 
<EOS>
The
Coffin
-
maker
.
 
<EOS>
3
.
 
<EOS>
The
Gamester
and
the
Bully
.
 
<EOS>
4
.
 
<EOS>
The
Interview
.
 
<EOS>
5
.
 
<EOS>
The
Pomander
-
box
.
 
<EOS>
6
.
 
<EOS>
The
Libertine
Punished
.
 
<EOS>
7
.
 
<EOS>
The
Plague
Nurse
.
 
<EOS>
8
.
 
<EOS>
The
Mosaical
Rods
.
 
<EOS>
9
.
 
<EOS>
The
Miniature
.
 
<EOS>
10
.
<EOS>
The
Duel
.
  
<EOS>
BOOK
<EOS>
THE
SECOND.--May
,
1665
.
 
<EOS>
1
.
 
<EOS>
The
Progress
of
the
Pestilence
.
 
<EOS>
2
.
 
<EOS>
In
what
Manner
the
Grocer
Victualled
his
House
.
 
<EOS>
3
.
 
<EOS>
The
Quack
Doctors
.
 
<EOS>
4
.
 
<EOS>
The
Two
Watchmen
.
 
<EOS>
5
.
 
<EOS>
The
Blind
Piper
and
his
Daughter
.
 
<EOS>
6
.
 
<EOS>
Old
London
from
Old
Saint
Paul
's
.
 
<EOS>
7
.
 
<EOS>
Paul
's
Walk
.
 
<EOS>
8
.
 
<EOS>
The
Amulet
.
 
<EOS>
9
.
 
<EOS>
How
Leonard
was
cured
of
the
Plague
.
 
<EOS>
10
.
<EOS>
The
Pest
-
house
in
Finsbury
Fields
.
 
<EOS>
11
.
<EOS>
How
the
Grocer
shut
up
his
House
.
  
<EOS>
BOOK
<EOS>
THE
THIRD.--June
,
1665
.
 
<EOS>
1
.
 
<EOS>
The
Imprisoned
Family
.
 
<EOS>
2
.
 
<EOS>
How
Fires
were
Lighted
in
the
Streets
.
 
<EOS>
3
.
 
<EOS>
The
Dance
of
Death
.
 
<EOS>
4
.
 
<EOS>
The
Plague
-
pit
.
 
<EOS>
5
.
 
<EOS>
How
Saint
Paul
's
was
used
as
a
Pest
-
house
.
 
<EOS>
6
.
 
<EOS>
The
Departure
.
 
<EOS>
7
.
 
<EOS>
The
Journey
.
 
<EOS>
8
.
 
<EOS>
Ashdown
Lodge
.
 
<EOS>
9
.
 
<EOS>
Kingston
Lisle
.
  
<EOS>
BOOK
<EOS>
THE
FOURTH.--September
,
1665
.
 
<EOS>
1
.
 
<EOS>
The
Plague
at
its
Height
.
 
<EOS>
2
.
 
<EOS>
The
Second
Plague
-
pit
.
 
<EOS>
3
.
 
<EOS>
The
House
in
Nicholas
-
lane
.
 
<EOS>
4
.
 
<EOS>
The
Trials
of
Amabel
.
 
<EOS>
5
.
 
<EOS>
The
Marriage
and
its
Consequences
.
 
<EOS>
6
.
 
<EOS>
The
Certificate
.
  
<EOS>
BOOK
<EOS>
THE
FIFTH.--December
,
1665
.
 
<EOS>
1
.
 
<EOS>
The
Decline
of
the
Plague
.
 
<EOS>
2
.
 
<EOS>
The
Midnight
Meeting
.
  
<EOS>
BOOK
THE
SIXTH.--September
,
1666
.
 
<EOS>
1
.
 
<EOS>
The
Fire
-
ball
.
 
<EOS>
2
.
 
<EOS>
The
First
Night
of
the
Fire
.
 
<EOS>
3
.
 
Progress
of
the
Fire
.
 
<EOS>
4
.
 
<EOS>
Leonard
's
Interview
with
the
King
.
 
<EOS>
5
.
 
<EOS>
How
Leonard
saved
the
King
's
Life
.
 
<EOS>
6
.
 
<EOS>
How
the
Grocer
's
House
was
Burnt
.
 
<EOS>
7
.
 
<EOS>
The
Burning
of
Saint
Paul
's
.
 
<EOS>
8
.
 
<EOS>
How
Leonard
rescued
the
Lady
Isabella
.
 
<EOS>
9
.
 
<EOS>
What
befel
Chowles
and
Judith
in
the
Vaults
of
Saint
Faith
's
.
 
<EOS>
10
.
<EOS>
Conclusion
.
    
<EOS>
OLD
SAINT
PAUL'S.
   
BOOK
<EOS>
THE
FIRST
.
 
<EOS>
APRIL
,
1665
.
  
<EOS>
I.
 
THE
GROCER
OF
WOOD
-
STREET
AND
HIS
FAMILY
.
 
<EOS>
One
night
,
at
the
latter
end
of
April
,
1665
,
the
family
of
a
citizen
of
London
carrying
on
an
extensive
business
as
a
grocer
in
Wood
-
street
,
Cheapside
,
were
assembled
,
according
to
custom
,
at
prayer
.
<EOS>
The
grocer
's
name
was
Stephen
Bloundel
.
<EOS>
His
family
consisted
of
his
wife
,
three
sons
,
and
two
daughters
.
<EOS>
He
had
,
moreover
,
an
apprentice
;
an
elderly
female
serving
as
cook
;
her
son
,
a
young
man
about
five
-
and
-
twenty
,
filling
the
place
of
porter
to
the
shop
and
general
assistant
;
and
a
kitchen
-
maid
.
<EOS>
The
whole
household
attended
;
for
the
worthy
grocer
,
being
a
strict
observer
of
his
religious
duties
,
as
well
as
a
rigid
disciplinarian
in
other
respects
,
suffered
no
one
to
be
absent
,
on
any
plea
<EOS>
whatever
,
except
indisposition
,
from
morning
and
evening
devotions
;
and
these
were
always
performed
at
stated
times
.
<EOS>
In
fact
,
the
establishment
was
conducted
with
the
regularity
of
clockwork
,
it
being
the
aim
of
its
master
not
to
pass
a
single
hour
of
the
day
unprofitably
.
 
<EOS>
The
ordinary
prayers
gone
through
,
Stephen
Bloundel
offered
up
along
and
fervent
supplication
to
the
Most
High
for
protection
against
the
devouring
pestilence
with
which
the
city
was
then
scourged
.
<EOS>
He
acknowledged
that
this
terrible
visitation
had
been
justly
brought
upon
it
by
the
wickedness
of
its
inhabitants
;
that
they
deserved
their
doom
,
dreadful
though
it
was
;
that
,
like
the
dwellers
in
Jerusalem
before
it
was
given
up
to
ruin
and
desolation
,
they
"
had
mocked
the
messengers
of
God
and
despised
His
word
;
"
that
in
the
language
of
the
prophet
,
"
they
had
refused
to
hearken
,
and
pulled
away
the
shoulder
,
and
stopped
their
ears
that
they
should
not
hear
;
yea
,
had
made
their
heart
like
an
adamant
stone
,
lest
they
should
hear
the
law
and
the
words
which
the
Lord
of
Hosts
had
sent
in
his
spirit
by
the
former
prophets
.
"
<EOS>
He
admitted
that
great
sins
require
great
chastisement
,
and
that
the
sins
of
London
were
enormous
;
that
it
was
filled
with
strifes
,
seditions
,
heresies
,
murders
,
drunkenness
,
revellings
,
and
every
kind
of
abomination
;
that
the
ordinances
of
God
were
neglected
,
and
all
manner
of
vice
openly
practised
;
that
,
despite
repeated
warnings
and
afflictions
less
grievous
than
the
present
,
these
vicious
practices
had
been
persisted
in
.
<EOS>
All
this
he
humbly
acknowledged
.
<EOS>
But
he
implored
a
gracious
Providence
,
in
consideration
of
his
few
faithful
servants
,
to
spare
the
others
yet
a
little
longer
,
and
give
them
a
last
chance
of
repentance
and
amendment
;
or
,
if
this
could
not
be
,
and
their
utter
extirpation
was
inevitable
,
that
the
habitations
of
the
devout
might
be
exempted
from
the
general
destruction
--
might
be
places
of
refuge
,
as
Zoar
was
to
Lot
.
<EOS>
He
concluded
by
earnestly
exhorting
those
around
him
to
keep
constant
watch
upon
themselves
;
not
to
murmur
at
God
's
dealings
and
dispensations
;
but
so
to
comport
themselves
,
that
"
they
might
be
able
to
stand
in
the
day
of
wrath
,
in
the
day
of
death
,
and
in
the
day
of
judgment
.
"
<EOS>
The
exhortation
produced
a
powerful
effect
upon
its
hearers
,
and
they
arose
,
some
with
serious
,
others
with
terrified
looks
.
 
<EOS>
Before
proceeding
further
,
it
may
be
desirable
to
show
in
what
manner
the
dreadful
pestilence
referred
to
by
the
grocer
commenced
,
and
how
far
its
ravages
had
already
extended
.
<EOS>
Two
years
before
,
namely
,
in
1663
,
more
than
a
third
of
the
population
of
Amsterdam
was
carried
off
by
a
desolating
plague
.
<EOS>
Hamburgh
was
also
grievously
afflicted
about
the
same
time
,
and
in
the
same
manner
.
<EOS>
Notwithstanding
every
effort
to
cut
off
communication
with
these
states
,
the
insidious
disease
found
its
way
into
England
by
means
of
some
bales
of
merchandise
,
as
it
was
suspected
,
at
the
latter
end
of
the
year
1664
,
when
two
persons
died
suddenly
,
with
undoubted
symptoms
of
the
distemper
,
in
Westminster
.
<EOS>
Its
next
appearance
was
at
a
house
in
Long
Acre
,
and
its
victims
two
Frenchmen
,
who
had
brought
goods
from
the
Levant
.
<EOS>
Smothered
for
a
short
time
,
like
a
fire
upon
which
coals
had
been
heaped
,
it
broke
out
with
fresh
fury
in
several
places
.
 
<EOS>
The
consternation
now
began
.
<EOS>
The
whole
city
was
panic
-
stricken
:
nothing
was
talked
of
but
the
plague
--
nothing
planned
but
means
of
arresting
its
progress
--
<EOS>
one
grim
and
ghastly
idea
possessed
the
minds
of
all
.
<EOS>
Like
a
hideous
phantom
stalking
the
streets
at
noon
-
day
,
and
scaring
all
in
its
path
,
Death
took
his
course
through
London
,
and
selected
his
prey
at
pleasure
.
<EOS>
The
alarm
was
further
increased
by
the
predictions
confidently
made
as
to
the
vast
numbers
who
would
be
swept
away
by
the
visitation
;
by
the
prognostications
of
astrologers
;
by
the
prophesyings
of
enthusiasts
;
by
the
denunciations
of
preachers
,
and
by
the
portents
and
prodigies
reported
to
have
occurred
.
<EOS>
During
the
long
and
frosty
winter
preceding
this
fatal
year
,
a
comet
appeared
in
the
heavens
,
the
sickly
colour
of
which
was
supposed
to
forebode
the
judgment
about
to
follow
.
<EOS>
Blazing
stars
and
other
meteors
,
of
a
lurid
hue
and
strange
and
preternatural
shape
,
were
likewise
seen
.
<EOS>
The
sun
was
said
to
have
set
in
streams
of
blood
,
and
the
moon
to
have
shown
without
reflecting
a
shadow
;
grisly
shapes
appeared
at
night
--
<EOS>
strange
clamours
and
groans
were
heard
in
the
air
--
<EOS>
hearses
,
coffins
,
and
heaps
of
unburied
dead
were
discovered
in
the
sky
,
and
great
cakes
and
clots
of
blood
were
found
in
the
Tower
moat
;
while
a
marvellous
double
tide
occurred
at
London
Bridge
.
<EOS>
All
these
prodigies
were
currently
reported
,
and
in
most
cases
believed
.
 
<EOS>
The
severe
frost
,
before
noticed
,
did
not
break
up
till
the
end
of
February
,
and
with
the
thaw
the
plague
frightfully
increased
in
violence
.
<EOS>
From
Drury
-
lane
it
spread
along
Holborn
,
eastward
as
far
as
Great
Turnstile
,
and
westward
to
Saint
Giles
's
Pound
,
and
so
along
the
Tyburn
-
road
.
<EOS>
Saint
Andrew
's
,
Holborn
,
was
next
infected
;
and
as
this
was
a
much
more
populous
parish
than
the
former
,
the
deaths
were
more
numerous
within
it
.
<EOS>
For
a
while
,
the
disease
was
checked
by
Fleet
Ditch
;
it
then
leaped
this
narrow
boundary
,
and
ascending
the
opposite
hill
,
carried
fearful
devastation
into
Saint
James
's
,
Clerkenwell
.
<EOS>
At
the
same
time
,
it
attacked
Saint
Bride
's
;
thinned
the
ranks
of
the
thievish
horde
haunting
Whitefriars
,
and
proceeding
in
a
westerly
course
,
decimated
Saint
Clement
Danes
.
 
<EOS>
Hitherto
,
the
city
had
escaped
.
<EOS>
The
destroyer
had
not
passed
Ludgate
or
Newgate
,
but
environed
the
walls
like
a
besieging
enemy
.
<EOS>
A
few
days
,
however
,
before
the
opening
of
this
history
,
fine
weather
having
commenced
,
the
horrible
disease
began
to
grow
more
rife
,
and
laughing
all
precautions
and
impediments
to
scorn
,
broke
out
in
the
very
heart
of
the
stronghold
--
namely
,
in
Bearbinder
-
lane
,
near
Stock
's
Market
,
where
nine
persons
died
.
 
<EOS>
At
a
season
so
awful
,
it
may
be
imagined
how
an
impressive
address
,
like
that
delivered
by
the
grocer
,
would
be
received
by
those
who
saw
in
the
pestilence
,
not
merely
an
overwhelming
scourge
from
which
few
could
escape
,
but
a
direct
manifestation
of
the
Divine
displeasure
.
<EOS>
Not
a
word
was
said
.
<EOS>
Blaize
Shotterel
,
the
porter
,
and
old
Josyna
,
his
mother
,
together
with
Patience
,
the
other
woman
-
servant
,
betook
themselves
silently
,
and
with
troubled
countenances
,
to
the
kitchen
.
<EOS>
Leonard
Holt
,
the
apprentice
,
lingered
for
a
moment
to
catch
a
glance
from
the
soft
blue
eyes
of
Amabel
,
the
grocer
's
eldest
daughter
(
for
even
the
plague
was
a
secondary
consideration
with
him
when
she
was
present
)
,
and
failing
in
the
attempt
,
he
heaved
a
deep
sigh
,
which
was
luckily
laid
to
the
account
of
the
discourse
he
had
just
listened
to
by
his
sharp
-
sighted
master
,
and
proceeded
to
the
shop
,
where
he
busied
himself
in
arranging
matters
for
the
night
.
 
<EOS>
Having
just
completed
his
twenty
-
first
year
,
and
his
apprenticeship
being
within
a
few
months
of
its
expiration
,
Leonard
Holt
began
to
think
of
returning
to
his
native
town
of
Manchester
,
where
he
intended
to
settle
,
and
where
he
had
once
fondly
hoped
the
fair
Amabel
would
accompany
him
,
in
the
character
of
his
bride
.
<EOS>
Not
that
he
had
ever
ventured
to
declare
his
passion
,
nor
that
he
had
received
sufficient
encouragement
to
make
it
matter
of
certainty
that
if
he
did
so
declare
himself
,
he
should
be
accepted
;
but
being
both
"
proper
and
tall
,
"
and
having
tolerable
confidence
in
his
good
looks
,
he
had
made
himself
,
up
to
a
short
time
prior
to
his
introduction
to
the
reader
,
quite
easy
on
the
point
.
 
<EOS>
His
present
misgivings
were
occasioned
by
Amabel
's
altered
manner
towards
him
,
and
by
a
rival
who
,
he
had
reason
to
fear
,
had
completely
superseded
him
in
her
good
graces
.
<EOS>
Brought
up
together
from
an
early
age
,
the
grocer
's
daughter
and
the
young
apprentice
had
at
first
regarded
each
other
as
brother
and
sister
.
<EOS>
By
degrees
,
the
feeling
changed
;
Amabel
became
more
reserved
,
and
held
little
intercourse
with
Leonard
,
who
,
busied
with
his
own
concerns
,
thought
little
about
her
.
<EOS>
But
,
as
he
grew
towards
manhood
,
he
could
not
remain
insensible
to
her
extraordinary
beauty
--
for
extraordinary
it
was
,
and
such
as
to
attract
admiration
wherever
she
went
,
so
that
the
"
Grocer
's
Daughter
"
became
the
toast
among
the
ruffling
gallants
of
the
town
,
many
of
whom
sought
to
obtain
speech
with
her
.
<EOS>
Her
parents
,
however
,
were
far
too
careful
to
permit
any
such
approach
.
<EOS>
Amabel
's
stature
was
lofty
;
her
limbs
slight
,
but
exquisitely
symmetrical
;
her
features
small
,
and
cast
in
the
most
delicate
mould
;
her
eyes
of
the
softest
blue
;
and
her
hair
luxuriant
,
and
of
the
finest
texture
and
richest
brown
.
<EOS>
Her
other
beauties
must
be
left
to
the
imagination
;
but
it
ought
not
to
be
omitted
that
she
was
barely
eighteen
,
and
had
all
the
freshness
,
the
innocence
,
and
vivacity
of
that
most
charming
period
of
woman
's
existence
.
<EOS>
No
wonder
she
ravished
every
heart
.
<EOS>
No
wonder
,
in
an
age
when
love
-
making
was
more
general
even
than
now
,
that
she
was
beset
by
admirers
.
<EOS>
No
wonder
her
father
's
apprentice
became
desperately
enamoured
of
her
,
and
proportionately
jealous
.
 
<EOS>
And
this
brings
us
to
his
rival
.
<EOS>
On
the
10th
of
April
,
two
gallants
,
both
richly
attired
,
and
both
young
and
handsome
,
dismounted
before
the
grocer
's
door
,
and
,
leaving
their
steeds
to
the
care
of
their
attendants
,
entered
the
shop
.
<EOS>
They
made
sundry
purchases
of
conserves
,
figs
,
and
other
dried
fruit
,
chatted
familiarly
with
the
grocer
,
and
tarried
so
long
,
that
at
last
he
began
to
suspect
they
must
have
some
motive
.
<EOS>
All
at
once
,
however
,
they
disagreed
on
some
slight
matter
--
Bloundel
could
not
tell
what
,
nor
,
perhaps
,
could
the
disputants
,
even
if
their
quarrel
was
not
preconcerted
--
high
words
arose
,
and
in
another
moment
,
swords
were
drawn
,
and
furious
passes
exchanged
.
<EOS>
The
grocer
called
to
his
eldest
son
,
a
stout
youth
of
nineteen
,
and
to
Leonard
Holt
,
to
separate
them
.
<EOS>
The
apprentice
seized
his
cudgel
--
<EOS>
no
apprentice
in
those
days
was
without
one
--
and
rushed
towards
the
combatants
,
but
before
he
could
interfere
,
the
fray
was
ended
.
<EOS>
One
of
them
had
received
a
thrust
through
the
sword
arm
,
and
his
blade
dropping
,
his
antagonist
declared
himself
satisfied
,
and
with
a
grave
salute
walked
off
.
<EOS>
The
wounded
man
wrapped
a
lace
handkerchief
round
his
arm
,
but
immediately
afterwards
complained
of
great
faintness
.
<EOS>
Pitying
his
condition
,
and
suspecting
no
harm
,
the
grocer
led
him
into
an
inner
room
,
where
restoratives
were
offered
by
Mrs.
Bloundel
and
her
daughter
Amabel
,
both
of
whom
had
been
alarmed
by
the
noise
of
the
conflict
.
<EOS>
In
a
short
time
,
the
wounded
man
was
so
far
recovered
as
to
be
able
to
converse
with
his
assistants
,
especially
the
younger
one
;
and
the
grocer
having
returned
to
the
shop
,
his
discourse
became
so
very
animated
and
tender
,
that
Mrs.
Bloundel
deemed
it
prudent
to
give
her
daughter
a
hint
to
retire
.
<EOS>
Amabel
reluctantly
obeyed
,
for
the
young
stranger
was
so
handsome
,
so
richly
dressed
,
had
such
a
captivating
manner
,
and
so
distinguished
an
air
,
that
she
was
strongly
prepossessed
in
his
favour
.
<EOS>
A
second
look
from
her
mother
,
however
,
caused
her
to
disappear
,
nor
did
she
return
.
<EOS>
After
waiting
with
suppressed
anxiety
for
some
time
,
the
young
gallant
departed
,
overwhelming
the
good
dame
with
his
thanks
,
and
entreating
permission
to
call
again
.
<EOS>
This
was
peremptorily
refused
,
but
,
notwithstanding
the
interdiction
,
he
came
on
the
following
day
.
<EOS>
The
grocer
chanced
to
be
out
at
the
time
,
and
the
gallant
,
who
had
probably
watched
him
go
forth
,
deriding
the
remonstrances
of
the
younger
Bloundel
and
Leonard
,
marched
straight
to
the
inner
room
,
where
he
found
the
dame
and
her
daughter
.
<EOS>
They
were
much
disconcerted
at
his
appearance
,
and
the
latter
instantly
rose
with
the
intention
of
retiring
,
but
the
gallant
caught
her
arm
and
detained
her
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
not
fly
me
,
Amabel
,
"
he
cried
,
in
an
impassioned
tone
,
"
but
suffer
me
to
declare
the
love
I
have
for
you
.
<EOS>
I
can
not
live
without
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
Amabel
,
whose
neck
and
cheeks
were
crimsoned
with
blushes
,
cast
down
her
eyes
before
the
ardent
regards
of
the
gallant
,
and
endeavoured
to
withdraw
her
hand
.
 
<EOS>
"
One
word
only
,
"
he
continued
,
"
and
I
release
you
.
<EOS>
Am
I
wholly
indifferent
to
you
!
<EOS>
Answer
me
--
yes
or
no
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
Do
_
not
_
answer
him
,
Amabel
,
"
interposed
her
mother
.
<EOS>
"
He
is
deceiving
you
.
<EOS>
He
loves
you
not
.
<EOS>
He
would
ruin
you
.
<EOS>
This
is
the
way
with
all
these
court
butterflies
.
<EOS>
Tell
him
you
hate
him
,
child
,
and
bid
him
begone
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
But
I
can
not
tell
him
an
untruth
,
mother
,
"
returned
Amabel
,
artlessly
,
"
for
I
do
_
not
_
hate
him
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Then
you
love
me
,
"
cried
the
young
man
,
falling
on
his
knees
,
and
pressing
her
hand
to
his
lips
.
<EOS>
"
Tell
me
so
,
and
make
me
the
happiest
of
men
.
"
 
<EOS>
But
Amabel
had
now
recovered
from
the
confusion
into
which
she
had
been
thrown
,
and
,
alarmed
at
her
own
indiscretion
,
forcibly
withdrew
her
hand
,
exclaiming
in
a
cold
tone
,
and
with
much
natural
dignity
,
"
Arise
,
sir
.
<EOS>
I
will
not
tolerate
these
freedoms
.
<EOS>
My
mother
is
right
--
you
have
some
ill
design
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
By
my
soul
,
no
!
"
cried
the
gallant
,
passionately
.
<EOS>
"
I
love
you
,
and
would
make
you
mine
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
No
doubt
,
"
remarked
Mrs.
Bloundel
,
contemptuously
,
"
but
not
by
marriage
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
by
marriage
,
"
rejoined
the
gallant
,
rising
.
<EOS>
"
If
she
will
consent
,
I
will
we
d
her
forthwith
.
"
 
<EOS>
Both
Amabel
and
her
mother
looked
surprised
at
the
young
man
's
declaration
,
which
was
uttered
with
a
fervour
that
seemed
to
leave
no
doubt
of
its
sincerity
;
but
the
latter
,
fearing
some
artifice
,
replied
,
"
If
what
you
say
is
true
,
and
you
really
love
my
daughter
as
much
as
you
pretend
,
this
is
not
the
way
to
win
her
;
for
though
she
can
have
no
pretension
to
we
d
with
one
of
your
seeming
degree
,
nor
is
it
for
her
happiness
that
she
should
,
yet
,
were
she
sought
by
the
proudest
noble
in
the
land
,
she
shall
never
,
if
I
can
help
it
,
be
lightly
won
.
<EOS>
If
your
intentions
are
honourable
,
you
must
address
yourself
,
in
the
first
place
,
to
her
father
,
and
if
he
agrees
(
which
I
much
doubt
)
that
you
shall
become
her
suitor
,
I
can
make
no
objection
.
<EOS>
Till
this
is
settled
,
I
must
pray
you
to
desist
from
further
importunity
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
so
must
I
,
"
added
Amabel
.
<EOS>
"
I
can
not
give
you
a
hope
till
you
have
spoken
to
my
father
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Be
it
so
,
"
replied
the
gallant
.
<EOS>
"
I
will
tarry
here
till
his
return
.
"
 
<EOS>
So
saying
,
he
was
about
to
seat
himself
,
but
Mrs.
Bloundel
prevented
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
can
not
permit
this
,
sir
,
"
she
cried
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Your
tarrying
here
may
,
for
aught
I
know
,
bring
scandal
upon
my
house;--I
am
sure
it
will
be
disagreeable
to
my
husband
.
<EOS>
I
am
unacquainted
with
your
name
and
condition
.
<EOS>
You
may
be
a
man
of
rank
.
<EOS>
You
may
be
one
of
the
profligate
and
profane
crew
who
haunt
the
court
.
<EOS>
You
may
be
the
worst
of
them
all
,
my
Lord
Rochester
himself
.
<EOS>
He
is
about
your
age
,
I
have
heard
,
and
though
a
mere
boy
in
years
,
is
a
veteran
in
libertinism
.
<EOS>
But
,
whoever
you
are
,
and
whatever
your
rank
and
station
may
be
,
unless
your
character
will
bear
the
strictest
scrutiny
,
I
am
certain
Stephen
Bloundel
will
never
consent
to
your
union
with
his
daughter
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Nay
,
mother
,
"
observed
Amabel
,
"
<EOS>
you
judge
the
gentleman
unjustly
.
<EOS>
I
am
sure
he
is
neither
a
profligate
gallant
himself
,
nor
a
companion
of
such
--
especially
of
the
wicked
Earl
of
Rochester
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
pretend
to
be
no
better
than
I
am
,
"
replied
the
young
man
,
repressing
a
smile
that
rose
to
his
lips
at
Mrs.
Bloundel
's
address
;
"
but
I
shall
reform
when
I
am
married
.
<EOS>
It
would
be
impossible
to
be
inconstant
to
so
fair
a
creature
as
Amabel
.
<EOS>
For
my
rank
,
I
have
none
.
<EOS>
My
condition
is
that
of
a
private
gentleman,--my
name
,
Maurice
Wyvil
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
What
you
say
of
yourself
,
Mr.
Maurice
Wyvil
,
convinces
me
you
will
meet
with
a
decided
refusal
from
my
husband
,
"
returned
Mrs.
Bloundel
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
trust
not
,
"
replied
Wyvil
,
glancing
tenderly
at
Amabel
.
<EOS>
"
If
I
should
be
so
fortunate
as
to
gain
_
<EOS>
his
_
consent
,
have
I
_
yours
_
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
too
soon
to
ask
that
question
,
"
she
rejoined
,
blushing
deeply
.
"
<EOS>
And
now
,
sir
,
you
must
go
,
indeed
,
you
must
.
<EOS>
You
distress
my
mother
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
If
I
do
not
distress
<EOS>
_
you
_
<EOS>
,
I
will
stay
,
"
resumed
Wyvil
,
with
an
imploring
look
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
_
do
_
distress
me
,
"
she
answered
,
averting
her
gaze
.
 
<EOS>
"
Nay
,
then
,
I
must
tear
myself
away
,
"
he
rejoined
.
<EOS>
"
I
shall
return
shortly
,
and
trust
to
find
your
father
less
flinty
-
hearted
than
he
is
represented
.
"
 
<EOS>
He
would
have
clasped
Amabel
in
his
arms
,
and
perhaps
snatched
a
kiss
,
if
her
mother
had
not
rushed
between
them
.
 
<EOS>
"
No
more
familiarities
,
sir
,
"
she
cried
angrily
;
"
no
court
manners
here
.
<EOS>
If
you
look
to
we
d
<EOS>
my
daughter
,
you
must
conduct
yourself
more
decorously
;
but
I
can
tell
you
,
you
have
no
chance
--
none
whatever
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Time
will
show
,
"
replied
Wyvil
,
audaciously
.
"
You
had
better
give
her
to
me
quietly
,
and
save
me
the
trouble
of
carrying
her
off,--for
have
her
I
will
.
"
 
"
Mercy
on
us
!
"
cried
Mrs.
Bloundel
,
in
accents
of
alarm
;
"
now
his
wicked
intentions
are
out
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Fear
nothing
,
mother
,
"
observed
Amabel
,
coldly
.
"
<EOS>
He
will
scarcely
carry
me
off
without
my
own
consent
;
and
I
am
not
likely
to
sacrifice
myself
for
one
who
holds
me
in
such
light
esteem
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Forgive
me
,
Amabel
,
"
rejoined
Wyvil
,
in
a
voice
so
penitent
that
it
instantly
effaced
her
displeasure
;
"
I
meant
not
to
offend
.
<EOS>
I
spoke
only
the
language
of
distraction
.
<EOS>
Do
not
dismiss
me
thus
,
or
my
death
will
lie
at
your
door
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
should
be
sorry
for
that
,
"
she
replied
;
"
but
,
inexperienced
<EOS>
as
I
am
,
I
feel
this
is
not
the
language
of
real
regard
,
but
of
furious
passion
.
"
 
<EOS>
A
dark
shade
passed
over
Wyvil
's
handsome
features
,
and
the
almost
feminine
beauty
by
which
they
were
characterized
gave
place
to
a
fierce
and
forbidding
expression
.
<EOS>
Controlling
himself
by
a
powerful
effort
,
he
replied
,
with
forced
calmness
,
"
Amabel
,
you
know
not
what
it
is
to
love
.
<EOS>
I
will
not
stir
hence
till
I
have
seen
your
father
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
We
will
see
that
,
sir
,
"
exclaimed
Mrs.
Bloundel
,
angrily
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
What
,
ho
!
<EOS>
son
Stephen
!
<EOS>
Leonard
Holt
!
<EOS>
I
say
.
<EOS>
This
gentleman
_
will
_
stay
here
,
whether
I
like
or
not
.
<EOS>
Show
him
forth
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
That
I
will
,
right
willingly
,
"
replied
the
apprentice
,
rushing
before
the
younger
Bloundel
,
and
flourishing
his
formidable
cudgel
.
<EOS>
"
Out
with
you
,
sir
!
<EOS>
Out
with
you
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
Not
at
your
bidding
you
,
saucy
knave
,
"
rejoined
Wyvil
,
laying
his
hand
upon
his
sword
:
"
and
if
it
were
not
for
the
presence
of
your
mistress
and
her
lovely
daughter
,
I
would
crop
your
ears
for
your
insolence
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Their
presence
shall
not
prevent
me
from
making
my
cudgel
and
your
shoulders
acquainted
,
if
you
do
not
budge
,
"
replied
the
apprentice
,
sturdily
.
 
<EOS>
Enraged
by
the
retort
,
Wyvil
would
have
drawn
his
sword
,
but
a
blow
on
the
arm
disabled
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
Plague
on
you
,
fellow
!
"
<EOS>
he
exclaimed
;
"
you
shall
rue
this
to
the
last
day
of
your
existence
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Threaten
those
who
heed
you
,
"
replied
Leonard
,
about
to
repeat
the
blow
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
him
no
further
injury
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Amabel
,
arresting
his
hand
,
and
looking
with
the
greatest
commiseration
at
Wyvil
.
<EOS>
"
You
have
dealt
with
him
far
too
rudely
already
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Since
I
have
your
sympathy
,
sweet
Amabel
,
"
rejoined
Wyvil
,
"
I
care
not
<EOS>
what
rude
treatment
I
experience
from
this
churl
.
<EOS>
We
shall
soon
meet
again
.
"
<EOS>
And
bowing
to
her
,
he
strode
out
of
the
room
.
 
<EOS>
Leonard
followed
him
to
the
shop
-
door
,
hoping
some
further
pretext
for
quarrel
would
arise
,
but
he
was
disappointed
.
<EOS>
Wyvil
took
no
notice
of
him
,
and
proceeded
at
a
slow
pace
towards
Cheapside
.
 
<EOS>
Half
an
hour
afterwards
,
Stephen
Bloundel
came
home
.
<EOS>
On
being
informed
of
what
had
occurred
,
he
was
greatly
annoyed
,
though
he
concealed
his
vexation
,
and
highly
applauded
his
daughter
's
conduct
.
<EOS>
Without
further
comment
,
he
proceeded
about
his
business
,
and
remained
in
the
shop
till
it
was
closed
.
<EOS>
Wyvil
did
not
return
,
and
the
grocer
tried
to
persuade
himself
they
should
see
nothing
more
of
him
.
<EOS>
Before
Amabel
retired
to
rest
,
he
imprinted
a
kiss
on
her
snowy
brow
,
and
said
,
in
a
tone
of
the
utmost
kindness
,
"
You
have
never
yet
deceived
me
,
child
,
and
I
hope
never
will
.
<EOS>
Tell
me
truly
,
do
you
take
any
interest
in
this
young
gallant
?
"
 
<EOS>
Amabel
blushed
deeply
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
should
not
speak
the
truth
,
father
,
"
she
rejoined
,
after
a
pause
,
"
if
I
were
to
say
I
do
not
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
sorry
for
it
,
"
replied
Bloundel
,
gravely
.
<EOS>
"
But
you
would
not
be
happy
with
him
.
<EOS>
I
am
sure
he
is
unprincipled
and
profligate:--you
must
forget
him
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
will
try
to
do
so
,
"
sighed
Amabel
.
<EOS>
And
the
conversation
dropped
.
 
<EOS>
On
the
following
day
,
Maurice
Wyvil
entered
the
grocer
's
shop
.
<EOS>
He
was
more
richly
attired
than
before
,
and
there
was
a
haughtiness
in
his
manner
which
he
had
not
hitherto
assumed
.
<EOS>
What
passed
between
him
and
Bloundel
was
not
known
,
for
the
latter
never
spoke
of
it
;
but
the
result
may
be
gathered
from
the
fact
that
the
young
gallant
was
not
allowed
an
interview
with
the
grocer
's
daughter
.
 
<EOS>
From
this
moment
the
change
previously
noticed
took
place
in
Amabel
's
demeanour
towards
Leonard
.
<EOS>
She
seemed
scarcely
able
to
endure
his
presence
,
and
sedulously
avoided
his
regards
.
<EOS>
From
being
habitually
gay
and
cheerful
,
she
became
pensive
and
reserved
.
<EOS>
Her
mother
more
than
once
caught
her
in
tears
;
and
it
was
evident
,
from
many
other
signs
,
that
Wyvil
completely
engrossed
her
thoughts
.
<EOS>
Fully
aware
of
this
,
Mrs.
Bloundel
said
nothing
of
it
to
her
husband
,
because
the
subject
was
painful
to
him
;
and
not
supposing
the
passion
deeply
rooted
,
she
hoped
it
would
speedily
wear
away
.
<EOS>
But
she
was
mistaken
--
the
flame
was
kept
alive
in
Amabel
's
breast
in
a
manner
of
which
she
was
totally
ignorant
.
<EOS>
Wyvil
found
means
to
deceive
the
vigilance
of
the
grocer
and
his
wife
,
but
he
could
not
deceive
the
vigilance
of
a
jealous
lover
.
<EOS>
Leonard
discovered
that
his
mistress
had
received
a
letter
.
<EOS>
He
would
not
betray
her
,
but
he
determined
to
watch
her
narrowly
.
 
<EOS>
Accordingly
,
when
she
went
forth
one
morning
in
company
with
her
younger
sister
(
a
little
girl
of
some
five
years
old
)
,
he
made
an
excuse
to
follow
them
,
and
,
keeping
within
sight
,
perceived
them
enter
Saint
Paul
's
Cathedral
,
the
mid
aisle
of
which
was
then
converted
into
a
public
walk
,
and
generally
thronged
with
town
gallants
,
bullies
,
bona
-
robas
,
cut
-
purses
,
and
rogues
of
every
description
.
<EOS>
In
short
,
it
was
the
haunt
of
the
worst
of
characters
of
the
metropolis
.
<EOS>
When
,
therefore
,
Amabel
entered
this
structure
,
Leonard
felt
certain
it
was
to
meet
her
lover
.
<EOS>
Rushing
forward
,
he
saw
her
take
her
course
through
the
crowd
,
and
attract
general
attention
from
her
loveliness
--
but
he
nowhere
discerned
Maurice
Wyvil
.
 
<EOS>
Suddenly
,
however
,
she
struck
off
to
the
right
,
and
halted
near
one
of
the
pillars
,
and
the
apprentice
,
advancing
,
detected
his
rival
behind
it
.
<EOS>
He
was
whispering
a
few
words
in
her
ear
,
unperceived
by
her
sister
.
<EOS>
Maddened
by
the
sight
,
Leonard
hurried
towards
them
,
but
before
he
could
reach
the
spot
Wyvil
was
gone
,
and
Amabel
,
though
greatly
confused
,
looked
at
the
same
time
so
indignant
,
that
he
almost
regretted
his
precipitation
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
will
,
of
course
,
make
known
to
my
father
what
you
have
just
seen
?
<EOS>
"
she
said
in
a
low
tone
.
 
<EOS>
"
If
you
will
promise
not
to
meet
that
gallant
again
without
my
knowledge
,
I
will
not
,
"
replied
Leonard
.
 
<EOS>
After
a
moment
's
reflection
,
Amabel
gave
the
required
promise
,
and
they
returned
to
Wood
-
street
together
.
<EOS>
Satisfied
she
would
not
break
her
word
,
the
apprentice
became
more
easy
,
and
as
a
week
elapsed
,
and
nothing
was
said
to
him
on
the
subject
,
he
persuaded
himself
she
would
not
attempt
to
meet
her
lover
again
.
 
<EOS>
Things
were
in
this
state
at
the
opening
of
our
tale
,
but
upon
the
night
in
question
,
Leonard
fancied
he
discerned
some
agitation
in
Amabel
's
manner
towards
him
,
and
in
consequence
of
this
notion
,
he
sought
to
meet
her
gaze
,
as
before
related
,
after
prayers
.
<EOS>
While
trying
to
distract
his
thoughts
by
arranging
sundry
firkins
of
butter
,
and
putting
other
things
in
order
,
he
heard
a
light
footstep
behind
him
,
and
turning
at
the

,
beheld
Amabel
.
 
<EOS>
"
Leonard
,
"
she
whispered
,
"
I
promised
to
tell
you
when
I
should
next
meet
Maurice
Wyvil
.
<EOS>
He
will
be
here
to
-
night
.
"
<EOS>
And
without
giving
him
time
to
answer
,
she
retired
.
 
<EOS>
For
awhile
,
Leonard
remained
in
a
state
almost
of
stupefaction
,
repeating
to
himself
,
as
if
unwilling
to
believe
them
,
the
words
he
had
just
heard
.
<EOS>
He
had
not
recovered
when
the
grocer
entered
the
shop
,
and
noticing
his
haggard
looks
,
kindly
inquired
if
he
felt
unwell
.
<EOS>
The
apprentice
returned
an
evasive
answer
,
and
half
determined
to
relate
all
he
knew
to
his
master
,
but
the
next
moment
he
changed
his
intention
,
and
,
influenced
by
that
chivalric
feeling
which
always
governs
those
,
of
whatever
condition
,
who
love
profoundly
,
resolved
not
to
betray
the
thoughtless
girl
,
but
to
trust
to
his
own
ingenuity
to
thwart
the
designs
of
his
rival
,
and
preserve
her
Acting
upon
this
resolution
,
he
said
he
had
a
slight
headache
,
and
instantly
resumed
his
occupation
.
 
<EOS>
At
nine
o'clock
,
the
whole
family
assembled
at
supper
.
<EOS>
The
board
was
plentifully
though
plainly
spread
,
but
the
grocer
observed
,
with
some
uneasiness
,
that
his
apprentice
,
who
had
a
good
appetite
in
ordinary
,
ate
little
or
nothing
.
<EOS>
He
kept
his
eye
constantly
upon
him
,
and
became
convinced
from
his
manner
that
something
ailed
him
.
<EOS>
Not
having
any
notion
of
the
truth
,
and
being
filled
with
apprehensions
of
the
plague
,
his
dread
was
that
Leonard
was
infected
by
the
disease
.
<EOS>
Supper
was
generally
the
pleasantest
meal
of
the
day
at
the
grocer
's
house
,
but
on
this
occasion
it
passed
off
cheerlessly
enough
,
and
a
circumstance
occurred
at
its
close
which
threw
all
into
confusion
and
distress
.
<EOS>
Before
relating
this
,
however
,
we
must
complete
our
description
of
the
family
under
their
present
aspect
.
 
<EOS>
Tall
,
and
of
a
spare
frame
,
with
good
features
,
somewhat
austere
in
their
expression
,
and
of
the
cast
which
we
are
apt
to
term
precise
and
puritanical
,
but
tempered
with
great
benevolence
,
Stephen
Bloundel
had
a
keen
,
deep
-
seated
eye
,
overshadowed
by
thick
brows
,
and
suffered
his
long
-
flowing
grey
hair
to
descend
over
his
shoulders
.
<EOS>
His
forehead
was
high
and
ample
,
his
chin
square
and
well
defined
,
and
his
general
appearance
exceedingly
striking
.
<EOS>
In
age
he
was
about
fifty
.
<EOS>
His
integrity
and
fairness
of
dealing
,
never
once
called
in
question
for
a
period
of
thirty
years
,
had
won
him
the
esteem
of
all
who
knew
him
;
while
his
prudence
and
economy
had
enabled
him
,
during
that
time
,
to
amass
a
tolerable
fortune
.
<EOS>
His
methodical
habits
,
and
strong
religious
principles
,
have
been
already
mentioned
.
<EOS>
His
eldest
son
was
named
after
him
,
and
resembled
him
both
in
person
and
character
,
promising
to
tread
in
his
footsteps
.
<EOS>
The
younger
sons
require
little
notice
at
present
.
<EOS>
One
was
twelve
,
and
the
other
only
half
that
age
;
but
both
appeared
to
inherit
many
of
their
father
's
good
qualities
.
<EOS>
Basil
,
the
elder
,
was
a
stout
,
well
-
grown
lad
,
and
had
never
known
a
day
's
ill
-
health
;
while
Hubert
,
the
younger
,
was
thin
,
delicate
,
and
constantly
ailing
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs.
Bloundel
was
a
specimen
of
a
city
dame
of
the
best
kind
.
<EOS>
She
had
a
few
pardonable
vanities
,
which
no
arguments
could
overcome
--
such
as
a
little
ostentation
in
dress
--
a
little
pride
in
the
neatness
of
her
house
--
and
a
good
deal
in
the
beauty
of
her
children
,
especially
in
that
of
Amabel
--
as
well
as
in
the
wealth
and
high
character
of
her
husband
,
whom
she
regarded
as
the
most
perfect
of
human
beings
.
<EOS>
These
slight
failings
allowed
for
,
nothing
but
good
remained
.
<EOS>
Her
conduct
was
exemplary
in
all
the
relations
of
life
.
<EOS>
The
tenderest
of
mothers
,
and
the
most
affectionate
of
wives
<EOS>
,
she
had
as
much
genuine
piety
and
strictness
of
moral
principles
as
her
husband
.
<EOS>
Short
,
plump
,
and
well
-
proportioned
,
<EOS>
though
somewhat
,
perhaps
,
exceeding
the
rules
of
symmetry
--
she
had
a
rich
olive
complexion
,
fine
black
eyes
,
beaming
with
good
nature
,
and
an
ever
-
laughing
mouth
,
ornamented
by
a
beautiful
set
of
teeth
.
<EOS>
To
wind
up
all
,
she
was
a
few
years
younger
than
her
husband
.
 
<EOS>
Amabel
has
already
been
described
.
<EOS>
The
youngest
girl
,
Christiana
,
was
a
pretty
little
dove
-
eyed
,
flaxen
-
haired
child
,
between
four
and
five
years
old
,
and
shared
the
fate
of
most
younger
children
,
being
very
much
caressed
,
and
not
a
little
spoiled
by
her
parents
.
 
<EOS>
The
foregoing
description
of
the
grocer
's
family
would
be
incomplete
without
some
mention
of
his
household
.
<EOS>
Old
Josyna
Shotterel
,
the
cook
,
who
had
lived
with
her
master
ever
since
his
marriage
,
and
had
the
strongest
attachment
for
him
,
was
a
hale
,
stout
dame
,
of
about
sixty
,
with
few
infirmities
for
her
years
,
and
with
less
asperity
of
temper
than
generally
belongs
to
servants
of
her
class
.
<EOS>
She
was
a
native
of
Holland
,
and
came
to
England
early
in
life
,
where
she
married
Blaize
's
father
,
who
died
soon
after
their
union
.
<EOS>
An
excellent
cook
in
a
plain
way
--
indeed
,
she
had
no
practice
in
any
other
--
she
would
brew
strong
ale
and
mead
,
or
mix
a
sack
-
posset
with
,
any
innkeeper
in
the
city
.
<EOS>
Moreover
,
she
was
a
careful
and
tender
nurse
,
if
her
services
were
ever
required
in
that
capacity
.
<EOS>
The
children
looked
upon
her
as
a
second
mother
;
and
her
affection
for
them
,
which
was
unbounded
,
deserved
their
regard
.
<EOS>
She
was
a
perfect
storehouse
of
what
are
termed
"
old
women
's
receipts
;
"
and
there
were
few
complaints
(
except
the
plague
)
for
which
she
did
not
think
herself
qualified
to
prescribe
and
able
to
cure
.
<EOS>
Her
skill
in
the
healing
art
was
often
tested
by
her
charitable
mistress
,
who
required
her
to
prepare
remedies
,
as
well
as
nourishing
broths
,
for
such
of
the
poor
of
the
parish
as
applied
to
her
for
relief
at
times
of
sickness
.
 
<EOS>
Her
son
,
Blaize
,
was
a
stout
,
stumpy
fellow
,
about
four
feet
ten
,
with
a
head
somewhat
too
large
for
his
body
,
and
extremely
long
arms
.
<EOS>
Ever
since
the
plague
had
broken
out
in
Drury
-
lane
,
it
haunted
him
like
a
spectre
,
and
scattered
the
few
faculties
he
possessed
.
<EOS>
In
vain
he
tried
to
combat
his
alarm
--
in
vain
his
mother
endeavoured
to
laugh
him
out
of
it
.
<EOS>
Nothing
would
do
.
<EOS>
He
read
the
bills
of
mortality
daily
;
ascertained
the
particulars
of
every
case
;
dilated
upon
the
agonies
of
the
sufferers
;
watched
the
progress
of
the
infection
,
and
calculated
the
time
it
would
take
to
reach
Wood
-
street
.
<EOS>
He
talked
of
the
pestilence
by
day
,
and
dreamed
of
it
at
night
;
and
more
than
once
alarmed
the
house
by
roaring
for
assistance
,
under
the
idea
that
he
was
suddenly
attacked
.
<EOS>
By
his
mother
's
advice
,
he
steeped
rue
,
wormwood
,
and
sage
in
his
drink
,
till
it
was
so
abominably
nauseous
that
he
could
scarcely
swallow
it
,
and
carried
a
small
ball
in
the
hollow
of
his
hand
,
compounded
of
wax
,
angelica
,
camphor
,
and
other
drugs
.
<EOS>
He
likewise
chewed
a
small
piece
of
Virginian
snake
-
root
,
or
zedoary
,
if
he
approached
any
place
supposed
to
be
infected
.
<EOS>
A
dried
toad
was
suspended
round
his
neck
,
as
an
amulet
of
sovereign
virtue
.
<EOS>
Every
nostrum
sold
by
the
quacks
in
the
streets
tempted
him
;
and
a
few
days
before
,
he
had
expended
his
last
crown
in
the
purchase
of
a
bottle
of
plague
-
water
.
<EOS>
Being
of
a
superstitious
nature
,
he
placed
full
faith
in
all
the
predictions
of
the
astrologers
,
who
foretold
that
London
should
be
utterly
laid
waste
,
that
grass
should
grow
in
the
streets
,
and
that
the
living
should
not
be
able
to
bury
the
dead
.
<EOS>
He
quaked
at
the
terrible
denunciations
of
the
preachers
,
who
exhorted
their
hearers
to
repentance
,
telling
them
a
judgment
was
at
hand
,
and
shuddered
at
the
wild
and
fearful
prophesying
of
the
insane
enthusiasts
who
roamed
the
streets
.
<EOS>
His
nativity
having
been
cast
,
and
it
appearing
that
he
would
be
in
great
danger
on
the
20th
of
June
,
he
made
up
his
mind
that
he
should
die
of
the
plague
on
that
day
.
<EOS>
Before
he
was
assailed
by
these
terrors
,
he
had
entertained
a
sneaking
attachment
for
Patience
,
the
kitchen
-
maid
,
a
young
and
buxom
damsel
,
who
had
no
especial
objection
to
him
.
<EOS>
But
of
late
,
his
love
had
given
way
to
apprehension
,
and
his
whole
thoughts
were
centred
in
one
idea
,
namely
,
self
-
preservation
.
 
<EOS>
By
this
time
supper
was
over
,
and
the
family
were
about
to
separate
for
the
night
,
when
Stephen
,
the
grocer
's
eldest
son
,
having
risen
to
quit
the
room
,
staggered
and
complained
of
a
strange
dizziness
and
headache
,
which
almost
deprived
him
of
sight
,
while
his
heart
palpitated
frightfully
.
<EOS>
A
dreadful
suspicion
seized
his
father
.
<EOS>
He
ran
towards
him
,
and
assisted
him
to
a
seat
.
<EOS>
Scarcely
had
the
young
man
reached
it
,
when
a
violent
sickness
seized
him
;
a
greenish
-
coloured
froth
appeared
at
the
mouth
,
and
he
began
to
grow
delirious
.
<EOS>
Guided
by
the
convulsive
efforts
of
the
sufferer
,
Bloundel
tore
off
his
clothes
,
and
after
a
moment
's
search
,
perceived
under
the
left
arm
a
livid
pustule
.
<EOS>
He
uttered
a
cry
of
anguish
.
<EOS>
His
son
was
plague
-
stricken
.
  
<EOS>
II
.
 
<EOS>
THE
COFFIN
-
MAKER
.
 
<EOS>
The
first
shock
over
,
the
grocer
bore
the
affliction
manfully
,
and
like
one
prepared
for
it
.
<EOS>
Exhibiting
little
outward
emotion
,
though
his
heart
was
torn
with
anguish
,
and
acting
with
the
utmost
calmness
,
he
forbade
his
wife
to
approach
the
sufferer
,
and
desired
her
instantly
to
retire
to
her
own
room
with
her
daughters
;
and
not
to
leave
it
on
any
consideration
whatever
,
without
his
permission
.
 
<EOS>
Accustomed
to
regard
her
husband
's
word
as
law
,
Mrs.
Bloundel
,
for
the
first
time
in
her
life
,
disputed
his
authority
,
and
,
falling
on
her
knees
,
besought
him
,
with
tears
in
her
eyes
,
to
allow
her
to
nurse
her
son
.
<EOS>
But
he
remained
inflexible
,
and
she
was
forced
to
comply
.
 
<EOS>
He
next
gave
similar
directions
to
old
Josyna
respecting
his
two
younger
sons
,
with
this
difference
only
,
that
when
they
were
put
to
rest
,
and
the
door
was
locked
upon
them
,
she
was
to
return
to
the
kitchen
and
prepare
a
posset
-
drink
of
canary
and
spirits
of
sulphur
,
together
with
a
poultice
of
mallows
,
lily
-
roots
,
figs
,
linseed
,
and
palm
-
oil
,
for
the
patient
.
 
<EOS>
These
orders
given
and
obeyed
,
with
Leonard
Holt
's
assistance
-
for
Blaize
,
who
had
crept
into
a
corner
,
in
extremity
of
terror
,
was
wholly
incapable
of
rendering
any
help
-
he
conveyed
his
son
to
the
adjoining
room
,
on
the
ground
floor
,
where
there
was
a
bed
,
and
placing
him
within
it
,
heaped
blankets
upon
him
to
promote
profuse
perspiration
,
while
the
apprentice
lighted
a
fire
.
 
<EOS>
Provided
with
the
most
efficacious
remedies
for
the
distemper
,
and
acquainted
with
the
mode
of
treating
it
prescribed
by
the
College
of
Physicians
,
Bloundel
was
at
no
loss
how
to
act
,
but
,
rubbing
the
part
affected
with
a
stimulating
ointment
<EOS>
,
he
administered
at
the
same
time
doses
of
mithridate
,
Venice
treacle
,
and
other
potent
alexipharmics
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
soon
the
satisfaction
of
perceiving
that
his
son
became
somewhat
easier
;
and
after
swallowing
the
posset
-
drink
prepared
by
old
Josyna
,
who
used
all
the
expedition
she
could
,
a
moisture
broke
out
upon
the
youth
's
skin
,
and
appeared
to
relieve
him
so
much
,
that
,
but
for
the
ghastly
paleness
of
his
countenance
,
and
the
muddy
look
of
his
eye
,
his
father
would
have
indulged
a
hope
of
his
recovery
.
 
<EOS>
Up
to
this
time
,
the
grocer
had
acted
for
himself
,
and
felt
confident
he
had
acted
rightly
;
but
he
now
deemed
it
expedient
to
call
in
advice
,
and
,
accordingly
,
commissioned
his
apprentice
to
fetch
Doctor
Hodges
,
a
physician
,
residing
in
Great
Knightrider
-
street
,
Doctors
'
Commons
,
who
had
recently
acquired
considerable
reputation
for
his
skilful
treatment
of
those
attacked
by
the
plague
,
and
who
(
it
may
be
incidentally
mentioned
)
afterwards
gave
to
the
medical
world
a
curious
account
of
the
ravages
of
the
disorder
,
as
well
as
of
his
own
professional
experiences
during
this
terrible
period
.
<EOS>
He
likewise
told
him
--
and
he
could
not
repress
a
sigh
as
he
did
so
--
to
give
notice
to
the
Examiner
of
Health
(
there
were
one
or
two
officers
,
so
designated
,
appointed
to
every
parish
,
at
this
awful
season
,
by
the
city
authorities
)
that
his
house
was
infected
.
 
<EOS>
While
preparing
to
set
out
,
Leonard
again
debated
with
himself
whether
he
should
acquaint
his
master
with
Maurice
Wyvil
's
meditated
visit
.
<EOS>
But
conceiving
it
wholly
impossible
that
Amabel
could
leave
her
mother
's
room
,
even
if
she
were
disposed
to
do
so
,
he
determined
to
let
the
affair
take
its
course
.
<EOS>
On
his
way
to
the
shop
,
he
entered
a
small
room
occupied
by
Blaize
,
and
found
him
seated
near
a
table
,
with
his
hands
upon
his
knees
,
and
his
eyes
fixed
upon
the
ground
,
looking
the
very
image
of
despair
.
<EOS>
The
atmosphere
smelt
like
that
of
an
apothecary
's
shop
,
and
was
so
overpowering
,
that
Leonard
could
scarcely
breathe
.
<EOS>
The
table
was
covered
with
pill
-
boxes
and
phials
,
most
of
which
were
emptied
,
and
a
dim
light
was
afforded
by
a
candle
with
a
most
portentous
crest
of
snuff
.
 
<EOS>
"
So
you
have
been
poisoning
yourself
,
I
perceive
,
"
observed
Leonard
,
approaching
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
Keep
off
!
"
<EOS>
cried
the
porter
,
springing
suddenly
to
his
feet
.
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
touch
me
,
I
say
.
<EOS>
Poisoning
myself
!
<EOS>
I
have
taken
three
rufuses
,
or
pestilential
pills
;
two
spoonfuls
of
alexiteral
water
;
the
same
quantity
of
anti
-
pestilential
decoction
;
half
as
much
of
Sir
Theodore
Mayerne
's
electuary
;
and
a
large
dose
of
orvietan
.
<EOS>
Do
you
call
that
poisoning
myself
?
<EOS>
I
call
it
taking
proper
precaution
,
and
would
recommend
you
to
do
the
same
.
<EOS>
Beside
this
,
I
have
sprinkled
myself
with
vinegar
,
fumigated
my
clothes
,
and
rubbed
my
nose
,
inside
and
out
,
till
it
smarted
so
intolerably
,
I
was
obliged
to
desist
,
with
balsam
of
sulphur
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Well
,
well
,
if
you
do
n't
escape
the
plague
,
it
wo
n't
be
your
fault
,
"
returned
Leonard
,
scarcely
able
to
refrain
from
laughing
.
<EOS>
"
But
I
have
something
to
tell
you
before
I
go
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
What
is
the
matter
?
<EOS>
"
demanded
Blaize
,
in
alarm
.
<EOS>
"
Where
--
where
are
you
going
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
To
fetch
the
doctor
,
"
replied
Leonard
.
 
<EOS>
"
Is
Master
Stephen
worse
?
"
rejoined
the
porter
.
 
<EOS>
"
On
the
contrary
,
I
hope
he
is
better
,
"
replied
Leonard
<EOS>
"
I
shall
be
back
directly
,
but
as
I
have
to
give
notice
to
the
Examiner
of
Health
that
the
house
is
infected
,
I
may
be
detained
a
few
minutes
longer
than
I
anticipate
.
<EOS>
Keep
the
street
-
door
locked
;
I
will
fasten
the
yard
-
gate
,
and
do
not
for
your
life
let
any
one
in
,
except
Doctor
Hodges
,
till
I
return
.
<EOS>
Do
you
hear?--do
<EOS>
you
understand
what
I
say
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
I
hear
plain
enough
,
"
growled
Blaize
.
<EOS>
"
You
say
that
the
house
is
infected
,
and
that
we
shall
all
be
locked
up
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Dolt
!
"
exclaimed
the
apprentice
<EOS>
,
"
I
said
no
such
thing
.
"
<EOS>
And
he
repeated
his
injunctions
,
but
Blaize
was
too
much
terrified
to
comprehend
them
.
<EOS>
At
last
,
losing
all
patience
,
Leonard
cried
in
a
menacing
tone
,
"
If
you
do
not
attend
to
me
,
I
will
cudgel
you
within
an
inch
of
your
life
,
and
you
will
find
the
thrashing
harder
to
bear
even
than
the
plague
itself
.
<EOS>
Rouse
yourself
,
fool
,
and
follow
me
.
"
 
<EOS>
Accompanied
by
the
porter
,
he
hurried
to
the
yard
-
gate
,
saw
it
bolted
within
-
side
,
and
then
returned
to
the
shop
,
where
,
having
found
his
cap
and
cudgel
,
he
directed
Blaize
to
lock
the
door
after
him
,
cautioning
him
,
for
the
third
time
,
not
to
admit
any
one
except
the
doctor
.
<EOS>
"
If
I
find
,
on
my
return
,
that
you
have
neglected
my
injunctions
,
"
he
concluded
,
"
as
sure
as
I
now
stand
before
you
,
I
'll
break
every
bone
in
your
body
.
"
 
<EOS>
Blaize
promised
obedience
,
adding
in
a
supplicating
tone
,
"
Leonard
,
if
I
were
you
,
I
would
not
go
to
the
Examiner
of
Health
.
<EOS>
Poor
Stephen
may
not
have
the
plague
,
after
all
.
<EOS>
It
's
a
dreadful
thing
to
be
imprisoned
for
a
month
,
for
that
's
the
time
appointed
by
the
Lord
Mayor
.
<EOS>
Only
a
week
ago
I
passed
several
houses
in
Holborn
,
shut
up
on
account
of
the
plague
,
with
a
watchman
at
the
door
,
and
I
never
shall
forget
the
melancholy
faces
I
saw
at
the
windows
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
dreadful
spectacle
,
and
has
haunted
me
ever
since
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
can
not
be
helped
,
"
rejoined
Leonard
,
with
a
sigh
.
<EOS>
"
If
we
disobey
the
Lord
Mayor
's
orders
,
and
neglect
giving
information
,
we
shall
all
be
sent
to
Newgate
,
while
poor
Stephen
will
be
taken
to
the
pest
-
house
.
<EOS>
Besides
,
the
searchers
will
be
here
before
morning
.
<EOS>
They
are
sure
to
learn
what
has
happened
from
Doctor
Hodges
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
True
,
true
,
"
replied
Blaize
;
"
I
had
forgotten
that
.
<EOS>
Let
me
go
with
you
,
dear
Leonard
.
<EOS>
I
dare
not
remain
here
longer
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
What
!
<EOS>
would
you
leave
your
kind
good
master
,
at
a
time
like
this
,
when
he
most
needs
your
services
?
"
rejoined
Leonard
,
reproachfully
.
<EOS>
"
Out
,
cowardly
hound
!
<EOS>
I
am
ashamed
of
you
.
<EOS>
Shake
off
your
fears
,
and
be
a
man
.
<EOS>
You
can
but
die
once
;
and
what
matters
it
whether
you
die
of
the
plague
or
the
cholic
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
matters
a
great
deal
,
"
replied
Blaize
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
afraid
of
nothing
but
the
plague
.
<EOS>
I
am
sure
I
shall
be
its
next
victim
in
this
house
.
<EOS>
But
you
are
right
<EOS>
--
I
can
not
desert
my
kind
master
,
nor
my
old
mother
.
<EOS>
Farewell
,
Leonard
.
<EOS>
Perhaps
we
may
never
meet
again
.
<EOS>
I
may
be
dead
before
you
come
back
.
<EOS>
I
feel
very
ill
already
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
No
wonder
,
after
all
the
stuff
you
have
swallowed
,
"
returned
Leonard
.
"
<EOS>
But
pluck
up
your
courage
,
or
you
will
bring
on
the
very
thing
you
are
anxious
to
avoid
.
<EOS>
As
many
people
have
died
from
fear
as
from
any
other
cause
.
<EOS>
One
word
before
I
go
.
<EOS>
If
any
one
should
get
into
the
house
by
scaling
the
yard
-
wall
,
or
through
the
window
,
instantly
alarm
our
master
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Certainly
,
"
returned
Blaize
,
with
a
look
of
surprise
,
"
But
do
you
expect
any
one
to
enter
the
house
in
that
way
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Ask
no
questions
,
but
do
as
I
bid
you
,
"
rejoined
Leonard
,
opening
the
door
,
and
about
to
go
forth
.
 
<EOS>
"
Stop
a
moment
,
"
cried
Blaize
,
detaining
him
,
and
drawing
from
his
pocket
a
handful
of
simples
.
<EOS>
"
Wo
n't
you
take
some
of
them
with
you
to
guard
against
infection
?
<EOS>
There
's
wormwood
,
woodsorrel
,
masterwort
,
zedoary
,
and
angelica
;
and
lastly
,
there
is
a
little
bottle
of
the
sovereign
preservative
against
the
plague
,
as
prepared
by
the
great
Lord
Bacon
,
and
approved
by
Queen
Elizabeth
.
<EOS>
Wo
n't
you
take
_
that
_
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
no
fear
,
"
replied
Leonard
,
shutting
the
door
in
his
face
.
<EOS>
And
as
he
lingered
for
a
moment
while
it
was
locked
,
he
heard
Blaize
say
to
himself
,
"
I
must
go
and
take
three
more
rufuses
and
a
large
dose
of
diascordium
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
It
was
a
bright
moonlight
night
,
and
as
the
apprentice
turned
to
depart
,
he
perceived
a
figure
hastily
retreating
on
the
other
side
of
the
way
.
<EOS>
Making
sure
it
was
Maurice
Wyvil
,
though
he
could
not
distinguish
the
garb
of
the
person
--
that
side
of
the
street
being
in
the
shade
--
and
stung
by
jealousy
,
he
immediately
started
in
pursuit
.
<EOS>
The
fugitive
struck
down
Lad
-
lane
,
and
run
on
till
he
came
to
the
end
of
Lawrence
-
lane
,
where
,
finding
himself
closely
pressed
,
he
suddenly
halted
,
and
pulling
his
hat
over
his
brows
to
conceal
his
features
,
fiercely
confronted
his
pursuer
.
 
<EOS>
"
Why
do
you
follow
me
thus
,
rascal
?
"
<EOS>
he
cried
,
drawing
his
sword
.
"
<EOS>
Would
you
rob
me
?
<EOS>
Begone
,
or
I
will
call
the
watch
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
_
is
_
his
voice
!
"
<EOS>
cried
the
apprentice
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
news
for
you
,
Mr.
Maurice
Wyvil
.
<EOS>
You
will
not
see
Amabel
to
-
night
.
<EOS>
The
plague
is
in
her
father
's
house
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
The
plague
!
"
exclaimed
Wyvil
,
in
an
altered
tone
,
and
dropping
the
point
of
his
sword
.
<EOS>
"
Is
she
smitten
by
it
?
"
 
<EOS>
The
apprentice
answered
by
a
bitter
laugh
,
and
without
tarrying
longer
to
enjoy
his
rival
's
distress
,
set
off
towards
Cheapside
.
<EOS>
Before
reaching
the
end
of
Lawrence
-
lane
,
however
,
he
half
-
repented
his
conduct
,
and
halted
to
see
whether
Wyvil
was
following
him
;
but
as
he
could
perceive
nothing
of
him
,
he
continued
his
course
.
 
<EOS>
Entering
Cheapside
,
he
observed
,
to
his
surprise
,
a
crowd
of
persons
collected
near
the
Cross
,
then
standing
a
little
to
the
east
of
Wood
-
street
.
<EOS>
This
cross
,
which
was
of
great
antiquity
,
and
had
undergone
many
mutilations
and
alterations
since
its
erection
in
1486
,
when
it
boasted
,
amongst
other
embellishments
,
images
of
the
Virgin
and
Saint
Edward
the
Confessor
,
was
still
not
without
some
pretensions
to
architectural
beauty
.
<EOS>
In
form
it
was
hexagonal
,
and
composed
of
three
tiers
,
rising
from
one
another
like
the
divisions
of
a
telescope
,
each
angle
being
supported
by
a
pillar
surmounted
by
a
statue
,
while
the
intervening
niches
were
filled
up
with
sculptures
,
intended
to
represent
some
of
the
sovereigns
of
England
.
<EOS>
The
structure
was
of
considerable
height
,
and
crowned
by
a
large
gilt
cross
.
<EOS>
Its
base
was
protected
by
a
strong
wooden
railing
.
<EOS>
About
a
hundred
yards
to
the
east
,
there
stood
a
smaller
hexagonal
tower
,
likewise
ornamented
with
carvings
,
and
having
a
figure
on
its
conical
summit
blowing
a
horn
.
<EOS>
This
was
the
Conduit
.
<EOS>
Midway
between
these
buildings
the
crowd
alluded
to
above
was
collected
.
 
<EOS>
As
Leonard
drew
near
,
he
found
the
assemblage
was
listening
to
the
exhortations
of
an
enthusiast
,
whom
he
instantly
recognised
from
a
description
he
had
heard
of
him
from
Blaize
.
<EOS>
The
name
of
this
half
-
crazed
being
was
Solomon
Eagle
.
<EOS>
Originally
a
Quaker
,
upon
the
outbreak
of
the
plague
he
had
abandoned
his
home
and
friends
,
and
roamed
the
streets
at
night
,
denouncing
doom
to
the
city
.
<EOS>
He
was
a
tall
gaunt
man
,
with
long
jet
-
black
hair
hanging
in
disordered
masses
over
his
shoulders
.
<EOS>
His
eyes
were
large
and
black
,
and
blazed
with
insane
lustre
,
and
his
looks
were
so
wild
and
terrific
,
that
it
required
no
great
stretch
of
imagination
to
convert
him
into
the
genius
of
the
pestilence
.
<EOS>
Entirely
stripped
of
apparel
except
that
his
loins
were
girt
with
a
sheep
-
skin
,
in
imitation
of
Saint
John
in
the
Wilderness
,
he
bore
upon
his
head
a
brazier
of
flaming
coals
,
the
lurid
light
of
which
falling
upon
his
sable
locks
and
tawny
skin
,
gave
him
an
unearthly
appearance
.
 
<EOS>
Impelled
by
curiosity
,
Leonard
paused
for
a
moment
to
listen
,
and
heard
him
thunder
forth
the
following
denunciation:--"And
<EOS>
now
,
therefore
,
as
the
prophet
Jeremiah
saith
,
'
I
have
this
day
declared
it
to
you
,
but
ye
have
not
obeyed
the
voice
of
the
Lord
your
God
,
nor
anything
for
the
which
<EOS>
he
hath
sent
me
unto
you
.
<EOS>
Now
,
therefore
,
know
certainly
that
ye
shall
die
by
the
sword
,
by
the
famine
,
and
by
the
pestilence
.
'
<EOS>
Again
,
in
the
words
of
the
prophet
Amos
,
the
Lord
saith
unto
YOU
by
my
mouth
,
'
I
have
sent
among
you
the
pestilence
after
the
manner
of
Egypt
,
yet
have
you
not
returned
unto
me
.
<EOS>
Therefore
,
will
I
do
this
unto
thee
,
O
Israel
;
and
because
I
will
do
this
unto
thee
,
prepare
to
meet
thy
God
?
'
<EOS>
Do
you
hear
this
,
O
sinners
?
<EOS>
God
will
proceed
against
you
in
the
day
of
His
wrath
,
though
He
hath
borne
with
you
in
the
day
of
His
patience
?
<EOS>
O
how
many
hundred
years
hath
<EOS>
He
spared
this
city
,
notwithstanding
its
great
provocations
and
wickedness
!
<EOS>
But
now
He
will
no
longer
show
it
pity
,
but
will
pour
out
His
wrath
upon
it
<EOS>
I
Plagues
shall
come
upon
it
,
and
desolation
;
and
it
shall
be
utterly
burnt
with
fire,--for
strong
<EOS>
is
the
Lord
who
judgeth
it
!
"
 
<EOS>
His
address
concluded
,
the
enthusiast
started
off
at
a
swift
pace
,
shrieking
,
in
a
voice
that
caused
many
persons
to
throw
open
their
windows
to
listen
to
him
,
"
Awake
!
<EOS>
sinners
,
awake'--the
plague
is
at
your
doors!--the
grave
yawns
for
you!--awake
,
and
repent
!
"
<EOS>
And
followed
by
the
crowd
,
many
of
whom
kept
up
with
him
,
he
ran
on
vociferating
in
this
manner
till
he
was
out
of
hearing
.
 
<EOS>
Hurrying
forward
in
the
opposite
direction
,
Leonard
glanced
at
the
ancient
and
picturesque
houses
on
either
side
of
the
way,--now
<EOS>
bathed
in
the
moonlight
,
and
apparently
hushed
in
repose
<EOS>
and
security,--and
he
could
not
repress
a
shudder
as
he
reflected
that
an
evil
angel
was
,
indeed
,
abroad
,
who
might
suddenly
arouse
their
slumbering
inmates
to
despair
and
death
.
<EOS>
His
thoughts
took
another
turn
as
he
entered
the
precincts
of
Saint
Paul
's
,
and
surveyed
the
venerable
and
majestic
fabric
before
him
.
<EOS>
His
eyes
rested
upon
its
innumerable
crocketed
pinnacles
,
its
buttresses
,
its
battlements
,
and
upon
the
magnificent
rose
-
window
terminating
the
choir
.
<EOS>
The
apprentice
had
no
especial
love
for
antiquity
,
but
being
of
an
imaginative
turn
,
the
sight
of
this
reverend
structure
conjured
up
old
recollections
,
and
brought
to
mind
the
noble
Collegiate
Church
of
his
native
town
.
 
<EOS>
"
Shall
I
ever
see
Manchester
again
?
"
<EOS>
he
sighed
:
"
shall
I
take
Amabel
with
me
there
?
<EOS>
Alas
!
<EOS>
I
doubt
it
.
<EOS>
If
I
survive
the
plague
,
she
,
I
fear
,
will
never
be
mine
.
"
 
<EOS>
Musing
<EOS>
thus
,
he
scanned
the
roof
of
the
cathedral
,
and
noticing
its
stunted
central
tower
,
could
not
help
thinking
how
much
more
striking
its
effects
must
have
been
,
when
the
lofty
spire
it
once
supported
was
standing
.
<EOS>
The
spire
,
it
may
be
remarked
,
was
twice
destroyed
by
lightning
;
first
in
February
,
1444
,
and
subsequently
in
June
,
1561
,
when
it
was
entirely
burnt
down
,
and
never
rebuilt
.
<EOS>
Passing
the
Convocation
House
,
which
then
stood
at
one
side
of
the
southern
transept
,
Leonard
struck
down
Paul
's
Chain
,
and
turning
to
the
right
,
speeded
along
Great
Knightrider
-
street
,
until
he
reached
an
old
habitation
at
the
corner
of
the
passage
leading
to
Doctors
'
Commons
.
 
<EOS>
Knocking
at
the
door
,
an
elderly
servant
presently
appeared
,
and
in
answer
to
his
inquiries
whether
Doctor
Hodges
was
at
home
,
stated
that
he
had
gone
out
,
about
half
an
hour
ago
,
to
attend
Mr.
Fisher
,
a
proctor
,
who
had
been
suddenly
attacked
by
the
plague
at
his
residence
in
Bartholomew
-
close
,
near
Smithfield
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
come
on
the
same
errand
,
"
said
Leonard
,
"
and
must
see
your
master
instantly
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
If
you
choose
to
go
to
Bartholomew
-
close
,
"
replied
the
servant
,
"
you
may
probably
meet
with
him
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Fisher
's
house
is
the
last
but
two
,
on
the
right
,
before
you
come
to
the
area
in
front
of
the
church
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
can
easily
find
it
,
"
returned
Leonard
,
"
and
will
run
there
as
fast
as
I
can
.
<EOS>
But
if
your
master
should
pass
me
on
the
road
,
beseech
him
to
go
instantly
to
Stephen
Bloundell
's
,
the
grocer
,
in
Wood
-
street
.
"
 
<EOS>
The
servant
assenting
,
Leonard
hastily
retraced
his
steps
,
and
traversing
Blow
-
bladder
-
street
and
Saint
-
Martin's
-
le
-
Grand
,
passed
through
Aldersgate
.
<EOS>
He
then
shaped
his
course
through
the
windings
of
Little
Britain
and
entered
Duck
-
lane
.
<EOS>
He
was
now
in
a
quarter
fearfully
assailed
by
the
pestilence
.
<EOS>
Most
of
the
houses
had
the
fatal
sign
upon
their
doors
--
a
red
cross
,
of
a
foot
long
,
with
the
piteous
words
above
it
,
"
Lord
have
mercy
upon
us
,
"
in
characters
so
legible
that
they
could
be
easily
distinguished
by
the
moonlight
,
while
a
watchman
,
with
a
halberd
in
his
hand
,
kept
guard
outside
.
 
<EOS>
Involuntarily
drawing
in
his
breath
,
Leonard
quickened
his
pace
.
<EOS>
But
he
met
with
an
unexpected
and
fearful
interruption
.
<EOS>
Just
as
he
reached
the
narrow
passage
leading
from
Duck
-
lane
to
Bartholomew
-
close
,
he
heard
the
ringing
of
a
bell
,
followed
by
a
hoarse
voice
,
crying
,
"
Bring
out
your
dead
--
bring
out
your
dead
!
"
<EOS>
he
then
perceived
that
a
large
,
strangely
-
shaped
cart
stopped
up
the
further
end
of
the
passage
,
and
heard
a
window
open
,
and
a
voice
call
out
that
all
was
ready
.
<EOS>
The
next
moment
a
light
was
seen
at
the
door
,
and
a
coffin
was
brought
out
and
placed
in
the
cart
.
<EOS>
This
done
,
the
driver
,
who
was
smoking
a
pipe
,
cracked
his
whip
,
and
put
the
vehicle
in
motion
.
 
<EOS>
Shrinking
into
a
doorway
,
and
holding
a
handkerchief
to
his
face
,
to
avoid
breathing
the
pestilential
effluvia
,
Leonard
saw
that
there
were
other
coffins
in
the
cart
,
and
that
it
was
followed
by
two
persons
in
long
black
cloaks
.
<EOS>
The
vehicle
itself
,
fashioned
like
an
open
hearse
,
and
of
the
same
sombre
colour
,
relieved
by
fantastical
designs
,
painted
in
white
,
emblematic
of
the
pestilence
,
was
drawn
by
a
horse
of
the
large
black
Flanders
breed
,
and
decorated
with
funeral
trappings
.
<EOS>
To
Leonard
's
inexpressible
horror
,
the
cart
again
stopped
opposite
him
,
and
the
driver
ringing
his
bell
,
repeated
his
doleful
cry
.
<EOS>
While
another
coffin
was
brought
out
,
and
placed
with
the
rest
,
a
window
in
the
next
house
was
opened
,
and
a
woman
looking
forth
screamed
,
"
Is
Anselm
Chowles
,
the
coffin
-
maker
,
there
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
here
I
am
,
Mother
Malmayns
,
"
replied
one
of
the
men
in
black
cloaks
,
looking
up
as
he
spoke
,
and
exhibiting
features
so
hideous
,
and
stamped
with
such
a
revolting
expression
,
that
Leonard
's
blood
curdled
at
the
sight
.
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
want
with
me
?
"
<EOS>
he
added
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
want
you
to
carry
away
old
Mike
Norborough
,
"
replied
the
woman
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
,
is
the
old
miser
gone
at
last
?
"
<EOS>
exclaimed
Chowles
,
with
an
atrocious
laugh
.
<EOS>
"
But
how
shall
I
get
paid
for
a
coffin
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
may
pay
yourself
with
what
you
can
find
in
the
house
,
"
replied
Mother
Malmayns
;
"
or
you
may
carry
him
to
the
grave
without
one
,
if
you
prefer
it
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
No
,
no
,
that
wo
n't
do
,
"
returned
Chowles
.
<EOS>
"
I
've
other
customers
to
attend
to
who
_
will
_
pay
;
and
,
besides
,
I
want
to
get
home
.
<EOS>
I
expect
friends
at
supper
.
<EOS>
Good
-
night
,
Mother
Malmayns
.
<EOS>
You
know
where
to
find
me
,
if
you
want
me
.
<EOS>
Move
on
,
Jonas
,
or
<EOS>
you
will
never
reach
Saint
Sepulchre
's
.
"
 
<EOS>
The
woman
angrily
expostulated
with
him
,
and
some
further
parley
ensued,--Leonard
did
not
tarry
to
hear
what
,
but
rushing
past
them
,
gained
Bartholomew
-
close
.
 
<EOS>
He
soon
reached
the
proctor
's
house
,
and
found
it
marked
with
the
fatal
cross
.
<EOS>
Addressing
a
watchman
at
the
door
,
he
learnt
,
to
his
great
dismay
,
that
Doctor
Hodges
had
been
gone
more
than
a
quarter
of
an
hour
.
"
<EOS>
He
was
too
late
,
"
said
the
man
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Poor
Mr.
Fisher
had
breathed
his
last
before
he
arrived
,
and
after
giving
some
directions
to
the
family
as
to
the
precautions
they
ought
to
observe
,
the
doctor
departed
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
How
unfortunate
!
"
exclaimed
Leonard
,
"
I
have
missed
him
a
second
time
.
<EOS>
But
I
will
run
back
to
his
house
instantly
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
will
not
find
him
at
home
,
"
returned
the
watchman
"
<EOS>
He
is
gone
to
Saint
Paul
's
,
to
attend
a
sick
person
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
To
Saint
Paul
's
at
this
hour
!
"
cried
the
apprentice
.
<EOS>
"
Why
,
no
one
is
there
,
except
the
vergers
or
the
sexton
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
He
is
gone
to
visit
the
sexton
,
who
is
ill
of
the
plague
,
"
replied
the
watchman
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
told
you
all
I
know
about
him
.
<EOS>
You
can
do
what
you
think
best
.
"
 
<EOS>
Determined
to
make
another
effort
before
giving
in
,
Leonard
hurried
back
as
fast
as
he
could
.
<EOS>
While
threading
Duck
-
lane
,
he
heard
the
doleful
bell
again
,
and
perceived
the
dead
-
cart
standing
before
a
house
,
from
which
two
small
coffins
were
brought
.
<EOS>
Hurrying
past
the
vehicle
,
he
remarked
that
its
load
was
fearfully
increased
,
but
that
the
coffin
-
maker
and
his
companion
had
left
it
.
<EOS>
Another
minute
had
not
elapsed
before
he
reached
Aldersgate
,
and
passing
through
the
postern
,
he
beheld
a
light
at
the
end
of
Saint
Anne's
-
lane
,
and
heard
the
terrible
voice
of
Solomon
Eagle
,
calling
to
the
sleepers
to
awake
and
repent
.
 
<EOS>
Shutting
his
ears
to
the
cry
,
Leonard
did
not
halt
till
he
reached
the
great
western
door
of
the
cathedral
,
against
which
he
knocked
.
<EOS>
His
first
summons
remaining
unanswered
,
he
repeated
it
,
and
a
wicket
was
then
opened
by
a
grey
-
headed
verger
,
with
a
lantern
in
his
hand
,
who
at
first
was
very
angry
at
being
disturbed
;
but
on
learning
whom
the
applicant
was
in
search
of
,
and
that
the
case
was
one
of
urgent
necessity
,
he
admitted
that
the
doctor
was
in
the
cathedral
at
the
time
.
 
<EOS>
"
Or
rather
,
I
should
say
,
"
he
added
,
"
he
is
in
Saint
Faith
's
.
<EOS>
I
will
conduct
you
to
him
,
if
you
think
proper
.
<EOS>
Doctor
Hodges
is
a
good
man,--a
charitable
man
,
"
he
continued
,
"
and
attends
the
poor
for
nothing
.
<EOS>
He
is
now
with
Matthew
Malmayns
,
the
sexton
,
who
was
taken
ill
of
the
plague
yesterday
,
and
will
get
nothing
but
thanks
--
if
he
gets
those
--
for
his
fee
.
<EOS>
But
,
follow
me
,
young
man
,
follow
me
.
"
 
<EOS>
So
saying
,
he
shut
the
wicket
,
and
led
the
way
along
the
transept
.
<EOS>
The
path
was
uneven
,
many
of
the
flags
having
been
removed
,
and
the
verger
often
paused
to
throw
a
light
upon
the
ground
,
and
warn
his
companion
of
a
hole
.
 
<EOS>
On
arriving
at
the
head
of
the
nave
,
Leonard
cast
his
eyes
down
it
,
and
was
surprised
at
the
magical
effect
of
the
moonlight
upon
its
magnificent
avenue
of
pillars
;
the
massive
shafts
on
the
left
being
completely
illuminated
by
the
silvery
beams
,
while
those
on
the
right
lay
in
deep
shadow
.
 
<EOS>
"
Ay
,
it
is
a
noble
structure
,
"
replied
the
old
verger
,
noticing
his
look
of
wonder
and
admiration
,
"
and
,
like
many
a
proud
human
being
,
has
known
better
days
.
<EOS>
It
has
seen
sad
changes
in
my
time
,
for
I
recollect
it
when
good
Queen
Bess
ruled
the
land
.
<EOS>
But
come
along
,
young
man,--you
have
something
else
to
think
of
now
.
"
 
<EOS>
Bestowing
a
momentary
glance
upon
the
matchless
choir
,
with
its
groined
roof
,
its
clerestory
windows
,
its
arched
openings
,
its
carved
stalls
,
and
its
gorgeous
rose
-
window
,
Leonard
followed
his
conductor
through
a
small
doorway
on
the
left
of
the
southern
transept
,
and
descending
a
flight
of
stone
steps
,
entered
a
dark
and
extensive
vault
,
for
such
it
seemed
.
<EOS>
The
feeble
light
of
the
lantern
fell
upon
ranks
of
short
heavy
pillars
,
supporting
a
ponderous
arched
roof
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
are
now
in
Saint
Faith
's
,
"
observed
the
verger
,
"
and
above
you
is
the
choir
of
Saint
Paul
's
.
"
 
<EOS>
Leonard
took
no
notice
of
the
remark
,
but
silently
crossing
the
nave
of
this
beautiful
subterranean
church
(
part
of
which
still
exists
)
,
traversed
its
northern
aisle
.
<EOS>
At
length
the
verger
stopped
before
the
entrance
of
a
small
chapel
,
once
dedicated
to
Saint
John
the
Baptist
,
but
now
devoted
to
a
less
sacred
purpose
.
<EOS>
As
they
advanced
,
Leonard
observed
a
pile
of
dried
skulls
and
bones
in
one
corner
,
a
stone
coffin
,
strips
of
woollen
shrouds
,
fragments
of
coffins
,
mattocks
,
and
spades
.
<EOS>
It
was
evidently
half
a
charnel
,
half
a
receptacle
for
the
sexton
's
tools
.
 
<EOS>
"
If
you
choose
to
open
that
door
,
"
said
the
verger
,
pointing
to
one
at
the
lower
end
of
the
chamber
,
"
you
will
find
him
you
seek
.
<EOS>
I
shall
go
no
further
.
"
 
<EOS>
Summoning
up
all
his
resolution
,
Leonard
pushed
open
the
door
.
<EOS>
A
frightful
scene
met
his
gaze
.
<EOS>
At
one
side
of
a
deep
,
low
-
roofed
vault
,
the
architecture
of
which
was
of
great
antiquity
,
and
showed
that
it
had
been
a
place
of
burial
,
was
stretched
a
miserable
pallet
,
and
upon
it
,
covered
by
a
single
blanket
,
lay
a
wretch
,
whose
groans
and
struggles
proclaimed
the
anguish
he
endured
.
<EOS>
A
lamp
was
burning
on
the
floor
,
and
threw
a
sickly
light
upon
the
agonized
countenance
of
the
sufferer
.
<EOS>
He
was
a
middle
-
aged
man
,
with
features
naturally
harsh
,
but
which
now
,
contracted
by
pain
,
had
assumed
a
revolting
expression
.
<EOS>
An
old
crone
,
who
proved
to
be
his
mother
,
and
a
young
man
,
who
held
him
down
in
bed
by
main
force
,
tended
him
.
<EOS>
He
was
rambling
in
a
frightful
manner
;
and
as
his
ravings
turned
upon
the
most
loathly
matters
,
it
required
some
firmness
to
listen
to
them
.
 
<EOS>
At
a
little
distance
from
him
,
upon
a
bench
,
sat
a
stout
,
shrewd
-
looking
,
but
benevolent
little
personage
,
somewhat
between
forty
and
fifty
.
<EOS>
This
was
Doctor
Hodges
.
<EOS>
He
had
a
lancet
in
his
hand
,
with
which
he
had
just
operated
upon
the
sufferer
,
and
he
was
in
the
act
of
wiping
it
on
a
cloth
.
<EOS>
As
Leonard
entered
the
vault
,
the
doctor
observed
to
the
attendants
of
the
sick
man
,
"
He
will
recover
.
<EOS>
The
tumour
has
discharged
its
venom
.
<EOS>
Keep
him
as
warm
as
you
can
,
and
do
not
let
him
leave
his
bed
for
two
days
.
<EOS>
All
depends
upon
that
.
<EOS>
I
will
send
him
proper
medicines
and
some
blankets
shortly
.
<EOS>
If
he
takes
cold
,
it
will
be
fatal
.
"
 
<EOS>
The
young
man
promised
to
attend
to
the
doctor
's
injunctions
,
and
the
old
woman
mumbled
her
thanks
.
 
<EOS>
"
Where
is
Judith
Malmayns
?
"
asked
Doctor
Hodges
:
"
I
am
surprised
not
to
see
her
.
<EOS>
Is
she
afraid
of
the
distemper
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
Afraid
of
it!--not
she
,
"
replied
the
old
woman
.
"
<EOS>
Since
the
plague
has
raged
so
dreadfully
,
she
has
gone
out
as
a
nurse
to
the
sick
,
and
my
poor
son
has
seen
nothing
of
her
.
"
 
<EOS>
Leonard
then
recollected
that
he
had
heard
the
woman
,
who
called
out
of
the
miser
's
house
,
addressed
as
Mother
Malmayns
by
the
coffin
-
maker
,
and
had
no
doubt
that
she
was
the
sexton
's
wife
.
<EOS>
His
entrance
having
been
so
noiseless
that
it
passed
unnoticed
,
he
now
stepped
forward
,
and
,
addressing
Doctor
Hodges
,
acquainted
him
with
his
errand
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
!
"
exclaimed
the
doctor
,
as
soon
as
he
concluded
,
"
a
son
of
Stephen
Bloundel
,
the
worthy
grocer
of
Wood
-
street
,
attacked
by
the
plague
!
<EOS>
I
will
go
with
you
instantly
,
young
man
.
<EOS>
I
have
a
great
regard
for
your
master
--
a
very
great
regard
.
<EOS>
There
is
not
a
better
man
living
.
<EOS>
The
poor
lad
must
be
saved
,
if
possible
.
"
<EOS>
And
hastily
repeating
his
instructions
to
the
attendants
of
the
sick
man
,
he
left
the
vault
with
the
apprentice
.
 
<EOS>
They
found
the
verger
in
the
charnel
,
and
before
quitting
it
,
the
doctor
drew
a
small
flask
of
canary
from
his
pocket
,
and
applied
it
to
his
lips
.
 
<EOS>
"
This
is
my
anti
-
pestilential
drink
,
"
he
remarked
with
a
smile
,
"
and
it
has
preserved
me
from
contagion
hitherto
.
<EOS>
You
must
let
us
out
of
the
south
door
,
friend
,
"
he
added
to
the
verger
,
"
for
I
shall
be
obliged
to
step
home
for
a
moment
,
and
it
will
save
time
.
<EOS>
Come
with
me
,
young
man
,
and
tell
me
what
has
been
done
for
the
grocer
's
son
.
"
 
<EOS>
As
they
traversed
the
gloomy
aisle
of
Saint
Faith
,
and
mounted
to
the
upper
structure
,
Leonard
related
all
that
had
taken
place
since
poor
Stephen
's
seizure
.
<EOS>
The
doctor
strongly
expressed
his
approval
of
what
had
been
done
,
and
observed
,
"
It
could
not
be
better
.
<EOS>
With
Heaven
's
help
,
I
have
no
doubt
we
shall
save
him
,
and
I
am
truly
glad
of
it
for
his
father
's
sake
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
By
this
time
they
had
reached
the
southern
door
,
and
the
verger
having
unlocked
it
,
they
issued
forth
.
<EOS>
It
was
still
bright
moonlight
,
and
Leonard
,
whose
mind
was
greatly
relieved
by
the
assurances
of
the
physician
,
felt
in
some
degree
reconciled
to
the
delay
,
and
kept
up
his
part
in
the
conversation
promoted
by
his
companion
.
<EOS>
The
doctor
,
who
was
an
extremely
kind
-
hearted
man
,
and
appeared
to
have
a
great
regard
for
the
grocer
,
made
many
inquiries
as
to
his
family
,
and
spoke
in
terms
of
the
highest
admiration
of
the
beauty
of
his
eldest
daughter
.
<EOS>
The
mention
of
Amabel
's
name
,
while
it
made
Leonard
's
cheek
burn
,
rekindled
all
his
jealousy
of
Wyvil
,
and
he
tried
to
make
some
excuse
to
get
away
,
but
his
companion
would
not
hear
of
it
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
tell
you
there
is
no
hurry
,
"
said
the
doctor
;
"
all
is
going
on
as
well
as
possible
.
<EOS>
I
will
make
your
excuses
to
your
master
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
On
reaching
the
doctor
's
house
they
were
ushered
into
a
large
room
,
surrounded
with
bookshelves
and
cases
of
anatomical
preparations
.
<EOS>
Hodges
seated
himself
at
a
table
,
on
which
a
shaded
lamp
was
placed
,
and
writing
out
a
prescription
,
desired
his
servant
to
get
it
made
up
at
a
neighbouring
apothecary
's
,
and
to
take
it
,
with
a
couple
of
blankets
,
to
the
sexton
of
Saint
Paul
's
.
<EOS>
He
then
produced
a
bottle
of
medicated
canary
,
and
pouring
out
a
large
glass
for
the
apprentice
,
drained
another
himself
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
will
answer
for
its
virtue
,
"
he
said
:
"
it
is
a
sure
preservative
against
the
plague
.
"
 
<EOS>
Having
furnished
himself
with
several
small
packets
of
simples
,
a
few
pots
of
ointment
,
one
or
two
phials
,
and
a
case
of
surgical
instruments
,
he
told
Leonard
he
was
ready
to
attend
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
We
will
go
round
by
Warwick
-
lane
,
"
he
added
.
<EOS>
"
I
must
call
upon
Chowles
,
the
coffin
-
maker
.
<EOS>
It
will
not
detain
us
a
moment
;
and
I
have
an
order
to
give
him
.
"
 
<EOS>
The
mention
of
this
name
brought
to
Leonard
's
mind
<EOS>
the
hideous
attendant
on
the
dead
-
cart
,
and
he
had
no
doubt
he
was
the
person
in
question
.
<EOS>
It
did
not
become
him
,
however
,
to
make
a
remark
,
and
they
set
out
.
 
<EOS>
Mounting
Addle
-
hill
,
and
threading
Ave
-
Maria
-
lane
,
they
entered
Warwick
-
lane
,
and
about
half
-
way
up
the
latter
thoroughfare
,
the
doctor
stopped
before
a
shop
,
bearing
on
its
immense
projecting
sign
the
representation
of
a
coffin
lying
in
state
,
and
covered
with
scutcheons
,
underneath
which
was
written
,
"
ANSELM
CHOWLES
,
COFFIN
-
MAKER
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
do
not
think
you
will
find
Mr.
Chowles
at
home
,
"
observed
Leonard
:
"
<EOS>
for
I
saw
him
with
the
dead
-
cart
not
half
an
hour
ago
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Very
likely
,
"
returned
the
doctor
;
"
but
I
shall
see
one
of
his
men
.
<EOS>
The
coffin
-
maker
's
business
is
now
carried
on
in
the
night
time
,
"
he
added
,
with
a
sigh
;
"
and
he
drives
a
flourishing
trade
.
<EOS>
These
sad
times
will
make
his
fortune
.
"
 
<EOS>
As
he
spoke
,
he
rapped
with
his
cane
at
the
door
,
which
,
after
a
little
delay
,
was
opened
by
a
young
man
in
a
carpenter
's
dress
,
with
a
hammer
in
his
hand
.
<EOS>
On
seeing
who
it
was
,
this
person
exhibited
great
confusion
,
and
would
have
retired
;
but
the
doctor
,
pushing
him
aside
,
asked
for
his
master
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
can
not
see
him
just
now
,
sir
,
"
replied
the
other
,
evidently
considerably
embarrassed
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He
is
just
come
home
greatly
fatigued
,
and
is
about
to
retire
to
rest
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
No
matter
,
"
returned
the
doctor
,
entering
a
room
,
in
which
three
or
four
other
men
were
at
work
,
hastily
finishing
coffins
;
"
I
_
must
_
see
him
.
"
 
<EOS>
No
further
opposition
being
offered
,
Hodges
,
followed
by
the
apprentice
,
marched
towards
an
inner
room
.
<EOS>
Just
as
he
reached
the
door
,
a
burst
of
loud
laughter
,
evidently
proceeding
from
a
numerous
party
,
arose
from
within
,
and
a
harsh
voice
was
heard
chanting
the
following
strains
:
   
SONG
OF
THE
PLAGUE
.
  
<EOS>
To
others
the
Plague
a
foe
may
be
,
  
To
me
'
tis
<EOS>
a
friend
--
not
an
enemy
;
  
My
coffins
and
coffers
alike
it
fills
,
  
And
the
richer
I
grow
the
more
it
kills
.
  
<EOS>
_
Drink
the
Plague
!
<EOS>
Drink
the
Plague
!
<EOS>
_
   
<EOS>
For
months
,
for
years
,
may
it
spend
its
rage
  
On
lusty
manhood
and
trembling
age
;
  
Though
half
mankind
of
the
scourge
should
die
,
  
<EOS>
My
coffins
will
sell
--
so
what
care
I
?
  
<EOS>
_
Drink
the
Plague
!
<EOS>
Drink
the
Plague
!
<EOS>
_
 
Loud
acclamations
followed
the
song
,
and
the
doctor
,
who
was
filled
with
disgust
and
astonishment
,
opened
the
door
.
<EOS>
He
absolutely
recoiled
at
the
scene
presented
to
his
gaze
.
<EOS>
In
the
midst
of
a
large
room
,
the
sides
of
which
were
crowded
with
coffins
,
piled
to
the
very
ceiling
,
sat
about
a
dozen
personages
,
with
pipes
in
their
mouths
,
and
flasks
and
glasses
before
them
.
<EOS>
Their
seats
were
coffins
,
and
their
table
was
a
coffin
set
upon
a
bier
.
<EOS>
Perched
on
a
pyramid
of
coffins
,
gradually
diminishing
in
size
as
the
pile
approached
its
apex
,
Chowles
was
waving
a
glass
in
one
hand
,
and
a
bottle
in
the
other
,
when
the
doctor
made
his
appearance
.
 
<EOS>
A
more
hideous
personage
can
not
be
imagined
than
the
coffin
-
maker
.
<EOS>
He
was
clothed
in
a
suit
of
rusty
black
,
which
made
his
skeleton
limbs
look
yet
more
lean
and
cadaverous
.
<EOS>
His
head
was
perfectly
bald
,
and
its
yellow
skin
,
divested
of
any
artificial
covering
,
glistened
like
polished
ivory
.
<EOS>
His
throat
was
long
and
scraggy
,
and
supported
a
head
unrivalled
for
ugliness
.
<EOS>
His
nose
had
been
broken
in
his
youth
,
and
was
almost
compressed
flat
with
his
face
.
<EOS>
His
few
remaining
teeth
were
yellow
and
discoloured
with
large
gaps
between
them
.
<EOS>
His
eyes
were
bright
,
and
set
in
deep
cavernous
recesses
,
and
,
now
that
he
was
more
than
half
-
intoxicated
,
gleamed
with
unnatural
lustre
.
<EOS>
The
friends
by
whom
he
was
surrounded
were
congenial
spirits,--searchers
,
watchmen
,
buriers
,
apothecaries
,
and
other
wretches
,
who
,
like
himself
,
rejoiced
in
the
pestilence
,
because
it
was
a
source
of
profit
to
them
.
 
<EOS>
At
one
corner
of
the
room
,
with
a
part
-
emptied
glass
before
her
,
and
several
articles
in
her
lap
,
which
she
hastily
pocketed
on
the
entrance
of
the
doctor
,
sat
the
plague
-
nurse
,
Mother
Malmayns
;
and
Leonard
thought
her
,
if
possible
,
more
villainous
-
looking
than
her
companions
.
<EOS>
She
was
a
rough
,
raw
-
boned
woman
,
with
sandy
hair
and
light
brows
,
a
sallow
,
freckled
complexion
,
a
nose
with
wide
nostrils
,
and
a
large
,
thick
-
lipped
mouth
.
<EOS>
She
had
,
moreover
,
a
look
of
mingled
cunning
and
ferocity
inexpressibly
revolting
.
 
<EOS>
Sharply
rebuking
Chowles
,
who
,
in
springing
from
his
lofty
seat
,
upset
several
of
the
topmost
coffins
,
the
doctor
gave
him
some
directions
,
and
,
turning
to
the
nurse
,
informed
her
of
her
husband
's
condition
,
and
ordered
her
to
go
to
him
immediately
<EOS>
Mother
Malmayns
arose
,
and
glancing
significantly
at
the
coffin
-
maker
,
took
her
departure
.
 
<EOS>
Repeating
his
injunctions
to
Chowles
in
a
severe
tone
,
the
doctor
followed
;
and
seeing
her
take
the
way
towards
Saint
Paul
's
,
proceeded
at
a
brisk
pace
along
Paternoster
-
row
with
the
apprentice
.
<EOS>
In
a
few
minutes
they
reached
Wood
-
street
,
and
knocking
at
the
door
,
were
admitted
by
Blaize
.
 
<EOS>
"
Heaven
be
praised
,
you
are
come
at
last
!
"
<EOS>
exclaimed
the
porter
.
<EOS>
"
Our
master
began
to
think
something
had
happened
to
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
all
my
fault
,
"
returned
Doctor
Hodges
;
"
but
how
is
the
young
man
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Better
,
much
better
,
as
I
understand
,
"
replied
Blaize
;
"
<EOS>
but
I
have
not
seen
him
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Come
,
that
's
well
,
"
rejoined
Hodges
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Lead
me
to
his
room
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Leonard
will
show
you
the
way
,
"
returned
the
porter
,
holding
back
.
 
<EOS>
Glancing
angrily
at
Blaize
,
the
apprentice
conducted
the
doctor
to
the
inner
room
,
where
they
found
the
grocer
,
with
the
Bible
on
his
knee
,
watching
by
the
bedside
of
his
son
.
<EOS>
He
was
delighted
with
their
appearance
,
but
looked
inquisitively
at
his
apprentice
for
some
explanation
of
his
long
absence
.
<EOS>
This
Hodges
immediately
gave
;
and
,
having
examined
the
sufferer
,
he
relieved
the
anxious
father
by
declaring
,
that
,
with
due
care
,
he
had
little
doubt
of
his
son
's
recovery
.
 
<EOS>
"
God
be
praised
!
"
<EOS>
exclaimed
Bloundel
,
falling
on
his
knees
.
 
<EOS>
Hodges
then
gave
minute
directions
to
the
