grocer
as
to
how
he
was
to
proceed
,
and
told
him
it
would
be
necessary
for
some
time
to
keep
his
family
separate
.
<EOS>
To
this
Bloundel
readily
agreed
.
<EOS>
The
doctor
's
next
inquiries
were
,
whether
notice
had
been
given
to
the
Examiner
of
Health
,
and
the
grocer
referring
to
Leonard
,
the
latter
acknowledged
that
he
had
forgotten
it
,
but
undertook
to
repair
his
omission
at
once
.
 
<EOS>
With
this
view
,
he
quitted
the
room
,
and
was
hastening
towards
the
shop
,
when
he
observed
a
figure
on
the
back
stairs
.
<EOS>
Quickly
mounting
them
,
he
overtook
on
the
landing
Maurice
Wyvil
.
        
<EOS>
*
      
<EOS>
*
      
<EOS>
*
      
<EOS>
*
      
<EOS>
*
  
III
.
 
<EOS>
THE
GAMESTER
AND
THE
BULLY
.
 
<EOS>
Before
proceeding
further
,
it
will
be
necessary
to
retrace
our
steps
for
a
short
time
,
and
see
what
was
done
by
Maurice
Wyvil
after
the
alarming
announcement
made
to
him
by
the
apprentice
.
<EOS>
Of
a
selfish
nature
and
ungovernable
temper
,
and
seeking
only
in
the
pursuit
of
the
grocer
's
daughter
the
gratification
of
his
lawless
desires
,
he
was
filled
,
in
the
first
instance
,
with
furious
disappointment
at
being
robbed
of
the
prize
,
at
the
very
moment
he
expected
it
to
fall
into
his
hands
.
<EOS>
But
this
feeling
was
quickly
effaced
by
anxiety
respecting
his
mistress
,
whose
charms
,
now
that
there
was
every
probability
of
losing
her
(
for
Leonard
's
insinuation
had
led
him
to
believe
she
was
assailed
by
the
pestilence
)
,
appeared
doubly
attractive
to
him
;
and
scarcely
under
the
governance
of
reason
,
he
hurried
towards
Wood
-
street
,
resolved
to
force
his
way
into
the
house
,
and
see
her
again
,
at
all
hazards
.
<EOS>
His
wild
design
,
however
,
was
fortunately
prevented
.
<EOS>
As
he
passed
the
end
of
the
court
leading
to
the
ancient
inn
(
for
it
was
ancient
even
at
the
time
of
this
history
)
,
the
Swan
-
with
-
two
-
Necks
,
in
Lad
-
lane
,
a
young
man
,
as
richly
attired
as
himself
,
and
about
his
own
age
,
who
had
seen
him
approaching
,
suddenly
darted
from
it
,
and
grasping
his
cloak
,
detained
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
thought
it
must
be
you
,
Wyvil
,
"
cried
this
person
.
<EOS>
"
Where
are
you
running
so
quickly
?
<EOS>
I
see
neither
angry
father
,
nor
jealous
apprentice
,
at
your
heels
.
<EOS>
What
has
become
of
the
girl
?
<EOS>
Are
you
tired
of
her
already
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
Let
me
go
,
Lydyard
,
"
returned
Wyvil
,
trying
to
extricate
himself
from
his
companion
's
hold
,
who
was
no
other
than
the
gallant
that
had
accompanied
him
on
his
first
visit
to
the
grocer
's
shop
,
and
had
played
his
part
so
adroitly
in
the
scheme
devised
between
them
to
procure
an
interview
with
Amabel,--"let
me
go
<EOS>
,
I
say
,
I
am
in
no
mood
for
jesting
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Why
,
what
the
plague
is
the
matter
?
"
rejoined
Lydyard
.
"
<EOS>
Has
your
mistress
played
you
false
?
<EOS>
Have
you
lost
your
wager
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
The
plague
_
is
_
the
matter
,
"
replied
Wyvil
,
sternly
.
<EOS>
"
Amabel
is
attacked
by
it
.
<EOS>
I
must
see
her
instantly
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
The
devil
!
"
exclaimed
Lydyard
.
<EOS>
"
Here
is
a
pretty
termination
to
the
affair
.
<EOS>
But
if
this
is
really
the
case
,
you
must
_
not
_
see
her
.
<EOS>
It
is
one
thing
to
be
run
through
the
arm,--which
<EOS>
you
must
own
I
managed
as
dexterously
as
<EOS>
the
best
master
of
fence
could
have
<EOS>
done,--and
lose
a
few
drops
of
blood
for
a
mistress
,
but
it
is
another
to
brave
the
plague
on
her
account
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
care
for
nothing
,
"
replied
Wyvil
;
"
I
_
will
_
see
her
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
This
is
madness
!
"
<EOS>
remonstrated
Lydyard
,
still
maintaining
his
grasp
.
<EOS>
"
What
satisfaction
will
it
afford
you
to
witness
her
sufferings
--
to
see
the
frightful
ravages
made
upon
her
charms
by
this
remorseless
disease,--to
throw
her
whole
family
into
consternation
,
and
destroy
the
little
chance
she
may
have
of
recovery
,
by
your
presence
?
<EOS>
What
good
will
this
do
?
<EOS>
No,--you
must
pay
your
wager
to
Sedley
,
and
forget
her
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
can
not
forget
her
,
"
replied
Wyvil
.
<EOS>
"
My
feelings
have
undergone
a
total
change
.
<EOS>
If
I
_
am
_
capable
of
real
love
,
it
is
for
her
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Real
love
!
"
exclaimed
Lydyard
,
in
an
incredulous
tone
.
<EOS>
"
If
the
subject
were
not
too
serious
,
I
should
laugh
in
your
face
.
<EOS>
No
doubt
you
would
marry
her
,
and
abandon
your
design
upon
the
rich
heiress
,
pretty
Mistress
Mallet
,
whom
old
Rowley
recommended
to
your
attention
,
and
whom
the
fair
Stewart
has
more
than
half
-
won
for
you
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
would
,
"
replied
the
other
,
energetically
.
 
<EOS>
"
Nay
,
then
,
you
are
more
insane
than
I
thought
you
,
"
rejoined
Lydyard
,
relinquishing
his
hold
;
"
and
the
sooner
you
take
the
plague
the
better
.
<EOS>
It
may
cure
your
present
brain
fever
.
<EOS>
I
shall
go
back
to
Parravicin
,
and
the
others
.
<EOS>
You
will
not
require
my
assistance
further
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
know
not
,
"
replied
Wyvil
,
distractedly
;
"
I
have
not
yet
given
up
my
intention
of
carrying
off
the
girl
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
If
you
carry
her
oft
in
this
state
,
"
rejoined
the
other
,
"
it
must
be
to
the
pest
-
house
.
<EOS>
But
who
told
you
she
was
attacked
by
the
plague
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
Her
father
's
apprentice
<EOS>
,
"
replied
Wyvil
.
 
<EOS>
"
And
you
believed
him
?
<EOS>
"
demanded
Lydyard
,
with
a
derisive
laugh
.
 
<EOS>
"
Undoubtedly
,
"
replied
Wyvil
.
<EOS>
"
Why
not
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
Because
it
is
evidently
a
mere
trick
to
frighten
you
from
the
house
,
"
rejoined
Lydyard
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
surprised
so
shallow
a
device
should
succeed
with
_
you
_
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
wish
I
could
persuade
myself
it
was
a
trick
,
"
returned
Wyvil
.
<EOS>
"
But
the
fellow
's
manner
convinced
me
he
was
in
earnest
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Well
,
I
will
not
dispute
the
point
,
though
I
am
sure
I
am
right
,
"
returned
Lydyard
.
<EOS>
"
But
be
not
too
precipitate
.
<EOS>
Since
the
apprentice
has
seen
you
,
some
alteration
may
be
necessary
in
your
plans
.
<EOS>
Come
with
me
into
the
house
.
<EOS>
A
few
minutes
can
make
no
difference
.
"
 
<EOS>
Wyvil
suffered
himself
to
be
led
up
the
court
,
and
passing
through
a
door
on
the
left
,
they
entered
a
spacious
room
,
across
which
ran
a
long
table
,
furnished
at
one
end
with
wine
and
refreshments
,
and
at
the
other
with
cards
and
dice
.
 
<EOS>
Three
persons
were
seated
at
the
table
,
the
most
noticeable
of
whom
was
a
dissipated
-
looking
young
man
,
dressed
in
the
extremity
of
the
prevailing
mode
,
with
ruffles
of
the
finest
colbertine
,
three
inches
in
depth
,
at
his
wrists
;
<EOS>
a
richly
-
laced
cravat
round
his
throat
;
white
silk
hose
,
adorned
with
gold
clocks
;
velvet
shoes
of
the
same
colour
as
the
hose
,
fastened
with
immense
roses
;
a
silver
-
hilted
sword
,
supported
by
a
broad
embroidered
silk
band
;
and
a
cloak
and
doublet
of
carnation
-
coloured
velvet
,
woven
with
gold
,
and
decorated
with
innumerable
glittering
points
and
ribands
.
<EOS>
He
had
a
flowing
wig
of
flaxen
hair
,
and
a
broad
-
leaved
hat
,
looped
with
a
diamond
buckle
,
and
placed
negligently
on
the
left
side
of
his
head
.
<EOS>
His
figure
was
slight
,
but
extremely
well
formed
;
and
his
features
might
have
been
termed
handsome
,
but
for
their
reckless
and
licentious
expression
.
<EOS>
He
was
addressed
by
his
companions
as
Sir
Paul
Parravicin
.
 
<EOS>
The
person
opposite
to
him
,
whose
name
was
Disbrowe
,
and
who
was
likewise
a
very
handsome
young
man
,
though
his
features
were
flushed
and
disturbed
,
partly
by
the
wine
he
had
drunk
,
and
partly
by
his
losses
at
play
,
was
equipped
in
the
splendid
accoutrements
of
a
captain
in
the
king
's
body
-
guard
.
<EOS>
His
left
hand
convulsively
clutched
an
empty
purse
,
and
his
eyes
were
fixed
upon
a
large
sum
of
money
,
which
he
had
just
handed
over
to
the
knight
,
and
which
the
latter
was
carelessly
transferring
to
his
pocket
.
 
<EOS>
The
last
of
the
three
,
whose
looks
betrayed
his
character
--
that
of
a
sharper
and
a
bully
--
called
himself
Major
Pillichody
,
his
pretensions
to
military
rank
being
grounded
upon
his
service
<EOS>
(
so
ran
his
own
statement
,
though
it
was
never
clearly
substantiated
)
in
the
king
's
army
during
the
civil
wars
.
<EOS>
Major
Pillichody
was
a
man
of
remarkably
fierce
exterior
.
<EOS>
Seamed
with
many
scars
,
and
destitute
of
the
left
eye
,
the
orifice
of
which
was
covered
,
with
a
huge
black
patch
;
his
face
was
of
a
deep
mulberry
colour
,
clearly
attesting
his
devotion
to
the
bottle
;
while
his
nose
,
which
was
none
of
the
smallest
,
was
covered
with
"
bubukles
,
and
whelks
,
and
knobs
,
and
flames
of
fire
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He
was
of
the
middle
size
,
stoutly
built
,
and
given
to
corpulency
,
though
not
so
much
so
as
to
impair
his
activity
.
<EOS>
His
attire
consisted
of
a
cloak
and
doublet
of
scarlet
cloth
,
very
much
stained
and
tarnished
,
and
edged
with
gold
lace
,
likewise
the
worse
for
wear
;
jack
-
boots
,
with
huge
funnel
tops
;
spurs
,
with
enormous
rowels
,
and
a
rapier
of
preposterous
length
.
<EOS>
He
wore
his
own
hair
,
which
was
swart
and
woolly
,
like
that
of
a
negro
;
and
had
beard
and
moustaches
to
match
.
<EOS>
His
hat
was
fiercely
cocked
;
his
gestures
swaggering
and
insolent
;
and
he
was
perpetually
racking
his
brain
to
invent
new
and
extra
-
ordinary
oaths
.
 
<EOS>
"
So
soon
returned
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Parravicin
,
as
Wyvil
appeared
.
<EOS>
"
Accept
my
congratulations
?
"
 
"
And
mine
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Pillichody
.
<EOS>
"
We
wild
fellows
have
but
to
be
seen
to
conquer
.
<EOS>
Sugar
and
spice
,
and
all
that
's
nice
!
"
<EOS>
he
added
,
smacking
his
lips
,
as
he
filled
a
glass
from
a
long
-
necked
bottle
on
the
table
;
"
May
the
grocer
's
daughter
prove
sweeter
than
her
father
's
plums
,
and
more
melting
than
his
butter
!
<EOS>
Is
she
without
?
<EOS>
Are
we
to
see
her
?
"
 
<EOS>
Wyvil
made
no
answer
,
but
,
walking
to
the
other
end
of
the
room
,
threw
himself
into
a
chair
,
and
,
covering
his
face
with
his
hands
,
appeared
wrapped
in
thought
.
<EOS>
Lydyard
took
a
seat
beside
him
,
and
endeavoured
to
engage
him
in
conversation
;
but
,
finding
his
efforts
fruitless
,
he
desisted
.
 
<EOS>
"
Something
is
wrong
,
"
observed
Parravicin
,
to
the
major
.
"
<EOS>
He
has
been
foiled
in
his
attempt
to
carry
off
the
girl
.
<EOS>
Sedley
has
won
his
wager
,
and
it
is
a
heavy
sum
.
<EOS>
Shall
we
resume
our
play
?
"
<EOS>
he
added
,
to
Disbrowe
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
nothing
more
to
lose
,
"
observed
the
young
man
,
filling
a
large
goblet
to
the
brim
,
and
emptying
it
at
a
draught
.
<EOS>
"
You
are
master
of
every
farthing
I
possess
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Hum
!
"
exclaimed
Parravicin
,
taking
up
a
pack
of
cards
,
and
snapping
them
between
his
finger
and
thumb
.
<EOS>
"
You
are
married
,
Captain
Disbrowe
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
What
if
I
am
?
"
cried
the
young
man
,
becoming
suddenly
pale
;
"
what
if
I
am
?
"
<EOS>
he
repeated
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
told
your
wife
is
beautiful
,
"
replied
Parravicin
.
 
<EOS>
"
Beautiful
!
"
<EOS>
ejaculated
Pillichody
;
"
by
the
well
-
filled
coffers
of
the
widow
of
Watling
-
street
!
<EOS>
she
is
an
angel
.
<EOS>
Beautiful
is
not
the
word
:
Mrs.
Disbrowe
is
divine
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
have
never
seen
her
,
"
said
the
young
man
,
sternly
.
 
<EOS>
"
Ha!--fire
and
fury
!
<EOS>
my
word
doubted
,
"
cried
the
major
,
fiercely
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
seen
her
at
the
play
-
houses
,
at
the
Mulberry
-
garden
,
at
court
,
and
at
church
.
<EOS>
Not
seen
her
!
<EOS>
By
the
one
eye
of
a
Cyclops
,
but
I
have
!
<EOS>
You
shall
hear
my
description
of
her
,
and
judge
of
its
correctness
.
<EOS>
_
Imprimis
_
,
she
has
a
tall
and
majestic
figure
,
and
might
be
a
queen
for
her
dignity
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Go
on
,
"
said
Disbrowe
,
by
no
means
displeased
with
the
commencement
.
 
<EOS>
"
Secondly
,
"
pursued
Pillichody
,
"
she
has
a
clear
olive
complexion
,
bright
black
eyes
,
hair
and
brows
to
match
,
a
small
foot
,
a
pretty
turn
-
up
nose
,
a
dimpling
cheek
,
a
mole
upon
her
throat
,
the
rosiest
lips
imaginable
,
an
alluring
look--
"
 
"
No
more
,
"
interrupted
Disbrowe
.
<EOS>
"
It
is
plain
you
have
never
seen
her
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Unbelieving
pagan
!
<EOS>
"
exclaimed
the
major
,
clapping
his
hand
furiously
upon
his
sword
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
done
more
--
I
have
spoken
with
her
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
A
lie
!
"
<EOS>
replied
Disbrowe
,
hurling
a
dice
-
box
at
his
head
.
 
<EOS>
"
Ha
!
"
roared
Pillichody
,
in
a
voice
of
thunder
,
and
pushing
back
his
chair
till
it
was
stopped
by
the
wall
.
"
Death
and
fiends
!
<EOS>
I
will
make
mincemeat
of
your
heart
,
and
send
it
as
a
love
-
offering
to
your
wife
.
"
 
<EOS>
And
,
whipping
out
his
long
rapier
,
he
would
have
assaulted
Disbrowe
,
if
Sir
Paul
had
not
interposed
,
and
commanded
him
authoritatively
to
put
up
his
blade
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
shall
have
your
revenge
in
a
safer
way
,
"
he
whispered
.
 
<EOS>
"
Well
,
Sir
Paul
,
"
rejoined
the
bully
,
with
affected
reluctance
,
"
as
you
desire
it
,
I
will
spare
the
young
man
's
life
.
<EOS>
I
must
wash
away
the
insult
in
burgundy
,
since
I
can
not
do
so
in
blood
.
"
 
<EOS>
With
this
,
he
emptied
the
flask
next
him
,
and
called
to
a
drawer
,
who
was
in
attendance
,
in
an
imperious
tone
,
to
bring
two
more
bottles
.
 
<EOS>
Parravicin
,
meanwhile
,
picked
up
the
dice
-
box
,
and
,
seating
himself
,
spread
a
large
heap
of
gold
on
the
table
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
mentioned
your
wife
,
Captain
Disbrowe
,
"
he
said
,
addressing
the
young
officer
,
who
anxiously
watched
his
movements
,
"
not
with
any
intention
of
giving
you
offence
,
but
to
show
you
that
,
although
you
have
lost
your
money
,
you
have
still
a
valuable
stake
left
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
do
not
understand
you
,
Sir
Paul
,
"
returned
Disbrowe
,
with
a
look
of
indignant
surprise
.
 
<EOS>
"
To
be
plain
<EOS>
,
then
,
"
replied
Parravicin
,
"
I
have
won
from
you
two
hundred
pounds
--
all
you
possess
.
<EOS>
You
are
a
ruined
man
,
and
,
as
such
,
will
run
any
hazard
to
retrieve
your
losses
.
<EOS>
I
give
you
a
last
chance
.
<EOS>
I
will
stake
all
my
winnings
,
nay
,
double
the
amount
,
against
your
wife
.
<EOS>
You
have
a
key
of
the
house
you
inhabit
,
by
which
you
admit
yourself
at
all
hours
;
so
at
least
the
major
informs
me
.
<EOS>
If
I
win
,
that
key
shall
be
mine
.
<EOS>
I
will
take
my
chance
for
the
rest
.
<EOS>
Do
you
understand
me
now
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
do
,
"
replied
the
young
man
,
with
concentrated
fury
.
<EOS>
"
I
understand
that
you
are
a
villain
.
<EOS>
You
have
robbed
me
of
my
money
,
and
would
rob
me
of
my
honour
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
These
are
harsh
words
,
sir
,
"
replied
the
knight
,
calmly
;
"
but
let
them
pass
.
<EOS>
We
will
play
first
,
and
fight
afterwards
.
<EOS>
But
you
refuse
my
challenge
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
false
!
"
<EOS>
replied
Disbrowe
,
fiercely
<EOS>
,
"
I
accept
it
.
"
<EOS>
And
producing
a
key
,
he
threw
it
on
the
table
.
<EOS>
"
My
life
is
,
in
truth
,
set
on
the
die
,
"
he
added
,
with
a
desperate
look--"for
if
I
lose
,
I
will
not
survive
my
shame
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
will
not
forget
our
terms
,
"
observed
Parravicin
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
to
be
your
representative
to
-
night
.
<EOS>
You
can
return
home
to
-
morrow
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Throw
,
sir
--
throw
,
"
cried
the
young
man
,
fiercely
.
 
<EOS>
"
Pardon
,
me
,
"
replied
the
knight
;
"
the
first
cast
is
with
you
.
<EOS>
A
single
main
decides
it
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Be
it
so
,
"
returned
Disbrowe
,
seizing
the
box
.
<EOS>
And
as
he
shook
the
dice
with
a
frenzied
air
,
the
major
and
Lydyard
drew
near
the
table
,
and
even
Wyvil
roused
himself
to
watch
the
result
.
 
<EOS>
"
Twelve
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Disbrowe
,
as
he
removed
the
box
.
<EOS>
"
My
honour
is
saved
!
<EOS>
My
fortune
retrieved
--
Huzza
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
Not
so
fast
,
"
returned
Parravicin
,
shaking
the
box
in
his
turn
.
<EOS>
"
You
were
a
little
too
hasty
,
"
he
added
,
uncovering
the
dice
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
twelve
,
too
.
<EOS>
We
must
throw
again
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
This
to
decide
,
"
cried
the
young
officer
,
again
rattling
the
dice
.
<EOS>
"
Six
!
"
 
<EOS>
Parravicin
smiled
,
took
the
box
,
and
threw
ten
.
 
<EOS>
"
Perdition
!
"
<EOS>
ejaculated
Disbrowe
,
striking
his
brow
with
his
clenched
hand
.
<EOS>
"
What
devil
tempted
me
to
my
undoing?--My
wife
trusted
to
this
profligate
!
<EOS>
Horror!--it
must
not
be
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
too
late
to
retract
,
"
replied
Parravicin
,
taking
up
the
key
,
and
turning
with
a
triumphant
look
to
his
friends
.
 
<EOS>
Disbrowe
noticed
the
smile
,
and
stung
beyond
endurance
,
drew
his
sword
,
and
called
to
the
knight
to
defend
himself
.
 
<EOS>
In
an
instant
,
passes
were
exchanged
.
<EOS>
But
the
conflict
was
brief
.
<EOS>
Fortune
,
as
before
,
declared
herself
in
favour
of
Parravicin
.
<EOS>
He
disarmed
his
assailant
,
who
rushed
out
of
the
room
,
uttering
the
wildest
ejaculations
of
rage
and
despair
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
told
you
you
should
have
your
revenge
,
"
observed
the
knight
to
Pillichody
,
as
soon
as
Disbrowe
was
gone
.
"
<EOS>
Is
his
wife
really
as
beautiful
as
you
represent
her
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
Words
are
too
feeble
to
paint
her
charms
,
"
replied
the
major
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Shafts
of
Cupid
!
<EOS>
she
must
be
seen
to
be
appreciated
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Enough
!
"
returned
Parravicin
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
not
made
a
bad
night
's
work
of
it
,
so
far
.
<EOS>
I'faith
,
Wyvil
,
I
pity
you
.
<EOS>
To
lose
a
heavy
wager
is
provoking
enough
--
but
to
lose
a
pretty
mistress
is
the
devil
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
lost
neither
yet
,
"
replied
Wyvil
,
who
had
completely
recovered
his
spirits
,
and
joined
in
the
general
merriment
occasioned
by
the
foregoing
occurrence
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
been
baffled
,
not
defeated
.
<EOS>
What
say
you
to
an
exchange
of
mistresses
?
<EOS>
I
am
so
diverted
with
your
adventure
,
that
I
am
half
inclined
to
give
you
the
grocer
's
daughter
for
Disbrowe
's
wife
.
<EOS>
She
is
a
superb
creature
--
languid
as
a
Circassian
,
and
passionate
as
an
Andalusian
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
ca
n't
agree
to
the
exchange
,
especially
after
your
rapturous
description
,
"
returned
Parravicin
,
"
but
I
'll
stake
Mrs.
Disbrowe
against
Amabel
.
<EOS>
The
winner
shall
have
both
.
<EOS>
A
single
cast
shall
decide
,
as
before
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
replied
Wyvil
,
"
I
could
not
resign
Amabel
,
if
I
lost
.
<EOS>
And
the
luck
is
all
on
your
side
to
-
night
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
As
you
please
,
"
rejoined
the
knight
,
sweeping
the
glittering
pile
into
his
pocket
.
<EOS>
"
Drawer
,
another
bottle
of
burgundy
.
<EOS>
A
health
to
our
mistresses
!
"
<EOS>
he
added
,
quaffing
a
brimmer
.
 
<EOS>
"
A
health
to
the
grocer
's
daughter
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Wyvil
,
with
difficulty
repressing
a
shudder
,
as
he
uttered
the
pledge
.
 
<EOS>
"
A
health
to
the
rich
widow
of
Watling
-
street
,
"
cried
Pillichody
,
draining
a
bumper
,
"
and
may
I
soon
call
her
mine
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
no
mistress
to
toast
,
"
said
Lydyard
;
"
and
I
have
drunk
wine
enough
.
<EOS>
Do
not
forget
,
gentlemen
,
that
the
plague
is
abroad
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
are
the
death's
-
head
at
the
feast
,
Lydyard
,
"
rejoined
Parravicin
,
setting
down
his
glass
.
<EOS>
"
I
hate
the
idea
of
the
plague
.
<EOS>
It
poisons
all
our
pleasures
.
<EOS>
We
must
meet
at
noon
to
-
morrow
,
at
the
Smyrna
,
to
compare
notes
as
to
our
successes
.
<EOS>
Before
we
separate
,
can
I
be
of
any
further
service
to
you
,
Wyvil
?
<EOS>
I
came
here
to
enjoy
_
your
_
triumph
;
but
,
egad
,
I
have
found
so
admirable
a
bubble
in
that
hot
-
headed
Disbrowe
,
whom
I
met
at
the
Smyrna
,
and
brought
here
to
while
away
the
time
,
that
I
must
demand
your
congratulations
upon
_
mine
_
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
have
certainly
achieved
an
easy
victory
over
the
husband
,
"
returned
Wyvil
;
"
and
I
trust
your
success
with
the
wife
will
be
commensurate
.
<EOS>
I
require
no
further
assistance
.
<EOS>
What
I
have
to
do
must
be
done
alone
.
<EOS>
Lydyard
will
accompany
me
to
the
house
,
and
then
I
must
shift
for
myself
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Nay
,
we
will
all
see
you
safe
inside
,
"
returned
Parravicin
,
"
We
shall
pass
by
the
grocer
's
shop
.
<EOS>
I
know
it
well
,
having
passed
it
a
hundred
times
,
in
the
vain
hope
of
catching
a
glimpse
of
its
lovely
inmate
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
glad
it
_
was
_
a
vain
hope
,
"
replied
Wyvil
.
<EOS>
"
But
I
must
scale
a
wall
to
surprise
the
garrison
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
In
that
case
you
will
need
the
rope
-
ladder
,
"
replied
Lydyard
;
"
it
is
in
readiness
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
will
carry
it
,
"
said
Pillichody
,
picking
up
the
ladder
which
was
lying
in
a
corner
of
the
room
,
and
throwing
it
over
his
shoulders
.
<EOS>
"
Bombs
and
batteries
!
<EOS>
I
like
to
be
an
escalader
when
the
forts
of
love
are
stormed
.
"
 
<EOS>
The
party
then
set
out
.
<EOS>
As
they
proceeded
,
Parravicin
ascertained
from
the
major
that
Disbrowe
's
house
was
situated
in
a
small
street
leading
out
of
Piccadilly
,
but
as
he
could
not
be
quite
sure
that
he
understood
his
informant
aright
,
he
engaged
him
to
accompany
him
and
point
it
out
.
 
<EOS>
By
this
time
they
had
reached
Wood
-
street
,
and
keeping
in
the
shade
,
reconnoitred
the
house
.
<EOS>
But
though
Wyvil
clapped
his
hands
,
blew
a
shrill
whistle
,
and
made
other
signals
,
no
answer
was
returned
,
nor
was
a
light
seen
at
any
of
the
upper
windows
.
<EOS>
On
the
contrary
,
all
was
still
and
silent
as
death
.
 
<EOS>
The
grocer
's
was
a
large
,
old
-
fashioned
house
,
built
about
the
middle
of
the
preceding
century
,
or
perhaps
earlier
,
and
had
four
stories
,
each
projecting
over
the
other
,
till
the
pile
seemed
completely
to
overhang
the
street
.
<EOS>
The
entire
front
,
except
the
upper
story
,
which
was
protected
by
oaken
planks
,
was
covered
with
panels
of
the
same
timber
,
and
the
projections
were
supported
by
heavy
beams
,
embellished
with
grotesque
carvings
.
<EOS>
Three
deeply
-
embayed
windows
,
having
stout
wooden
bars
,
filled
with
minute
diamond
panes
,
set
in
leaden
frames
,
were
allotted
to
each
floor
;
while
the
like
number
of
gables
,
ornamented
with
curiously
-
carved
coignes
,
and
long
-
moulded
leaden
spouts
,
shooting
far
into
the
street
,
finished
the
roof
.
<EOS>
A
huge
sign
,
with
the
device
of
Noah
's
Ark
,
and
the
owner
's
name
upon
it
,
hung
before
the
door
.
 
<EOS>
After
carefully
examining
the
house
,
peeping
through
the
chinks
in
the
lower
shutters
,
and
discovering
the
grocer
seated
by
the
bedside
of
his
son
,
though
he
could
not
make
out
the
object
of
his
solicitude
,
Wyvil
decided
upon
attempting
an
entrance
by
the
backyard
.
<EOS>
To
reach
it
,
a
court
and
a
narrow
alley
,
leading
to
an
open
space
surrounded
by
high
walls
,
had
to
be
traversed
.
<EOS>
Arrived
at
this
spot
,
Wyvil
threw
one
end
of
the
rope
ladder
over
the
wall
,
which
was
about
twelve
feet
high
,
and
speedily
succeeding
in
securing
it
,
mounted
,
and
drawing
it
up
after
him
,
waved
his
hand
to
his
companions
,
and
disappeared
on
the
other
side
.
<EOS>
After
waiting
for
a
moment
to
listen
,
and
hearing
a
window
open
,
they
concluded
he
had
gained
admittance
,
and
turned
to
depart
.
 
<EOS>
"
And
now
for
Mrs.
Disbrowe
!
"
cried
Parravicin
.
<EOS>
"
We
shall
find
a
coach
or
a
chair
in
Cheapside
.
<EOS>
Can
I
take
you
westward
,
Lydyard
?
"
 
<EOS>
But
the
other
declined
the
offer
,
saying
,
"
I
will
not
desert
Wyvil
.
<EOS>
I
feel
certain
he
will
get
into
some
scrape
,
and
may
need
me
to
help
him
out
of
it
.
<EOS>
Take
care
of
yourself
,
Parravicin
.
<EOS>
Beware
of
the
plague
,
and
of
what
is
worse
than
the
plague
,
an
injured
husband
.
<EOS>
Good
-
night
,
major
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Farewell
,
sir
,
"
returned
Pillichody
,
raising
his
hat
.
"
<EOS>
A
merry
watching
,
and
a
good
catching
,
as
the
sentinels
were
wo
nt
to
say
,
when
I
served
King
Charles
the
First
.
<EOS>
Sir
Paul
,
I
attend
you
.
"
  
<EOS>
IV
.
 
<EOS>
THE
INTERVIEW
.
 
<EOS>
Maurice
Wyvil
,
as
his
friends
conjectured
,
had
found
his
way
into
the
house
.
<EOS>
Creeping
through
the
window
,
and
entering
a
passage
,
he
moved
noiselessly
along
till
he
reached
the
head
of
the
kitchen
stairs
,
where
,
hearing
voices
below
,
and
listening
to
what
was
said
,
he
soon
ascertained
from
the
discourse
of
the
speakers
,
who
were
no
other
than
old
Josyna
and
Patience
,
that
it
was
not
the
grocer
's
daughter
,
but
one
of
his
sons
,
who
was
attacked
by
the
plague
,
and
that
Amabel
was
in
perfect
health
,
though
confined
in
her
mother
's
bedroom
.
 
<EOS>
Overjoyed
at
the
information
he
had
thus
acquired
,
he
retired
as
noiselessly
as
he
came
,
and
after
searching
about
for
a
short
time
,
discovered
the
main
staircase
,
and
ascended
it
on
the
points
of
his
feet
.
<EOS>
He
had
scarcely
,
however
,
mounted
a
dozen
steps
,
when
a
door
opened
,
and
Blaize
crawled
along
the
passage
,
groaning
to
himself
,
and
keeping
his
eyes
bent
on
the
ground
.
<EOS>
Seeing
he
was
unnoticed
,
Wyvil
gained
the
landing
,
and
treading
softly
,
placed
his
ear
at
every
door
,
until
at
last
the
musical
accents
of
Amabel
convinced
him
he
had
hit
upon
the
right
one
.
 
<EOS>
His
heart
beat
so
violently
that
,
for
a
few
seconds
,
he
was
unable
to
move
.
<EOS>
Becoming
calmer
,
he
tried
the
door
,
and
finding
it
locked
,
rapped
with
his
knuckles
against
it
.
<EOS>
The
grocer
's
wife
demanded
who
was
there
.
<EOS>
But
Wyvil
,
instead
of
returning
an
answer
,
repeated
his
application
.
<EOS>
The
same
demand
followed
,
and
in
a
louder
key
.
<EOS>
Still
no
answer
.
<EOS>
A
third
summons
,
however
,
so
alarmed
Mrs.
Bloundel
,
that
,
forgetful
of
her
husband
's
injunctions
,
she
opened
the
door
and
looked
out
;
but
,
as
Wyvil
had
hastily
retired
into
a
recess
,
she
could
see
no
one
.
 
<EOS>
Greatly
frightened
and
perplexed
,
Mrs.
Bloundel
rushed
to
the
head
of
the
stairs
,
to
see
whether
there
was
any
one
below
;
and
as
she
did
so
,
Wyvil
slipped
into
the
room
,
and
locked
the
door
.
<EOS>
The
only
object
he
beheld
--
for
he
had
eyes
for
nothing
else
--
was
Amabel
,
who
,
seeing
him
,
uttered
a
faint
scream
.
<EOS>
Clasping
her
in
his
arms
,
Wyvil
forgot
,
in
the
delirium
of
the
moment
,
the
jeopardy
in
which
he
was
placed
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
you
know
what
has
happened
?
"
cried
Amabel
,
extricating
herself
from
his
embrace
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
know
all
,
"
replied
her
lover
;
"
I
would
risk
a
thousand
deaths
for
your
sake
.
<EOS>
You
must
fly
with
me
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Fly
!
"
exclaimed
Amabel
;
"
at
such
a
time
as
this?--my
brother
dying
--
the
whole
house
,
perhaps
,
infected
!
<EOS>
How
can
you
ask
me
to
fly
?
<EOS>
Why
have
you
come
hither
?
<EOS>
You
will
destroy
me
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Not
so
,
sweet
Amabel
,
"
replied
Wyvil
,
ardently
.
<EOS>
"
I
would
bear
you
from
the
reach
of
this
horrible
disease
.
<EOS>
I
am
come
to
save
you
,
and
will
not
stir
without
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
What
shall
I
do
?
"
<EOS>
cried
Amabel
,
distractedly
.
<EOS>
"
But
I
am
rightly
punished
for
my
disobedience
and
ingratitude
to
my
dear
father
.
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
Wyvil
,
I
did
not
deserve
this
from
you
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Hear
me
,
Amabel
,
"
cried
her
lover
;
"
I
implore
your
forgiveness
.
<EOS>
What
I
have
done
has
been
from
irresistible
passion
,
and
from
no
other
cause
.
<EOS>
You
promised
to
meet
me
to
-
night
.
<EOS>
Nay
,
you
half
consented
to
fly
with
me
.
<EOS>
I
have
prepared
all
for
it
.
<EOS>
I
came
hither
burning
with
impatience
for
the
meeting
.
<EOS>
I
received
no
signal
,
but
encountering
your
father
's
apprentice
,
was
informed
that
you
were
attacked
by
the
plague
.
<EOS>
Imagine
my
horror
and
distress
at
the
intelligence
.
<EOS>
I
thought
it
would
have
killed
me
.
<EOS>
I
determined
,
however
,
at
all
risks
,
to
see
you
once
more
--
to
clasp
you
in
my
arms
before
you
died
--
to
die
with
you
,
if
need
be
.
<EOS>
I
accomplished
my
purpose
.
<EOS>
I
entered
the
house
unobserved
.
<EOS>
I
overheard
the
servants
<EOS>
say
it
was
your
brother
who
was
ill
,
not
you
.
<EOS>
I
also
learnt
that
you
were
in
your
mother
's
room
.
<EOS>
I
found
the
door
,
and
by
a
fortunate
device
,
obtained
admittance
.
<EOS>
Now
you
know
all
,
and
will
you
not
fly
with
me
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
How
_
can
_
I
fly
?
"
<EOS>
cried
Amabel
,
gazing
wildly
round
the
room
,
as
if
in
search
of
some
place
of
refuge
or
escape
,
and
,
noticing
her
little
sister
,
Christiana
,
who
was
lying
asleep
in
the
bed--"Oh
!
<EOS>
how
I
envy
that
innocent
!
"
<EOS>
she
murmured
.
 
<EOS>
"
Think
of
nothing
but
yourself
,
"
rejoined
Wyvil
,
seizing
her
hand
.
<EOS>
"
If
you
stay
here
,
it
will
be
to
perish
of
the
plague
.
<EOS>
Trust
to
me
,
and
I
will
secure
your
flight
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
cannot
--
I
dare
not
,
"
cried
Amabel
,
resisting
him
with
all
her
force
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
_
must
_
come
,
"
cried
Wyvil
,
dragging
her
along
.
 
<EOS>
As
he
spoke
,
Mrs.
Bloundel
,
who
had
been
down
to
Blaize
's
room
to
ascertain
what
was
the
matter
,
returned
.
<EOS>
Trying
the
door
,
and
finding
it
fastened
,
she
became
greatly
alarmed
,
and
called
to
Amabel
to
open
it
directly
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
my
mother
,
"
cried
Amabel
.
"
<EOS>
Pity
me
,
Heaven
!
<EOS>
I
shall
die
with
shame
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Heed
her
not
,
"
replied
Wyvil
,
in
a
deep
whisper
;
"
in
her
surprise
and
confusion
at
seeing
me
,
she
will
not
be
able
to
stop
us
.
<EOS>
Do
not
hesitate
.
<EOS>
There
is
not
a
moment
to
lose
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
What
is
the
matter
,
child
?
"
cried
Mrs.
Bloundel
.
<EOS>
"
Why
have
you
fastened
the
door
?
<EOS>
Is
there
any
one
in
the
room
with
you
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
She
hears
us
,
"
whispered
Amabel
.
<EOS>
"
What
shall
I
do
?
<EOS>
You
must
not
be
seen
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
There
is
no
use
in
further
concealment
,
"
cried
Wyvil
.
<EOS>
"
You
are
mine
,
and
twenty
mothers
should
not
bar
the
way
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Hold
!
"
cried
Amabel
,
disengaging
herself
by
a
sudden
effort
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
gone
too
far
--
but
not
so
far
as
you
imagine
.
<EOS>
I
am
not
utterly
lost
.
"
 
<EOS>
And
before
she
could
be
prevented
,
she
rushed
to
the
door
,
threw
it
open
,
and
flung
herself
into
her
mother
's
arms
,
who
uttered
an
exclamation
of
terror
at
beholding
Wyvil
.
<EOS>
The
latter
,
though
filled
with
rage
and
confusion
,
preserved
an
unmoved
exterior
,
and
folded
his
arms
upon
his
breast
.
 
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
so
it
was
you
who
knocked
at
the
door
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Mrs.
Bloundel
,
regarding
the
gallant
with
a
look
of
fury--"it
<EOS>
was
you
who
contrived
to
delude
me
into
opening
it
!
<EOS>
I
do
not
ask
why
you
have
come
hither
like
a
thief
in
the
night
,
because
I
require
no
information
on
the
subject
.
<EOS>
You
are
come
to
dishonour
my
child
--
to
carry
her
away
from
those
who
love
her
and
cherish
her
,
and
would
preserve
her
from
such
mischievous
serpents
as
you
.
<EOS>
But
,
Heaven
be
praised
!
<EOS>
I
have
caught
you
before
your
wicked
design
could
Be
effected
.
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
Amabel
,
my
child
,
my
child
!
"
<EOS>
she
added
,
straining
her
to
her
bosom
,
"
I
had
rather
--
far
rather
--
<EOS>
see
you
stricken
with
the
plague
,
like
your
poor
brother
,
though
I
felt
there
was
not
a
hope
of
your
recovery
,
than
you
should
fall
into
the
hands
of
this
Satan
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
been
greatly
to
blame
,
dear
mother
,
"
returned
Amabel
,
bursting
into
tears
;
"
and
I
shall
neither
seek
to
exculpate
myself
,
nor
conceal
what
I
have
done
.
<EOS>
I
have
deceived
you
and
my
father
.
<EOS>
I
have
secretly
encouraged
the
addresses
of
this
gentleman
.
<EOS>
Nay
,
if
the
plague
had
not
broken
out
in
our
house
to
-
night
,
I
should
have
flown
from
it
with
him
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
shock
me
,
greatly
,
child
,
"
returned
Mrs.
Bloundel
;
"
but
you
relieve
me
at
the
same
time
.
<EOS>
Make
a
clean
breast
,
and
hide
nothing
from
me
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
nothing
more
to
tell
,
dear
mother
,
"
replied
Amabel
,
"
except
that
Maurice
Wyvil
has
been
in
the
room
ever
since
you
left
it
,
and
might
,
perhaps
,
have
carried
me
off
in
spite
of
my
resistance
,
if
you
had
not
returned
when
you
did
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
was
,
indeed
,
a
providential
interference
,
"
rejoined
Mrs.
Bloundel
.
<EOS>
"
From
what
a
snare
of
the
evil
one
--
from
what
a
pitfall
have
you
been
preserved
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
feel
I
have
had
a
narrow
escape
,
dear
mother
,
"
replied
Amabel
.
"
<EOS>
Pardon
me
.
<EOS>
I
do
not
deserve
your
forgiveness
.
<EOS>
But
I
will
never
offend
you
more
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
forgive
you
from
my
heart
,
child
,
and
will
trust
you
,
"
returned
Mrs.
Bloundel
,
in
a
voice
broken
by
emotion
.
 
<EOS>
"
That
is
more
than
I
would
,
"
thought
Maurice
Wyvil
.
<EOS>
"
A
woman
who
has
once
deceived
those
she
holds
dear
,
will
not
fail
to
do
so
a
second
time
.
<EOS>
The
fairest
promises
are
forgotten
when
the
danger
is
past
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Mr.
Wyvil
,
if
you
have
a
particle
of
regard
for
me
,
you
will
instantly
leave
the
house
,
"
said
Amabel
,
turning
to
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
If
had
my
own
way
,
he
should
leave
it
through
the
window
,
"
said
Mrs.
Bloundel
;
"
and
if
he
tarries
a
minute
longer
,
I
will
give
the
alarm
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
hear
this
,
sir
,
"
cried
Amabel:--"go
,
I
entreat
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
yield
to
circumstance
,
Amabel
,
"
replied
Wyvil
;
"
but
think
not
I
resign
you
.
<EOS>
Come
what
will
,
and
however
I
may
be
foiled
,
I
will
not
desist
till
I
make
you
mine
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
tremble
to
hear
him
,
"
cried
Mrs.
Bloundel
,
"
and
could
not
have
believed
such
depravity
existed
.
<EOS>
Quit
the
house
,
sir
,
directly
,
or
I
will
have
you
turned
out
of
it
.
<EOS>
"
 
"
Do
not
remain
another
moment
,
"
implored
Amabel
.
<EOS>
"
Do
not
,
do
not
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
Since
I
have
no
other
way
of
proving
my
love
,
I
must
perforce
obey
,
"
returned
Wyvil
,
trying
to
snatch
her
hand
and
press
it
to
his
lips
;
but
she
withdrew
it
,
and
clung
more
closely
to
her
mother
.
<EOS>
"
We
part
,
"
he
added
,
significantly
,
"
only
for
a
time
.
"
 
<EOS>
Quitting
the
room
,
he
was
about
to
descend
the
stairs
,
when
Mrs.
Bloundel
,
who
had
followed
to
see
him
safely
off
the
premises
,
hearing
a
noise
below
,
occasioned
by
the
return
of
Leonard
with
the
doctor
,
cautioned
him
to
wait
.
<EOS>
A
further
delay
was
caused
by
Blaize
,
who
,
stationing
himself
at
the
foot
of
the
stairs
,
with
a
light
in
his
hand
,
appeared
unwilling
to
move
.
<EOS>
Apprehensive
of
a
discovery
,
Mrs.
Bloundel
then
directed
the
gallant
to
the
back
staircase
,
and
he
had
got
about
halfway
down
,
when
he
was
surprised
by
Leonard
Holt
,
as
before
related
.
 
<EOS>
At
the
very
moment
that
Wyvil
was
overtaken
on
the
landing
by
the
apprentice
,
Amabel
appeared
at
the
door
of
her
chamber
with
a
light
.
<EOS>
The
different
emotions
of
each
party
at
this
unexpected
rencontre
may
be
imagined
.
<EOS>
Leonard
Holt
,
with
a
breast
boiling
with
jealous
rage
,
prepared
to
attack
his
rival
.
<EOS>
He
had
no
weapon
about
him
,
having
left
his
cudgel
in
the
shop
,
but
he
doubled
his
fists
,
and
,
nerved
by
passion
,
felt
he
had
the
force
of
a
Hercules
in
his
arm
.
<EOS>
Wyvil
,
in
his
turn
,
kept
his
hand
upon
his
sword
,
and
glanced
at
his
mistress
,
as
if
seeking
instructions
how
to
act
.
<EOS>
At
length
,
Mrs.
Bloundel
,
who
formed
one
of
the
group
,
spoke
.
 
<EOS>
"
Leonard
Holt
,
"
she
said
,
"
show
this
person
out
at
the
door
.
<EOS>
Do
not
lose
sight
of
him
for
an
instant
;
and
,
as
soon
as
he
is
gone
,
try
to
find
out
how
he
entered
the
house
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
He
entered
it
like
a
robber
,
"
returned
Leonard
,
looking
fiercely
at
the
gallant
,
"
and
if
I
did
my
strict
duty
,
I
should
seize
him
and
give
him
in
charge
to
the
watch
.
<EOS>
He
has
come
here
for
the
purpose
of
stealing
my
master
's
chief
valuable
--
his
daughter
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
aware
of
it
,
"
replied
Mrs.
Bloundel
,
"
and
nothing
but
consideration
for
my
husband
prevents
my
delivering
him
up
to
justice
.
<EOS>
As
it
is
,
he
may
go
free
.
<EOS>
But
should
he
return--
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
If
I
catch
him
here
again
,
"
interrupted
Leonard
,
"
I
will
shoot
him
as
I
would
a
dog
,
though
I
should
be
hanged
for
the
deed
.
<EOS>
Have
you
considered
well
what
you
are
doing
,
madam
?
<EOS>
I
would
not
presume
beyond
my
station
,
but
there
are
seasons
when
an
inferior
may
give
wholesome
advice
.
<EOS>
Are
you
certain
you
are
acting
as
your
worthy
husband
<EOS>
would
,
in
allowing
this
person
to
depart
?
<EOS>
If
you
have
any
doubt
,
speak
.
<EOS>
Fear
nothing
.
<EOS>
Unarmed
as
I
am
,
I
am
a
match
for
him
,
and
will
detain
him
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Do
not
heed
what
Leonard
says
,
dear
mother
,
"
interposed
Amabel
.
"
<EOS>
For
my
sake
,
let
Mr.
Wyvil
go
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
_
have
<EOS>
_
considered
the
matter
,
Leonard
,
"
returned
Mrs.
Bloundel
,
"
and
trust
I
am
acting
rightly
.
<EOS>
At
all
events
,
I
am
sure
I
am
sparing
my
husband
pain
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
mistaken
tenderness
,
"
rejoined
Leonard
,
"
and
Heaven
grant
<EOS>
you
may
not
have
cause
to
repent
it
.
<EOS>
If
I
had
your
permission
,
I
would
so
deal
with
this
audacious
intruder
,
that
he
should
never
venture
to
repeat
his
visit
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
know
that
you
speak
safely
,
fellow
,
"
rejoined
Wyvil
,
"
and
you
,
therefore
,
give
full
license
to
your
scurrile
tongue
.
<EOS>
But
a
time
will
come
when
I
will
chastise
your
insolence
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
No
more
of
this
,
"
cried
Mrs.
Bloundel
.
<EOS>
"
Do
as
I
bid
you
,
Leonard
;
and
,
as
you
value
my
regard
,
say
nothing
of
what
has
occurred
to
your
master
.
"
 
<EOS>
Sullenly
acquiescing
,
the
apprentice
preceded
Wyvil
to
the
shop
,
and
opened
the
door
.
 
<EOS>
As
the
other
passed
through
it
,
he
said
,
"
You
spoke
of
chastising
me
just
now
.
<EOS>
If
you
have
courage
enough
--
which
I
doubt
--
to
make
good
your
words
,
and
will
wait
for
me
for
five
minutes
,
near
Saint
Alban
's
Church
in
this
street
,
you
shall
have
the
opportunity
.
"
 
<EOS>
Wyvil
did
not
deign
a
reply
,
but
wrapping
his
cloak
around
him
,
strode
away
.
<EOS>
He
had
not
proceeded
far
,
when
it
occurred
to
him
that
,
possibly
,
notwithstanding
his
interdiction
,
some
of
his
companions
might
be
waiting
for
him
,
and
hurrying
down
the
passage
leading
to
the
yard
,
he
found
Lydyard
,
to
whom
he
recounted
his
ill
-
success
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
shall
not
,
however
,
abandon
my
design
,
"
he
said
.
<EOS>
"
These
failures
are
only
incentives
to
further
exertion
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
In
the
meantime
,
you
must
pay
your
wager
to
Sedley
,
"
laughed
Lydyard
,
"
and
as
the
house
is
really
infected
with
the
plague
,
it
behoves
you
to
call
at
the
first
apothecary
's
shop
we
find
open
,
and
get
your
apparel
fumigated
.
<EOS>
You
must
not
neglect
due
precautions
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
True
,
"
replied
Wyvil
,
"
<EOS>
and
as
I
feel
too
restless
to
go
home
at
present
,
suppose
we
amuse
ourselves
by
calling
on
some
astrologer
,
to
see
whether
the
stars
are
favourable
to
my
pursuit
of
this
girl
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
A
good
idea
,
"
replied
Lydyard
.
<EOS>
"
There
are
plenty
of
the
'
Sons
of
Urania
,
'
as
they
term
themselves
,
hereabouts
.
 
<EOS>
"
A
mere
juggler
will
not
serve
my
turn
,
"
returned
Wyvil
.
 
<EOS>
"
William
Lilly
,
the
almanack
-
maker
,
who
predicted
the
plague
,
and
,
if
old
Rowley
is
to
be
believed
,
has
great
skill
in
the
occult
sciences
,
lives
somewhere
in
Friday
-
street
,
not
a
stone
's
throw
from
this
place
.
<EOS>
Let
us
go
and
find
him
out
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Agreed
,
"
replied
Lydyard
.
  
<EOS>
V.
 
<EOS>
THE
POMANDER
-
BOX
.
 
<EOS>
Any
doubts
entertained
by
Leonard
Holt
as
to
the
manner
in
which
his
rival
entered
the
house
,
were
removed
by
discovering
the
open
window
in
the
passage
and
the
rope
-
ladder
hanging
to
the
yard
-
wall
.
<EOS>
Taking
the
ladder
away
,
and
making
all
as
secure
as
he
could
,
he
next
seized
his
cudgel
,
and
proceeded
to
Blaize
's
room
,
with
the
intention
of
inflicting
upon
him
the
punishment
he
had
threatened
:
for
he
naturally
enough
attributed
to
the
porter
's
carelessness
all
the
mischief
that
had
just
occurred
.
<EOS>
Not
meeting
with
him
,
however
,
and
concluding
he
was
in
the
kitchen
,
he
descended
thither
,
and
found
him
in
such
a
pitiable
plight
,
that
his
wrath
was
instantly
changed
to
compassion
.
 
<EOS>
Stretched
upon
the
hearth
before
a
blazing
sea
-
coal
fire
,
which
seemed
large
enough
to
roast
him
,
with
his
head
resting
upon
the
lap
of
Patience
,
the
pretty
kitchen
-
maid
,
and
his
left
hand
upon
his
heart
,
the
porter
loudly
complained
of
a
fixed
and
burning
pain
in
that
region
;
while
his
mother
,
who
was
kneeling
beside
him
,
having
just
poured
a
basin
of
scalding
posset
-
drink
down
his
throat
,
entreated
him
to
let
her
examine
his
side
to
see
whether
he
had
any
pestilential
mark
upon
it
,
but
he
vehemently
resisted
her
efforts
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
you
feel
any
swelling
,
myn
lief
zoon
?
<EOS>
"
asked
old
Josyna
,
trying
to
remove
his
hand
.
 
<EOS>
"
Swelling
!
"
<EOS>
ejaculated
Blaize,--"there
's
a
tumour
as
big
as
an
egg
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Is
i
d
possible
?
"
exclaimed
Josyna
,
in
great
alarm
.
<EOS>
"
Do
let
me
look
ad
i
d
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
No
,
no
,
leave
me
alone
,
"
rejoined
Blaize
.
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
disturb
me
further
.
<EOS>
You
will
catch
the
distemper
if
you
touch
the
sore
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Dat
wond
hinder
me
from
drying
to
zaave
you
,
"
replied
his
mother
,
affectionately
.
<EOS>
"
I
must
see
vad
is
de
madder
vid
you
,
or
I
cannod
cure
you
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
past
your
doctoring
,
mother
,
"
groaned
Blaize
.
"
<EOS>
Leave
me
alone
,
I
say
.
<EOS>
You
hurt
me
shockingly
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
Poor
child
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Josyna
,
soothingly
<EOS>
,
"
I
'll
be
as
dender
as
possible
.
<EOS>
I
'll
nod
give
you
de
leasd
pain
--
nod
de
leasd
bid
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
But
I
tell
you
,
you
_
do
_
give
me
a
great
deal
,
"
rejoined
Blaize
.
<EOS>
"
I
ca
n't
bear
it
.
<EOS>
Your
fingers
are
like
iron
nails
.
<EOS>
Keep
them
away
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Bless
us
!
<EOS>
did
I
ever
hear
de
like
of
dad
!
"
exclaimed
Josyna
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Iron
nails
!
<EOS>
if
you
think
so
,
myn
arm
zoon
,
you
musd
be
very
ill
indeed
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
_
am
_
very
ill
,
"
groaned
her
son
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
not
long
for
this
world
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
!
do
n't
say
so
,
dear
Blaize
,
"
sobbed
Patience
,
letting
fall
a
plentiful
shower
of
tears
on
his
face
.
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
say
so
.
<EOS>
I
ca
n't
bear
to
part
with
you
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Then
do
n't
survive
me
,
"
returned
Blaize
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
there
's
little
chance
of
your
doing
so
.
<EOS>
You
are
certain
to
take
the
plague
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
care
not
what
becomes
of
myself
,
if
I
lose
you
,
Blaize
,
"
responded
Patience
,
bedewing
his
countenance
with
another
shower
;
"
<EOS>
but
I
hope
you
wo
n't
die
yet
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
<EOS>
it
's
all
over
with
me
--
all
over
,
"
rejoined
Blaize
.
<EOS>
"
I
told
Leonard
Holt
how
it
would
be
.
<EOS>
I
said
I
should
be
the
next
victim
.
<EOS>
And
my
words
are
come
true
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
are
as
clever
as
a
conjurer
,
"
sobbed
Patience
;
"
but
I
wish
you
had
n't
been
right
in
this
instance
.
<EOS>
However
,
comfort
yourself
.
<EOS>
I
'll
die
with
you
.
<EOS>
We
'll
be
carried
to
the
grave
in
the
same
plague
-
cart
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
That
's
cold
comfort
,
"
returned
Blaize
,
angrily
.
<EOS>
"
I
beg
you
'll
never
mention
the
plague
-
cart
again
.
<EOS>
The
thought
of
it
makes
me
shiver
all
over
--
<EOS>
oh
!
"
<EOS>
And
he
uttered
a
dismal
and
prolonged
groan
.
 
<EOS>
At
this
juncture
,
Leonard
thought
it
time
to
interfere
.
 
<EOS>
"
If
you
are
really
attacked
by
the
plague
,
Blaize
,
"
he
said
,
advancing
,
"
you
must
have
instant
advice
.
<EOS>
Doctor
Hodges
is
still
upstairs
with
our
master
.
<EOS>
He
must
see
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
On
no
account
,
"
returned
the
porter
,
in
the
greatest
alarm
,
and
springing
to
his
feet
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
better
--
much
better
.
<EOS>
I
do
n't
think
I
am
ill
at
all
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
For
the
first
time
,
I
suspect
the
contrary
,
"
replied
the
apprentice
,
"
since
you
are
afraid
of
owning
it
.
<EOS>
But
this
is
not
a
matter
to
be
trifled
with
.
<EOS>
Doctor
Hodges
will
soon
settle
the
point
.
"
<EOS>
And
he
hurried
out
of
the
room
to
summon
the
physician
.
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
!
mother!--dear
Patience
!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
roared
Blaize
,
capering
about
in
an
ecstasy
of
terror
<EOS>
;
"
do
n't
let
the
doctor
come
near
me
.
<EOS>
Keep
me
out
of
his
sight
.
<EOS>
You
do
n't
know
what
horrid
things
are
done
to
those
afflicted
with
my
complaint
.
<EOS>
But
I
do,--for
I
have
informed
myself
on
the
subject
.
<EOS>
Their
skins
are
scarified
,
and
their
sores
blistered
,
lanced
,
cauterized
,
and
sometimes
burned
away
with
a
knob
of
red
-
hot
iron
,
called
'
the
button
.
'
"
 
<EOS>
"
But
iv
i
d
is
necessary
,
myn
goed
<EOS>
Blaize
,
you
musd
submid
,
"
replied
his
mother
.
<EOS>
"
Never
mind
de
hod
iron
or
de
lance
,
or
de
blisder
,
iv
dey
make
you
well
.
<EOS>
Never
mind
de
pain
.
<EOS>
It
will
soon
be
over
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Soon
over
!
"
bellowed
Blaize
,
sinking
into
a
chair
.
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
I
feel
it
will
.
<EOS>
But
not
in
the
way
you
imagine
.
<EOS>
This
Doctor
Hodges
will
kill
me
.
<EOS>
He
is
fond
of
trying
experiments
,
and
will
make
me
his
subject
.
<EOS>
Do
n't
let
him
--
for
pity
's
sake
,
do
n't
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
But
I
musd
,
myn
lief
jonger
,
"
replied
his
mother
,
"
I
musd
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
Patience
!
"
supplicated
Blaize
,
"
you
were
always
fond
of
me
.
<EOS>
My
mother
has
lost
her
natural
affection
.
<EOS>
She
wishes
to
get
rid
of
me
.
<EOS>
Do
n't
take
part
with
her
.
<EOS>
My
sole
dependence
is
upon
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
will
do
all
I
can
for
you
,
dear
Blaize
,
"
blubbered
the
kitchen
-
maid
.
"
<EOS>
But
it
is
absolutely
necessary
you
should
see
the
doctor
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Then
I
wo
n't
stay
here
another
minute
,
"
vociferated
Blaize
.
<EOS>
"
I
'll
die
in
the
street
rather
than
under
his
hands
.
"
 
<EOS>
And
bursting
from
them
,
he
would
have
made
good
his
retreat
,
but
for
the
entrance
of
Leonard
and
Hodges
.
 
<EOS>
At
the
sight
of
the
latter
,
Blaize
ran
back
and
endeavoured
to
screen
himself
behind
Patience
.
 
<EOS>
"
Is
this
the
sick
man
?
"
remarked
Hodges
,
scarcely
able
to
refrain
from
laughing
.
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
think
he
can
be
in
such
imminent
danger
as
you
led
me
to
suppose
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
No
,
I
am
better
--
much
better
,
thank
you
,
"
returned
Blaize
,
still
keeping
Patience
between
him
and
the
doctor
.
<EOS>
"
The
very
sight
of
you
has
frightened
away
the
plague
.
<EOS>
"
 
"
Indeed
!
"
exclaimed
Hodges
,
smiling
,
"
then
it
is
the
most
marvellous
cure
I
ever
yet
effected
.
<EOS>
But
,
come
forward
,
young
man
,
and
let
us
see
what
is
the
matter
with
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
neither
lance
nor
cauterize
an
incipient
tumour
,
do
you
,
doctor
?
<EOS>
"
demanded
Blaize
,
without
abandoning
his
position
.
 
<EOS>
"
Eh
,
day
!
<EOS>
"
exclaimed
Hodges
,
"
have
we
one
of
the
faculty
here
?
<EOS>
I
see
how
it
is
,
friend
.
<EOS>
You
have
been
reading
some
silly
book
about
the
disease
,
and
have
frightened
yourself
into
the
belief
that
you
have
some
of
its
symptoms
.
<EOS>
I
hope
you
have
n't
been
doctoring
yourself
,
likewise
.
<EOS>
What
have
you
taken
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
would
be
difficult
to
say
what
he
has
_
not
_
taken
,
"
remarked
Leonard
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
His
stomach
must
be
like
an
apothecary
's
shop
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
only
used
proper
precautions
,
"
rejoined
Blaize
,
testily
.
 
<EOS>
"
And
what
may
those
be
--
eh
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
the
doctor
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
curious
to
learn
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Come
from
behind
Patience
,
"
cried
Leonard
,
"
and
do
n't
act
the
fool
longer
,
or
I
will
see
whether
your
disorder
will
not
yield
to
a
sound
application
of
the
cudgel
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
rate
him
thus
,
good
Master
Leonard
,
"
interposed
Patience
.
"
He
is
very
ill
--
he
is
,
indeed
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Then
let
him
have
a
chance
of
getting
better
,
"
returned
the
apprentice
.
<EOS>
"
If
he
_
is
_
ill
,
he
has
no
business
near
you
.
<EOS>
Come
from
behind
her
,
Blaize
,
I
say
.
<EOS>
Now
speak
,
"
he
added
,
as
the
porter
crept
tremblingly
forth
,
"
and
let
us
hear
what
nostrums
you
have
swallowed
.
<EOS>
I
know
you
have
dosed
yourself
with
pills
,
electuaries
,
balsams
,
tinctures
,
conserves
,
spirits
,
elixirs
,
decoctions
,
and
every
other
remedy
,
real
or
imaginary
.
<EOS>
What
else
have
you
done
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
What
Dr.
Hodges
,
I
am
sure
,
will
approve
,
"
replied
Blaize
,
confidently
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
rubbed
myself
with
vinegar
,
oil
of
sulphur
,
extract
of
tar
,
and
spirit
of
turpentine
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
What
next
?
"
demanded
Hodges
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
placed
saltpetre
,
brimstone
,
amber
,
and
juniper
upon
a
chafing
-
dish
to
fumigate
my
room
,
"
replied
Blaize
;
"
but
the
vapour
was
so
overpowering
,
I
could
not
bear
it
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
should
be
surprised
if
you
could
,
"
replied
the
doctor
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Indeed
,
it
is
astonishing
to
me
,
if
you
have
taken
half
the
remedies
Leonard
says
you
have
,
and
which
,
taken
in
this
way
,
are
no
remedies
at
all
,
since
they
counteract
each
other
--
that
you
are
still
alive
.
<EOS>
But
let
us
see
what
is
the
matter
with
you
.
<EOS>
What

you
particularly
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Nothing
,
"
replied
Blaize
,
trembling
;
"
I
am
quite
well
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
He
complains
of
a
fixed
pain
near
de
haard
,
docdor
,
"
interposed
his
mother
,
"
and
says
he
has
a
large
dumour
on
his
side
.
<EOS>
But
he
wond
let
me
examine
i
d
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
That
's
a
bad
sign
,
"
observed
Hodges
,
shaking
his
head
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
afraid
it
's
not
all
fancy
,
as
I
at
first
supposed
.
<EOS>
Have
you
felt
sick
of
late
,
young
man
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Not
of
late
,
"
replied
Blaize
,
becoming
as
white
as
ashes
;
"
but
I
do
now
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Another
bad
symptom
,
"
rejoined
the
doctor
.
<EOS>
"
Take
off
your
doublet
and
open
your
shirt
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Do
as
the
doctor
bids
you
,
"
said
Leonard
,
seeing
that
Blaize
hesitated
,
"
or
I
apply
the
cudgel
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
bless
my
life
!
<EOS>
what
's
this
?
"
<EOS>
cried
Hodges
,
running
his
hand
down
the
left
side
of
the
porter
,
and
meeting
with
a
large
lump
.
"
<EOS>
Can
it
be
a
carbuncle
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
it
's
a
terrible
carbuncle
,
"
replied
Blaize
;
"
but
do
n't
cauterize
it
,
doctor
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Let
me
look
at
it
,
"
cried
Hodges
,
"
and
I
shall
then
know
how
to
proceed
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
And
as
he
spoke
,
he
tore
open
the
porter
's
shirt
,
and
a
silver
ball
,
about
as
large
as
a
pigeon
's
egg
,
fell
to
the
ground
.
<EOS>
Leonard
picked
it
up
,
and
found
it
so
hot
that
he
could
scarcely
hold
it
.
 
<EOS>
"
Here
is
the
terrible
carbuncle
,
"
he
cried
,
with
a
laugh
,
in
which
all
the
party
,
except
Blaize
,
joined
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
's
my
pomander
-
box
,
"
said
the
latter
.
<EOS>
"
I
filled
it
with
a
mixture
of
citron
-
peel
,
angelica
seed
,
zedoary
,
yellow
saunders
,
aloes
,
benzoin
,
camphor
,
and
gum
-
tragacanth
,
moistened
with
spirit
of
roses
;
and
after
placing
it
on
the
chafing
-
dish
to
heat
it
,
hung
it
by
a
string
round
my
neck
,
next
my
dried
toad
.
<EOS>
I
suppose
,
by
some
means
or
other
,
it
dropped
through
my
doublet
,
and
found
its
way
to
my
side
.
<EOS>
I
felt
a
dreadful
burning
there
,
and
that
made
me
fancy
<EOS>
I
was
attacked
by
the
plague
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
A
very
satisfactory
solution
of
the
mystery
<EOS>
,
"
replied
the
doctor
,
laughing
;
"
and
you
may
think
yourself
well
off
with
the
blister
which
your
box
has
raised
.
<EOS>
It
will
be
easier
to
bear
than
the
cataplasm
I
should
have
given
you
,
had
your
apprehensions
been
well
founded
.
<EOS>
As
yet
,
you
are
free
from
infection
,
young
man
;
but
if
you
persist
in
this
silly
and
pernicious
practice
of
quacking
yourself
,
you
will
infallibly
bring
on
some
fatal
disorder
--
perhaps
the
plague
itself
.
<EOS>
If
your
mother
has
any
regard
for
you
she
will
put
all
your
medicines
out
of
your
reach
.
<EOS>
There
are
few
known
remedies
against
this
frightful
disease
;
and
what
few
there
are
,
must
be
adopted
cautiously
.
<EOS>
My
own
specific
is
sack
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Sack
!
"
exclaimed
Blaize
,
in
astonishment
.
<EOS>
"
Henceforth
,
I
will
drink
nothing
else
.
<EOS>
I
like
the
remedy
amazingly
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
must
be
taken
in
moderation
,
"
said
the
doctor
:
"
<EOS>
otherwise
it
is
as
dangerous
as
too
much
physic
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
a
boddle
or
doo
of
de
liquor
<EOS>
you
commend
,
docdor
,
in
my
private
cupboard
,
"
observed
Josyna
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Will
you
dasde
i
d
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
With
great
pleasure
,
"
replied
Hodges
,
"
and
a
drop
of
it
will
do
your
son
no
harm
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
The
wine
was
accordingly
produced
,
and
the
doctor
pronounced
it
excellent
,
desiring
that
a
glass
might
always
be
brought
him
when
he
visited
the
grocer
's
house
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
may
rely
upon
i
d
,
mynheer
,
as
long
as
my
small
sdore
lasds
,
"
replied
Josyna
.
 
<EOS>
Blaize
,
who
,
in
obedience
to
the
doctor
's
commands
,
had
drained
a
large
glass
of
sack
,
felt
so
much
inspirited
by
it
,
that
he
ventured
,
when
his
mother
's
back
was
turned
,
to
steal
a
kiss
from
Patience
,
and
to
whisper
in
her
ear
,
that
if
he
escaped
the
plague
,
he
would
certainly
marry
her
--
an
assurance
that
seemed
to
give
her
no
slight
satisfaction
.
<EOS>
His
new
-
born
courage
,
however
,
was
in
some
degree
damped
by
Leonard
,
who
observed
to
him
in
an
undertone
:
 
<EOS>
"
You
have
neglected
my
injunctions
,
sirrah
,
and
allowed
the
person
I
warned
you
of
to
enter
the
house
.
<EOS>
When
a
fitting
season
arrives
,
I
will
not
fail
to
pay
off
old
scores
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
Blaize
would
have
remonstrated
,
and
asked
for
some
explanation
,
but
the
apprentice
instantly
left
him
,
and
set
out
upon
his
errand
to
the
Examiner
of
Health
.
<EOS>
Accompanied
by
his
mother
,
who
would
not
even
allow
him
to
say
good
-
night
to
Patience
,
the
porter
then
proceeded
to
his
own
room
,
where
the
old
woman
,
to
his
infinite
regret
,
carried
off
his
stores
of
medicine
in
a
basket
,
which
she
brought
with
her
for
that
purpose
,
and
locked
the
door
upon
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
This
has
escaped
her
,
"
said
Blaize
,
as
soon
as
she
was
gone
,
opening
a
secret
drawer
in
the
cupboard
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
How
fortunate
that
I
kept
this
reserve
.
<EOS>
I
have
still
a
tolerable
supply
in
case
of
need
.
<EOS>
Let
me
examine
my
stock
.
<EOS>
First
of
all
,
there
are
plague
-
lozenges
,
composed
of
angelica
,
liquorice
,
flower
of
sulphur
,
myrrh
,
and
oil
of
cinnamon
.
<EOS>
Secondly
,
an
electuary
of
bole
-
armoniac
,
hartshorn
-
shavings
,
saffron
,
and
syrup
of
wood
-
sorrel
.
<EOS>
I
long
to
taste
it
.
<EOS>
But
then
it
would
be
running
in
the
doctor
's
teeth
.
<EOS>
Thirdly
,
there
is
a
phial
labelled
<EOS>
_
Aqua
Theriacalis
Stillatitia_--in
plain
English
,
distilled
treacle
-
water
.
<EOS>
A
spoonful
of
this
could
n't
hurt
me
.
<EOS>
Fourthly
,
a
packet
of
powders
,
entitled
_
Manus
Christi_--an
excellent
mixture
.
<EOS>
Fifthly
,
a
small
pot
of
diatesseron
,
composed
of
gentian
,
myrrh
,
bayberries
,
and
round
aristolochia
.
<EOS>
I
must
just
taste
it
.
<EOS>
Never
mind
the
doctor
!
<EOS>
He
does
not
know
what
agrees
with
my
constitution
as
well
as
I
do
myself
.
<EOS>
Physic
comes
as
naturally
to
me
as
mother
's
milk
.
<EOS>
Sixthly
,
there
is
_
Aqua
Epidemica
_
,
commonly
called
the
Plague
-
Water
of
Matthias
--
delicious
stuff
!
<EOS>
I
will
only
just
sip
it
.
<EOS>
What
a
fine
bitter
it
has
!
<EOS>
I
'm
sure
it
must
be
very
wholesome
.
<EOS>
Next
,
for
I
've
lost
my
count
,
comes
salt
of
vipers
--
next
,
powder
of
unicorn
's
horn
--
<EOS>
next
,
oil
of
scorpions
from
Naples
--
next
,
dragon
-
water
--
all
admirable
.
<EOS>
Then
there
are
cloves
of
garlics
--
sovereign
fortifiers
of
the
stomach
--
and
,
lastly
,
there
is
a
large
box
of
my
favourite
rufuses
.
<EOS>
How
many
pills
have
I
taken
?
<EOS>
Only
half
a
dozen
!
<EOS>
Three
more
may
as
well
go
to
keep
the
others
company
.
"
 
<EOS>
And
hastily
swallowing
them
,
as
if
afraid
of
detection
,
he
carefully
shut
the
drawer
,
and
then
crept
into
bed
,
and
,
covering
himself
with
blankets
,
endeavoured
to
compose
himself
to
slumber
.
 
<EOS>
Doctor
Hodges
,
meantime
,
returned
to
the
grocer
,
and
acquainted
him
that
it
was
a
false
alarm
,
and
that
the
porter
was
entirely
free
from
infection
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
glad
to
hear
it
,
"
replied
Bloundel
;
"
but
I
expected
as
much
.
<EOS>
Blaize
is
like
the
shepherd
's
boy
in
the
fable
:
he
has
cried
'
wolf
'
so
often
,
that
when
the
danger
really
arrives
,
no
one
will
heed
him
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
must
now
take
my
leave
,
Mr.
Bloundel
,
"
said
Hodges
.
<EOS>
"
I
will
be
with
you
the
first
thing
to
-
morrow
,
and
have
little
doubt
I
shall
find
your
son
going
on
well
.
<EOS>
But
you
must
not
merely
take
care
of
him
,
but
of
yourself
,
and
your
household
.
<EOS>
It
will
be
well
to
set
a
chafing
-
dish
in
the
middle
of
the
room
,
and
scatter
some
of
these
perfumes
occasionally
upon
it
!
"
<EOS>
and
producing
several
small
packets
,
he
gave
them
to
the
grocer
.
<EOS>
"
If
you
ever
smoke
a
pipe
,
I
would
advise
you
to
do
so
now
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
never
smoke
,
"
replied
Bloundel
,
"
and
hold
it
as
a
filthy
and
mischievous
habit
,
which
nothing
but
necessity
should
induce
me
to
practise
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
advisable
now
,
"
returned
Hodges
,
"
and
you
should
neglect
no
precaution
.
<EOS>
Take
my
word
for
it
,
Mr.
Bloundel
,
the
plague
is
only
beginning
.
<EOS>
When
the
heats
of
summer
arrive
,
its
ravages
will
be
frightful
.
<EOS>
Heaven
only
knows
what
will
become
of
us
all
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
If
my
poor
son
is
spared
,
and
we
escape
contagion
,
"
returned
Bloundel
,
"
I
will
put
into
execution
a
scheme
which
has
occurred
to
me
,
and
which
(
under
Providence
!
)
<EOS>
will
,
I
trust
,
secure
my
family
from
further
hazard
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Ah
,
indeed
!
<EOS>
what
is
that
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Hodges
.
 
<EOS>
"
We
must
talk
of
it
some
other
time
,
"
returned
Bloundel
"
Good
-
night
,
doctor
,
and
accept
my
thanks
for
your
attention
.
<EOS>
To
-
morrow
,
at
as
early
an
hour
as
you
can
make
convenient
,
I
shall
hope
to
see
you
.
"
<EOS>
And
with
a
friendly
shake
of
the
hand
,
and
a
reiteration
of
advice
and
good
wishes
,
Hodges
departed
.
 
<EOS>
Soon
after
this
the
apprentice
returned
,
and
by
his
master
's
directions
,
placed
a
chafing
-
dish
in
the
middle
of
the
room
,
supplying
it
with
the
drugs
and
herbs
left
by
the
doctor
.
<EOS>
About
four
o'clock
,
a
loud
knocking
was
heard
.
<EOS>
Instantly
answering
the
summons
,
Leonard
found
four
men
at
the
shop
-
door
,
two
of
whom
he
knew
,
by
red
wands
they
carried
,
were
searchers
;
while
their
companions
appeared
to
be
undertakers
,
from
their
sable
habits
and
long
black
cloaks
.
 
<EOS>
Marching
unceremoniously
into
the
shop
,
the
searchers
desired
to
see
the
sick
man
;
and
the
apprentice
then
perceived
that
one
of
the
men
in
black
cloaks
was
the
coffin
-
maker
,
Chowles
.
<EOS>
He
could
not
,
however
,
refuse
him
admittance
,
and
led
the
way
to
the
grocer
's
chamber
.
<EOS>
As
they
entered
it
,
Bloundel
arose
,
and
placing
his
finger
to
his
lips
in
token
of
silence
,
raised
the
blankets
,
and
exhibited
the
blotch
,
which
had
greatly
increased
in
size
,
under
the
arm
of
his
slumbering
son
.
<EOS>
The
foremost
of
the
searchers
,
who
kept
a
phial
of
vinegar
to
his
nose
all
the
time
he
remained
in
the
room
,
then
demanded
in
a
low
tone
whether
there
were
any
other
of
the
household
infected
?
<EOS>
The
grocer
replied
in
the
negative
.
<EOS>
Upon
this
,
Chowles
,
whose
manner
showed
he
was
more
than
half
intoxicated
,
took
off
his
hat
,
and
bowing
obsequiously
to
the
grocer
,
said
,
"
Shall
I
prepare
you
a
coffin
,
Mr.
Bloundel?--you
are
sure
to
want
one
,
and
had
better
give
the
order
in
time
,
for
there
is
a
great
demand
for
such
articles
just
now
.
<EOS>
If
you
like
,
I
will
call
with
it
tomorrow
night
.
<EOS>
I
have
a
plague
-
cart
of
my
own
,
and
bury
all
my
customers
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
God
grant
<EOS>
I
may
not
require
your
services
,
sir
!
"
<EOS>
replied
the
grocer
,
shuddering
.
<EOS>
"
But
I
will
give
you
timely
notice
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
If
you
are
in
want
of
a
nurse
,
I
can
recommend
an
experienced
one
,
"
added
Chowles
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Her
last
employer
is
just
dead
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
may
need
assistance
,
"
replied
the
grocer
,
after
a
moment
's
reflection
.
<EOS>
"
Let
her
call
to
-
morrow
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
She
understands
her
business
perfectly
,
and
will
save
you
a
world
of
trouble
,
"
replied
Chowles
;
"
besides
securing
me
the
sale
of
another
coffin
,
"
he
added
to
himself
.
 
<EOS>
He
then
quitted
the
room
with
the
searchers
,
and
Leonard
felt
inexpressibly
relieved
by
their
departure
.
 
<EOS>
As
soon
as
the
party
gained
the
street
,
the
fourth
person
,
who
was
provided
with
materials
for
the
task
,
painted
a
red
cross
of
the
prescribed
size
--
namely
,
a
foot
in
length
--
in
the
middle
of
the
door
;
tracing
above
it
,
in
large
characters
,
the
melancholy
formula--"LORD
,
HAVE
MERCY
UPON
US
!
"
  
<EOS>
VI
.
 
<EOS>
THE
LIBERTINE
PUNISHED
.
 
<EOS>
Sir
Paul
Parravicin
and
Major
Pillichody
arrived
without
any
particular
adventure
at
the
top
of
the
Haymarket
,
where
the
former
dismissed
the
coach
he
had
hired
in
Cheapside
,
and
they
proceeded
towards
Piccadilly
on
foot
.
<EOS>
Up
to
this
time
the
major
had
been
in
very
high
spirits
,
boasting
what
he
would
do
,
in
case
they
encountered
Disbrowe
,
and
offering
to
keep
guard
outside
the
door
while
the
knight
remained
in
the
house
.
<EOS>
But
he
now
began
to
alter
his
tone
,
and
to
frame
excuses
to
get
away
.
<EOS>
He
had
noticed
with
some
uneasiness
,
that
another
coach
stopped
lower
down
the
Haymarket
,
at
precisely
the
same
time
as
their
own
;
and
though
he
could
not
be
quite
certain
of
the
fact
,
he
fancied
he
perceived
a
person
greatly
resembling
Captain
Disbrowe
alight
from
it
.
<EOS>
Mentioning
the
circumstance
to
his
companion
,
he
pointed
out
a
tall
figure
following
them
at
some
distance
;
but
the
other
only
laughed
at
him
,
and
said
,
"
It
may
possibly
be
Disbrowe
--
but
what
if
it
is
?
<EOS>
He
can
not
get
into
the
house
without
the
key
;
and
if
he
is
inclined
to
measure
swords
with
me
a
second
time
,
he
shall
not
escape
so
lightly
as
he
did
the
first
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Right
,
Sir
Paul
,
right
,
"
returned
Pillichody
,
"
exterminate
him
--
spare
him
not
.
<EOS>
By
Bellerophon
!
<EOS>
that
's
my
way
.
<EOS>
My
only
apprehension
is
lest
he
should
set
upon
us
unawares
.
<EOS>
The
bravest
are
not
proof
against
the
dagger
of
an
assassin
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
There
you
wrong
Disbrowe
,
major
,
I
am
persuaded
,
"
returned
Parravicin
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He
is
too
much
a
man
of
honour
to
stab
a
foe
behind
his
back
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
may
be
,
"
replied
Pillichody
,
"
but
jealousy
will
sometimes
turn
a
man
's
brain
.
<EOS>
By
the
snakes
of
Tisiphone
!
<EOS>
I
have
known
an
instance
of
it
myself
.
<EOS>
I
once
made
love
to
a
tailor
's
wife
,
and
the
rascal
coming
in
unawares
,
struck
me
to
the
ground
with
his
goose
,
and
well
nigh
murdered
me
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
After
such
a
mischance
,
I
am
surprised
you
should
venture
to
carry
on
so
many
hazardous
intrigues
,
"
laughed
the
knight
.
<EOS>
"
But
you
proposed
just
now
to
keep
watch
outside
the
house
.
<EOS>
If
it
is
Disbrowe
who
is
following
us
,
you
had
better
do
so
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Why
,
Sir
Paul
--
you
<EOS>
see,"--stammered
<EOS>
the
major
,
"
I
have
just
bethought
me
of
an
engagement
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
An
engagement
at
this
hour
--
impossible
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Parravicin
.
 
<EOS>
"
An
assignation
,
I
ought
to
say
,
"
returned
Pillichody
.
 
<EOS>
"
Couches
of
Cytheraea!--an
affair
like
your
own
.
<EOS>
You
would
not
have
me
keep
a
lady
waiting
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
strange
<EOS>
you
should
not
recollect
it
till
this
moment
,
"
replied
Parravicin
.
"
<EOS>
But
be
your
inamorata
whom
she
may
--
even
the
rich
widow
of
Watling
-
street
,
of
whom
you
prate
so
much
--
you
must
put
her
off
to
-
night
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
But
,
Sir
Paul----
"
 
"
I
will
have
no
denial
,
"
replied
the
knight
,
peremptorily
.
<EOS>
If
you
refuse
,
you
will
find
me
worse
to
deal
with
than
Disbrowe
.
<EOS>
You
must
remain
at
the
door
till
I
come
out
.
<EOS>
And
now
let
us
lose
no
more
time
.
<EOS>
I
am
impatient
to
behold
the
lady
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Into
what
a
cursed
scrape
have
I
got
myself
!
"
<EOS>
thought
the
major
,
as
he
walked
by
the
side
of
his
companion
,
ever
and
anon
casting
wistful
glances
over
his
shoulder
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
fairly
caught
on
the
horns
of
a
dilemma
.
<EOS>
I
instinctively
feel
that
Disbrowe
_
is
_
dogging
us
.
<EOS>
What
will
become
of
me
?
<EOS>
The
moment
this
harebrained
coxcomb
enters
the
house
,
I
will
see
whether
a
light
pair
of
heels
can
not
bear
me
out
of
harm
's
way
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
By
this
time
,
they
had
reached
a
passage
known
as
Bear
-
alley
(
all
traces
of
which
have
been
swept
away
by
modern
improvements
)
,
and
threading
it
,
they
entered
a
narrow
thoroughfare
,
called
Castle
-
street
.
<EOS>
Just
as
they
turned
the
corner
,
Pillichody
again
noticed
the
figure
at
the
further
end
of
the
alley
,
and
,
but
for
his
fears
of
the
knight
,
would
have
instantly
scampered
off
.
 
<EOS>
"
Are
we
far
from
the
house
?
"
inquired
Parravicin
.
 
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
replied
the
major
,
scarcely
able
to
conceal
his
trepidation
.
<EOS>
"
It
is
close
at
hand
--
and
so
is
the
lady
's
husband
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
So
much
the
better
,
"
replied
the
knight
;
"
it
will
afford
you
some
amusement
to
beat
him
off
.
<EOS>
You
may
affect
not
to
know
him
,
and
may
tell
him
the
lady
's
husband
is
just
come
home
--
her
<EOS>
_
husband_!--do
you
take
,
Pillichody
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
do
--
ha
!
<EOS>
ha
!
<EOS>
I
do
,
"
replied
the
major
,
in
a
quavering
tone
.
 
<EOS>
"
But
you
do
n't
appear
to
relish
the
jest
,
"
rejoined
Parravicin
,
sneeringly
.
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
yes
,
I
relish
it
exceedingly
,
"
replied
Pillichody
;
"
her
husband
--
ha!--ha!--and
Disbrowe
is
the
disappointed
lover
--
capital
!
<EOS>
But
here
we
are
--
and
I
wish
we
were
anywhere
else
,
"
he
added
to
himself
.
 
<EOS>
"
Are
you
sure
you
are
right
?
"
<EOS>
asked
Parravicin
,
searching
for
the
key
.
 
<EOS>
"
Quite
sure
,
"
returned
Pillichody
.
"
<EOS>
Do
n't
you
see
some
one
behind
that
wall
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
see
nothing
,
"
rejoined
the
knight
.
<EOS>
"
You
are
afraid
of
shadows
,
major
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Afraid
!
"
<EOS>
ejaculated
Pillichody
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Thousand
thunders
!
<EOS>
I
am
afraid
of
nothing
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
In
that
case
,
I
shall
expect
to
find
you
have
slain
Disbrowe
,
on
my
return
,
"
rejoined
Parravicin
,
unlocking
the
door
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
night
is
chilly
,
"
observed
the
major
,
"
and
ever
since
my
campaigns
in
the
Low
Countries
,
I
have
been
troubled
with
rheumatism
.
<EOS>
I
should
prefer
keeping
guard
inside
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
No
,
no
,
you
must
remain
where
you
are
,
"
replied
the
knight
,
shutting
the
door
.
 
<EOS>
Pillichody
was
about
to
take
to
his
heels
,
when
he
felt
himself
arrested
by
a
powerful
arm
.
<EOS>
He
would
have
roared
for
aid
,
but
a
voice
,
which
he
instantly
recognised
,
commanded
him
to
keep
silence
,
if
he
valued
his
life
.
 
<EOS>
"
Is
your
companion
in
the
house
?
"
demanded
Disbrowe
,
in
a
hollow
tone
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
sorry
to
say
he
is
,
Captain
Disbrowe
,
"
replied
the
bully
.
<EOS>
"
I
did
my
best
to
prevent
him
,
but
remonstrance
was
in
vain
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Liar
,
"
cried
Disbrowe
,
striking
him
with
his
clenched
hand
.
<EOS>
"
Do
you
think
to
impose
upon
me
by
such
a
pitiful
fabrication
?
<EOS>
It
was
you
who
introduced
me
to
this
heartless
libertine
--
you
who
encouraged
me
to
play
with
him
,
telling
me
I
should
easily
strip
him
of
all
he
possessed
--
you
who
excited
his
passion
for
my
wife
,
by
praising
her
beauty
--
and
it
was
you
who
put
it
into
his
head
to
propose
that
fatal
stake
to
me
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
There
you
are
wrong
,
Captain
Disbrowe
,
"
returned
Pillichody
,
in
a
supplicatory
tone
.
<EOS>
"
On
my
soul
,
you
are
!
<EOS>
I
certainly
praised
your
wife
(
as
who
would
not
?
)
,
but
I
never
advised
Parravicin
to
play
for
her
.
<EOS>
That
was
his
own
idea
entirely
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
The
excuse
shall
not
avail
you
,
"
cried
Disbrowe
,
fiercely
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
To
you
I
owe
all
my
misery
.
<EOS>
Draw
and
defend
yourself
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Be
not
so
hasty
,
captain
,
"
cried
Pillichody
,
abjectedly
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
injured
you
sufficiently
already
.
<EOS>
I
would
not
have
your
blood
on
my
head
.
<EOS>
On
the
honour
of
a
soldier
,
I
am
sorry
for
the
wrong
I
have
done
you
,
and
will
strive
to
repair
it
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Repair
it
!
"
<EOS>
shrieked
Disbrowe
.
<EOS>
"
It
is
too
late
.
"
<EOS>
And
seizing
the
major
's
arm
,
he
dragged
him
by
main
force
into
the
alley
.
 
<EOS>
"
Help
!
<EOS>
help
!
"
<EOS>
roared
Pillichody
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Would
you
murder
me
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
will
assuredly
cut
your
throat
,
if
you
keep
up
this
clamour
,
"
rejoined
Disbrowe
,
snatching
the
other
's
long
rapier
from
his
side
.
<EOS>
"
Coward
!
"
<EOS>
he
added
,
striking
him
with
the
flat
side
of
the
weapon
,
"
this
will
teach
you
to
mix
yourself
up
in
such
infamous
affairs
for
the
future
.
"
 
<EOS>
And
heedless
of
the
major
's
entreaties
and
vociferations
,
he
continued
to
belabour
him
,
until
compelled
by
fatigue
to
desist
;
when
the
other
,
contriving
to
extricate
himself
,
ran
off
as
fast
as
his
legs
could
carry
him
.
<EOS>
Disbrowe
looked
after
him
for
a
moment
,
as
if
uncertain
whether
to
follow
,
and
then
hurrying
to
the
house
,
stationed
himself
beneath
the
porch
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
will
stab
him
as
he
comes
forth
,
"
he
muttered
,
drawing
his
sword
,
and
hiding
it
beneath
his
mantle
.
 
<EOS>
Parravicin
,
meanwhile
,
having
let
himself
into
the
house
,
marched
boldly
forward
,
though
the
passage
was
buried
in
darkness
,
and
he
was
utterly
unacquainted
with
it
.
<EOS>
Feeling
against
the
wall
,
he
presently
discovered
a
door
,
and
opening
it
,
entered
a
room
lighted
by
a
small
silver
lamp
placed
on
a
marble
slab
.
<EOS>
The
room
was
empty
,
but
its
furniture
and
arrangements
proclaimed
it
the
favourite
retreat
of
the
fair
mistress
of
the
abode
.
<EOS>
Parravicin
gazed
curiously
round
,
as
if
anxious
to
gather
from
what
he
saw
some
idea
of
the
person
he
so
soon
expected
to
encounter
.
<EOS>
Everything
betokened
a
refined
and
luxurious
taste
.
<EOS>
A
few
French
romances
,
the
last
plays
of
Etherege
,
Dryden
,
and
Shadwell
,
a
volume
of
Cowley
,
and
some
amorous
songs
,
lay
on
the
table
;
and
not
far
from
them
were
a
loomask
,
pulvil
purse
,
a
pair
of
scented
gloves
,
a
richly
-
laced
mouchoir
,
a
manteau
girdle
,
palatine
tags
,
and
a
golden
bodkin
for
the
hair
.
 
<EOS>
Examining
all
these
things
,
and
drawing
his
own
conclusions
as
to
the
character
of
their
owner
,
Parravicin
turned
to
a
couch
on
which
a
cittern
was
thrown
,
while
beside
it
,
on
a
cushion
,
were
a
pair
of
tiny
embroidered
velvet
slippers
.
<EOS>
A
pocket
-
mirror
,
or
sprunking
-
glass
,
as
it
was
then
termed
,
lay
on
a
side
-
table
,
and
near
it
stood
an
embossed
silver
chocolate
-
pot
,
and
a
small
porcelain
cup
with
a
golden
spoon
inside
it
,
showing
what
the
lady
's
last
repast
had
been
.
<EOS>
On
another
small
table
,
covered
with
an
exquisitely
white
napkin
,
stood
a
flask
of
wine
,
a
tall
-
stemmed
glass
,
and
a
few
cakes
on
a
China
dish
,
evidently
placed
there
for
Disbrowe
's
return
.
 
<EOS>
As
Parravicin
drew
near
this
table
,
a
slip
of
paper
,
on
which
a
few
lines
were
traced
,
attracted
his
attention
,
and
taking
it
up
,
he
read
as
follows
:
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
now
midnight
,
and
you
promised
to
return
early
.
<EOS>
I
have
felt
your
absence
severely
,
and
have
been
suffering
from
a
violent
headache
,
which
has
almost
distracted
me
.
<EOS>
I
have
also
been
troubled
with
strange
and
unaccountable
misgivings
respecting
you
.
<EOS>
I
am
a
little
easier
now
,
but
still
far
from
well
,
and
about
to
retire
to
rest
.
<EOS>
At
what
hour
will
this
meet
your
eye
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
MARGARET
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Charming
creature
!
"
exclaimed
Parravicin
,
as
the
paper
dropped
from
his
hand
;
"
she
little
dreamed
,
when
she
wrote
it
,
who
would
read
her
billet
.
<EOS>
Disbrowe
does
not
deserve
such
a
treasure
.
<EOS>
I
am
sorry
she
is
unwell
.
<EOS>
I
hope
she
has
not
taken
the
plague
.
<EOS>
Pshaw
,
what
could
put
such
an
idea
into
my
head
?
<EOS>
Lydyard
's
warning
,
I
suppose
.
<EOS>
That
fellow
,
who
is
the
veriest
rake
among

,
is
always

.
<EOS>
Confound
him
!
<EOS>
I
wish
he
had
not
mentioned
it
.
<EOS>
A
glass
of
wine
may
exhilarate
me
.
"
<EOS>
And
pouring
out
a

,
he
swallowed
it
at
a

.
"
<EOS>
And
so
the
fond
fool
is
pining
for
her
husband
,
and
has
some
misgivings
about
him
.
<EOS>
Egad
!
<EOS>
it
is
well
for
her
<EOS>
she
does
not
know
what
has
really
taken
place
.
<EOS>
She
'll
learn
that
soon
enough
.
<EOS>
What
's
this
?
"
he
added
,
glancing
at
a

on

wall
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Her
miniature
!
<EOS>
It
must
be
;
for
it
answers
exactly
to
Pillichody
's
description
.
<EOS>
A
sparkling
brunette
,
with
raven
hair
,
and
eyes
of
night
.
<EOS>
I
am
on
fire
to
behold
her
:
but
I
must
proceed
with
prudence
,
or
I
may
ruin
all
.
<EOS>
Is
there
nothing
of
Disbrowe
's
that
I
could
put
on
for
the
nonce
?
'
<EOS>
Fore
Heaven
!
<EOS>
the
very
thing
I
want
!
"
 
<EOS>
The
exclamation
was
occasioned
by
his
observing
a
loose
silken
robe
lying
across
a
chair
.
<EOS>
Wrapping
it
round
him
,
and
throwing
down
his
hat
,
he
took
the
lamp
and
went
up
stairs
.
 
<EOS>
Daring
as
he
was
,
Parravicin
felt
his
courage
desert
him
,
as
having
found
the
door
of
Mrs.
Disbrowe
's
chamber
,
he
cautiously
opened
it
.
<EOS>
A
single
glance
showed
him
that
the
room
was
more
exquisitely
,
more
luxuriously
furnished
than
that
he
had
just
quitted
.
<EOS>
Articles
of
feminine
attire
,
of
the
richest
kind
,
were
hung
against
the
walls
,
or
disposed
on
the
chairs
.
<EOS>
On
one
side
stood
the
toilette
-
table
,
with
its
small
mirror
then
in
vogue
,
and
all
its
equipage
of
silver
flasks
,
filligree
cassets
,
japan
patch
-
boxes
,
scent
-

,
and
pomatum
-
pots
.
 
<EOS>
As
he
entered
the
room
,
a
faint

issuing
from
behind
the
rich
damask
curtains
of
the
bed
,
demanded
,
"
Is
it
you
,
Disbrowe
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
,
Margaret
,
"
replied
Parravicin
,
setting
down
the
lamp
,
and
speaking
with
a
handkerchief
at
his
mouth
,
to
disguise
his
voice
and
conceal

features
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
are
late
--
very
late
,
"
she
rejoined
,
"
and
I
have
been
ill
.
<EOS>
I
fancied
myself
dying
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
What
has
been
the
matter
with
you
sweet
,
Meg
?
"
<EOS>
asked
Parravicin
,
approaching
the
bed
,
and
seating
himself
behind
the

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
know
not
,
"
she

.
<EOS>
"
I
was
seized
with
a
dreadful
headache
about
an
hour
ago
.
<EOS>
It
has
left
me
;
but
I
have
a
strange
oppression
at
my
chest
,
and
breathe

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
alarm
me
,
my
love
,
"
rejoined
Parravicin
.
<EOS>
"
Were
you
ever
attacked
thus

?
"
 
<EOS>
"
Never
,
"
she

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
Disbrowe
!
<EOS>
if
you
knew
how
I
have
longed
for
your
return
,
you
would
blame
yourself
for
your

.
<EOS>
You
have
grown
sadly

of
late
.
<EOS>
I
suspect
you
love
some
one
else
.
<EOS>
If
I

<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
What

,
Margaret
?
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
What
!
"
cried
Mrs.
Disbrowe
,

in

.
<EOS>
"
I
would
requite

--
terribly

!
"
 
<EOS>
"
Then
learn
that
Captain
Disbrowe
_
is
_
faithless
,
"
cried
Parravicin
,
throwing
back
the

,
and
disclosing

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Learn
that
he
loves
another
,
and

.
<EOS>
Learn
that
he
cares

little
for
you
,
that
he
has

.
"
 
<EOS>
"
What

hear
?
"

Mrs.
Disbrowe
.
<EOS>
"
Who
are

,
and
what

here
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
may
guess
my
errand
from

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
I
am

Sir
Paul
Parravicin
,

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
My
husband
surrender

to
a

!
<EOS>
It
can
not
be
!
"
<EOS>
cried
the

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
You
see

here
,
and
may
judge
of
the
truth

,
"
rejoined

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Your
husband
gave
me
this
key
,
with

I
introduced

to
the
house
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
What
motive
could
he
have
for
such
unheard
-
of
baseness
--
<EOS>
such
barbarity
?
"
cried
Mrs.
Disbrowe
,
bursting
into

.
 
<EOS>
"
Shall
I
tell

,

?
"

Parravicin
.
"
<EOS>
He
is
tired
of
you
,
and
has
taken
this
means
of
ridding
himself
of
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
Mrs.
Disbrowe
uttered
a
loud

,
and
fell
back
in
the
bed
.
<EOS>
Parravicin
waited
for
a
moment
;
but
not
hearing
her
move
,
brought
the
lamp
to
see
what
was
the
matter
.
<EOS>
She
had
fainted
,
and
was
lying
across
the
pillow
,
with
her
night
-
dress
partly
open
,
so
as
to
expose

and

.
 
<EOS>
The
knight
was
at
first
ravished
with
her
beauty
;
but
his
countenance
suddenly
fell
,
and
an
expression
of
horror
and
alarm
took
possession
of
it
.
<EOS>
He
appeared
rooted
to
the
spot
,
and
instead
of
attempting
to
render
her
any
assistance
,
remained
with
his
gaze
fixed
upon
her
neck
.
 
<EOS>
Rousing
himself
at
length
,
he
rushed
out
of
the
room
,
hurried
down
stairs
,
and
without
pausing
for
a
moment
,
threw
open
the
street
-
door
.
<EOS>
As
he
issued
from
it
,
his
throat
was
forcibly
griped
,
and
the
point
of
a
sword
was
placed
at
his
breast
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
are
now
in
my
power
,
villain
,
"
cried
Disbrowe
,
"
and
shall
not
escape
my

.
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
are
already
avenged
,
"
replied
Parravicin
,
shaking
off
his
