.
"
<EOS>
Your
wife
has
the
plague
.
"
  
<EOS>
VII
.
 
<EOS>
THE
PLAGUE
NURSE
.
 
<EOS>
"
And
so
my
husband
has
got
the
plague
,
"
muttered
Mother
Malmayns
,
as
she
hastened
towards
Saint
Paul
's
,
after
the
reproof
she
had
received
from
Doctor
Hodges
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
,
it
's
a
disorder
that
few
recover
from
,
and
I
do
n't
think
he
stands
a
better
chance
than
his
fellows
.
<EOS>
I
've
been
troubled
with
him
long
enough
.
<EOS>
I
've
borne
his
ill
-
usage
and
savage
temper
for
twenty
years
,
vainly
hoping
something
would
take
him
off
;
but
though
he
tried
his
constitution
hard
,
it
was
too
tough
to
yield
.
<EOS>
However
,
he
's
likely
to
go
now
.
<EOS>
If
I
find
him
better
than
I
expect
,
I
can
easily
make
all
sure
.
<EOS>
That
's
one
good
thing
about
the
plague
.
<EOS>
You
may
get
rid
of
a
patient
without
any
one
being
the
wiser
.
<EOS>
A
wrong
mixture
--
a
pillow
removed
--
a
moment
's
chill
during
the
fever
--
a
glass
of
cold
water
<EOS>
--
the
slightest
thing
will
do
it
.
<EOS>
Matthew
Malmayns
,
you
will
die
of
the
plague
,
that
's
certain
.
<EOS>
But
I
must
be
careful
how
I
proceed
.
<EOS>
That
cursed
doctor
has
his
eye
upon
me
.
<EOS>
As
luck
would
have
it
,
I
've
got
Sibbald
's
ointment
in
my
pocket
.
<EOS>
That
is
sure
to
do
its
business
--
and
safely
.
"
 
<EOS>
Thus
ruminating
,
she
shaped
her
course
towards
the
southwest
corner
of
the
cathedral
,
and
passing
under
the
shrouds
and
cloisters
of
the
Convocation
House
,
raised
the
latch
of
a
small
wooden
shed
fixed
in
the
angle
of
a
buttress
.
<EOS>
Evidently
well
acquainted
with
the
place
,
she
was
not
long
in
finding
a
lantern
and
materials
to
light
it
,
and
inserting
her
fingers
in
a
crevice
of
the
masonry
,
from
which
the
mortar
had
been
removed
,
she
drew
forth
a
key
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
has
not
been
stirred
since
I
left
it
here
a
month
ago
,
"
she
muttered
.
<EOS>
"
I
must
take
care
of
this
key
,
for
if
Matthew
_
should
_
die
,
I
may
not
be
able
to
enter
the
vaults
of
Saint
Faith
's
without
it
;
and
as
I
know
all
their
secret
places
and
passages
,
which
nobody
else
does
,
except
my
husband
,
I
can
make
them
a
storehouse
for
the
plunder
I
may
obtain
during
the
pestilence
.
<EOS>
If
it
rages
for
a
year
,
or
only
half
that
time
,
and
increases
in
violence
(
as
God
grant
it
may
)
,
I
will
fill
every
hole
in
those
walls
with
gold
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
With
this
,
she
took
up
the
lantern
,
and
crept
along
the
side
of
the
cathedral
,
until
she
came
to
a
flight
of
stone
steps
.
<EOS>
Descending
them
,
she
unlocked
a
small
but
strong
door
,
cased
with
iron
,
and
fastening
it
after
her
,
proceeded
along
a
narrow
stone
passage
,
which
brought
her
to
another
door
,
opening
upon
the
south
aisle
of
Saint
Faith
's
.
 
<EOS>
Pausing
for
a
moment
to
listen
whether
any
one
was
within
the
sacred
structure
--
for
such
was
the
dead
and
awful
silence
of
the
place
,
that
the
slightest
whisper
or
footfall
,
even
at
its
farthest
extremity
,
could
be
distinguished
<EOS>
--
she
crossed
to
the
other
side
,
glancing
fearfully
around
her
as
she
threaded
the
ranks
of
pillars
,
whose
heavy
and
embrowned
shafts
her
lantern
feebly
illumined
,
and
entering
a
recess
,
took
a
small
stone
out
of
the
wall
,
and
deposited
the
chief
part
of
the
contents
of
her
pocket
behind
it
,
after
which
she
carefully
replaced
the
stone
.
<EOS>
This
done
,
she
hurried
to
the
charnel
,
and
softly
opened
the
door
of
the
crypt
.
 
<EOS>
Greatly
relieved
by
the
operation
he
had
undergone
,
the
sexton
had
sunk
into
a
slumber
,
and
was
,
therefore
,
unconscious
of
the
entrance
of
his
wife
,
who
,
setting
down
the
lantern
,
advanced
towards
the
pallet
.
<EOS>
His
mother
and
the
young
man
were
still
in
attendance
,
and
the
former
,
on
seeing
her
daughter
-
in
-
law
,
exclaimed
,
in
low
but
angry
accents--"What
brings
you
here
,
Judith
?
<EOS>
I
suppose
you
expected
to
find
my
son
dead
.
<EOS>
But
he
will
disappoint
you
.
<EOS>
Doctor
Hodges
said
he
would
recover
--
<EOS>
did
he
not
Kerrich
?
<EOS>
"
she

,
appealing
to
the
young
man
,
who
nodded

.
"
<EOS>
He
will
recover
,
I
tell
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Well
,
well
,
"
replied
Judith
,
in
the
blandest
tone
she
could
assume
;
"
I
hope
he
will
.
<EOS>
And
if
the
doctor
says
so
,
I
have
no
doubt
of
it
.
<EOS>
I
only
heard
of
his
illness
a
few
minutes
ago
,
and
came
instantly
to
nurse

.
"
 
<EOS>
"
_
<EOS>
You
_
nurse
him
?
<EOS>
"
cried
the
old
woman
;
"
if
you
show
him
any
affection
now
,
it
will
be
for
the
first
time
since
your
wedding
-
day
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
How
long
has
he
been
unwell
?
<EOS>
"
demanded
Judith
,
with
difficulty
repressing
her
anger
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
was
seized
the
night
before
last
,
"
replied
the
old
woman
;
"
but
he
did
n't
know
what
was
the
matter
with
him
when
it
began
.
<EOS>
I
saw
him
just
before
he
went
to
rest
,
and
he
complained
of
a
slight
illness
,
but
nothing
to
signify
.
<EOS>
He
must
have
passed
a
frightful
night
,
for
the
vergers
found
him
in
the
morning
running
about
Saint
Faith
's
like
a
madman
,
and
dashing
his
spades
and
mattocks
against
the
walls
and
pillars
.
<EOS>
They
secured
him
,
and
brought
him
here
,
and
on
examination
,
he
proved
to
have
the
plague
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
surprise
me
by
what
you
say
,
"
replied
Judith
.
<EOS>
"
During
the
last
month
,
I
have
nursed
more
than
a
dozen
patients
,
and
never
knew
any
of
them
so
violent
.
<EOS>
I
must
look
at
his
sore
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
The
doctor
has
just
dressed
it
,
"
observed
the
old
woman
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
mind
that
,
"
rejoined
Judith
,
turning
down
the
blanket
,
and
examining
her
husband
's
shoulder
.
<EOS>
"
You
are
right
,
"
she
added
,
"
he
is
doing
as
well
as
possible
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
suppose
I
sha
n't
be
wanted
any
more
,
"
observed
Kerrich
,
"
<EOS>
now
you
're
come
back
to
nurse
your
husband
,
Mrs.
Malmayns
?
<EOS>
I
shall
be
glad
to
get
home
to
my
own
bed
,
for
I
do
n't
feel
well
at
all
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
alarm
yourself
,
"
replied
Judith
.
<EOS>
"
There
's
a
bottle
of
plague
vinegar
for
you
.
<EOS>
Dip
<EOS>
a
piece
of
linen
in
it
,
and
smell
at
it
,
and
<EOS>
I
'll
insure
you
against
the
pestilence
.
"
 
<EOS>
Kerrich
took
the
phial
,
and
departed
.
<EOS>
But
the
remedy
was
of
little
avail
.
<EOS>
Before
daybreak
,
he
was
seized
with
the
distemper
,
and
died
two
days
afterwards
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
hope
poor
Kerrich
has
n't
got
the
plague
?
"
said
the
old
woman
,
in
a
tremulous
tone
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
afraid
he
has
,
"
replied
the
daughter
-
in
-
law
,
"
but
I
did
n't
like
to
alarm
him
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Mercy
on
us
!
"
cried
the
other
,
getting
up
.
<EOS>
"
What
a
dreadful
scourge
it
is
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
would
say
so
,
if
you
had
seen
whole
families
swept
off
by
it
,
as
I
have
,
"
replied
Judith
.
<EOS>
"
But
it
mostly
attacks
old
persons
and
children
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Lord
help
us
!
"
<EOS>
cried
the
crone
,
"
<EOS>
I
hope
it
will
spare
me
.
<EOS>
I
thought
my
age
secured
me
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Quite
the
reverse
,
"
replied
Judith
,
desirous
of
exciting
her
mother
-
in
-
law
's
terrors
;
"
quite
the
reverse
.
<EOS>
You
must
take
care
of
yourself
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
But
you
do
n't
think
I
'm
ill
,
do
you
?
"
<EOS>
asked
the
other
,
anxiously
.
 
<EOS>
"
Sit
down
,
and
let
me
look
at
you
,
"
returned
Judith
.
 
<EOS>
And
the
old
woman
tremblingly
obeyed
.
 
<EOS>
"
Well
,
what
do
you
think
of
me
--
what
's
the
matter
?
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
she
asked
,
as
her
daughter
-
in
-
law
eyed
her
for
some
minutes
in
silence
.
<EOS>
"
What
's
the
matter
,
I
say
?
"
 
<EOS>
But
Judith
remained
silent
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
insist
upon
knowing
,
"
continued
the
old
woman
.
 
<EOS>
"
Are
you
able
to
bear
the
truth
?
<EOS>
"
returned
her
daughter
-
in
-
law
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
need
say
no
more
,
"
groaned
the
old
woman
.
<EOS>
"
I
know
what
the
truth
must
be
,
and
will
try
to
bear
it
.
<EOS>
I
will
get
home
as
fast
as
I
can
,
and
put
my
few
affairs
in
order
,
so
that
if
I
am
carried
off
,
I
may
not
go
unprepared
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
had
better
do
so
,
"
replied
her
daughter
-
in
-
law
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
will
take
care
of
my
poor
son
,
Judith
,
"
rejoined
the
old
woman
,
shedding
a
flood
of
tears
.
<EOS>
"
I
would
stay
with
him
,
if
I
thought
I
could
do
him
any
good
;
but
if
I
really
am
infected
,
I
might
only
be
in
the
way
.
<EOS>
Do
n't
neglect
him
--
as
you
hope
for
mercy
hereafter
,
do
not
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Make
yourself
easy
,
mother
,
"
replied
Judith
.
<EOS>
"
I
will
take
every
care
of
him
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Have
you
no
fears
of
the
disorder
yourself
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
the
old
woman
.
 
<EOS>
"
None
whatever
,
"
replied
Judith
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
_
a
safe
woman
_
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
do
not
understand
you
,
"
replied
her
mother
-
in
-
law
,
in
surprise
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
had
the
plague
,
"
replied
Judith
;
"
and
those
who
have
had
it
once
,
never
take
it
a
second
time
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
This
opinion
,
entertained
at
the
commencement
of
the
pestilence
,
it
may
be
incidentally
remarked
,
was
afterwards
found
to
be
entirely
erroneous
;
some
persons
being
known
to
have
the
distemper
three
or
four
times
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
never
let
us
know
you
were
ill
,
"
said
the
old
woman
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
could
not
do
so
,
"
replied
Judith
,
"
and
<EOS>
I
do
n't
know
that
I
should
have
done
if
I
could
.
<EOS>
I
was
nursing
two
sisters
at
a
small
house
in
Clerkenwell
Close
,
and
they
both
died
in
the
night
-
time
,
within
a
few
hours
of
each
other
.
<EOS>
The
next
day
,
as
I
was
preparing
to
leave
the
house
,
I
was
seized
myself
,
and
had
scarcely
strength
to
creep
up
-
stairs
to
bed
.
<EOS>
An
old
apothecary
,
named
Sibbald
,
who
had
brought
drugs
to
the
house
,
attended
me
,
and
saved
my
life
.
<EOS>
In
less
than
a
week
,
I
was
well
again
,
and
able
to
move
about
,
and
should
have
returned
home
,
but
the
apothecary
told
me
,
as
I
had
had
the
distemper
once
,
I
might
resume
my
occupation
with
safety
.
<EOS>
I
did
so
,
and
have
found
plenty
of
employment
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
No
doubt
,
"
rejoined
the
old
woman
;
"
and
you
will
find
plenty
more
--
plenty
more
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
hope
so
,
"
replied
the
other
.
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
!
do
not
give
utterance
to
such
a
dreadful
wish
,
Judith
,
"
rejoined
her
mother
-
in
-
law
.
<EOS>
"
Do
not
let
cupidity
steel
your
heart
to
every
better
feeling
.
"
 
<EOS>
A
slight
derisive
smile
passed
over
the
harsh
features
of
the
plague
-
nurse
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
heed
me
not
,
"
pursued
the
old
woman
.
"
<EOS>
But
a
time
will
come
when
you
will
recollect
my
words
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
content
to
wait
till
then
,
"
rejoined
Judith
.
 
<EOS>
"
Heaven
grant
you
a
better
frame
of
mind
!
"
<EOS>
exclaimed
the
old
woman
.
<EOS>
"
I
must
take
one
last
look
of
my
son
,
for
it
is
not
likely
I
shall
see
him
again
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Not
in
this
world
,
"
thought
Judith
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
conjure
you
,
by
all
that
is
sacred
,
not
to
neglect
him
,
"
said
the
old
woman
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
already
promised
to
do
so
,
"
replied
Judith
,
impatiently
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Good
-
night
,
mother
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
will
be
a
long
good
-
night
to
me
,
I
fear
,
"
returned
the
dame
.
"
<EOS>
Doctor
Hodges
promised
to
send
some
blankets
and
medicine
for
poor
Matthew
.
<EOS>
The
doctor
is
a
charitable
man
to
the
poor
,
and
if
he
learns
I
am
sick
,
he
may
,
perhaps
,
call
and
give
me
advice
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
sure
he
will
,
"
replied
Judith
.
"
<EOS>
Should
the
man
bring
the
blankets
,
I
will
tell
him
to
acquaint
his
master
with
your
condition
.
<EOS>
And
now
take
this
lantern
,
mother
,
and
get
home
as
fast
as
you
can
.
"
 
<EOS>
So
saying
,
she
almost
pushed
her
out
of
the
vault
,
and
closed
the
door
after
her
.
 
<EOS>
"
At
last
I
am
rid
of
her
,
"
she
muttered
.
<EOS>
"
She
would
have
been
a
spy
over
me
.
<EOS>
I
hope
I
have
frightened
her
into
the
plague
.
<EOS>
But
if
she
dies
of
fear
,
it
will
answer
my
purpose
as
well
.
<EOS>
And
now
for
my
husband
.
"
 
<EOS>
Taking
up
the
lamp
,
and
shading
it
with
her
hand
,
she
gazed
at
his
ghastly
countenance
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
slumbers
tranquilly
,
"
she
muttered
,
after
contemplating
him
for
some
time
,
adding
with
a
chuckling
laugh
,
"
it
would
be
a
pity
to
waken
him
.
"
 
<EOS>
And
seating
herself
on
a
stool
near
the
pallet
,
she
turned
over
in
her
mind
in
what
way
she
could
best
execute
her
diabolical
purpose
.
 
<EOS>
While
she
was
thus
occupied
,
the
messenger
from
Doctor
Hodges
arrived
with
a
bundle
of
blankets
and
several
phials
and
pots
of
ointment
.
<EOS>
The
man
offered
to
place
the
blankets
on
the
pallet
,
but
Judith
would
not
let
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
can
do
it
better
myself
,
and
without
disturbing
the
poor
sufferer
,
"
she
said
.
<EOS>
"
Give
my
dutiful
thanks
to
your
master
.
<EOS>
Tell
him
my
husband
's
mother
,
old
widow
Malmayns
,
fancies
herself
attacked
by
the
plague
,
and
if
he
will
be
kind
enough
to
visit
her
,
she
lodges
in
the
upper
attic
of
a
baker
's
house
,
at
the
sign
of
the
Wheatsheaf
,
in
Little
Distaff
-
lane
,
hard
by
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
will
not
fail
to
deliver
your
message
to
the
doctor
,
"
replied
the
man
,
as
he
took
his
departure
.
 
<EOS>
Left
alone
with
her
husband
a
second
time
,
Judith
waited
till
she
thought
the
man
had
got
out
of
the
cathedral
,
and
then
rising
and
taking
the
lamp
,
she
repaired
to
the
charnel
,
to
make
sure
it
was
untenanted
.
<EOS>
Not
content
with
this
,
she
stole
out
into
Saint
Faith
's
,
and
gazing
round
as
far
as
the
feeble
light
of
her
lamp
would
permit
,
called
out
in
a
tone
that
even
startled
herself
,
"
<EOS>
Is
any
one
lurking
there
?
"
<EOS>
but
receiving
no
other
answer
than
was
afforded
by
the
deep
echoes
of
the
place
,
she
returned
to
the
vault
.
<EOS>
Just
as
she
reached
the
door
,
a
loud
cry
burst
upon
her
ear
,
and
rushing
forward
<EOS>
,
she
found
that
her
husband
had
wakened
.
 
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
"
<EOS>
roared
Malmayns
,
raising
himself
in
bed
,
as
he
perceived
her
,
"
are
you
come
back
again
,
<EOS>
you
she
-
devil
?
<EOS>
Where
is
my
mother
?
<EOS>
Where
is
Kerrich
?
<EOS>
What
have
you
done
with
them
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
They
have
both
got
the
plague
,
"
replied
his
wife
.
<EOS>
"
They
caught
it
from
you
.
<EOS>
But
never
mind
them
.
<EOS>
I
will
watch
over
you
as
long
as
you
live
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
And
that
will
be
for
years
,
you
accursed
jade
,
"
replied
the
sexton
;
"
Dr.
Hodges
says
I
shall
recover
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
have
got
worse
since
he
left
you
,
"
replied
Judith
.
<EOS>
"
Lie
down
,
and
let
me
throw
these
blankets
over
you
.
"
 
"
Off
!
"
cried
the
sick
man
,
furiously
.
<EOS>
"
You
shall
not
approach
me
.
<EOS>
You
want
to
smother
me
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
want
to
cure
you
,
"
replied
his
wife
,
heaping
the
blankets
upon
the
pallet
.
<EOS>
"
The
doctor
has
sent
some
ointment
for
your
sore
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Then
let
him
apply
it
himself
,
"
cried
Malmayns
,
shaking
his
fist
at
her
.
<EOS>
"
You
shall
not
touch
me
.
<EOS>
I
will
strangle
you
if
you
come
near
me
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Matthew
,
"
replied
his
wife
,
"
I
have
had
the
plague
myself
,
and
know
how
to
treat
it
better
than
any
doctor
in
London
.
<EOS>
I
will
cure
you
,
if
you
will
let
me
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
no
faith
in
you
,
"
replied
Malmayns
,
"
but
I
suppose
I
must
submit
.
<EOS>
Take
heed
what
you
do
to
me
,
for
if
I
have
but
five
minutes
to
live
,
it
will
be
long
enough
to
revenge
myself
upon
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
will
anoint
your
sore
with
this
salve
,
"
rejoined
Judith
,
producing
a
pot
of
dark
-
coloured
ointment
,
and
rubbing
his
shoulder
with
it
.
<EOS>
"
It
was
given
me
by
Sibbald
,
the
apothecary
of
Clerkenwell
<EOS>
He
is
a
friend
of
Chowles
,
the
coffin
-
maker
.
<EOS>
You
know
Chowles
,
Matthew
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
know
him
for
as
great
a
rascal
as
ever
breathed
,
"
replied
her
husband
,
gruffly
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He
has
always
cheated
me
out
of
my
dues
,
and
his
coffins
are
the
worst
I
ever
put
under
ground
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
He
is
making
his
fortune
now
,
"
said
Judith
.
 
<EOS>
"
By
the
plague
,
eh
?
"
replied
Matthew
.
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
envy
him
.
<EOS>
Money
so
gained
wo
n't
stick
to
him
.
<EOS>
He
will
never
prosper
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
wish
_
<EOS>
you
_
had
his
money
,
Matthew
,
"
replied
his
wife
,
in
a
coaxing
tone
.
 
<EOS>
"
If
the
plague
had
n't
attacked
me
when
it
did
,
I
should
have
been
richer
than
Chowles
will
ever
be
,
"
replied
the
sexton,--"nay
,
I
am
richer
as
it
is
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
surprise
me
,
"
replied
Judith
,
suddenly
pausing
in
her
task
.
<EOS>
"
How
have
you
obtained
your
wealth
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
discovered
a
treasure
,
"
replied
,
the
sexton
,
with
a
mocking
laugh,--"a
secret
hoard
--
a
chest
of
gold
--
ha
!
ha
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
Where
--
where
?
"
demanded
his
wife
,
eagerly
.
 
<EOS>
"
That
's
a
secret
,
"
replied
Matthew
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
must
have
it
from
him
before
he
dies
,
"
thought
his
wife
.
<EOS>
"
Had
we
better
not
secure
it
without
delay
?
<EOS>
"
she
added
,
aloud
.
"
<EOS>
Some
other
person
may
find
it
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
it
's
safe
enough
,
"
replied
Matthew
.
<EOS>
"
It
has
remained
undiscovered
for
more
than
a
hundred
years
,
and
will
continue
so
for
a
hundred
to
come
,
unless
I
bring
it
forth
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
But
you
_
will
_
bring
it
forth
,
wo
n't
you
?
"
said
Judith
.
 
<EOS>
"
Undoubtedly
,
"
replied
Matthew
,
"
if
I
get
better
.
<EOS>
But
not
otherwise
.
<EOS>
Money
would
be
of
no
use
to
me
in
the
grave
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
But
it
would
be
of
use
to
_
me
_
,
"
replied
his
wife
.
 
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
it
might
,
"
replied
the
sexton
;
"
but
if
I
die
,
the
knowledge
of
the
treasure
shall
die
with
me
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
He
is
deceiving
me
,
"
thought
Judith
,
beginning
to
rub
his
shoulder
afresh
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
suspect
you
have
played
me
false
,
you
jade
,
"
cried
Malmayns
,
writhing
with
pain
.
<EOS>
"
The
stuff
you
have
applied
burns
like
caustic
,
and
eats
into
my
flesh
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
doing
its
duty
,
"
replied
his
wife
,
calmly
watching
his
agonies
.
<EOS>
"
You
will
soon
be
easier
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
I
shall
--
in
death
,
"
groaned
the
sufferer
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
parched
with
thirst
.
<EOS>
Give
me
a
glass
of
water
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
shall
have
wine
,
Matthew
,
if
you
prefer
it
.
<EOS>
I
have
a
flask
in
my
pocket
,
"
she
replied
.
<EOS>
"
But
what
of
the
treasure
--
where
is
it
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
Peace
!
"
<EOS>
he
cried
.
<EOS>
"
I
will
baulk
your
avaricious
hopes
.
<EOS>
You
shall
never
know
where
it
is
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
shall
know
as
much
as
you
do
,
"
she
rejoined
,
in
a
tone
of
incredulity
.
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
believe
a
word
you
tell
me
.
<EOS>
You
have
found
no
treasure
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
If
this
is
the
last
word
I
shall
ever
utter
,
I
_
have
_
,
"
he
returned
;
--"a
<EOS>
mighty
treasure
.
<EOS>
But
you
shall
never
possess
it
--
<EOS>
never!--ah
!
ah
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
Nor
shall
you
have
the
wine
,
"
she
replied
;
"
there
is
water
for
you
,
<EOS>
"
she
added
,
handing
him
a
jug
,
which
he
drained
with
frantic
eagerness
.
"
<EOS>
He
is
a
dead
man
,
"
she
muttered
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
chilled
to
the
heart
,
"
grasped
the
sexton
,
shivering
from
head
to
foot
,
while
chill
damps
gathered
on
his
brow
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
done
wrong
in
drinking
the
water
,
and
you
ought
not
to
have
given
it
me
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
asked
for
it
,
"
she
replied
.
<EOS>
"
You
should
have
had
wine
but
for
your
obstinacy
.
<EOS>
But
I
will
save
you
yet
,
if
you
will
tell
me
where
to
find
the
treasure
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Look
for
it
in
my
grave
,
"
he
returned
,
with
a
hideous
grin
.
 
<EOS>
Soon
after
this
,
he
fell
into
a
sort
of
stupor
.
<EOS>
His
wife
could
now
have
easily
put
a
period
to
his
existence
,
but
she
still
hoped
to
wrest
the
secret
from
him
.
<EOS>
She
was
assured
,
moreover
,
that
his
recovery
was
hopeless
.
<EOS>
At
the
expiration
of
about
two
hours
,
he
was
aroused
by
the
excruciating
anguish
of
his
sore
.
<EOS>
He
had
again
become
delirious
,
and
raved
as
before
about
coffins
,
corpses
,
graves
,
and
other
loathsome
matters
.
<EOS>
Seeing
,
from
his
altered
looks
and
the
livid
and
gangrenous
appearance
which
the
tumour
had
assumed
,
that
his
end
was
not
far
off
,
Judith
resolved
not
to
lose
a
moment
,
but
to
try
the
effect
of
a
sudden
surprise
.
<EOS>
Accordingly
,
she
bent
down
her
head
,
and
shouted
in
his
ear
,
"
What
has
become
of
your
treasure
,
Matthew
?
"
 
<EOS>
The
plan
succeeded
to
a
miracle
.
<EOS>
The
dying
man
instantly
raised
himself
.
 
<EOS>
"
My
treasure
!
"
<EOS>
he
echoed
with
a
yell
that
made
the
vault
ring
again
.
"
<EOS>
Well
thought
on
!
<EOS>
I
have
not
secured
it
.
<EOS>
They
are
carrying
it
off
.
<EOS>
I
must
prevent
them
.
"
<EOS>
And
throwing
off
the
coverings
,
he
sprang
out
of
bed
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
shall
have
it
now
,
"
thought
his
wife
.
<EOS>
"
You
are
right
,
"
she
added,--"they
are
carrying
it
off
.
<EOS>
The
vergers
have
discovered
it
.
<EOS>
They
are
digging
it
up
.
<EOS>
We
must
instantly
prevent
them
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
We
must
!
"
shrieked
Malmayns
.
<EOS>
"
Bring
the
light
!
<EOS>
bring
the
light
!
"
<EOS>
And
bursting
open
the
door
,
he
rushed
into
the
adjoining
aisle
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
will
kill
himself
,
and
discover
the
treasure
into
the
bargain
,
"
cried
Judith
,
following
him
.
"
<EOS>
Ah
!
<EOS>
what
do
I
see
!
<EOS>
People
in
the
church
.
<EOS>
Curses
on
them
!
<EOS>
they
have
ruined
my
hopes
.
"
  
<EOS>
VIII
.
 
<EOS>
THE
MOSAICAL
RODS
.
 
<EOS>
In
pursuance
of
their
design
of
seeking
out
an
astrologer
,
Maurice
Wyvil
and
Lydyard
crossed
Cheapside
and
entered
Friday
-
street
.
<EOS>
They
had
not
proceeded
far
,
when
they
perceived
a
watchman
standing
beneath
a
porch
with
a
lantern
in
his
hand
,
and
thinking
it
an
intimation
that
the
house
was
attacked
by
the
plague
,
they
hurried
to
the
opposite
side
of
the
street
,
and
called
to
the
watchman
to
inquire
whether
he
knew
where
Mr.
Lilly
lived
.
 
<EOS>
Ascertaining
that
the
house
they
sought
was
only
a
short
distance
off
,
they
repaired
thither
,
and
knocking
at
the
door
,
<EOS>
a
small
wicket
,
protected
by
a
grating
,
was
open
within
it
,
and
a
sharp
female
voice
inquired
their
business
.
 
<EOS>
"
Give
this
to
your
master
,
sweetheart
,
"
replied
Wyvil
,
slipping
a
purse
through
the
grating
;
"
and
tell
him
that
two
gentlemen
desire
to
consult
him
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
He
is
engaged
just
now
,
"
replied
the
woman
,
in
a
much
softer
tone
;
"
but
I
will
take
your
message
to
him
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
have
more
money
than
wit
,
"
laughed
Lydyard
.
<EOS>
"
You
should
have
kept
back
your
fee
till
you
had
got
the
information
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
In
that
case
I
should
never
have
received
any
,
"
replied
Wyvil
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
taken
the
surest
means
of
obtaining
admission
to
the
house
.
"
 
<EOS>
As
he
spoke
,
the
door
was
unbolted
by
the
woman
,
who
proved
to
be
young
and
rather
pretty
.
<EOS>
She
had
a
light
in
her
hand
,
and
directing
them
to
follow
her
,
led
the
way
to
a
sort
of
anteroom
,
divided
,
as
it
appeared
,
from
a
larger
room
by
a
thick
black
curtain
.
<EOS>
Drawing
aside
the
drapery
,
their
conductress
ushered
them
into
the
presence
of
three
individuals
,
who
were
seated
at
a
table
strewn
with
papers
,
most
of
which
were
covered
with
diagrams
and
,
astrological
calculations
.
 
<EOS>
One
of
these
persons
immediately
rose
on
their
appearance
,
and
gravely
but
courteously
saluted
them
.
<EOS>
He
was
a
tall
man
,
somewhat
advanced
in
life
,
being
then
about
sixty
-
three
,
with
an
aquiline
nose
,
dark
eyes
,
not
yet
robbed
of
their
lustre
,
grey
hair
waving
over
his
shoulders
,
and
a
pointed
beard
and
moustache
.
<EOS>
The
general
expression
of
his
countenance
was
shrewd
and
penetrating
,
and
yet
there
were
certain
indications
of
credulity
about
it
,
showing
that
he
was
as
likely
to
be
imposed
upon
himself
as
to
delude
others
.
<EOS>
It
is
scarcely
necessary
to
say
that
this
way
Lilly
.
 
<EOS>
The
person
on
his
right
,
whose
name
was
John
Booker
,
and
who
,
like
himself
,
was
a
proficient
in
astrology
,
was
so
buried
in
calculation
,
that
he
did
not
raise
his
eyes
from
the
paper
on
the
approach
of
the
strangers
.
<EOS>
He
was
a
stout
man
,
with
homely
but
thoughtful
features
,
and
though
not
more
than
a
year
older
than
Lilly
,
looked
considerably
his
senior
.
<EOS>
With
the
exception
of
a
few
silver
curls
hanging
down
the
back
of
his
neck
,
he
was
completely
bald
;
but
his
massive
and
towering
brow
seemed
to
indicate
the
possession
of
no
ordinary
intellectual
qualities
.
<EOS>
He
was
a
native
of
Manchester
,
and
was
born
in
1601
,
of
a
good
family
.
"
<EOS>
His
excellent
verses
upon
the
twelve
months
,
"
says
Lilly
,
in
his
autobiography
,
"
framed
according
to
the
configurations
of
each
month
,
being
blessed
with
success
according
to
his
predictions
,
procured
him
much
reputation
all
over
England
.
<EOS>
He
was
a
very
honest
man
,
"
continues
the
same
authority
;
"
abhorred
any
deceit
in
the
art
he
studied
;
had
a
curious
fancy
in
judging
of
thefts
;
and
was
successful
in
resolving
love
-
questions
.
<EOS>
He
was
no
mean
proficient
in
astronomy
;
understood
much
in
physic
!
<EOS>
was
a
great
admirer
of
the
antimonial
cup
;
and
not
unlearned
in
chemistry
,
which
he
loved
well
,
but
did
not
practise
.
<EOS>
"
At
the
period
of
this
history
,
he
was
clerk
to
Sir
Hugh
Hammersley
,
alderman
.
 
<EOS>
The
third
person,--a
minor
canon
of
Saint
Paul
's
,
named
Thomas
Quatremain,--was
a
grave
,
sallow
-
complexioned
man
,
with
a
morose
and
repulsive
physiognomy
.
<EOS>
He
was
habited
in
the
cassock
of
a
churchman
of
the
period
,
and
his
black
velvet
cap
lay
beside
him
on
the
table
.
<EOS>
Like
Booker
,
he
was
buried
in
calculations
,
and
though
he
looked
up
for
a
moment
as
the
others
entered
the
room
,
he
instantly
resumed
his
task
,
without
regard
to
their
presence
.
 
<EOS>
After
looking
earnestly
at
his
visitors
for
a
few
moments
,
and
appearing
to
study
their
features
,
Lilly
motioned
them
to
be
seated
;
but
they
declined
the
offer
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
not
come
to
take
up
your
time
,
Mr.
Lilly
,
"
said
Wyvil
,
"
but
simply
to
ask
your
judgment
in
a
matter
in
which
I
am
much
interested
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
First
permit
me
to
return
you
your
purse
,
sir
,
since
it
is
from
you
,
I
presume
,
that
I
received
it
,
"
replied
the
astrologer
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
information
that
I
can
give
deserves
so
large
a
reward
as
this
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
Wyvil
would
have
remonstrated
.
<EOS>
But
seeing
the
other
resolute
,
he
was
fain
to
concede
the
point
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
question
do
you
desire
to
have
resolved
,
sir
?
<EOS>
"
pursued
Lilly
.
 
<EOS>
"
Shall
I
be
fortunate
in
my
hopes
?
"
rejoined
Wyvil
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
must
be
a
little
more
precise
,
"
returned
the
astrologer
.
<EOS>
"
To
what
do
your
hopes
relate?--to
wealth
,
dignity
,
or
love
?
"
 
"
To
the
latter
,
"
replied
Wyvil
.
 
<EOS>
"
So
I
inferred
from
your
appearance
,
sir
,
"
rejoined
Lilly
,
smiling
.
<EOS>
"
Venus
was
strong
in
your
nativity
,
though
well
-
dignified
;
and
I
should
,
therefore
,
say
you
were
not
unfrequently
entangled
in
love
affairs
.
<EOS>
Your
inamorata
,
I
presume
,
is
young
,
perhaps
fair,--blue
-
eyed
,
brown
-
haired
,
tall
,
slender
,
and
yet
perfectly
proportioned
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
She
is
all
you
describe
,
"
replied
Wyvil
.
 
<EOS>
"
Is
she
of
your
own
rank
?
"
asked
Lilly
.
 
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Scarcely
so
,
"
replied
Wyvil
,
hesitating
before
he
answered
the
question
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
will
instantly
erect
a
scheme
,
"
replied
the
astrologer
,
rapidly
tracing
a
figure
on
a
sheet
of
paper
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
question
refers
to
the
seventh
house
.
<EOS>
I
shall
take
Venus
as
the
natural
significatrix
of
the
lady
.
<EOS>
The
moon
is
in
trine
with
the
lord
of
the
ascendant,--so
far
,
good
;
but
there
is
a
cross
aspect
from
Mars
,
who
darts
forth
malicious
rays
upon
them
.
<EOS>
Your
suit
will
probably
be
thwarted
.
<EOS>
But
what
Mars
bindeth
,
Venus
dissolveth
.
<EOS>
It
is
not
wholly
hopeless
.
<EOS>
I
should
recommend
you
to
persevere
.
<EOS>
"
 
"
Juggler
!
"
exclaimed
"
Wyvil
between
his
teeth
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
no
juggler
!
"
<EOS>
replied
Lilly
,
angrily
;
"
and
to
prove
I
am
not
<EOS>
,
I
will
tell
you
who
you
are
who
thus
insult
me
,
though
you
have
not
announced
yourself
,
and
are
desirous
of
preserving
your
_
incognito
_
.
<EOS>
You
are
the
Earl
of
Rochester
,
and
your
companion
is
Sir
George
Etherege
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
'
Fore
heaven
!
<EOS>
we
are
discovered
,
"
cried
the
earl
;
"
but
whether
by
art
,
magic
,
or
from
previous
acquaintance
with
our
features
,
I
pretend
not
to
determine
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
In
either
case
,
my
lord,--for
<EOS>
it
is
useless
,
since
you
have
avowed
yourself
,
to
address
you
longer
as
Wyvil
,
"
replied
<EOS>
Etherege,--"you
owe
Mr.
Lilly
an
apology
for
the
insult
you
have
offered
him
.
<EOS>
It
was
as
undeserved
as
uncalled
for
;
for
he
described
your
position
with
Amabel
exactly
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
sorry
for
what
I
said
,
"
replied
the
earl
,
with
great
frankness
,
"
and
entreat
Mr.
Lilly
to
overlook
it
,
and
impute
it
to
its
real
cause,--disappointment
at
his
judgment
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
wish
I
could
give
you
better
hopes
,
my
lord
,
"
replied
Lilly
;
"
but
I
readily
accept
your
apology
.
<EOS>
Have
you
any
further
questions
to
ask
me
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
Not
to
-
night
,
"
replied
the
earl
;
"
except
that
I
would
gladly
learn
whether
it
is
your
opinion
that
the
plague
will
extend
its
ravages
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
will
extend
them
so
far
,
my
lord
,
that
there
shall
neither
be
buriers
for
the
dead
,
nor
sound
to
look
after
the
sick
,
"
replied
Lilly
.
<EOS>
"
You
may
have
seen
a
little
tract
of
mine
published
in
1651,--some
fourteen
years
<EOS>
ago,--called
'
<EOS>
_
Monarchy
or
No
Monarchy
in
England
_
,
'
in
which
,
by
an
hieroglyphic
,
I
foretold
this
terrible
calamity
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
heard
his
majesty
speak
of
the
book
no
later
than
yesterday
,
"
replied
Rochester
.
<EOS>
"
He
has
the
highest
opinion
of
your
skill
,
Mr.
Lilly
,
as
he
can
not
blind
himself
to
the
fact
that
you
foretold
his
father
's
death
.
<EOS>
But
this
is
not
the
only
visitation
with
which
you
threaten
our
devoted
city
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
threatened
by
Heaven
,
not
by
me
,
my
lord
,
"
replied
Lilly
.
"
<EOS>
London
will
be
devoured
by
plague
and
consumed
by
fire
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
In
our
time
?
"
asked
Etherege
.
 
<EOS>
"
Before
two
years
have
passed
over
our
heads
,
"
returned
the
astrologer
.
<EOS>
"
The
pestilence
originated
in
the
conjunction
of
Saturn
and
Jupiter
in
Sagittarius
,
on
the
10th
of
last
October
,
and
the
conjunction
of
Saturn
and
Mars
in
the
same
sign
,
on
the
12th
of
November
.
<EOS>
It
was
harbingered
also
by
the
terrible
comet
of
January
,
which
appeared
in
a
cadent
and
obscure
house
,
denoting
sickness
and
death
:
and
another
and
yet
more
terrible
comet
,
which
will
be
found
in
the
fiery
triplicity
of
Aries
,
Leo
,
and
Sagittarius
,
will
be
seen
before
the
conflagration
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
My
calculations
are
,
that
the
plague
will
be
at
its
worst
in
August
and
September
,
and
will
not
cease
entirely
till
the
beginning
of
December
,
"
observed
Booker
,
laying
aside
his
pen
.
 
<EOS>
"
And
I
doubt
not
you
are
right
,
sir
,
"
said
Lilly
,
"
for
your
calculations
are
ever
most
exact
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
My
labour
is
not
thrown
away
,
Mr.
Lilly
,
"
cried
Quatremain
,
who
had
finished
his
task
at
the
same
time
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
discovered
what
I
have
long
suspected
,
that
treasure
<EOS>
_
is
_
hidden
in
Saint
Paul
's
Cathedral
.
<EOS>
Mercury
is
posited
in
the
north
angle
of
the
fourth
house
;
the
dragon
's
tail
is
likewise
within
it
;
and
as
Sol
is
the
significator
,
it
must
be
gold
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
True
,
"
replied
Lilly
.
 
<EOS>
"
Furthermore
,
"
proceeded
Quatremain
,
"
as
the
sign
is
earthy
,
the
treasure
must
be
buried
in
the
vaults
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Undoubtedly
,
"
replied
Booker
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
all
impatience
to
search
for
it
,
"
said
Quatremain
.
<EOS>
"
Let
us
go
there
at
once
,
and
make
trial
of
the
mosaical
rods
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
With
all
my
heart
,
"
replied
Lilly
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
lord
,
"
he
added
to
Rochester
,
"
I
must
pray
you
to
excuse
me
.
<EOS>
You
have
heard
what
claims
my
attention
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
,
"
returned
the
earl
,
"
and
should
like
to
accompany
you
in
the
quest
,
if
you
will
permit
me
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
must
address
yourself
to
Mr.
Quatremain
,
"
rejoined
Lilly
.
<EOS>
"
If
he
consents
,
I
can
make
no
objection
.
"
 
<EOS>
The
minor
canon
,
on
being
appealed
to
,
signified
his
acquiescence
,
and
after
some
slight
preparation
,
Lilly
produced
two
hazel
rods
,
and
the
party
set
out
.
 
<EOS>
A
few
minutes
'
walking
brought
them
to
the
northern
entrance
of
the
cathedral
,
where
they
speedily
aroused
the
poor
verger
,
who
began
to
fancy
<EOS>
he
was
to
have
no
rest
that
night
.
<EOS>
On
learning
their
purpose
,
however
,
he
displayed
the
utmost
alacrity
,
and
by
Quatremain
's
directions
went
in
search
of
his
brother
-
verger
,
and
a
mason
,
who
,
being
employed
at
the
time
in
making
repairs
in
the
chantries
,
lodged
within
the
cathedral
.
 
<EOS>
This
occasioned
a
delay
of
a
few
minutes
,
during
which
Rochester
and
Etherege
had
an
opportunity
,
like
that
enjoyed
a
short
time
before
by
Leonard
Holt
,
of
beholding
the
magnificent
effect
of
the
columned
aisles
by
moonlight
.
<EOS>
By
this
time
the
other
verger
,
who
was
a
young
and
active
man
,
and
the
mason
,
arrived
,
and
mattocks
,
spades
,
and
an
iron
bar
being
procured
,
and
a
couple
of
torches
lighted
,
they
descended
to
Saint
Faith
's
.
 
<EOS>
Nothing
more
picturesque
can
be
conceived
than
the
effect
of
the
torchlight
on
the
massive
pillars
and
low
-
browed
roof
of
the
subterranean
church
.
<EOS>
Nor
were
the
figures
inappropriate
to
the
scene
.
<EOS>
Lilly
,
with
the
mosaical
rods
in
his
hand
,
which
he
held
at
a
short
distance
from
the
floor
,
moving
first
to
one
point
,
then
to
another
;
now
lingering
within
the
gloomy
nave
,
now
within
the
gloomier
aisles
;
the
grave
minor
canon
,
who
kept
close
beside
him
,
and
watched
his
movements
with
the
most
intense
anxiety
;
Booker
,
with
his
venerable
head
uncovered
,
and
his
bald
brow
reflecting
the
gleam
of
the
torches
;
the
two
court
gallants
in
their
rich
attire
;
and
the
vergers
and
their
comrade
,
armed
with
the
implements
for
digging;--all
constituted
a
striking
picture
.
<EOS>
And
as
Rochester
stepped
aside
to
gaze
at
it
,
he
thought
he
had
never
beheld
a
more
singular
scene
.
 
<EOS>
Hitherto
,
no
success
had
attended
the
searchers
.
<EOS>
The
mosaical
rods
had
continued
motionless
.
<EOS>
At
length
,
however
,
Lilly
reached
a
part
of
the
wall
where
a
door
appeared
to
have
been
stopped
up
,
and
playing
the
rods
near
it
,
they
turned
one
over
the
other
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
treasure
is
here
!
"
<EOS>
he
exclaimed
.
<EOS>
"
It
is
hidden
beneath
this
flag
.
"
 
<EOS>
Instantly
,
all
were
in
action
.
<EOS>
Quatremain
called
to
his
assistants
to
bring
their
mattocks
and
the
iron
bar
.
<EOS>
Rochester
ran
up
and
tendered
his
aid
;
Etherege
did
the
same
;
and
in
a
few
moments
the
flag
was
forced
from
its
position
.
 
<EOS>
On
examination
,
it
seemed
as
if
the
ground
beneath
it
had
been
recently
disturbed
,
though
it
was
carefully
trodden
down
.
<EOS>
But
without
stopping
to
investigate
the
matter
,
the
mason
and
the
younger
verger
commenced
digging
.
<EOS>
When
they
were
tired
,
Lilly
and
Quatremain
took
their
places
,
and
in
less
than
an
hour
they
had
got
to
the
depth
of
upwards
of
four
feet
.
<EOS>
Still
nothing
had
been
found
,
and
Lilly
was
just
about
to
relinquish
his
spade
to
the
mason
,
<EOS>
when
,
plunging
it
more
deeply
into
the
ground
,
it
struck
against
some
hard
substance
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
here
--
we
have
it
!
"
<EOS>
he
cried
,
renewing
his
exertions
.
 
<EOS>
Seconded
by
Quatremain
,
they
soon
cleared
off
the
soil
,
and
came
to
what
appeared
to
be
a
coffin
or
a
large
chest
.
<EOS>
Both
then
got
out
of
the
pit
to
consider
how
they
should
remove
the
chest
;
the
whole
party
were
discussing
the
matter
,
when
a
tremendous
crash
,
succeeded
by
a
terrific
yell
,
was
heard
at
the
other
end
of
the
church
,
and
a
ghastly
and
half
-
naked
figure
,
looking
like
a
corpse
broken
from
the
tomb
,
rushed
forward
with
lightning
swiftness
,
and
shrieking--"My
treasure!--my
treasure!--you
shall
not
have
it!"--thrust
aside
the
group
,
and
plunged
into
the
excavation
.
 
<EOS>
When
the
bystanders
recovered
sufficient
courage
to
drag
the
unfortunate
sexton
out
of
the
pit
,
they
found
him
quite
dead
.
  
<EOS>
IX
.
 
<EOS>
THE
MINIATURE
.
 
<EOS>
According
to
his
promise
,
Doctor
Hodges
visited
the
grocer
's
house
early
on
the
following
day
,
and
the
favourable
opinion
he
had
expressed
respecting
Stephen
Bloundel
was
confirmed
by
the
youth
's
appearance
.
<EOS>
The
pustule
had
greatly
increased
in
size
;
but
this
the
doctor
looked
upon
as
a
good
sign
:
and
after
applying
fresh
poultices
,
and
administering
a
hot
posset
-
drink
,
he
covered
the
patient
with
blankets
,
and
recommending
as
much
tranquillity
as
possible
,
he
proceeded
,
at
Bloundel
's
request
,
to
ascertain
the
state
of
health
of
the
rest
of
the
family
.
<EOS>
Satisfied
that
all
the
household
(
including
Blaize
,
who
,
being
a
little
out
of
order
from
the
quantity
of
medicine
he
had
swallowed
,
kept
his
bed
)
<EOS>
were
uninfected
,
he
went
upstairs
,
and
finding
the
two
boys
quite
well
,
and
playing
with
their
little
sister
Christiana
,
in
the
happy
unconsciousness
of
childhood
,
he
tapped
at
the
door
of
Mrs.
Bloundel
's
chamber
,
and
was
instantly
admitted
.
<EOS>
Amabel
did
not
raise
her
eyes
at
his
entrance
,
but
continued
the
employment
on
which
she
was
engaged
.
<EOS>
Her
mother
,
however
,
overwhelmed
him
with
inquiries
as
to
the
sufferer
,
and
entreated
him
to
prevail
upon
her
husband
to
let
her
take
his
place
at
the
sick
bed
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
can
not
accede
to
your
request
,
madam
,
"
replied
Hodges
;
"
because
I
think
the
present
arrangement
the
best
that
could
be
adopted
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
And
am
I
not
to
see
poor
Stephen
again
?
<EOS>
"
cried
Mrs.
Bloundel
,
bursting
into
tears
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
hope
you
will
soon
see
him
again
,
and
not
lose
sight
of
him
for
many
years
to
come
,
"
replied
the
doctor
.
<EOS>
"
As
far
as
I
can
judge
,
the
danger
is
over
,
and
,
aided
by
your
husband
's
care
and
watchfulness
,
I
have
little
doubt
of
bringing
the
youth
round
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
reconcile
me
to
the
deprivation
,
doctor
,
"
rejoined
Mrs.
Bloundel
;
"
but
can
you
insure
my
husband
against
the
distemper
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
can
insure
no
one
against
contagion
,
"
replied
Hodges
;
"
but
there
is
much
in
his
favour
.
<EOS>
He
has
no
fear
,
and
takes
every
needful
precaution
.
<EOS>
You
must
hope
for
the
best
.
<EOS>
I
think
it
right
to
tell
you
,
that
you
will
be
separated
from
him
for
a
month
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Separated
from
my
husband
for
a
month
,
doctor
!
"
cried
Mrs.
Bloundel
.
<EOS>
"
I
must
see
him
to
-
day
.
<EOS>
I
have
something
of
importance
to
say
to
him
.
"
 
<EOS>
At
this
point
of
the
conversation
Amabel
for
the
first
time
looked
up
.
<EOS>
Her
eyes
were
red
and
inflamed
with
weeping
,
and
her
looks
betrayed
great
internal
suffering
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
can
not
see
my
father
,
mother
,
"
she
said
in
a
broken
and
supplicatory
tone
.
 
<EOS>
"
But
she
can
write
to
him
,
or
send
a
message
by
me
,
"
rejoined
Hodges
.
<EOS>
"
I
will
deliver
it
when
I
go
downstairs
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
What
my
mother
has
to
say
can
not
be
confided
to
a
third
party
,
sir
,
"
returned
Amabel
.
 
<EOS>
"
Better
defer
it
,
then
,
"
said
the
doctor
,
who
,
as
he
looked
hard
at
her
,
and
saw
the
colour
mount
to
her
cheeks
,
began
to
suspect
something
of
the
truth
.
<EOS>
"
Whatever
you
have
to
say
,
Mrs.
Bloundel
,
may
be
very
well
delayed
;
for
the
house
is
now
closed
,
with
a
watchman
at
the
door
,
and
will
continue
so
for
a
month
to
come
.
<EOS>
No
one
can
quit
it
,
except
members
of
our
profession
,
searchers
,
nurses
,
and
other
authorized
persons
,
during
that
time
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
But
can
no
one
enter
it
,
do
you
think
?
"
asked
Mrs.
Bloundel
.
 
<EOS>
"
No
one
would
desire
to
do
so
<EOS>
,
I
should
conceive
,
except
a
lover
,
"
replied
Hodges
,
with
a
sly
look
at
Amabel
,
who
instantly
averted
her
gaze
.
<EOS>
"
Where
a
pretty
girl
is
concerned
,
the
plague
itself
has
no
terrors
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Precisely
my
opinion
,
doctor
,
"
rejoined
Mrs.
Bloundel
;
"
and
as
I
can
not
consult
my
husband
,
perhaps
you
will
favour
me
with
your
advice
as
to
how
I
ought
to
act
,
if
such
a
person
as
you
describe
should
get
into
the
house
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
seldom
meddle
with
family
matters
,
"
rejoined
Hodges
;
"
but
I
feel
so
much
interest
in
all
that
relates
to
Mr.
Bloundel
,
that
I
am
induced
to
depart
from
my
rule
on
the
present
occasion
.
<EOS>
It
is
evident
you
have
lost
your
heart
,
"
he
added
,
to
Amabel
,
whose
blushes
told
him
he
was
right
;
"
but
not
,
I
hope
,
to
one
of
those
worthless
court
-
gallants
,
who
,
as
I
learn
from
common
report
,
are
in
the
habit
of
toasting
you
daily
.
<EOS>
If
it
is
so
,
you
must
subdue
your
passion
;
for
it
can
not
lead
to
good
.
<EOS>
Be
not
dazzled
by
a
brilliant
exterior
,
which
often
conceals
a
treacherous
heart
;
but
try
to
fix
your
affections
on
some
person
of
little
pretension
,
but
of
solid
worth
.
<EOS>
Never
,
I
grieve
to
say
,
was
there
a
season
when
such
universal
profligacy
prevailed
as
at
present
.
<EOS>
Never
was
it
so
necessary
for
a
young
maiden
,
possessed
of
beauty
like
yours
,
to
act
with
discretion
.
<EOS>
Never
was
a
court
so
licentious
as
that
of
our
sovereign
,
Charles
the
Second
,
whose
corrupt
example
is
imitated
by
every
one
around
him
,
while
its
baneful
influence
extends
to
all
classes
.
<EOS>
Were
I
to
echo
the
language
of
the
preachers
,
I
should
say
it
was
owing
to
the
wickedness
and
immorality
of
the
times
that
this
dreadful
judgment
of
the
plague
has
been
inflicted
upon
us
;
but
I
merely
bring
it
forward
as
an
argument
to
prove
to
you
,
Amabel
,
that
if
you
would
escape
the
moral
contagion
by
which
you
are
threatened
,
you
must
put
the
strictest
guard
upon
your
conduct
.
"
 
<EOS>
Amabel
faintly
murmured
her
thanks
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
speak
as
my
husband
himself
would
have
spoken
,
"
said
Mrs.
Bloundel
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ah
!
<EOS>
we
little
thought
,
when
we
prayed
that
the
pestilence
might
be
averted
from
us
,
that
a
worse
calamity
was
behind
,
and
that
one
of
the
most
profligate
of
the
courtiers
you
have
mentioned
would
find
his
way
to
our
house
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
One
of
the
most
profligate
of
them
?
"
cried
Hodges
.
<EOS>
"
Who
,
in
Heaven
's
name
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
He
calls
himself
Maurice
Wyvil
,
"
replied
Mrs.
Bloundel
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
never
heard
of
such
a
person
,
"
rejoined
the
doctor
.
<EOS>
"
It
must
be
an
assumed
name
.
<EOS>
Have
you
no
letter
or
token
that
might
lead
to
his
discovery
?
"
<EOS>
he
added
,
turning
to
Amabel
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
his
portrait
,
"
she
replied
,
drawing
a
small
miniature
from
her

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
glad
I
have
seen
this
,
"
said
the
doctor
,
slightly
starting
as
he
cast
his
eyes
upon
it
.
<EOS>
"
I
hope
it
is
not
too
late
to
save
you
,
Amabel
,
"
he
added
,
in
a
severe
tone
.
<EOS>
"
I
hope
you
are
free
from
contamination
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
As
I
live
,
I
am
,
"
she
replied
.
<EOS>
"
But
you
recognise
the
likeness
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
do
,
"
returned
Hodges
.
<EOS>
"
It
is
the
portrait
of
one
whose
vices
and
depravity
are
the
town
's
cry
,
and
whose
name
coupled
with
that
of
a
woman
,
is
sufficient
to
sully
her
reputation
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
the
Earl
of
Rochester
,
"
said
Mrs.
Bloundel
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
have
guessed
aright
,
"
replied
the
doctor
;
"
it
is
.
"
 
<EOS>
Uttering
an
exclamation
of
surprise
and
terror
,
Amabel
fell
back
in
her
chair
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
thought
it
must
be
that
wicked
nobleman
,
"
cried
Mrs.
Bloundel
.
<EOS>
"
Would
you
believe
it
,
doctor
,
that
he
forced
himself
into
the
house
--
nay
,
into
this
room
--
last
night
,
and
would
have
carried
off
my
daughter
,
in
spite
of
her
resistance
,
if
I
had
not
prevented
him
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
can
believe
anything
of

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
But
your
husband
,
of

,
knows
nothing
of
the
matter
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
Not
as
yet
,
"
replied
Mrs.
Bloundel
;
"
but
I
authorize
you
to
tell
him
all
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Mother
,
dear
mother
,
"
cried
Amabel
,
flinging

on
her

before
her
,
"
I
implore
you
not
to
add
to
my
father
's
present
distress
.
<EOS>
I
might
not
have
been
able
to
conquer
my
attachment
to
Maurice
Wyvil
,
but
now
that
I
find
he
is
the
Earl
of
Rochester
,
I
regard
him
with
abhorrence
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
If
I
could
believe
you
sincere
,
"
said
Mrs.
Bloundel
,
"
I
might
be
induced
to
spare
your
father
the
pain
which
the
knowledge
of
this

affair
would
necessarily

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
sincere,--indeed
<EOS>
I
am
,
"
replied
Amabel
.
 
<EOS>
"
To
prove
that
the
earl
could
not
have
had
honourable

towards

,
Amabel
,
"
said

doctor
,
"
I
may
mention
that
he
is

suit

Mistress
Mallet,--a
young

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
"

Amabel
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
was
in

upon
Mistress
Stewart
,
the
king
's
present
favourite
,
the
day
before
yesterday
,
"
continued
Hodges
,
"
and
heard

majesty
entreat
her
to
use
her

with
Mistress
Mallet
in
Rochester
's
behalf
.
<EOS>
After
this
,
you
can
not
doubt
the
nature
of
his

towards

.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
cannot
--
<EOS>
I
can
not
,
"
rejoined
Amabel
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He
is
perfidy
itself
.
<EOS>
But
is
Mistress
Mallet
very

,
doctor
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Very
beautiful
,

,
"
he

,
"
and
the
earl
is
desperately
in

with

.
<EOS>
I

him
declare
laughingly
to

,
that

,
he

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Just
what
he
said

,
"

and
faithless
that
he
is
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
Harp
on
that
string
,
doctor
,
"

Bloundel
.
<EOS>
"
You
understand
her
feelings

.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Strangely
enough
,
"
pursued

doctor
,
who
,

,
had
opened
the
back

case
,
and
could
not

smile
at
what
he

,
this

picture
will
convince

of

's

.
<EOS>
It
was

designed
for
Mistress
Mallet
,
and
,
as
she
would

,
transferred

.
"
 
<EOS>
"
How
do
you
know
this
,

?
"
<EOS>

,
in

.
 
<EOS>
"
Hear
what
is
written
within

,
"

,

,

:
"
'
<EOS>
To

of

,

,

--
ROCHESTER
.
'
'
<EOS>
The
_
sole
_

his
heart
!
'
<EOS>
So
you
have
no
share
in
it
<EOS>
,

,
Amabel
.
'
<EOS>
Her

slave
!
'
<EOS>
Is
he
your
slave
likewise
?
<EOS>
Ha
!
ha
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
<EOS>
_
is
_
<EOS>
his
writing
,
"

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
This
note
,
"
she

,

,
"
is
in

same

.
<EOS>
My

are
indeed
open
to
his
treachery
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
glad
to

,
"
replied
Hodges
,
"
and
if
I

preserve

from

this
noble

,
I

as

brother
of

.
<EOS>
But
can
you
rely
upon

,

should
make

to

?
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
can
,
"
she
averred
confidently
.
 
<EOS>
"
In
that
case
there
is
nothing
to
apprehend
,
"
rejoined
Hodges
;
"
and
I
think
it
better
on
many

not
to
mention
the

to
your
father
.
<EOS>
It
would
only
distract
his
mind
,
and
prevent
him
from
duly
discharging
the
painful
task
he
has

.
<EOS>
Were
I
in
your

,
<EOS>
Amabel
,
I
would
not
only
forget
my
present
perfidious
lover
,
but
would
instantly
bestow
my
affections
on
some
worthy

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
It

gladden

if

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
There

's

,
Leonard
Holt
,

-

,

,
"

;
"
and

much
mistake
if

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
sure
he
loves

,

,
"

Bloundel
.
<EOS>
"
He
is

-

as

-

.
<EOS>
I
have
never

to
find

.
<EOS>
It
will

,
and
I

,

Holt
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Well
,

,
Amabel
?
"

.
<EOS>
"
Can
you
give
him
a
hope
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
Alas
,
no
!
"
replied
Amabel
;
"
I
have
been
deceived
once
,
but
I
will
not
be
deceived
a
second
time
.
<EOS>
I
will
never
we
d
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
So
every
woman
says
after
her
first
disappointment
,
"
observed
Hodges
;
"
but
not
one
in
ten
adheres
to
the
resolution
.
<EOS>
When
you
become
calmer
,
I
would
recommend
you
to
think
seriously
of
Leonard
Holt
.
"
 
<EOS>
At
this
moment
,
a
tap
was
heard
at
the
door
,
and
opening

,
the
doctor
beheld
the
person
in
question
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
is
the
matter
?
"
<EOS>
cried
Hodges
.
<EOS>
"
I
hope
nothing
is
amiss
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Nothing
whatever
,
"
replied
Leonard
,
"
but
my
master
wishes
to
see
you
before
you
leave
the
house
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
will
go
to
him
at
once
,
"
replied
the
doctor
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Good
day
,
Mrs.
Bloundel
.
<EOS>
Take
care
of
your
daughter
,
and
I
hope
she
will

.
<EOS>
We
have
been
talking
about
you
,
young
man
,
"
he

in

low

to
the

,
"
and
I
have
recommended
you
as
a

to
Amabel
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
There
was
a
time
,
sir
,
"
rejoined
Leonard
,
in
a
tone
of
deep
emotion
,
"
when
I
hoped
it
might
be
so
,
but
that
time
is
past
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
No
such
thing
,
"
replied
the
doctor
.
"
<EOS>
Now
is
the
time
to
make
an
impression
.
<EOS>
Her
heart
is
on
the
rebound
.
<EOS>
She
is
satisfied
of
her
lover
's
treachery
.
<EOS>
Her
mother
is
on
your
side
.
<EOS>
Do
not
neglect
the
present
opportunity
,
for
another
may
not
arrive
.
<EOS>
"
With

he
pushed
Leonard
into

room
,
and
,

,
hurried

.
 
<EOS>
"
You
have
arrived
at
a
seasonable
juncture
,
Leonard
,
"
observed
Mrs.
Bloundel
,
noticing
the
apprentice
's

,
and

.
<EOS>
"
We
have
just
discovered
that
the

Maurice
Wyvil
is
no
other
than
the
Earl
of
Rochester
.
"
 
"
Indeed
!
"

Leonard
.
 
<EOS>
"
Yes
,

,
"
returned
Mrs.
Bloundel
.
<EOS>
"
But
this
is
not
all
.
<EOS>
Amabel
has
promised
to
forget
him
,
and
I
have
urged
her
to
think
of
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Amabel
,
"
said
Leonard
,
advancing
towards
her
,
and
taking
her
hand
,
"
I
can
scarcely
credit
what
I
hear
.
<EOS>
Will
you
confirm
your
mother
's
words
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Leonard
,
"
returned
Amabel
,
"
I
am
not
insensible
to
your
good
qualities
,
and
no
one
can
more
truly
esteem
you
than
I
do
.
<EOS>
Nay
,
till
I
unfortunately
saw
the
Earl
of
Rochester
,
whom
I
knew
not
as
such
,
I
might
have
loved
you
.
<EOS>
But
now
I
can
not
call
my
heart
my
own
.
<EOS>
I
have
not
the
affection
you
deserve
to
bestow
upon
you
.
<EOS>
If
I
can
obliterate
this
treacherous
man
's
image
from
my
memory
--
and
Heaven
,
I
trust
,
will
give
me
strength
to
do
so
--
I
will
strive
to
replace
it
with
your
own
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
That
is
all
I
ask
,
"
cried
Leonard
,
dropping
on
his
knee
before
her
,
and
pressing
his
lips
to
her
hand
.
 
<EOS>
"
Nothing
would
make
me
happier
than
to
see
you
united
,
my
children
,
"
said
Mrs.
Bloundel
,
bending
affectionately
over
them
.
 
<EOS>
"
And
I
would
do
anything
to
make
you
happy
,
<EOS>
dear
mother
,
"
replied
Amabel
,
gently
withdrawing
her
hand
,
from
that
of
the
apprentice
.
 
<EOS>
"
Before
I
leave
you
,
"
said
Leonard
,
rising
,
"
I
must
give
you
this
note
.
<EOS>
I
found
it
lying
before
your
chamber
door
as
I
passed
this
morning
.
<EOS>
How
it
came
there
I
know
not
,
but
I
can
give
a
shrewd
guess
as
to
the
writer
.
<EOS>
I
ought
to
tell
you
,
that
but
for
what
has
just
occurred
,
I
should
not
have
delivered
it
to
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
from
Wyvil
--
I
mean
Rochester
,
"
said
Amabel
,
taking
the
note
with
a
trembling
hand
.
 
<EOS>
"
Let
me
see
it
,
child
,
"
cried
Mrs.
Bloundel
,
snatching
it
from
her
,
and
breaking
the
seal
.
<EOS>
"
Insolent
!
"
<EOS>
she
exclaimed
,
as
she
cast
her
eyes
over
it
.
<EOS>
"
I
can
scarcely
contain
my
indignation
.
<EOS>
But
let
him
cross
my
path
again
,
and
he
shall
find
whether
I
can
not
resent
such
shameful
usage
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
What
does
he
say
,
dear
mother
?
"
asked
Amabel
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
shall
hear
,
"
replied
Mrs.
Bloundel
,
"
though
I
blush
to
repeat
his
words
:
'
Amabel
,
you
are
mine
.
<EOS>
No
one
shall
keep
you
from
me
.
<EOS>
Love
like
mine
will
triumph
over
all
obstacles!'--Love
like
his
,
forsooth
!
"
<EOS>
she
remarked
;
"
let
him
keep
such
stuff
as
that
for
Mistress
Mallet
,
or
his
other
mistresses
.
<EOS>
But
I
will
go
on
:
'
I
may
be
foiled
ninety
-
nine
times
,
but
the
hundredth
will
succeed
.
<EOS>
We
shall
soon
meet
again
.
  
<EOS>
'
MAURICE
WYVIL
.
'
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Never
!
"
cried
Amabel
.
<EOS>
"
We
will
never
meet
again
.
<EOS>
If
he
holds
me
thus
cheaply
,
I
will
let
him
see
that
he
is
mistaken
.
<EOS>
Leonard
Holt
,
I
have
told
you
the
exact
state
of
my
feelings
.
<EOS>
I
do
not
love
you
now
,
but
I
regard
you
as
a
true
friend
,
and
love
may
come
hereafter
.
<EOS>
If
in
a
month
's
time
you
claim
my
hand
;
if
my
father
consents
to
our
union
,
for
you
are
aware
that
my
mother
will
not
oppose
it
--
I
am
yours
.
"
 
<EOS>
Leonard
attempted
to
speak
,
but
his
voice
was
choked
with
emotion
,
and
the
tears
started
to
his
eyes
.
 
<EOS>
"
Farewell
,
"
said
Amabel
.
<EOS>
"
Do
not
let
us
meet
till
the
appointed
time
.
<EOS>
Rest
assured
,
I
will
think
of
you
as
you
deserve
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
We
could
not
meet
till
that
time
,
even
if
you
desired
it
,
"
said
Leonard
,
"
for
your
father
has
forbidden
any
of
the
household
,
except
old
Josyna
,
to
approach
you
till
all
fear
of
contagion
is
at
an
end
,
and
I
am
now
transgressing
his
commands
.
<EOS>
But
your
mother
,
I
am
sure
,
will
acquit
me
of
intentional
disobedience
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
do
,
"
replied
Mrs.
Bloundel
;
"
it
was
the
doctor
who
forced
you
into
the
room
.
<EOS>
But
I
am
heartily
glad
he
did
so
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Farewell
,
Amabel
,
"
said
Leonard
.
<EOS>
"
Though
I
shall
not
see
you
,
I
will
watch
carefully
over
you
.
"
<EOS>
And
gazing
at
her
with
unutterable
affection
,
he
quitted
the
chamber
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
must
now
choose
between
the
heartless
and
depraved
nobleman
,
who
would
desert
you
as
soon
as
won
,
"
observed
Mrs.
Bloundel
,
"
and
the
honest
apprentice
,
whose
life
would
be
devoted
to
your
happiness
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
_
have
_
chosen
,
"
replied
her
daughter
.
 
<EOS>
Doctor
Hodges
found
the
grocer
writing
at
a
small
table
,
close
to
the
bedside
of
his
son
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
happy
to
tell
you
,
Mr.
Bloundel
,
"
he
said
,
in
a
low
tone
,
as
he
entered
the
room
,
"
that
all
your
family
are
still
free
from
infection
,
and
with
due
care
will
,
I
hope
,
continue
so
.
<EOS>
But
I
entirely
approve
of
your
resolution
of
keeping
apart
from
them
till
the
month
has
expired
.
<EOS>
If
your
son
goes
on
as
he
is
doing
now
,
he
will
be
as
strong
as
ever
in
less
than
a
fortnight
.
<EOS>
Still
,
as
we
can
not
foresee
what
may
occur
,
it
is
better
to
err
on
the
cautious
side
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Pray
be
seated
for
a
moment
,
"
rejoined
the
grocer
,
motioning
the
other
to
the
chair
.
<EOS>
"
I
mentioned
to
you
last
night
that
in
case
my
son
recovered
,
I
had
a
plan
which
I
trusted
(
under
Providence
!
)
<EOS>
would
preserve
my
family
from
the
further
assaults
of
the
pestilence
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
remember
your
alluding
to
it
,
"
replied
Hodges
,
"
and
should
be
glad
to
know
what
it
is
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
must
tell
it
you
in
confidence
,
"
rejoined
Bloundel
,
"
because
I
think
secresy
essential
to
its
entire
accomplishment
.
<EOS>
My
plan
is
a
very
simple
one
,
and
only
requires
firmness
in
its
execution
--
and
that
quality
,
I
think
,
I
possess
.
<EOS>
It
is
your
opinion
,
I
know
,
as
it
is
my
own
,
that
the
plague
will
increase
in
violence
and
endure
for
months
--
probably
,
till
next
winter
.
<EOS>
My
intention
is
to
store
my
house
with
provisions
,
as
a
ship
is
victualled
for
a
long
voyage
,
and
then
to
shut
it
up
entirely
till
the
scourge
ceases
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
If
your
project
is
practicable
,
"
said
Hodges
,
after
a
moment
's
reflection
,
"
I
have
no
doubt
it
will
be
attended
,
with
every
good
result
you
can
desire
.
<EOS>
This
house
,
which
is
large
and
roomy
,
is
well
adapted
for
your
purpose
.
<EOS>
But
you
must
consider
well
whether
your
family
will
submit
to
be
imprisoned
during
the
long
period
you
propose
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
They
shall
remain
close
prisoners
,
even
if
the
pestilence
lasts
for
a
twelvemonth
,
"
replied
the
grocer
.
<EOS>
"
Whoever
quits
the
house
,
when
it
is
once
closed
,
and
on
whatever
plea
,
be
it
wife
,
son
,
or
daughter
,
returns
not
.
<EOS>
That
is
my
fixed
resolve
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
And
you
are
right
,
"
rejoined
Hodges
,
"
for
on
that
determination
the
success
of
your
scheme
entirely
depends
.
<EOS>
"
 
While
they
were
thus
conversing
,
Leonard
entered
the
chamber
,
and
informed
his
master
that
Chowles
,
the
coffin
-
maker
,
and
Mrs.
Malmayns
,
the
plague
-
nurse
,
desired
to
see
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
Mrs.
Malmayns
!
<EOS>
"
exclaimed
Hodges
,
in
surprise
.
<EOS>
"
I
heard
that
something
very
extraordinary
occurred
last
night
in
Saint
Faith
's
.
<EOS>
With
your
permission
,
Mr.
Bloundel
,
she
shall
be
admitted
;
I
want
to
ask
her
a
few
questions
.
<EOS>
You
had
better
hesitate
about
engaging
her
,
"
he
observed
to
the
grocer
,
as
Leonard
departed
,
"
for
she
is
a
woman
of
very
indifferent
character
,
though
she
may
(
for
aught
I
know
)
be
a
good
and
fearless
nurse
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
If
there
is
any
doubt
about
her
,
I
_
can
not
_
hesitate
,
"
returned
Bloundel
.
 
<EOS>
As
he
said
this
,
the
door
was
opened
by
Leonard
,
and
Chowles
and
Judith
entered
the
room
.
<EOS>
The
latter
,
on
seeing
the
doctor
,
looked
greatly
embarrassed
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
brought
you
the
nurse
I
spoke
of
,
Mr.
Bloundel
,
"
said
Chowles
,
bowing
,
"
and
am
come
to
inquire
whether
you
want
a
coffin
to
-
night
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Mr.
Bloundel
is
not
likely
to
require
a
coffin
at
present
,
Chowles
,
"
returned
the
doctor
,
severely
;
"
neither
does
his
son
stand
in
need
of
a
nurse
.
<EOS>
How
is
your
husband
,
Mrs.
Malmayns
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
He
is
dead
,
sir
,
"
replied
Judith
.
 
<EOS>
"
Dead
!
"
echoed
the
doctor
.
<EOS>
"
When
I
left
him
at
one
o'clock
this
morning
,
he
was
doing
well
.
<EOS>
Your
attendance
seems
to
have
accelerated
his
end
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
His
death
was
occasioned
by
an
accident
,
sir
,
"
replied
Judith
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He
became
delirious
about
three
o'clock
,
and
,
in
spite
of
all
my
efforts
to
detain
him
,
started
out
of
bed
,
rushed
into
Saint
Faith
's
,
and
threw
himself
into
a
pit
,
which
Mr.
Lilly
and
some
other
persons
had
digged
in
search
of
treasure
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
This
is
a
highly
improbable
story
,
Mrs.
Malmayns
,
"
returned
Hodges
,
"
and
I
must
have
the
matter
thoroughly
investigated
before
I
lose
sight
of
you
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
will
vouch
for
the
truth
of
Mrs.
Malmayn
's
statement
,
"
interposed
Chowles
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Hodges
,
contemptuously
.
 
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
I
,
"
replied
the
coffin
-
maker
.
<EOS>
"
It
seems
that
the
sexton
had
found
a
chest
of
treasure
buried
in
Saint
Faith
's
,
and
being
haunted
by
the
idea
that
some
one
was
carrying
it
off
,
he
suddenly
sprang
out
of
bed
,
and
rushed
to
the
church
,
where
,
sure
enough
,
Mr.
Lilly
,
Mr.
Quatremain
,
the
Earl
of
Rochester
,
and
Sir
George
Etherege
,
having
,
by
the
help
of
mosaical
rods
,
discovered
this
very
chest
,
were
digging
it
up
.
<EOS>
Poor
Matthew
instantly
plunged
into
the
grave
,
and
died
of
a
sudden
chill
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
That
is
not
impossible
,
"
observed
Hodges
,
after
a
pause
.
<EOS>
"
But
what
has
become
of
the
treasure
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
in
the
possession
of
Mr.
Quatremain
,
who
has
given
notice
of
it
to
the
proper
authorities
,
"
replied
Chowles
.
<EOS>
"
It
consists
,
as
I
understand
,
of
gold
pieces
struck
in
the
reign
of
Philip
and
Mary
,
images
of
the
same
metal
,
crosses
,
pyxes
,
chalices
,
and
other
Popish
and
superstitious
vessels
,
buried
,
probably
,
when
Queen
Elizabeth
came
to
the
throne
,
and
the
religion
changed
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Not
unlikely
,
"
replied
Hodges
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Where
is
your
husband
's
body
,
Mrs.
Malmayns
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
has
been
removed
to
the
vault
which
he
usually
occupied
,
"
replied
Judith
.
"
<EOS>
Mr.
Chowles
has
undertaken
to
bury
it
to
-
night
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
must
see
it
first
,
"
replied
Hodges
,
"
and
be
sure
that
he
has
not
met
with
foul
play
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
And
I
will
accompany
you
,
"
said
Chowles
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
So
you
do
not
want
a
coffin
,
Mr.
Bloundel
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
The
grocer
shook
his
head
.
 
<EOS>
"
Good
day
,
Mr.
Bloundel
,
"
said
Hodges
.
<EOS>
"
I
shall
visit
you
to
-
morrow
,
and
hope
to
find
your
son
as
well
as
I
leave
him
.
<EOS>
Chowles
,
you
will
be
answerable
for
the
safe
custody
of
Mrs.
Malmayns
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
no
desire
to
escape
,
sir
,
"
replied
the
nurse
.
<EOS>
"
You
will
find
everything
as
I
have
represented
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
We
shall
see
,
"
replied
the
doctor
.
<EOS>
"
If
not
,
you
will
have
to
tend
the
sick
in
Newgate
.
"
 
<EOS>
The
trio
then
proceeded
to
Saint
Paul
's
,
and
descended
to
the
vaults
.
<EOS>
Hodges
carefully
examined
the
body
of
the
unfortunate
sexton
,
but
though
he
entertained
strong
suspicions
,
he
could
not
pronounce
positively
that
he
had
been
improperly
treated
;
and
as
the
statement
of
Mrs.
Malmayns
was
fully
borne
out
by
the
vergers
and
others
,
he
did
not
think
it
necessary
to
pursue
the
investigation
further
.
<EOS>
As
soon
as
he
was
gone
,
Judith
accompanied
the
coffin
-
maker
to
his
residence
,
where
she
remained
,
till
the
evening
,
when
she
was
suddenly
summoned
,
in
a
case
of
urgency
,
by
a
messenger
from
Sibbald
,
the
apothecary
of
Clerkenwell
.
  
<EOS>
X.
 
THE
DUEL
.
 
<EOS>
After
Parravicin
's
terrible
announcement
,
Disbrowe
offered
him
no
further
violence
,
but
,
flinging
down
his
sword
,
burst
open
the
door
,
and
rushed
upstairs
.
<EOS>
His
wife
was
still
insensible
,
but
the
fatal
mark
that
had
betrayed
the
presence
of
the
plague
to
the
knight
manifested
itself
also
to
him
,
and
he
stood
like
one
entranced
,
until
Mrs.
Disbrowe
,
recovering
from
her
swoon
,
opened
her
eyes
,
and
,
gazing
at
him
<EOS>
,
cried--"You
here!--Oh
Disbrowe
,
I
dreamed
you
had
deserted
me
--
had
sold
me
to
another
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Would
it
were
a
dream
!
"
<EOS>
replied
her
husband
.
 
<EOS>
"
And
was
it
not
so
?
"
<EOS>
she
rejoined
,
pressing
her
hand
to
her
temples
.
<EOS>
"
It
is
true
!
<EOS>
oh
!
<EOS>
yes
,
I
feel
it
is
.
<EOS>
Every
circumstance
rushes
upon
me
plainly
and
distinctly
.
<EOS>
I
see
the
daring
libertine
before
me
.
<EOS>
He
stood
where
you
stand
,
and
told
me
what
you
had
done
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
What
did
he
tell
you
,
Margaret
?
"
asked
Disbrowe
in
a
hollow
voice
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
told
me
you
were
false
--
that
you
loved
another
,
and
had
abandoned
me
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
He
lied
!
"
<EOS>
exclaimed
Disbrowe
,
in
a
voice
of
uncontrollable
fury
.
<EOS>
"
It
is
true
that
,
in
a
moment
of
frenzy
,
I
was
tempted
to
set
you
--
<EOS>
yes
,
_
you
_
,
Margaret
--
against
all
I
had
lost
at
play
,
and
was
compelled
to
yield
up
the
key
of
my
house
to
the
winner
.
<EOS>
But
I
have
never
been
faithless
to
you
--
never
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Faithless
or
not
<EOS>
,
"
replied
his
wife
,
bitterly
,
"
it
is
plain
you
value
me
less
than
play
,
or
you
would
not
have
acted
thus
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Reproach
me
not
,
Margaret
,
"
replied
Disbrowe
;
"
I
would
give
worlds
to
undo
what
I
have
done
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Who
shall
guard
me
against
the
recurrence
of
such
conduct
?
"
said
Mrs.
Disbrowe
,
coldly
.
<EOS>
"
But
you
have
not
yet
informed
me
how
I
was
saved
.
"
 
<EOS>
Disbrowe
averted
his
head
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
mean
you
?
<EOS>
"
she
cried
,
seizing
his
arm
.
<EOS>
"
What
has
happened
?
<EOS>
Do
not
keep
me
in
suspense
?
<EOS>
Were
you
my
preserver
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
Your
preserver
was
the
plague
,
"
rejoined
Disbrowe
,
in
a
sombre
tone
.
 
<EOS>
The
unfortunate
lady
then
,
for
the
first
time
,
perceived
that
she
was
attacked
by
the
pestilence
,
and
a
long
and
dreadful
pause
ensued
,
broken
only
by
exclamations
of
anguish
from
both
.
 
<EOS>
"
Disbrowe
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Margaret
,
at
length
,
raising
herself
in
bed
,
"
you
have
deeply
--
irrecoverably
injured
me
.
<EOS>
But
promise
me
one
thing
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
swear
to
do
whatever
you
may
desire
,
"
he
replied
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
know
not
,
after
what
I
have
heard
,
whether
you
have
courage
for
the
deed
,
"
she
continued
.
<EOS>
"
But
I
would
have
you
kill
this
man
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
will
do
it
,
"
replied
Disbrowe
.
 
<EOS>
"
Nothing
but
his
blood
can
wipe
out
the
wrong
he
has
done
me
,
"
she
rejoined
.
<EOS>
"
Challenge
him
to
a
duel
--
a
mortal
duel
.
<EOS>
If
he
survives
,
by
my
soul
,
I
will
give
myself
to
him
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Margaret
!
"
exclaimed
Disbrowe
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
swear
it
,
"
she
rejoined
.
"
<EOS>
And
you
know
my
passionate
nature
too
well
to
doubt
I
will
keep
my
word
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
But
you
have
the
plague
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
What
does
that
matter
?
<EOS>
I
may
recover
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Not
so
,
"
muttered
Disbrowe
.
<EOS>
"
If
I
fall
,
I
will
take
care
<EOS>
you
do
not
recover
.
<EOS>
I
will
fight
him
to
-
morrow
,
"
he
added
aloud
.
 
<EOS>
He
then
summoned
his
servants
,
but
when
they
found
their
mistress
was
attacked
by
the
plague
,
they
framed
some
excuse
to
leave
the
room
,
and
instantly
fled
the
house
.
<EOS>
Driven
almost
to
his
wits
'
end
,
Disbrowe
went
in
search
of
other
assistance
,
and
was
for
a
while
unsuccessful
,
until
a
coachman
,
to
whom
he
applied
,
offered
,
for
a
suitable
reward
,
to
drive
to
Clerkenwell
--
to
the
shop
of
an
apothecary
named
Sibbald
(
with
whose
name
the
reader
is
already
familiar
)
,
who
was
noted
for
his
treatment
of
plague
patients
,
and
to
bring
him
to
the
other
's
residence
.
<EOS>
Disbrowe
immediately
closed
with
the
man
,
and
in
less
than
two
hours
Sibbald
made
his
appearance
.
<EOS>
He
was
a
singular
and
repulsive
personage
,
with
an
immense
hooked
nose
,
dark
,
savage
-
looking
eyes
,
a
skin
like
parchment
,
and
high
round
shoulders
,
which
procured
him
the
nickname
of
Aesop
among
his
neighbours
.
<EOS>
He
was
under
the
middle
size
,
and
of
a
spare
figure
,
and
in
age
might
be
about
sixty
-
five
.
 
<EOS>
On
seeing
Mrs.
Disbrowe
,
he
at
once
boldly
asserted
that
he
could
cure
her
,
and
proceeded
to
apply
his
remedies
.
<EOS>
Finding
the
servants
fled
,
he
offered
to
procure
a
nurse
for
Disbrowe
,
and
the
latter
,
thanking
him
,
eagerly
embraced
the
offer
.
<EOS>
Soon
after
this
he
departed
.
<EOS>
In
the
evening
the
nurse
,
who
(
as
may
be
surmised
)
was
no
other
than
Judith
Malmayns
,
arrived
,
and
immediately
commenced
her
functions
.
 
<EOS>
Disbrowe
had
no
rest
that
night
.
<EOS>
His
wife
slept
occasionally
for
a
few
minutes
,
but
,
apparently
engrossed
by
one
idea
,
never
failed
when
she
awoke
to
urge
him
to
slay
Parravicin
;
repeating
her
oath
to
give
herself
to
the
knight
if
he
came
off
victorious
.
<EOS>
Worn
out
at
length
,
Disbrowe
gave
her
a
terrible
look
,
and
rushed
out
of
the
room
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
not
been
alone
many
minutes
when
he
was
surprised
by
the
entrance
of
Judith
.
<EOS>
He
eagerly
inquired
whether
his
wife
was
worse
,
but
was
informed
she
had
dropped
into
a
slumber
.
 
<EOS>
"
Hearing
what
has
passed
between
you
,
"
said
the
nurse
,
"
and
noticing
your
look
when
you
left
the
room
<EOS>
,
I
came
to
tell
you
,
that
if
you
fall
in
this
duel
,
your
last
moments
need
not
be
embittered
by
any
thoughts
of
your
wife
.
<EOS>
I
will
take
care
<EOS>
she
does
not
recover
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
A
horrible
smile
lighted
up
Disbrowe
's
features
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
are
the
very
person
I
want
,
"
he
said
.
<EOS>
"
When
I
would
do
evil
,
the
fiend
rises
to
my
bidding
.
<EOS>
If
I
am
slain
,
you
know
what
to
do
.
<EOS>
How
shall
I
requite
the
service
?
<EOS>
"
 
"
Do
not
concern
yourself
about
that
,
captain
,
"
rejoined
Judith
.
<EOS>
"
I
will
take
care
of
myself
.
"
 
<EOS>
About
noon
,
on
the
following
day
,
Disbrowe
,
without
venturing
to
see
his
wife
,
left
the
house
,
and
proceeded
to
the
Smyrna
,
where
,
as
he
expected
,
he
found
Parravicin
and
his
companions
.
 
<EOS>
The
knight
instantly
advanced
towards
him
,
and
,
laying
aside
for
the
moment
his
reckless
air
,
inquired
,
with
a
look
of
commiseration
,
after
his
wife
.
 
<EOS>
"
She
is
better
,
"
replied
Disbrowe
,
fiercely
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
come
to
settle
accounts
with
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
thought
they
were
settled
long
ago
,
"
returned
Parravicin
,
instantly
resuming
his
wonted
manner
.
<EOS>
"
But
I
am
glad
to
find
you
consider
the
debt
unpaid
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
Disbrowe
lifted
the
cane
he
held
in
his
hand
,
and
struck
the
knight
with
it
forcibly
on
the
shoulder
.
<EOS>
"
Be
that
my
answer
,
"
he
said
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
will
have
your
life
first
,
and
your
wife
afterwards
,
"
replied
Parravicin
,
furiously
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
shall
have
her
if
you
slay
me
,
but
not
otherwise
,
"
retorted
Disbrowe
.
<EOS>
"
It
must
be
a
mortal
duel
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
must
,
"
replied
Parravicin
.
<EOS>
"
I
will
not
spare
you
this
time
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Spare
him
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Pillichody
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Shield
of
Agamemnon
!
<EOS>
I
should
hope
not
.
<EOS>
Spit
him
as
you
would
a
wild
boar
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Peace
,
fool
!
"
cried
Parravicin
.
"
<EOS>
Captain
Disbrowe
,
I
shall
instantly
proceed
to
the
west
side
of
Hyde
Park
,
beneath
the
trees
.
<EOS>
I
shall
expect
you
there
.
<EOS>
On
my
return
I
shall
call
on
your
wife
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
pray
you
do
so
,
sir
,
"
replied
Disbrowe
,
disdainfully
.
 
<EOS>
Both
then
quitted
the
coffee
-
house
,
Parravicin
attended
by
Rochester
and
Pillichody
,
and
Disbrowe
accompanied
by
a
military
friend
,
whom
he
accidentally
encountered
.
<EOS>
Each
party
taking
a
coach
,
they
soon
reached
the
ground,--a
retired
spot
,
completely
screened
from
observation
by
trees
.
<EOS>
The
preliminaries
were
soon
arranged
,
for
neither
would
admit
of
delay
.
<EOS>
The
conflict
then
commenced
with
great
fury
on
both
sides
;
but
Parravicin
,
in
spite
of
his
passion
,
observed
far
more
caution
than
his
antagonist
;
and
,
taking
advantage
of
an
unguarded
movement
,
occasioned
by
the
other
's
impetuosity
,
passed
his
sword
through
his
body
.
 
<EOS>
Disbrowe
fell
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
are
again
successful
,
"
he
groaned
,
"
but
save
my
wife
--
save
her
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
What
mean
you
?
"
cried
Parravicin
,
leaning
over
him
,
as
he
wiped
his
sword
.
 
<EOS>
But
Disbrowe
could
make
no
answer
.
<EOS>
His
utterance
was
choked
by
a
sudden
effusion
of
blood
on
the
lungs
,
and
he
instantly
expired
.
<EOS>
Leaving
the
body
in
care
of
the
second
,
Parravicin
and
his
friends
returned
to
the
coach
,
where
the
major
rejoiced
greatly
at
the
issue
of
the
duel
;
but
the
knight
looked
grave
,
and
pondered
upon
the
words
of
the
dying
man
.
<EOS>
After
a
time
,
however
,
he
recovered
his
spirits
,
and
dined
with
his
friends
at
the
Smyrna
;
but
they
observed
that
he
drank
more
deeply
than
usual
.
<EOS>
His
excesses
did
not
,
however
,
prevent
him
from
playing
with
his
usual
skill
,
and
he
won
a
large
sum
from
Rochester
at
hazard
.
 
<EOS>
Flushed
with
success
,
and
heated
with
wine
,
he
walked
up
to
Disbrowe
's
residence
about
an
hour
after
midnight
.
<EOS>
As
he
approached
the
house
,
he
observed
a
strangely
-
shaped
cart
at
the
door
,
and
,
halting
for
a
moment
,
saw
a
body
,
wrapped
in
a
shroud
,
brought
out
.
<EOS>
Could
it
be
Mrs.
Disbrowe
?
<EOS>
Rushing
forward
,
to
one
of
the
assistants
in
black
cloaks
--
and
who
was
no
other
than
Chowles
--
he
asked
whom
he
was
about
to
inter
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
a
Mrs.
Disbrowe
,
"
replied
the
coffin
-
maker
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
She
died
of
grief
,
because
her
husband
was
killed
this
morning
in
a
duel
;
but
as
she
had
the
plague
,
it
must
be
put
down
to
that
.
<EOS>
We
are
not
particular
in
such
matters
,
and
shall
bury
her
and
her
husband
together
;
and
as
there
is
no
money
left
to
pay
for
coffins
,
they
must
go
to
the
grave
without
them
.
<EOS>
What
,
ho
!
<EOS>
Mother
Malmayns
,
let
Jonas
have
the
captain
as
soon
as
you
have
stripped
him
.
<EOS>
I
must
be
starting
.
"
 
<EOS>
And
as
the
body
of
his
victim
was
brought
forth
,
Parravicin
fell
against
the
wall
in
a
state
almost
of
stupefaction
.
 
<EOS>
At
this
moment
Solomon
Eagle
,
with
his
brazier
on
his
head
,
suddenly
turned
the
corner
of
the
street
,
and
stationing
himself
before
the
dead
-
cart
,
cried
in
a
voice
of
thunder
,
"
<EOS>
Woe
to
the
libertine
!
<EOS>
woe
to
the
homicide
!
<EOS>
for
he
shall
perish
in
everlasting
fire
!
<EOS>
Woe
!
<EOS>
woe
!
"
    
<EOS>
BOOK
THE
SECOND
.
 
<EOS>
MAY
,
1665
.
  
<EOS>
I.
 
PROGRESS
OF
THE
PESTILENCE
.
 
<EOS>
Towards
the
middle
of
May
,
the
bills
of
mortality
began
to
swell
greatly
in
amount
,
and
though
but
few
were
put
down
to
the
plague
,
and
a
large
number
to
the
spotted
fever
(
another
frightful
disorder
raging
at
the
period
)
,
it
is
well
known
that
the
bulk
had
died
of
the
former
disease
.
<EOS>
The
rigorous
measures
adopted
by
the
authorities
(
whether
salutary
or
not
has
been
questioned
)
,
in
shutting
up
houses
and
confining
the
sick
and
sound
within
them
for
forty
days
,
were
found
so
intolerable
,
that
most
persons
were
disposed
to
run
any
risk
rather
than
be
subjected
to
such
a
grievance
,
and
every
artifice
was
resorted
to
for
concealing
a
case
when
it
occurred
.
<EOS>
Hence
,
it
seldom
happened
,
unless
by
accident
,
that
a
discovery
was
made
.
<EOS>
Quack
doctors
were
secretly
consulted
,
instead
of
the
regular
practitioners
;
the
searchers
were
bribed
to
silence
;
and
large
fees
were
given
to
the
undertakers
and
buriers
to
lay
the
deaths
to
the
account
of
some
other
disorder
.
<EOS>
All
this
,
however
,
did
not
blind
the
eyes
of
the
officers
to
the
real
state
of
things
.
<EOS>
Redoubling
their
vigilance
,
they
entered
houses
on
mere
suspicion
;
inflicted
punishments
where
they
found
their
orders
disobeyed
or
neglected
;
sent
the
sound
to
prison,--the
sick
to
the
pest
-
house
;
and
replaced
the
faithless
searchers
by
others
upon
whom
they
could
place
reliance
.
<EOS>
Many
cases
were
thus
detected
;
but
in
spite
of
every
precaution
,
the
majority
escaped
;
and
the
vent
was
no
sooner
stopped
in
one
quarter
than
it
broke
out
with
additional
violence
in
another
.
 
<EOS>
By
this
time
the
alarm
had
become
general
.
<EOS>
All
whose
business
or
pursuits
permitted
it
,
prepared
to
leave
London
,
which
they
regarded
as
a
devoted
city
,
without
delay
.
<EOS>
As
many
houses
were
,
therefore
,
closed
from
the
absence
of
the
inhabitants
as
from
the
presence
of
the
plague
,
and
this
added
to
the
forlorn
appearance
of
the
streets
,
which
in
some
quarters
were
almost
deserted
.
<EOS>
For
a
while
,
nothing
was
seen
at
the
great
outlets
of
the
city
but
carts
,
carriages
,
and
other
vehicles
,
filled
with
goods
and
movables
,
on
their
way
to
the
country
;
and
,
as
may
be
supposed
,
the
departure
of
their
friends
did
not
tend
to
abate
the
dejection
of
those
whose
affairs
compelled
them
to
remain
behind
.
 
<EOS>
One
circumstance
must
not
be
passed
unnoticed
,
namely
,
the
continued
fineness
and
beauty
of
the
weather
.
<EOS>
No
rain
had
fallen
for
upwards
of
three
weeks
.
<EOS>
The
sky
was
bright
and
cloudless
;
the
atmosphere
,
apparently
,
pure
and
innoxious
;
while
the
heat
was
as
great
as
is
generally
experienced
in
the
middle
of
summer
.
<EOS>
But
instead
of
producing
its
usual
enlivening
effect
on
the
spirits
,
the
fine
weather
added
to
the
general
gloom
and
apprehension
,
inasmuch
as
it
led
to
the
belief
(
afterwards
fully
confirmed
)
,
that
if
the
present
warmth
was
so
pernicious
,
the
more
sultry
seasons
which
were
near
at
hand
would
aggravate
the
fury
of
the
pestilence
.
<EOS>
Sometimes
,
indeed
,
when
the
deaths
were
less
numerous
,
a
hope
began
to
be
entertained
that
the
distemper
was
abating
,
and
confidence
was
for
a
moment
restored
;
but
these
anticipations
were
speedily
checked
by
the
reappearance
of
the
scourge
,
which
seemed
to
baffle
and
deride
all
human
skill
and
foresight
.
 
<EOS>
London
now
presented
a
lamentable
spectacle
.
<EOS>
Not
a
street
but
had
a
house
in
it
marked
with
a
red
cross
--
some
streets
had
many
such
.
<EOS>
The
bells
were
continually
tolling
for
burials
,
and
the
dead
-
carts
went
their
melancholy
rounds
at
night
and
were
constantly
loaded
.
<EOS>
Fresh
directions
were
issued
by
the
authorities
;
and
as
domestic
animals
were
considered
to
be
a
medium
of
conveying
the
infection
,
an
order
,
which
was
immediately
carried
into
effect
,
was
given
to
destroy
all
dogs
and
cats
.
<EOS>
But
this
plan
proved
prejudicial
rather
than
the
reverse
,
as
the
bodies
of
the
poor
animals
,
most
of
which
were
drowned
in
the
Thames
,
being
washed
ashore
,
produced
a
horrible
and
noxious
effluvium
,
supposed
to
contribute
materially
to
the
propagation
of
the
distemper
.
 
<EOS>
No
precautionary
measure
was
neglected
;
but
it
may
be
doubted
whether
any
human
interference
could
have
averted
the
severity
of
the
scourge
,
which
,
though
its
progress
might
be
checked
for
a
few
days
by
attention
,
or
increased
in
the
same
ratio
by
neglect
,
would
in
the
end
have
unquestionably
fulfilled
its
mission
.
<EOS>
The
College
of
Physicians
,
by
the
king
's
command
,
issued
simple
and
intelligible
directions
,
in
the
mother
tongue
,
for
the
sick
.
<EOS>
Certain
of
their
number
,
amongst
whom
was
the
reader
's
acquaintance
,
Doctor
Hodges
,
were
appointed
to
attend
the
infected
;
and
two
out
of
the
Court
of
Aldermen
were
required
to
see
that
they
duly
executed
their
dangerous
office
.
<EOS>
Public
prayers
and
a
general
fast
were
likewise
enjoined
.
<EOS>
But
Heaven
seemed
deaf
to
the
supplications
of
the
doomed
inhabitants
--
their
prayers
being
followed
by
a
fearful
increase
of
deaths
.
<EOS>
A
vast
crowd
was
collected
within
Saint
Paul
's
to
hear
a
sermon
preached
by
Doctor
Sheldon
,
Archbishop
of
Canterbury,--a
prelate
greatly
distinguished
during
the
whole
course
of
the
visitation
,
by
his
unremitting
charity
and
attention
to
the
sick
;
and
before
the
discourse
was
concluded
,
several
fell
down
within
the
sacred
walls
,
and
,
on
being
conveyed
to
their
own
homes
,
were
found
to
be
infected
.
 
<EOS>
On
the
following
day
,
too
,
many
others
who
had
been
present
were
seized
with
the
disorder
.
 
<EOS>
A
fresh
impulse
was
given
to
the
pestilence
from
an
unlooked
for
cause
.
<EOS>
It
has
been
mentioned
that
the
shutting
up
of
houses
and
seclusion
of
the
sick
were
regarded
as
an
intolerable
grievance
,
and
though
most
were
compelled
to
submit
to
it
,
some
few
resisted
,
and
tumults
and
disturbances
ensued
.
<EOS>
As
the
plague
increased
,
these
disturbances
became
more
frequent
,
and
the
mob
always
taking
part
against
the
officers
,
they
were
frequently
interrupted
in
the
execution
of
their
duty
.
 
<EOS>
About
this
time
a
more
serious
affray
than
usual
occurred
,
attended
-
with
loss
of
life
and
other
unfortunate
consequences
,
which
it
may
be
worth
while
to
relate
,
as
illustrative
of
the
peculiar
state
of
the
times
.
<EOS>
The
wife
of
a
merchant
,
named
Barcroft
,
residing
in
Lothbury
,
being
attacked
by
the
plague
,
the
husband
,
fearing
his
house
would
be
shut
up
,
withheld
all
information
from
the
examiners
and
searchers
.
<EOS>
His
wife
died
,
and
immediately
afterwards
one
of
his
children
was
attacked
.
<EOS>
Still
he
refused
to
give
notice
.
<EOS>
The
matter
,
however
,
got
wind
.
<EOS>
The
searchers
arrived
at
night
,
and
being
refused
admittance
,
they
broke
into
the
house
.
<EOS>
Finding
undoubted
evidence
of
infection
,
they
ordered
it
to
be
closed
,
stationed
a
watchman
at
the
door
,
and
marked
it
with
the
fatal
sign
.
<EOS>
Barcroft
remonstrated
against
their
proceedings
,
but
in
vain
.
<EOS>
They
told
him
he
might
think
himself
well
off
that
he
was
not
carried
before
the
Lord
Mayor
,
who
would
undoubtedly
send
him
to
Ludgate
;
and
with
other
threats
to
the
like
effect
,
they
departed
.
 
<EOS>
The
unfortunate
man
's
wife
and
child
were
removed
the
following
night
in
the
dead
-
cart
,
and
,
driven
half
-
mad
by
grief
and
terror
<EOS>
,
he
broke
open
the
door
of
his
dwelling
,
and
,
plunging
a
sword
in
the
watchman
's
breast
,
who
opposed
his
flight
,
gained
the
street
.
<EOS>
A
party
of
the
watch
happened
to
be
passing
at
the
time
,
and
the
fugitive
was
instantly
secured
.
<EOS>
He
made
a
great
clamour
,
however,--calling
to
his
neighbours
and
the
bystanders
to
rescue
him
,
and
in
another
moment
the
watch
was
beaten
off
,
and
Barcroft
placed
on
a
post
,
whence
he
harangued
his
preservers
on
the
severe
restraints
imposed
upon
the
citizens
,
urging
them
to
assist
in
throwing
open
the
doors
of
all
infected
houses
,
and
allowing
free
egress
to
their
inmates
.
 
<EOS>
Greedily
listening
to
this
insane
counsel
,
the
mob
resolved
to
act
upon
it
.
<EOS>
Headed
by
the
merchant
,
they
ran
down
Thread
-
needle
-
street
,
and
,
crossing
Stock
's
Market
,
burst
open
several
houses
in
Bearbinder
-
lane
,
and
drove
away
the
watchmen
.
<EOS>
One
man
,
more
courageous
than
the
others
,
tried
to
maintain
his
post
,
and
was
so
severely
handled
by
his
assailants
,
that
he
died
a
few
days
afterwards
of
the
injuries
he
had
received
.
<EOS>
Most
of
those
who
had
been
imprisoned
within
their
dwellings
immediately
issued
forth
,
and
joining
the
mob
,
which
received
fresh
recruits
each
moment
,
started
on
the
same
errand
.
 
<EOS>
Loud
shouts
were
now
raised
of--"Open
the
doors
!
<EOS>
No
plague
prisoners
!
<EOS>
No
plague
prisoners
!
"
<EOS>
and
the
mob
set
off
along
the
Poultry
.
<EOS>
They
halted
,
however
,
before
