the
Great
Conduit
,
near
the
end
of
Bucklersbury
,
and
opposite
Mercer
's
Hall
,
because
they
perceived
a
company
of
the
Train
-
bands
advancing
to
meet
them
.
<EOS>
A
council
of
war
was
held
,
and
many
of
the
rabble
were
disposed
to
fly
;
but
Barcroft
again
urged
them
to
proceed
,
and
they
were
unexpectedly
added
by
Solomon
Eagle
,
who
,
bursting
through
their
ranks
,
with
his
brazier
on
his
head
,
crying
,
"
<EOS>
Awake
!
<EOS>
sleepers
,
awake
!
<EOS>
the
plague
is
at
your
doors
!
<EOS>
awake
!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
speeded
towards
the
Train
-
bands
,
scattering
sparks
of
fire
as
he
pursued
his
swift
career
.
<EOS>
The
mob
instantly
followed
,
and
,
adding
their
shouts
to
his
outcries
,
dashed
on
with
such
fury
that
the
Train
-
bands
did
not
dare
to
oppose
them
,
and
,
after
a
slight
and
ineffectual
resistance
,
were
put
to
rout
.
 
<EOS>
Barcroft
,
who
acted
as
leader
,
informed
them
that
there
was
a
house
in
Wood
-
street
shut
up
,
and
the
crowd
accompanied
him
thither
.
<EOS>
In
a
few
minutes
they
had
reached
Bloundel
's
shop
,
but
finding
no
one
on
guard
--
for
the
watchman
,
guessing
their
errand
,
had
taken
to
his
heels
--
they
smeared
over
the
fatal
cross
and
inscription
with
a
pail
of
mud
gathered
from
the
neighbouring
kennel
,
and
then
broke
open
the
door
.
<EOS>
The
grocer
and
his
apprentice
hearing
the
disturbance
,
and
being
greatly
alarmed
at
it
,
hurried
to
the
shop
,
and
found
it
full
of
people
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
are
at
liberty
Mr.
Bloundel
,
"
cried
the
merchant
,
who
was
acquainted
with
the
grocer
.
<EOS>
"
We
are
determined
no
longer
to
let
our
families
be
imprisoned
at
the
pleasure
of
the
Lord
Mayor
and
aldermen
.
<EOS>
We
mean
to
break
open
all
the
plague
houses
,
and
set
free
their
inmates
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
For
Heaven
's
sake
,
consider
what
you
are
about
,
Mr.
Barcroft
,
"
cried
the
grocer
.
<EOS>
"
My
house
has
been
closed
for
nearly
a
month
.
<EOS>
Nay
,
as
my
son
has
entirely
recovered
,
and
received
his
certificate
of
health
from
Doctor
Hodges
,
it
would
have
been
opened
in
three
days
hence
by
the
officers
;
so
that
I
have
suffered
all
the
inconvenience
of
the
confinement
,
and
can
speak
to
it
.
<EOS>
It
is
no
doubt
very
irksome
,
and
may
be
almost
intolerable
to
persons
of
an
impatient
temperament
:
<EOS>
but
I
firmly
believe
it
is
the
only
means
to
check
the
progress
of
contagion
.
<EOS>
Listen
to
me
,
Mr.
Barcroft
--
listen
to
me
,
good
friends
,
and
hesitate
before
you
violate
laws
which
have
been
made
expressly
to
meet
this
terrible
emergency
.
"
 
<EOS>
Here
he
was
checked
by
loud
groans
and
upbraidings
from
the
bystanders
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
tells
you
himself
that
the
period
of
his
confinement
is
just
over
,
"
cried
Barcroft
.
<EOS>
"
It
is
plain
he
has
no
interest
in
the
matter
,
except
that
he
would
have
others
suffer
as
he
has
done
.
<EOS>
Heed
him
not
,
my
friends
;
but
proceed
with
the
good
work
.
<EOS>
Liberate
the
poor
plague
prisoners
.
<EOS>
Liberate
them
.
<EOS>
On
!
on
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
Forbear
,
rash
men
"
cried
Bloundel
,
in
an
authoritative
voice
.
"
<EOS>
In
the
name
of
those
you
are
bound
to
obey
,
I
command
you
to
desist
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Command
us
!
"
cried
one
of
the
bystanders
,
raising
his
staff
in
a
menacing
manner
.
<EOS>
"
Is
this
your
gratitude
for
the
favour
we
have
just
conferred
upon
you
?
<EOS>
Command
us
,
forsooth
!
<EOS>
You
had
better
repeat
the
order
,
and
see
how
it
will
be
obeyed
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
_
do
<EOS>
_
repeat
it
<EOS>
,
"
rejoined
the
grocer
,
firmly
.
"
<EOS>
In
the
Lord
Mayor
's
name
,
I
command
you
to
desist
,
and
return
to
your
homes
.
"
 
<EOS>
The
man
would
have
struck
him
with
his
staff
,
if
he
had
not
been
himself
felled
to
the
ground
by
Leonard
.
<EOS>
This
was
the
signal
for
greater
outrage
.
<EOS>
The
grocer
and
his
apprentice
were
instantly
assailed
by
several
others
of
the
mob
,
who
,
leaving
them
both
on
the
floor
covered
with
bruises
,
helped
themselves
to
all
they
could
lay
hands
on
in
the
shop
,
and
then
quitted
the
premises
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
scarcely
necessary
to
track
their
course
further
;
and
it
may
be
sufficient
to
state
,
that
they
broke
open
upwards
of
fifty
houses
in
different
streets
.
<EOS>
Many
of
the
plague
-
stricken
joined
them
,
and
several
half
-
naked
creatures
were
found
dead
in
the
streets
on
the
following
morning
.
<EOS>
Two
houses
in
Blackfriars
-
lane
were
set
on
fire
,
and
the
conflagration
was
with
difficulty
checked
;
nor
was
it
until
late
on
the
following
day
that
the
mob
could
be
entirely
dispersed
.
<EOS>
The
originator
of
the
disturbance
,
Barcroft
,
after
a
desperate
resistance
,
was
shot
through
the
head
by
a
constable
.
 
<EOS>
The
result
of
this
riot
,
as
will
be
easily
foreseen
,
was
greatly
to
increase
the
pestilence
;
and
many
of
those
who
had
been
most
active
in
it
perished
in
prison
of
the
distemper
.
<EOS>
Far
from
being
discouraged
by
the
opposition
offered
to
their
decrees
,
the
city
authorities
enforced
them
with
greater
rigour
than
ever
,
and
,
doubling
the
number
of
the
watch
,
again
shut
up
all
those
houses
which
had
been
broken
open
during
the
late
tumult
.
 
<EOS>
Bloundel
received
a
visit
from
the
Lord
Mayor
,
Sir
John
Lawrence
,
who
,
having
been
informed
of
his
conduct
,
came
to
express
his
high
approval
of
it
,
offering
to
remit
the
few
days
yet
unexpired
of
his
quarantine
.
<EOS>
The
grocer
,
however
,
declined
the
offer
,
and
with
renewed
expressions
of
approbation
,
Sir
John
Lawrence
took
his
leave
.
 
<EOS>
Three
days
afterwards
,
the
Examiner
of
Health
pronounced
the
grocer
's
house
free
from
infection
.
<EOS>
The
fatal
mark
was
obliterated
from
the
door
;
the
shutters
were
unfastened
;
and
Bloundel
resumed
his
business
as
usual
.
<EOS>
Words
are
inadequate
to
describe
the
delight
that
filled
the
breast
of
every
member
of
his
family
,
on
their
first
meeting
after
their
long
separation
.
<EOS>
It
took
place
in
the
room
adjoining
the
shop
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Bloundel
received
the
joyful
summons
from
Leonard
,
and
,
on
descending
with
her
children
,
found
her
husband
and
her
son
Stephen
anxiously
expecting
her
.
<EOS>
Scarcely
able
to
make
up
her
mind
as
to
which
of
the
two
she
should
embrace
first
,
Mrs.
Bloundel
was
decided
by
the
pale
countenance
of
her
son
,
and
rushing
towards
him
,
she
strained
him
to
her
breast
,
while
Amabel
flew
to
her
father
's
arms
.
<EOS>
The
grocer
could
not
repress
his
tears
;
but
they
were
tears
of
joy
,
and
that
night
's
happiness
made
him
ample
amends
for
all
the
anxiety
he
had
recently
undergone
.
 
<EOS>
"
Well
,
Stephen
,
my
dear
child
,
"
said
his
mother
,
as
soon
as
the
first
tumult
of
emotion
had
subsided,--"well
,
Stephen
,
"
she
said
,
smiling
at
him
through
her
tears
,
and
almost
smothering
him
with
kisses
,
"
you
are
not
so
much
altered
as
I
expected
;
and
I
do
not
think
,
if
I
had
had
the
care
of
you
,
I
could
have
nursed
you
better
myself
.
<EOS>
You
owe
your
father
a
second
life
,
and
we
all
owe
him
the
deepest
gratitude
for
the
care
he
has
taken
of
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
can
never
be
sufficiently
grateful
for
his
kindness
,
"
returned
Stephen
,
affectionately
.
 
<EOS>
"
Give
thanks
to
the
beneficent
Being
who
has
preserved
you
from
this
great
danger
,
my
son
,
not
to
me
,
"
returned
Bloundel
.
<EOS>
"
The
first
moments
of
our
reunion
should
be
worthily
employed
.
"
 
<EOS>
So
saying
,
he
summoned
the
household
,
and
,
for
the
first
time
for
a
month
,
the
whole
family
party
assembled
,
as
before
,
at
prayer
.
<EOS>
Never
were
thanksgivings
more
earnestly
,
more
devoutly
uttered
.
<EOS>
All
arose
with
bright
and
cheerful
countenances
;
and
even
Blaize
seemed
to
have
shaken
off
his
habitual
dread
of
the
pestilence
.
<EOS>
As
he
retired
with
Patience
,
he
observed
to
her
,
"
Master
Stephen
looks
quite
well
,
though
a
little
thinner
.
<EOS>
I
must
ascertain
from
him
the
exact
course
of
treatment
pursued
by
his
father
.
<EOS>
I
wonder
whether
Mr.
Bloundel
would
nurse
_
me
<EOS>
_
<EOS>
if
I
were
to
be
suddenly
seized
with
the
distemper
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
If
he
would
n't
,
I
_
<EOS>
would
_
,
"
replied
Patience
.
 
<EOS>
"
Thank
you
,
thank
you
,
"
replied
Blaize
.
<EOS>
"
I
begin
to
think
we
shall
get
through
it
.
<EOS>
I
shall
go
out
to
-
morrow
and
examine
the
bills
of
mortality
,
and
see
what
progress
the
plague
is
making
.
<EOS>
I
am
all
anxiety
to
know
.
<EOS>
I
must
get
a
fresh
supply
of
medicine
,
too
.
<EOS>
My
private
store
is
quite
gone
,
except
three
of
my
favourite
rufuses
,
which
I
shall
take
before
I
go
to
bed
to
-
night
.
<EOS>
Unluckily
,
my
purse
is
as
empty
as
my
phials
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
can
lend
you
a
little
money
,
"
said
Patience
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
n't
touched
my
last
year
's
wages
.
<EOS>
They
are
quite
at
your
service
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
are
too
good
,
"
replied
Blaize
;
"
but
I
wo
n't
decline
the
offer
.
<EOS>
I
heard
a
man
crying
a
new
anti
-
pestilential
elixir
,
as
he
passed
the
house
yesterday
.
<EOS>
I
must
find
him
out
and
buy
a
bottle
.
<EOS>
Besides
,
I
must
call
on
my
friend
Parkhurst
,
the
apothecary.--You
are
a
good
girl
,
Patience
,
and
I
'll
marry
you
as
soon
as
the
plague
ceases
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
something
else
to
give
you
,
"
rejoined
Patience
.
<EOS>
"
This
little
bag
contains
a
hazel
-
nut
,
from
which
I
have
picked
the
kernel
,
and
filled
its
place
with
quicksilver
,
stopping
the
hole
with
wax
.
<EOS>
Wear
it
round
your
neck
,
and
you
will
find
it
a
certain
preservative
against
the
pestilence
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Who
told
you
of
this
remedy
?
"
asked
Blaize
,
taking
the
bag
.
 
<EOS>
"
Your
mother
,
"
returned
Patience
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
wonder
I
never
heard
of
it
,
"
said
the
porter
.
 
<EOS>
"
She
would
n't
mention
it
to
you
,
because
the
doctor
advised
her
not
to
put
such
matters
into
your
head
,
"
replied
Patience
.
<EOS>
"
But
I
could
n't
help
indulging
you
.
<EOS>
Heigho
!
<EOS>
I
hope
the
plague
will
soon
be
over
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
wo
n't
be
over
for
six
months
,
"
rejoined
Blaize
,
shaking
his
head
.
<EOS>
"
I
read
in
a
little
book
,
published
in
1593
,
in
Queen
Elizabeth
's
reign
,
and
written
by
Simon
Kelway
,
'
that
when
little
children
flock
together
,
and
pretend
that
some
of
their
number
are
dead
,
solemnizing
the
burial
in
a
mournful
sort
,
it
is
a
certain
token
that
a
great
mortality
is
at
hand
.
'
<EOS>
This
I
have
myself
seen
more
than
once
.
<EOS>
Again
,
just
before
the
great
sickness
of
1625
,
the
churchyard
wall
of
St.
Andrew
's
,
Holborn
,
fell
down
.
<EOS>
I
need
not
tell
you
that
the
same
thing
occurred
after
the
frost
this
winter
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
heard
of
it
,
"
replied
Patience
:
"
<EOS>
but
I
did
not
know
it
was
a
bad
sign
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
a
dreadful
sign
,
"
returned
Blaize
,
with
a
shudder
"
The
thought
of
it
brings
back
my
old
symptoms
.
<EOS>
I
must
have
a
supper
to
guard
against
infection
--
a
slice
of
toasted
bread
,
sprinkled
with
,
vinegar
,
and
powdered
with
nutmeg
.
"
 
<EOS>
And
chattering
thus
,
they
proceeded
to
the
kitchen
.
 
<EOS>
Before
supper
could
be
served
,
Dr.
Hodges
made
his
appearance
.
<EOS>
He
was
delighted
to
see
the
family
assembled
together
again
,
and
expressed
a
hearty
wish
that
they
might
never
more
be
divided
.
<EOS>
He
watched
Amabel
and
Leonard
carefully
,
and
seemed
annoyed
that
the
former
rather
shunned
than
favoured
the
regards
of
the
apprentice
.
 
<EOS>
Leonard
,
too
,
looked
disconcerted
;
and
though
he
was
in
possession
of
his
mistress
's
promise
,
he
did
not
like
to
reclaim
it
.
<EOS>
During
the
whole
of
the
month
,
he
had
been
constantly
on
the
watch
,
and
had
scarcely
slept
at
night
,
<EOS>
so
anxious
was
he
to
prevent
the
possibility
of
any
communication
taking
place
between
Rochester
and
his
mistress
.
<EOS>
But
,
in
spite
of
all
his
caution
,
it
was
possible
he
might
be
deceived
.
<EOS>
And
when
on
this
,
their
first
meeting
,
she
returned
his
anxious
gaze
with
averted
looks
,
he
felt
all
his
jealous
misgivings
return
.
 
<EOS>
Supper
,
meanwhile
,
proceeded
.
<EOS>
Doctor
Hodges
was
in
excellent
spirits
,
and
drank
a
bottle
of
old
sack
with
great
relish
.
<EOS>
Overcome
by
the
sight
of
his
wife
and
children
,
the
grocer
abandoned
himself
to
his
feelings
.
<EOS>
As
to
his
wife
,
she
could
scarcely
contain
herself
,
but
wept
and
laughed
by
turns
--
now
embracing
her
husband
,
now
her
son
,
between
whom
she
had
placed
herself
.
<EOS>
Nor
did
she
forget
Doctor
Hodges
;
and
such
was
the
exuberance
of
her
satisfaction
,
that
when
the
repast
was
ended
,
she
arose
,
and
,
flinging
her
arms
about
his
neck
,
termed
him
the
preserver
of
her
son
.
 
<EOS>
"
If
any
one
is
entitled
to
that
appellation
it
is
his
father
,
"
replied
Hodges
,
"
and
I
may
say
,
that
in
all
my
experience
I
have
never
witnessed
such
generous
self
-
devotion
as
Mr.
Bloundel
has
exhibited
towards
his
son
.
<EOS>
You
must
now
be
satisfied
,
madam
,
that
no
person
can
so
well
judge
what
is
proper
for
the
safety
of
his
family
as
your
husband
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
never
doubted
it
,
sir
,
"
replied
Mrs.
Bloundel
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
must
apprise
you
,
then
,
that
he
has
conceived
a
plan
by
which
he
trusts
to
secure
you
and
his
children
and
household
from
any
future
attack
,
"
returned
Hodges
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
care
not
what
it
is
,
so
it
does
not
separate
me
from
him
,
"
replied
Mrs.
Bloundel
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
does
not
,
"
replied
the
grocer
.
<EOS>
"
It
will
knit
us
more
closely
together
than
we
have
yet
been
.
<EOS>
I
mean
to
shut
up
my
house
,
having
previously
stored
it
with
provisions
for
a
twelvemonth
,
and
shall
suffer
no
member
of
my
family
to
stir
forth
as
long
as
the
plague
endures
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
ready
to
remain
within
doors
,
if
it
continues
twenty
years
,
"
replied
his
wife
.
<EOS>
"
But
how
long
do
you
think
it
_
will
<EOS>
_
last
,
doctor
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Till
next
December
,
I
have
no
doubt
,
"
returned
Hodges
.
 
<EOS>
"
So
long
?
"
exclaimed
Amabel
.
 
<EOS>
"
Ay
,
so
long
,
"
repeated
the
doctor
.
<EOS>
"
It
has
scarcely
begun
now
.
<EOS>
Your
father
is
right
to
adopt
these
precautions
.
<EOS>
It
is
the
only
way
to
insure
the
safety
of
his
family
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
But----
"
cried
Amabel
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
resolved
,
"
interrupted
Bloundel
,
peremptorily
.
<EOS>
"
Who
ever
leaves
the
house
--
if
but
for
a
moment
--
never
returns
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
And
when
do
you
close
it
,
father
?
<EOS>
"
asked
Amabel
.
 
<EOS>
"
A
week
hence
,
"
replied
the
grocer
;
"
as
soon
as
I
have
laid
in
a
sufficient
stock
of
provisions
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
And
am
I
not
to
leave
the
house
for
a
year
?
"
<EOS>
cried
Amabel
,
with
a
dissatisfied
look
.
 
<EOS>
"
Why
should
you
wish
to
leave
it
?
"
<EOS>
asked
her
father
,
curiously
.
 
<EOS>
"
Ay
,
why
?
"
repeated
Leonard
,
in
a
low
tone
.
<EOS>
"
I
shall
be
here
.
"
 
<EOS>
Amabel
seemed
confused
,
and
looked
from
her
father
to
Leonard
.
<EOS>
The
former
,
however
,
did
not
notice
her
embarrassment
,
but
observed
to
Hodges--"I
shall
begin
to
victual
the
house
to
-
morrow
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Amabel
,
"
whispered
Leonard
,
"
you
told
me
if
I
claimed
your
hand
in
a
month
,
you
would
yield
it
to
me
.
<EOS>
I
require
the
fulfilment
of
your
promise
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Give
me
till
to
-
morrow
,
"
she
replied
,
distractedly
.
 
<EOS>
"
She
has
seen
Rochester
,
"
muttered
the
apprentice
,
turning
away
.
  
<EOS>
II
.
 
<EOS>
IN
WHAT
MANNER
<EOS>
THE
GROCER
VICTUALLED
HIS
HOUSE
.
 
<EOS>
Leonard
Holt
was
wrong
in
his
suspicions
.
<EOS>
Amabel
had
neither
seen
nor
heard
from
Rochester
.
<EOS>
But
,
if
the
truth
must
be
told
,
he
was
never
out
of
her
mind
,
and
she
found
,
to
her
cost
,
that
the
heart
will
not
be
controlled
.
<EOS>
Convinced
of
her
noble
lover
's
perfidy
,
and
aware
she
was
acting
wrongfully
in
cherishing
a
passion
for
him
,
after
the
exposure
of
his
base
designs
towards
herself
,
no
reasoning
of
which
she
was
capable
could
banish
him
from
her
thoughts
,
or
enable
her
to
transfer
her
affections
to
the
apprentice
.
 
<EOS>
This
conflict
of
feeling
produced
its
natural
result
.
<EOS>
She
became
thoughtful
and
dejected
--
was
often
in
tears
--
had
no
appetite
--
and
could
scarcely
rouse
herself
sufficiently
to
undertake
any
sort
of
employment
.
<EOS>
Her
mother
watched
her
with
great
anxiety
,
and
feared
--
though
she
sought
to
disguise
it
from
herself
--
what
was
the
real
cause
of
her
despondency
.
 
<EOS>
Things
were
in
this
position
at
the
end
of
the
month
,
and
it
occasioned
no
surprise
to
Mrs.
Bloundel
,
though
it
afflicted
her
deeply
,
to
find
that
Amabel
sedulously
avoided
the
apprentice
's
regards
on
their
first
meeting
.
<EOS>
When
Doctor
Hodges
was
gone
,
and
the
rest
of
the
family
had
retired
,
she
remarked
to
her
husband
,
"
Before
you
shut
up
the
house
as
you
propose
,
I
should
,
wish
one
important
matter
settled
.
"
 
<EOS>
The
grocer
inquired
what
she
meant
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
should
wish
to
have
Amabel
married
,
"
was
the
answer
.
 
<EOS>
"
Married
!
"
exclaimed
Bloundel
,
in
astonishment
.
"
<EOS>
To
whom
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
To
Leonard
Holt
.
"
 
<EOS>
Bloundel
could
scarcely
repress
his
displeasure
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
will
be
time
enough
to
talk
of
that
a
year
hence
,
"
he
answered
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
think
so
,
"
returned
his
wife
;
"
and
now
,
since
the
proper
time
for
the
disclosure
of
the
secret
has
arrived
,
I
must
tell
you
that
the
gallant
who
called
himself
Maurice
Wyvil
,
and
whom
you
so
much
dreaded
,
was
no
other
than
the
Earl
of
Rochester
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Rochester
!
"
echoed
the
grocer
,
while
an
angry
flush
stained
his
cheek
;
"
has
that
libertine
dared
to
enter
my
house
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
Ay
,
and
more
than
once
,
"
replied
Mrs.
Bloundel
.
 
<EOS>
"
Indeed
!
"
cried
her
husband
,
with
difficulty
controlling
his
indignation
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
When
was
he
here?--tell
me
quickly
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
His
wife
then
proceeded
to
relate
all
that
had
occurred
,
and
he
listened
with
profound
attention
to
her
recital
.
<EOS>
At
its
close
,
he
arose
and
paced
the
chamber
for
some
time
in
great
agitation
.
 
<EOS>
At
length
he
suddenly
paused
,
and
,
regarding
his
wife
with
great
sternness
,
observed
,
in
a
severe
tone
,
"
You
have
done
very
wrong
in
concealing
this
from
me
,
Honora
--
very
wrong
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
If
I
have
erred
,
it
was
to
spare
you
uneasiness
,
"
returned
Mrs.
Bloundel
,
bursting
into
tears
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Doctor
Hodges
agreed
with
me
that
it
was
better
not
to
mention
the
subject
while
you
had
so
many
other
anxieties
pressing
upon
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
a
stout
heart
,
and
a
firm
reliance
on
the
goodness
of
Heaven
,
which
will
enable
me
to
bear
up
against
most
evils
,
"
returned
the
grocer
.
"
<EOS>
But
on
this
point
I
ought
,
under
any
circumstances
,
to
have
been
consulted
.
<EOS>
And
I
am
greatly
surprised
that
Doctor
Hodges
should
advise
the
contrary
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
He
was
influenced
,
like
myself
,
by
the
kindliest
feelings
towards
you
,
"
sobbed
Mrs.
Bloundel
.
 
<EOS>
"
Well
,
well
,
I
will
not
reproach
you
further
,
"
returned
the
grocer
,
somewhat
moved
by
her
tears
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
no
doubt
you
conceived
you
were
acting
for
the
best
.
<EOS>
But
I
must
caution
you
against
such
conduct
for
the
future
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
After
a
pause
,
he
added
,
"
Is
it
your
opinion
that
our
poor
deluded
child
still
entertains
any
regard
for
this
profligate
nobleman
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
sure
she
does
,
"
replied
Mrs.
Bloundel
;
"
and
it
is
from
that
conviction
that
I
so
strongly
urge
the
necessity
of
marrying
her
to
Leonard
Holt
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
will
never
compel
her
to
do
anything
to
endanger
her
future
happiness
,
"
returned
the
grocer
.
<EOS>
"
She
must
not
marry
Leonard
Holt
without
loving
him
.
<EOS>
It
is
better
to
risk
an
uncertain
evil
,
than
to
rush
upon
a
certain
one
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Then
I
wo
n't
answer
for
the
consequences
,
"
replied
his
wife
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Bloundel
;
"
am
I
to
understand
you
have
no
reliance
on
Amabel
?
<EOS>
Has
all
our
care
been
thrown
away
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
do
not
distrust
her
,
"
returned
Mrs.
Bloundel
;
"
but
consider
whom
she
has
to
deal
with
.
<EOS>
She
is
beset
by
the
handsomest
and
most
fascinating
man
of
the
day
--
by
one
understood
to
be
practised
in
all
the
arts
most
dangerous
to
our
sex
--
and
a
nobleman
to
boot
.
<EOS>
Some
allowance
must
be
made
for
her
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
will
make
none
,
"
rejoined
Bloundel
,
austerely
.
"
<EOS>
She
has
been
taught
to
resist
temptation
in
whatever
guise
it
may
present
itself
;
and
if
the
principles
I
have
endeavoured
to
implant
within
her
breast
had
found
lodgment
there
,
she
_
would
_
have
resisted
it
.
<EOS>
I
am
deeply
grieved
to
find
this
is
not
the
case
,
and
that
she
must
trust
to
others
for
protection
,
when
she
ought
to
be
able
to
defend
herself
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
The
subject
was
not
further
discussed
,
and
the
grocer
and
his
wife
shortly
afterwards
retired
to
rest
.
 
<EOS>
On
the
following
morning
,
Bloundel
remarked
to
the
apprentice
as
they
stood
together
in
the
shop
,
"
Leonard
,
you
are
aware
I
am
about
to
shut
up
my
house
.
<EOS>
Before
doing
so
,
I
must
make
certain
needful
arrangements
.
<EOS>
I
will
not
disguise
from
you
that
I
should
prefer
your
remaining
with
me
,
but
at
the
same
time
I
beg
you
distinctly
to
understand
that
I
will
not
detain
you
against
your
will
.
<EOS>
Your
articles
are
within
two
months
of
expiring
;
and
,
if
you
desire
it
,
I
will
deliver
them
to
you
to
-
morrow
,
and
release
you
from
the
rest
of
your
time
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
do
not
desire
it
,
sir
,
"
replied
Leonard
;
"
I
will
remain
as
long
as
I
can
be
serviceable
to
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Take
time
for
reflection
,
"
rejoined
his
master
,
kindly
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
In
all
probability
,
it
will
be
a
long
confinement
,
and
you
may
repent
,
when
too
late
,
having
subjected
yourself
to
it
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Last
month
's
experience
has
taught
me
what
I
have
to
expect
,
"
remarked
Leonard
,
with
a
smile
.
<EOS>
"
My
mind
is
made
up
,
I
will
stay
with
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
glad
of
it
,
"
returned
Bloundel
,
"
and
now
I
have
something
further
to
say
to
you
.
<EOS>
My
wife
has
acquainted
me
with
the
daring
attempt
of
the
Earl
of
Rochester
to
carry
off
Amabel
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Has
my
mistress
,
also
,
told
you
of
my
attachment
to
your
daughter
?
"
demanded
Leonard
,
trembling
,
in
spite
of
his
efforts
to
maintain
a
show
of
calmness
.
 
<EOS>
Bloundel
nodded
an
affirmative
.
 
<EOS>
"
And
of
Amabel
's
promise
to
bestow
her
hand
upon
me
,
if
I
claimed
it
at
the
month
's
end
?
"
continued
the
apprentice
.
 
<EOS>
"
No
!
"
replied
the
grocer
,
a
good
deal
<EOS>
surprised--"I
heard
of
no
such
promise
.
<EOS>
Nor
was
I
aware
the
matter
had
gone
so
far
.
<EOS>
But
have
you
claimed
it
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
,
"
replied
Leonard
;
"
but
she
declined
giving
an
answer
till
to
-
day
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
We
will
have
it
,
then
,
at
once
,
"
cried
Bloundel
"
Come
with
me
to
her
.
"
 
<EOS>
So
saying
,
he
led
the
way
to
the
inner
room
,
where
they
found
Amabel
and
her
mother
.
<EOS>
At
the
sight
of
Leonard
,
the
former
instantly
cast
down
her
eyes
.
 
<EOS>
"
Amabel
,
"
said
her
father
,
in
a
tone
of
greater
severity
than
he
had
ever
before
used
towards
her
,
"
all
that
has
passed
is
known
to
me
.
<EOS>
I
shall
take
another
and
more
fitting
opportunity
to
speak
to
you
on
your
ill
-
advised
conduct
.
<EOS>
I
am
come
for
a
different
purpose
.
<EOS>
You
have
given
Leonard
Holt
a
promise
(
I
need
not
tell
you
of
what
nature
)
,
and
he
claims
its
fulfilment
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
If
he
insists
upon
my
compliance
,
"
replied
Amabel
,
in
a
tremulous
voice
,
"
I
must
obey
.
<EOS>
But
it
will
make
me
wretched
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Then
I
at
once
release
you
,
"
replied
Leonard
.
<EOS>
"
I
value
your
happiness
far
more
than
my
own
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
deserve
better
treatment
,
Leonard
,
"
said
Bloundel
;
"
and
I
am
sorry
my
daughter
can
not
discern
what
is
for
her
good
.
<EOS>
Let
us
hope
that
time
will
work
a
change
in
your
favour
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
replied
the
apprentice
,
bitterly
;
"
I
will
no
longer
delude
myself
with
any
such
vain
expectation
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Amabel
,
"
observed
the
grocer
,
"
as
your
father
--
as
your
wellwisher
--
I
should
desire
to
see
you
wedded
to
Leonard
.
<EOS>
But
I
have
told
your
mother
,
and
now
tell
you
,
that
I
will
not
control
your
inclinations
,
and
will
only
attempt
to
direct
you
so
far
as
I
think
likely
to
be
conducive
to
your
happiness
.
<EOS>
On
another
point
,
I
must
assume
a
very
different
tone
.
<EOS>
You
can
no
longer
plead
ignorance
of
the
designs
of
the
depraved
person
who
besets
you
.
<EOS>
You
may
not
be
able
to
forget
him
--
but
you
can
avoid
him
.
<EOS>
If
you
see
him
alone
again
--
if
but
for
a
moment
--
I
cast
you
off
for
ever
.
<EOS>
Yes
,
for
ever
,
"
he
repeated
,
with
stern
emphasis
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
will
never
voluntarily
see
him
again
,
"
replied
Amabel
,
tremblingly
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
have
heard
my
determination
,
"
rejoined
her
father
.
<EOS>
"
Do
you
still
adhere
to
your
resolution
of
remaining
with
me
,
Leonard
?
"
<EOS>
he
added
,
turning
to
the
apprentice
.
<EOS>
"
If
what
has
just
passed
makes
any
alteration
in
your
wishes
,
state
so
,
frankly
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
will
stay
,
"
replied
Leonard
.
 
<EOS>
"
There
will
be
one
advantage
,
which
I
did
not
foresee
,
in
closing
my
house
,
"
remarked
the
grocer
aside
to
the
apprentice
.
<EOS>
"
It
will
effectually
keep
away
this
libertine
earl
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
so
,
"
replied
the
other
.
"
<EOS>
But
I
have
more
faith
in
my
own
vigilance
than
in
bolts
and
bars
.
<EOS>
"
 
Bloundel
and
Leonard
then
returned
to
the
shop
,
where
the
former
immediately
began
to
make
preparations
for
storing
his
house
;
and
in
the
prosecution
of
his
scheme
he
was
greatly
aided
by
the
apprentice
.
 
<EOS>
The
grocer
's
dwelling
,
as
has
been
stated
,
was
large
and
commodious
.
<EOS>
It
was
three
stories
high
;
and
beneath
the
ground
-
floor
there
were
kitchens
and
extensive
cellars
.
<EOS>
Many
of
the
rooms
were
spacious
,
and
had
curiously
carved
fireplaces
,
walls
pannelled
with
fine
brown
oak
,
large
presses
,
and
cupboards
.
 
<EOS>
In
the
yard
,
at
the
back
of
the
house
,
there
was
a
pump
,
from
which
excellent
water
was
obtained
.
<EOS>
There
were
likewise
three
large
cisterns
,
supplied
from
the
New
River
.
<EOS>
Not
satisfied
with
this
,
and
anxious
to
obtain
water
in
which
no
infected
body
could
have
lain
,
or
clothes
have
been
washed
,
Bloundel
had
a
large
tank
placed
within
the
cellar
,
and
connecting
it
by
pipes
with
the
pump
,
he
contrived
an
ingenious
machine
,
by
which
he
could
work
the
latter
from
within
the
house
--
thus
making
sure
of
a
constant
supply
of
water
direct
from
the
spring
.
 
<EOS>
He
next
addressed
himself
to
the
front
of
the
house
,
where
he
fixed
a
pulley
,
with
a
rope
and
hook
attached
to
it
,
to
the
beam
above
one
of
the
smaller
bay
windows
on
the
second
story
.
<EOS>
By
this
means
,
he
could
let
down
a
basket
or
any
other
article
into
the
street
,
or
draw
up
whatever
he
desired
;
and
as
he
proposed
using
this
outlet
as
the
sole
means
of
communication
with
the
external
world
when
his
house
was
closed
,
he
had
a
wooden
shutter
made
in
the
form
of
a
trap
-
door
,
which
he
could
open
and
shut
at
pleasure
.
 
<EOS>
Here
it
was
his
intention
to
station
himself
at
certain
hours
of
the
day
,
and
whenever
he
held
any
communication
below
,
to
flash
off
a
pistol
,
so
that
the
smoke
of
the
powder
might
drive
back
the
air
,
and
purify
any
vapour
that
found
entrance
of
its
noxious
particles
.
 
<EOS>
He
laid
down
to
himself
a
number
of
regulations
,
which
will
be
more
easily
shown
and
more
clearly
understood
,
on
arriving
at
the
period
when
his
plans
came
to
be
in
full
operation
.
<EOS>
To
give
an
instance
,
however
--
if
a
letter
should
be
conveyed
to
him
by
means
of
the
pulley
,
he
proposed
to
steep
it
in
a
solution
of
vinegar
and
sulphur
;
and
when
dried
and
otherwise
fumigated
,
to
read
it
at
a
distance
by
the
help
of
strong
glasses
.
 
<EOS>
In
regard
to
provisions
,
after
a
careful
calculation
,
he
bought
upwards
of
three
thousand
pounds
'
weight
of
hard
sea
-
biscuits
,
similar
to
those
now
termed
captain
's
biscuits
,
and
had
them
stowed
away
in
hogsheads
.
<EOS>
He
next
ordered
twenty
huge
casks
of
the
finest
flour
,
which
he
had
packed
up
with
the
greatest
care
,
as
if
for
a
voyage
to
Barbadoes
or
Jamaica
.
<EOS>
As
these
were
brought
in
through
the
yard
an
accident
had
well
-
nigh
occurred
which
might
have
proved
fatal
to
him
.
<EOS>
While
superintending
the
labours
of
Leonard
and
Blaize
,
who
were
rolling
the
casks
into
the
house
--
having
stowed
away
as
many
as
he
conveniently
could
in
the
upper
part
of
the
premises
--
he
descended
to
the
cellar
,
and
,
opening
a
door
at
the
foot
of
a
flight
of
steps
leading
from
the
yard
,
called
to
them
to
lower
the
remaining
barrels
with
ropes
below
.
<EOS>
In
the
hurry
,
Blaize
rolled
a
cask
towards
the
open
door
,
and
in
another
instant
it
would
have
fallen
upon
the
grocer
,
and
perhaps
have
crushed
him
,
but
for
the
interposition
of
Leonard
.
<EOS>
Bloundel
made
no
remark
at
the
time
;
but
he
never
forgot
the
service
rendered
him
by
the
apprentice
.
 
<EOS>
To
bake
the
bread
required
an
oven
,
and
he
accordingly
built
one
in
the
garret
,
laying
in
a
large
stock
of
wood
for
fuel
.
<EOS>
Neither
did
he
neglect
to
provide
himself
with
two
casks
of
meal
.
 
<EOS>
But
the
most
important
consideration
was
butcher
's
meat
;
and
for
this
purpose
he
went
to
Rotherhithe
,
where
the
plague
had
not
yet
appeared
,
and
agreed
with
a
butcher
to
kill
him
four
fat
bullocks
,
and
pickle
and
barrel
them
as
if
for
sea
stores
.
<EOS>
He
likewise
directed
the
man
to
provide
six
large
barrels
of
pickled
pork
,
on
the
same
understanding
.
<EOS>
These
were
landed
at
Queenhithe
,
and
brought
up
to
Wood
-
street
,
so
that
they
passed
for
newly
-
landed
grocery
.
 
<EOS>
Hams
and
bacon
forming
part
of
his
own
trade
<EOS>
,
he
wrote
to
certain
farmers
with
whom
he
was
in
the
habit
of
dealing
,
to
send
him
up
an
unlimited
supply
of
flitches
and
gammons
;
and
his
orders
being
promptly
and
abundantly
answered
,
he
soon
found
he
had
more
bacon
than
he
could
possibly
consume
.
<EOS>
He
likewise
laid
in
a
good
store
of
tongues
,
hung
beet
,
and
other
dried
meats
.
 
<EOS>
As
to
wine
,
he
already
had
a
tolerable
stock
;
but
he
increased
it
by
half
a
hogshead
of
the
best
canary
he
could
procure
;
two
casks
of
malmsey
,
each
containing
twelve
gallons
;
a
quarter
-
cask
of
Malaga
sack
;
a
runlet
of
muscadine
;
two
small
runlets
of
aqua
vitae
;
twenty
gallons
of
aniseed
water
;
and
two
eight
-
gallon
runlets
of
brandy
.
<EOS>
To
this
he
added
six
hogsheads
of
strongly
-
hopped
Kent
ale
,
calculated
for
keeping
,
which
he
placed
in
a
cool
cellar
,
together
with
three
hogsheads
of
beer
,
for
immediate
use
.
<EOS>
Furthermore
,
he
procured
a
variety
of
distilled
waters
for
medicinal
purposes
,
amongst
which
he
included
a
couple
of
dozen
of
the
then
fashionable
and
costly
preparation
,
denominated
plague
-
water
.
 
<EOS>
As
,
notwithstanding
all
his
precautions
,
it
was
not
impossible
that
some
of
his
household
might
be
attacked
by
the
distemper
,
he
took
care
to
provide
proper
remedies
,
and
,
to
Blaize
's
infinite
delight
,
furnished
himself
with
mithridates
,
Venice
treacle
,
diascorium
,
the
pill
rufus
<EOS>
(
oh
!
how
the
porter
longed
to
have
the
key
of
the
medicine
chest
!
)
,
London
treacle
,
turpentine
,
and
other
matters
.
<EOS>
He
likewise
collected
a
number
of
herbs
and
simples
;
as
Virginian
snakeweed
,
contrajerva
,
pestilence
-
wort
,
angelica
,
elecampane
,
zedoary
,
tormentil
,
valerian
,
lovage
,
devils
-
bit
,
dittany
,
master
-
wort
,
rue
,
sage
,
ivy
-
berries
,
and
walnuts
;
together
with
bole
ammoniac
,
terra
sigillata
,
bezoar
-
water
,
oil
of
sulphur
,
oil
of
vitriol
,
and
other
compounds
.
<EOS>
His
store
of
remedies
was
completed
by
a
tun
of
the
best
white
-
wine
vinegar
,
and
a
dozen
jars
of
salad
-
oil
.
 
<EOS>
Regulating
his
supplies
by
the
provisions
he
had
laid
in
,
he
purchased
a
sufficient
stock
of
coals
and
fagots
to
last
him
during
the
whole
period
of
his
confinement
;
and
he
added
a
small
barrel
of
gunpowder
,
and
a
like
quantity
of
sulphur
for
fumigation
.
 
<EOS>
His
eatables
would
not
have
been
complete
without
cheese
;
and
he
therefore
ordered
about
six
hundredweight
from
Derbyshire
,
Wiltshire
,
and
Leicestershire
,
besides
a
couple
of
large
old
cheeses
from
Rostherne
,
in
Cheshire
--
even
then
noted
for
the
best
dairies
in
the
whole
county
.
<EOS>
Several
tubs
of
salted
butter
were
sent
him
out
of
Berkshire
,
and
a
few
pots
,
from
Suffolk
.
 
<EOS>
It
being
indispensable
,
considering
the
long
period
he
meant
to
close
his
house
,
to
provide
himself
and
his
family
with
every
necessary
,
he
procured
a
sufficient
stock
of
wearing
apparel
,
hose
,
shoes
and
boots
.
<EOS>
Spice
,
dried
fruit
,
and
other
grocery
articles
,
were
not
required
,
because
he
already
possessed
them
.
<EOS>
Candles
also
formed
an
article
of
his
trade
,
and
lamp
-
oil
;
but
he
was
recommended
by
Doctor
Hodges
,
from
a
fear
of
the
scurvy
,
to
provide
a
plentiful
supply
of
lemon
and
lime
juice
.
 
<EOS>
To
guard
against
accident
,
he
also
doubly
stocked
his
house
with
glass
,
earthenware
,
and
every
article
liable
to
breakage
.
<EOS>
He
destroyed
all
vermin
,
such
as
rats
and
mice
,
by
which
the
house
was
infested
;
and
the
only
live
creatures
he
would
suffer
to
be
kept
were
a
few
poultry
.
<EOS>
He
had
a
small
hutch
constructed
near
the
street
-
door
,
to
be
used
by
the
watchman
he
meant
to
employ
;
and
he
had
the
garrets
fitted
up
with
beds
to
form
an
hospital
,
if
any
part
of
the
family
should
be
seized
with
the
distemper
,
so
that
the
sick
might
be
sequestered
from
the
sound
.
        
<EOS>
*
      
<EOS>
*
      
<EOS>
*
      
<EOS>
*
      
<EOS>
*
  
III
.
 
<EOS>
THE
QUACK
DOCTORS
.
 
<EOS>
Patience
,
it
may
be
remembered
,
had
promised
Blaize
to
give
him
her
earnings
to
enable
him
to
procure
a
fresh
supply
of
medicine
,
and
about
a
week
after
he
had
received
the
trifling
amount
(
for
he
had
been
so
constantly
employed
by
the
grocer
that
he
had
no
opportunity
of
getting
out
before
)
,
he
sallied
forth
to
visit
a
neighbouring
apothecary
,
named
Parkhurst
,
from
whom
he
had
been
in
the
habit
of
purchasing
drugs
,
and
who
occupied
a
small
shop
not
far
from
the
grocer
's
,
on
the
opposite
side
of
the
street
.
<EOS>
Parkhurst
appeared
overjoyed
to
see
him
,
and
,
without
giving
him
time
to
prefer
his
own
request
,
inquired
after
his
master
's
family
--
whether
they
were
all
well
,
especially
fair
Mistress
Amabel
--
and
,
further
,
what
was
the
meaning
of
the
large
supplies
of
provision
which
he
saw
daily
conveyed
to
the
premises
?
<EOS>
Blaize
shook
his
head
at
the
latter
question
,
and
for
some
time
refused
to
answer
it
.
<EOS>
But
being
closely
pressed
by
Parkhurst
,
he
admitted
that
his
master
was
about
to
shut
up
his
house
.
 
<EOS>
"
Shut
up
his
house
!
"
exclaimed
Parkhurst
.
<EOS>
"
I
never
heard
of
such
a
preposterous
idea
.
<EOS>
If
he
does
so
,
not
one
of
you
will
come
out
alive
.
<EOS>
But
I
should
hope
that
he
will
be
dissuaded
from
his
rash
design
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Dissuaded
!
"
echoed
Blaize
.
<EOS>
"
You
do
n't
know
my
master
.
<EOS>
He
's
as
obstinate
as
a
mule
when
he
takes
a
thing
into
his
head
.
<EOS>
Nothing
will
turn
him
.
<EOS>
Besides
,
Doctor
Hodges
sanctions
and
even
recommends
the
plan
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
no
opinion
of
Doctor
Hodges
,
"
sneered
the
apothecary
.
<EOS>
"
He
is
not
fit
to
hold
a
candle
before
a
learned
friend
of
mine
,
a
physician
,
who
is
now
in
that
room
.
<EOS>
The
person
I
speak
of
thoroughly
understands
the
pestilence
,
and
never
fails
to
cure
every
case
that
comes
before
him
.
<EOS>
No
shutting
up
houses
with
him
.
<EOS>
He
is
in
possession
of
an
infallible
remedy
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Indeed
!
"
exclaimed
Blaize
,
pricking
up
his
ears
.
<EOS>
"
What
is
his
name
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
His
name
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Parkhurst
,
with
a
puzzled
look
.
<EOS>
"
How
strange
it
should
slip
my
memory
!
<EOS>
Ah
,
now
I
recollect
.
<EOS>
It
is
Doctor
Calixtus
Bottesham
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
A
singular
name
,
truly
,
"
remarked
Blaize
;
"
but
it
sounds
like
that
of
a
clever
man
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Doctor
Calixtus
Bottesham
is
a
wonderful
man
,
"
returned
the
apothecary
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
never
met
with
his
like
.
<EOS>
I
would
trumpet
forth
his
merits
through
the
whole
city
,
but
that
it
would
ruin
my
trade
.
<EOS>
The
plague
is
our
harvest
,
as
my
friend
Chowles
,
the
coffin
-
maker
,
says
,
and
it
will
not
do
to
stop
it
--
<EOS>
ha
!
ha
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
too
serious
a
subject
to
laugh
at
,
"
returned
Blaize
,
gravely
.
"
<EOS>
But
are
the
doctor
's
fees
exorbitant
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
To
the
last
degree
,
"
replied
Parkhurst
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
afraid
to
state
how
much
he
asks
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
fear
I
shall
not
be
able
to
consult
him
,
then
,
"
said
Blaize
,
turning
over
the
coin
in
his
pocket
;
"
<EOS>
and
yet
I
should
greatly
like
to
do
so
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Have
no
fear
on
that
score
,
"
returned
the
apothecary
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
been
able
to
render
him
an
important
service
,
and
he
will
do
anything
for
me
.
<EOS>
He
shall
give
you
his
advice
gratis
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Thank
you
!
<EOS>
thank
you
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Blaize
,
transported
with
delight
.
 
<EOS>
"
Wait
here
a
moment
,
and
I
will
ascertain
whether
he
will
see
you
,
"
replied
Parkhurst
.
 
<EOS>
So
saying
,
he
quitted
the
porter
,
who
amused
himself
during
his
absence
by
studying
the
labels
affixed
to
the
jars
and
bottles
on
the
shelves
.
<EOS>
He
had
much
ado
to
restrain
himself
from
opening
some
of
them
,
and
tasting
their
contents
.
 
<EOS>
Full
a
quarter
of
an
hour
elapsed
before
the
apothecary
appeared
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
sorry
to
have
detained
you
so
long
,
"
he
said
;
"
<EOS>
but
I
had
more
difficulty
with
the
doctor
than
I
expected
,
and
for
some
time
he
refused
to
see
you
on
any
terms
,
because
he
has
a
violent
antipathy
to
Doctor
Hodges
,
whom
he
regards
as
a
mere
pretender
,
and
whose
patient
he
conceives
you
to
be
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
not
Doctor
Hodges
'
patient
,
"
returned
Blaize
;
"
and
I
regard
him
as
a
pretender
myself
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
That
opinion
will
recommend
you
to
Doctor
Bottesham
,
"
replied
Parkhurst
;
"
and
since
I
have
smoothed
the
way
for
you
,
you
will
find
him
very
affable
and
condescending
.
<EOS>
He
has
often
heard
me
speak
of
your
master
;
and
if
it
were
not
for
his
dislike
of
Doctor
Hodges
,
whom
he
might
accidentally
encounter
,
he
would
call
upon
him
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
wish
I
could
get
my
master
to
employ
him
instead
of
the
other
,
"
said
Blaize
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
wish
so
too
,
"
cried
Parkhurst
,
eagerly
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Do
you
think
it
could
be
managed
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
fear
not
,
"
returned
Blaize
.
 
<EOS>
"
There
would
be
no
harm
in
making
the
trial
,
"
replied
Parkhurst
.
<EOS>
"
But
you
shall
now
see
the
learned
gentleman
.
<EOS>
I
ought
to
apprise
you
that
he
has
two
friends
with
him
--
one
a
young
gallant
,
named
Hawkswood
,
whom
he
has
recently
cured
of
the
distemper
,
and
who
is
so
much
attached
to
him
that
he
never
leaves
him
;
the
other
,
a
doctor
,
like
himself
,
named
Martin
Furbisher
,
who
always
accompanies
him
in
his
visits
to
his
patients
,
and
prepares
his
mixtures
for
him
.
<EOS>
You
must
not
be
surprised
at
their
appearance
.
<EOS>
And
now
come
with
me
.
"
 
<EOS>
With
this
,
he
led
the
way
into
a
small
room
at
the
back
of
the
shop
,
where
three
personages
were
seated
at
the
table
,
with
a
flask
of
wine
and
glasses
before
them
.
<EOS>
Blaize
detected
Doctor
Bottesham
at
a
glance
.
<EOS>
He
was
an
ancient
-
looking
man
,
clad
in
a
suit
of
rusty
black
,
over
which
was
thrown
a
velvet
robe
,
very
much
soiled
and
faded
,
but
originally
trimmed
with
fur
,
and
lined
with
yellow
silk
.
<EOS>
His
powers
of
vision
appeared
to
be
feeble
,
for
he
wore
a
large
green
shade
over
his
eyes
,
and
a
pair
of
spectacles
of
the
same
colour
.
<EOS>
A
venerable
white
beard
descended
almost
to
his
waist
.
<EOS>
His
head
was
protected
by
a
long
flowing
grey
wig
,
over
which
he
wore
a
black
velvet
cap
.
<EOS>
His
shoulders
were
high
and
round
,
his
back
bent
,
and
he
evidently
required
support
when
he
moved
,
as
a
crutch
-
headed
staff
was
reared
against
his
chair
.
<EOS>
On
his
left
was
a
young
,
handsome
,
and
richly
-
attired
gallant
,
answering
to
the
apothecary
's
description
of
Hawkswood
;
and
on
the
right
sat
a
stout
personage
precisely
habited
like
himself
,
except
that
he
wore
a
broad
-
leaved
hat
,
which
completely
overshadowed
his
features
.
<EOS>
Notwithstanding
this
attempt
at
concealment
,
it
was
easy
to
perceive
that
Doctor
Furbisher
's
face
was
covered
with
scars
,
that
he
had
a
rubicund
nose
,
studded
with
carbuncles
,
and
a
black
patch
over
his
left
eye
.
 
<EOS>
"
Is
this
the
young
man
who
desires
to
consult
me
?
"
asked
Doctor
Calixtus
Bottesham
,
in
the
cracked
and
quavering
voice
of
old
age
,
of
Parkhurst
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
,
"
replied
the
apothecary
,
respectfully
.
"
<EOS>
Go
forward
,
"
he
added
to
Blaize
,
"
and
speak
for
yourself
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
What
ails
you
?
"
<EOS>
pursued
Bottesham
,
gazing
at
him
through
his
spectacles
.
<EOS>
"
You
look
strong
and
hearty
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
So
I
am
,
learned
sir
,
"
replied
Blaize
,
bowing
to
the
ground
;
"
but
understanding
from
Mr.
Parkhurst
that
you
have
an
infallible
remedy
against
the
plague
,
I
would
gladly
procure
it
from
you
,
as
,
if
I
should
be
attacked
,
I
may
not
have
an
opportunity
of
consulting
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Why
not
?
"
demanded
Bottesham
.
<EOS>
"
I
will
come
to
you
if
you
send
for
me
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Because
,
"
replied
Blaize
,
after
a
moment
's
hesitation
,
"
<EOS>
my
master
is
about
to
shut
up
his
house
,
and
no
one
will
be
allowed
to
go
forth
,
or
to
enter
it
,
till
the
pestilence
is
at
an
end
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Your
master
must
be
mad
to
think
of
such
a
thing
,
"
rejoined
Bottesham
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
What
say
you
,
brother
Furbisher?--is
<EOS>
that
the
way
to
keep
off
the
plague
?
"
 
"
Gallipots
of
Galen
!
<EOS>
no
,
"
returned
the
other
;
"
it
is
rather
the
way
to
invite
its
assaults
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
When
does
your
master
talk
of
putting
this
fatal
design
--
for
fatal
it
will
be
to
him
and
all
his
household
--
into
execution
?
<EOS>
"
demanded
Bottesham
.
 
<EOS>
"
Very
shortly
,
I
believe
,
"
replied
Blaize
.
"
<EOS>
He
meant
to
begin
on
the
first
of
June
,
but
as
the
pestilence
is
less
violent
than
it
was
,
Doctor
Hodges
has
induced
him
to
defer
his
purpose
for
a
few
days
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Doctor
Hodges
!
"
exclaimed
Bottesham
,
contemptuously
.
<EOS>
"
It
was
an
unfortunate
day
for
your
master
when
he
admitted
that
sack
-
drinking
impostor
into
his
house
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
no
great
opinion
of
his
skill
,
"
replied
Blaize
,
"
but
,
nevertheless
,
it
must
be
admitted
that
he
cured
Master
Stephen
in
a
wonderful
manner
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Pshaw
!
"
exclaimed
Bottesham
,
"
that
was
mere
accident
.
<EOS>
I
heard
the
particulars
of
the
case
from
Parkhurst
,
and
am
satisfied
the
youth
would
have
recovered
without
his
aid
.
<EOS>
But
what
a
barbarian
Mr.
Bloundel
must
be
to
think
of
imprisoning
his
family
in
this
way
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
He
certainly
does
not
consult
my
inclinations
in
the
matter
,
"
returned
Blaize
.
 
<EOS>
"
Nor
those
of
his
wife
and
daughter
,
I
should
imagine
,
"
continued
Bottesham
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
How
do
_
<EOS>
they
_
<EOS>
like
it
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
can
not
exactly
say
,
"
answered
Blaize
.
<EOS>
"
What
a
dreadful
thing
it
would
be
if
I
should
be
attacked
by
the
plague
,
and
no
assistance
could
be
procured
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
would
be
still
more
dreadful
if
so
angelic
a
creature
as
Bloundel
's
daughter
is
represented
to
be
--
<EOS>
for
I
have
never
seen
her
--
should
be
so
seized
,
"
observed
Bottesham
.
<EOS>
"
I
feel
so
much
interested
about
her
that
I
would
do
anything
to
preserve
her
from
the
fate
with
which
she
is
menaced
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Were
it
not
inconsistent
with
your
years
,
learned
sir
,
I
might
suspect
you
of
a
tenderer
feeling
towards
her
,
"
observed
Blaize
,
archly
.
"
<EOS>
But
,
in
good
sooth
,
her
charms
are
so
extraordinary
,
that
I
should
not
be
surprised
at
any
effect
they
might
produce
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
They
would
produce
no
effect
on
me
,
"
replied
Bottesham
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
long
past
such
feelings
.
<EOS>
But
in
regard
to
yourself
.
<EOS>
You
say
you
are
afraid
of
the
plague
.
<EOS>
I
will
give
you
an
electuary
to
drive
away
the
panic
;
"
and
he
produced
a
small
jar
,
and
handed
it
to
the
porter
.
<EOS>
"
It
is
composed
of
conserve
of
roses
,
gillyflowers
,
borage
,
candied
citron
,
powder
of
_
laetificans
Galeni
_
,
Roman
zedoary
,
doronicum
,
and
saffron
.
<EOS>
You
must
take
about
the
quantity
of
a
large
nutmeg
,
morning
and
evening
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
make
me
for
ever
your
debtor
,
learned
sir
,
"
rejoined
Blaize
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
What
a
charming
mixture
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
will
also
add
my
remedy
,
"
said
Furbisher
.
<EOS>
"
It
is
a
powder
compounded
of
crabs
'
eyes
,
burnt
hartshorn
,
the
black
tops
of
crabs
'
claws
,
the
bone
from
a
stag
's
heart
,
unicorn
's
horn
,
and
salt
of
vipers
.
<EOS>
You
must
take
one
or
two
drams
--
not
more
--
in
a
glass
of
hot
posset
-
drink
,
when
you
go
to
bed
,
and
swallow
another
draught
of
the
same
potion
to
wash
it
down
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
will
carefully
observe
your
directions
,
"
replied
Blaize
,
thankfully
receiving
the
powder
.
 
<EOS>
"
Of
all
things
,
"
said
Bottesham
,
claiming
the
porter
's
attention
by
tapping
him
on
the
head
with
his
cane
,
"
take
care
never
to
be
without
vinegar
.
<EOS>
It
is
the
grand
specific
,
not
merely
against
the
plague
,
but
against
all
disorders
.
<EOS>
It
is
food
and
physic
,
meat
and
medicine
,
drink
and
julep
,
cordial
and
antidote
.
<EOS>
If
you
formerly
took
it
as
a
sauce
,
now
take
it
as
a
remedy
.
<EOS>
To
the
sound
it
is
a
preservative
from
sickness
,
to
the
sick
,
a
restorative
to
health
.
<EOS>
It
is
like
the
sword
which
is
worn
not
merely
for
ornament
,
but
for
defence
.
<EOS>
Vinegar
is
my
remedy
against
the
plague
.
<EOS>
It
is
a
simple
remedy
,
but
an
effectual
one
.
<EOS>
I
have
cured
a
thousand
patients
with
it
,
and
hope
to
cure
a
thousand
more
.
<EOS>
Take
vinegar
with
all
you
eat
,
and
flavour
all
you
drink
with
it
.
<EOS>
Has
the
plague
taken
away
your
appetite
,
vinegar
will
renew
it
.
<EOS>
Is
your
throat
ulcerated
,
use
vinegar
as
a
gargle
.
<EOS>
Are
you
disturbed
with
phlegmatic
humours
,
vinegar
will
remove
them
.
<EOS>
Is
your
brain
laden
with
vapours
,
throw
vinegar
on
a
hot
shovel
,
and
inhale
its
fumes
,
and
you
will
obtain
instantaneous
relief
.
<EOS>
Have
you
the
headache
,
wet
a
napkin
in
vinegar
,
and
apply
it
to
your
temples
,
and
the
pain
will
cease
.
<EOS>
In
short
,
there
is
no
ailment
that
vinegar
will
not
cure
.
<EOS>
It
is
the
grand
panacea
;
and
may
be
termed
the
elixir
of
long
life
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
wonder
its
virtues
have
not
been
found
out
before
,
"
observed
Blaize
,
innocently
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
surprising
how
slow
men
are
in
discovering
the
most
obvious
truths
,
"
replied
Bottesham
.
"
<EOS>
But
take
my
advice
,
and
never
be
without
it
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
never
will
,
"
returned
Blaize
.
<EOS>
"
Heaven
be
praised
,
my
master
has
just
ordered
in
three
tuns
.
<EOS>
I
'll
tap
one
of
them
directly
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
That
idea
of
the
vinegar
remedy
is
borrowed
from
Kemp
's
late
treatise
on
the
pestilence
and
its
cure
,
"
muttered
Furbisher
.
<EOS>
"
Before
you
enter
upon
the
new
system
,
young
man
,
"
he
added
aloud
to
Blaize
,
"
let
me
recommend
you
to
fortify
your
stomach
with
a
glass
of
canary
.
"
 
<EOS>
And
pouring
out
a
bumper
,
he
handed
it
to
the
porter
,
who
swallowed
it
at
a
draught
.
 
<EOS>
"
And
now
,
"
said
Bottesham
,
"
to
return
to
this
mad
scheme
of
your
master's
--
<EOS>
is
there
no
way
of
preventing
it
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
aware
of
none
,
"
replied
Blaize
.
 
<EOS>
"
Bolts
and
bars
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Furbisher
,
"
something
must
be
done
for
the
fair
Amabel
.
<EOS>
We
owe
it
to
society
not
to
permit
so
lovely
a
creature
to
be
thus
immured
.
<EOS>
What
say
you
,
Hawkswood
?
"
<EOS>
he
added
to
the
gallant
by
his
side
,
who
had
not
hitherto
spoken
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
would
be
unpardonable
to
permit
it
--
quite
unpardonable
,
"
replied
this
person
.
 
<EOS>
"
Might
not
some
plan
be
devised
to
remove
her
for
a
short
time
,
and
frighten
him
out
of
his
project
?
"
said
Bottesham
.
<EOS>
"
I
would
willingly
assist
in
such
a
scheme
.
<EOS>
I
pledge
you
in
a
bumper
,
young
man
.
<EOS>
You
appear
a
trusty
servant
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
so
accounted
,
learned
sir
,
"
replied
Blaize
,
upon
whose
brain
the
wine
thus
plentifully
bestowed
began
to
operate--"and
<EOS>
I
may
add
,
justly
so
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
really
will
be
doing
your
master
a
service
if
you
can
prevent
him
from
committing
this
folly
,
"
rejoined
Bottesham
.
 
<EOS>
"
Let
us
have
a
bottle
of
burnt
malmsey
,
with
a
few
bruised
raisins
in
it
,
Mr.
Parkhurst
.
<EOS>
This
poor
young
man
requires
support
.
<EOS>
Be
seated
,
friend
.
"
 
<EOS>
With
some
hesitation
,
Blaize
complied
,
and
while
the
apothecary
went
in
search
of
the
wine
,
he
observed
to
Bottesham
,
"
I
would
gladly
comply
with
your
suggestion
,
learned
sir
,
if
I
saw
any
means
of
doing
so
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Could
you
not
pretend
to
have
the
plague
?
"
said
Bottesham
.
<EOS>
"
I
could
then
attend
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
should
be
afraid
of
playing
such
a
trick
as
that
,
"
replied
Blaize
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Besides
,
I
do
not
see
what
purpose
it
would
answer
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
would
enable
me
to
get
into
the
house
,
"
returned
Bottesham
,
"
and
then
I
might
take
measures
for
Amabel
's
deliverance
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
If
you
merely
wish
to
get
into
the
house
,
"
replied
Blaize
,
"
that
can
be
easily
managed
.
<EOS>
I
will
admit
you
this
evening
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Without
your
master
's
knowledge
?
"
asked
Bottesham
,
eagerly
.
 
<EOS>
"
Of
course
,
"
returned
Blaize
.
 
<EOS>
"
But
he
has
an
apprentice
?
"
said
the
doctor
.
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
!
you
mean
Leonard
Holt
,
"
replied
Blaize
.
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
we
must
take
care
<EOS>
he
does
n't
see
you
.
<EOS>
If
you
come
about
nine
o'clock
,
he
will
be
engaged
with
my
master
in
putting
away
the
things
in
the
shop
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
will
be
punctual
,
"
replied
Bottesham
,
"
and
will
bring
Doctor
Furbisher
with
me
.
<EOS>
We
will
only
stay
a
few
minutes
.
<EOS>
But
here
comes
the
burnt
malmsey
.
<EOS>
Fill
the
young
man
's
glass
,
Parkhurst
.
<EOS>
I
will
insure
you
against
the
plague
,
if
you
will
follow
my
advice
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
But
will
you
insure
me
against
my
master
's
displeasure
,
if
he
finds
me
out
?
"
said
Blaize
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
will
provide
you
with
a
new
one
,
"
returned
Bottesham
.
<EOS>
"
You
shall
serve
me
if
you
wish
to
change
your
place
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
That
would
answer
my
purpose
exactly
,
"
thought
Blaize
.
<EOS>
"
I
need
never
be
afraid
of
the
plague
if
I
live
with
him
.
<EOS>
I
will
turn
over
your
proposal
,
learned
sir
,
"
he
added
,
aloud
.
 
<EOS>
After
priming
him
with
another
bumper
of
malmsey
,
Blaise
's
new
friends
suffered
him
to
depart
.
<EOS>
On
returning
home
,
he
proceeded
to
his
own
room
,
and
feeling
unusually
drowsy
,
he
threw
himself
on
the
bed
,
and
almost
instantly
dropped
asleep
.
<EOS>
When
he
awoke
,
the
fumes
of
the
liquor
had
,
in
a
great
degree
,
evaporated
,
and
he
recalled
,
with
considerable
self
-
reproach
,
the
promise
he
had
given
,
and
would
gladly
have
recalled
it
,
if
it
had
been
possible
.
<EOS>
But
it
was
now
not
far
from
the
appointed
hour
,
and
he
momentarily
expected
the
arrival
of
the
two
doctors
.
<EOS>
The
only
thing
that
consoled
him
was
the
store
of
medicine
he
had
obtained
,
and
,
locking
it
up
in
his
cupboard
,
he
descended
to
the
kitchen
.
<EOS>
Fortunately
,
his
mother
was
from
home
,
so
that
he
ran
no
risk
from
her
;
and
,
finding
Patience
alone
,
after
some
hesitation
<EOS>
,
he
let
her
into
the
secret
of
his
anticipated
visitors
.
<EOS>
She
was
greatly
surprised
,
and
expressed
much
uneasiness
lest
they
should
be
discovered
;
as
,
if
they
were
so
,
it
would
be
sure
to
bring
them
both
into
trouble
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
can
they
want
with
Mistress
Amabel
?
<EOS>
"
she
cried
.
<EOS>
"
I
should
not
wonder
if
Doctor
Calixtus
Bottesham
,
as
you
call
him
,
turns
out
a
lover
in
disguise
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
A
lover
!
"
exclaimed
Blaize
.
"
<EOS>
Your
silly
head
is
always
running
upon
lovers
.
<EOS>
He
's
an
old
man
--
old
enough
to
be
your
grandfather
,
with
a
long
white
beard
,
reaching
to
his
waist
.
<EOS>
He
a
lover
!
<EOS>
Mr.
Bloundel
is
much
more
like
one
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
For
all
that
,
it
looks
suspicious
,
"
returned
Patience
;
"
and
I
shall
have
my
eyes
about
me
on
their
arrival
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
Shortly
after
this
,
Blaize
crept
cautiously
up
to
the
back
yard
,
and
,
opening
the
door
,
found
,
as
he
expected
,
Bottesham
and
his
companion
.
<EOS>
Motioning
them
to
follow
him
,
he
led
the
way
to
the
kitchen
,
where
they
arrived
without
observation
.
<EOS>
Patience
eyed
the
new
-
comers
narrowly
,
and
felt
almost
certain
,
from
their
appearance
and
manner
,
that
her
suspicions
were
correct
.
<EOS>
All
doubts
were
removed
when
Bottesham
,
slipping
a
purse
into
her
hand
,
entreated
her
,
on
some
plea
or
other
,
to
induce
Amabel
to
come
into
the
kitchen
.
<EOS>
At
first
she
hesitated
;
but
having
a
tender
heart
,
inclining
her
to
assist
rather
than
oppose
the
course
of
any
love
-
affair
,
her
scruples
were
soon
overcome
.
<EOS>
Accordingly
she
hurried
upstairs
,
and
chancing
to
meet
with
her
young
mistress
,
who
was
about
to
retire
to
her
own
chamber
,
entreated
her
to
come
down
with
her
for
a
moment
in
the
kitchen
.
<EOS>
Thinking
it
some
unimportant
matter
,
but
yet
wondering
why
Patience
should
appear
so
urgent
,
Amabel
complied
.
<EOS>
She
was
still
more
perplexed
when
she
saw
the
two
strangers
,
and
would
have
instantly
retired
if
Bottesham
had
not
detained
her
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
will
pardon
the
liberty
I
have
taken
in
sending
for
you
,
"
he
said
,
"
when
I
explain
that
I
have
done
so
to
offer
you
counsel
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
as
much
at
a
loss
to
understand
what
counsel
you
can
have
to
offer
,
sir
,
as
to
guess
why
you
are
here
,
"
she
replied
.
 
<EOS>
"
Amabel
,
"
returned
Bottesham
,
in
a
low
tone
,
but
altering
his
voice
,
and
slightly
raising
his
spectacles
so
as
to
disclose
his
features
;
"
it
is
I
--
Maurice
Wyvil
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
"
<EOS>
she
exclaimed
,
in
the
utmost
astonishment
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
told
you
we
should
meet
again
,
"
he
rejoined
;
"
and
I
have
kept
my
word
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Think
not
to
deceive
me
,
my
lord
,
"
she
returned
,
controlling
her
emotion
by
a
powerful
effort
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
aware
you
are
not
Maurice
Wyvil
,
but
the
Earl
of
Rochester
.
<EOS>
Your
love
is
as
false
as
your
character
.
<EOS>
Mistress
Mallet
is
the
real
object
of
your
regards
.
<EOS>
You
see
I
am
acquainted
with
your
perfidy
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Amabel
,
you
are
deceived
,
"
replied
Rochester
.
<EOS>
"
On
my
soul
,
you
are
.
<EOS>
When
I
have
an
opportunity
of
explaining
myself
more
fully
,
I
will
prove
to
you
that
I
was
induced
by
the
king
,
for
an
especial
purpose
,
to
pay
feigned
addresses
to
the
lady
you
have
named
.
<EOS>
But
I
never
loved
her
.
<EOS>
You
alone
are
the
possessor
of
my
heart
,
and
shall
be
the
sharer
of
my
title
.
<EOS>
You
shall
be
Countess
of
Rochester
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Could
I
believe
you
?
"
<EOS>
she
cried
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
_
may
_
believe
me
,
"
he
answered
.
<EOS>
"
Do
not
blight
my
hopes
and
your
own
happiness
a
second
time
.
<EOS>
Your
father
is
about
to
shut
up
his
house
for
a
twelvemonth
,
if
the
plague
lasts
so
long
.
<EOS>
This
done
,
we
shall
meet
no
more
,
for
access
to
you
will
be
impossible
.
<EOS>
Do
not
hesitate
,
or
you
will
for
ever
rue
your
irresolution
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
know
not
what
to
do
,
"
cried
Amabel
,
distractedly
.
 
<EOS>
"
Then
I
will
decide
for
you
,
"
replied
the
earl
,
grasping
her
hand
.
<EOS>
"
Come
!
"
 
<EOS>
While
this
was
passing
,
Furbisher
,
or
rather
,
as
will
be
surmised
,
Pillichody
,
had
taken
Blaize
aside
,
and
engaged
his
attention
by
dilating
upon
the
efficacy
of
a
roasted
onion
filled
with
treacle
in
the
expulsion
of
the
plague
.
<EOS>
Patience
stationed
herself
near
the
door
,
not
with
a
view
of
interfering
with
the
lovers
,
but
rather
of
assisting
them
;
and
at
the
very
moment
that
the
earl
seized
his
mistress
's
hand
,
and
would
have
drawn
her
forward
,
she
ran
towards
them
,
and
hastily
whispered
,
"
Leonard
Holt
is
coming
downstairs
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
<EOS>
I
am
lost
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Amabel
.
 
<EOS>
"
Fear
nothing
,
"
said
the
earl
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Keep
near
me
,
and
I
will
soon
dispose
of
him
.
"
 
<EOS>
As
he
spoke
,
the
apprentice
entered
the
kitchen
,
and
,
greatly
surprised
by
the
appearance
of
the
strangers
,
angrily
demanded
from
Blaize
who
they
were
.
 
<EOS>
"
They
are
two
doctors
come
to
give
me
advice
respecting
the
plague
,
"
stammered
the
porter
.
 
<EOS>
"
How
did
they
get
into
the
house
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Leonard
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
let
them
in
through
the
back
door
,
"
replied
Blaize
.
 
<EOS>
"
Then
let
them
out
by
the
same
way
,
"
rejoined
the
apprentice
.
"
<EOS>
May
I
ask
what
you
are
doing
here
?
"
<EOS>
he
added
,
to
Amabel
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
is
that
to
you
,
fellow
?
"
<EOS>
cried
Rochester
,
in
his
assumed
voice
.
 
<EOS>
"
Much
,
as
you
shall
find
,
my
lord
,
"
replied
the
apprentice
;
"
for
,
in
spite
of
your
disguise
,
I
know
you
.
<EOS>
Quit
the
house
instantly
with
your
companion
,
or
I
will
give
the
alarm
,
and
Amabel
well
knows
what
the
consequences
will
be
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
must
go
,
my
lord
,
"
she
replied
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
will
not
stir
unless
you
accompany
me
,
"
said
Rochester
.
 
<EOS>
"
Then
I
have
no
alternative
,
"
rejoined
Leonard
.
<EOS>
"
You
know
your
father
's
determination
--
I
would
willingly
spare
you
,
Amabel
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
goodness
!
<EOS>
what
_
will
_
become
of
us
?
"
<EOS>
cried
Patience--"if
<EOS>
there
is
n't
Mr.
Bloundel
coming
downstairs
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Amabel
,
"
said
Leonard
,
sternly
,
"
the
next
moment
decides
your
fate
.
<EOS>
If
the
earl
departs
,
I
will
keep
your
secret
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
hear
that
,
my
lord
,
"
she
cried
;
"
I
command
you
to
leave
me
.
"
 
<EOS>
And
disengaging
herself
from
him
,
and
hastily
passing
her
father
,
who
at
that
moment
entered
the
kitchen
,
she
rushed
upstairs
.
 
<EOS>
On
hearing
the
alarm
of
the
grocer
's
approach
,
Pillichody
took
refuge
in
a
cupboard
,
the
door
of
which
stood
invitingly
open
,
so
that
Bloundel
only
perceived
the
earl
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
is
the
matter
?
"
<EOS>
he
cried
,
gazing
around
him
.
<EOS>
"
Whom
have
we
here
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
a
quack
doctor
,
whom
Blaize
has
been
consulting
about
the
plague
,
"
returned
Leonard
.
 
<EOS>
"
See
him
instantly
out
of
the
house
,
"
rejoined
the
grocer
,
angrily
,
"
and
take
care
<EOS>
he
never
enters
it
again
.
<EOS>
I
will
have
no
such
charlatans
here
.
"
 
<EOS>
Leonard
motioned
Rochester
to
follow
him
,
and
the
latter
reluctantly
obeyed
.
 
<EOS>
As
soon
as
Bloundel
had
retired
,
Leonard
,
who
had
meanwhile
provided
himself
with
his
cudgel
,
descended
to
the
kitchen
,
where
he
dragged
Pillichody
from
his
hiding
-
place
,
and
conducted
him
to
the
back
door
.
<EOS>
But
he
did
not
suffer
him
to
depart
without
belabouring
him
soundly
.
<EOS>
Locking
the
door
,
he
then
went
in
search
of
Blaize
,
and
administered
a
similar
chastisement
to
him
.
  
<EOS>
IV
.
 
<EOS>
THE
TWO
WATCHMEN
.
 
<EOS>
On
the
day
following
the
events
last
related
,
as
Leonard
Holt
was
standing
at
the
door
of
the
shop,--his
master
having
just
been
called
out
by
some
important
business,--a
man
in
the
dress
of
a
watchman
,
with
a
halberd
in
his
hand
,
approached
him
,
and
inquired
if
he
was
Mr.
Bloundel
's
apprentice
.
 
<EOS>
Before
returning
an
answer
,
Leonard
looked
hard
at
the
newcomer
,
and
thought
he
had
never
beheld
so
ill
-
favoured
a
person
before
.
<EOS>
Every
feature
in
his
face
was
distorted
.
<EOS>
His
mouth
was
twisted
on
one
side
,
his
nose
on
the
other
,
while
his
right
eyebrow
was
elevated
more
than
an
inch
above
the
left
;
added
to
which
he
squinted
intolerably
,
had
a
long
fell
of
straight
sandy
hair
,
a
sandy
beard
and
moustache
,
and
a
complexion
of
the
colour
of
brickdust
.
 
<EOS>
"
An
ugly
dog
,
"
muttered
Leonard
to
himself
,
as
he
finished
his
scrutiny
;
"
what
can
he
want
with
me
?
<EOS>
Suppose
I
should
be
Mr.
Bloundel
's
apprentice
,
"
he
added
,
aloud
,
"
<EOS>
what
then
,
friend
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Your
master
has
a
beautiful
daughter
,
has
he
not
?
"
asked
the
ill
-
favoured
watchman
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
answer
no
idle
questions
,
"
rejoined
Leonard
,
coldly
.
 
<EOS>
"
As
you
please
,
"
returned
the
other
,
in
an
offended
tone
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
A
plan
to
carry
her
off
has
accidentally
come
to
my
knowledge
.
<EOS>
But
,
since
incivility
is
all
I
am
likely
to
get
for
my
pains
in
coming
to
acquaint
you
with
it
,
e'en
find
it
out
yourself
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Hold
!
"
cried
the
apprentice
,
detaining
him
;
"
I
meant
no
offence
.
<EOS>
Step
indoors
for
a
moment
.
<EOS>
We
can
converse
there
more
freely
.
"
 
<EOS>
The
watchman
,
who
,
notwithstanding
his
ill
-
looks
,
appeared
to
be
a
good
-
natured
fellow
,
was
easily
appeased
.
<EOS>
Following
the
apprentice
into
the
shop
,
on
the
promise
of
a
handsome
reward
,
he
instantly
commenced
his
relation
.
 
<EOS>
"
Last
night
,
"
he
said
,
"
I
was
keeping
watch
at
the
door
of
Mr.
Brackley
,
a
saddler
in
Aldermanbury
,
whose
house
having
been
attacked
by
the
pestilence
is
now
shut
up
,
when
I
observed
two
persons
,
rather
singularly
attired
,
pass
me
.
<EOS>
Both
were
dressed
like
old
men
,
but
neither
their
gait
nor
tone
of
voice
corresponded
with
their
garb
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
must
have
been
the
Earl
of
Rochester
and
his
companion
,
"
remarked
Leonard
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
are
right
,
"
replied
the
other
;
"
for
I
afterwards
heard
one
of
them
addressed
by
that
title
.
<EOS>
But
to
proceed
.
<EOS>
I
was
so
much
struck
by
the
strangeness
of
their
appearance
,
that
I
left
my
post
for
a
few
minutes
,
and
followed
them
.
<EOS>
They
halted
beneath
a
gateway
,
and
,
as
they
conversed
together
very
earnestly
,
and
in
a
loud
tone
,
I
could
distinctly
hear
what
they
said
.
<EOS>
One
of
them
,
the
stoutest
of
the
two
,
complained
bitterly
of
the
indignities
he
had
received
from
Mr.
Bloundel
's
apprentice
(
meaning
you
,
of
course
)
,
averring
that
nothing
but
his
devotion
to
his
companion
had
induced
him
to
submit
to
them
;
and
affirming
,
with
many
tremendous
oaths
,
that
he
would
certainly
cut
the
young
man
's
throat
the
very
first
opportunity
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
He
shall
not
want
it
then
,
"
replied
Leonard
contemptuously
;
"
neither
shall
he
lack
a
second
application
of
my
cudgel
when
we
meet
.
<EOS>
But
what
of
his
companion
?
<EOS>
What
did
he
say
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
He
laughed
heartily
at
the
other
's
complaints
,
"
returned
the
watchman
,
"
and
told
him
to
make
himself
easy
,
for
he
should
soon
have
his
revenge
.
'
<EOS>
To
-
morrow
night
,
'
he
said
,
'
we
will
carry
off
Amabel
,
in
spite
of
the
apprentice
or
her
father
;
and
,
as
I
am
equally
indebted
with
yourself
to
the
latter
,
we
will
pay
off
old
scores
with
him
.
'
"
 
<EOS>
"
How
do
they
intend
to
effect
their
purpose
?
"
demanded
Leonard
.
 
<EOS>
"
That
I
can
not
precisely
tell
,
"
replied
the
watchman
.
<EOS>
"
All
I
could
hear
was
,
that
they
meant
to
enter
the
house
by
the
back
yard
about
midnight
.
<EOS>
And
now
,
if
you
will
make
it
worth
my
while
,
I
will
help
you
to
catch
them
in
their
own
trap
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Hum
!
"
said
Leonard
.
<EOS>
"
What
is
your
name
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
Gregory
Swindlehurst
,
"
replied
the
other
.
 
<EOS>
"
To
help
me
,
you
must
keep
watch
with
me
to
-
night
,
"
rejoined
Leonard
.
"
<EOS>
Can
you
do
so
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
see
nothing
to
hinder
me
,
provided
I
am
paid
for
my
trouble
,
"
replied
Gregory
.
<EOS>
"
I
will
find
some
one
to
take
my
place
at
Mr.
Brackley
's
.
<EOS>
At
what
hour
shall
I
come
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
Soon
after
ten
,
"
said
Leonard
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Be
at
the
shop
-
door
,
and
I
will
let
you
in
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Count
upon
me
,
"
rejoined
Gregory
,
a
smile
of
satisfaction
illumining
his
ill
-
favoured
countenance
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Shall
I
bring
a
comrade
with
me
?
<EOS>
I
know
a
trusty
fellow
who
would
like
the
job
.
<EOS>
If
Lord
Rochester
should
have
his
companions
with
him
,
assistance
will
be
required
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
True
,
"
replied
Leonard
.
<EOS>
"
Is
your
comrade
a
watchman
,
like
yourself
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
He
is
an
old
soldier
,
who
has
been
lately
employed
to
keep
guard
over
infected
houses
,
"
replied
Gregory
.
<EOS>
"
We
must
take
care
<EOS>
his
lordship
does
not
overreach
us
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
If
he
gets
into
the
house
without
my
knowledge
,
I
will
forgive
him
,
"
replied
the
apprentice
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
wo
n't
get
into
it
without
mine
,
"
muttered
Gregory
,
significantly
.
<EOS>
"
But
do
you
not
mean
to
warn
Mistress
Amabel
of
her
danger
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
shall
consider
of
it
,
"
replied
the
apprentice
.
 
<EOS>
At
this
moment
Mr.
Bloundel
entered
the
shop
,
and
Leonard
,
feigning
to
supply
his
companion
with
a
small
packet
of
grocery
,
desired
him
,
in
a
low
tone
,
to
be
punctual
to
his
appointment
,
and
dismissed
him
.
<EOS>
In
justice
to
the
apprentice
,
it
must
be
stated
that
he
had
no
wish
for
concealment
,
but
was
most
anxious
to
acquaint
his
master
with
the
information
he
had
just
obtained
,
and
was
only
deterred
from
doing
so
by
a
dread
of
the
consequences
it
might
produce
to
Amabel
.
 
<EOS>
The
evening
passed
off
much
as
usual
.
<EOS>
The
family
assembled
at
prayer
;
and
.
<EOS>
Blaize
,
whose
shoulders
still
ached
with
the
chastisement
he
had
received
,
eyed
the
apprentice
with
sullen
and
revengeful
looks
.
<EOS>
Patience
,
too
,
was
equally
angry
,
and
her
indignation
was
evinced
in
a
manner
so
droll
,
that
at
another
season
it
would
have
drawn
a
smile
from
Leonard
.
 
<EOS>
Supper
over
,
Amabel
left
the
room
.
<EOS>
Leonard
followed
her
,
and
overtook
her
on
the
landing
of
the
stairs
.
 
<EOS>
"
Amabel
,
"
he
said
,
"
I
have
received
certain
intelligence
that
the
Earl
of
Rochester
will
make
another
attempt
to
enter
the
house
,
and
carry
you
off
to
-
night
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
!
<EOS>
when
will
he
cease
from
persecuting
me
?
"
<EOS>
she
cried
.
 
<EOS>
"
When
you
cease
to
encourage
him
,
"
replied
the
apprentice
,
bitterly
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
do
_
<EOS>
not
_
encourage
him
,
Leonard
,
"
she
rejoined
,
"
and
to
prove
that
I
do
not
,
I
will
act
in
any
way
you
think
proper
tonight
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
If
I
could
trust
you
,
"
said
Leonard
,
you
might
be
of
the
greatest
service
in
convincing
the
earl
that
his
efforts
are
fruitless
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
_
may
_
trust
me
,
"
she
rejoined
.
 
<EOS>
"
Well
,
then
,
"
returned
Leonard
,
"
when
the
family
have
retired
to
rest
,
come
downstairs
,
and
I
will
tell
you
what
to
do
.
"
 
<EOS>
Hastily
promising
compliance
,
Amabel
disappeared
;
and
Leonard
ran
down
the
stairs
,
at
the
foot
of
which
he
encountered
Mrs.
Bloundel
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
is
the
matter
?
"
she
asked
.
 
<EOS>
"
Nothing
--
nothing
,
"
replied
the
apprentice
,
evasively
.
 
<EOS>
"
That
-
will
not
serve
my
turn
,
"
she
rejoined
.
<EOS>
"
Something
,
I
am
certain
,
troubles
you
,
though
you
do
not
choose
to
confess
it
.
<EOS>
Heaven
grant
<EOS>
your
anxiety
is
not
occasioned
by
aught
relating
to
that
wicked
Earl
of
Rochester
!
<EOS>
I
can
not
sleep
in
my
bed
for
thinking
of
him
.
<EOS>
I
noticed
that
you
followed
Amabel
out
of
the
room
.
<EOS>
I
hope
you
do
not
suspect
anything
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Do
not
question
me
further
,
madam
,
I
entreat
,
"
returned
the
apprentice
.
<EOS>
"
Whatever
I
may
suspect
,
I
have
taken
all
needful
precautions
.
<EOS>
Rest
easy
,
and
sleep
soundly
,
if
you
can
.
<EOS>
All
will
go
well
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
shall
never
rest
easy
,
Leonard
,
"
rejoined
Mrs.
Bloundel
,
"
till
you
are
wedded
to
my
daughter
.
<EOS>
Then
,
indeed
,
I
shall
feel
happy
.
<EOS>
My
poor
child
,
I
am
sure
,
is
fully
aware
how
indiscreet
her
conduct
has
been
;
and
when
this
noble
libertine
desists
from
annoying
her
--
or
rather
,
when
he
is
effectually
shut
out
--
we
may
hope
for
a
return
of
her
regard
for
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
a
vain
hope
,
madam
,
"
replied
Leonard
;
"
there
will
be
no
such
return
.
<EOS>
I
neither
expect
it
nor
desire
it
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Have
you
ceased
to
love
her
?
"
asked
Mrs.
Bloundel
,
in
surprise
.
 
<EOS>
"
Ceased
to
love
her
!
"
<EOS>
echoed
Leonard
,
fiercely
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Would
I
had
done
so!--would
<EOS>
I
_
could
_
do
so
!
<EOS>
I
love
her
too
well
--
too
well
.
"
 
<EOS>
And
repeating
the
words
to
himself
with
great
bitterness
,
he
hurried
away
.
 
<EOS>
"
His
passion
has
disturbed
his
brain
,
"
sighed
Mrs.
Bloundel
,
as
she
proceeded
to
her
chamber
.
<EOS>
"
I
must
try
to
reason
him
into
calmness
to
-
morrow
.
"
 
<EOS>
Half
an
hour
after
this
,
the
grocer
retired
for
the
night
;
and
Leonard
,
who
had
gone
to
his
own
room
,
cautiously
opened
the
door
,
and
repaired
to
the
shop
.
<EOS>
On
the
way
he
met
Amabel
.
<EOS>
She
looked
pale
as
death
,
and
trembled
so
violently
,
that
she
could
scarcely
support
herself
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
hope
you
do
not
mean
to
use
any
violence
towards
the
earl
,
Leonard
?
<EOS>
"
she
said
in
a
supplicating
voice
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
will
never
repeat
his
visit
,
"
rejoined
the
apprentice
,
gloomily
.
 
<EOS>
"
Your
looks
terrify
me
,
"
cried
Amabel
,
gazing
with
great
uneasiness
at
his
stern
and
determined
countenance
.
<EOS>
"
I
will
remain
by
you
.
<EOS>
He
will
depart
at
my
bidding
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Did
he
depart
at
your
bidding
before
?
"
demanded
Leonard
,
sarcastically
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
did
not
,
I
grant
,
"
she
replied
,
more
supplicatingly
than
before
.
"
<EOS>
But
do
not
harm
him
--
for
mercy
's
sake
,
do
not
--
take
my
life
sooner
.
<EOS>
I
alone
have
offended
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
The
apprentice
made
no
reply
,
but
,
unlocking
a
box
,
took
out
a
brace
of
large
horse
-
pistols
and
a
sword
,
and
thrust
them
into
his
girdle
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
do
not
mean
to
use
those
murderous
weapons
?
"
<EOS>
cried
Amabel
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
depends
on
circumstances
,
"
replied
Leonard
.
<EOS>
"
Force
must
be
met
by
force
.
<EOS>
"
 
"
Nay
,
then
,
"
she
rejoined
,
"
the
affair
assumes
too
serious
an
aspect
to
be
trifled
with
.
<EOS>
I
will
instantly
alarm
my
father
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Do
so
,
"
retorted
Leonard
,
"
and
he
will
cast
you
off
for
ever
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Better
that
,
than
be
the
cause
of
bloodshed
,
"
she
returned
.
<EOS>
"
But
is
there
nothing
I
can
do
to
prevent
this
fatal
result
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
replied
Leonard
.
"
<EOS>
Make
your
lover
understand
he
is
unwelcome
to
you
.
<EOS>
Dismiss
him
for
ever
.
<EOS>
On
that
condition
,
he
shall
depart
unharmed
and
freely
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
will
do
so
,
"
she
rejoined
.
 
<EOS>
Nothing
more
was
then
said
.
<EOS>
Amabel
seated
herself
and
kept
her
eyes
fixed
on
Leonard
,
who
,
avoiding
her
regards
,
stationed
himself
near
the
door
.
 
<EOS>
By
-
and
-
by
a
slight
tap
was
heard
without
,
and
the
apprentice
cautiously
admitted
Gregory
Swindlehurst
and
his
comrade
.
<EOS>
The
latter
was
habited
like
the
other
watchman
,
in
a
blue
night
-
rail
,
and
was
armed
with
a
halberd
.
<EOS>
He
appeared
much
stouter
,
much
older
,
and
,
so
far
as
could
be
discovered
of
his
features
--
for
a
large
handkerchief
muffled
his
face
--
much
uglier
(
if
that
were
possible
)
than
his
companion
.
<EOS>
He
answered
to
the
name
of
Bernard
Boutefeu
.
<EOS>
They
had
no
sooner
entered
the
shop
,
than
Leonard
locked
the
door
.
 
<EOS>
"
Who
are
these
persons
?
"
<EOS>
asked
Amabel
,
rising
in
great
alarm
.
 
<EOS>
"
Two
watchmen
whom
I
have
hired
to
guard
the
house
,
"
replied
Leonard
.
 
<EOS>
"
We
are
come
to
protect
you
,
fair
mistress
,
"
said
Gregory
,
"
and
,
if
need
be
,
to
cut
the
Earl
of
Rochester
's
throat
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
heavens
!
"
exclaimed
Amabel
.
 
<EOS>
"
Ghost
of
Tarquin
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Boutefeu
,
"
we
'll
teach
him
to
break
into
the
houses
of
quiet
citizens
,
and
attempt
to
carry
off
their
daughters
against
their
will
.
<EOS>
By
the
soul
of
Dick
Whittington
,
Lord
Mayor
of
London
!
<EOS>
we
'll
maul
and
mangle
him
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Silence
!
<EOS>
Bernard
Boutefeu
,
"
interposed
Gregory
.
<EOS>
"
You
frighten
Mistress
Amabel
by
your
strange
oaths
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
should
be
sorry
to
do
that
,
"
replied
Boutefeu--"I
only
wish
to
show
my
zeal
for
her
.
<EOS>
Do
n't
be
afraid
of
the
Earl
of
Rochester
,
fair
mistress
.
<EOS>
With
all
his
audacity
,
he
wo
n't
dare
to
enter
the
house
when
he
finds
we
are
there
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Is
it
your
pleasure
that
we
should
thrust
a
halberd
through
his
body
,
or
lodge
a
bullet
in
his
brain
?
"
asked
Gregory
,
appealing
to
Amabel
.
 
<EOS>
"
Touch
him
not
<EOS>
,
I
beseech
you
,
"
she
rejoined
.
<EOS>
"
Leonard
,
I
have
your
promise
that
,
if
I
can
prevail
upon
him
to
depart
,
you
will
not
molest
him
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
have
,
"
he
replied
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
hear
that
,
"
she
observed
to
the
watchmen
.
 
<EOS>
"
We
are
all
obedience
,
"
said
Gregory
.
 
<EOS>
"
Bless
your
tender
heart
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Boutefeu
,
"
we
would
not
pain
you
for
the
world
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
A
truce
to
this
,
"
said
Leonard
.
<EOS>
"
Come
to
the
yard
,
we
will
wait
for
him
there
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
will
go
with
you
,
"
cried
Amabel
.
<EOS>
"
If
any
harm
should
befall
him
,
I
should
never
forgive
myself
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Remember
what
I
told
you
,
"
rejoined
Leonard
,
sternly
;
"
it
depends
upon
yourself
whether
he
leaves
the
house
alive
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Heed
him
not
,
"
whispered
Gregory
.
<EOS>
"
I
and
my
comrade
will
obey
no
one
but
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
Amabel
could
not
repress
an
exclamation
of
surprise
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
are
you
muttering
,
sirrah
?
"
demanded
Leonard
,
angrily
.
 
<EOS>
"
Only
that
the
young
lady
may
depend
on
our
fidelity
,
"
replied
Gregory
.
<EOS>
"
There
can
be
no
offence
in
that
.
<EOS>
Come
with
us
,
"
he
whispered
to
Amabel
.
 
<EOS>
The
latter
part
of
his
speech
escaped
Leonard
,
but
the
tone
in
which
it
was
uttered
was
so
significant
,
that
Amabel
,
who
began
to
entertain
new
suspicions
,
hesitated
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
must
come
,
"
said
Leonard
,
seizing
her
hand
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
fault
be
his
,
not
mine
,
"
murmured
Amabel
,
as
she
suffered
herself
to
be
drawn
along
.
 
<EOS>
The
party
then
proceeded
noiselessly
towards
the
yard
.
<EOS>
On
the
way
,
Amabel
felt
a
slight
pressure
on
her
arm
,
but
,
afraid
of
alarming
Leonard
,
she
made
no
remark
.
 
<EOS>
The
back
-
door
was
opened
,
and
the
little
group
stood
in
the
darkness
.
<EOS>
They
had
not
long
to
wait
.
<EOS>
Before
they
had
been
in
the
yard
five
minutes
,
a
noise
was
heard
of
footsteps
and
muttered
voices
in
the
entry
.
<EOS>
This
was
followed
by
a
sound
like
that
occasioned
by
fastening
a
rope
-
ladder
against
the
wall
,
and
the
next
moment
two
figures
were
perceived
above
it
.
<EOS>
After
dropping
the
ladder
into
the
yard
,
these
persons
,
the
foremost
of
whom
the
apprentice
concluded
was
the
Earl
of
Rochester
,
descended
.
<EOS>
They
had
no
sooner
touched
the
ground
than
Leonard
,
drawing
his
pistols
,
advanced
towards
them
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
are
my
prisoner
,
my
lord
,
"
he
said
,
in
a
stern
voice
,
"
and
shall
not
depart
with
life
,
unless
you
pledge
your
word
never
to
come
hither
again
on
the
same
errand
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Betrayed
!
"
cried
the
earl
,
laying
his
hand
upon
his
sword
.
 
<EOS>
"
Resistance
is
in
vain
,
my
lord
,
"
rejoined
Leonard
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
better
armed
than
yourself
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Will
nothing
bribe
you
to
silence
,
fellow
?
"
<EOS>
cried
the
earl
.
<EOS>
"
I
will
give
you
a
thousand
pounds
,
if
you
will
hold
your
tongue
,
and
conduct
me
to
my
mistress
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
can
scarcely
tell
what
stays
my
hand
,
"
returned
Leonard
,
in
a
furious
tone
.
<EOS>
"
But
I
will
hold
no
further
conversation
with
you
.
<EOS>
Amabel
is
present
,
and
will
give
you
your
final
dismissal
herself
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
If
I
receive
it
from
her
own
lips
,
"
replied
the
earl
,
"
I
will
instantly
retire
--
but
not
otherwise
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Amabel
,
"
said
Leonard
in
a
low
tone
to
her
,
"
you
hear
what
is
said
.
<EOS>
Fulfil
your
promise
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Do
so
,
"
cried
a
voice
,
which
she
instantly
recognised
,
in
her
ear--"I
am
near
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
"
<EOS>
she
exclaimed
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
you
hesitate
?
<EOS>
"
cried
the
apprentice
,
sternly
.
 
<EOS>
"
My
lord
,
"
said
Amabel
,
in
a
faint
voice
,
"
I
must
pray
you
to
retire
,
your
efforts
are
in
vain
.
<EOS>
I
will
never
fly
with
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
That
will
not
suffice
,
"
whispered
Leonard
;
"
you
must
tell
him
you
no
longer
love
him
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Hear
me
,
"
pursued
Amabel
;
"
you
who
present
yourself
as
Lord
Rochester
,
I
entertain
no
affection
for
you
,
and
never
wish
to
behold
you
again
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Enough
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Leonard
.
 
<EOS>
"
Admirable
!
"
<EOS>
whispered
Gregory
.
<EOS>
"
Nothing
could
be
better
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Well
,
"
cried
the
supposed
earl
,
"
since
I
no
longer
hold
a
place
in
your
affections
,
it
would
be
idle
to
pursue
the
matter
further
.
<EOS>
Heaven
be
praised
,
there
are
other
damsels
quite
as
beautiful
,
though
not
so
cruel
.
<EOS>
Farewell
for
ever
,
Amabel
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
So
saying
he
mounted
the
ladder
,
and
,
followed
by
his
companion
,
disappeared
on
the
other
side
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
is
gone
,
"
said
Leonard
,
"
and
I
hope
for
ever
.
<EOS>
Now
let
us
return
to
the
house
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
coming
,
"
rejoined
Amabel
.
 
<EOS>
"
Let
him
go
,
"
whispered
Gregory
.
<EOS>
"
The
ladder
is
still
upon
the
wall
;
we
will
climb
it
.
"
 
<EOS>
And
as
the
apprentice
moved
towards
the
house
,
he
tried
to
drag
her
in
that
direction
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
cannot
--
will
not
fly
thus
,
"
she
cried
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
is
the
matter
?
"
<EOS>
exclaimed
Leonard
,
suddenly
turning
.
 
<EOS>
"
Further
disguise
is
useless
,
"
replied
the
supposed
Gregory
Swindlehurst
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
the
Earl
of
Rochester
.
<EOS>
The
other
was
a
counterfeit
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
"
exclaimed
Leonard
,
rushing
towards
them
,
and
placing
a
pistol
against
the
breast
of
his
mistress
?
"
<EOS>
Have
I
been
duped
?
<EOS>
But
it
is
not
yet
too
late
to
retrieve
my
error
.
<EOS>
Move
a
foot
further
<EOS>
,
my
lord,--and
do
you
,
Amabel
,
attempt
to
fly
with
him
,
and
I
fire
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
can
not
mean
this
?
"
cried
Rochester
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Raise
your
hand
against
the
woman
you
love
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
Against
the
woman
who
forgets
her
duty
,
and
the
libertine
who
tempts
her
,
the
arm
that
is
raised
is
that
of
justice
,
"
replied
Leonard
.
"
<EOS>
Stir
another
footstep
,
and
I
fire
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
As
he
spoke
,
his
arms
were
suddenly
seized
by
a
powerful
grasp
from
behind
,
and
,
striking
the
pistols
from
his
hold
,
the
earl
snatched
up
Amabel
in
his
arms
,
and
,
mounting
the
ladder
,
made
good
his
retreat
.
 
<EOS>
A
long
and
desperate
struggle
took
place
between
Leonard
and
his
assailant
,
who
was
no
other
than
Pillichody
,
in
his
assumed
character
of
Bernard
Boutefeu
.
<EOS>
But
notwithstanding
the
superior
strength
of
the
bully
,
and
the
advantage
he
had
taken
of
the
apprentice
,
he
was
worsted
in
the
end
.
 
<EOS>
Leonard
had
no
sooner
extricated
himself
,
than
,
drawing
his
sword
,
he
would
have
passed
it
through
Pillichody
's
body
,
if
the
latter
had
not
stayed
his
hand
by
offering
to
tell
him
where
he
would
find
his
mistress
,
<EOS>
provided
his
life
were
spared
.
 
<EOS>
"
Where
has
the
earl
taken
her
?
"
<EOS>
cried
Leonard
,
scarcely
able
to
articulate
from
excess
of
passion
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
meant
to
take
her
to
Saint
<EOS>
Paul's,--to
the
vaults
below
the
cathedral
,
to
avoid
pursuit
<EOS>
,
"
replied
Pillichody
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
no
doubt
you
will
find
her
there
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
will
go
there
instantly
and
search
,
"
cried
Leonard
,
rushing
up
the
ladder
.
  
<EOS>
V.
 
<EOS>
THE
BLIND
PIPER
AND
HIS
DAUGHTER
 
<EOS>
Scarcely
knowing
how
he
got
there
,
Leonard
Holt
found
himself
at
the
great
northern
entrance
of
the
cathedral
.
<EOS>
Burning
with
fury
,
he
knocked
at
the
door
;
but
no
answer
being
returned
to
the
summons
,
though
he
repeated
it
still
more
loudly
,
he
shook
the
heavy
latch
with
such
violence
as
to
rouse
the
sullen
echoes
of
the
aisles
.
<EOS>
Driven
almost
to
desperation
,
he
retired
a
few
paces
,
and
surveyed
the
walls
of
the
vast
structure
