,
in
the
hope
of
descrying
some
point
by
which
he
might
obtain
an
entrance
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
a
bright
moonlight
night
,
and
the
reverend
pile
looked
so
beautiful
,
that
,
under
any
other
frame
of
mind
,
Leonard
must
,
have
been
struck
with
admiration
.
<EOS>
The
ravages
of
time
could
not
now
be
discerned
,
and
the
architectural
incongruities
which
,
seen
in
the
broad
glare
of
day
,
would
have
offended
the
eye
of
taste
,
were
lost
in
the
general
grand
effect
.
<EOS>
On
the
left
ran
the
magnificent
pointed
windows
of
the
choir
,
divided
by
massive
buttresses,--the
latter
ornamented
with
crocketed
pinnacles
.
<EOS>
On
the
right
,
the
building
had
been
new
-
faced
,
and
its
original
character
,
in
a
great
measure
,
destroyed
by
the
tasteless
manner
in
which
the
repairs
had
been
executed
.
<EOS>
On
this
side
,
the
lower
windows
were
round
-
headed
and
separated
by
broad
pilasters
,
while
above
them
ran
a
range
of
small
circular
windows
.
<EOS>
At
the
western
angle
was
seen
one
of
the
towers
(
since
imitated
by
Wren
)
,
which
flanked
this
side
of
the
fane
,
together
with
a
part
of
the
portico
erected
,
about
twenty
-
five
years
previously
,
by
Inigo
Jones
,
and
which
,
though
beautiful
in
itself
,
was
totally
out
of
character
with
the
edifice
,
and
,
in
fact
,
a
blemish
to
it
.
 
<EOS>
Insensible
alike
to
the
beauties
or
defects
of
the
majestic
building
,
and
regarding
it
only
as
the
prison
of
his
mistress
,
Leonard
Holt
scanned
it
carefully
on
either
side
.
<EOS>
But
his
scrutiny
was
attended
with
no
favourable
result
.
 
<EOS>
Before
resorting
to
force
to
obtain
admission
,
he
determined
to
make
the
complete
circuit
of
the
structure
,
and
with
this
view
he
shaped
his
course
towards
the
east
.
 
<EOS>
He
found
two
small
doors
on
the
left
of
the
northern
transept
,
but
both
were
fastened
,
and
the
low
pointed
windows
beneath
the
choir
,
lighting
the
subterranean
church
of
Saint
Faith
's
,
were
all
barred
.
<EOS>
Running
on
,
he
presently
came
to
a
flight
of
stone
steps
at
the
north
-
east
corner
of
the
choir
,
leading
to
a
portal
opening
upon
a
small
chapel
dedicated
to
Saint
George
.
<EOS>
But
this
was
secured
like
the
others
,
and
,
thinking
it
vain
to
waste
time
in
trying
to
force
it
,
he
pursued
his
course
.
 
<EOS>
Skirting
the
eastern
extremity
of
the
fane
--
then
the
most
beautiful
part
of
the
structure
,
from
its
magnificent
rose
window
--
he
speeded
past
the
low
windows
which
opened
on
this
side
,
as
on
the
other
upon
Saint
Faith
's
,
and
did
not
pause
till
he
came
to
the
great
southern
portal
,
the
pillars
and
arch
of
which
differed
but
slightly
in
character
from
those
of
the
northern
entrance
.
 
<EOS>
Here
he
knocked
as
before
,
and
was
answered
,
as
on
the
former
occasion
,
by
sullen
echoes
from
within
.
<EOS>
When
these
sounds
died
away
,
he
placed
his
ear
to
the
huge
key
-
hole
in
the
wicket
,
but
could
not
even
catch
the
fall
of
a
footstep
.
<EOS>
Neither
could
he
perceive
any
light
,
except
that
afforded
by
the
moonbeams
,
which
flooded
the
transept
with
radiance
.
 
<EOS>
Again
hurrying
on
,
he
passed
the
cloister
-
walls
surrounding
the
Convocation
House
;
tried
another
door
between
that
building
and
the
church
of
Saint
Gregory
,
a
small
fane
attached
to
the
larger
structure
;
and
failing
in
opening
it
,
turned
the
corner
and
approached
the
portico,--the
principal
entrance
to
the
cathedral
being
then
,
as
now
,
on
the
west
.
 
<EOS>
Erected
,
as
before
mentioned
,
from
the
designs
of
the
celebrated
Inigo
Jones
,
this
magnificent
colonnade
was
completed
about
1640
,
at
which
time
preparations
were
made
for
repairing
the
cathedral
throughout
,
and
for
strengthening
the
tower
,
for
enabling
it
to
support
a
new
spire
.
<EOS>
But
this
design
,
owing
to
the
disorganised
state
of
affairs
,
was
never
carried
into
execution
.
 
<EOS>
At
the
time
of
the
Commonwealth
,
while
the
interior
of
the
sacred
fabric
underwent
every
sort
of
desecration
and
mutilation,--while
stones
were
torn
from
the
pavement
,
and
monumental
brasses
from
tombs,--while
carved
stalls
were
burnt
,
and
statues
plucked
from
their
niches,--a
similar
fate
attended
the
portico
.
<EOS>
Shops
were
built
beneath
it
,
and
the
sculptures
ornamenting
its
majestic
balustrade
were
thrown
down
.
 
<EOS>
Amongst
other
obstructions
,
it
appears
that
there
was
a
"
high
house
in
the
north
angle
,
which
hindered
the
masons
from
repairing
that
part
of
it
.
"
<EOS>
The
marble
door
-
cases
,
the
capitals
,
cornices
,
and
pillars
were
so
much
injured
by
the
fires
made
against
them
,
that
it
required
months
to
put
them
in
order
.
<EOS>
At
the
Restoration
,
Sir
John
Denham
,
the
poet
,
was
appointed
surveyor
-
general
of
the
works
,
and
continued
to
hold
the
office
at
the
period
of
this
history
.
 
<EOS>
As
Leonard
drew
near
the
portico
,
he
perceived
,
to
his
surprise
,
that
a
large
concourse
of
people
was
collected
in
the
area
in
front
of
it
;
and
,
rushing
forward
,
he
found
the
assemblage
listening
to
the
denunciations
of
Solomon
Eagle
,
who
was
standing
in
the
midst
of
them
with
his
brazier
on
his
head
.
<EOS>
The
enthusiast
appeared
more
than
usually
excited
.
<EOS>
He
was
tossing
aloft
his
arms
in
a
wild
and
frenzied
manner
,
and
seemed
to
be
directing
his
menaces
against
the
cathedral
itself
.
 
<EOS>
Hoping
to
obtain
assistance
from
the
crowd
,
Leonard
resolved
to
await
a
fitting
period
to
address
them
.
<EOS>
Accordingly
,
he
joined
them
,
and
listened
to
the
discourse
of
the
enthusiast
.
 
<EOS>
"
Hear
me
!
"
<EOS>
cried
the
latter
,
in
a
voice
of
thunder
.
<EOS>
"
I
had
a
vision
last
night
and
will
relate
it
to
you
.
<EOS>
During
my
brief
slumbers
,
I
thought
I
was
standing
on
this
very
spot
,
and
gazing
as
now
upon
yon
mighty
structure
.
<EOS>
On
a
sudden
the
day
became
overcast
,
and
ere
long
it
grew
pitchy
dark
.
<EOS>
Then
was
heard
a
noise
of
rushing
wings
in
the
air
,
and
I
could
just
discern
many
strange
figures
hovering
above
the
tower
,
uttering
doleful
cries
and
lamentations
.
<EOS>
All
at
once
these
figures
disappeared
,
and
gave
place
to
,
or
,
it
may
be
,
were
chased
away
by
,
others
of
more
hideous
appearance
.
<EOS>
The
latter
brought
lighted
brands
which
they
hurled
against
the
sacred
fabric
,
and
,
in
an
instant
,
flames
burst
forth
from
it
on
all
sides
.
<EOS>
My
brethren
,
it
was
a
fearful
,
yet
a
glorious
sight
to
see
that
vast
pile
wrapped
in
the
devouring
element
!
<EOS>
The
flames
were
so
vivid
--
so
intense
--
that
I
could
not
bear
to
look
upon
them
,
and
I
covered
my
face
with
my
hands
.
<EOS>
On
raising
my
eyes
again
the
flames
were
extinguished
,
but
the
building
was
utterly
in
ruins
--
its
columns
cracked
--
its
tower
hurled
from
its
place
--
its
ponderous
roof
laid
low
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
mournful
spectacle
,
and
a
terrible
proof
of
the
Divine
wrath
and
vengeance
.
<EOS>
Yes
,
my
brethren
,
the
temple
of
the
Lord
has
been
profaned
,
and
it
will
be
razed
to
the
ground
.
<EOS>
It
has
been
the
scene
of
abomination
and
impiety
,
and
must
be
purified
by
fire
.
<EOS>
Theft
,
murder
,
sacrilege
,
and
every
other
crime
have
been
committed
within
its
walls
,
and
its
destruction
will
follow
.
<EOS>
The
ministers
of
Heaven
's
vengeance
are
even
now
hovering
above
it
.
<EOS>
Repent
,
therefore
,
ye
who
listen
to
me
,
and
repent
speedily
;
for
sudden
death
,
plague
,
fire
,
and
famine
,
are
at
hand
.
<EOS>
As
the
prophet
Amos
saith
,
'
The
Lord
will
send
a
fire
,
the
Lord
will
commission
a
fire
,
the
Lord
will
kindle
a
fire
;
'
and
the
fire
so
commissioned
and
so
kindled
shall
consume
you
and
your
city
;
nor
shall
one
stone
of
those
walls
be
left
standing
on
another
.
<EOS>
Repent
,
or
burn
,
for
he
cometh
to
judge
the
earth
.
<EOS>
Repent
,
or
burn
<EOS>
,
I
say
!
"
 
<EOS>
As
soon
as
he
concluded
,
Leonard
Holt
ran
up
the
steps
of
the
portico
,
and
in
a
loud
voice
claimed
the
attention
of
the
crowd
.
 
<EOS>
"
Solomon
Eagle
is
right
,
"
he
cried
;
"
the
vengeance
of
Heaven
will
descend
upon
this
fabric
,
since
it
continues
to
be
the
scene
of
so
much
wickedness
.
<EOS>
Even
now
it
forms
the
retreat
of
a
profligate
nobleman
,
who
has
this
night
forcibly
carried
off
the
daughter
of
a
citizen
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
What
nobleman
?
<EOS>
"
cried
a
bystander
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
Earl
of
Rochester
,
"
replied
Leonard
.
"
<EOS>
He
has
robbed
Stephen
Bloundel
,
the
grocer
of
Wood
-
street
,
of
his
daughter
,
and
has
concealed
her
,
to
avoid
pursuit
,
in
the
vaults
of
the
cathedral
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
know
Mr.
Bloundel
<EOS>
well
,
"
rejoined
the
man
who
had
made
the
inquiry
,
and
whom
Leonard
recognised
as
a
hosier
named
Lamplugh
,
"
and
I
know
the
person
who
addresses
us
.
<EOS>
It
is
his
apprentice
.
<EOS>
We
must
restore
the
damsel
to
her
father
,
friends
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Agreed
!
"
cried
several
voices
.
 
<EOS>
"
Knock
at
the
door
,
"
cried
a
man
,
whose
occupation
of
a
smith
was
proclaimed
by
his
leathern
apron
,
brawny
chest
,
and
smoke
-
begrimed
visage
,
as
well
as
by
the
heavy
hammer
which
he
bore
upon
his
shoulder
.
<EOS>
"
If
it
is
not
instantly
opened
,
we
will
break
it
down
.
<EOS>
I
have
an
implement
here
which
will
soon
do
the
business
.
"
 
<EOS>
A
rush
was
then
made
to
the
portal
,
which
rang
with
the
heavy
blows
dealt
against
it
.
<EOS>
While
this
was
passing
,
Solomon
Eagle
,
whose
excitement
was
increased
by
the
tumult
,
planted
himself
in
the
centre
of
the
colonnade
,
and
vociferated--"I
speak
in
the
words
of
the
prophet
Ezekiel:--'Thou
hast
<EOS>
defiled
thy
sanctuaries
by
the
multitude
of
thine
iniquities
,
by
the
iniquity
of
thy
traffic
.
<EOS>
Therefore
will
I
bring
forth
a
fire
from
the
midst
of
thee
,
and
will
bring
thee
to
ashes
upon
the
earth
,
in
the
sight
of
all
them
that
behold
thee
!
'
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
The
crowd
continued
to
batter
the
door
until
they
were
checked
by
Lamplugh
,
who
declared
he
heard
some
one
approaching
,
and
the
next
moment
the
voice
of
one
of
the
vergers
inquired
in
trembling
tones
,
who
they
were
,
and
what
they
wanted
.
 
<EOS>
"
No
matter
who
we
are
,
"
replied
Leonard
,
"
we
demand
admittance
to
search
for
a
young
female
who
has
been
taken
from
her
home
by
the
Earl
of
Rochester
,
and
is
now
concealed
within
the
vaults
of
the
cathedral
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
If
admittance
is
refused
us
,
we
will
soon
let
ourselves
in
,
"
vociferated
Lamplugh
.
 
<EOS>
"
Ay
,
that
we
will
,
"
added
the
smith
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
are
mistaken
,
friends
,
"
returned
the
verger
,
timorously
.
<EOS>
"
The
Earl
of
Rochester
is
not
here
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
We
will
not
take
your
word
for
it
,
"
rejoined
the
smith
.
<EOS>
"
This
will
show
you
we
are
not
to
be
trifled
with
.
"
 
<EOS>
So
saying
,
he
raised
his
hammer
,
and
struck
such
a
tremendous
blow
against
the
door
,
that
the
bolts
started
in
their
sockets
.
 
<EOS>
"
Hold
!
hold
!
"
<EOS>
cried
the
verger
;
"
sooner
than
violence
shall
be
committed
,
I
will
risk
your
admission
.
"
 
<EOS>
And
he
unfastened
the
door
.
 
<EOS>
"
Keep
together
,
"
shouted
the
smith
,
stretching
out
his
arms
to
oppose
the
progress
of
the
crowd
.
<EOS>
"
Keep
together
,
I
say
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Ay
,
ay
,
keep
together
,
"
added
Lamplugh
,
seconding
his
efforts
.
 
<EOS>
"
Conduct
us
to
the
Earl
of
Rochester
,
and
no
harm
shall
befall
you
,
"
cried
Leonard
,
seizing
the
verger
by
the
collar
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
tell
you
<EOS>
I
know
nothing
about
him
,
"
replied
the
man
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He
is
not
here
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
false
!
<EOS>
you
are
bribed
to
silence
,
"
rejoined
the
apprentice
.
<EOS>
"
We
will
search
till
we
find
him
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Search
where
you
please
,
"
rejoined
the
verger
;
"
and
if
you
_
do
_
find
him
,
do
what
you
please
with
me
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
be
afraid
of
that
,
friend
,
"
replied
the
smith
;
"
we
will
hang
you
and
the
earl
to
the
same
pillar
.
"
 
<EOS>
By
this
time
,
the
crowd
had
pushed
aside
the
opposition
offered
by
the
smith
and
Lamplugh
.
<EOS>
Solomon
Eagle
darted
along
the
nave
with
lightning
swiftness
,
and
,
mounting
the
steps
leading
to
the
choir
,
disappeared
from
view
.
<EOS>
Some
few
persons
followed
him
,
while
others
took
their
course
along
the
aisles
.
<EOS>
But
the
majority
kept
near
the
apprentice
.
 
<EOS>
Snatching
the
lamp
from
the
grasp
of
the
verger
,
Leonard
Holt
ran
on
with
his
companions
till
they
came
to
the
beautiful
chapel
built
by
Thomas
Kempe
,
bishop
of
London
.
<EOS>
The
door
was
open
,
and
the
apprentice
,
holding
the
light
forward
,
perceived
there
were
persons
inside
.
<EOS>
He
was
about
to
enter
the
chapel
,
when
a
small
spaniel
rushed
forth
,
and
,
barking
furiously
,
held
him
in
check
for
a
moment
.
<EOS>
Alarmed
by
the
noise
,
an
old
man
in
a
tattered
garb
,
and
a
young
female
,
who
were
slumbering
on
benches
in
the
chapel
,
immediately
started
to
their
feet
,
and
advanced
towards
them
.
 
<EOS>
"
We
are
mistaken
,
"
said
Lamplugh
;
"
this
is
only
Mike
Macascree
,
the
blind
piper
and
his
daughter
Nizza
.
<EOS>
I
know
them
well
enough
.
"
 
<EOS>
Leonard
was
about
to
proceed
with
his
search
,
but
a
slight
circumstance
detained
him
for
a
few
minutes
,
during
which
time
he
had
sufficient
leisure
to
note
the
extraordinary
personal
attractions
of
Nizza
Macascree
.
 
<EOS>
In
age
she
appeared
about
seventeen
,
and
differed
in
the
character
of
her
beauty
,
as
well
as
in
the
natural
gracefulness
of
her
carriage
and
demeanour
,
from
all
the
persons
he
had
seen
in
her
humble
sphere
of
life
.
<EOS>
Her
features
were
small
,
and
of
the
utmost
delicacy
.
<EOS>
She
had
a
charmingly
-
formed
nose
--
slightly
_
retroussé_--a
small
mouth
,
garnished
with
pearl
-
like
teeth
,
and
lips
as
fresh
and
ruddy
as
the
dew
-
steeped
rose
.
<EOS>
Her
skin
was
as
dark
as
a
gipsy
's
,
but
clear
and
transparent
,
and
far
more
attractive
than
the
fairest
complexion
.
<EOS>
Her
eyes
were
luminous
as
the
stars
,
and
black
as
midnight
;
while
her
raven
tresses
,
gathered
beneath
a
spotted
kerchief
tied
round
her
head
,
escaped
in
many
a
wanton
curl
down
her
shoulders
.
<EOS>
Her
figure
was
slight
,
but
exquisitely
proportioned
;
and
she
had
the
smallest
foot
and
ankle
that
ever
fell
to
the
lot
of
woman
.
<EOS>
Her
attire
was
far
from
unbecoming
,
though
of
the
coarsest
material
;
and
her
fairy
feet
were
set
off
by
the
daintiest
shoes
and
hose
.
<EOS>
Such
was
the
singular
and
captivating
creature
that
attracted
the
apprentice
's
attention
.
 
<EOS>
Her
father
,
Mike
Macascree
,
was
upwards
of
sixty
,
but
still
in
the
full
vigour
of
life
,
with
features
which
,
though
not
ill
-
looking
,
bore
no
particular
resemblance
to
those
of
his
daughter
.
<EOS>
He
had
a
good
-
humoured
,
jovial
countenance
,
the
mirthful
expression
of
which
even
his
sightless
orbs
could
not
destroy
.
<EOS>
Long
white
locks
descended
upon
his
shoulders
,
and
a
patriarchal
beard
adorned
his
chin
.
<EOS>
He
was
wrapped
in
a
loose
grey
gown
,
patched
with
different
coloured
cloths
,
and
supported
himself
with
a
staff
.
<EOS>
His
pipe
was
suspended
from
his
neck
by
a
green
worsted
cord
.
 
<EOS>
"
Lie
down
,
Bell
<EOS>
,
"
he
cried
to
his
dog
;
"
what
are
you
barking
at
thus
?
<EOS>
Lie
down
,
I
say
.
<EOS>
"
 
"
Something
is
the
matter
,
father
,
"
replied
Nizza
.
<EOS>
"
The
church
is
full
of
people
.
"
 
"
Indeed
!
"
exclaimed
the
piper
.
 
<EOS>
"
We
are
sorry
to
disturb
you
,
"
said
Leonard
;
"
but
we
are
in
search
of
a
nobleman
who
has
run
away
with
a
citizen
's
daughter
,
and
conveyed
her
to
the
cathedral
,
<EOS>
and
we
thought
they
might
have
taken
refuge
in
this
chapel
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
No
one
is
here
except
myself
and
daughter
,
"
replied
the
piper
.
<EOS>
"
We
are
allowed
this
lodging
by
Mr.
Quatremain
,
the
minor
canon
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
All
dogs
are
ordered
to
be
destroyed
by
the
Lord
Mayor
,
"
cried
the
smith
,
seizing
Bell
by
the
neck
.
<EOS>
"
This
noisy
animal
must
be
silenced
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
no
!
do
not
hurt
her
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Nizza
.
<EOS>
"
My
father
loves
poor
Bell
almost
as
well
as
he
loves
me
.
<EOS>
She
is
necessary
to
his
existence
.
<EOS>
You
must
not
--
will
not
destroy
her
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
Wo
n't
I
?
<EOS>
"
replied
the
smith
,
gruffly
;
"
we
'll
see
that
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
But
we
are
not
afraid
of
contagion
,
are
we
,
father
?
"
<EOS>
cried
Nizza
,
appealing
to
the
piper
.
 
<EOS>
"
Not
in
the
least
,
"
replied
Mike
,
"
and
we
will
take
care
the
poor
beast
touches
no
one
else
.
<EOS>
Do
not
harm
her
,
sir
--
for
pity
's
sake
,
do
not
.
<EOS>
I
should
miss
her
sadly
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
The
Lord
Mayor
's
commands
must
be
obeyed
,
"
rejoined
the
smith
,
brutally
.
 
<EOS>
As
if
conscious
of
the
fate
awaiting
her
,
poor
Bell
struggled
hard
to
get
free
,
and
uttered
a
piteous
yell
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
are
not
going
to
kill
the
dog
?
"
<EOS>
interposed
Leonard
.
 
<EOS>
"
Have
you
anything
to
say
to
the
contrary
?
"
rejoined
the
smith
,
in
a
tone
calculated
,
as
he
thought
,
to
put
an
end
to
further
interference
.
 
<EOS>
"
Only
this
,
"
replied
Leonard
,
"
that
I
will
not
allow
it
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
won't
--
eh
?
"
returned
the
smith
,
derisively
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
will
not
,
"
rejoined
Leonard
,
"
so
put
her
down
and
come
along
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Go
your
own
way
,
"
replied
the
smith
,
"
and
leave
me
to
mine
.
"
 
<EOS>
Leonard
answered
by
snatching
Bell
suddenly
from
his
grasp
.
<EOS>
Thus
liberated
,
the
terrified
animal
instantly
flew
to
her
mistress
.
 
<EOS>
"
Is
this
the
return
I
get
for
assisting
you
?
"
cried
the
smith
,
savagely
.
<EOS>
"
You
are
bewitched
by
a
pair
of
black
eyes
.
<EOS>
But
you
will
repent
your
folly
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
shall
never
forget
your
kindness
,
"
replied
Nizza
,
clasping
Bell
to
her
bosom
,
and
looking
gratefully
at
the
apprentice
.
<EOS>
"
You
say
you
are
in
search
of
a
citizen
's
daughter
and
a
nobleman
.
<EOS>
About
half
an
hour
ago
,
or
scarcely
so
much
,
I
was
awakened
by
the
opening
of
the
door
of
the
southern
transept
,
and
peeping
out
<EOS>
,
I
saw
three
persons
--
a
young
man
in
the
dress
of
a
watchman
,
but
evidently
disguised
,
and
a
very
beautiful
young
woman
,
conducted
by
Judith
Malmayns
,
bearing
a
lantern,--pass
through
the
doorway
leading
to
Saint
Faith
's
.
<EOS>
Perhaps
they
are
the
very
persons
you
are
in
search
of
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
They
are
,
"
returned
Leonard
;
"
and
you
have
repaid
me
a
hundredfold
for
the
slight
service
I
have
rendered
you
by
the
information
.
<EOS>
We
will
instantly
repair
to
the
vaults
.
<EOS>
Come
along
.
"
 
<EOS>
Accompanied
by
the
whole
of
the
assemblage
,
except
the
smith
,
who
skulked
off
in
the
opposite
direction
,
he
passed
through
the
low
doorway
on
the
right
of
the
choir
,
and
descended
to
Saint
Faith
's
.
<EOS>
The
subterranean
church
was
buried
in
profound
darkness
,
and
apparently
wholly
untenanted
.
<EOS>
On
reaching
the
charnel
,
they
crossed
it
,
and
tried
the
door
of
the
vault
formerly
occupied
by
the
sexton
.
<EOS>
It
was
fastened
,
but
Leonard
knocking
violently
against
it
,
it
was
soon
opened
by
Judith
Malmayns
,
who
appeared
much
surprised
,
and
not
a
little
alarmed
,
at
the
sight
of
so
many
persons
.
<EOS>
She
was
not
alone
,
and
her
companion
was
Chowles
.
<EOS>
He
was
seated
at
a
table
,
on
which
stood
a
flask
of
brandy
and
a
couple
of
glasses
,
and
seemed
a
good
deal
confused
at
being
caught
in
such
a
situation
,
though
he
endeavoured
to
cover
his
embarrassment
by
an
air
of
effrontery
.
 
<EOS>
"
Where
is
the
Earl
of
<EOS>
Rochester?--where
is
Amabel
?
"
demanded
Leonard
Holt
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
know
nothing
about
either
of
them
,
"
replied
Judith
.
<EOS>
"
Why
do
you
put
these
questions
to
me
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
Because
you
admitted
them
to
the
cathedral
,
"
cried
the
apprentice
,
furiously
,
"
and
because
you
have
concealed
them
.
<EOS>
If
you
do
not
instantly
guide
me
to
their
retreat
,
I
will
make
you
a
terrible
example
to
all
such
evil
-
doers
in
future
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
If
you
think
to
frighten
me
by
your
violence
,
you
are
mistaken
,
"
returned
Judith
,
boldly
.
"
<EOS>
Mr.
Chowles
has
been
here
more
than
two
hours
--
ask
him
whether
he
has
seen
any
one
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Certainly
not
,
"
replied
Chowles
.
<EOS>
"
There
is
no
Amabel
--
no
Earl
of
Rochester
here
.
<EOS>
You
must
be
dreaming
,
young
man
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
The
piper
's
daughter
affirmed
the
contrary
,
"
replied
Leonard
.
"
<EOS>
She
said
she
saw
this
woman
admit
them
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
She
lies
,
"
replied
Judith
,
fiercely
.
<EOS>
But
suddenly
altering
her
tone
,
she
continued
,
"
If
I
_
had
_
admitted
them
,
you
would
find
them
here
.
"
 
<EOS>
Leonard
looked
round
uneasily
.
<EOS>
He
was
but
half
convinced
,
and
yet
he
scarcely
knew
what
to
think
.
 
<EOS>
"
If
you
doubt
what
I
say
to
you
,
"
continued
Judith
,
"
I
will
take
you
to
every
chamber
in
the
cathedral
.
<EOS>
You
will
then
be
satisfied
that
I
speak
the
truth
.
<EOS>
But
I
will
not
have
this
mob
with
me
.
<EOS>
Your
companions
must
remain
here
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Ay
,
stop
with
me
and
make
yourselves
comfortable
,
"
cried
Chowles
.
<EOS>
"
You
are
not
so
much
used
to
these
places
as
I
am
,
I
prefer
a
snug
crypt
,
like
this
,
to
the
best
room
in
a
tavern
--
ha
!
ha
!
"
 
<EOS>
Attended
by
Judith
,
Leonard
Holt
searched
every
corner
of
the
subterranean
church
,
except
the
vestry
,
the
door
of
which
was
locked
,
and
the
key
removed
;
but
without
success
.
<EOS>
They
then
ascended
to
the
upper
structure
,
and
visited
the
choir
,
the
transepts
,
and
the
nave
,
but
with
no
better
result
.
 
<EOS>
"
If
you
still
think
they
are
here
,
"
said
Judith
,
"
we
will
mount
to
the
summit
of
the
tower
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
will
never
quit
the
cathedral
without
them
,
"
replied
Leonard
.
 
<EOS>
"
Come
on
,
then
,
"
returned
Judith
.
 
<EOS>
So
saying
,
she
opened
the
door
in
the
wall
on
the
left
of
the
choir
,
and
,
ascending
a
winding
stone
staircase
to
a
considerable
height
,
arrived
at
a
small
cell
contrived
within
the
thickness
of
the
wall
,
and
desired
Leonard
to
search
it
.
<EOS>
The
apprentice
unsuspectingly
obeyed
.
<EOS>
But
he
had
scarcely
set
foot
inside
when
the
door
was
locked
behind
him
,
and
he
was
made
aware
of
the
treachery
practised
upon
him
by
a
peal
of
mocking
laughter
from
his
conductress
.
  
<EOS>
VI
.
 
<EOS>
OLD
LONDON
FROM
OLD
SAINT
PAUL'S.
 
After
repeated
,
but
ineffectual
efforts
to
burst
open
the
door
,
Leonard
gave
up
the
attempt
in
despair
,
and
endeavoured
to
make
his
situation
known
by
loud
outcries
.
<EOS>
But
his
shouts
,
if
heard
,
were
unheeded
,
and
he
was
soon
compelled
from
exhaustion
to
desist
.
<EOS>
Judith
having
carried
away
the
lantern
,
he
was
left
in
total
darkness
;
but
on
searching
the
cell
,
which
was
about
four
feet
wide
and
six
deep
,
he
discovered
a
narrow
grated
loophole
.
<EOS>
By
dint
of
great
exertion
,
and
with
the
help
of
his
sword
,
which
snapped
in
twain
as
he
used
it
,
he
managed
to
force
off
one
of
the
rusty
bars
,
and
to
squeeze
himself
through
the
aperture
.
<EOS>
All
his
labour
,
however
,
was
thrown
away
.
<EOS>
The
loophole
opened
on
the
south
side
of
the
tower
,
near
one
of
the
large
buttresses
,
which
projected
several
yards
beyond
it
on
the
left
,
and
was
more
than
twenty
feet
above
the
roof
;
so
that
it
would
be
certain
destruction
to
drop
from
so
great
a
height
.
 
<EOS>
The
night
was
overcast
,
and
the
moon
hidden
behind
thick
clouds
.
<EOS>
Still
,
there
was
light
enough
to
enable
him
to
discern
the
perilous
position
in
which
he
stood
.
<EOS>
After
gazing
below
for
some
time
,
Leonard
was
about
to
return
to
the
cell
,
when
,
casting
his
eyes
upwards
,
he
thought
he
perceived
the
end
of
a
rope
about
a
foot
above
his
head
,
dangling
from
the
upper
part
of
the
structure
.
<EOS>
No
sooner
was
this
discovery
made
,
than
it
occurred
to
him
that
he
might
possibly
liberate
himself
by
this
unlooked
for
aid
;
and
,
regardless
of
the
risk
he
ran
,
he
sprang
upwards
and
caught
hold
of
the
rope
.
<EOS>
It
was
firmly
fastened
above
,
and
sustained
his
weight
well
.
 
<EOS>
Possessed
of
great
bodily
strength
and
activity
,
and
nerved
by
desperation
,
Leonard
Holt
placed
his
feet
against
the
buttress
,
and
impelled
himself
towards
one
of
the
tall
pointed
windows
lighting
the
interior
of
the
tower
;
but
though
he
reached
the
point
at
which
he
aimed
,
the
sway
of
the
rope
dragged
him
back
before
he
could
obtain
a
secure
grasp
of
the
stone
shaft
;
and
,
after
another
ineffectual
effort
,
fearful
of
exhausting
his
strength
,
he
abandoned
the
attempt
,
and
began
to
climb
up
the
rope
with
his
hands
and
knees
.
<EOS>
Aided
by
the
inequalities
of
the
roughened
walls
,
he
soon
gained
a
range
of
small
Saxon
arches
ornamenting
the
tower
immediately
beneath
the
belfry
,
and
succeeded
in
planting
his
right
foot
on
the
moulding
of
one
of
them
;
he
instantly
steadied
himself
,
and
with
little
further
effort
clambered
through
an
open
window
.
 
<EOS>
His
first
act
on
reaching
the
belfry
was
to
drop
on
his
knees
,
and
return
thanks
to
Heaven
for
his
deliverance
.
<EOS>
He
then
looked
about
for
an
outlet
;
but
though
a
winding
staircase
existed
in
each
of
the
four
angles
of
the
tower
,
all
the
doors
,
to
his
infinite
disappointment
,
were
fastened
on
the
other
side
.
<EOS>
He
was
still
,
therefore
,
a
prisoner
.
 
<EOS>
Determined
,
however
,
not
to
yield
to
despair
,
he
continued
his
search
,
and
finding
a
small
door
opening
upon
a
staircase
communicating
with
the
summit
of
the
tower
,
he
unfastened
it
(
for
the
bolt
was
on
his
own
side
)
,
and
hurried
up
the
steps
.
<EOS>
Passing
through
another
door
bolted
like
the
first
within
side
,
he
issued
upon
the
roof
.
<EOS>
He
was
now
on
the
highest
part
of
the
cathedral
,
and
farther
from
his
hopes
than
ever
;
and
so
agonizing
were
his
feelings
,
that
he
almost
felt
tempted
to
fling
himself
headlong
downwards
.
<EOS>
Beneath
him
lay
the
body
of
the
mighty
fabric
,
its
vast
roof
,
its
crocketed
pinnacles
,
its
buttresses
and
battlements
scarcely
discernible
through
the
gloom
,
but
looking
like
some
monstrous
engine
devised
to
torture
him
.
 
<EOS>
Wearied
with
gazing
at
it
,
and
convinced
of
the
futility
of
any
further
attempt
at
descent
,
Leonard
Holt
returned
to
the
belfry
,
and
,
throwing
himself
on
the
boarded
floor
,
sought
some
repose
.
<EOS>
The
fatigue
he
had
undergone
was
so
great
,
that
,
notwithstanding
his
anxiety
,
he
soon
dropped
asleep
,
and
did
not
awake
for
several
hours
.
<EOS>
On
opening
his
eyes
,
it
was
just
getting
light
,
and
shaking
himself
,
he
again
prepared
for
action
.
<EOS>
All
the
events
of
the
night
rushed
upon
his
mind
,
and
he
thought
with
unutterable
anguish
of
Amabel
's
situation
.
<EOS>
Glancing
round
the
room
,
it
occurred
to
him
that
he
might
give
the
alarm
by
ringing
the
enormous
bells
near
him
;
but
though
he
set
them
slightly
in
motion
,
he
could
not
agitate
the
immense
clappers
sufficiently
to
produce
any
sound
.
 
<EOS>
Resolved
,
however
,
to
free
himself
at
any
hazard
,
he
once
more
repaired
to
the
summit
of
the
tower
,
and
leaning
over
the
balustrade
,
gazed
below
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
sublime
spectacle
,
and
,
in
spite
of
his
distress
,
filled
him
with
admiration
and
astonishment
.
<EOS>
He
had
stationed
himself
on
the
south
side
of
the
tower
,
and
immediately
beneath
him
lay
the
broad
roof
of
the
transept
,
stretching
out
to
a
distance
of
nearly
two
hundred
feet
.
<EOS>
On
the
right
,
surrounded
by
a
double
row
of
cloisters
,
remarkable
for
the
beauty
of
their
architecture
,
stood
the
convocation
,
or
chapter
-
house
.
<EOS>
The
exquisite
building
was
octagonal
in
form
,
and
supported
by
large
buttresses
,
ornamented
on
each
gradation
by
crocketed
pinnacles
.
<EOS>
Each
side
,
moreover
,
had
a
tall
pointed
window
,
filled
with
stained
glass
,
and
was
richly
adorned
with
trefoils
and
cinquefoils
.
<EOS>
Further
on
,
on
the
same
side
,
was
the
small
low
church
dedicated
to
Saint
Gregory
,
overtopped
by
the
south
-
western
tower
of
the
mightier
parent
fane
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
not
,
however
,
the
cathedral
itself
,
but
the
magnificent
view
it
commanded
,
that
chiefly
attracted
the
apprentice
's
attention
.
<EOS>
From
the
elevated
point
on
which
he
stood
,
his
eye
ranged
over
a
vast
tract
of
country
bounded
by
the
Surrey
hills
,
and
at
last
settled
upon
the
river
,
which
in
some
parts
was
obscured
by
a
light
haze
,
and
in
others
tinged
with
the
ruddy
beams
of
the
newly
-
risen
sun
.
<EOS>
Its
surface
was
spotted
,
even
at
this
early
hour
,
with
craft
,
while
innumerable
vessels
of
all
shapes
and
sizes
were
moored
,
to
its
banks
.
<EOS>
On
.
<EOS>
the
left
,
he
noted
the
tall
houses
covering
London
Bridge
;
and
on
the
right
,
traced
the
sweeping
course
of
the
stream
as
it
flowed
from
Westminster
.
<EOS>
On
this
hand
,
on
the
opposite
bank
,
lay
the
flat
marshes
of
Lambeth
;
while
nearer
stood
the
old
bull
-
baiting
and
bear
-
baiting
establishments
,
the
flags
above
which
could
be
discerned
above
the
tops
of
the
surrounding
habitations
.
<EOS>
A
little
to
the
left
was
the
borough
of
Southwark
,
even
then
a
large
and
populous
district
--
<EOS>
the
two
most
prominent
features
in
the
scene
being
Winchester
House
,
and
Saint
Saviour
's
old
and
beautiful
church
.
 
<EOS>
Filled
with
wonder
at
what
he
saw
,
Leonard
looked
towards
the
east
,
and
here
an
extraordinary
prospect
met
his
gaze
.
<EOS>
The
whole
of
the
city
of
London
was
spread
out
like
a
map
before
him
,
and
presented
a
dense
mass
of
ancient
houses
,
with
twisted
chimneys
,
gables
,
and
picturesque
roofs
--
here
and
there
overtopped
by
a
hall
,
a
college
,
an
hospital
,
or
some
other
lofty
structure
.
<EOS>
This
vast
collection
of
buildings
was
girded
in
by
grey
and
mouldering
walls
,
approached
by
seven
gates
,
and
intersected
by
innumerable
narrow
streets
.
<EOS>
The
spires
and
towers
of
the
churches
shot
up
into
the
clear
morning
air
--
for
,
except
in
a
few
quarters
,
no
smoke
yet
issued
from
the
chimneys
.
<EOS>
On
this
side
,
the
view
of
the
city
was
terminated
by
the
fortifications
and
keep
of
the
Tower
.
<EOS>
Little
did
the
apprentice
think
,
when
he
looked
at
the
magnificent
scene
before
him
,
and
marvelled
at
the
countless
buildings
he
beheld
,
that
,
ere
fifteen
months
had
elapsed
,
the
whole
mass
,
together
with
the
mighty
fabric
on
which
he
stood
,
would
be
swept
away
by
a
tremendous
conflagration
.
<EOS>
Unable
to
foresee
this
direful
event
,
and
lamenting
only
that
so
fair
<EOS>
a
city
should
be
a
prey
to
an
exterminating
pestilence
,
he
turned
towards
the
north
,
and
suffered
his
gaze
to
wander
over
Finsbury
-
fields
,
and
the
hilly
ground
beyond
them
--
over
Smithfield
and
Clerkenwell
,
and
the
beautiful
open
country
adjoining
Gray's
-
inn
-
lane
.
 
<EOS>
So
smiling
and
beautiful
<EOS>
did
these
districts
appear
,
that
ha
could
scarcely
fancy
they
were
the
chief
haunts
of
the
horrible
distemper
.
<EOS>
But
he
could
not
blind
himself
to
the
fact
that
in
Finsbury
-
fields
,
as
well
as
in
the
open
country
to
the
north
of
Holborn
,
plague
-
pits
had
been
digged
and
pest
-
houses
erected
;
and
this
consideration
threw
such
a
gloom
over
the
prospect
,
that
,
in
order
to
dispel
the
effect
,
he
changed
the
scene
by
looking
towards
the
west
.
<EOS>
Here
his
view
embraced
all
the
proudest
mansions
of
the
capital
,
and
tracing
the
Strand
to
Charing
Cross
,
long
since
robbed
of
the
beautiful
structure
from
which
it
derived
its
name
,
and
noticing
its
numerous
noble
habitations
,
his
eye
finally
rested
upon
Whitehall
:
and
he
heaved
a
sigh
as
he
thought
that
the
palace
of
the
sovereign
was
infected
by
as
foul
a
moral
taint
as
the
hideous
disease
that
ravaged
the
dwellings
of
his
subjects
.
 
<EOS>
At
the
time
that
Leonard
Holt
gazed
upon
the
capital
,
its
picturesque
beauties
were
nearly
at
their
close
.
<EOS>
In
a
little
more
than
a
year
and
a
quarter
afterwards
,
the
greater
part
of
the
old
city
was
consumed
by
fire
;
and
though
it
was
rebuilt
,
and
in
many
respects
improved
,
its
original
and
picturesque
character
was
entirely
destroyed
.
 
<EOS>
It
seems
scarcely
possible
to
conceive
a
finer
view
than
can
be
gained
from
the
dome
of
the
modern
cathedral
at
sunrise
on
a
May
morning
,
when
the
prospect
is
not
dimmed
by
the
smoke
of
a
hundred
thousand
chimneys
--
when
the
river
is
just
beginning
to
stir
with
its
numerous
craft
,
or
when
they
are
sleeping
on
its
glistening
bosom
--
when
every
individual
house
,
court
,
church
,
square
,
or
theatre
,
can
be
discerned
--
when
the
eye
can
range
over
the
whole
city
on
each
side
,
and
calculate
its
vast
extent
.
<EOS>
It
seems
scarcely
possible
,
we
say
,
to
suppose
at
any
previous
time
it
could
be
more
striking
;
and
yet
,
at
the
period
under
consideration
,
it
was
incomparably
more
so
.
<EOS>
Then
,
every
house
was
picturesque
,
and
every
street
a
collection
of
picturesque
objects
.
<EOS>
Then
,
that
which
was
objectionable
in
itself
,
and
contributed
to
the
insalubrity
of
the
city
,
namely
,
the
extreme
narrowness
of
the
streets
,
and
overhanging
stories
of
the
houses
,
was
the
main
source
of
their
beauty
.
<EOS>
Then
,
the
huge
projecting
signs
with
their
fantastical
iron
-
work
--
the
conduits
--
the
crosses
(
where
crosses
remained)--the
maypoles
--
all
were
picturesque
;
and
as
superior
to
what
can
now
be
seen
,
as
the
attire
of
Charles
the
Second
's
age
is
to
the
ugly
and
disfiguring
costume
of
our
own
day
.
 
<EOS>
Satiated
with
this
glorious
prospect
,
Leonard
began
to
recur
to
his
own
situation
,
and
carefully
scrutinizing
every
available
point
on
the
side
of
the
Tower
,
he
thought
it
possible
to
effect
his
descent
by
clambering
down
the
gradations
of
one
of
the
buttresses
.
<EOS>
Still
,
as
this
experiment
would
be
attended
with
the
utmost
danger
,
while
,
even
if
he
reached
the
roof
,
he
would
yet
be
far
from
his
object
,
he
resolved
to
defer
it
for
a
short
time
,
in
the
hope
that
ere
long
seine
of
the
bell
-
ringers
,
or
other
persons
connected
with
the
cathedral
,
might
come
thither
and
set
him
free
.
 
<EOS>
While
thus
communing
with
himself
,
he
heard
a
door
open
below
;
and
hurrying
down
the
stairs
at
the
sound
,
he
beheld
,
to
his
great
surprise
and
joy
,
the
piper
's
daughter
,
Nizza
Macascree
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
searched
for
you
everywhere
,
"
she
cried
,
"
and
began
to
think
some
ill
had
befallen
you
.
<EOS>
I
overheard
<EOS>
Judith
Malmayns
say
she
had
shut
you
up
in
a
cell
in
the
upper
part
of
the
tower
.
<EOS>
How
did
you
escape
thence
?
"
 
<EOS>
Leonard
hastily
explained
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
told
you
I
should
never
forget
the
service
you
rendered
me
in
preserving
the
life
of
poor
Bell
,
"
pursued
Nizza
,
"
and
what
I
have
done
will
prove
I
am
not
unmindful
of
my
promise
<EOS>
I
saw
you
search
the
cathedral
last
night
with
Judith
,
and
noticed
that
she
returned
from
the
tower
unaccompanied
by
you
.
<EOS>
At
first
I
supposed
you
might
have
left
the
cathedral
without
my
observing
you
,
and
I
was
further
confirmed
in
the
idea
by
what
I
subsequently
heard
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Indeed
!
"
exclaimed
Leonard
.
<EOS>
"
What
did
you
hear
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
followed
Judith
to
the
vaults
of
Saint
Faith
's
,
"
replied
Nizza
,
"
and
heard
her
inform
your
companions
that
you
had
found
the
grocer
's
daughter
,
and
had
taken
her
away
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
And
this
false
statement
imposed
upon
them
?
"
cried
Leonard
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
did
,
"
replied
Nizza
.
<EOS>
"
They
were
by
this
time
more
than
half
intoxicated
by
the
brandy
given
them
by
Chowles
,
the
coffin
-
maker
,
and
they
departed
in
high
dudgeon
with
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
No
wonder
!
"
exclaimed
Leonard
.
 
<EOS>
"
They
had
scarcely
been
gone
many
minutes
,
"
pursued
Nizza
,
"
when
,
having
stationed
myself
behind
one
of
the
massive
pillars
in
the
north
aisle
of
Saint
Faith's
--
for
I
suspected
something
was
wrong
--
I
observed
Judith
and
Chowles
steal
across
the
nave
,
and
proceed
towards
the
vestry
.
<EOS>
The
former
tapped
at
the
door
,
and
they
were
instantly
admitted
by
Mr.
Quatremain
,
the
minor
canon
.
<EOS>
Hastening
to
the
door
,
which
was
left
slightly
ajar
,
I
perceived
two
young
gallants
,
whom
I
heard
addressed
as
the
Earl
of
Rochester
and
Sir
George
Etherege
,
and
a
young
female
,
who
I
could
not
doubt
was
Amabel
.
<EOS>
The
earl
and
his
companion
laughed
heartily
at
the
trick
Judith
had
played
you
,
and
which
the
latter
detailed
to
them
;
but
Amabel
took
no
part
in
their
merriment
,
but
,
on
the
contrary
,
looked
very
grave
,
and
even
wept
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Wept
,
did
she
?
"
<EOS>
cried
Leonard
,
in
a
voice
of
much
emotion
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Then
,
there
is
hope
for
her
yet
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
appear
greatly
interested
in
her
,
"
observed
Nizza
,
pausing
,
in
her
narration
.
<EOS>
"
Do
you
love
her
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
Can
you
ask
it
?
"
<EOS>
cried
Leonard
,
passionately
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
would
advise
you
to
think
no
more
of
her
,
and
to
fix
your
heart
elsewhere
,
"
returned
Nizza
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
know
not
what
it
is
to
love
,
"
replied
the
apprentice
,
"
or
you
would
not
offer
such
a
counsel
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
not
,
"
replied
Nizza
;
"
but
I
am
sorry
you
have
bestowed
your
heart
upon
one
who
so
little
appreciates
the
boon
.
"
 
<EOS>
And
,
feeling
she
had
said
too
much
,
she
blushed
deeply
,
and
cast
down

.
 
<EOS>
Unconscious
of
her
confusion
,
and
entirely
engrossed
by
the
thought
of
his
mistress
,
Leonard
urged
her
to
proceed
.
 
<EOS>
"
Tell
me
what
has
become
of
Amabel
--
where
I
shall
find
her
?
"
<EOS>
he
cried
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
will
find
her
soon
enough
,
"
replied
Nizza
.
<EOS>
"
She
has
not
left
the
cathedral
.
<EOS>
But
hear
me
to
an
end
.
<EOS>
On
learning
you
were
made
a
prisoner
,
I
ran
to
the
door
leading
to
the
tower
,
but
found
that
Judith
had
locked
it
,
and
removed
the
key
.
<EOS>
Not
daring
to
give
the
alarm
--
for
I
had
gathered
from

was

that
the
three
vergers
were
in

earl
's

--
I
determined
to

a

to

.
<EOS>
Accordingly
I
returned
to
the
vestry
door
,
and
again
played
the
eaves
-
dropper
.
<EOS>
By
this
time
,
another
person
,
who
was
addressed
as
Major
Pillichody
,
and
who
,
it

,
had

in

,
had

.
<EOS>
He
informed
the
earl
that
Mr.
Bloundel
was
in
the

distress
at
his
daughter
's
disappearance
,
and
advised

to
lose

to

.
<EOS>
These
tidings
troubled
Amabel
exceedingly
,
and
the
earl
endeavoured
to
pacify
her
by
promising
to
espouse
her
at
daybreak
,
and
,
as
soon

the
ceremony
was
over
,
to
introduce
her
in
the

to

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Villain
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Leonard
;
"
but
go
on
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
little
more
to
tell
,
"
replied
Nizza
,
"
except
that

consented

the

,
<EOS>
provided

,

,
with

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Bad
as
that

is
,
it

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
But

did

key
of

?
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
fortunately

Judith
had

,
"

,
"
and
when

,

,
I
possessed

of

.
<EOS>
For

use

,
because
the

of
Rochester
and
Sir
George
Etherege
kept

,
and

that

was

,

strove

;
but

.
<EOS>
As

,
which
is

,

,

.
<EOS>
I
searched
every

,
and
began
to
think
you

gone
,

Judith
's

.
<EOS>
But
I

until

,

accordingly

.
<EOS>
You
are
aware
of
the
result
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
have
rendered
me
a

,
"
replied

;
"
and
I

.
<EOS>
But

,

.
<EOS>
This

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
Before

,

to

left

,

,

's

.
 
<EOS>
On

,

,
and
there

,

,

.
<EOS>
The

.
<EOS>
Not

.
<EOS>
Grasping
his

,
the

darted

,
and
,

,

,
"
Hold
!
<EOS>
I
forbid
this

.
<EOS>
It
must
not

!
"
 
<EOS>
"
Back
,

!
"
<EOS>
cried

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
You

.
<EOS>
Proceed
,

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Forbear
!
"
cried

of

near

--
and
all

,

Solomon
Eagle
,
with

,
issue

.
<EOS>
"
Forbear
!
"
cried
the
enthusiast
,
placing

between

earl
and
Amabel
,
both

.
<EOS>
"
Heaven
's
altar
must
not
be
profaned
with
these

!
<EOS>
And
you
,
Thomas
Quatremain
,
who
have
taken

in
this

transaction
,
make
clean
your
breast
,
and
purge

of
your

,
for
your
hours
are
numbered
.
<EOS>
I
read
in
your
livid
looks
and
red
and
burning
eyeballs
that
you
are
smitten
by
the
pestilence
.
"
  
<EOS>
VII
.
 
<EOS>
PAUL
'S
WALK
.
 
<EOS>
It
will
now
be
necessary
to
ascertain
what
took
place
at
the
grocer
's
habitation
subsequently
to
Amabel
's
abduction
.
<EOS>
Leonard
Holt
having
departed
,
Pillichody
was
preparing
to
make
good
his
retreat
,
when
he
was
prevented
by
Blaize
,
who
,
hearing
a
noise
in
the
yard
,
peeped
cautiously
out
at
the
back
-
door
,
and
inquired
who
was
there
?
 
<EOS>
"
Are
you
Mr.
Bloundel
?
"
rejoined
Pillichody
,
bethinking
him
of
a
plan
to
turn
the
tables
upon
the
apprentice
.
 
<EOS>
"
No
,
I
am
his
porter
,
"
replied
the
other
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
,
Blaize
!
"
replied
Pillichody
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Thunder
and
lightning
!
<EOS>
do
n't
you
remember
Bernard
Boutefeu
,
the
watchman
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
remember
any
watchman
of
that
name
,
and
I
can
not
discern
your
features
,
"
rejoined
Blaize
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
your
voice
sounds
familiar
to
me
.
<EOS>
What
are
you
doing
there
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
been
trying
to
prevent
Leonard
Holt
from
carrying
off
your
master
's
daughter
,
the
fair
Mistress
Amabel
,
"
answered
Pillichody
.
<EOS>
"
But
he
has
accomplished
his
villanous
purpose
in
spite
of
me
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
The
devil
he
has
!
"
cried
Blaize
.
<EOS>
"
Here
is
a
pretty
piece
of
news
for
my
master
.
<EOS>
But
how
did
you
discover
him
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
Chancing
to
pass
along
the
entry
on
the
other
side
of
that
wall
about
a
quarter
of
an
hour
ago
,
"
returned
Pillichody
,
"
I
perceived
a
rope
-
ladder
fastened
to
it
,
and
wishing
to
ascertain
what
was
the
matter
,
I
mounted
it
,
and
had
scarcely
got
over
into
the
yard
,
when
I
saw
two
persons
advancing
.
<EOS>
I
concealed
myself
beneath
the
shadow
of
the
wall
,
and
they
did
not
notice
me
;
but
I
gathered
from
their
discourse
who
they
were
and
what
was
their
design
.
<EOS>
I
allowed
Amabel
to
ascend
,
but
just
as
the
apprentice
was
following
,
I
laid
hold
of
the
skirt
of
his
doublet
,
and
,
pulling
him
back
,
desired
him
to
come
with
me
to
his
master
.
<EOS>
He
answered
by
drawing
his
sword
,
and
would
have
stabbed
me
,
but
I
closed
with
him
,
and
should
have
secured
him
if
my
foot
had
not
slipped
.
<EOS>
While
I
was
on
the
ground
,
he
dealt
me
a
severe
blow
,
and
ran
after
his
mistress
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Just
like
him
,
"
replied
Blaize
.
"
<EOS>
He
took
the
same
cowardly
advantage
of
me
last
night
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
No
punishment
will
be
too
severe
for
him
,
"
rejoined
Pillichody
,
"
and
I
hope
your
master
will
make
a
terrible
example
of
him
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
How
fortunate
I
was
not
gone
to
bed
!
"
<EOS>
exclaimed
Blaize
,
"
I
had
just
taken
a
couple
of
rufuses
,
and
was
about
to
put
on
my
nightcap
,
when
,
hearing
a
noise
without
,
and
being
ever
on
the
alert
to
defend
my
master
's
property
,
even
at
the
hazard
of
my
life
,
I
stepped
forth
and
found
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
will
bear
testimony
to
your
vigilance
and
courage
,
"
returned
Pillichody
;
"
but
you
had
better
go
and
alarm
your
master
,
I
will
wait
here
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Instantly
I
-
instantly
!
"
cried
Blaize
,
rushing
upstairs
.
 
<EOS>
On
the
way
to
Mr.
Bloundel
's
chamber
,
he
met
Patience
,
and
told
her
what
he
had
heard
.
<EOS>
She
was
inclined
to
put
a
very
different
construction
on
the
story
;
but
as
she
bore
the
apprentice
<EOS>
no
particular
good
-
will
,
she
determined
to
keep
her
opinion
to
herself
,
and
let
affairs
take
their
course
.
<EOS>
The
grocer
was
soon
aroused
,
and
scarcely
able
to
credit
the
porter
's
intelligence
,
and
yet
fearing
something
must
be
wrong
,
he
hastily
attired
himself
,
and
proceeded
to
Amabel
's
room
.
<EOS>
It
was
empty
,
and
it
was
evident
from
the
state
in
which
everything
was
left
,
that
she
had
never
retired
to
rest
.
<EOS>
Confounded
by
the
sight
,
Bloundel
then
hurried
downstairs
in
search
of
the
apprentice
,
but
he
was
nowhere
to
be
found
.
<EOS>
By
this
time
,
Mrs.
Bloundel
had
joined
him
,
and
on
hearing
Blaize
's
story
,
utterly
scouted
it
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
can
not
be
,
"
she
cried
.
<EOS>
"
Leonard
could
have
no
motive
for
acting
thus
.
<EOS>
He
had
our
consent
to
the
union
,
and
the
sole
obstacle
to
it
was
Amabel
herself
.
<EOS>
Is
it
likely
he
would
run
away
with
her
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
sure
I
do
not
know
,
"
replied
Patience
,
"
but
he
was
desperately
in
love
,
that
's
certain
;
and
when
people
are
in
love
,
I
am
told
they
do
very
strange
and
unaccountable
things
.
<EOS>
Perhaps
he
may
have
carried
her
off
against
her
will
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Very
likely
,
"
rejoined
Blaize
.
<EOS>
"
I
thought
I
heard
a
scream
,
and
should
have
called
out
at
the
moment
,
but
a
rufus
stuck
in
my
throat
and
prevented
me
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Where
is
the
person
who
says
he
intercepted
them
?
"
asked
Bloundel
.
 
<EOS>
"
In
the
yard
,
"
answered
Blaize
.
 
<EOS>
"
Bid
him
come
hither
,
"
rejoined
his
master
.
<EOS>
"
Stay
,
I
will
go
to
him
myself
.
"
 
<EOS>
With
this
,
the
whole
party
,
including
old
Josyna
and
Stephen
--
the
two
boys
and
little
Christiana
not
having
been
disturbed
--
proceeded
to
the
yard
,
where
they
found
Pillichody
in
his
watchman
's
dress
,
who
related
his
story
more
circumstantially
than
before
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
believe
a
word
of
it
,
"
cried
Mrs.
Bloundel
;
"
and
I
will
stake
my
life
<EOS>
it
is
one
of
the
Earl
of
Rochester
's
tricks
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Were
I
assured
that
such
was
the
case
,
"
said
the
grocer
,
in
a
stern
whisper
to
his
wife
,
"
I
would
stir
no
further
in
the
matter
.
<EOS>
My
threat
to
Amabel
was
not
an
idle
one
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
may
be
mistaken
,
"
returned
Mrs.
Bloundel
,
almost
at
her
wit
's
end
with
anxiety
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Do
n't
mind
what
I
say
.
<EOS>
Judge
for
yourself
.
<EOS>
Oh
dear
!
<EOS>
what
_
will
_
become
of
her
?
"
<EOS>
she
mentally
ejaculated
.
 
<EOS>
"
Lanterns
and
links
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Pillichody
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Do
you
mean
to
impeach
my
veracity
,
good
mistress
?
<EOS>
I
am
an
old
soldier
,
and
as
tenacious
of
my
honour
as
your
husband
is
of
his
credit
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
This
blustering
will
not
serve
your
turn
,
fellow
,
"
observed
the
grocer
,
seizing
him
by
the
collar
.
<EOS>
"
I
begin
to
suspect
my
wife
is
in
the
right
,
and
will
at
all
events
detain
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Detain
me
!
<EOS>
on
what
ground
?
"
asked
Pillichody
.
 
<EOS>
"
As
an
accomplice
in
my
daughter
's
abduction
,
"
replied
Bloundel
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Here
,
Blaize
--
Stephen
,
hold
him
while
I
call
the
watch
.
<EOS>
This
is
a
most
mysterious
affair
,
but
I
will
soon
get
at
the
bottom
of
it
.
"
 
<EOS>
By
the
grocer
's
directions
,
Pillichody
,
who
very
quietly
entered
the
house
,
and
surrendered
his
halberd
to
Blaize
,
was
taken
to
the
kitchen
.
<EOS>
Bloundel
then
set
forth
,
leaving
Stephen
on
guard
at
the
yard
door
,
while
his
wife
remained
in
the
shop
,
awaiting
his
return
.
 
<EOS>
On
reaching
the
kitchen
with
the
prisoner
,
Blaize
besought
his
mother
,
who
,
as
well
as
Patience
,
had
accompanied
him
thither
,
to
fetch
a
bottle
of
sack
.
<EOS>
While
she
went
for
the
wine
,
and
the
porter
was
stalking
to
and
fro
before
the
door
with
the
halberd
on
his
shoulder
,
Patience
whispered
to
Pillichody
,
"
I
know
who
you
are
.
<EOS>
You
came
here
last
night
with
the
Earl
of
Rochester
in
the
disguise
of
a
quack
doctor
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Hush
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Pillichody
,
placing
his
finger
on
his
lips
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
not
going
to
betray
you
,
"
returned
Patience
,
in
the
same
tone
.
<EOS>
"
But
you
are
sure
to
be
found
out
,
and
had
better
beat
a
retreat
before
Mr.
Bloundel
returns
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
wo
n't
lose
a
moment
,
"
replied
Pillichody
,
starting
to
his
feet
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
's
the
matter
?
"
<EOS>
cried
Blaize
,
suddenly
halting
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
only
got
up
to
see
whether
the
wine
was
coming
,
"
replied
Pillichody
.
 
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
here
it
is
,
"
replied
Blaize
,
as
his
mother
reappeared
;
"
and
now
you
shall
have
a
glass
of
such
sack
as
you
never
yet
tasted
.
"
 
<EOS>
And
pouring
out
a
bumper
,
he
offered
it
to
Pillichody
.
<EOS>
The
latter
took
the
glass
;
but
his
hand
shook
so
violently
that
he
could
not
raise
it
to
his
lips
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
ails
you
,
friend
?
"
inquired
Blaize
,
uneasily
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
,
"
replied
Pillichody
;
"
but
I
feel
extremely
unwell
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
He
looks
to
me
as
if
he
had
got
the
plague
,
"
observed
Patience
,
to
Blaize
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
plague
!
<EOS>
"
exclaimed
the
latter
,
letting
fall
the
glass
,
which
shivered
to
pieces
on
the
stone
floor
.
"
<EOS>
And
I
have
touched
him
.
<EOS>
Where
is
the
vinegar
-
bottle
?
<EOS>
I
must
sprinkle
myself
directly
,
and
rub
myself
from
head
to
foot
with
oil
of
hartshorn
and
spirits
of
sulphur
.
<EOS>
Mother
!
<EOS>
dear
mother
!
<EOS>
you
have
taken
away
my
medicine
-
chest
.
<EOS>
If
you
love
me
,
go
and
fetch
me
a
little
conserve
of
Roman
wormwood
and
mithridate
.
<EOS>
You
will
find
them
in
two
small
jars
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
yes
,
do
,
"
cried
Patience
;
"
or
he
may
die
with
fright
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
Moved
by
their
joint
entreaties
,
old
Josyna
again
departed
;
and
her
back
was
no
sooner
turned
,
than
Patience
said
in
an
undertone
to
Pillichody,--"Now
is
your
time
.
<EOS>
You
have
not
a
moment
to
lose
.
"
 
<EOS>
Instantly
taking
the
hint
,
the
other
uttered
a
loud
cry
,
and
springing
up
,
caught
at
Blaize
,
who
instantly
dropped
the
halberd
,
and
fled
into
one
corner
of
the
room
.
 
<EOS>
Pillichody
then
hurried
upstairs
,
while
Blaize
shouted
after
him
,
"
Do
n't
touch
him
,
Master
Stephen
.
<EOS>
He
has
got
the
plague
!
<EOS>
he
has
got
the
plague
!
"
 
<EOS>
Alarmed
by
this
outcry
,
Stephen
suffered
Pillichody
to
pass
;
and
the
latter
,
darting
across
the
yard
,
mounted
the
rope
-
ladder
,
and
quickly
disappeared
.
<EOS>
A
few
minutes
afterwards
,
Bloundel
returned
with
the
watch
,
and
was
greatly
enraged
when
he
found
that
the
prisoner
had
got
off
.
<EOS>
No
longer
doubting
that
he
had
been
robbed
of
his
daughter
by
the
Earl
of
Rochester
,
he
could
not
make
up
his
mind
to
abandon
her
to
her
fate
,
and
his
conflicting
feelings
occasioned
him
a
night
of
indescribable
anxiety
.
<EOS>
The
party
of
watch
whom
he
had
summoned
searched
the
street
for
him
,
and
endeavoured
to
trace
out
the
fugitives,--but
without
success
;
and
they
returned
before
daybreak
to
report
their
failure
.
 
<EOS>
About
six
o'clock
,
Mr.
Bloundel
,
unable
to
restrain
himself
longer
,
sallied
forth
with
Blaize
in
search
of
his
daughter
and
Leonard
.
<EOS>
Uncertain
where
to
bend
his
steps
,
he
trusted
to
chance
to
direct
him
,
resolved
,
if
he
were
unsuccessful
,
to
lay
a
petition
for
redress
before
the
throne
.
<EOS>
Proceeding
along
Cheapside
,
he
entered
Paternoster
-
row
,
and
traversed
it
till
he
came
to
Paul
's
Alley,--a
narrow
passage
leading
to
the
north
-
west
corner
of
the
cathedral
.
<EOS>
Prompted
by
an
unaccountable
impulse
,
he
no
sooner
caught
sight
of
the
reverend
structure
,
than
he
hastened
,
towards
it
,
and
knocked
against
the
great
northern
door
.
 
<EOS>
We
shall
,
however
,
precede
him
,
and
return
to
the
party
at
the
altar
.
<EOS>
The
awful
warning
of
Solomon
Eagle
so
alarmed
Quatremain
,
that
he
let
fall
his
prayer
-
book
,
and
after
gazing
vacantly
round
for
a
few
moments
,
staggered
to
one
of
the
stalls
,
where
,
feeling
a
burning
pain
in
his
breast
,
he
tore
open
his
doublet
,
and
found
that
the
enthusiast
had
spoken
the
truth
,
and
that
he
was
really
attacked
by
the
pestilence
.
<EOS>
As
to
Amabel
,
on
hearing
the
terrible
denunciation
,
she
uttered
a
loud
cry
,
and
would
have
fallen
to
the
ground
but
for
the
timely
assistance
of
the
apprentice
,
who
caught
her
with
one
arm
,
while
with
the
other
he
defended
himself
against
the
earl
and
his
companions
.
 
<EOS>
But
,
in
spite
of
his
resistance
,
they
would
have
soon
compelled
him
to
relinquish
his
charge
,
if
Solomon
Eagle
,
who
had
hitherto
contented
himself
with
gazing
sternly
on
what
was
passing
,
had
not
interfered
;
and
,
rushing
towards
the
combatants
,
seized
Rochester
and
Etherege
,
and
hurled
them
backwards
with
almost
supernatural
force
.
<EOS>
When
they
arose
,
and
menaced
him
with
their
swords
,
he
laughed
loudly
and
contemptuously
,
crying
,
"
Advance
,
if
ye
dare
!
<EOS>
and
try
your
strength
against
one
armed
by
Heaven
,
and
ye
will
find
how
far
it
will
avail
.
"
 
<EOS>
At
this
juncture
,
Leonard
Holt
heard
a
musical
voice
behind
him
,
and
turning
,
beheld
Nizza
Macascree
.
<EOS>
She
beckoned
him
to
follow
her
;
and
,
raising
Amabel
in
his
arms
,
he
ran
towards
the
door
leading
to
Saint
Faith
's
,
through
which
his
conductress
passed
.
<EOS>
All
this
was
the
work
of
a
moment
,
and
when
Rochester
and
Etherege
,
who
rushed
after
him
,
tried
the
door
,
they
found
it
fastened
withinside
.
 
<EOS>
Just
then
,
a
loud
knocking
was
heard
at
the
northern
entrance
of
the
cathedral
,
and
a
verger
answering
the
summons
,
Mr.
Bloundel
and
Blaize
were
admitted
.
<EOS>
On
beholding
the
newcomers
,
Rochester
and
his
companions
were
filled
with
confusion
.
<EOS>
Equally
astonished
at
the
recounter
,
the
grocer
grasped
his
staff
,
and
rushing
up
to
the
earl
,
demanded
,
in
a
voice
that
made
the
other
,
despite
his
natural
audacity
,
<EOS>
quail--"Where
is
my
child
,
my
lord
?
<EOS>
What
have
you
done
with
her
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
know
nothing
about
her
,
"
replied
Rochester
,
with
affected
carelessness.--"Yes
<EOS>
,
I
am
wrong
,
"
he
added
,
as
if
recollecting
himself
;
"
lam
told
she
has
run
away
with
your
apprentice
.
"
 
<EOS>
Pillichody
,
who
had
changed
his
attire
since
his
escape
from
the
grocer
's
dwelling
,
thought
he
might
now
venture
to
address
him
without
fear
of
discovery
,
and
,
setting
his
arms
a
-
kimbo
,
and
assuming
a
swaggering
demeanour
,
strutted
forward
and
said
,
"
Your
daughter
has
just
been
wedded
to
Leonard
Holt
,
Mr.
Bloundel
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
false
,
"
cried
Bloundel
,
"
as
false
as
the
character
you
just
personated
,
for
I
recognise
you
as
the
knave
who
recently
appeared
before
me
as
a
watchman
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
pledge
you
my
word
as
a
nobleman
,
"
interposed
Rochester
,
"
that
your
daughter
has
just
descended
to
Saint
Faith
's
with
your
apprentice
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
can
corroborate
his
lordship
's
assertion
,
"
said
Etherege
.
 
<EOS>
"
And
I
,
"
added
Pillichody
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
By
the
holy
apostle
to
whom
this
fane
is
dedicated
!
it
is
so
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
To
convince
you
that
we
speak
the
truth
,
we
will
go
with
you
and
assist
you
to
search
,
"
said
Rochester
.
 
<EOS>
Attaching
little
credit
to
what
he
heard
,
and
yet
unwilling
to
lose
a
chance
of
recovering
his
daughter
,
the
grocer
rushed
to
the
door
indicated
by
his
informant
,
but
found
it
fastened
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
had
better
go
to
the
main
entrance
,
"
said
one
of
the
vergers
;
"
I
have
the
keys
with
me
,
and
will
admit
you
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
will
keep
guard
here
till
you
return
,
"
said
another
verger
 
Accompanied
by
Rochester
and
Etherege
,
Bloundel
then
proceeded
to
the
chief
door
of
the
subterranean
church
.
<EOS>
It
was
situated
at
the
south
of
the
cathedral
,
between
two
of
the
larger
buttresses
,
and
at
the
foot
of
a
flight
of
stone
steps
.
<EOS>
On
reaching
it
,
the
verger
produced
his
keys
,
but
they
were
of
no
avail
,
for
the
door
was
barred
withinside
.
<EOS>
After
many
fruitless
attempts
to
obtain
admission
,
they
were
fain
to
give
up
the
attempt
.
 
<EOS>
"
Well
,
if
we
can
not
get
in
,
no
one
shall
get
out
,
"
observed
the
verger
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
only
key
that
opens
this
door
is
in
my
possession
,
so
we
have
them
safe
enough
.
"
 
<EOS>
The
party
then
returned
to
the
cathedral
,
where
they
found
Blaize
,
Pillichody
,
and
the
two
other
vergers
keeping
watch
at
the
door
near
the
choir
.
<EOS>
No
one
had
come
forth
.
 
<EOS>
Rochester
then
walked
apart
with
his
companions
,
while
Bloundel
,
feeling
secure
so
long
as
he
kept
the
earl
in
view
,
folded
his
arms
upon
his
breast
,
and
determined
to
await
the
result
.
 
<EOS>
By
this
time
,
the
doors
being
opened
,
a
great
crowd
was
soon
collected
within
the
sacred
structure
.
<EOS>
Saint
Paul
's
Churchyard
,
as
is
well
known
,
was
formerly
the
great
mart
for
booksellers
,
who
have
not
,
even
in
later
times
,
deserted
the
neighbourhood
,
but
still
congregate
in
Paternoster
-
row
,
Ave
-
Maria
-
lane
,
and
the
adjoining
streets
.
<EOS>
At
the
period
of
this
history
they
did
not
confine
themselves
to
the
precincts
of
the
cathedral
,
but
,
as
has
been
previously
intimated
,
fixed
their
shops
against
the
massive
pillars
of
its
nave
.
<EOS>
Besides
booksellers
,
there
were
seamstresses
,
tobacco
-
merchants
,
vendors
of
fruit
and
provisions
,
and
Jews
--
all
of
whom
had
stalls
within
the
cathedral
,
and
who
were
now
making
preparations
for
the
business
of
the
day
.
<EOS>
Shortly
afterwards
,
numbers
who
came
for
recreation
and
amusement
made
their
appearance
,
and
before
ten
o'clock
,
Paul
's
Walk
,
as
the
nave
was
termed
,
was
thronged
,
by
apprentices
,
rufflers
,
porters
,
water
-
carriers
,
higglers
,
with
baskets
on
their
heads
,
or
under
their
arms
,
fish
-
wives
,
quack
-
doctors
,
cutpurses
,
bonarobas
,
merchants
,
lawyers
,
and
serving
-
men
,
who
came
to
be
hired
,
and
who
stationed
themselves
near
an
oaken
block
attached
to
one
of
the
pillars
,
and
which
was
denominated
,
from
the
use
it
was
put
to
,
the
"
serving
-
man
's
log
.
<EOS>
"
Some
of
the
crowd
were
smoking
,
some
laughing
,
<EOS>
others
gathering
round
a
ballad
-
singer
,
who
was
chanting
one
of
Rochester
's
own
licentious
ditties
;
some
were
buying
quack
medicines
and
remedies
for
the
plague
,
the
virtues
of
which
the
vendor
loudly
extolled
;
while
others
were
paying
court
to
the
dames
,
many
of
whom
were
masked
.
<EOS>
Everything
seemed
to
be
going
forward
within
this
sacred
place
,
except
devotion
.
<EOS>
Here
,
a
man
,
mounted
on
the
carved
marble
of
a
monument
,
bellowed
forth
the
news
of
the
Dutch
war
,
while
another
,
not
far
from
him
,
on
a
bench
,
announced
in
lugubrious
accents
the
number
of
those
who
had
died
on
the
previous
day
of
the
pestilence
.
<EOS>
There
,
at
the
very
font
,
was
a
usurer
paying
over
a
sum
of
money
to
a
gallant
--
it
was
Sir
Paul
Parravicin
--
who
was
sealing
a
bond
for
thrice
the
amount
of
the
loan
.
<EOS>
There
,
a
party
of
choristers
,
attended
by
a
troop
of
boys
,
were
pursuing
another
gallant
,
who
had
ventured
into
the
cathedral
booted
and
spurred
,
and
were
demanding
"
spur
-
money
"
of
him
--
an
exaction
which
they
claimed
as
part
of
their
perquisites
.
 
<EOS>
An
admirable
picture
of
this
curious
scene
has
been
given
by
Bishop
Earle
,
in
his
_
Microcosmographia
_
,
published
in
1629
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Paul
's
Walk
,
"
he
writes
,
"
is
the
land
's
epitome
,
or
you
may
call
it
the
lesser
isle
of
Great
Britain
.
<EOS>
It
is
more
than
this
--
it
is
the
whole
world
's
map
,
which
you
may
here
discern
in
its
perfectest
motion
,
jostling
and
turning
.
<EOS>
It
is
a
heap
of
stones
and
men
,
with
a
vast
confusion
of
languages
;
and
were
the
steeple
not
sanctified
,
nothing
could
be
liker
Babel
.
<EOS>
The
noise
in
it
is
like
that
of
bees
,
a
strange
humming
,
or
buzzing
,
mixed
of
walking
,
tongues
,
and
feet
:
it
is
a
kind
of
still
roar
,
or
loud
whisper
.
<EOS>
It
is
the
great
exchange
of
all
discourse
,
and
no
business
whatsoever
,
but
is
here
stirring
and
afoot
.
<EOS>
It
is
the
synod
of
all
parts
politic
,
jointed
and
laid
together
in
most
serious
posture
,
and
they
are
not
half
so
busy
at
the
Parliament
.
<EOS>
It
is
the
market
of
young
lecturers
,
whom
you
may
cheapen
here
at
all
rates
and
sizes
.
<EOS>
It
is
the
general
mint
of
all
famous
lies
,
which
are
here
,
like
the
legends
of
Popery
,
first
coined
and
stamped
in
the
church
.
<EOS>
All
inventions
are
emptied
here
,
and
not
a
few
pockets
.
<EOS>
The
best
sign
of
the
Temple
in
it
is
that
it
is
the
thieves
'
sanctuary
,
who
rob
more
safely
in
a
crowd
than
a
wilderness
,
while
every
pillar
is
a
bush
to
hide
them
.
<EOS>
It
is
the
other
expense
of
the
day
,
after
plays
and
taverns
;
and
men
have
still
some
oaths
to
swear
here
.
<EOS>
The
visitants
are
all
men
without
exceptions
;
but
the
principal
inhabitants
are
stale
knights
and
captains
out
of
service
,
men
of
long
rapiers
and
short
purses
,
who
after
all
turn
merchants
here
,
and
traffic
for
news
.
<EOS>
Some
make
it
a
preface
to
their
dinner
,
and
travel
for
an
appetite
;
but
thirstier
men
make
it
their
ordinary
,
and
board
here
very
cheap
.
<EOS>
Of
all
such
places
it
is
least
haunted
by
hobgoblins
,
for
if
a
ghost
would
walk
here
,
he
could
not
.
"
 
<EOS>
Decker
,
moreover
,
terms
Paul
's
Walk
,
or
the
"
Mediterranean
Isle
,
"
in
his
"
Gull
's
Hornbook"--"the
only
gallery
wherein
the
pictures
of
all
your
true
fashionate
and
complimental
gulls
are
,
and
ought
to
be
,
hung
up
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
After
giving
circumstantial
directions
for
the
manner
of
entering
the
walk
,
he
proceeds
thus
:
<EOS>
"
Bend
your
course
directly
in
the
middle
line
that
the
whole
body
of
the
church
may
appear
to
be
yours
,
where
in
view
of
all
,
you
may
publish
your
suit
in
what
manner
you
affect
most
,
either
with
the
slide
of
your
cloak
from
the
one
shoulder
or
the
other
.
"
<EOS>
He
then
recommends
the
gull
,
after
four
or
five
turns
in
the
nave
,
to
betake
himself
to
some
of
the
semsters
'
shops
the
new
tobacco
office
,
or
the
booksellers
'
stalls
,
"
where
,
if
you
can
not
read
,
exercise
your
smoke
,
and
inquire
who
has
written
against
the
divine
weed
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Such
,
or
something
like
it
,
was
Paul
's
Walk
at
the
period
of
this
history
.
 
<EOS>
The
grocer
,
who
had
not
quitted
his
post
,
remained
a
silent
and
sorrowful
spectator
of
the
scene
.
<EOS>
Despite
his
anxiety
,
he
could
not
help
moralizing
upon
it
,
and
it
furnished
him
with
abundant
food
for
reflection
.
<EOS>
As
to
Rochester
and
his
companions
,
they
mingled
with
the
crowd
--
though
the
earl
kept
a
wary
eye
on
the
door
--
chatted
with
the
prettiest
damsels
--
listened
to
the
newsmongers
,
and
broke
their
fast
at
the
stall
of
a
vendor
of
provisions
,
who
supplied
them
with
tolerable
viands
,
and
a
bottle
of
excellent
Rhenish
.
<EOS>
Blaize
was
soon
drawn
away
by
one
of
the
quacks
,
and
,
in
spite
of
his
master
's
angry
looks
,
he
could
not
help
purchasing
one
of
the
infallible
antidotes
offered
for
sale
by
the
charlatan
.
<EOS>
Parravicin
had
no
sooner
finished
his
business
with
the
usurer
than
he
strolled
along
the
nave
,
and
was
equally
surprised
and
delighted
at
meeting
with
his
friends
,
who
briefly
explained
to
him
why
they
were
there
.
 
<EOS>
"
And
how
do
you
expect
the
adventure
to
terminate
?
"
<EOS>
asked
Parravicin
,
laughing
heartily
at
the
recital
.
 
<EOS>
"
Heaven
knows
,
"
replied
the
earl
.
<EOS>
"
But
what
are
you
doing
here
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
came
partly
to
replenish
my
purse
,
for
I
have
had
a
run
of
ill
luck
of
late
,
"
replied
the
knight
;
"
and
partly
to
see
a
most
beautiful
creature
,
whom
I
accidentally
discovered
here
yesterday
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
A
new
beauty
!
"
cried
Rochester
.
<EOS>
"
Who
is
she
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
Before
I
tell
you
,
you
must
engage
not
to
interfere
with
me
,
"
replied
Parravicin
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
marked
her
for
my
own
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Agreed
,
"
replied
Rochester
.
<EOS>
"
Now
,
her
name
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
She
is
the
daughter
of
a
blind
piper
,
who
haunts
the
cathedral
,
"
replied
Parravicin
,
"
and
her
name
is
Nizza
Macascree
.
<EOS>
Is
it
not
charming
?
<EOS>
But
you
shall
see
her
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
We
must
not
go
too
far
from
the
door
of
Saint
Faith
's
,
"
rejoined
Rochester
.
<EOS>
"
Can
you
not
contrive
to
bring
her
hither
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
That
is
more
easily
said
than
done
,
"
replied
Parravicin
.
<EOS>
"
She
is
as
coy
as
the
grocer
's
daughter
.
<EOS>
However
,
I
will
try
to
oblige
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
With
this
,
he
quitted
his
companions
,
and
returning
shortly
afterwards
,
said
,
"
My
mistress
has
likewise
disappeared
.
<EOS>
I
found
the
old
piper
seated
at
the
entrance
of
Bishop
Kempe
's
chapel
,
attended
by
his
dog
--
but
he
missed
his
daughter
when
he
awoke
in
the
morning
,
and
is
in
great
trouble
about
her
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Strange
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Etherege
<EOS>
;
"
I
begin
to
think
the
place
is
enchanted
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
would
seem
so
,
indeed
,
"
replied
Rochester
.
 
<EOS>
While
they
were
thus
conversing
,
Pillichody
,
who
was
leaning
against
a
column
,
with
his
eye
fixed
upon
the
door
leading
to
Saint
Faith
's
,
observed
it
open
,
and
the
apprentice
issue
from
it
accompanied
by
two
masked
females
.
<EOS>
All
three
attempted
to
dart
across
the
transept
and
gain
the
northern
entrance
,
but
they
were
Intercepted
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Bloundel
caught
hold
of
Leonard
's
arm
,
and
Rochester
seized
her
whom
he
judged
by
the
garb
to
be
Amabel
,
while
Parravicin
,
recognising
Nizza
Macascree
,
as
he
thought
,
by
her
dress
,
detained
her
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
is
the
meaning
of
all
this
,
Leonard
?
"
demanded
the
grocer
,
angrily
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
shall
have
an
explanation
instantly
,
"
replied
the
apprentice
;
"
but
think
not
of
me
--
think
only
of
your
daughter
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
My
father!--my
father
!
"
cried
the
damsel
,
who
had
been
detained
by
Parravicin
,
taking
off
her
mask
,
and
rushing
towards
the
grocer
.
 
<EOS>
"
Who
then
have
I
got
?
<EOS>
"
cried
Rochester
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
piper
's
daughter
,
I
'll
be
sworn
,
"
replied
Etherege
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
are
right
,
"
replied
Nizza
,
unmasking
.
<EOS>
"
I
changed
dresses
with
Amabel
,
and
hoped
by
so
doing
to
accomplish
her
escape
,
but
we
have
been
baffled
.
<EOS>
However
,
as
her
father
is
here
,
it
is
of
little
consequence
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Amabel
,
"
said
the
grocer
,
repulsing
her
,
"
before
I
receive
you
again
<EOS>
,
I
must
be
assured
that
you
have
not
been
alone
with
the
Earl
of
Rochester
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
She
has
not
,
sir
,
"
replied
the
apprentice
.
<EOS>
"
Visit
your
displeasure
on
my
head
.
<EOS>
I
carried
her
off
and
would
have
wedded
her
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
What
motive
had
you
for
this
strange
conduct
?
"
asked
Bloundel
,
incredulously
.
 
<EOS>
Before
Leonard
could
answer
,
Pillichody
stepped
forward
,
and
said
to
the
grocer
,
"
Mr.
Bloundel
,
you
are
deceived
--
on
the
faith
of
a
soldier
you
are
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Peace
,
fool
!
<EOS>
"
said
Rochester
,
"
I
will
not
be
outdone
in
generosity
by
an
apprentice
.
<EOS>
Leonard
Holt
speaks
the
truth
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
If
so
,
"
replied
Bloundel
,
"
he
shall
never
enter
my
house
again
.
<EOS>
Send
for
your
indentures
to
-
night
,
"
he
continued
sharply
,
to
Leonard
,
"
but
never
venture
to
approach
me
more
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Father
,
you
are
mistaken
,
"
cried
Amabel
.
"
<EOS>
Leonard
Holt
is
not
to
blame
.
<EOS>
I
alone
deserve
your
displeasure
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Be
silent
!
"
<EOS>
whispered
the
apprentice
;
"
you
destroy
yourself
.
<EOS>
I
care
not
what
happens
to
me
,
provided
you
escape
the
earl
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Come
home
,
mistress
,
"
cried
the
grocer
,
dragging
her
through
the
crowd
which
had
gathered
round
them
.
 
<EOS>
"
Here
is
a
pretty
conclusion
to
the
adventure
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Parravicin
;
"
but
where
is
the
apprentice
--
and
where
is
the
pretty
Nizza
Macascree
?
'
<EOS>
Fore
heaven
,
"
he
added
,
as
he
looked
around
for
them
in
vain
,
"
I
should
not
wonder
if
they
have
eloped
together
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Nor
I
,
"
replied
Rochester
.
<EOS>
"
I
admire
the
youth
's
spirit
,
and
trust
he
may
be
more
fortunate
with
his
second
mistress
than
with
his
first
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
shall
be
my
business
to
prevent
that
,
"
rejoined
Parravicin
.
"
<EOS>
Help
me
to
search
for
her
.
"
        
<EOS>
*
      
<EOS>
*
      
<EOS>
*
      
<EOS>
*
      
<EOS>
*
  
VIII
.
 
<EOS>
THE
AMULET
.
 
<EOS>
As
the
grocer
disappeared
with
his
daughter
,
Nizza
Macascree
,
who
had
anxiously
watched
the
apprentice
,
observed
him
turn
deadly
pale
,
and
stagger
;
and
instantly
springing
to
his
side
,
she
supported
him
to
a
neighbouring
column
,
against
which
he
leaned
till
he
had
in
some
degree
recovered
from
the
shock
.
<EOS>
He
then
accompanied
her
to
Bishop
Kempe
's
beautiful
chapel
in
the
northern
aisle
,
where
she
expected
to
find
her
father
;
but
it
was
empty
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
will
be
back
presently
,
"
said
Nizza
.
<EOS>
"
He
is
no
doubt
making
the
rounds
of
the
cathedral
.
<EOS>
Bell
will
take
care
of
him
.
<EOS>
Sit
down
on
that
bench
while
I
procure
you
some
refreshment
.
<EOS>
You
appear
much
in
need
of
it
.
"
 
<EOS>
And
without
waiting
for
a
reply
,
she
ran
off
,
and
presently
afterwards
returned
with
a
small
loaf
of
bread
and
a
bottle
of
beer
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
can
not
eat
,
"
said
Leonard
,
faintly
.
<EOS>
But
seeing
that
his
kind
provider
looked
greatly
disappointed
,
he
swallowed
a
few
mouthfuls
,
and
raised
the
bottle
to
his
lips
.
<EOS>
As
he
did
so
,
a
sudden
feeling
of
sickness
seized
him
,
and
he
set
it
down
untasted
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
ails
you
?
"
<EOS>
asked
Nizza
,
noticing
his
altered
looks
with
uneasiness
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
know
not
,
"
he
replied
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
never
felt
so
ill
before
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
thought
you
were
suffering
from
agitation
,
"
she
rejoined
,
as
a
fearful
foreboding
crossed
her
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
shall
be
speedily
released
from
further
trouble
,
"
replied
the
apprentice
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
sure
I
am
attacked
by
the
plague
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
!
say
not
so
!
<EOS>
"
she
rejoined
.
<EOS>
"
You
may
be
mistaken
.
"
 
<EOS>
But
though
she
tried
to
persuade
herself
she
spoke
the
truth
,
her
heart
could
not
be
deceived
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
scarcely
desire
to
live
,
"
replied
the
apprentice
,
in
a
melancholy
tone
,
"
for
life
has
lost
all
charms
for
me
.
<EOS>
But
do
not
remain
here
,
or
you
may
be
infected
by
the
distemper
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
will
never
leave
you
,
"
she
hastily
rejoined
;
"
that
is
,
"
she
added
,
checking
herself
,
"
till
I
have
placed
you
in
charge
of
some
one
who
will
watch
over
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
No
one
will
watch
over
me
,
"
returned
Leonard
.
<EOS>
"
My
master
has
dismissed
me
from
his
service
,
and
I
have
no
other
friend
left
.
<EOS>
If
you
will
tell
one
of
the
vergers
<EOS>
what
is
the
matter
with
me
,
he
will
summon
the
Examiner
of
Health
,
who
will
bring
a
litter
to
convey
me
to
the
pest
-
house
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
If
you
go
thither
your
fate
is
sealed
,
"
replied
Nizza
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
said
I
do
not
desire
to
live
,
"
returned
the
apprentice
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
not
indulge
in
these
gloomy
thoughts
,
or
you
are
certain
to
bring
about
a
fatal
result
,
"
said
Nizza
.
<EOS>
"
Would
I
knew
how
to
aid
you
!
<EOS>
But
I
still
hope
you
are
deceived
as
to
the
nature
of
your
attack
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
can
not
be
deceived
,
"
replied
Leonard
,
whose
countenance
proclaimed
the
anguish
he
endured
.
"
<EOS>
Doctor
Hodges
,
I
think
,
is
interested
about
me
,
"
he
continued
,
describing
the
physician
's
residence--"if
you
will
inform
him
of
my
seizure
,
he
may
,
perhaps
,
come
to
me
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
will
fly
to
him
instantly
,
"
replied
Nizza
;
and
she
was
about
to
quit
the
chapel
,
when
she
was
stopped
by
Parravicin
and
his
companions
.
 
<EOS>
"
Let
me
pass
,
"
she
said
,
trying
to
force
her
way
through
them
.
 
<EOS>
"
Not
so
fast
,
fair
Nizza
,
"
rejoined
Parravicin
,
forcing
her
back
,
"
I
must
have
a
few
words
with
you
.
<EOS>
Have
I
overrated
her
charms
?
<EOS>
"
he
added
to
Rochester
.
<EOS>
"
Is
she
not
surpassingly
beautiful
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
In
good
sooth
she
is
,
"
replied
the
earl
,
gazing
at
her
with
admiration
.
 
<EOS>
"
By
the
nut
-
brown
skin
of
Cleopatra
!
"
cried
Pillichody
,
"
she
beats
Mrs.
Disbrowe
,
Sir
Paul
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
never
seen
any
one
so
lovely
,
"
said
the
knight
,
attempting
to
press
her
hand
to
his
lips
.
 
<EOS>
"
Release
me
,
sir
,
"
cried
Nizza
,
struggling
to
free
herself
.
 
<EOS>
"
Not
till
I
have
told
you
how
much
I
love
you
,
"
returned
the
knight
,
ardently
.
 
<EOS>
"
Love
me
!
"
<EOS>
she
echoed
,
scornfully
.
 
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
love
you
,
"
reiterated
Parravicin
.
<EOS>
"
It
would
be
strange
if
I
,
who
profess
myself
so
great
an
admirer
of
beauty
,
did
otherwise
.
<EOS>
I
am
passionately
enamoured
of
you
.
<EOS>
If
you
will
accompany
me
,
fair
Nizza
,
you
shall
change
your
humble
garb
for
the
richest
attire
that
gold
can
purchase
,
shall
dwell
in
a
magnificent
mansion
,
and
have
troops
of
servants
at
your
command
.
<EOS>
In
short
,
my
whole
fortune
,
together
with
myself
,
shall
be
placed
at
your
disposal
.
<EOS>
"
 
"
Do
not
listen
to
him
,
Nizza
,
"
cried
Leonard
Holt
,
in
a
faint
voice
.
 
<EOS>
"
Be
assured
I
will
not
,
"
she
answered
.
<EOS>
"
Your
insulting
proposal
only
heightens
the
disgust
<EOS>
I
at
first
conceived
for
you
,
"
she
added
to
the
knight
:
"
I
reject
it
with
scorn
,
and
command
you
to
let
me
pass
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Nay
,
if
you
put
on
these
airs
,
sweetheart
,
"
replied
Parravicin
,
insolently
<EOS>
,
"
I
must
alter
my
tone
likewise
.
<EOS>
I
am
not
accustomed
to
play
the
humble
suitor
to
persons
of
your
condition
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
not
,
"
replied
Nizza
;
"
neither
am
I
accustomed
to
this
unwarrantable
usage
.
<EOS>
Let
me
go
.
<EOS>
My
errand
is
one
of
life
and
death
.
<EOS>
Do
not
hinder
me
,
or
you
will
have
a
heavy
crime
on
your
soul
--
heavier
,
it
may
be
,
than
any
that
now
loads
it
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Where
are
you
going
?
"
<EOS>
asked
Parravicin
,
struck
by
her
earnest
manner
.
 
<EOS>
"
To
fetch
assistance
,
"
she
replied
,
"
for
one
suddenly
assailed
by
the
pestilence
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
"
exclaimed
the
knight
,
trembling
,
and
relinquishing
his
grasp
.
<EOS>
"
My
path
is
ever
crossed
by
that
hideous
spectre
.
<EOS>
Is
it
your
father
who
is
thus
attacked
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
she
replied
,
pointing
to
Leonard
,
"
it
is
that
youth
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
The
apprentice
!
"
exclaimed
Rochester
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
sorry
for
him
.
<EOS>
Let
us
be
gone
,
"
he
added
to
his
companions
.
<EOS>
"
It
may
be
dangerous
to
remain
here
longer
.
"
 
<EOS>
With
this
they
all
departed
except
Parravicin
.
 
<EOS>
"
Come
with
us
,
Nizza
,
"
said
the
latter
;
"
we
will
send
assistance
to
the
sufferer
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
already
told
you
my
determination
<EOS>
,
"
she
rejoined
;
"
I
will
not
stir
a
footstep
with
you
.
<EOS>
And
if
you
have
any
compassion
in
your
nature
,
you
will
not
detain
me
longer
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
will
not
leave
you
here
to
certain
destruction
,
"
said
the
knight
.
<EOS>
"
You
shall
come
with
me
whether
you
will
or
not
.
"
 
<EOS>
And
as
he
spoke
,
he
advanced
towards
her
,
while
she
retreated
towards
Leonard
,
who
,
rising
with
difficulty
,
placed
himself
between
her
and
her
persecutor
.
 
<EOS>
"
If
you
advance
another
footstep
,
"
cried
the
apprentice
,
"
I
will
fling
myself
upon
you
,
and
the
contact
may
be
fatal
.
"
 
<EOS>
Parravicin
gazed
,
furiously
at
him
,
and
half
unsheathed
his
sword
.
<EOS>
But
the
next
moment
he
returned
it
to
the
scabbard
,
and
exclaiming
,
"
Another
time
!
<EOS>
another
time
!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
darted
after
his
companions
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
scarcely
gone
,
when
Leonard
reeled
against
the
wall
,
and
before
Nizza
could
catch
him
,
fell
in
a
state
of
insensibility
on
the
floor
.
 
<EOS>
After
vainly
attempting
to
raise
him
,
Nizza
flew
for
assistance
,
and
had
just
passed
through
the
door
of
the
chapel
,
when
she
met
Judith
Malmayns
and
Chowles
.
<EOS>
She
instantly
stopped
them
,
and
acquainting
them
with
the
apprentice
's
condition
,
implored
them
to
take
charge
of
him
while
she
went
in
search
of
Doctor
Hodges
.
 
<EOS>
"
Before
you
go
,
"
said
Judith
,
"
let
me
make
sure
that
he
is
attacked
by
the
plague
.
<EOS>
It
may
be
some
other
disorder
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
hope
so
,
indeed
,
"
said
Nizza
,
pausing
;
<EOS>
"
but
I
fear
the
contrary
.
"
 
<EOS>
So
saying
,
she
returned
with
them
to
the
chapel
.
<EOS>
Raising
the
apprentice
with
the
greatest
ease
,
Judith
tore
open
his
doublet
.
 
<EOS>
"
Your
suspicion
is
correct
,
"
she
said
,
with
a
malignant
smile
.
<EOS>
"
Here
is
the
fatal
sign
upon
his
breast
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
will
fetch
Doctor
Hodges
instantly
,
"
cried
Nizza
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
so
,
"
replied
Judith
;
"
we
will
convey
him
to
the
vaults
in
Saint
Faith
's
,
where
poor
Mr.
Quatremain
has
just
been
taken
.
<EOS>
He
will
be
better
there
than
in
the
pest
-
house
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Anything
is
better
than
that
,
"
said
Nizza
,
shuddering
.
 
<EOS>
As
soon
as
she
was
gone
,
Chowles
took
off
his
long
black
cloak
,
and
,
throwing
it
over
the
apprentice
,
laid
him
at
full
length
upon
the
bench
,
and
,
assisted
by
Judith
,
carried
him
towards
the
choir
.
<EOS>
As
they
proceeded
,
Chowles
called
out
,
"
Make
way
for
one
sick
of
the
plague
!
"
<EOS>
and
the
crowd
instantly
divided
,
and
gave
them
free
passage
.
<EOS>
In
this
way
they
descended
to
Saint
Faith
's
,
and
,
shaping
their
course
to
the
vault
,
deposited
their
burden
on
the
very
bed
lately
occupied
by
the
unfortunate
sexton
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
has
come
here
to
die
,
"
observed
Judith
to
her
companion
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
His
attack
is
but
a
slight
one
,
and
he
might
with
care
recover
.
<EOS>
But
I
can
bargain
with
the
Earl
of
Rochester
for
his
removal
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Take
heed
how
you
make
such
a
proposal
to
his
lordship
,
"
returned
Chowles
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
From
what
I
have
seen
,
he
is
likely
to
,
revolt
at
it
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Every
man
is
glad
to
get
rid
of
a
rival
,
"
rejoined
Judith
.
 
<EOS>
"
Granted
,
"
replied
Chowles
;
"
but
no
man
will
_
pay
_
for
the
riddance
when
the
plague
will
accomplish
it
for
him
for
nothing
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
With
due
attention
,
I
would
answer
for
that
youth
's
recovery
,
"
said
Judith
.
<EOS>
"
It
is
not
an
incurable
case
,
like
Mr.
Quatremain
's
.
<EOS>
And
so
Doctor
Hodges
,
when
he
comes
,
will
pronounce
it
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
Shortly
after
this
,
Nizza
Macaseree
appeared
with
a
countenance
fraught
with
anxiety
,
and
informed
them
that
Doctor
Hodges
was
from
home
,
and
would
not
probably
return
till
late
at
night
.
 
<EOS>
"
That
's
unfortunate
,
"
said
Judith
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Luckily
,
however
,
there
are
other
doctors
in
London
,
and
some
who
understand
the
treatment
of
the
plague
far
better
than
he
does
--
Sibbald
,
the
apothecary
of
Clerkenwell
,
for
instance
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Do
you
think
Sibbald
would
attend
him
?
"
<EOS>
asked
Nizza
,
eagerly
.
 
<EOS>
"
To
be
sure
he
would
,
"
replied
Mrs.
Malmayns
,
"
if
he
were
paid
for
it
.
<EOS>
But
you
seem
greatly
interested
about
this
youth
.
<EOS>
I
have
been
young
,
and
know
what
effect
good
looks
and
a
manly
deportment
have
upon
our
sex
.
<EOS>
He
has
won
your
heart
!
<EOS>
Ha
!
<EOS>
ha
!
<EOS>
You
need
not
seek
to
disguise
it
.
<EOS>
Your
blushes
answer
for
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
A
truce
to
this
,
"
cried
Nizza
,
whose
cheeks
glowed
with
shame
and
anger
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
can
answer
a
plain
question
,
I
suppose
,
"
returned
Judith
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Is
his
life
dear
to
you
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
Dearer
than
my
own
?
<EOS>
"
replied
Nizza
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
thought
as
much
,
"
returned
Judith
.
<EOS>
"
What
will
you
give
me
to
save
him
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
nothing
,
"
rejoined
Nizza
,
with
a
troubled
look--"nothing
<EOS>
but
thanks
to
give
you
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Think
again
,
"
said
Judith
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Girls
like
you
,
if
they
have
no
money
,
have
generally
some
trinket
--
some
valuable
in
their
possession
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
That
is
not
my
case
,
"
said
Nizza
,
bursting
into
tears
.
<EOS>
"
I
never
received
a
present
in
my
life
,
and
never
desired
one
till
now
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
But
your
father
must
have
some
money
?
"
said
Judith
,
inquisitively
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
know
not
,
"
replied
Nizza
,
"
but
I
will
ask
him
.
<EOS>
What
sum
will
content
you
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
Bring
all
you
can
,
"
returned
Judith
,
"
and
I
will
do
my
best
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
Nizza
then
departed
,
while
Judith
,
with
the
assistance
of
Chowles
,
covered
Leonard
with
blankets
,
and
proceeded
to
light
a
fire
.
<EOS>
Long
before
this
,
the
sick
youth
was
restored
to
animation
.
<EOS>
But
he
was
quite
light
-
headed
and
unconscious
of
his
situation
,
and
rambled
about
Amabel
and
her
father
.
<EOS>
After
administering
such
remedies
as
she
thought
fit
,
and
as
were
at
hand
,
Judith
sat
down
with
the
coffin
-
maker
beside
a
small
table
,
and
entered
into
conversation
with
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
Well
,
"
said
Chowles
,
in
an
indifferent
tone
,
as
he
poured
out
a
glass
of
brandy
,
"
is
it
to
be
kill
or
cure
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
not
decided
,
"
replied
Judith
,
pledging
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
still
do
not
see
what
gain
there
would
be
in
shortening
his
career
,
"
observed
Chowles
.
 
<EOS>
"
If
there
would
be
no
gain
,
there
would
be
gratification
,
"
replied
Judith
.
<EOS>
"
He
has
offended
me
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
If
that
is
the
case
,
I
have
nothing
further
to
say
,
"
returned
Chowles
.
<EOS>
"
But
you
promised
the
piper
's
daughter
to
save
him
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
We
shall
see
what
she
offers
,
"
rejoined
Judith
;
"
all
will
depend
upon
that
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
extraordinary
,
"
observed
Chowles
,
after
a
pause
,
"
that
while
all
around
us
are
sick
or
dying
of
