the
pestilence
,
we
should
escape
contagion
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
We
are
not
afraid
of
it
,
"
replied
Judith
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Besides
,
we
are
part
of
the
plague
ourselves
.
<EOS>
But
I
_
have
_
been
attacked
,
and
am
,
therefore
,
safe
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
True
,
"
replied
Chowles
;
"
I
had
forgotten
that
.
<EOS>
Well
,
if
I
fall
ill
,
you
Sha'n't
nurse
me
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
wo
n't
be
able
to
help
yourself
then
,
"
returned
Judith
.
 
<EOS>
"
Eh
!
"
exclaimed
Chowles
,
shifting
uneasily
on
his
seat
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
be
afraid
,
"
returned
Judith
,
laughing
at
his
alarm
.
<EOS>
"
I
'll
take
every
care
of
you
.
<EOS>
We
are
necessary
to
each
other
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
So
we
are
,
"
replied
Chowles
;
"
so
we
are
;
<EOS>
and
if
nothing
else
could
,
that
consideration
would
make
us
true
to
each
other
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Of
course
,
"
assented
Judith
.
<EOS>
"
Let
us
reap
as
rich
a
harvest
as
we
can
,
and
when
the
scourge
is
over
,
we
can
enjoy
ourselves
upon
the
spoils
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Exactly
so
,
"
replied
Chowles
.
<EOS>
"
My
business
is
daily
-
hourly
on
the
increase
.
<EOS>
My
men
are
incessantly
employed
,
and
my
only
fear
is
that
an
order
will
be
issued
to
bury
the
dead
without
coffins
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Not
unlikely
,
"
replied
Mrs.
Malmayns
.
<EOS>
"
But
there
are
plenty
of
ways
of
getting
money
in
a
season
like
this
.
<EOS>
If
one
fails
,
we
must
resort
to
another
.
<EOS>
I
shall
make
all
I
can
,
and
in
the
shortest
manner
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Right
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Chowles
,
with
,
an
atrocious
laugh
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Right
!
<EOS>
ha
!
<EOS>
ha
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
found
out
a
means
of
propagating
the
distemper
,
"
pursued
Judith
,
in
a
low
tone
,
and
with
a
mysterious
air
,
"
of
inoculating
whomsoever
<EOS>
I
please
with
the
plague
-
venom
.
<EOS>
I
have
tried
the
experiment
on
Mr.
Quatremain
and
that
youth
,
and
you
see
how
well
it
has
answered
in
both
instances
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
do
,
"
replied
Chowles
,
looking
askance
at
her
.
"
<EOS>
But
why
destroy
the
poor
minor
canon
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
Because
I
want
to
get
hold
of
the
treasure
discovered
by
the
help
of
the
Mosaical
rods
in
Saint
Faith
's
,
which
by
right
belonged
to
my
husband
,
and
which
is
now
in
Mr.
Quatremain
's
possession
,
"
replied
Judith
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
understand
,
"
nodded
Chowles
.
 
<EOS>
While
they
were
thus
conversing
,
Nizza
Macascree
again
returned
,
and
informed
them
that
she
could
not
find
her
father
.
"
<EOS>
He
has
left
the
cathedral
,
"
she
said
,
"
and
will
not
,
probably
,
return
till
nightfall
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
sorry
for
it
,
on
your
account
,
"
observed
Judith
,
coldly
.
 
<EOS>
"
Why
,
you
will
not
have
the
cruelty
to
neglect
the
poor
young
man
till
then
--
you
will
take
proper
precautions
?
<EOS>
"
exclaimed
Nizza
.
 
<EOS>
"
Why
should
I
exert
myself
for
one
about
whose
recovery
<EOS>
I
am
indifferent
?
"
said
Judith
.
 
<EOS>
"
Why
?
"
exclaimed
Nizza
.
<EOS>
"
But
it
is
in
vain
to
argue
with
you
.
<EOS>
I
must
appeal
to
your
avarice
,
since
you
are
deaf
to
the
pleadings
of
humanity
.
<EOS>
I
have
just
bethought
me
that
I
have
an
old
gold
coin
,
which
was
given
me
years
ago
by
my
father
.
<EOS>
He
told
me
it
had
been
my
mother
's
,
and
charged
me
not
to
part
with
it
.
<EOS>
I
never
should
have
done
so
,
except
in
an
emergency
like
the
present
.
"
 
<EOS>
As
she
spoke
,
she
drew
from
her
bosom
a
broad
gold
piece
.
<EOS>
A
hole
was
bored
through
it
,
and
it
was
suspended
from
her
neck
by
a
chain
of
twisted
hair
.
 
<EOS>
"
Let
me
look
at
it
,
"
said
Judith
taking
the
coin
.
<EOS>
"
Who
gave
you
this
?
"
<EOS>
she
asked
,
in
an
altered
tone
.
 
<EOS>
"
My
father
?
<EOS>
"
replied
Nizza
;
"
I
have
just
told
you
so
.
<EOS>
It
was
my
mother
's
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Impossible
!
"
exclaimed
Judith
!
 
<EOS>
"
Have
you
ever
seen
it
before
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Nizza
,
astonished
at
the
change
in
the
nurse
's
manner
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
,
"
replied
Judith
,
"
and
in
very
different
hands
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
surprise
me
,
"
cried
Nizza
.
<EOS>
"
Explain
yourself
,
I
beseech
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Not
now
--
not
now
,
"
cried
Judith
,
hastily
returning
the
coin
.
"
<EOS>
And
this
is
to
be
mine
in
case
<EOS>
I
cure
the
youth
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
said
so
,
"
replied
Nizza
.
 
<EOS>
"
Then
make
yourself
easy
,
"
rejoined
Judith
;
"
he
shall
be
well
again
in
less
than
two
days
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
With
this
,
she
set
a
pan
on
the
fire
,
and
began
to
prepare
a
poultice
,
the
materials
for
which
she
took
from
a
small
oaken
chest
in
one
corner
of
the
vault
.
<EOS>
Nizza
looked
on
anxiously
,
and
while
they
were
thus
employed
,
a
knock
was
heard
at
the
door
,
and
<EOS>
Chowles
opening
it
,
found
the
piper
and
one
of
the
vergers
.
 
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
is
it
you
,
father
?
"
<EOS>
cried
Nizza
,
rushing
to
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
glad
I
have
found
you
,
"
returned
the
piper
,
"
<EOS>
for
I
began
to
fear
some
misfortune
must
have
befallen
you
.
<EOS>
Missing
you
in
the
morning
,
I
traversed
the
cathedral
in
search
of
you
with
Bell
,
<EOS>
well
knowing
,
if
you
were
in
the
crowd
,
she
would
speedily
discover
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
His
daughter
then
hastily
recounted
what
had
happened
.
<EOS>
When
the
piper
heard
that
she
had
promised
the
piece
of
gold
to
the
plague
-
nurse
,
a
cloud
came
over
his
open
countenance
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
must
never
part
with
it
,
"
he
said--"never
.
<EOS>
It
is
an
amulet
,
and
if
you
lose
it
,
or
give
it
away
,
your
good
luck
will
go
with
it
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Judith
Malmayns
says
she
has
seen
it
before
,
"
rejoined
Nizza
.
 
<EOS>
"
No
such
thing
,
"
cried
the
piper
hastily
,
"
she
knows
nothing
about
it
.
<EOS>
But
come
with
me
.
<EOS>
You
must
not
stay
here
longer
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
But
,
father
--
dear
father!--I
want
a
small
sum
to
pay
the
nurse
for
attending
this
poor
young
man
,
"
cried
Nizza
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
no
money
,
"
replied
the
piper
;
"
and
if
I
had
,
I
should
not
throw
it
away
in
so
silly
a
manner
.
<EOS>
Come
along
;
I
shall
begin
think
you
are
in
love
with
the
youth
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Then
you
will
not
be
far
wide
of
the
mark
,
"
observed
Judith
,
coarsely
.
 
<EOS>
The
piper
uttered
an
angry
exclamation
,
and
taking
his
daughter
's
hand
,
dragged
her
out
of
the
vault
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
will
not
get
your
fee
,
"
laughed
Chowles
,
as
they
were
left
alone
.
 
<EOS>
"
So
it
appears
,
"
replied
Judith
,
taking
the
pan
from
the
fire
;
"
there
is
no
use
in
wasting
a
poultice
.
"
 
<EOS>
Shortly
after
this
,
the
door
of
the
vault
again
opened
,
and
Parravicin
looked
in
.
<EOS>
He
held
a
handkerchief
sprinkled
with
vinegar
to
his
face
,
and
had
evidently
,
from
the
manner
in
which
he
spoke
,
some
antidote
against
the
plague
in
his
mouth
.
 
<EOS>
"
Nizza
Macascree
has
been
here
,
has
she
not
?
"
<EOS>
he
asked
.
 
<EOS>
"
She
has
just
left
with
her
father
,
"
replied
Judith
.
 
<EOS>
Parravicin
beckoned
her
to
follow
him
,
and
led
the
way
to
the
north
aisle
of
Saint
Faith
's
.
 
<EOS>
"
Is
the
apprentice
likely
to
recover
?
"
he
asked
.
 
<EOS>
"
Humph
!
"
<EOS>
exclaimed
Judith
;
"
that
depends
upon
circumstances
.
<EOS>
Nizza
Macascree
offered
me
a
large
reward
to
cure
him
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Is
he
any
connexion
of
hers
?
"
asked
the
knight
,
sharply
.
 
<EOS>
"
None
whatever
,
"
returned
Judith
,
with
a
significant
smile
.
<EOS>
"
But
he
may
possibly
be
so
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
thought
as
much
,
"
muttered
the
knight
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
never
_
shall
_
recover
,
"
said
Judith
,
halting
,
and
speaking
in
a
low
tone
,
"
if
you
make
it
worth
my
while
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
read
my
wishes
,
"
replied
Parravicin
,
in
a
sombre
tone
.
<EOS>
"
Take
this
purse
,
and
free
me
from
him
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
He
will
never
more
cross
your
path
,
"
replied
Judith
,
eagerly
grasping
the
reward
.
 
<EOS>
"
Enough
!
"
exclaimed
Parravicin
.
<EOS>
"
What
has
passed
between
us
must
be
secret
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
As
the
grave
which
shall
soon
close
over
the
victim
,
"
she
rejoined
.
 
<EOS>
Parravicin
shuddered
,
and
hurried
away
,
while
Judith
returned
at
a
slow
pace
,
and
chinking
the
purse
as
she
went
to
the
vault
.
 
<EOS>
She
had
scarcely
passed
through
the
door
,
when
Nizza
Macascree
appeared
from
behind
one
of
the
massive
pillars
.
<EOS>
"
This
dreadful
crime
must
be
prevented
,
"
she
cried--"but
how
?
<EOS>
If
I
run
to
give
the
alarm
,
it
may
be
executed
,
and
no
one
will
believe
me
.
<EOS>
I
will
try
to
prevent
it
myself
.
"
 
<EOS>
Crossing
the
channel
,
she
was
about
to
enter
the
vault
,
when
Chowles
stepped
forth
.
<EOS>
She
shrank
backwards
,
and
allowed
him
to
pass
,
and
then
trying
the
door
,
found
it
unfastened
.
  
<EOS>
IX
.
 
<EOS>
HOW
LEONARD
WAS
CURED
OF
THE
PLAGUE
.
 
<EOS>
Nizza
Macascree
found
Judith
leaning
over
her
intended
victim
,
and
examining
the
plague
-
spot
on
his
breast
.
<EOS>
The
nurse
was
so
occupied
by
her
task
that
she
did
not
hear
the
door
open
,
and
it
was
not
until
the
piper
's
daughter
was
close
beside
her
,
that
she
was
aware
of
her
presence
.
<EOS>
Hastily
drawing
the
blankets
over
the
apprentice
,
she
then
turned
,
and
regarded
Nizza
with
a
half
-
fearful
,
half
-
menacing
look
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
brings
you
here
again
?
<EOS>
"
she
inquired
,
sharply
.
 
<EOS>
"
Ask
your
own
heart
,
and
it
will
tell
you
,
"
rejoined
Nizza
,
boldly
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
come
to
preserve
the
life
of
this
poor
youth
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
If
you
think
you
can
nurse
him
better
than
I
can
,
you
can
take
my
place
and
welcome
,
"
returned
Judith
,
affecting
not
to
understand
her
;
"
I
have
plenty
of
other
business
to
attend
to
,
and
should
be
glad
to
be
released
from
the
trouble
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Can
she
already
have
effected
her
fell
purpose
?
"
<EOS>
thought
Nizza
,
gazing
at
the
apprentice
,
whose
perturbed
features
proclaimed
that
his
slumber
procured
him
no
rest
from
suffering
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
--
no
--
she
has
not
had
time
.
<EOS>
I
accept
your
offer
,
"
she
added
,
aloud
.
 
<EOS>
"
But
what
will
your
father
say
to
this
arrangement
?
"
asked
Judith
.
 
<EOS>
"
When
he
knows
my
motive
,
he
will
not
blame
me
,
"
answered
Nizza
.
<EOS>
"
Here
I
take
my
place
,
"
she
continued
,
seating
herself
,
"
and
will
not
quit
it
till
he
is
out
of
danger
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Your
love
for
this
youth
borders
upon
insanity
,
"
cried
Judith
,
angrily
.
<EOS>
"
You
shall
not
destroy
yourself
thus
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Neither
shall
you
destroy
him
,
"
retorted
Nizza
.
<EOS>
"
It
is
to
prevent
the
commission
of
the
crime
you
meditate
,
and
for
which
you
have
been
_
paid
_
,
that
I
am
determined
to
remain
with
him
.
"
 
<EOS>
As
she
said
this
,
a
singular
and
frightful
change
took
place
in
the
nurse
's
appearance
.
<EOS>
A
slight
expression
of
alarm
was
at
first
visible
,
but
it
was
instantly
succeeded
by
a
look
so
savage
and
vindictive
,
that
Nizza
almost
repented
having
provoked
the
ire
of
so
unscrupulous
a
person
.
<EOS>
But
summoning
up
all
her
resolution
,
she
returned
Judith
's
glance
with
one
as
stern
and
steady
,
if
not
so
malignant
as
her
own
.
<EOS>
A
deep
silence
prevailed
for
a
few
minutes
,
during
which
each
fancied
she
could
read
the
other
's
thoughts
.
<EOS>
In
Nizza
's
opinion
,
the
nurse
was
revolving
some
desperate
expedient
,
and
she
kept
on
her
guard
,
lest
an
attack
should
be
made
upon
her
life
.
<EOS>
And
some
such
design
did
,
in
reality
,
cross
Judith
;
but
abandoning
it
as
soon
as
formed
,
she
resolved
to
have
recourse
to
more
secret
,
but
not
less
certain
measures
.
 
<EOS>
"
Well
,
"
she
said
,
breaking
silence
,
"
since
you
are
determined
to
have
your
own
way
,
and
catch
the
plague
,
and
most
likely
perish
from
it
,
I
shall
not
try
to
hinder
you
.
<EOS>
Do
what
you
please
,
and
see
what
will
come
of
it
.
"
 
<EOS>
And
she
made
as
if
about
to
depart
;
but
finding
Nizza
did
not
attempt
to
stop
her
,
she
halted
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
can
not
leave
you
thus
,
"
she
continued
;
"
if
you
_
will
_
remain
,
take
this
ointment
,
"
producing
a
small
jar
,
"
and
rub
the
plague
-
spot
with
it
.
<EOS>
It
is
a
sovereign
remedy
,
and
will
certainly
effect
a
cure
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
will
not
touch
it
,
"
returned
Nizza
.
 
<EOS>
"
His
death
,
then
,
be
upon
your
head
,
"
rejoined
Judith
,
quitting
the
vault
,
and
closing
the
door
after
her
.
 
<EOS>
Greatly
relieved
by
her
departure
,
Nizza
began
to
consider
what
she
should
do
,
and
whether
it
would
be
possible
to
remove
the
apprentice
to
some
safer
place
.
"
<EOS>
While
occupied
with
these
reflections
,
the
object
of
her
solicitude
heaved
a
deep
sigh
,
and
opening
his
eyes
,
fixed
them
upon
her
.
<EOS>
It
was
evident
,
however
,
that
he
did
not
know
her
,
but
as
far
as
could
be
gathered
from
his
ravings
,
mistook
her
for
Amabel
.
<EOS>
By
degrees
he
grew
calmer
,
and
the
throbbing
anguish
of
the
tumour
in
some
measure
subsiding
,
his
faculties
returned
to
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
Where
am
I
?
"
<EOS>
he
exclaimed
,
pressing
his
hand
forcibly
to
his
brow
,
"
and
what
is
the
matter
with
me
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
are
in
a
vault
,
near
Saint
Faith
's
,
"
replied
Nizza
,
"
and
--
<EOS>
I
will
not
deceive
you
--
the
disorder
you
are
labouring
under
is
the
plague
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
The
plague
!
<EOS>
"
echoed
Leonard
,
with
a
look
of
horror
.
"
<EOS>
Ah
!
<EOS>
now
I
recollect
.
<EOS>
I
was
attacked
immediately
after
Amabel
's
departure
with
her
father
.
<EOS>
Heaven
be
praised
!
<EOS>
she
is
safe
.
<EOS>
That
is
some
consolation
amid
all
this
misery
.
<EOS>
Could
my
master
behold
me
now
,
he
would
pity
me
,
and
so
perhaps
would
his
daughter
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Heed
her
not
,
"
rejoined
Nizza
,
in
a
slightly
reproachful
tone
,
"
she
does
not
deserve
consideration
.
<EOS>
To
return
to
yourself
.
<EOS>
You
are
not
safe
here
.
<EOS>
Judith
Malmayns
has
been
hired
to
take
away
your
life
.
<EOS>
Are
you
able
to
move
hence
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
hope
so
,
"
replied
Leonard
,
raising
himself
on
his
arm
.
 
<EOS>
"
Wrap
a
blanket
round
you
,
then
,
and
follow
me
,
"
said
Nizza
,
taking
up
the
lamp
and
hastening
to
the
door
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ah
!
"
<EOS>
she
exclaimed
,
with
a
cry
of
anguish--"it
is
locked
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
This
building
is
destined
to
be
my
prison
,
and
that
treacherous
woman
my
gaoler
,
"
groaned
Leonard
,
sinking
backwards
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
not
despair
,
"
cried
Nizza
;
"
I
will
accomplish
your
deliverance
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
So
saying
,
she
tried
,
by
knocking
against
the
door
and
by
loud
outcries
,
to
give
the
alarm
.
<EOS>
But
no
answer
was
returned
,
and
she
soon
became
convinced
that
Judith
had
fastened
the
door
of
the
charnel
,
which
,
it
will
be
remembered
,
lay
between
the
vault
and
the
body
of
Saint
Faith
's
.
<EOS>
Hence
,
no
sound
could
teach
the
outer
structure
.
<EOS>
Disturbed
by
what
had
just
occurred
.
<EOS>
Leonard
's
senses
again
wandered
;
but
,
exerting
all
her
powers
to
tranquillize
him
,
Nizza
at
last
succeeded
so
well
that
he
sunk
into
a
slumber
.
 
<EOS>
Almost
regarding
his
situation
as
hopeless
,
she
took
up
the
lamp
,
and
searching
the
vault
,
found
the
pan
containing
the
half
-
made
poultice
.
<EOS>
The
fire
smouldered
on
the
hearth
,
and
replenishing
it
from
a
scanty
supply
in
one
corner
,
she
heated
the
poultice
and
applied
it
to
the
tumour
.
<EOS>
This
done
,
she
continued
her
search
.
<EOS>
But
though
she
found
several
phials
,
each
bearing
the
name
of
some
remedy
for
the
pestilence
,
her
distrust
of
Judith
would
not
allow
her
to
use
any
of
them
.
<EOS>
Resuming
her
seat
by
the
couch
of
the
sufferer
,
and
worn
out
with
fatigue
and
anxiety
,
she
presently
dropped
asleep
.
 
<EOS>
She
was
awakened
after
awhile
by
a
slight
noise
near
her
,
and
beheld
Judith
bending
over
the
apprentice
,
with
a
pot
of
ointment
in
her
hand
,
which
she
was
about
to
apply
to
the
part
affected
.
<EOS>
The
poultice
had
already
been
removed
.
<EOS>
Uttering
a
loud
cry
,
Nizza
started
to
her
feet
,
and
snatching
the
ointment
from
the
nurse
,
threw
it
away
.
<EOS>
As
soon
as
the
latter
recovered
from
her
surprise
,
she
seized
her
assailant
,
and
forced
her
into
the
seat
she
had
just
quitted
.
 
<EOS>
"
Stir
not
till
I
give
you
permission
,
"
she
cried
,
fiercely
;
"
I
wish
to
cure
this
young
man
,
if
you
will
let
me
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
intend
to
murder
him
,
"
replied
Nizza
;
"
but
while
I
live
you
shall
never
accomplish
your
atrocious
purpose
.
<EOS>
Help
!
<EOS>
help
!
"
<EOS>
And
she
uttered
a
prolonged
piercing
scream
.
 
<EOS>
"
Peace
!
<EOS>
or
I
will
strangle
you
,
"
cried
Judith
,
compressing
Nizza
's
slender
throat
with
a
powerful
gripe
.
 
<EOS>
And
she
would
,
in
all
probability
,
have
executed
her
terrible
threat
,
if
a
secret
door
in
the
wall
had
not
suddenly
opened
and
admitted
Solomon
Eagle
.
<EOS>
A
torch
supplied
the
place
of
his
brazier
,
and
he
held
it
aloft
,
and
threw
its
ruddy
light
upon
the
scene
.
<EOS>
On
seeing
him
,
Judith
relinquished
her
grasp
,
and
glared
at
him
with
a
mixture
of
defiance
and
apprehension
;
while
Nizza
,
half
dead
with
terror
,
instantly
rushed
towards
him
,
and
throwing
herself
at
his
feet
,
besought
him
to
save
her
.
 
<EOS>
"
No
harm
shall
befall
you
,
"
replied
Solomon
Eagle
,
extending
his
arm
over
her
.
"
<EOS>
Tell
me
what
has
happened
.
"
 
<EOS>
Nizza
hastily
explained
the
motive
of
Judith
's
attack
upon
her
life
.
<EOS>
The
plague
-
nurse
endeavoured
to
defend
herself
,
and
,
in
her
turn
,
charged
her
accuser
with
a
like
attempt
.
<EOS>
But
Solomon
Eagle
interrupted
her
.
 
<EOS>
"
Be
silent
,
false
woman
!
"
<EOS>
he
cried
,
"
and
think
not
to
delude
me
with
these
idle
fabrications
.
<EOS>
I
fully
believe
that
you
would
have
taken
the
life
of
this
poor
youth
,
and
,
did
I
not
regard
you
as
one
of
the
necessary
agents
of
Heaven
's
vengeance
,
I
would
instantly
deliver
you
up
to
justice
.
<EOS>
But
the
measure
of
your
iniquities
is
not
yet
filled
up
.
<EOS>
Your
former
crimes
are
not
unknown
to
me
.
<EOS>
Neither
is
the
last
dark
deed
,
which
you
imagined
concealed
from
every
human
eye
,
hidden
from
me
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
know
not
what
you
mean
,
"
returned
Judith
,
trembling
,
in
spite
of
herself
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
will
tell
you
,
then
,
"
rejoined
Solomon
Eagle
,
catching
her
hand
,
and
dragging
her
into
the
furthest
corner
of
the
vault
.
"
<EOS>
Give
ear
to
me
,
"
he
continued
,
in
a
low
voice
,
"
and
doubt
,
if
you
can
,
that
I
have
witnessed
what
I
relate
.
<EOS>
I
saw
you
enter
a
small
chamber
behind
the
vestry
,
in
which
Thomas
Quatremain
,
who
once
filled
the
place
of
minor
canon
in
this
cathedral
,
was
laid
.
<EOS>
No
one
was
there
beside
yourself
and
the
dying
man
.
<EOS>
Your
first
business
was
to
search
his
vestments
,
and
take
away
his
keys
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Ha
!
"
exclaimed
Judith
,
starting
.
 
<EOS>
"
While
securing
his
keys
,
"
pursued
Solomon
Eagle
,
"
the
owner
awakened
,
and
uttered
a
low
,
but
angry
remonstrance
.
<EOS>
Better
he
had
been
silent
.
<EOS>
Dipping
a
napkin
in
an
ewer
of
water
that
stood
beside
him
,
you
held
the
wet
cloth
over
his
face
,
and
did
not
remove
it
till
life
was
extinct
.
<EOS>
All
this
I
saw
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
But
you
will
not
reveal
it
,
"
said
Judith
,
tremblingly
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
will
not
,
"
replied
Solomon
Eagle
,
"
for
the
reasons
I
have
just
stated
;
namely
,
that
I
look
upon
you
as
one
of
the
scourges
appointed
by
Heaven
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
And
so
I
am
,
"
rejoined
Judith
,
with
impious
exultation
;
"
it
is
my
mission
to
destroy
and
pillage
,
and
I
will
fulfil
it
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Take
heed
you
do
not
exceed
it
,
"
replied
Solomon
Eagle
.
<EOS>
"
Lift
a
finger
against
either
of
these
young
persons
,
and
I
will
reveal
all
.
<EOS>
Yes
,
"
he
continued
,
menacingly
,
"
I
will
disclose
such
dreadful
things
against
you
,
that
you
will
assuredly
be
adjudged
to
a
gibbet
higher
than
the
highest
tower
of
this
proud
fane
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
defy
you
,
wretch
!
"
<EOS>
retorted
Judith
.
<EOS>
"
You
can
prove
nothing
against
me
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Defy
me?--ha
!
<EOS>
"
cried
Solomon
Eagle
,
with
a
terrible
laugh
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
First
,
"
he
added
,
dashing
her
backwards
against
the
wall--"first
,
to
prove
my
power
.
<EOS>
Next
,
"
he
continued
,
drawing
from
her
pockets
a
bunch
of
keys
,
"
to
show
that
I
speak
the
truth
.
<EOS>
These
were
taken
from
the
vest
of
the
murdered
man
.
<EOS>
No
one
,
as
yet
,
but
ourselves
,
knows
that
he
is
dead
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
And
who
shall
say
which
of
the
two
is
the
murderer
?
"
cried
Judith
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Villain
!
<EOS>
I
charge
you
with
the
deed
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
are
,
indeed
,
well
fitted
for
your
appointed
task
,
"
returned
Solomon
Eagle
,
gazing
at
her
with
astonishment
,
"
for
sometimes
Heaven
,
for
its
own
wise
purpose
,
will
allow
the
children
of
hell
to
execute
its
vengeance
upon
earth
.
<EOS>
But
think
not
you
will
always
thus
escape
.
<EOS>
No
,
you
may
pursue
your
evil
course
for
a
while
--
you
,
and
your
companion
in
crime
;
but
a
day
of
retribution
will
arrive
for
both
--
a
day
when
ye
shall
be
devoured
,
living
,
by
flames
of
fire
--
when
all
your
sins
shall
arise
before
your
eyes
,
and
ye
shall
have
no
time
for
repentance
--
and
when
ye
shall
pass
from
one
fierce
fire
to
another
yet
fiercer
,
and
wholly
unquenchable
!
"
 
<EOS>
As
he
concluded
,
he
again
dashed
her
against
the
wall
with
such
violence
that
she
fell
senseless
upon
the
ground
.
 
<EOS>
"
And
now
,
"
he
said
,
turning
to
Nizza
Macascree
,
who
looked
on
in
alarm
and
surprise
,
"
what
can
I
do
for
you
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
Bear
this
youth
to
a
place
of
safety
,
"
was
her
answer
.
 
<EOS>
Solomon
Eagle
answered
by
lifting
up
the
pallet
upon
which
Leonard
was
laid
,
with
as
much
ease
as
if
it
had
been
an
infant
's
cradle
,
and
calling
on
Nizza
to
bring
the
torch
,
passed
with
his
burden
through
the
secret
door
.
<EOS>
Directing
her
to
close
it
after
them
,
he
took
his
way
alone
a
narrow
stone
passage
,
until
he
came
to
a
chink
in
the
wall
commanding
a
small
chamber
,
and
desired
her
to
look
through
it
.
<EOS>
She
obeyed
,
and
beheld
,
stretched
upon
a
couch
,
the
corpse
of
a
man
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
Mr.
Quatremain
,
the
minor
canon
,
"
she
said
,
retiring
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
,
"
returned
Solomon
Eagle
,
"
and
it
will
be
supposed
that
he
died
of
the
plague
.
<EOS>
But
his
end
was
accelerated
by
Judith
Malmayns
.
"
 
<EOS>
Without
allowing
her
time
for
reply
,
he
pursued
his
course
,
traversing
another
long
,
narrow
passage
.
 
<EOS>
"
Where
are
we
?
"
<EOS>
asked
Nizza
,
as
they
arrived
at
the
foot
of
a
spiral
stone
staircase
.
 
<EOS>
"
Beneath
the
central
tower
of
the
cathedral
,
"
replied
Solomon
Eagle
.
<EOS>
"
I
will
take
you
to
a
cell
known
only
to
myself
,
where
this
youth
will
be
in
perfect
safety
.
"
 
<EOS>
Ascending
the
staircase
,
they
passed
through
an
arched
door
,
and
entered
the
great
northern
ambulatory
.
<EOS>
Nizza
gazed
down
for
a
moment
into
the
nave
,
but
all
was
buried
in
darkness
,
and
no
sound
reached
her
to
give
her
an
idea
that
any
one
was
below
.
<EOS>
Proceeding
towards
the
west
,
Solomon
Eagle
arrived
at
a
small
recess
in
the
wall
opposite
one
of
the
broad
-
arched
openings
looking
into
the
nave
,
and
entering
it
,
pressed
against
a
spring
at
the
further
extremity
,
and
a
stone
door
flying
open
,
discovered
a
secret
cell
,
on
the
floor
of
which
his
brazier
was
burning
.
<EOS>
Depositing
his
burden
on
the
floor
,
he
said
to
Nizza
,
"
He
is
now
safe
.
<EOS>
Go
in
search
of
proper
assistance
,
and
I
will
watch
by
him
till
you
return
.
"
 
<EOS>
Nizza
did
not
require
a
second
exhortation
,
but
quitting
the
cell
,
and
noticing
its
situation
,
swiftly
descended
the
winding
staircase
,
and
hurrying
along
the
northern
aisle
,
proceeded
to
a
small
chamber
beneath
the
tower
at
its
western
extremity
,
which
she
knew
was
occupied
by
one
of
the
vergers
.
<EOS>
Speedily
arousing
him
,
she
told
him
her
errand
,
and
implored
him
to
remain
on
the
watch
till
she
returned
with
Doctor
Hodges
.
<EOS>
The
verger
promised
compliance
;
and
,
opening
a
wicket
in
the
great
doorway
,
allowed
her
to
go
forth
.
<EOS>
A
few
seconds
brought
her
to
the
doctor
's
dwelling
,
and
though
it
was
an
hour
after
midnight
,
her
summons
was
promptly
answered
by
the
old
porter
,
who
conveyed
her
message
to
his
master
.
<EOS>
Doctor
Hodges
had
just
retired
to
rest
;
but
,
on
learning
in
whose
behalf
his
services
were
required
,
he
sprang
out
of
bed
,
and
hastily
slipped
on
his
clothes
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
would
not
,
for
half
I
am
worth
,
that
that
poor
youth
should
perish
,
"
he
cried
.
<EOS>
"
I
take
a
great
interest
in
him
--
a
very
great
interest
.
<EOS>
He
must
not
be
neglected
.
<EOS>
How
comes
he
at
Saint
Paul
's
,
I
wonder
?
<EOS>
But
I
can
obtain
information
on
that
point
as
I
go
thither
.
<EOS>
No
time
must
be
lost
.
"
 
<EOS>
Ruminating
thus
,
he
swallowed
a
glass
of
sack
,
and
providing
himself
with
a
case
of
instruments
,
and
such
medicines
as
he
thought
he
might
require
,
he
descended
to
Nizza
.
<EOS>
On
the
way
to
the
cathedral
,
she
acquainted
him
with
what
had
befallen
Leonard
during
the
last
four
-
and
-
twenty
hours
,
and
the
only
circumstance
that
she
kept
back
was
Judith
's
attempt
on
his
life
.
<EOS>
This
she
intended
to
reveal
at
a
more
fitting
opportunity
.
<EOS>
The
doctor
expressed
somewhat
emphatically
his
disapproval
of
the
conduct
of
Mr.
Bloundel
,
but
promised
to
set
all
to
rights
without
loss
of
time
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
only
difficulty
I
foresee
,
"
he
observed
,
"
is
that
the
poor
youth
is
attacked
by
the
pestilence
;
and
though
I
may
succeed
in
curing
him
,
his
master
will
probably
have
shut
up
his
house
before
I
can
accomplish
my
object
,
in
which
case
,
all
chance
of
his
union
with
Amabel
will
be
at
an
end
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
So
much
the
better
,
"
rejoined
Nizza
,
sharply
;
"
she
does
not
deserve
him
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
There
I
agree
with
you
,
"
returned
Hodges
.
<EOS>
"
But
could
you
point
out
any
one
who
does
?
"
<EOS>
he
added
,
with
a
slight
but
significant
laugh
.
 
<EOS>
No
answer
was
returned
;
and
as
they
had
just
reached
the
portico
of
the
cathedral
,
they
entered
the
sacred
structure
in
silence
.
 
<EOS>
As
they
ascended
the
winding
stairs
,
loud
outcries
resounded
along
the
ambulatory
,
and
echoed
by
the
vaulted
roof
of
the
nave
,
convinced
them
that
the
sufferer
was
again
in
a
state
of
frenzy
,
produced
by
fever
and
the
anguish
of
his
sore
;
and
on
reaching
the
cell
they
found
him
struggling
violently
with
Solomon
Eagle
,
who
held
him
down
by
main
force
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
is
in
a
fearfully
excited
state
,
truly
,
"
observed
Hodges
,
as
he
drew
near
,
"
and
must
not
be
left
for
a
moment
,
or
he
will
do
himself
a
mischief
.
<EOS>
I
must
give
him
a
draught
to
allay
the
fever
,
and
compose
his
nerves
--
for
in
this
state
<EOS>
I
dare
not
have
recourse
to
the
lancet
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
With
this
he
dressed
the
tumour
;
and
pouring
the
contents
of
a
large
phial
which
he
had
brought
with
him
in
a
cup
,
he
held
it
to
the
burning
lips
of
the
apprentice
,
who
eagerly
quaffed
it
.
<EOS>
It
was
soon
apparent
that
the
dose
produced
a
salutary
effect
,
and
a
second
was
administered
.
<EOS>
Still
the
sufferer
,
though
calmer
,
continued
to
ramble
as
before
--
complained
that
his
veins
were
filled
with
molten
lead
--
entreated
them
to
plunge
him
in
a
stream
,
so
that
he
might
cool
his
intolerable
thirst
,
and
appeared
to
be
in
great
agony
.
<EOS>
Doctor
Hodges
watched
by
him
till
daybreak
,
at
which
time
he
sank
into
a
slumber
;
and
Solomon
Eagle
,
who
had
never
till
then
relinquished
his
hold
of
him
,
now
ventured
to
resign
his
post
.
<EOS>
The
doctor
was
then
about
to
depart
;
but
at
the
urgent
solicitation
of
Nizza
,
who
had
stationed
herself
at
the
door
of
the
cell
,
he
agreed
to
remain
a
little
longer
.
 
<EOS>
Two
hours
after
this
,
the
doors
of
the
cathedral
were
opened
,
and
a
large
crowd
soon
assembled
within
the
nave
,
as
on
the
preceding
day
.
<EOS>
The
tumult
of
voices
reached
the
cell
and
awakened
the
sleeper
.
<EOS>
Before
he
could
be
prevented
he
started
from
his
bed
,
and
dashing
aside
the
feeble
opposition
offered
by
Nizza
and
the
doctor
,
ran
along
the
ambulatory
,
uttering
a
loud
and
fearful
cry
.
<EOS>
Finding
the
door
of
the
winding
staircase
open
,
he
darted
through
it
,
and
in
a
few
seconds
reappeared
in
the
aisle
.
<EOS>
Hearing
the
cries
,
several
persons
rushed
to
meet
him
;
but
on
beholding
his
haggard
looks
and
strange
appearance
--
he
was
merely
wrapped
in
a
blanket,--they
instantly
recoiled
.
<EOS>
Mean
-
time
,
Doctor
Hodges
,
who
had
run
to
one
of
the
arched
openings
looking
on
the
nave
,
called
out
to
them
to
secure
the
fugitive
.
<EOS>
But
all
fled
at
his
approach
;
and
when
he
reached
the
door
of
the
southern
transept
,
the
verger
,
instead
of
attempting
to
stop
him
,
retreated
with
a
cry
of
alarm
.
<EOS>
As
he
passed
through
the
outlet
,
one
man
bolder
than
the
rest
caught
hold
of
him
,
and
endeavoured
to
detain
him
.
<EOS>
But
,
leaving
the
blanket
in
his
hands
,
and
without
other
covering
than
his
shirt
,
the
apprentice
dashed
across
the
churchyard
--
next
shaped
his
course
down
Saint
Bennet's
-
hill
--
then
crossed
<EOS>
Thames
-
street,--and
finally
speeding
along
another
narrow
thoroughfare
,
reached
Paul
's
Wharf
.
<EOS>
Gazing
for
a
moment
at
the
current
sweeping
past
him
--
it
was
high
-
tide,--he
plunged
head
foremost
into
it
from
the
high
embankment
,
and
on
rising
to
the
surface
,
being
a
strong
and
expert
swimmer
,
struck
out
for
the
opposite
shore
.
<EOS>
Those
who
beheld
him
were
filled
with
amazement
;
but
such
was
the
alarm
occasioned
by
his
appearance
,
that
none
ventured
to
interfere
with
him
.
<EOS>
He
had
not
crossed
more
than
a
fourth
part
of
the
stream
when
Doctor
Hodges
arrived
at
the
wharf
;
but
neither
promises
of
reward
nor
threats
could
induce
any
of
the
watermen
to
follow
him
.
<EOS>
The
humane
physician
would
have
sprung
into
a
boat
,
but
feeling
he
should
be
wholly
unable
to
manage
it
,
he
most
reluctantly
abandoned
his
purpose
.
<EOS>
Scarcely
doubting
what
the
result
of
this
rash
attempt
would
be
,
and
yet
unable
to
tear
himself
away
,
he
lingered
on
the
wharf
till
he
saw
Leonard
reach
the
opposite
bank
,
where
an
attempt
was
made
by
a
party
of
persons
to
seize
him
.
<EOS>
But
instead
of
quietly
surrendering
himself
,
the
apprentice
instantly
leapt
into
the
river
again
,
and
began
to
swim
back
towards
the
point
whence
he
had
started
.
<EOS>
Amazed
at
what
he
saw
,
the
doctor
ordered
his
servant
,
who
by
this
time
had
joined
the
group
,
to
bring
a
blanket
,
and
descending
to
the
edge
of
the
river
,
awaited
the
swimmer
's
arrival
.
<EOS>
In
less
than
ten
minutes
he
had
reached
the
shore
,
and
clambering
on
the
bank
,
fell
from
exhaustion
.
 
<EOS>
"
This
is
a
violent
effort
of
nature
,
which
has
accomplished
more
than
science
or
skill
could
do
,
"
said
Hodges
,
as
he
gazed
on
the
body
,
and
saw
that
the
pestilential
tumour
had
wholly
disappeared--"he
is
completely
cured
of
the
plague
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
And
throwing
the
blanket
over
him
,
he
ordered
him
to
be
conveyed
to
his
own
house
.
  
<EOS>
X.
 
<EOS>
THE
PEST
-
HOUSE
IN
FINSBURY
FIELDS
.
 
<EOS>
Not
a
word
passed
between
the
grocer
and
his
daughter
,
as
he
took
her
home
from
Saint
Paul
's
.
<EOS>
Amabel
,
in
fact
,
was
so
overpowered
by
conflicting
emotions
that
she
could
not
speak
;
while
her
father
,
who
could
not
help
reproaching
himself
for
the
harshness
he
had
displayed
towards
Leonard
Holt
,
felt
no
disposition
to
break
silence
.
<EOS>
They
found
Mrs.
Bloundel
at
the
shop
-
door
,
drowned
in
tears
,
and
almost
in
a
state
of
distraction
.
<EOS>
On
seeing
them
,
she
rushed
towards
her
daughter
,
and
straining
her
to
her
bosom
,
gave
free
vent
to
the
impulses
of
her
affection
.
<EOS>
Allowing
the
first
transports
of
joy
to
subside
,
Mr.
Bloundel
begged
,
her
to
retire
to
her
own
room
with
Amabel
,
and
not
to
leave
it
till
they
had
both
regained
their
composure
,
when
he
wished
to
have
some
serious
conversation
with
them
.
 
<EOS>
His
request
complied
with
,
the
grocer
then
retraced
his
steps
to
the
cathedral
with
the
intention
of
seeking
an
explanation
from
Leonard
,
and
,
if
he
saw
occasion
to
do
so
,
of
revoking
his
severe
mandate
.
<EOS>
But
long
before
he
reached
the
southern
transept
,
the
apprentice
had
disappeared
,
nor
could
he
learn
what
had
become
of
him
.
<EOS>
While
anxiously
pursuing
his
search
among
the
crowd
,
and
addressing
inquiries
to
all
whom
he
thought
likely
to
afford
him
information
,
he
perceived
a
man
pushing
his
way
towards
him
.
<EOS>
As
this
person
drew
near
,
he
recognised
Pillichody
,
and
would
have
got
out
of
his
way
<EOS>
had
it
been
possible
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
are
looking
for
your
apprentice
,
I
understand
,
Mr.
Bloundel
,
"
said
the
bully
,
raising
his
hat--"if
you
desire
,
it
<EOS>
,
I
will
lead
you
to
him
.
"
 
<EOS>
Unwilling
as
he
was
to
be
obliged
to
one
whom
he
knew
to
be
leagued
with
the
Earl
of
Rochester
,
the
grocer
's
anxiety
overcame
his
scruples
,
and
,
signifying
his
acquiescence
,
Pillichody
shouldered
his
way
through
the
crowd
,
and
did
not
stop
till
they
reached
the
northern
aisle
,
where
they
were
comparatively
alone
.
 
<EOS>
"
Your
apprentice
is
a
fortunate
spark
,
Mr.
Bloundel
,
"
he
said
.
<EOS>
"
No
sooner
does
he
lose
one
mistress
than
he
finds
another
.
<EOS>
Tour
daughter
is
already
forgotten
,
and
he
is
at
this
moment
enjoying
a
tender
_
tête
-
à
-
tête
_
in
Bishop
Kempe
's
chapel
with
Nizza
Macascree
,
the
blind
piper
's
daughter
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
false
,
sir
,
"
replied
the
grocer
,
incredulously
.
 
<EOS>
"
Unbelieving
dog
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Pillichody
,
in
a
furious
tone
,
and
clapping
his
hand
upon
his
sword
<EOS>
,
"
it
is
fortunate
for
you
that
the
disparity
of
our
stations
prevents
me
from
compelling
you
to
yield
me
satisfaction
for
the
insult
you
have
offered
me
.
<EOS>
But
I
caution
you
to
keep
better
guard
upon
your
tongue
for
the
future
,
especially
when
addressing
one
who
has
earned
his
laurels
under
King
Charles
the
Martyr
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
no
especial
reverence
for
the
monarch
you
served
under
,
"
replied
Bloundel
;
"
but
he
would
have
blushed
to
own
such
a
follower
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
may
thank
my
generosity
that
I
do
not
crop
your
ears
,
base
Roundhead
,
"
rejoined
Pillichody
;
"
but
I
will
convince
you
that
I
speak
the
truth
,
and
if
you
have
any
shame
in
your
composition
,
it
will
be
summoned
to
your
cheeks
.
"
 
<EOS>
So
saying
,
he
proceeded
to
Bishop
Kempe
's
chapel
,
the
door
of
which
was
slightly
ajar
,
and
desired
the
grocer
to
look
through
the
chink
.
<EOS>
This
occurred
at
the
precise
time
that
the
apprentice
was
seized
with
sudden
faintness
,
and
was
leaning
for
support
upon
Nizza
Macascree
's
shoulder
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
see
how
lovingly
they
are
seated
together
,
"
observed
Pillichody
,
with
a
smile
of
triumph
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Bowers
of
Paphos
!
<EOS>
I
would
I
were
as
near
the
rich
widow
of
Watling
-
street
.
<EOS>
Will
you
speak
with
him
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
replied
Bloundel
,
turning
away
;
"
I
have
done
with
him
for
ever
.
<EOS>
I
have
been
greatly
deceived
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
True
,
"
chuckled
Pillichody
,
as
soon
as
the
grocer
was
out
of
hearing
;
"
but
not
by
your
apprentice
,
Mr.
Bloundel
.
<EOS>
I
will
go
and
inform
Parravicin
and
Rochester
that
I
have
discovered
the
girl
.
<EOS>
The
knight
must
mind
what
he
is
about
,
or
Leonard
Holt
will
prove
too
much
for
him
.
<EOS>
Either
I
am
greatly
out
,
or
the
apprentice
is
already
master
of
Nizza
's
heart
.
"
 
<EOS>
To
return
to
Amabel
.
<EOS>
As
soon
as
she
was
alone
with
her
mother
,
she
threw
herself
on
her
knees
before
her
,
and
,
imploring
her
forgiveness
,
hastily
related
all
that
had
occurred
.
 
<EOS>
"
But
for
Leonard
Holt
,
"
she
said
,
"
I
should
have
been
duped
into
a
false
marriage
with
the
earl
,
and
my
peace
of
mind
would
have
been
for
ever
destroyed
.
<EOS>
As
it
is
,
I
shall
never
be
easy
till
he
is
restored
to
my
father
's
favour
.
<EOS>
To
have
done
wrong
myself
is
reprehensible
enough
;
but
that
another
should
suffer
for
my
fault
is
utterly
inexcusable
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
lament
that
your
father
should
be
deceived
,
"
rejoined
Mrs.
Bloundel
,
"
and
I
lament
still
more
that
Leonard
Holt
should
be
so
unjustly
treated
.
<EOS>
Nevertheless
,
we
must
act
with
the
utmost
caution
.
<EOS>
I
know
my
husband
too
well
to
doubt
for
a
moment
that
he
will
hesitate
to
fulfil
his
threat
.
<EOS>
And
now
,
my
dear
child
,
"
she
continued
,
"
do
not
the
repeated
proofs
you
have
received
of
this
wicked
nobleman
's
perfidy
,
and
of
Leonard
's
devotion
--
do
they
not
,
I
say
,
open
your
eyes
to
the
truth
,
and
show
you
which
of
the
two
really
loves
you
,
and
merits
your
regard
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
will
hide
nothing
from
you
,
mother
,
"
replied
Amabel
.
"
<EOS>
In
spite
of
his
perfidy
,
in
spite
of
my
conviction
of
his
unworthiness
,
I
still
love
the
Earl
of
Rochester
.
<EOS>
Nor
can
I
compel
myself
to
feel
any
regard
,
stronger
than
that
of
friendship
,
for
Leonard
Holt
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
distress
me
,
sadly
,
child
,
"
cried
Mrs.
Bloundel
.
<EOS>
"
What
will
become
of
you
!
<EOS>
I
wish
my
husband
would
shut
up
his
house
.
<EOS>
That
might
put
an
end
to
the
difficulty
.
<EOS>
I
am
not
half
so
much
afraid
of
the
plague
as
I
am
of
the
Earl
of
Rochester
.
<EOS>
But
compose
yourself
,
as
your
father
desired
,
that
when
he
sends
for
us
we
may
be
ready
to
meet
him
with
cheerfulness
.
"
 
<EOS>
Mr.
Bloundel
,
however
,
did
_
not
_
send
for
them
.
<EOS>
He
remained
in
the
shop
all
day
,
except
at
meal
-
times
,
when
he
said
little
,
and
appeared
to
be
labouring
under
a
great
weight
of
anxiety
.
<EOS>
As
Amabel
took
leave
of
him
for
the
night
,
he
dismissed
her
with
coldness
;
and
though
he
bestowed
his
customary
blessing
upon
her
,
the
look
that
accompanied
it
was
not
such
as
it
used
to
be
.
 
<EOS>
On
the
following
day
things
continued
in
the
same
state
.
<EOS>
The
grocer
was
cold
and
inscrutable
,
and
his
wife
,
fearing
he
was
meditating
some
severe
course
against
Amabel
,
and
aware
of
his
inflexible
nature
,
if
a
resolution
was
once
formed
,
shook
off
her
habitual
awe
,
and
thus
addressed
him
:
 
<EOS>
"
I
fear
you
have
not
forgiven
our
daughter
.
<EOS>
Be
not
too
hasty
in
your
judgment
.
<EOS>
However
culpable
she
may
appear
,
she
has
been
as
much
deceived
as
yourself
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
may
be
so
,
"
replied
Bloundel
.
<EOS>
"
Still
she
has
acted
with
such
indiscretion
that
I
can
never
place
confidence
in
her
again
,
and
without
confidence
affection
is
as
nought
.
<EOS>
Can
I
say
to
him
who
may
seek
her
in
marriage
,
and
whom
I
may
approve
as
a
husband,--'Take
her
!
<EOS>
she
has
never
deceived
me
,
and
will
never
deceive
you
?
'
<EOS>
No
.
<EOS>
She
_
has
<EOS>
_
deceived
me
,
and
will
,
therefore
,
deceive
others
.
<EOS>
I
do
not
know
the
precise
truth
of
the
story
of
her
abduction
(
if
such
it
was
)
by
Leonard
Holt
,
neither
<EOS>
do
I
wish
to
know
it
,
because
I
might
be
compelled
to
act
with
greater
severity
than
I
desire
towards
her
.
<EOS>
But
I
know
enough
to
satisfy
me
<EOS>
she
has
been
excessively
imprudent
,
and
has
placed
herself
voluntarily
in
situations
of
the
utmost
jeopardy
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Not
voluntarily
,
"
returned
Mrs.
Bloundel
.
<EOS>
"
She
has
been
lured
into
difficulties
by
others
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
No
more
!
<EOS>
"
interrupted
the
grocer
,
sternly
.
<EOS>
"
If
you
wish
to
serve
her
,
keep
guard
upon
your
tongue
.
<EOS>
If
you
have
any
preparations
to
make
,
they
must
not
be
delayed
.
<EOS>
I
shall
shut
up
my
house
to
-
morrow
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Whether
Leonard
returns
or
not
?
"
asked
Mrs.
Bloundel
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
shall
wait
for
no
one
,
"
returned
her
husband
,
peremptorily
.
 
<EOS>
They
then
separated
,
and
Mrs.
Bloundel
hastened
to
her
daughter
to
acquaint
her
with
the
result
of
the
interview
.
 
<EOS>
In
the
afternoon
of
the
same
day
,
the
grocer
,
who
began
to
feel
extremely
uneasy
about
Leonard
,
again
repaired
to
Saint
Paul
's
to
see
whether
he
could
obtain
any
tidings
of
him
,
and
learnt
,
to
his
great
dismay
,
from
one
of
the
vergers
,
that
a
young
man
,
answering
to
the
description
of
the
apprentice
,
had
been
attacked
by
the
pestilence
,
and
having
been
taken
to
the
vaults
of
Saint
Faith
's
,
had
made
his
escape
from
his
attendants
,
and
,
it
was
supposed
,
had
perished
.
<EOS>
Horror
-
stricken
by
this
intelligence
,
he
descended
to
the
subterranean
church
,
where
he
met
Judith
Malmayns
and
Chowles
,
who
confirmed
the
verger
's
statement
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
poor
young
man
,
I
am
informed
,
"
said
Chowles
,
"
threw
himself
into
the
Thames
,
and
was
picked
up
by
a
boat
,
and
afterwards
conveyed
,
in
a
dying
state
,
to
the
pest
-
house
in
Finsbury
Fields
,
where
you
will
probably
find
him
,
if
he
is
still
alive
.
"
 
<EOS>
Mr.
Bloundel
heard
no
more
.
<EOS>
Quitting
the
cathedral
,
he
hastened
to
Finsbury
Fields
,
and
sought
out
the
building
to
which
he
had
been
directed
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
solitary
farm
-
house
,
of
considerable
size
,
surrounded
by
an
extensive
garden
,
and
had
only
been
recently
converted
to
its
present
melancholy
use
.
<EOS>
Near
it
was
a
barn
,
also
fitted
up
with
beds
for
the
sick
.
<EOS>
On
approaching
the
pest
-
house
,
Mr.
Bloundel
was
greatly
struck
with
the
contrast
presented
by
its
exterior
to
the
misery
he
knew
to
be
reigning
within
.
<EOS>
Its
situation
was
charming,--in
the
midst
,
as
has
just
been
stated
,
of
a
large
and
,
until
recently
,
well
-
cultivated
garden
,
and
seen
under
the
influence
of
a
bright
and
genial
May
day
,
the
whole
place
looked
the
picture
of
healthfulness
and
comfort
.
<EOS>
But
a
closer
view
speedily
dispelled
the
illusion
,
and
showed
that
it
was
the
abode
of
disease
and
death
.
<EOS>
Horrid
sounds
saluted
the
ears
;
ghastly
figures
met
the
eyes
;
and
the
fragrance
of
the
flowers
was
overpowered
by
the
tainted
and
noisome
atmosphere
issuing
from
the
open
doors
and
windows
.
<EOS>
The
grocer
had
scarcely
entered
the
gate
when
he
was
arrested
by
an
appalling
shriek
,
followed
by
a
succession
of
cries
so
horrifying
that
he
felt
half
disposed
to
fly
.
<EOS>
But
mustering
up
his
resolution
,
and
breathing
at
a
phial
of
vinegar
,
he
advanced
towards
the
principal
door
,
which
stood
wide
open
,
and
called
to
one
of
the
assistants
.
<EOS>
The
man
,
however
,
was
too
busy
to
attend
to
him
,
and
while
waiting
his
leisure
,
he
saw
no
fewer
than
three
corpses
carried
out
to
an
outbuilding
in
the
yard
,
where
they
were
left
till
they
could
be
taken
away
at
night
for
interment
.
 
<EOS>
Sickened
by
the
sight
,
and
blaming
himself
for
entering
near
this
contagious
spot
,
Mr.
Bloundel
was
about
to
depart
,
when
a
young
chirurgeon
stepped
out
to
him
,
and
,
in
reply
to
his
inquiries
after
Leonard
,
said
:
"
Twelve
persons
were
brought
in
here
last
night
,
and
five
this
morning
,
but
I
do
not
remember
any
of
their
names
.
<EOS>
You
can
go
through
the
rooms
and
search
for
your
apprentice
,
if
you
think
proper
.
"
 
<EOS>
Mr.
Bloundel
hesitated
,
but
his
humanity
overcame
his
apprehension
,
and
murmuring
a
prayer
that
he
might
be
preserved
from
infection
,
he
followed
his
conductor
into
the
house
.
<EOS>
Prepared
as
he
was
for
a
dreadful
spectacle
,
the
reality
far
exceeded
his
anticipations
.
<EOS>
Along
both
sides
of
a
large
room
,
occupying
nearly
the
whole
of
the
ground
-
floor
,
were
rows
of
pallets
,
on
which
were
laid
the
sick
,
many
of
whom
were
tied
down
to
their
couches
.
<EOS>
Almost
all
seemed
in
a
hopeless
state
,
and
the
cadaverous
hue
of
their
countenances
proclaimed
that
death
was
not
far
off
.
<EOS>
Though
the
doors
and
windows
were
open
,
and
the
room
was
filled
with
vapours
and
exhalations
,
arising
from
pans
of
coal
and
plates
of
hot
iron
,
on
which
drugs
were
burning
,
nothing
could
remove
the
putrid
,
and
pestilential
smell
that
pervaded
the
chamber
.
<EOS>
The
thick
vapour
settled
on
the
panes
of
the
windows
,
and
on
the
roof
,
and
fell
to
the
ground
in
heavy
drops
.
<EOS>
Marching
quickly
past
each
bed
,
the
grocer
noted
the
features
of
its
unfortunate
occupant
;
but
though
there
were
many
young
men
,
Leonard
was
not
among
the
number
.
<EOS>
His
conductor
then
led
him
to
an
upper
room
,
where
he
found
the
chirurgeons
dressing
the
sores
of
their
patients
,
most
of
whom
uttered
loud
shrieks
while
under
their
hands
.
<EOS>
Here
an
incident
occurred
which
deeply
affected
the
grocer
.
<EOS>
A
poor
young
woman
,
who
had
been
brought
to
the
pest
-
house
with
her
child
on
the
previous
evening
,
had
just
expired
,
and
the
infant
,
unable
to
obtain
its
customary
nourishment
,
uttered
the
most
piteous
cries
.
<EOS>
It
was
instantly
removed
by
a
nurse
and
proper
food
given
it
;
but
Mr.
Bloundel
was
informed
that
the
plague
-
tokens
had
already
appeared
,
and
that
it
would
not
probably
live
over
the
night
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
no
doubt
,
"
said
the
young
chirurgeon
,
"
it
will
be
buried
with
its
mother
.
"
<EOS>
And
so
it
happened
.
 
<EOS>
The
grocer
turned
away
to
hide
his
emotion
,
and
endeavoured
through
his
blinded
gaze
to
discover
Leonard
,
but
,
as
will
be
anticipated
,
without
success
.
<EOS>
Stunned
by
the
cries
and
groans
that
pierced
his
ears
,
and
almost
stifled
by
the
pestilential
effluvia
,
he
rushed
out
of
the
house
,
and
gladly
accepted
a
glass
of
sack
offered
him
by
his
conductor
,
which
removed
the
dreadful
nausea
that
affected
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
now
remember
that
the
two
last
persons
brought
here
were
taken
to
the
barn
,
"
observed
the
chirurgeon
;
"
I
will
go
with
you
thither
,
if
you
think
proper
.
"
 
<EOS>
The
grocer
assented
,
and
the
chirurgeon
crossed
the
yard
,
and
opened
the
door
of
the
barn
,
on
the
floor
of
which
upwards
of
twenty
beds
were
laid
.
<EOS>
Passing
between
them
,
Mr.
Bloundel
narrowly
scrutinized
every
countenance
;
but
,
to
his
great
relief
,
recognised
no
one
.
<EOS>
One
couch
alone
remained
to
be
examined
.
<EOS>
The
poor
sufferer
within
it
had
drawn
the
coverings
over
his
face
,
and
when
they
were
removed
he
was
found
quite
dead
!
<EOS>
He
was
a
young
man
;
and
the
agony
he
had
endured
in
the
last
struggle
was
shown
by
his
collapsed
frame
and
distorted
features
.
<EOS>
It
was
not
,
however
,
Leonard
;
and
,
so
far
satisfied
,
though
greatly
shocked
,
Mr.
Bloundel
hurried
out
.
 
<EOS>
"
Thank
Heaven
<EOS>
he
is
not
here
!
"
<EOS>
he
exclaimed
to
his
conductor
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
have
not
seen
the
dead
bodies
in
the
outhouse
,
"
returned
the
other
;
"
it
is
possible
his
may
be
among
them
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
trust
not
,
"
rejoined
the
grocer
,
shuddering
;
"
but
as
I
have
gone
thus
far
,
I
will
not
leave
my
errand
unaccomplished
.
<EOS>
Suffer
me
to
look
at
them
.
"
 
<EOS>
The
chirurgeon
then
led
the
way
to
a
spacious
outbuilding
,
once
used
for
cattle
,
in
the
midst
of
which
stood
a
large
frame
supporting
six
bodies
,
covered
only
with
a
sheet
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Bloundel
could
not
overcome
his
repugnance
to
enter
this
shed
;
but
the
chirurgeon
,
who
appeared
habituated
to
such
scenes
,
and
to
regard
them
lightly
,
threw
off
the
sheet
,
and
raised
the
corpses
,
one
by
one
,
that
he
might
the
better
view
them
.
<EOS>
One
peculiarity
Mr.
Bloundel
noticed
;
<EOS>
namely
,
that
the
limbs
of
these
unfortunate
victims
of
the
pestilence
did
not
stiffen
,
as
would
have
been
the
case
if
they
had
died
of
any
other
disorder
;
while
the
blotches
that
appeared
on
the
livid
flesh
made
them
objects
almost
too
horrible
to
look
upon
.
<EOS>
In
many
cases
the
features
were
frightfully
distorted
--
the
tongues
of
the
poor
wretches
swollen
and
protruding
--
the
hands
clenched
,
and
the
toes
bent
towards
the
soles
of
the
feet
.
<EOS>
Everything
denoted
the
dreadful
pangs
that
must
have
attended
dissolution
.
 
<EOS>
Greatly
relieved
to
find
that
the
whole
of
this
ghastly
group
were
strangers
to
him
,
Mr.
Bloundel
thanked
the
chirurgeon
,
and
departed
.
<EOS>
Convinced
that
he
had
been
deceived
by
the
coffin
-
maker
,
he
now
began
to
hope
that
the
whole
story
was
false
;
but
he
determined
not
to
rest
till
he
had
thoroughly
investigated
the
matter
.
<EOS>
Before
doing
so
,
however
,
he
thought
it
advisable
to
return
home
,
and
accordingly
shaped
his
course
toward
Cripplegate
,
and
,
passing
through
the
postern
,
stopped
at
an
apothecary
's
shop
,
and
got
his
apparel
fumigated
and
sprinkled
with
spirits
of
hartshorn
and
sulphur
.
 
<EOS>
On
reaching
Wood
-
street
,
he
noticed
,
with
some
uneasiness
,
a
number
of
persons
gathered
together
before
his
dwelling
.
<EOS>
His
fears
were
speedily
relieved
by
finding
that
the
assemblage
was
collected
by
a
preacher
,
who
was
pronouncing
an
exhortation
to
them
in
tones
almost
as
loud
and
emphatic
as
those
of
Solomon
Eagle
.
<EOS>
The
preacher
's
appearance
was
very
remarkable
,
and
attracted
the
attention
of
the
grocer
,
who
joined
the
crowd
to
listen
to
him
.
<EOS>
As
far
as
could
be
judged
,
he
was
a
middle
-
aged
man
,
with
black
hair
floating
over
his
shoulders
,
earnest
features
,
and
a
grey
eye
of
extraordinary
brilliancy
.
<EOS>
His
figure
was
slight
and
erect
,
and
his
gestures
as
impassioned
as
his
looks
.
<EOS>
He
spoke
with
great
rapidity
;
and
his
eloquence
,
combined
with
his
fervent
manner
and
expression
,
completely
entranced
his
audience
.
<EOS>
He
was
habited
in
a
cassock
and
bands
,
and
had
taken
off
his
cap
,
which
was
held
by
an
attendant
,
who
stood
near
the
stool
on
which
he
was
mounted
.
<EOS>
The
latter
differed
materially
from
his
master
.
<EOS>
His
closely
-
cropped
hair
,
demure
looks
,
sugar
-
loaf
hat
,
and
suit
of
rusty
sable
,
seemed
to
proclaim
him
a
Puritan
;
but
his
twinkling
eye
--
for
he
had
but
one
,
and
wore
a
black
patch
over
the
orifice
--
his
inflamed
cheeks
,
and
mulberry
nose
contradicted
the
idea
.
 
<EOS>
As
soon
as
the
preacher
distinguished
Mr.
Bloundel
,
he
addressed
his
discourse
to
him
;
and
,
alluding
to
his
religious
habits
and
general
excellence
of
character
,
held
him
up
as
an
example
to
others
.
<EOS>
The
grocer
would
fain
have
retreated
;
but
the
preacher
besought
him
to
stay
,
and
was
proceeding
in
the
same
strain
,
when
a
sudden
interruption
took
place
.
<EOS>
A
slight
disturbance
occurring
amid
the
crowd
,
the
attendant
attempted
to
check
it
,
and
in
doing
so
received
a
sound
buffet
on
the
ears
.
<EOS>
In
endeavouring
to
return
the
blow
,
he
struck
another
party
,
who
instantly
retaliated
,
and
a
general
affray
commenced
--
<EOS>
some
taking
one
side
,
some
the
other
.
<EOS>
In
the
midst
of
the
confusion
three
persons
forced
their
way
towards
the
preacher
,
knocked
him
from
his
stool
,
and
,
assailing
him
with
the
most
opprobrious
epithets
,
dealt
him
several
seemingly
severe
blows
,
and
would
have
further
maltreated
him
,
if
Mr.
Bloundel
had
not
interposed
,
and
,
pushing
aside
his
assailants
,
gave
him
his
hand
,
and
led
him
into
his
dwelling
,
the
door
of
which
he
closed
.
<EOS>
Shortly
afterwards
,
the
crowd
dispersing
,
the
preacher
's
companion
entered
the
shop
in
search
of
his
master
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
hope
you
have
sustained
no
injury
during
this
tumult
,
reverend
and
dear
sir
?
"
<EOS>
he
asked
,
with
great
apparent
solicitude
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
not
much
hurt
,
"
replied
the
preacher
;
"
but
I
have
received
a
blow
on
the
head
,
which
has
stunned
me
.
<EOS>
The
faintness
will
go
off
presently
.
<EOS>
You
were
the
cause
of
this
disturbance
,
Bambolio
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
,
Doctor
Maplebury
?
"
replied
Bambolio
.
<EOS>
"
I
endeavoured
to
stop
it
.
<EOS>
But
your
reverence
looks
extremely
ill
.
<EOS>
I
am
sure
,
sir
,
"
he
added
to
Mr.
Bloundel
,
"
after
the
high
character
my
master
gave
you
in
his
discourse
,
and
which
I
am
persuaded
you
deserve
,
you
will
extend
your
hospitality
towards
him
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Readily
,
"
replied
the
grocer
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Here
,
Blaize
,
assist
the
reverend
gentleman
within
,
and
bid
your
mistress
come
down
stairs
immediately
.
"
 
<EOS>
Doctor
Maplebury
was
then
conveyed
between
the
porter
and
Bambolio
into
the
inner
room
,
where
he
sank
into
a
chair
in
a
complete
state
of
exhaustion
.
<EOS>
The
next
moment
Mrs.
Bloundel
made
her
appearance
with
Amabel
.
<EOS>
The
latter
no
sooner
beheld
the
preacher
,
than
she
started
and
trembled
so
violently
,
that
she
could
scarcely
support
herself
;
but
her
mother
,
who
only
saw
a
fainting
man
,
flew
to
his
assistance
,
and
called
to
Patience
to
bring
restoratives
.
<EOS>
These
applied
,
Doctor
Maplebury
was
soon
able
to
rouse
himself
sufficiently
to
gaze
round
the
room
,
and
fix
his
eyes
on
Amabel
.
 
<EOS>
"
So
our
old
friends
are
here
again
,
"
said
Patience
in
a
low
tone
to
Blaize
,
as
they
left
the
room
together
.
 
<EOS>
"
Old
friends
!
<EOS>
What
do
you
mean
?
"
rejoined
the
porter
.
 
<EOS>
"
Why
,
the
Earl
of
Rochester
and
Major
Pillichody
,
"
replied
Patience
.
<EOS>
"
I
knew
them
at
a
glance
,
and
so
did
Mistress
Amabel
.
<EOS>
But
if
I
had
n't
discovered
them
,
the
major
would
soon
have
let
me
into
the
secret
by
the
way
in
which
he
squeezed
my
hand
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Indeed
!
"
exclaimed
Blaize
,
angrily
.
<EOS>
"
I
'll
go
and
acquaint
my
master
with
the
trick
directly
.
<EOS>
"
 
"
Do
so
,
"
replied
Patience
,
"
and
the
house
will
be
shut
up
to
-
morrow
.
<EOS>
Our
only
chance
of
averting
that
calamity
is
in
the
earl
.
"
  
<EOS>
XI
.
 
<EOS>
HOW
THE
GROCER
SHUT
UP
HIS
HOUSE
.
 
<EOS>
Placed
in
a
warm
bed
,
and
carefully
tended
by
the
humane
physician
,
Leonard
Holt
slept
tranquilly
for
some
hours
,
and
when
he
awoke
,
though
so
weak
as
scarcely
to
be
able
to
lift
an
arm
,
he
was
free
from
all
ailment
.
<EOS>
Feeling
ravenously
hungry
,
he
made
known
his
wants
;
and
,
provisions
being
set
before
him
,
he
was
allowed
to
eat
and
drink
in
moderation
.
<EOS>
Greatly
revived
by
the
meal
,
he
arose
and
attired
himself
in
habiliments
provided
for
him
by
Hodges
,
who
,
finding
him
fully
equal
to
conversation
,
questioned
him
as
to
all
that
had
occurred
prior
to
his
seizure
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
have
acted
nobly
,
"
observed
the
doctor
,
at
the
close
of
his
recital
;
"
and
if
Amabel
had
a
spark
of
generosity
in
her
composition
,
she
would
worthily
requite
you
.
<EOS>
But
I
do
not
expect
it
.
<EOS>
How
different
is
her
conduct
from
that
of
the
piper
's
pretty
daughter
.
<EOS>
The
latter
really
loves
you
;
and
I
would
advise
you
as
a
friend
to
turn
your
thoughts
to
her
.
<EOS>
She
will
make
you
happy
:
whereas
the
indulgence
of
your
present
hopeless
passion
--
for
hopeless
it
is
--
can
only
lead
to
wretchedness
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Would
I
could
follow
your
advice
!
"
<EOS>
replied
Leonard
;
"
but
,
alas
!
<EOS>
I
can
not
.
<EOS>
Amabel
does
not
love
the
Earl
of
Rochester
more
blindly
,
more
constantly
,
than
I
love
her
;
and
I
could
as
soon
change
my
nature
as
transfer
my
affection
to
another
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
truly
sorry
for
it
,
"
rejoined
Hodges
,
in
a
tone
of
deep
sympathy
.
"
<EOS>
And
you
still
desire
to
return
to
your
master
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Unquestionably
,
"
replied
Leonard
.
<EOS>
"
If
I
am
banished
the
house
,
I
shall
wander
round
it
night
and
day
like
a
ghost
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
will
accompany
you
there
this
evening
,
"
rejoined
Hodges
,
"
and
I
trust
I
shall
be
able
to
arrange
matters
without
compromising
Amabel
.
<EOS>
I
wish
I
could
forward
your
suit
more
efficiently
;
but
I
see
no
chance
of
it
,
and
,
to
deal
plainly
with
you
,
I
do
not
think
a
marriage
with
her
would
be
for
your
happiness
.
<EOS>
The
brilliant
qualities
of
your
noble
rival
at
present
so
dazzle
her
eyes
,
that
your
own
solid
worth
is
completely
overlooked
.
<EOS>
It
will
be
well
if
her
father
can
preserve
her
from
ruin
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
The
earl
shall
die
by
my
hand
rather
than
he
shall
succeed
in
his
infamous
purpose
,
"
cried
Leonard
,
fiercely
.
 
<EOS>
"
No
more
of
this
!
"
exclaimed
Hodges
.
<EOS>
"
If
you
would
have
me
take
an
interest
in
you
,
you
will
never
give
utterance
to
such
a
sentiment
again
.
<EOS>
Amabel
has
another
guardian
,
more
powerful
even
than
her
father
--
the
plague
.
<EOS>
Ere
long
the
earl
,
who
has
a
sufficient
value
for
his
own
safety
,
will
fly
the
city
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
hope
the
pestilence
will
number
him
among
its
victims
,
"
observed
Leonard
,
in
a
sombre
tone
.
 
<EOS>
At
this
juncture
the
old
porter
entered
the
room
,
and
informed
his
master
that
the
piper
's
daughter
was
below
,
and
had
called
to
inquire
after
the
apprentice
.
 
<EOS>
Hodges
desired
she
might
be
shown
upstairs
,
and
the
next
moment
Nizza
was
ushered
into
the
room
.
<EOS>
On
beholding
the
improved
appearance
of
Leonard
,
she
could
not
repress
an
exclamation
of
delight
,
while
a
deep
blush
suffused
her
cheeks
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
are
surprised
to
find
him
quite
well
,
"
observed
Hodges
,
with
a
smile
.
<EOS>
"
Nay
,
you
may
approach
him
with
safety
.
<EOS>
There
is
no
fear
of
contagion
now
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Having
satisfied
myself
on
that
point
,
I
will
take
my
leave
,
"
rejoined
Nizza
,
in
some
confusion
.
 
<EOS>
"
Not
till
you
have
allowed
me
to
return
my
thanks
<EOS>
,
I
trust
,
"
said
Leonard
,
advancing
towards
her
,
and
taking
her
hand
.
<EOS>
"
I
owe
my
life
to
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Then
pay
the
debt
by
devoting
it
to
her
,
"
rejoined
Hodges
.
"
<EOS>
Excuse
me
for
a
few
minutes
.
<EOS>
I
have
business
to
attend
to
,
but
will
be
back
again
directly
.
"
 
<EOS>
Left
alone
together
,
the
young
couple
felt
so
much
embarrassment
that
for
some
minutes
neither
could
utter
a
word
.
<EOS>
At
length
Nizza
,
who
had
suffered
her
hand
to
remain
in
that
of
Leonard
,
gently
withdrew
it
.
 
<EOS>
"
Circumstances
have
given
me
a
claim
to
your
confidence
<EOS>
,
"
she
faltered
,
"
and
you
will
not
misconstrue
my
motive
,
when
I
ask
you
whether
you
still
retain
the
same
affection
as
formerly
for
Amabel
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Unfortunately
for
myself
,
I
do
,
"
replied
Leonard
.
 
<EOS>
"
And
unfortunately
for
me
too
,
"
sighed
Nizza
.
"
<EOS>
Doctor
Hodges
says
he
can
restore
you
to
your
master
's
favour
.
<EOS>
You
will
therefore
return
home
,
and
we
shall
meet
no
more
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
In
these
precarious
times
,
those
who
part
,
though
even
for
a
few
days
,
can
feel
no
certainty
of
meeting
again
,
"
rejoined
Leonard
.
"
<EOS>
But
I
hope
we
shall
be
more
fortunate
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
mistake
me
,
"
replied
Nizza
.
<EOS>
"
Henceforth
I
shall
sedulously
avoid
you
.
<EOS>
Till
I
saw
you
,
I
was
happy
,
and
indifferent
to
all
else
,
my
affections
being
centred
in
my
father
and
in
my
dog
.
<EOS>
Now
I
am
restless
and
miserable
.
<EOS>
My
former
pursuits
are
abandoned
,
and
I
think
only
of
you
.
<EOS>
Despise
me
if
you
will
after
this
frank
avowal
.
<EOS>
But
believe
that
I
would
not
have
made
it
if
I
had
not
resolved
to
see
you
no
more
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Despise
you
!
"
echoed
Leonard
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
On
no
!
<EOS>
I
shall
ever
feel
the
deepest
gratitude
towards
you
;
but
perhaps
it
is
better
we
should
meet
no
more
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
And
yet
you
throw
yourself
in
the
way
of
Amabel
,
"
cried
Nizza
.
<EOS>
"
You
have
not
resolution
to
fly
from
the
danger
which
you
counsel
me
to
shun
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
too
true
,
"
replied
Leonard
;
"
but
she
is
beset
by
temptations
from
which
I
hope
to
preserve
her
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
That
excuse
will
not
avail
me
,
"
returned
Nizza
,
bitterly
.
<EOS>
"
You
can
not
live
without
her
.
<EOS>
But
I
have
said
enough
--
more
than
enough
,
"
she
added
,
correcting
herself
.
<EOS>
"
I
must
now
bid
you
farewell
--
for
ever
.
<EOS>
May
you
be
happy
with
Amabel
,
and
may
she
love
you
as
I
love
you
!
"
 
<EOS>
As
she
said
this
she
would
have
rushed
out
of
the
room
,
if
she
had
not
been
stopped
by
Doctor
Hodges
.
 
<EOS>
"
Whither
so
fast
?
<EOS>
"
he
inquired
.
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
!
let
me
go
--
let
me
go
,
I
implore
of
you
!
"
<EOS>
she
cried
,
bursting
into
an
agony
of
tears
.
 
<EOS>
"
Not
till
you
have
composed
yourself
,
"
rejoined
the
doctor
.
<EOS>
"
What
is
the
matter
?
<EOS>
But
I
need
not
ask
.
<EOS>
I
wonder
Leonard
can
be
insensible
to
charms
like
yours
,
coupled
with
such
devotion
.
<EOS>
Everything
seems
to
be
at
cross
purposes
,
and
it
requires
some
one
more
skilled
in
the
affairs
of
the
heart
than
an
old
bachelor
like
myself
to
set
them
right
.
<EOS>
Sit
down
.
<EOS>
I
have
a
few
questions
of
importance
to
ask
you
before
you
depart
.
"
 
<EOS>
And
partly
by
entreaty
,
partly
by
compulsion
,
he
made
her
take
a
chair
;
and
as
soon
as
she
was
sufficiently
composed
to
answer
him
,
questioned
her
as
to
what
she
knew
relating
to
Judith
Malmayns
and
Chowles
.
 
<EOS>
"
Mr.
Quatremain
,
the
minor
canon
,
has
died
of
the
plague
in
one
of
the
vaults
of
Saint
Faith
's
,
"
he
observed
;
"
and
I
more
than
suspect
,
from
the
appearance
of
the
body
,
has
not
met
with
fair
play
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Your
suspicion
is
well
founded
,
sir
,
"
replied
Nizza
.
"
<EOS>
Solomon
Eagle
told
me
that
the
unfortunate
man
's
end
was
hastened
by
the
plague
-
nurse
.
<EOS>
Nor
is
this
her
sole
crime
.
<EOS>
She
was
hired
to
make
away
with
Leonard
Holt
in
the
same
manner
,
and
would
have
accomplished
her
purpose
but
for
the
intervention
of
Solomon
Eagle
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Neither
she
nor
her
partner
in
guilt
,
the
coffin
-
maker
,
shall
escape
justice
this
time
,
"
replied
Hodges
.
<EOS>
"
I
will
instantly
cause
her
to
be
arrested
,
and
I
trust
she
will
expiate
her
offences
at
Tyburn
.
<EOS>
But
to
change
the
subject
.
<EOS>
I
am
sincerely
interested
about
you
,
Nizza
,
and
I
wish
I
could
make
Leonard
as
sensible
of
your
merits
as
I
am
myself
.
<EOS>
I
still
hope
a
change
will
take
place
in
his
feelings
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
My
heart
tells
me
the
contrary
,
"
replied
Nizza
.
<EOS>
"
There
is
no
hope
for
either
of
us
.
<EOS>
Farewell
,
Leonard
!
"
<EOS>
and
she
rushed
out
of
the
room
.
 
<EOS>
Soon
after
this
Hodges
quitted
the
apprentice
,
and
going
before
a
magistrate
,
detailed
all
that
had
come
to
his
knowledge
concerning
the
criminal
practices
of
Judith
Malmayns
and
Chowles
.
<EOS>
In
the
course
of
the
day
the
accused
parties
were
arrested
,
and
,
after
a
long
examination
,
conveyed
to
Newgate
.
<EOS>
Solomon
Eagle
could
not
be
found
,
neither
could
Sir
Paul
Parravicin
.
<EOS>
It
appeared
that
Mr.
Quatremain
's
residence
had
been
entered
on
that
very
morning
,
and
the
box
of
treasure
discovered
in
Saint
Faith
's
abstracted
.
<EOS>
But
though
the
strongest
suspicion
of
the
robbery
attached
to
Chowles
and
Judith
,
it
could
not
be
brought
home
to
them
.
 
<EOS>
We
shall
now
proceed
to
Wood
-
street
,
and
ascertain
what
took
place
there
.
<EOS>
Refreshments
were
placed
before
the
supposed
Doctor
Maplebury
by
the
grocer
,
while
his
attendant
was
sent
to
the
kitchen
,
and
directions
given
to
Blaize
to
take
every
care
of
him
;
old
Josyna
was
occupied
about
her
own
concerns
;
and
Pillichody
,
perceiving
from
the
porter
's
manner
that
his
disguise
was
detected
,
laid
aside
concealment
altogether
,
and
endeavoured
to
win
the
other
over
to
his
patron
's
interests
.
 
<EOS>
"
If
this
marriage
takes
place
,
"
he
said
,
"
I
am
authorized
by
my
noble
friend
to
state
that
he
will
appoint
you
his
steward
with
a
large
salary
,
and
that
will
be
a
very
different
situation
from
the
one
you
hold
at
present
.
<EOS>
A
nobleman
's
steward
!
<EOS>
Think
of
that
.
<EOS>
You
will
have
a
retinue
of
servants
under
your
control
,
and
will
live
quite
as
well
as
his
lordship
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
some
scruples
,
"
hesitated
Blaize
.
 
<EOS>
"
Scruples
!
<EOS>
pshaw
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Pillichody
.
<EOS>
"
You
can
have
no
hesitation
in
benefiting
yourself
.
<EOS>
If
you
remain
here
,
the
house
will
be
shut
up
,
and
you
will
be
kept
a
close
prisoner
for
months
in
the
very
heart
of
an
infected
city
,
and
I
dare
say
will
be
buried
in
yonder
cellar
;
whereas
,
if
you
go
with
the
Earl
of
Rochester
,
you
will
dwell
in
a
magnificent
country
mansion
--
a
palace
,
I
ought
to
call
it
--
enjoy
every
luxury
,
and
remain
there
till
the
plague
is
over
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
That
last
reason
decides
me
,
"
replied
Blaize
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
I
suppose
his
lordship
will
provide
himself
with
a
medicine
chest
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
He
has
already
got
one
as
large
as
this
table
,
"
said
Pillichody
,
"
and
you
shall
have
the
key
of
it
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Enough
!
"
exclaimed
Blaise
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
yours
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Pray
,
what
am
I
to
be
?
"
<EOS>
asked
Patience
,
who
had
listened
to
the
foregoing
conversation
with
a
smile
at
Blaize
's
credulity
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
,
sweetheart
!
"
<EOS>
exclaimed
Pillichody
.
<EOS>
"
I
will
take
care
of
you
.
<EOS>
You
shall
be
my
housekeeper
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Hold
!
"
cried
Blaize
.
<EOS>
"
I
can
not
admit
that
.
<EOS>
Patience
and
I
are
engaged
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Since
you
are
promoted
to
such
an
important
situation
,
you
can
make
a
better
match
,
"
observed
Patience
.
<EOS>
"
I
release
you
from
the
engagement
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
choose
to
be
released
,
"
returned
Blaize
;
"
I
will
marry
you
on
the
same
day
that
the
earl
weds
Amabel
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
That
will
be
to
-
night
,
or
to
-
morrow
at
the
latest
,
"
said
Pillichody
.
<EOS>
"
Consent
,
sweetheart
,
"
he
added
,
in
a
whisper
to
Patience
;
"
if
we
can
once
get
you
and
your
pretty
mistress
out
of
the
house
,
we
will
leave
this
simpleton
fool
in
the
lurch
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
No
,
I
will
never
consent
to
such
a
thing
,
"
returned
Patience
,
in
the
same
tone
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
's
that
you
are
saying
?
"
inquired
Blaize
,
suspiciously
.
 
<EOS>
"
Major
Pillichody
says
he
will
marry
me
,
if
you
wo
n't
,
"
returned
Patience
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
just
told
you
I
will
,
"
rejoined
Blaize
.
"
<EOS>
But
he
must
not
continue
his
attentions
.
<EOS>
I
feel
I
shall
be
very
jealous
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
glad
to
hear
it
,
"
returned
Patience
,
bursting
into
a
loud
laugh
,
"
for
that
proves
you
love
me
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Well
,
"
observed
Pillichody
,
"
I
wo
n't
interfere
with
a
friend
;
and
as
there
is
no
knowing
what
may
occur
,
it
will
be
as
well
to
prepare
accordingly
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
So
saying
,
he
fell
to
work
upon
the
provisions
loading
the
board
,
and
ate
and
drank
as
if
determined
to
lay
in
a
stock
for
the
next
two
days
.
 
<EOS>
Meantime
the
earl
made
rapid
progress
in
the
good
opinion
both
of
Mr.
Bloundel
and
his
wife
.
<EOS>
Adapting
his
discourse
precisely
to
their
views
,
and
exerting
his
matchless
conversational
powers
to
their
full
extent
,
he
so
charmed
them
that
they
thought
they
could
listen
to
him
for
ever
.
<EOS>
While
thus
engaged
,
he
contrived
ever
and
anon
to
steal
a
glance
at
Amabel
,
and
on
these
occasions
,
his
eyes
were
quite
as
eloquent
and
intelligible
as
his
tongue
.
 
<EOS>
Among
other
topics
interesting
to
the
grocer
,
the
persecution
to
which
his
daughter
had
been
recently
subjected
was
brought
forward
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Bloundel
could
not
reprobate
the
earl
's
conduct
more
strongly
than
his
guest
did
;
and
he
assailed
himself
with
such
virulence
that
,
in
spite
of
her
uneasiness
,
Amabel
could
not
repress
a
smile
.
<EOS>
In
short
,
he
so
accommodated
himself
to
the
grocer
's
opinion
,
and
so
won
upon
his
regard
,
that
the
latter
offered
him
an
asylum
in
his
house
during
the
continuance
of
the
pestilence
.
<EOS>
This
was
eagerly
accepted
,
and
the
earl
,
hazarding
a
look
at
Amabel
at
the
moment
,
perceived
her
change
colour
and
become
greatly
agitated
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Bloundel
also
noticed
her
confusion
,
but
attributing
it
to
any
other
than
the
right
cause
,
begged
her
,
in
a
low
tone
,
to
control
herself
.
 
<EOS>
At
length
,
the
opportunity
for
which
the
earl
had
been
secretly
sighing
occurred
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Bloundel
called
his
wife
out
of
the
room
for
a
moment
,
and
as
their
eldest
son
,
Stephen
,
was
in
the
shop
,
and
the
two
other
children
upstairs
,
Amabel
was
left
alone
with
her
lover
.
<EOS>
The
door
was
no
sooner
closed
than
he
sprang
towards
her
and
threw
himself
at
her
feet
.
 
<EOS>
"
Shall
I
avail
myself
of
your
father
's
offer
,
sweetheart
?
"
<EOS>
he
cried
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Shall
I
remain
here
with
you
--
the
happiest
of
prisoners
--
or
will
you
once
more
accompany
me
?
<EOS>
This
time
,
our
marriage
shall
not
be
interrupted
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
not
,
my
lord
,
"
she
replied
,
gravely
;
"
but
it
will
be
a
mock
ceremonial
,
like
the
last
.
<EOS>
Do
not
attempt
to
deceive
me
.
<EOS>
I
am
fully
aware
of
your
intentions
,
and
after
the
awful
fate
of
the
wretched
instrument
of
your
purposed
criminality
,
you
will
not
readily
get
another
person
to
tempt
in
like
manner
the
vengeance
of
Heaven
.
<EOS>
I
have
had
a
severe
struggle
with
myself
.
<EOS>
But
at
length
I
have
triumphed
over
my
irresolution
.
<EOS>
I
will
not
disguise
from
you
that
I
love
you
<EOS>
still,--and
must
ever
,
I
fear
,
continue
to
love
you
.
<EOS>
But
I
will
not
be
yours
on
the
terms
you
propose
.
<EOS>
Neither
will
I
leave
this
house
with
you
,
nor
suffer
you
to
remain
in
it
,
in
any
other
than
your
proper
character
.
<EOS>
On
my
father
's
return
I
will
disclose
all
to
him
.
<EOS>
If
your
designs
are
honourable
,
I
am
sure
he
will
no
longer
oppose
my
union
with
you
.
<EOS>
If
not
,
we
part
for
ever
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Be
prudent
,
sweet
girl
,
I
entreat
of
you
,
"
cried
the
earl
imploringly
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Your
indiscretion
will
ruin
all
.
<EOS>
There
are
a
thousand
reasons
why
your
father
should
not
be
consulted
on
the
matter
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
There
are
none
that
weigh
with
me
,
"
she
interrupted
,
decidedly
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
been
bewildered
--
beside
myself,--but
,
thank
Heaven
,
I
have
recovered
before
it
is
too
late
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
are
beside
yourself
at
this
moment
,
"
cried
Rochester
,
unable
to
control
his
anger
and
mortification
,
"
and
will
bitterly
repent
your
folly
.
<EOS>
Neither
your
supplications
nor
my
rank
will
have
any
weight
with
your
father
,
prejudiced
as
he
is
against
me
.
<EOS>
Fly
with
me
,
and
I
swear
to
make
you
mine
,
without
a
moment
's
loss
of
time
.
<EOS>
Will
not
my
plighted
word
content
you
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
No
,
my
lord
,
you
have
broken
it
already
,
"
returned
Amabel
.
<EOS>
"
My
father
shall
know
the
truth
.
"
 
<EOS>
A
dark
shade
passed
over
Rochester
's
countenance
,
and
a
singular
and
most
forbidding
expression
,
which
Amabel
had
once
before
noticed
,
took
possession
of
it
.
<EOS>
His
love
for
her
seemed
changed
to
hate
,
and
she
tremblingly
averted
her
gaze
.
<EOS>
At
this
juncture
,
the
door
opened
,
and
the
grocer
and
his
wife
entered
the
room
.
<EOS>
The
former
started
,
on
seeing
Amabel
and
the
supposed
preacher
in
such
close
propinquity
,
and
a
painful
suspicion
of
the
truth
crossed
his
mind
.
<EOS>
He
was
not
,
however
,
kept
long
in
suspense
.
<EOS>
Throwing
off
his
wig
,
and
letting
his
own
fair
ringlets
fall
over
his
shoulders
,
the
earl
tore
open
his
cassock
,
and
disclosed
his
ordinary
rich
attire
.
<EOS>
At
the
same
time
,
his
face
underwent
an
equally
striking
change,--each
feature
resuming
its
original
expression
;
and
the
grocer
,
though
he
witnessed
the
whole
transformation
,
could
scarcely
believe
that
the
same
individual
he
had
recently
beheld
stood
before
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
now
know
who
I
am
,
Mr.
Bloundel
,
and
what
brought
me
hither
,
"
said
Rochester
,
with
a
haughty
salutation
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
do
,
my
lord
,
"
replied
the
grocer
,
"
and
I
give
you
full
credit
for
your
daring
and
ingenuity
.
<EOS>
After
the
manner
in
which
I
have
been
imposed
upon
myself
,
I
can
make
allowance
for
others
.
"
<EOS>
He
then
turned
to
Amabel
,
and
said
,
in
a
severe
tone
,
"
You
are
no
longer
my
daughter
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Father
!
"
<EOS>
she
cried
,
rushing
towards
him
and
throwing
herself
at
his
feet
,
"
do
not
cast
me
off
for
ever
.
<EOS>
I
am
not
now
to
blame
.
<EOS>
It
is
owing
to
my
determination
to
disclose
all
to
you
that
the
earl
has
thus
revealed
himself
.
<EOS>
I
might
have
deceived
you
further
--
might
have
fled
with
him
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Forgive
her
!
<EOS>
oh
,
forgive
her
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Mrs.
Bloundel--"or
,
if
any
ill
happens
to
her
,
you
will
be
answerable
for
it
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Is
this
the
truth
,
my
lord
?
"
asked
the
grocer
.
 
<EOS>
Rochester
bowed
stiffly
in
acquiescence
.
 
<EOS>
"
Then
you
are
again
my
child
,
"
said
Bloundel
,
raising
her
,
and
pressing
her
to
his
bosom
.
<EOS>
"
What
are
your
intentions
towards
her
?
"
<EOS>
he
continued
,
addressing
the
earl
.
 
<EOS>
"
They
may
be
readily
surmised
,
"
replied
Rochester
,
with
a
scornful
laugh
.
 
<EOS>
"
Will
you
we
d
her
,
if
I
agree
to
the
union
,
"
asked
Bloundel
,
trembling
with
concentrated
rage
.
 
<EOS>
Amabel
looked
at
her
lover
as
if
her
life
hung
on
his
answer
.
 
<EOS>
Rochester
affected
not
to
hear
the
question
,
but
,
as
it
was
repeated
still
more
peremptorily
,
he
repeated
carelessly,--"I
will
consider
of
it
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Deceived
!
<EOS>
deceived
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Amabel
,
falling
on
her
mother
's
neck
,
and
bursting
into
tears
.
 
<EOS>
"
This
outrage
shall
not
pass
unpunished
,
"
cried
Bloundel
.
<EOS>
And
before
the
earl
could
draw
his
sword
or
offer
any
resistance
,
he
threw
himself
upon
him
,
and
hurling
him
to
the
ground
,
set
his
foot
upon
his
bosom
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
not
kill
him
,
"
shrieked
Amabel
,
terrified
by
the
stern
expression
of
her
father
's
countenance
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
are
you
about
to
do
?
"
gasped
Rochester
,
struggling
ineffectually
to
get
free
.
 
<EOS>
"
Bid
Stephen
bring
a
cord
,
"
cried
the
grocer
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
are
not
going
to
hang
him
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Mrs.
Bloundel
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
as
I
bid
you
,
"
rejoined
her
husband
,
"
and
lose
no
time
.
"
 
<EOS>
As
she
was
about
to
leave
the
room
,
the
door
opened
,
and
Doctor
Hodges
entered
,
followed
by
Leonard
and
Stephen
.
 
<EOS>
"
Mercy
on
us
!
<EOS>
what
's
the
matter
?
<EOS>
"
cried
the
former
,
in
astonishment
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
are
just
arrived
in
time
to
prevent
mischief
,
"
replied
Mrs.
Bloundel
.
<EOS>
"
Pray
interfere
between
them
.
<EOS>
My
husband
will
attend
to
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Arise
,
my
lord
,
"
said
Mr.
Bloundel
,
removing
his
foot
from
the
prostrate
nobleman
;
"
you
are
sufficiently
punished
by
being
found
in
this
disgraceful
condition
.
<EOS>
Remember
that
your
life
has
been
at
my
disposal
.
"
 
<EOS>
Thus
liberated
,
Rochester
sprang
to
his
feet
,
and
regarding
the
group
with
a
menacing
and
disdainful
look
,
walked
up
to
Amabel
,
and
saying
to
her
,
"
You
shall
yet
be
mine
,
"
strode
out
of
the
room
.
<EOS>
He
then
marched
along
the
passage
,
and
called
to
Pillichody
,
who
instantly
answered
the
summons
.
<EOS>
Accompanied
by
Hodges
,
the
grocer
followed
them
to
the
shop
,
where
the
bully
not
departing
so
quickly
as
he
desired
,
and
refusing
to
be
more
expeditious
,
he
kicked
him
into
the
street
.
<EOS>
This
done
,
and
the
door
fastened
,
he
tarried
only
till
he
had
received
all
needful
explanations
from
the
friendly
physician
,
and
then
returning
to
the
inner
room
,
warmly
greeted
Leonard
,
and
congratulated
him
on
his
extraordinary
recovery
from
the
plague
.
 
<EOS>
Happiness
was
thus
once
more
restored
to
every
member
of
the
grocer
's
family
,
except
Amabel
,
who
still
continued
downcast
and
dejected
,
and
entreated
permission
to
retire
to
her
own
room
.
<EOS>
A
cheerful
evening
was
then
passed
by
the
others
,
and
the
doctor
did
not
offer
to
take
his
departure
till
the
clock
struck
eleven
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
the
last
night
I
shall
spend
here
for
some
months
,
"
he
said
;
"
<EOS>
perhaps
the
last
I
shall
ever
spend
here
,
and
I
have
stayed
longer
than
I
intended
,
but
I
did
not
like
to
abridge
my
enjoyment
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
After
shaking
hands
cordially
with
the
whole
party
,
he
added
in
an
under
tone
,
as
he
took
leave
of
Leonard
,
"
Do
not
forget
Nizza
Macascree
.
"
 
<EOS>
On
the
following
day
the
grocer
nailed
up
the
shutters
,
and
locked
and
barred
the
doors
of
his
house
.
    
<EOS>
BOOK
THE
THIRD
.
 
<EOS>
JUNE
,
1665
.
  
<EOS>
I.
 
THE
IMPRISONED
FAMILY
.
 
<EOS>
The
first
few
days
of
their
confinement
were
passed
by
the
grocer
's
family
in
a
very
uncomfortable
manner
.
<EOS>
No
one
,
except
Mr.
Bloundel
,
appeared
reconciled
to
the
plan
,
and
even
he
found
it
more
difficult
of
accomplishment
that
he
had
anticipated
.
<EOS>
The
darkness
of
the
rooms
,
and
the
want
of
ventilation
caused
by
the
closed
windows
and
barred
doors
,
gave
the
house
the
air
of
a
prison
,
and
occasioned
a
sense
of
oppression
almost
intolerable
.
<EOS>
Blaize
declared
it
was
"
worse
than
being
in
Newgate
,
and
that
he
must
take
an
additional
rufus
to
set
right
his
digestion
;
"
while
Patience
affirmed
"
that
it
was
like
being
buried
alive
,
and
that
she
would
not
stand
it
.
"
<EOS>
Mr.
Bloundel
paid
no
attention
to
their
complaints
,
but
addressed
himself
seriously
to
the
remedy
.
<EOS>
Insisting
upon
the
utmost
attention
being
paid
to
cleanliness
,
he
had
an
abundant
supply
of
water
drawn
,
with
which
the
floors
of
every
room
and
passage
were
washed
down
daily
.
<EOS>
By
such
means
the
house
was
kept
cool
and
wholesome
;
and
its
inmates
,
becoming
habituated
to
the
gloom
,
in
a
great
degree
recovered
their
cheerfulness
.
 
<EOS>
The
daily
routine
of
the
establishment
was
as
follows
.
<EOS>
The
grocer
arose
at
dawn
,
and
proceeded
to
call
up
the
whole
of
his
family
.
<EOS>
They
then
assembled
in
a
large
room
on
the
second
story
,
where
he
offered
up
thanks
that
they
had
been
spared
during
the
night
,
and
prayed
for
their
preservation
during
the
day
.
<EOS>
He
next
assigned
a
task
to
each
,
and
took
care
to
see
it
afterwards
duly
fulfilled
;
<EOS>
well
knowing
that
constant
employment
was
the
best
way
to
check
repining
and
promote
contentment
.
<EOS>
Heretofore
the
servants
had
always
taken
their
meals
in
the
kitchen
,
but
now
they
always
sat
down
to
table
with
him
.
<EOS>
"
I
will
make
no
distinction
at
this
season
,
"
he
said
;
"
all
shall
fare
as
I
fare
,
and
enjoy
the
same
comforts
as
myself
.
<EOS>
And
I
trust
that
my
dwelling
may
be
as
sure
a
refuge
amid
this
pestilential
storm
as
the
ark
of
the
patriarch
proved
when
Heaven
's
vengeance
was
called
forth
in
the
mighty
flood
.
"
 
<EOS>
Their
devotions
ended
,
the
whole
party
repaired
to
one
of
the
lower
rooms
,
where
a
plentiful
breakfast
was
provided
,
and
of
which
they
all
partook
.
<EOS>
The
business
of
the
day
then
began
,
and
,
as
has
just
been
observed
,
no
one
was
suffered
to
remain
idle
.
<EOS>
The
younger
children
were
allowed
to
play
and
exercise
themselves
as
much
as
they
chose
in
the
garret
,
and
Blaize
and
Patience
were
occasionally
invited
to
join
them
.
<EOS>
A
certain
portion
of
the
evening
was
also
devoted
to
harmless
recreation
and
amusements
.
<EOS>
The
result
may
be
anticipated
.
<EOS>
No
one
suffered
in
health
,
while
all
improved
in
spirits
.
<EOS>
Prayers
,
as
usual
,
concluded
the
day
,
and
the
family
retired
to
rest
at
an
early
hour
.
 
<EOS>
This
system
of
things
may
appear
sufficiently
monotonous
,
but
it
was
precisely
adapted
to
the
exigencies
of
the
case
,
and
produced
a
most
salutary
effect
.
<EOS>
Regular
duties
and
regular
employments
being
imposed
upon
each
,
and
their
constant
recurrence
,
so
far
from
being
irksome
,
soon
became
agreeable
.
<EOS>
After
a
while
the
whole
family
seemed
to
grow
indifferent
to
the
external
world
--
to
live
only
for
each
other
,
and
to
think
only
of
each
other
--
and
to
Leonard
Holt
,
indeed
,
that
house
was
all
the
world
.
<EOS>
Those
walls
contained
everything
dear
to
him
,
and
he
would
have
been
quite
content
never
to
leave
them
if
Amabel
had
been
always
near
.
<EOS>
He
made
no
attempt
to
renew
his
suit
--
seldom
or
never
exchanging
a
word
with
her
,
and
might
have
been
supposed
to
have
become
wholly
indifferent
to
her
.
<EOS>
But
it
was
not
so
.
<EOS>
His
heart
was
consumed
by
the
same
flame
as
before
.
<EOS>
No
longer
,
however
,
a
prey
to
jealousy
--
no
longer
apprehensive
of
the
earl
<EOS>
--
he
felt
so
happy
,
in
comparison
with
what
he
had
been
,
that
he
almost
prayed
that
the
term
of
their
imprisonment
might
be
prolonged
.
<EOS>
Sometimes
the
image
of
Nizza
Macascree
would
intrude
upon
him
,
and
he
thought
,
with
a
feeling
akin
to
remorse
,
of
what
she
might
suffer
--
for
he
was
too
well
acquainted
with
the
pangs
of
unrequited
love
not
to
sympathise
deeply
with
her
.
<EOS>
As
to
Amabel
,
she
addressed
herself
assiduously
to
the
tasks
enjoined
by
her
father
,
and
allowed
her
mind
to
dwell
as
little
as
possible
on
the
past
,
but
employed
all
her
spare
time
in
devotional
exercises
.
 
<EOS>
It
will
be
remembered
that
the
grocer
had
reserved
a
communication
with
the
street
,
by
means
of
a
shutter
opening
from
a
small
room
in
the
upper
story
.
<EOS>
Hither
he
would
now
frequently
repair
,
and
though
he
did
not
as
yet
think
it
necessary
to
have
recourse
to
all
the
precautionary
measures
he
intended
eventually
to
adopt
--
such
as
flashing
a
pistol
when
he
looked
forth
--
yet
he
never
opened
the
shutter
without
holding
a
