phial
of
vinegar
,
or
a
handkerchief
wetted
with
the
same
liquid
,
to
his
face
.
 
<EOS>
Before
closing
his
house
he
had
hired
a
porter
,
who
occupied
the
hutch
at
his
door
,
and
held
himself
in
readiness
to
execute
any
commission
,
or
perform
any
service
that
might
be
required
.
<EOS>
Fresh
vegetables
,
poultry
,
eggs
,
butter
,
and
milk
,
were
brought
by
a
higgler
from
the
country
,
and
raised
by
means
of
a
basket
or
a
can
attached
to
the
pulley
.
<EOS>
Butcher
's
meat
was
fetched
him
from
Newgate
-
market
by
the
porter
.
<EOS>
This
man
,
whose
name
was
Ralph
Dallison
,
had
been
formerly
in
the
employ
of
the
grocer
,
who
,
knowing
his
character
,
could
place
entire
reliance
on
him
.
<EOS>
Dallison
reported
the
progress
of
the
pestilence
daily
,
and
acquainted
him
with
the
increasing
amount
of
the
bills
of
mortality
.
<EOS>
Several
houses
,
he
said
,
were
infected
in
Cheapside
,
and
two
in
Wood
-
street
,
one
of
which
was
but
a
short
distance
from
the
grocer
's
habitation
.
<EOS>
A
watchman
was
stationed
at
the
door
,
and
the
red
cross
marked
upon
it
,
and
on
the
following
night
the
grocer
heard
the
sound
of
the
doleful
bell
announcing
the
approach
of
the
pest
-
cart
.
 
<EOS>
The
weather
still
continued
as
serene
and
beautiful
as
ever
,
but
no
refreshing
showers
fell
--
no
soft
and
healthful
breezes
blew
--
and
it
was
now
found
to
be
true
,
what
had
been
prognosticated
--
viz
,
that
with
the
heats
of
summer
the
plague
would
fearfully
increase
.
<EOS>
The
grocer
was
not
incommoded
in
the
same
degree
as
his
neighbours
.
<EOS>
By
excluding
the
light
he
excluded
the
heat
,
and
the
care
which
he
took
to
have
his
house
washed
down
kept
it
cool
.
<EOS>
The
middle
of
June
had
arrived
,
and
such
dismal
accounts
were
now
brought
him
of
the
havoc
occasioned
by
the
scourge
,
that
he
would
no
longer
take
in
fresh
provisions
,
but
began
to
open
his
stores
.
<EOS>
Dallison
told
him
that
the
alarm
was
worse
than
ever
--
that
vast
numbers
were
endeavouring
to
leave
the
city
,
but
no
one
could
now
do
so
without
a
certificate
,
which
was
never
granted
if
the
slightest
suspicion
was
attached
to
the
party
.
 
<EOS>
"
If
things
go
on
in
this
way
,
"
said
the
porter
,
"
London
will
soon
be
deserted
.
<EOS>
No
business
is
conducted
,
as
it
used
to
be
,
and
everybody
is
viewed
with
distrust
.
<EOS>
The
preachers
,
who
ought
to
be
the
last
to
quit
,
have
left
their
churches
,
and
the
Lord
's
day
is
no
longer
observed
.
<EOS>
Many
medical
men
even
have
departed
,
declaring
their
services
are
no
longer
of
any
avail
.
<EOS>
All
public
amusements
are
suspended
,
and
the
taverns
are
only
open
to
the
profane
and
dissolute
,
who
deride
God
's
judgments
,
and
declare
they
have
no
fear
.
<EOS>
Robberies
,
murders
,
and
other
crimes
,
have
greatly
increased
,
and
the
most
dreadful
deeds
are
now
committed
with
impunity
.
<EOS>
You
have
done
wisely
,
sir
,
in
protecting
yourself
against
them
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
reason
to
be
thankful
that
I
have
done
so
,
"
replied
Bloundel
.
<EOS>
And
he
closed
his
shutter
to
meditate
on
what
he
had
just
heard
.
 
<EOS>
And
there
was
abundant
food
for
reflection
.
<EOS>
Around
him
lay
a
great
and
populous
city
,
hemmed
in
,
as
by
a
fire
,
by
an
exterminating
plague
,
that
spared
neither
age
,
condition
,
nor
sex
.
<EOS>
No
man
could
tell
what
the
end
of
all
this
would
be
--
neither
at
what
point
the
wrath
of
the
offended
Deity
would
stop
--
nor
whether
He
would
relent
,
till
He
had
utterly
destroyed
a
people
who
so
contemned
his
word
.
<EOS>
Scarcely
daring
to
hope
for
leniency
,
and
filled
with
a
dreadful
foreboding
of
what
would
ensue
,
the
grocer
addressed
a
long
and
fervent
supplication
to
Heaven
,
imploring
a
mitigation
of
its
wrath
.
 
<EOS>
On
joining
his
family
,
his
grave
manner
and
silence
showed
how
powerfully
he
had
been
affected
.
<EOS>
No
one
questioned
him
as
to
what
had
occurred
,
but
all
understood
he
had
received
some
distressing
intelligence
.
 
<EOS>
Amid
his
anxiety
one
circumstance
gave
him
unalloyed
satisfaction
.
<EOS>
This
was
the
change
wrought
in
Amabel
's
character
.
<EOS>
It
has
been
stated
that
she
had
become
extremely
devout
,
and
passed
the
whole
of
the
time
not
appointed
for
other
occupations
,
in
the
study
of
the
Scriptures
,
or
in
prayer
.
<EOS>
Her
manner
was
extremely
sedate
,
and
her
conversation
assumed
a
tone
that
gave
her
parents
,
and
especially
her
father
,
inexpressible
pleasure
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Bloundel
would
have
been
equally
delighted
with
the
change
,
if
it
had
tended
to
forward
her
own
favourite
scheme
of
a
union
with
Leonard
;
but
as
this
was
not
the
case
,
though
she
rejoiced
in
the
improvement
,
she
still
was
not
entirely
satisfied
.
<EOS>
She
could
not
help
noting
also
,
that
her
daughter
had
become
pale
and
thin
,
and
though
she
uttered
no
complaint
,
Mrs.
Bloundel
began
to
fear
her
health
was
declining
.
<EOS>
Leonard
Holt
looked
on
in
wonder
and
admiration
,
and
if
possible
his
love
increased
,
though
his
hopes
diminished
;
for
though
Amabel
was
kinder
to
him
than
before
,
her
kindness
seemed
the
result
rather
of
a
sense
of
duty
than
regard
.
 
<EOS>
Upon
one
occasion
they
were
left
alone
together
,
and
instead
of
quitting
the
room
,
as
she
had
been
accustomed
,
Amabel
called
to
Leonard
,
who
was
about
to
depart
,
and
requested
him
to
stay
.
<EOS>
The
apprentice
instantly
obeyed
;
the
colour
forsook
his
cheek
,
and
his
heart
beat
violently
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
desire
to
speak
with
me
,
Amabel
,
"
he
said:--"Ha
!
<EOS>
you
have
relented?--Is
there
any
hope
for
me
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Alas
!
<EOS>
no
,
"
she
replied
;
"
and
it
is
on
that
very
point
I
have
now
detained
you
.
<EOS>
You
will
,
I
am
sure
,
rejoice
to
learn
that
I
have
at
length
fully
regained
my
peace
of
mind
,
and
have
become
sensible
of
the
weakness
of
which
I
have
been
guilty
--
of
the
folly
,
worse
than
folly
,
I
have
committed
.
<EOS>
My
feelings
are
now
under
proper
restraint
,
and
viewing
myself
with
other
eyes
,
I
see
how
culpable
I
have
been
.
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
Leonard
,
if
you
knew
the
effort
it
has
been
to
conquer
the
fatal
passion
that
consumed
me
,
if
I
were
to
tell
you
of
the
pangs
it
has
cost
me
,
of
the
tears
I
have
shed
,
of
<EOS>
the
heart
-
quakes
endured
,
you
would
pity
me
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
do
,
indeed
,
pity
you
,
"
replied
Leonard
,
"
for
my
own
sufferings
<EOS>
have
been
equally
severe
.
<EOS>
But
I
have
not
been
as
successful
as
you
in
subduing
them
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Because
you
have
not
pursued
the
right
means
,
Leonard
,
"
she
rejoined
.
<EOS>
"
Fix
your
thoughts
on
high
;
build
your
hopes
of
happiness
on
Heaven
;
strengthen
your
faith
;
and
you
will
soon
find
the
victory
easy
.
<EOS>
A
short
time
ago
I
thought
only
of
worldly
pleasures
,
and
was
ensnared
by
vanity
and
admiration
,
enchained
to
one
whom
I
knew
to
be
worthless
,
and
who
pursued
me
only
to
destroy
me
.
<EOS>
Religion
has
preserved
me
from
the
snare
,
and
religion
will
restore
you
to
happiness
.
<EOS>
But
you
must
devote
yourself
to
Heaven
,
not
lightly
,
but
with
your
whole
soul
.
<EOS>
You
must
forget
me
--
forget
yourself
--
forget
all
but
the
grand
object
.
<EOS>
And
this
is
a
season
of
all
others
,
when
it
is
most
needful
to
lead
a
life
of
piety
,
to
look
upon
yourself
as
dead
to
this
world
,
and
to
be
ever
prepared
for
that
to
come
.
<EOS>
I
shudder
to
think
what
might
have
been
my
portion
<EOS>
had
I
perished
in
my
sin
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Yours
is
a
most
happy
frame
of
mind
,
"
returned
Leonard
,
"
and
I
would
I
had
a
chance
of
attaining
the
same
tranquillity
.
<EOS>
But
if
you
have
conquered
your
love
for
the
<EOS>
earl,--if
your
heart
is
disengaged
,
why
deny
me
a
hope
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
My
heart
is
_
not
_
disengaged
,
Leonard
,
"
she
replied
;
"
it
is
engrossed
by
Heaven
.
<EOS>
While
the
plague
is
raging
around
us
thus
--
while
thousands
are
daily
carried
off
by
that
devouring
scourge
--
and
while
every
hour
,
every
moment
,
may
be
our
last
,
our
thoughts
ought
always
to
be
fixed
above
.
<EOS>
I
have
ceased
to
love
the
earl
,
but
I
can
never
love
another
,
and
therefore
it
would
be
unjust
to
you
,
to
whom
I
owe
so
much
,
to
hold
out
hopes
that
never
can
be
realized
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Alas
!
alas
!
"
cried
Leonard
,
unable
to
control
his
emotion
.
 
<EOS>
"
Compose
yourself
,
dear
Leonard
,
"
she
cried
,
greatly
moved
.
<EOS>
"
I
would
I
could
comply
with
your
wishes
.
<EOS>
But
,
alas
!
<EOS>
I
can
not
.
<EOS>
I
could
only
give
you
,
"
she
added
,
in
a
tone
so
thrilling
,
that
it
froze
the
blood
in
his
veins--"a
breaking
,
perhaps
a
broken
heart
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
Gracious
heaven
!
<EOS>
"
exclaimed
Leonard
,
becoming
as
pale
as
death
;
"
is
it
come
to
this
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
Again
,
I
beg
you
to
compose
yourself
,
"
she
rejoined
,
<EOS>
calmly--"and
<EOS>
I
entreat
you
not
to
let
what
I
have
told
you
pass
your
lips
.
<EOS>
I
would
not
alarm
my
father
,
or
my
dear
and
anxious
mother
,
on
my
account
.
<EOS>
And
there
may
be
no
reason
for
alarm
.
<EOS>
Promise
me
,
therefore
,
you
will
be
silent
.
"
 
<EOS>
Leonard
reluctantly
gave
the
required
pledge
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
unwittingly
been
the
cause
of
much
affliction
to
you
,
"
pursued
Amabel--"and
<EOS>
would
gladly
see
you
happy
,
and
there
is
one
person
,
I
think
,
who
would
make
you
so
--
<EOS>
I
mean
Nizza
Macascree
.
<EOS>
From
what
she
said
to
me
when
we
were
alone
together
in
the
vaults
of
Saint
Faith
's
,
I
am
sure
she
is
sincerely
attached
to
you
.
<EOS>
Could
you
not
requite
her
love
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
replied
Leonard
.
<EOS>
"
There
is
no
change
in
affection
like
mine
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Pursue
the
course
I
have
advised
,
"
replied
Amabel
,
"
and
you
will
find
all
your
troubles
vanish
.
<EOS>
Farewell
!
<EOS>
I
depend
upon
your
silence
!
"
 
<EOS>
And
she
quitted
the
room
,
leaving
Leonard
in
a
state
of
indescribable
anxiety
.
 
<EOS>
Faithful
,
however
,
to
his
promise
,
he
made
no
mention
of
his
uneasiness
to
the
grocer
or
his
wife
,
but
indulged
his
grief
in
secret
.
<EOS>
Ignorant
of
what
was
passing
,
Mr.
Bloundel
,
who
was
still
not
without
apprehension
of
some
further
attempt
on
the
part
of
the
earl
,
sent
Dallison
to
make
inquiries
after
him
,
and
learnt
that
he
was
at
Whitehall
,
but
that
the
court
had
fixed
to
remove
to
Hampton
Court
at
the
end
of
June
.
<EOS>
The
porter
also
informed
him
that
the
city
was
emptying
fast
--
that
the
Lord
Mayor
's
residence
was
literally
besieged
with
applications
for
bills
of
health
--
that
officers
were
stationed
at
the
gates
--
and
that
,
besides
these
,
barriers
and
turnpikes
were
erected
on
all
the
main
roads
,
at
which
the
certificates
were
required
to
be
exhibited
--
and
that
such
persons
as
escaped
without
them
were
driven
back
by
the
inhabitants
of
the
neighbouring
villages
,
who
refused
to
supply
them
with
necessaries
;
and
as
they
could
not
return
home
,
many
had
perished
of
want
,
or
perhaps
of
the
pestilence
,
in
the
open
fields
.
<EOS>
Horses
and
coaches
,
he
added
,
were
not
to
be
procured
,
except
at
exorbitant
prices
;
and
thousands
had
departed
on
foot
,
locking
up
their
houses
,
and
leaving
their
effects
behind
them
.
 
<EOS>
"
In
consequence
of
this
,
"
added
Dallison
,
"
several
houses
have
been
broken
open
;
and
though
the
watch
had
been
trebled
,
still
they
can
not
be
in
all
places
at
once
;
and
strong
as
the
force
is
,
it
is
not
adequate
to
the
present
emergency
.
<EOS>
Bands
of
robbers
stalk
the
streets
at
night
,
taking
vehicles
with
them
,
built
to
resemble
pest
-
carts
,
and
beating
off
the
watch
,
they
break
open
the
houses
,
and
carry
off
any
goods
they
please
.
"
 
<EOS>
This
intelligence
greatly
alarmed
the
grocer
,
and
he
began
to
fear
his
plans
would
be
defeated
in
an
unexpected
manner
.
<EOS>
He
engaged
Dallison
to
procure
another
trusty
companion
to
take
his
place
at
night
,
and
furnished
him
with
money
to
purchase
arms
.
<EOS>
He
no
longer
slept
as
tranquilly
as
before
,
but
frequently
repaired
to
his
place
of
observation
to
see
that
the
watchman
was
at
his
post
,
and
that
all
was
secure
.
<EOS>
For
the
last
few
days
,
he
had
remarked
with
some
uneasiness
that
a
youth
frequently
passed
the
house
and
gazed
at
the
barred
windows
,
and
he
at
first
imagined
he
might
be
leagued
with
the
nocturnal
marauders
he
had
heard
of
;
but
the
prepossessing
appearance
of
the
stripling
,
who
could
not
be
more
than
sixteen
,
and
who
was
singularly
slightly
made
,
soon
dispelled
the
idea
.
<EOS>
Still
,
as
he
constantly
appeared
at
the
same
spot
,
the
grocer
began
to
have
a
new
apprehension
,
and
to
suspect
he
was
an
emissary
of
the
Earl
of
Rochester
,
and
he
sent
Dallison
to
inquire
his
business
.
<EOS>
The
youth
returned
an
evasive
answer
,
and
withdrew
;
but
the
next
day
he
was
there
again
.
<EOS>
On
this
occasion
,
Mr.
Bloundel
pointed
him
out
to
Leonard
Holt
,
and
asked
him
if
he
had
seen
him
before
.
<EOS>
The
youth
's
back
being
towards
them
,
the
apprentice
unhesitatingly
answered
in
the
negative
,
but
as
the
subject
of
investigation
turned
the
next
moment
,
and
looked
up
,
revealing
features
of
feminine
delicacy
and
beauty
,
set
off
by
long
flowing
jet
-
black
ringlets
,
Leonard
started
,
and
coloured
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
was
mistaken
,
"
he
said
,
"
I
_
have
_
seen
him
before
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Is
he
one
of
the
Earl
of
Rochester
's
pages
?
"
asked
Mr.
Bloundel
.
 
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
replied
Leonard
,
"
and
you
need
not
be
uneasy
about
him
.
<EOS>
I
am
sure
he
intends
no
harm
.
"
 
<EOS>
Thus
satisfied
,
the
grocer
thought
no
more
about
the
matter
.
<EOS>
He
then
arranged
with
Leonard
that
he
should
visit
the
window
at
certain
hours
on
alternate
nights
with
himself
,
and
appointed
the
following
night
as
that
on
which
the
apprentice
's
duties
should
commence
.
 
<EOS>
On
the
same
night
,
however
,
an
alarming
incident
occurred
,
which
kept
the
grocer
and
his
apprentice
for
a
long
time
on
the
watch
.
<EOS>
The
family
had
just
retired
to
rest
when
the
report
of
fire
-
arms
was
heard
close
to
the
street
door
,
and
Mr.
Bloundel
hastily
calling
up
Leonard
,
they
repaired
to
the
room
overlooking
the
street
,
and
found
that
a
desperate
struggle
was
going
on
below
.
<EOS>
The
moon
being
overclouded
,
and
the
lantern
extinguished
,
it
was
too
dark
to
discern
the
figures
of
the
combatants
,
and
in
a
few
seconds
all
became
silent
,
except
the
groans
of
a
wounded
man
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Bloundel
then
called
out
to
know
what
was
the
matter
,
and
ascertained
from
the
sufferer
,
who
proved
to
be
his
own
watchman
,
that
the
adjoining
house
,
being
infected
,
had
been
shut
up
by
the
authorities
;
and
its
owner
,
unable
to
bear
the
restraint
,
had
burst
open
the
door
,
shot
the
watchman
stationed
at
it
,
and
firing
another
pistol
at
the
poor
wretch
who
was
making
the
statement
,
because
he
endeavoured
to
oppose
his
flight
,
had
subsequently
attacked
him
with
his
sword
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
great
grief
to
Mr.
Bloundel
not
to
be
able
to
aid
the
unfortunate
watchman
,
and
he
had
almost
determined
to
hazard
a
descent
by
the
pulley
,
when
a
musical
voice
was
heard
below
,
and
the
grocer
soon
understood
that
the
youth
,
about
whom
his
curiosity
had
been
excited
,
was
raising
the
sufferer
,
and
endeavouring
to
stanch
his
wounds
.
<EOS>
Finding
this
impossible
,
however
,
at
Mr.
Bloundel
's
request
,
he
went
in
search
of
assistance
,
and
presently
afterwards
returned
with
a
posse
of
men
,
bearing
halberds
and
lanterns
,
who
carried
off
the
wounded
man
,
and
afterwards
started
in
pursuit
of
the
murderer
.
 
<EOS>
Mr.
Bloundel
then
entered
into
conversation
with
the
youth
,
who
informed
him
that
his
name
was
Flitcroft
,
that
he
was
without
a
home
,
all
his
relations
having
died
of
the
plague
,
and
that
he
was
anxious
to
serve
as
a
watchman
in
place
of
the
poor
wretch
who
had
just
been
removed
.
<EOS>
Leonard
remonstrated
against
this
arrangement
,
but
Mr.
Bloundel
was
so
much
pleased
with
Flitcroft
's
conduct
that
he
would
listen
to
no
objection
.
<EOS>
Accordingly
provisions
were
lowered
down
in
a
basket
to
the
poor
youth
,
and
he
stationed
himself
in
the
hutch
.
<EOS>
Nothing
material
occurred
during
the
day
.
<EOS>
Flitcroft
resigned
his
post
to
Dallison
,
but
returned
in
the
evening
.
 
<EOS>
At
midnight
,
Leonard
took
his
turn
to
watch
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
bright
moonlight
night
,
but
though
he
occasionally
looked
out
into
the
street
,
and
perceived
Flitcroft
below
,
he
gave
no
intimation
of
his
presence
.
<EOS>
All
at
once
,
however
,
he
was
alarmed
by
a
loud
cry
,
and
opening
the
shutter
,
perceived
the
youth
struggling
with
two
persons
,
whom
he
recognised
as
Sir
Paul
Parravicin
and
Pillichody
.
 
<EOS>
He
shouted
to
them
to
release
their
captive
,
but
they
laughed
at
his
vociferations
,
and
in
spite
of
his
resistance
dragged
the
youth
away
.
<EOS>
Maddened
at
the
sight
,
Leonard
lowered
the
rope
as
quickly
as
he
could
with
the
intention
of
descending
by
it
.
<EOS>
At
this
moment
,
Flitcroft
turned
an
agonized
look
behind
him
,
and
perceiving
what
had
been
done
,
broke
suddenly
from
his
captors
,
and
before
he
could
be
prevented
,
sprang
into
the
basket
,
and
laid
hold
of
the
rope
.
<EOS>
Leonard
,
who
had
seen
the
movement
,
and
divined
its
object
,
drew
up
the
pulley
with
the
quickness
of
thought
;
and
so
expeditiously
was
the
whole
accomplished
,
<EOS>
that
ere
the
knight
and
his
companion
reached
the
spot
<EOS>
,
Flitcroft
was
above
their
heads
,
and
the
next
moment
was
pulled
through
the
window
,
and
in
safety
by
the
side
of
Leonard
.
  
<EOS>
II
.
 
<EOS>
HOW
FIRES
WERE
LIGHTED
IN
THE
STREETS
.
 
<EOS>
Nizza
Macascree
,
for
it
is
useless
to
affect
further
mystery
,
as
soon
as
she
could
find
utterance
,
murmured
her
thanks
to
the
apprentice
,
whose
satisfaction
at
her
deliverance
was
greatly
diminished
by
his
fears
lest
his
master
should
disapprove
of
what
he
had
done
.
<EOS>
Seeing
his
uneasiness
,
and
guessing
the
cause
,
Nizza
hastened
to
relieve
it
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
reproach
myself
bitterly
for
having
placed
you
in
this
situation
!
"
<EOS>
she
said
,
"
but
I
could
not
help
it
,
and
will
free
you
from
my
presence
the
moment
I
can
do
so
with
safety
.
<EOS>
When
I
bade
you
farewell
,
I
meant
it
to
be
for
ever
,
and
persuaded
myself
I
could
adhere
to
my
resolution
.
<EOS>
But
I
was
deceived
.
<EOS>
You
would
pity
me
,
were
I
to
tell
you
the
anguish
I
endured
.
<EOS>
I
could
not
accompany
my
poor
father
in
his
rambles
;
and
if
I
went
forth
at
all
,
my
steps
involuntarily
led
me
to
Wood
-
street
.
<EOS>
At
last
,
I
resolved
to
disguise
myself
,
and
borrowed
this
suit
from
a
Jew
clothesman
,
who
has
a
stall
in
Saint
Paul
's
.
<EOS>
Thus
equipped
,
I
paced
backwards
and
forwards
before
the
house
,
in
the
hope
of
obtaining
a
glimpse
of
you
,
and
fortune
has
favoured
me
more
than
I
expected
,
though
it
has
led
to
this
unhappy
result
.
<EOS>
Heaven
only
knows
what
will
become
of
me
!
"
<EOS>
she
added
,
bursting
into
tears
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
that
the
pestilence
would
select
me
as
one
of
its
victims
.
<EOS>
But
,
like
your
own
sex
,
it
shuns
all
those
who
court
it
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
can
neither
advise
you
,
"
replied
Leonard
,
in
sombre
tone
,
"
nor
help
you
.
<EOS>
Ah
!
"
<EOS>
he
exclaimed
,
as
the
sounds
of
violent
blows
were
heard
against
the
door
<EOS>
below--"your
persecutors
are
trying
to
break
into
the
house
.
"
 
<EOS>
Rushing
to
the
window
,
and
gazing
downwards
,
he
perceived
Sir
Paul
Parravicin
and
Pillichody
battering
against
the
shop
door
,
and
endeavouring
to
burst
it
open
.
<EOS>
It
was
,
however
,
so
stoutly
barricaded
,
that
it
resisted
all
their
efforts
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
is
to
be
done
?
"
cried
Leonard
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
noise
will
certainly
alarm
my
master
,
and
you
will
be
discovered
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Heed
me
not
,
"
rejoined
Nizza
,
distractedly
,
"
you
shall
not
run
any
risk
on
my
account
.
<EOS>
Let
me
down
the
pulley
.
<EOS>
Deliver
me
to
them
.
<EOS>
Anything
is
better
than
that
you
should
suffer
by
my
indiscretion
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
No
,
no
,
"
replied
Leonard
;
"
Mr.
Bloundel
shall
know
all
.
<EOS>
His
love
for
his
own
daughter
will
make
him
feel
for
you
.
<EOS>
But
come
what
will
,
I
will
not
abandon
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
As
he
spoke
a
timid
knock
was
heard
at
the
door
,
and
a
voice
without
exclaimed
,
in
accents
of
the
utmost
trepidation
,
"
Are
you
there
,
Leonard?--Robbers
are
breaking
into
the
house
.
<EOS>
We
shall
all
be
murdered
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Come
in
,
Blaize
,
"
returned
Leonard
,
opening
the
door
and
admitting
the
porter--"you
may
be
of
some
assistance
to
me
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
In
what
way
?
"
demanded
Blaize
.
"
<EOS>
Ah
!
<EOS>
who
's
this
?
<EOS>
"
he
added
,
perceiving
Nizza--"what
<EOS>
is
this
page
doing
here
?
<EOS>
"
 
"
Do
not
concern
yourself
about
him
but
attend
to
me
,
"
replied
Leonard
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
about
to
drive
away
those
persons
from
the
door
.
<EOS>
You
must
lower
me
down
in
the
basket
attached
to
the
pulley
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
And
will
you
dare
to
engage
them
?
"
<EOS>
asked
Blaize
,
peeping
out
at
the
shutter
.
<EOS>
"
They
are
armed
.
<EOS>
As
I
live
,
one
is
Major
Pillichody
,
the
rascal
who
dared
to
make
love
to
Patience
.
<EOS>
I
have
half
a
mind
to
go
down
with
you
,
and
give
him
a
sound
drubbing
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
shall
not
encounter
this
danger
for
me
,
"
interposed
Nizza
,
endeavouring
to
stay
Leonard
,
who
,
having
thrust
a
sword
into
his
girdle
<EOS>
,
was
about
to
pass
through
the
window
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
not
hinder
me
,
"
replied
the
apprentice
,
breaking
from
her
.
"
<EOS>
Take
hold
of
the
rope
,
Blaize
,
and
mind
it
does
not
run
down
too
quickly
.
"
 
<EOS>
With
this
,
he
got
into
the
basket
,
and
as
the
porter
carefully
obeyed
his
instructions
,
he
reached
the
ground
in
safety
.
<EOS>
On
seeing
him
,
Pillichody
bolted
across
the
street
,
and
flourishing
his
sword
,
and
uttering
tremendous
imprecations
,
held
himself
in
readiness
to
beat
an
immediate
retreat
.
<EOS>
Not
so
Parravicin
.
<EOS>
Instantly
assailing
the
apprentice
,
he
slightly
wounded
him
in
the
arm
.
<EOS>
Seeing
how
matters
stood
,
and
that
victory
was
pretty
certain
to
declare
itself
for
his
patron
,
Pillichody
returned
,
and
,
attacking
the
apprentice
,
by
their
combined
efforts
,
he
was
speedily
disarmed
.
<EOS>
Pillichody
would
have
passed
his
sword
through
his
body
,
but
the
knight
stayed
his
hand
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
fool
has
placed
himself
in
our
power
,
"
he
said
,
"
and
he
shall
pay
for
his
temerity
;
nevertheless
,
I
will
spare
his
life
provided
he
assist
us
to
get
into
the
house
,
or
will
deliver
up
Nizza
Macascree
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
will
do
neither
,
"
replied
Leonard
,
fiercely
.
 
<EOS>
Parravicin
raised
his
sword
,
and
was
about
to
strike
,
when
,
at
the
moment
,
the
basket
was
again
quickly
lowered
to
the
ground
.
<EOS>
It
bore
Nizza
Macascree
,
who
,
rushing
between
them
,
arrested
the
stroke
.
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
!
why
have
you
done
this
?
"
<EOS>
cried
Leonard
,
in
a
tone
of
reproach
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
will
tell
you
why
,
"
rejoined
Parravicin
,
triumphantly
;
"
because
she
saw
you
were
unable
to
defend
her
,
and
,
like
a
true
woman
,
surrendered
herself
to
the
victor
.
<EOS>
Take
care
of
him
,
Pillichody
,
while
I
secure
the
girl
.
<EOS>
Spit
him
,
if
he
attempts
to
stir
.
"
 
<EOS>
And
twining
his
arms
round
Nizza
,
notwithstanding
her
shrieks
and
resistance
,
he
bore
her
away
.
<EOS>
Infuriated
by
the
sight
,
Leonard
Holt
threw
himself
upon
Pillichody
,
and
a
desperate
struggle
took
place
between
them
,
which
terminated
this
time
successfully
for
the
apprentice
.
<EOS>
Wresting
his
long
rapier
from
the
bully
,
Leonard
rushed
after
Parravicin
,
and
reached
the
end
of
Wood
-
street
,
just
in
time
to
see
him
spring
into
a
coach
,
and
drive
off
with
his
prize
.
<EOS>
Speeding
after
them
along
Blowbladder
-
street
,
and
Middle
-
row
,
as
Newgate
-
street
was
then
termed
,
the
apprentice
shouted
to
the
coachman
to
stop
,
but
no
attention
being
paid
to
his
vociferations
,
and
finding
pursuit
unavailing
,
he
came
to
a
halt
.
<EOS>
He
then
more
slowly
retraced
his
steps
,
and
on
arriving
at
the
grocer
's
residence
,
found
the
basket
drawn
up
.
<EOS>
Almost
afraid
to
call
out
,
he
at
length
mustered
courage
enough
to
shout
to
Blaize
to
lower
it
,
and
was
answered
by
Mr.
Bloundel
,
who
,
putting
his
head
through
the
window
,
demanded
in
a
stern
tone
why
he
had
left
the
house
?
 
<EOS>
Leonard
briefly
explained
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
deeply
regret
your
imprudence
,
"
replied
his
master
;
"
because
I
can
now
no
more
admit
you
.
<EOS>
It
is
my
fixed
determination
,
as
you
well
know
,
not
to
suffer
any
member
of
my
family
who
may
quit
my
house
,
to
enter
it
again
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
shall
not
attempt
to
remonstrate
with
you
,
sir
,
"
replied
Leonard
.
<EOS>
"
All
I
pray
of
you
is
to
allow
me
to
occupy
this
hutch
,
and
to
act
as
your
porter
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Willingly
,
"
rejoined
Mr.
Bloundel
;
"
and
as
you
have
had
the
plague
,
you
will
run
no
risk
of
infection
.
<EOS>
You
shall
know
all
that
passes
within
doors
;
and
I
only
lament
that
you
should
have
banished
yourself
from
the
asylum
which
I
hoped
to
afford
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
After
some
further
conversation
between
them
,
a
bundle
was
lowered
by
the
grocer
,
containing
a
change
of
clothes
and
a
couple
of
blankets
.
<EOS>
On
receiving
these
,
Leonard
retired
to
the
hutch
,
and
tying
a
handkerchief
round
his
wounded
arm
,
wrapped
himself
in
a
night
trail
,
and
stretching
himself
on
the
ground
,
in
spite
of
his
anxiety
,
soon
sank
asleep
.
<EOS>
He
awoke
about
four
o'clock
in
the
morning
,
with
a
painful
consciousness
of
what
had
taken
place
during
the
night
.
<EOS>
It
was
just
beginning
to
grow
light
,
and
he
walked
across
the
street
to
gaze
at
the
house
from
which
he
was
exiled
.
<EOS>
Its
melancholy
,
uninhabited
look
did
not
serve
to
cheer
him
.
<EOS>
It
seemed
totally
altered
since
he
knew
it
first
.
<EOS>
The
sign
,
which
then
invited
the
passers
-
by
to
enter
the
shop
and
deal
with
its
honest
owner
,
now
appeared
no
longer
significant
,
unless
--
and
it
will
be
remembered
it
was
the
Noah
's
Ark
<EOS>
--
it
could
be
supposed
to
have
reference
to
those
shut
up
within
.
<EOS>
The
apprentice
looked
at
the
habitation
with
misgiving
,
and
,
instead
of
regarding
it
as
a
sanctuary
from
the
pestilence
,
could
not
help
picturing
it
as
a
living
tomb
.
<EOS>
The
last
conversation
he
had
had
with
Amabel
also
arose
forcibly
to
his
recollection
,
and
the
little
likelihood
there
appeared
of
seeing
her
again
gave
him
acute
agony
.
<EOS>
Oppressed
by
this
painful
idea
,
and
unable
to
exclude
from
his
thoughts
the
unhappy
situation
of
Nizza
Macascree
,
he
bent
his
steps
,
scarcely
knowing
whither
he
was
going
,
towards
Saint
Paul
's
.
 
<EOS>
Having
passed
so
much
of
his
time
of
late
in
the
cathedral
,
Leonard
began
to
regard
it
as
a
sort
of
home
,
and
it
now
appeared
like
a
place
of
refuge
to
him
.
<EOS>
Proceeding
to
the
great
western
entrance
,
he
seated
himself
on
one
of
the
large
blocks
of
stone
left
there
by
the
masons
occupied
in
repairing
the
exterior
of
the
fane
.
<EOS>
His
eye
rested
upon
the
mighty
edifice
before
him
,
and
the
clear
sparkling
light
revealed
numberless
points
of
architectural
grandeur
and
beauty
which
he
had
never
before
noticed
.
<EOS>
The
enormous
buttresses
and
lofty
pinnacles
of
the
central
tower
were
tinged
with
the
beams
of
the
rising
sun
,
and
glowed
as
if
built
of
porphyry
.
<EOS>
While
gazing
at
the
summit
of
this
tower
,
and
calling
to
mind
the
magnificent
view
he
had
recently
witnessed
from
it
at
the
same
hour
,
if
a
wish
could
have
transported
him
thither
at
that
moment
,
he
would
have
enjoyed
it
again
.
<EOS>
But
as
this
could
not
be
,
he
tried
to
summon
before
his
mental
vision
the
whole
glorious
prospect
--
the
broad
and
shining
river
,
with
its
moving
or
motionless
craft
--
the
gardens
,
the
noble
mansions
,
the
warehouses
,
and
mighty
wharfs
on
its
banks
--
London
Bridge
,
with
its
enormous
pile
of
habitations
--
the
old
and
picturesque
city
,
with
its
innumerable
towers
,
and
spires
,
and
girdle
of
grey
walls
--
the
green
fields
and
winding
lanes
leading
to
the
lovely
hills
around
it
<EOS>
--
all
these
objects
arose
obedient
to
his
fancy
,
and
came
arrayed
in
colouring
as
fresh
as
that
wherein
they
had
before
appeared
to
him
.
<EOS>
While
thus
occupied
,
his
gaze
remained
riveted
on
the
summit
of
the
central
tower
,
and
he
fancied
he
perceived
some
one
leaning
over
the
balustrade
;
but
as
little
beyond
the
upper
part
of
the
figure
could
be
discerned
,
and
as
it
appeared
perfectly
motionless
,
he
could
not
be
quite
sure
that
his
eyes
did
not
deceive
him
.
<EOS>
Having
gazed
at
the
object
for
some
minutes
,
during
which
it
maintained
the
same
attitude
,
he
continued
his
survey
of
the
pile
,
and
became
so
excited
by
the
sublime
emotions
inspired
by
the
contemplation
,
as
to
be
insensible
to
aught
else
.
 
<EOS>
After
a
while
he
arose
,
and
was
about
to
proceed
towards
the
portico
,
when
,
chancing
to
look
at
the
top
of
the
tower
,
he
remarked
that
the
figure
had
disappeared
,
and
while
wondering
who
it
could
be
,
he
perceived
a
person
emerge
from
one
of
the
tall
windows
in
the
lower
part
of
the
tower
.
<EOS>
It
was
Solomon
Eagle
,
and
he
no
longer
wondered
at
what
he
had
seen
.
<EOS>
The
enthusiast
was
without
his
brazier
,
but
carried
a
long
stout
staff
.
<EOS>
He
ran
along
the
pointed
roof
of
the
nave
with
inconceivable
swiftness
,
till
,
reaching
the
vast
stone
cross
,
upwards
of
twelve
feet
in
height
,
ornamenting
the
western
extremity
,
he
climbed
its
base
,
and
clasping
the
transverse
bar
of
the
sacred
symbol
of
his
faith
with
his
left
arm
,
extended
his
staff
with
his
right
,
and
described
a
circle
,
as
if
pointing
out
the
walls
of
the
city
.
<EOS>
He
then
raised
his
staff
towards
heaven
to
invoke
its
vengeance
,
and
anon
pointed
it
menacingly
downwards
.
<EOS>
After
this
he
broke
into
loud
denunciations
;
but
though
the
apprentice
could
not
hear
the
words
,
he
gathered
their
purport
from
his
gestures
.
 
<EOS>
By
this
time
a
few
masons
had
assembled
,
and
producing
their
implements
,
commenced
working
at
the
blocks
of
stone
.
<EOS>
Glancing
at
the
enthusiast
,
one
of
them
observed
with
a
smile
to
his
companion
,
"
There
is
Solomon
Eagle
pronouncing
his
morning
curse
upon
the
city
.
<EOS>
I
wonder
whether
the
judgments
he
utters
against
it
will
come
to
pass
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Assuredly
,
Phil
Gatford
,
"
replied
the
other
mason
,
gravely
;
"
and
I
look
upon
all
the
work
we
are
now
doing
as
labour
thrown
away
.
<EOS>
Was
he
not
right
about
the
plague
?
<EOS>
Did
he
not
foretell
the
devouring
scourge
by
which
we
are
visited
?
<EOS>
And
he
will
be
right
also
about
the
fire
.
<EOS>
Since
he
has
doomed
it
,
this
cathedral
will
be
consumed
by
flames
,
and
one
stone
will
not
be
left
standing
on
another
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
strange
,
Ned
Turgis
,
"
observed
Gatford
,
"
that
,
though
Solomon
Eagle
may
always
be
seen
at
daybreak
at
the
top
of
the
tower
or
on
the
roof
of
the
cathedral
--
sometimes
at
one
point
and
sometimes
at
another
--
no
one
can
tell
where
he
hides
himself
at
other
times
.
<EOS>
He
no
longer
roams
the
streets
at
night
,
but
you
may
remember
when
the
officers
of
justice
were
in
search
of
him
,
to
give
evidence
against
Mother
Malmayns
and
Chowles
,
he
was
not
to
be
found
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
remember
it
,
"
replied
Turgis
;
"
but
I
have
no
doubt
he
was
hidden
in
some
out
-
of
-
the
-
way
corner
of
the
cathedral
--
perhaps
among
the
immense
wooden
beams
of
the
clerestory
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Or
in
some
of
the
secret
passages
or
cells
contrived
in
the
thickness
of
the
walls
,
"
rejoined
the
first
speaker
.
<EOS>
"
I
say
,
Ned
Turgis
,
if
the
plague
increases
,
as
there
is
every
likelihood
<EOS>
it
will
,
Solomon
Eagle
will
be
the
only
preacher
left
in
Saint
Paul
's
.
<EOS>
Neither
deans
,
prebends
,
minor
-
canons
,
nor
vicars
will
attend
.
<EOS>
As
it
is
,
they
have
almost
abandoned
it
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Shame
on
them
!
"
exclaimed
Leonard
Holt
,
who
,
being
much
interested
in
the
conversation
of
the
masons
,
had
silently
approached
them
.
<EOS>
"
At
this
season
,
more
than
ever
,
they
are
bound
to
attend
to
their
duty
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Why
,
so
I
think
,
"
rejoined
Gatford
;
"
but
I
suppose
they
consider
self
-
preservation
their
first
duty
.
<EOS>
They
aver
that
all
assemblages
,
whether
called
together
for
religious
purposes
or
not
,
are
dangerous
,
and
likely
to
extend
the
pestilence
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
And
yet
crowds
are
permitted
to
assemble
for
purposes
of
amusement
,
if
not
for
worship
,
in
those
holy
walls
,
"
returned
Leonard
.
 
<EOS>
"
Not
so
,
"
replied
Gatford
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Very
few
persons
now
come
there
,
and
none
for
amusement
.
<EOS>
Paul
's
Walk
is
completely
deserted
.
<EOS>
The
shops
and
stalls
have
been
removed
,
and
the
pillars
to
which
they
were
attached
are
restored
to
their
former
appearance
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
glad
to
hear
it
,
"
rejoined
Leonard
.
<EOS>
"
I
would
far
rather
the
sacred
edifice
were
altogether
abandoned
than
be
what
it
has
been
of
late
--
a
den
of
thieves
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
was
a
stable
and
a
magazine
of
arms
in
the
time
of
the
Commonwealth
,
"
remarked
Gatford
.
 
<EOS>
"
And
if
Solomon
Eagle
's
foreboding
come
to
pass
,
it
will
be
a
heap
of
ruins
in
our
own
time
,
"
rejoined
Turgis
.
<EOS>
"
But
I
see
the
prophet
of
ill
has
quitted
his
post
,
and
retired
to
his
hiding
-
place
.
"
 
<EOS>
Looking
up
as
this
was
said
,
Leonard
saw
that
the
enthusiast
had
disappeared
.
<EOS>
At
this
moment
the
great
door
of
the
cathedral
was
thrown
open
,
and
,
quitting
the
masons
,
he
ascended
the
broad
steps
under
the
portico
,
and
entered
the
fane
,
where
he
found
that
the
information
he
had
received
was
correct
,
and
that
the
stalls
and
other
disfigurements
to
the
pillars
had
been
removed
.
<EOS>
After
pacing
the
solitary
aisles
for
some
time
,
he
made
inquiries
from
the
verger
concerning
Solomon
Eagle
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
know
nothing
about
him
,
"
replied
the
man
,
reluctantly
.
<EOS>
"
I
believe
he
always
appears
at
daybreak
on
some
part
of
the
roof
,
but
I
am
as
ignorant
as
yourself
where
he
hides
himself
.
<EOS>
The
door
of
the
winding
staircase
leading
to
the
central
tower
is
open
.
<EOS>
You
can
ascend
it
,
and
search
for
him
,
if
you
think
proper
.
"
 
<EOS>
Acting
upon
the
suggestion
,
Leonard
mounted
to
the
belfry
,
and
from
thence
to
the
summit
of
the
tower
.
<EOS>
Having
indulged
himself
with
a
brief
survey
of
the
glorious
view
around
,
he
descended
,
and
glanced
into
every
cell
and
chamber
as
he
passed
,
in
the
hopes
of
meeting
with
the
enthusiast
,
but
he
was
disappointed
.
<EOS>
At
length
,
as
he
got
about
half
-
way
down
,
he
felt
his
arm
forcibly
grasped
,
and
,
<EOS>
instantly
conjecturing
who
it
was
,
offered
no
resistance
.
<EOS>
Without
uttering
a
word
,
the
person
who
had
seized
him
dragged
him
up
a
few
steps
,
pushed
aside
a
secret
door
,
which
closed
behind
them
with
a
hollow
clangour
,
and
leading
him
along
a
dark
narrow
passage
,
opened
another
door
,
and
they
emerged
upon
the
roof
.
<EOS>
He
then
found
that
his
suspicion
was
correct
,
and
that
his
mysterious
guide
was
no
other
than
Solomon
Eagle
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
glad
to
find
you
have
recovered
from
the
pestilence
,
"
said
the
enthusiast
,
regarding
him
with
a
friendly
glance
;
"
it
proves
you
are
favoured
by
Heaven
.
<EOS>
I
saw
you
in
the
open
space
before
the
cathedral
this
morning
,
and
instantly
recognised
you
.
<EOS>
I
was
in
the
belfry
when
you
descended
,
but
you
did
not
perceive
me
,
and
I
wished
to
be
certain
you
were
alone
before
I
discovered
myself
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
have
ceased
to
roam
the
streets
at
night
,
and
rouse
the
slumbering
citizens
to
repentance
?
"
asked
Leonard
.
 
<EOS>
"
For
the
present
I
have
,
"
returned
Solomon
Eagle
.
<EOS>
"
But
I
shall
appear
again
when
I
am
required
.
<EOS>
But
you
shall
now
learn
why
I
have
brought
you
hither
.
<EOS>
Look
along
those
streets
,
"
he
added
,
pointing
to
the
thoroughfares
opening
in
different
directions
.
<EOS>
"
What
see
you
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
see
men
piling
heaps
of
wood
and
coals
at
certain
distances
,
as
if
they
were
preparing
bonfires
,
"
replied
Leonard
.
"
<EOS>
And
yet
it
can
not
be
.
<EOS>
This
is
no
season
for
rejoicing
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
has
been
supposed
that
the
lighting
of
many
thousand
fires
at
once
will
purify
the
air
,
"
replied
Solomon
Eagle
;
"
and
therefore
the
Lord
Mayor
has
given
orders
that
heaps
of
fuel
shall
be
placed
before
every
house
in
every
street
in
the
city
,
and
that
all
these
heaps
shall
be
kindled
at
a
certain
hour
.
<EOS>
But
it
will
be
of
no
avail
.
<EOS>
The
weather
is
now
fine
and
settled
,
and
the
sky
cloudless
.
<EOS>
But
the
offended
Deity
will
cause
the
heaviest
rain
to
descend
,
and
extinguish
their
fires
.
<EOS>
No
--
the
way
to
avert
the
pestilence
is
not
by
fire
,
but
by
prayer
and
penitence
,
by
humiliation
and
fasting
.
<EOS>
Let
this
sinful
people
put
on
sackcloth
and
ashes
.
<EOS>
Let
them
beseech
God
,
by
constant
prayer
,
to
forgive
them
,
and
they
may
prevail
,
but
not
otherwise
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
And
when
are
these
fires
to
be
lighted
?
"
asked
the
apprentice
.
 
<EOS>
"
To
-
night
,
at
midnight
,
"
replied
Solomon
Eagle
.
 
<EOS>
He
then
took
Leonard
by
the
hand
,
and
led
him
back
the
same
way
he
had
brought
him
.
<EOS>
On
reaching
the
spiral
staircase
,
he
said
,
"
If
you
desire
to
behold
a
sight
,
such
as
a
man
has
seldom
witnessed
,
ascend
to
the
summit
of
this
tower
an
hour
after
midnight
,
when
all
these
fires
are
lighted
.
<EOS>
A
small
door
on
the
left
of
the
northern
entrance
shall
be
left
open
.
<EOS>
It
will
conduct
you
to
the
back
of
the
choir
,
and
you
must
then
find
your
way
hither
as
well
as
you
can
.
"
 
<EOS>
Murmuring
his
thanks
,
Leonard
hurried
down
the
spiral
staircase
,
and
quitting
the
cathedral
,
proceeded
in
the
direction
of
Wood
-
street
.
<EOS>
Preparations
were
everywhere
making
for
carrying
the
Lord
Mayor
's
orders
into
effect
;
and
such
was
the
beneficial
result
anticipated
,
that
a
general
liveliness
prevailed
,
on
reaching
his
master
's
residence
,
he
found
him
at
the
shutter
,
curious
to
know
what
was
going
forward
;
and
having
informed
him
,
the
grocer
immediately
threw
him
down
money
to
procure
wood
and
coal
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
but
<EOS>
little
faith
in
the
experiment
,
"
he
said
,
"
but
the
Lord
Mayor
's
injunctions
must
be
obeyed
.
"
 
<EOS>
With
the
help
of
Dallison
,
who
had
now
arrived
,
Leonard
Holt
soon
procured
a
large
heap
of
fuel
,
and
placed
it
in
the
middle
of
the
street
.
<EOS>
The
day
was
passed
in
executing
other
commissions
for
the
grocer
,
and
he
took
his
meals
in
the
hutch
with
the
porter
.
<EOS>
Time
appeared
to
pass
with
unusual
slowness
,
and
not
he
alone
,
but
anxious
thousands
,
awaited
the
signal
to
kindle
their
fires
.
<EOS>
The
night
was
profoundly
dark
and
sultry
,
and
Leonard
could
not
help
thinking
that
the
enthusiast
's
prediction
would
be
verified
,
and
that
rain
would
fall
.
<EOS>
But
these
gloomy
anticipations
vanished
as
the
hour
of
midnight
was
tolled
forth
by
the
neighbouring
clocks
of
Saint
Michael
's
and
Saint
Alban
's
.
<EOS>
Scarcely
had
the
strokes
died
away
,
when
Leonard
seized
a
light
and
set
fire
to
the
pile
.
<EOS>
Ten
thousand
other
piles
were
kindled
at
the
same
moment
,
and
in
an
instant
the
pitchy
darkness
was
converted
into
light
as
bright
as
that
of
noonday
.
 
<EOS>
Anxious
to
behold
this
prodigious
illumination
at
its
best
,
Leonard
Holt
committed
the
replenishing
of
the
pile
and
the
custody
of
the
house
to
Dallison
,
and
hastened
to
Saint
Paul
's
.
<EOS>
A
great
fire
was
burning
at
each
angle
of
the
cathedral
,
but
without
pausing
to
notice
the
effect
of
the
flames
upon
the
walls
of
the
building
,
he
passed
through
the
door
to
which
he
had
been
directed
,
and
hastening
to
the
spiral
staircase
beyond
the
choir
,
ascended
it
with
swift
steps
.
<EOS>
He
did
not
pause
till
he
reached
the
summit
of
the
tower
,
and
there
,
indeed
,
a
wondrous
spectacle
awaited
him
.
<EOS>
The
whole
city
seemed
on
fire
,
and
girded
with
a
flaming
belt
--
for
piles
were
lighted
at
certain
distances
along
the
whole
line
of
walls
.
<EOS>
The
groups
of
dark
figures
collected
round
the
fires
added
to
their
picturesque
effect
;
and
the
course
of
every
street
could
be
traced
by
the
reflection
of
the
flames
on
the
walls
and
gables
of
the
houses
.
<EOS>
London
Bridge
was
discernible
from
the
fires
burning
upon
it
--
and
even
upon
the
river
braziers
were
lighted
on
all
the
larger
craft
,
which
cast
a
ruddy
glow
upon
the
stream
.
 
<EOS>
After
gazing
at
this
extraordinary
sight
for
some
time
,
Leonard
began
to
descend
.
<EOS>
As
yet
he
had
seen
nothing
of
Solomon
Eagle
,
and
searching
for
him
in
vain
in
the
belfry
,
he
quitted
the
cathedral
.
<EOS>
From
a
knot
of
persons
gathered
round
one
of
the
fires
he
learnt
that
the
enthusiast
was
addressing
the
crowd
at
the
west
side
of
the
building
,
and
proceeding
thither
<EOS>
he
perceived
him
standing
on
the
edge
of
the
balustrade
of
the
south
-
western
tower
,
surmounting
the
little
church
of
Saint
Gregory
.
<EOS>
His
brazier
was
placed
on
one
of
the
buttresses
,
and
threw
its
light
on
the
mighty
central
tower
of
the
fabric
,
and
on
a
large
clock
-
face
immediately
beneath
.
<EOS>
Solomon
Eagle
was
evidently
denouncing
the
city
,
but
his
words
were
lost
in
the
distance
.
<EOS>
As
he
proceeded
,
a
loud
clap
of
thunder
pealed
overhead
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
comes
--
it
comes
!
"
<EOS>
cried
the
enthusiast
,
in
a
voice
that
could
be
distinctly
heard
in
the
death
-
like
stillness
that
followed
the
thunder
.
<EOS>
"
The
wrath
of
Heaven
is
at
hand
.
"
 
<EOS>
As
he
spoke
,
a
bright
flash
cut
the
air
,
and
a
bolt
struck
down
,
one
of
the
pinnacles
of
the
great
tower
.
<EOS>
Flash
after
flash
followed
in
quick
succession
,
and
the
enthusiast
,
who
seemed
wrapped
in
flame
,
extended
his
arms
towards
Heaven
,
as
if
beseeching
a
further
display
of
its
vengeance
.
<EOS>
Suddenly
the
lightning
ceased
to
flash
and
the
thunder
to
roll
.
<EOS>
A
few
heavy
drops
of
rain
fell
.
<EOS>
These
were
succeeded
by
a
deluging
shower
of
such
violence
,
that
in
less
than
a
quarter
of
an
hour
every
fire
within
the
city
was
extinguished
,
and
all
was
darkness
and
despair
.
 
<EOS>
The
deepest
gloom
and
despondency
prevailed
that
night
throughout
London
.
<EOS>
The
sudden
storm
was
regarded
as
a
manifestation
of
the
displeasure
of
Heaven
,
and
as
an
intimation
that
the
arrows
of
its
wrath
were
not
to
be
turned
aside
by
any
human
efforts
.
<EOS>
So
impressed
were
all
with
this
feeling
,
that
when
,
in
less
than
half
an
hour
,
the
rain
entirely
ceased
,
the
clouds
cleared
off
,
and
the
stars
again
poured
down
their
lustre
,
no
one
attempted
to
relight
the
quenched
embers
,
fearing
to
provoke
the
Divine
vengeance
.
<EOS>
Nor
was
a
monitor
wanting
to
enforce
the
awful
lesson
.
<EOS>
Solomon
Eagle
,
with
his
brazier
on
his
head
,
ran
through
the
streets
,
calling
on
the
inhabitants
to
take
to
heart
what
had
happened
,
to
repent
,
and
prepare
for
their
doom
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
Lord
will
not
spare
you
,
"
he
cried
,
as
he
stationed
himself
in
the
open
space
before
St.
Stephen
's
,
Walbrook
.
"
<EOS>
He
will
visit
your
sins
upon
you
.
<EOS>
Pray
,
therefore
,
that
ye
may
not
be
destroyed
,
both
body
and
soul
.
<EOS>
Little
time
is
allowed
you
for
repentance
.
<EOS>
Many
that
hear
me
shall
not
live
till
tomorrow
;
few
shall
survive
the
year
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
Thou
,
thyself
,
shalt
not
survive
the
night
,
false
prophet
,
"
cried
a
voice
from
a
neighbouring
window
.
<EOS>
And
immediately
afterwards
the
barrel
of
a
gun
was
thrust
forth
and
a
shot
fired
at
the
enthusiast
.
<EOS>
But
though
Solomon
Eagle
never
altered
his
position
,
he
was
wholly
uninjured
--
the
ball
striking
a
bystander
,
who
fell
to
the
ground
mortally
wounded
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
have
shot
your
own
son
,
Mr.
Westwood
,
"
cried
one
of
the
spectators
,
rushing
up
to
the
fallen
man
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Who
will
henceforth
doubt
that
Solomon
Eagle
is
under
the
care
of
a
special
providence
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Not
I
,
"
replied
another
spectator
.
<EOS>
"
I
shall
never
disregard
his
words
in
future
.
"
 
<EOS>
Setting
down
his
brazier
,
the
enthusiast
bent
over
the
dead
man
--
for
dead
he
was
--
and
noted
the
placid
smile
upon
his
features
.
<EOS>
By
this
time
the
unfortunate
father
had
joined
the
group
,
and
,
on
seeing
the
body
of
his
son
,
wrung
his
hands
in
a
pitiable
manner
,
and
gave
utterance
to
the
wildest
expression
of
despair
.
<EOS>
No
one
attempted
to
seize
him
,
till
at
length
Solomon
Eagle
,
rising
from
his
kneeling
posture
,
laid
his
hand
upon
his
arm
,
and
regarding
him
sternly
,
said
,
"
What
wrong
have
I
done
you
,
that
you
should
seek
to
slay
me
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
What
wrong
?
<EOS>
"
rejoined
Westwood--"such
wrong
as
can
never
be
repaired
.
<EOS>
Your
fearful
prophecies
and
denunciations
so
terrified
my
daughter
,
that
she
died
distracted
.
<EOS>
My
brokenhearted
wife
was
not
long
in
following
her
;
and
now
you
have
made
me
the
murderer
of
my
son
.
<EOS>
Complete
the
tragedy
,
and
take
my
life
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
no
desire
to
do
so
,
"
replied
Solomon
Eagle
,
in
a
tone
of
commiseration
.
<EOS>
"
My
wish
is
to
save
your
soul
,
and
the
souls
of
all
who
listen
to
me
.
<EOS>
I
wonder
not
that
your
anger
was
at
first
stirred
against
me
;
but
if
your
heart
had
been
properly
directed
,
indignation
would
have
soon
given
way
to
better
feelings
.
<EOS>
My
mission
is
not
to
terrify
,
but
to
warn
.
<EOS>
Why
will
ye
thus
continue
impenitent
when
ye
are
spoken
to
,
not
by
my
voice
alone
,
but
by
a
thousand
others?--by
<EOS>
the
thunder
--
by
the
rain
--
by
the
pestilence!--and
ye
shall
be
spoken
to
,
if
ye
continue
senseless
,
by
fire
and
by
famine
.
<EOS>
Look
at
these
quenched
embers
--
at
these
flooded
streets
--
they
are
types
of
your
vain
struggle
with
a
superior
power
.
<EOS>
Now
,
mark
me
what
you
must
do
to
free
the
city
from
contagion
.
<EOS>
You
must
utterly
and
for
ever
abandon
your
evil
courses
.
<EOS>
You
must
pray
incessantly
for
remission
of
your
sins
.
<EOS>
You
must
resign
yourselves
without
repining
to
such
chastisement
as
you
have
provoked
,
and
must
put
your
whole
trust
and
confidence
in
God
.
<EOS>
Do
this
,
and
do
it
heartily
;
it
is
possible
that
His
wrath
may
be
averted
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
feel
the
force
of
your
words
,
"
<EOS>
faltered
<EOS>
Westwood--"would
<EOS>
I
had
felt
it
sooner
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
Repentance
never
comes
too
late
,
"
rejoined
the
enthusiast
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Let
this
be
an
example
to
you
all
.
"
 
<EOS>
And
snatching
up
his
brazier
,
he
continued
his
course
at
the
same
lightning
speed
as
before
.
<EOS>
The
unfortunate
father
was
taken
into
his
own
dwelling
,
whither
likewise
the
body
of
his
son
was
conveyed
.
<EOS>
A
strict
watch
was
kept
over
him
during
the
night
,
and
in
the
morning
he
was
removed
to
Newgate
,
where
he
perished
,
in
less
than
a
week
,
of
the
distemper
.
 
<EOS>
The
aspect
of
the
streets
on
the
following
day
was
deplorable
enough
.
<EOS>
Not
that
the
weather
was
unfavourable
.
<EOS>
On
the
contrary
,
it
was
bright
and
sunny
,
while
the
heated
atmosphere
,
cooled
,
by
the
showers
,
felt
no
longer
oppressive
.
<EOS>
But
the
sight
of
the
half
-
burnt
fires
struck
a
chill
into
every
bosom
,
and
it
was
not
until
the
heaps
were
removed
,
that
the
more
timorous
ventured
forth
at
all
.
<EOS>
The
result
,
too
,
of
the
experiment
was
singularly
unfortunate
.
<EOS>
Whether
it
was
from
the
extraordinary
heat
occasioned
by
the
lighting
of
so
many
fires
,
or
that
the
smoke
did
not
ascend
,
and
so
kept
down
the
pestilential
effluvia
,
or
that
the
number
of
persons
who
met
together
spread
the
contagion
,
<EOS>
certain
it
was
that
the
pestilence
was
more
widely
extended
than
before
,
and
the
mortality
fearfully
increased
.
 
<EOS>
On
the
commencement
of
the
storm
,
Leonard
Holt
hurried
back
to
Wood
-
street
,
and
reached
his
master
's
dwelling
just
as
the
rain
began
to
descend
in
torrents
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Bloundel
was
at
the
window
,
and
a
few
words
only
passed
between
him
and
the
apprentice
when
the
latter
was
compelled
to
take
refuge
in
the
hutch
.
<EOS>
Here
he
found
Dallison
the
watchman
,
and
they
listened
in
awe
-
struck
silence
to
the
heavy
showers
,
and
to
the
hissing
of
the
blazing
embers
in
their
struggle
against
the
hostile
element
.
<EOS>
By
-
and
-
by
the
latter
sound
ceased
.
<EOS>
Not
a
light
could
be
seen
throughout
the
whole
length
of
the
street
,
nor
was
there
any
red
reflection
of
the
innumerable
fires
as
heretofore
in
the
sky
.
<EOS>
It
was
evident
all
were
extinguished
;
and
the
pitiless
pelting
of
the
rain
,
the
roar
of
the
water
-
spouts
,
and
the
rush
of
the
over
-
filled
kennels
,
now
converted
into
rivulets
,
could
alone
be
heard
After
awhile
the
storm
cleared
off
,
and
Leonard
and
his
companion
issued
from
their
retreat
,
and
gazed
in
silence
at
the
drenched
heap
before
them
.
<EOS>
While
thus
occupied
,
the
window
above
them
opened
,
and
the
grocer
appeared
at
it
.
 
<EOS>
"
This
is
,
indeed
,
a
sad
and
striking
lesson
,
"
he
said
,
"
<EOS>
and
I
hope
will
not
be
lost
upon
those
who
have
witnessed
it
.
<EOS>
It
shows
the
utter
impotency
of
a
struggle
against
the
Divine
will
,
and
that
when
a
man
relies
upon
himself
for
preservation
,
he
depends
upon
a
broken
reed
.
<EOS>
If
I
did
not
place
myself
under
Heaven
's
protection
,
I
should
be
sure
that
all
my
own
precautions
were
unavailing
.
<EOS>
I
am
now
about
to
call
up
my
family
to
prayer
.
<EOS>
You
can
join
us
in
our
supplications
,
and
I
trust
they
will
not
be
unheard
.
"
 
<EOS>
Closing
the
window
,
the
grocer
retired
,
and
Leonard
returned
to
the
hutch
,
where
he
fell
upon
his
knees
,
and
as
soon
as
he
supposed
the
family
were
gathered
together
,
commenced
his
own
prayers
.
<EOS>
He
pictured
the
whole
group
assembled
--
the
fervour
of
the
grocer
excited
to
an
unwonted
pitch
by
what
had
just
occurred
--
the
earnest
countenances
of
his
wife
and
the
younger
children
--
and
the
exalted
looks
of
Amabel
.
<EOS>
He
could
not
see
her
--
neither
could
he
hear
her
voice
--
but
he
fancied
how
she
looked
,
and
in
what
terms
she
prayed
--
and
it
was
no
slight
satisfaction
to
him
to
think
that
his
own
voice
ascended
to
Heaven
coupled
with
hers
.
 
<EOS>
On
quitting
the
hutch
,
he
found
Dallison
conversing
with
Doctor
Hodges
.
<EOS>
The
physician
expressed
great
surprise
at
seeing
him
,
and
inquired
how
he
came
to
have
left
his
master
's
house
.
<EOS>
Leonard
related
all
that
had
happened
,
and
besought
his
assistance
in
Nizza
's
behalf
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
will
do
all
I
can
for
her
,
"
replied
Hodges
,
"
<EOS>
for
I
feel
greatly
interested
about
her
.
<EOS>
But
who
is
this
Sir
Paul
Parravicin
?
<EOS>
I
never
heard
of
him
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
know
nothing
more
of
him
than
what
I
have
told
you
,
sir
,
"
replied
Leonard
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He
is
a
friend
of
the
Earl
of
Rochester
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
must
be
a
feigned
name
,
"
rejoined
Hodges
;
"
but
I
will
speedily
find
him
out
.
<EOS>
You
must
lodge
at
my
house
tonight
.
<EOS>
It
will
be
better
for
you
than
sleeping
in
that
damp
shed
.
<EOS>
But
,
first
,
I
must
have
a
word
or
two
with
your
master
.
<EOS>
I
have
been
abroad
all
night
,
and
came
hither
to
ascertain
what
he
thought
of
this
plan
of
the
fires
,
and
what
he
had
done
.
<EOS>
How
do
you
give
the
signal
to
him
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
There
is
a
cord
within
the
hutch
by
which
you
can
sound
a
bell
within
his
chamber
,
"
returned
Leonard
;
"
I
will
ring
it
.
"
 
<EOS>
Accordingly
,
he
did
so
,
and
the
summons
was
almost
instantly
answered
by
the
grocer
.
<EOS>
A
kindly
greeting
passed
between
the
latter
and
Hodges
,
who
inquired
whether
all
was
going
on
satisfactorily
within
,
and
whether
anything
could
be
done
for
the
family
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
would
not
have
disturbed
you
at
this
unseasonable
hour
,
"
he
said
,
"
but
chancing
to
be
in
your
neighbourhood
,
and
thinking
it
likely
you
would
be
on
the
watch
,
I
called
to
have
a
word
with
you
.
<EOS>
Though
I
could
not
foresee
what
would
happen
,
I
entirely
disapproved
of
these
fires
as
likely
to
increase
rather
than
check
the
pestilence
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
The
hand
of
Heaven
has
extinguished
them
because
they
were
lighted
in
opposition
to
its
decrees
,
"
replied
Bloundel
;
"
but
you
have
asked
me
whether
all
is
going
on
well
within
.
<EOS>
I
should
answer
readily
in
the
affirmative
,
but
that
my
wife
expresses
much
anxiety
respecting
Amabel
.
<EOS>
We
have
no
longer
any
apprehension
of
misconduct
.
<EOS>
She
is
all
we
could
desire
--
serious
and
devout
.
<EOS>
But
we
have
fears
for
her
health
.
<EOS>
The
confinement
may
be
too
much
for
her
.
<EOS>
What
would
you
recommend
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
must
see
her
to
be
able
to
speak
confidently
,
"
replied
Hodges
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
know
not
how
that
can
be
accomplished
,
unless
you
choose
to
ascend
by
a
basket
attached
to
the
pulley
,
"
replied
the
grocer
,
with
some
hesitation
,
"
and
it
is
against
my
plan
to
admit
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
But
your
daughter
's
life
,
my
good
friend
,
"
rejoined
Hodges
;
"
think
of
that
.
<EOS>
If
I
choose
to
risk
life
and
limb
to
visit
her
,
you
may
surely
risk
the
chance
of
contagion
to
admit
me
.
<EOS>
But
you
need
have
no
fear
.
<EOS>
Sprinkle
your
room
with
spirits
of
sulphur
,
and
place
a
phial
of
vinegar
so
that
I
can
use
it
on
my
first
entrance
into
the
house
,
and
I
will
answer
for
the
safety
of
your
family
.
"
 
<EOS>
These
preparations
made
,
Mr.
Bloundel
lowered
the
basket
,
into
which
Hodges
got
,
and
grasping
the
rope
,
not
without
some
misgiving
on
his
part
,
he
was
drawn
up
.
<EOS>
Leonard
witnessed
his
ascent
with
a
beating
heart
,
and
could
scarcely
repress
a
feeling
of
envy
when
he
saw
him
pass
through
the
window
,
and
knew
that
he
would
soon
be
in
the
presence
of
Amabel
.
<EOS>
But
this
feeling
quickly
changed
into
one
of
deep
anxiety
concerning
her
.
<EOS>
Her
father
's
account
of
her
had
increased
the
uneasiness
he
previously
felt
,
and
he
was
as
anxious
to
know
the
doctor
's
opinion
of
her
,
as
if
his
own
fate
had
depended
upon
it
.
<EOS>
He
was
kept
in
this
painful
state
of
suspense
for
nearly
an
hour
,
when
voices
were
heard
at
the
window
,
and
presently
afterwards
Hodges
was
carefully
let
down
.
<EOS>
Bidding
the
grocer
farewell
,
he
desired
Leonard
to
follow
him
,
and
led
the
way
towards
Cheapside
.
<EOS>
They
proceeded
a
short
distance
in
silence
,
when
the
latter
ventured
to
remark
,
"
You
say
nothing
about
Amabel
,
sir
?
<EOS>
I
fear
you
found
her
seriously
indisposed
.
<EOS>
"
 
"
Do
not
question
me
about
her
just
now
,
"
rejoined
the
doctor
,
in
a
subdued
emotion
.
<EOS>
"
I
would
rather
not
discuss
the
subject
.
"
 
<EOS>
Nothing
more
was
said
;
for
though
the
apprentice
would
willingly
have
continued
the
conversation
,
his
companion
's
evident
disinclination
to
pursue
it
compelled
him
to
desist
.
<EOS>
In
this
way
,
they
reached
the
doctor
's
residence
,
where
Leonard
was
immediately
shown
to
a
comfortable
bed
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
late
when
he
awoke
next
day
,
and
as
the
doctor
was
gone
forth
,
he
partook
of
a
plentiful
breakfast
which
was
placed
before
him
,
and
repaired
to
Wood
-
street
,
but
his
master
having
no
commissions
for
him
to
execute
,
he
went
back
again
.
<EOS>
By
this
time
,
Doctor
Hodges
had
returned
,
and
calling
him
into
his
library
told
him
he
wished
to
speak
with
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
were
right
last
night
,
"
he
said
,
"
in
construing
my
silence
into
alarm
for
Amabel
.
<EOS>
In
truth
,
I
fear
she
is
rapidly
sinking
into
a
decline
,
and
nothing
will
arrest
the
progress
of
the
insidious
disease
but
instant
removal
to
the
country
.
<EOS>
To
this
she
will
not
consent
,
neither
do
I
know
how
it
could
be
accomplished
.
<EOS>
It
is
pitiable
to
see
so
lovely
a
creature
dying
,
as
I
fear
she
is
,
of
a
broken
heart
.
"
 
<EOS>
Leonard
covered
his
face
with
his
hands
,
and
wept
aloud
.
 
<EOS>
"
We
have
not
yet
spoken
of
Nizza
Macascree
,
"
said
Hodges
,
after
a
pause
,
tapping
him
kindly
on
the
shoulder
.
<EOS>
"
I
think
I
have
discovered
a
trace
of
her
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
glad
to
hear
it
,
"
replied
Leonard
,
rousing
himself
.
<EOS>
"
She
is
another
victim
of
these
profligates
.
<EOS>
But
I
will
be
revenged
upon
them
all
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
before
enjoined
you
to
restrain
your
indignation
,
just
though
it
be
,
"
returned
Hodges
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
not
yet
found
out
whither
she
has
been
taken
.
<EOS>
But
I
have
a
clue
which
,
unless
I
am
mistaken
,
will
lead
me
to
it
.
<EOS>
But
I
must
now
dismiss
you
,
I
have
other
affairs
to
attend
to
,
and
must
give
a
dangerous
and
difficult
case
,
on
which
I
have
been
consulted
,
undisturbed
consideration
.
<EOS>
Make
my
house
your
home
as
long
as
you
think
proper
.
"
 
<EOS>
Warmly
thanking
the
doctor
,
Leonard
then
withdrew
.
<EOS>
Shortly
after
this
,
he
walked
forth
,
and
ascertaining
that
he
was
not
required
by
his
master
,
determined
to
satisfy
himself
by
actual
observation
of
the
extent
of
the
ravages
of
the
plague
.
 
<EOS>
With
this
view
,
he
shaped
his
course
along
Lad
-
lane
,
and
traversing
Cateaton
-
street
,
entered
Lothbury
.
<EOS>
The
number
of
houses
which
he
here
found
closed
,
with
red
crosses
on
the
doors
,
and
the
fatal
inscription
above
them
,
convinced
him
that
the
deplorable
accounts
he
had
heard
were
not
exaggerated
.
<EOS>
In
passing
some
of
these
habitations
,
he
saw
such
ghastly
faces
at
the
windows
,
and
heard
such
lamentable
cries
,
that
he
was
glad
to
hurry
on
and
get
out
of
sight
and
hearing
.
<EOS>
In
Throgmorton
-
street
,
nearly
opposite
Drapers
'
Hall
,
a
poor
wretch
suddenly
opened
a
casement
,
and
before
his
attendants
could
force
him
back
,
threw
himself
from
a
great
height
to
the
ground
,
and
broke
his
neck
.
<EOS>
Another
incident
,
of
an
equally
distressing
nature
,
occurred
.
<EOS>
A
young
and
richly
-
dressed
young
man
issued
from
a
tavern
in
Broad
-
street
,
and
with
a
wild
and
inflamed
countenance
,
staggered
along
.
<EOS>
He
addressed
some
insulting
language
to
Leonard
,
but
the
latter
,
who
desired
no
quarrel
,
disregarded
his
remarks
,
and
let
him
pass
.
<EOS>
The
next
person
encountered
by
the
drunken
man
was
a
young
female
.
<EOS>
Suddenly
catching
her
in
his
arms
,
he
imprinted
a
kiss
upon
her
lips
:
and
then
,
with
a
frightful
laugh
,
shouted
,
"
I
have
given
you
the
plague
!
<EOS>
Look
here
!
"
and
tearing
aside
the
collar
of
his
shirt
,
he
exhibited
a
large
tumour
.
<EOS>
The
young
woman
uttered
a
shriek
of
terror
and
fainted
,
while
her
ruthless
assailant
took
to
his
heels
,
and
running
as
long
as
his
strength
lasted
,
fell
down
,
and
was
taken
to
the
pest
-
house
,
where
he
was
joined
that
same
night
by
his
victim
.
<EOS>
And
this
was
by
no
means
an
uncommon
occurrence
.
<EOS>
The
distemper
acted
differently
on
different
temperaments
.
<EOS>
Some
it
inflamed
to
an
ungovernable
pitch
of
madness
,
others
it
reduced
to
the
depths
of
despair
,
while
in
many
cases
it
brought
out
and
aggravated
the
worst
parts
of
the
character
.
<EOS>
Wives
conveyed
the
infection
intentionally
to
their
husbands
,
husbands
to
their
wives
,
parents
to
their
children
,
lovers
to
the
objects
of
their
affection
,
while
,
as
in
the
case
above
mentioned
,
many
persons
ran
about
like
rabid
hounds
,
striving
to
communicate
it
to
all
they
met
.
<EOS>
Greatly
shocked
at
what
had
occurred
,
and
yet
not
altogether
surprised
at
it
,
for
his
mind
had
become
familiarized
with
horrors
<EOS>
,
Leonard
struck
down
Finch
-
lane
,
and
proceeded
towards
Cornhill
.
<EOS>
On
the
way
,
he
noticed
two
dead
bodies
lying
at
the
mouth
of
a
small
alley
,
and
hastening
past
,
was
stopped
at
the
entrance
to
Cornhill
by
a
butcher
's
apprentice
,
who
was
wheeling
away
the
body
of
an
old
man
,
who
had
just
died
while
purchasing
meat
at
a
stall
at
Stock
's
Market
.
<EOS>
Filled
with
unutterable
loathing
at
this
miserable
spectacle
,
Leonard
was
fain
to
procure
a
glass
of
canary
to
recruit
his
spirits
.
 
<EOS>
Accordingly
he
proceeded
to
the
Globe
Tavern
at
the
corner
of
Birchin
-
lane
.
<EOS>
As
he
entered
the
house
,
a
lively
strain
of
music
caught
his
ear
,
and
glancing
in
the
direction
of
the
sound
,
he
found
it
proceeded
from
the
blind
piper
,
Mike
Macascree
,
who
was
playing
to
some
half
-
dozen
roystering
youths
.
<EOS>
Bell
lay
at
her
master
's
feet
;
and
as
Leonard
approached
the
party
,
she
pricked
up
her
ears
,
and
being
called
by
name
,
instantly
sprang
towards
him
,
and
manifested
the
strongest
delight
.
<EOS>
The
piper
stopped
playing
to
listen
to
what
was
going
forward
<EOS>
but
the
young
men
urged
him
to
proceed
,
and
again
filled
his
glass
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
drink
any
more
,
Mike
,
"
said
Leonard
,
"
but
step
aside
with
me
.
<EOS>
I
've
something
to
say
to
you
--
something
about
your
daughter
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
My
daughter
!
<EOS>
"
exclaimed
the
piper
,
in
a
half
-
angry
,
half
-
sorrowful
voice
,
while
a
slight
moisture
forced
itself
through
his
orbless
lids
.
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
want
to
hear
anything
about
her
,
except
that
she
is
dead
.
<EOS>
She
has
deserted
me
,
and
disgraced
herself
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
are
mistaken
,
"
rejoined
Leonard
;
"
and
if
you
will
come
with
me
,
I
will
explain
the
truth
to
you
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
will
listen
to
no
explanation
,
"
rejoined
the
piper
,
furiously
,
"
she
has
given
me
pain
enough
already
.
<EOS>
I
'm
engaged
with
this
jovial
company
.
<EOS>
Fill
my
glass
,
my
masters
--
there
,
fill
it
again
,
"
he
added
,
draining
it
eagerly
,
and
with
the
evident
wish
to
drown
all
thought
.
<EOS>
"
There
,
now
you
shall
have
such
a
tune
,
as
was
never
listened
to
by
mortal
ears
.
"
 
A
loud
laugh
from
the
young
men
followed
this
proposition
,
and
the
piper
played
away
so
furiously
,
that
it
added
to
their
merriment
.
<EOS>
Touched
with
compassion
,
Leonard
walked
aside
,
hoping
,
when
the
party
broke
up
,
to
be
able
to
have
a
word
with
the
poor
man
.
<EOS>
But
the
piper
's
excitement
increased
.
<EOS>
He
played
faster
and
drank
harder
,
until
it
was
evident
he
was
no
longer
in
a
condition
to
speak
rationally
.
<EOS>
Leonard
,
therefore
,
addressed
himself
to
the
drawer
,
and
desired
him
to
look
after
the
piper
,
engaging
to
return
before
midnight
to
see
how
he
went
on
.
<EOS>
The
drawer
promising
compliance
,
Leonard
departed
;
and
not
feeling
disposed
to
continue
his
walk
,
returned
to
Wood
-
street
.
 
<EOS>
Nothing
particular
occurred
during
the
evening
.
<EOS>
Leonard
did
not
see
Doctor
Hodges
,
who
was
engaged
in
his
professional
duties
;
and
after
keeping
watch
before
the
grocer
's
till
nearly
midnight
,
he
again
retraced
his
steps
to
the
Globe
.
<EOS>
The
drawer
was
at
the
door
,
and
about
to
close
the
house
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
will
be
sorry
to
learn
the
fate
of
the
poor
piper
,
"
he
said
.
 
<EOS>
"
Why
,
what
has
happened
to
him
?
"
cried
Leonard
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
is
dead
of
the
plague
,
"
was
the
reply
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
,
so
suddenly
!
"
exclaimed
the
apprentice
.
<EOS>
"
You
are
jesting
with
me
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Alas
!
<EOS>
it
is
no
jest
,
"
rejoined
the
drawer
,
in
a
tone
that
convinced
the
apprentice
of
his
sincerity
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
His
entertainers
quitted
him
about
two
hours
ago
,
and
in
spite
of
my
efforts
to
detain
him
,
he
left
the
house
,
and
sat
down
on
those
steps
.
<EOS>
Concluding
he
would
fall
asleep
,
I
did
not
disturb
him
,
and
his
dog
kept
careful
watch
over
him
.
<EOS>
I
forgot
all
about
him
till
a
short
time
ago
,
when
hearing
the
pest
-
cart
pass
,
I
went
forth
,
and
learnt
that
the
drivers
having
found
him
dead
,
as
they
supposed
,
of
the
pestilence
,
had
placed
their
forks
under
his
belt
,
and
thrown
him
upon
the
other
dead
bodies
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
And
where
is
the
dog
?
"
cried
Leonard
.
 
<EOS>
"
She
would
not
quit
her
master
,
"
replied
the
drawer
,
"
<EOS>
so
the
men
threw
her
into
the
cart
with
him
,
saying
,
they
would
bury
her
in
the
plague
-
pit
,
as
all
dogs
were
ordered
to
be
destroyed
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
This
must
be
prevented
,
"
cried
Leonard
.
<EOS>
"
Which
way
did
the
dead
-
cart
go
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
Towards
Moorgate
,
"
replied
the
drawer
.
 
<EOS>
Leonard
heard
no
more
;
but
dashing
through
a
narrow
passage
opposite
the
Conduit
,
passed
Bartholomew
-
lane
,
and
traversing
Lothbury
,
soon
reached
Coleman
-
street
and
the
old
city
gate
,
to
which
he
had
been
directed
.
<EOS>
Here
he
learnt
that
the
dead
-
cart
had
passed
through
it
about
five
minutes
before
,
and
he
hurried
on
towards
Finsbury
Fields
.
<EOS>
He
had
not
proceeded
far
when
he
heard
a
sound
as
of
a
pipe
at
a
distance
,
furiously
played
,
and
accompanied
by
the
barking
of
a
dog
.
<EOS>
These
sounds
were
followed
by
cries
of
alarm
,
and
he
presently
perceived
two
persons
running
towards
him
,
with
a
swiftness
which
only
could
be
occasioned
by
terror
.
<EOS>
One
of
them
carried
a
lantern
,
and
grasping
his
arm
,
the
apprentice
detained
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
is
the
matter
?
"
<EOS>
he
asked
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
devil
's
the
matter
,
"
replied
the
man--"the
piper
's
ghost
has
appeared
in
that
cart
,
and
is
playing
his
old
tunes
again
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Ay
,
it
's
either
his
spirit
,
or
he
is
come
to
life
again
,
"
observed
the
other
man
,
stopping
likewise
.
<EOS>
"
I
tossed
him
into
the
cart
myself
,
and
will
swear
he
was
dead
enough
then
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
have
committed
a
dreadful
mistake
,
"
cried
Leonard
.
<EOS>
"
You
have
tossed
a
living
man
into
the
cart
instead
of
a
dead
one
.
<EOS>
Do
you
not
hear
those
sounds
?
"
<EOS>
And
as
he
spoke
,
the
notes
of
the
pipe
swelled
to
a
louder
strain
than
ever
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
tell
you
it
is
the
devil
--
or
a
ghost
,
"
replied
the
driver
;
"
I
will
stay
here
no
longer
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Lend
me
your
lantern
,
and
I
will
go
to
the
cart
,
"
rejoined
Leonard
.
 
<EOS>
"
Take
it
,
"
replied
the
man
;
"
but
I
caution
you
to
stay
where
you
are
.
<EOS>
You
may
receive
a
shock
you
will
never
survive
.
"
 
<EOS>
Paying
no
attention
to
what
was
said
,
Leonard
ran
towards
the
cart
,
and
found
the
piper
seated
upon
a
pile
of
dead
bodies
,
most
of
them
stripped
of
their
covering
,
with
Bell
by
his
side
,
and
playing
away
at
a
prodigious
rate
.
  
<EOS>
III
.
 
<EOS>
THE
DANCE
OF
DEATH
.
 
<EOS>
The
condition
of
the
prisons
at
this
season
was
really
frightful
.
<EOS>
In
Newgate
,
in
particular
,
where
the
distemper
broke
out
at
the
beginning
of
June
,
it
raged
with
such
violence
that
in
less
than
a
week
,
more
than
half
the
prisoners
were
swept
off
,
and
it
appeared
probable
,
that
,
unless
its
fury
abated
,
not
a
soul
would
be
left
alive
within
it
.
<EOS>
At
all
times
,
this
crowded
and
ill
-
kept
prison
was
infested
by
the
gaol
-
fever
and
other
pestilential
disorders
,
but
these
were
mild
in
comparison
with
the
present
terrible
visitation
.
<EOS>
The
atmosphere
was
noisome
and
malignant
;
the
wards
were
never
cleansed
;
and
many
poor
wretches
,
who
died
in
their
cells
,
were
left
there
till
the
attendants
on
the
dead
-
cart
chose
to
drag
them
forth
.
<EOS>
No
restraint
being
placed
upon
the
sick
,
and
the
rules
of
the
prison
allowing
them
the
free
use
of
any
strong
liquors
they
could
purchase
,
the
scenes
that
occurred
were
too
dreadful
and
revolting
for
description
,
and
could
only
be
paralleled
by
the
orgies
of
a
pandemonium
.
<EOS>
Many
reckless
beings
,
conscious
that
they
were
attacked
by
a
fatal
disorder
,
drank
as
long
as
they
could
raise
the
'
cup
to
their
lips
,
and
after
committing
the
wildest
and
most
shocking
extravagances
,
died
in
a
state
of
frenzy
.
 
<EOS>
Newgate
became
thus
,
as
it
were
,
the
very
focus
of
infection
,
where
the
plague
assumed
its
worst
aspect
,
and
where
its
victims
perished
far
more
expeditiously
than
elsewhere
.
<EOS>
Two
of
the
turnkeys
had
already
died
of
the
distemper
,
and
such
was
the
alarm
entertained
,
that
no
persons
could
be
found
to
supply
their
places
.
<EOS>
To
penetrate
the
recesses
of
the
prison
,
was
almost
to
insure
destruction
,
and
none
but
the
attendants
of
the
dead
-
cart
and
the
nurses
attempted
it
.
<EOS>
Among
the
latter
was
Judith
.
<EOS>
Employed
as
a
nurse
on
the
first
outburst
of
the
plague
,
she
willingly
and
fearlessly
undertook
the
office
.
<EOS>
The
worse
the
disease
became
the
better
pleased
she
appeared
;
and
she
was
so
utterly
without
apprehension
,
that
when
no
one
would
approach
the
cell
where
some
wretched
sufferer
lay
expiring
,
she
unhesitatingly
entered
it
.
<EOS>
But
it
was
not
to
render
aid
,
but
to
plunder
,
that
she
thus
exercised
her
functions
.
<EOS>
She
administered
no
medicine
,
dressed
no
tumours
,
and
did
not
contribute
in
the
slightest
degree
to
the
comfort
of
the
miserable
wretches
committed
to
her
charge
.
<EOS>
All
she
desired
was
to
obtain
whatever
valuables
they
possessed
,
or
to
wring
from
them
any
secret
that
might
afterwards
be
turned
to
account
.
<EOS>
Foreseeing
that
Newgate
must
ere
long
be
depopulated
,
and
having
no
fears
for
herself
,
she
knew
that
she
must
then
be
liberated
,
and
be
able
once
more
to
renew
her
mischievous
practices
upon
mankind
.
<EOS>
Her
marvellous
preservation
throughout
all
the
dangers
to
which
she
was
exposed
seemed
almost
to
warrant
the
supposition
that
she
had
entered
into
a
compact
with
the
pestilence
,
to
extend
its
ravages
by
every
means
in
her
power
,
on
the
condition
of
being
spared
herself
.
 
<EOS>
Soon
after
the
outbreak
of
the
plague
in
Newgate
,
all
the
debtors
were
liberated
,
and
if
the
keepers
had
had
their
own
way
,
the
common
felons
would
have
been
likewise
released
.
<EOS>
But
this
could
not
be
,
and
they
were
kept
to
perish
as
before
described
.
<EOS>
Matters
,
however
,
grew
so
serious
,
that
it
became
a
question
whether
the
few
miserable
wretches
left
alive
ought
to
be
longer
detained
,
and
at
last
the
turnkeys
refusing
to
act
any
longer
,
and
delivering
their
keys
to
the
governor
,
the
whole
of
the
prisoners
were
set
free
.
 
<EOS>
On
the
night
of
their
liberation
,
Chowles
and
Judith
proceeded
to
the
vaults
of
Saint
Faith
's
,
to
deposit
within
them
the
plunder
they
had
obtained
in
the
prison
.
<EOS>
They
found
them
entirely
deserted
.
<EOS>
Neither
verger
,
sexton
,
nor
any
other
person
,
was
to
be
seen
,
and
they
took
up
their
quarters
in
the
crypt
.
<EOS>
Having
brought
a
basket
of
provisions
and
a
few
bottles
of
wine
with
them
,
they
determined
to
pass
the
night
in
revelry
;
and
,
accordingly
,
having
lighted
a
fire
with
the
fragments
of
old
coffins
brought
from
the
charnel
,
they
sat
down
to
their
meal
.
<EOS>
Having
done
full
justice
to
it
,
and
disposed
of
the
first
flask
,
they
were
about
to
abandon
themselves
to
unrestrained
enjoyment
,
when
their
glee
was
all
at
once
interrupted
by
a
strange
and
unaccountable
noise
in
the
adjoining
church
.
<EOS>
Chowles
,
who
had
just
commenced
chanting
one
of
his
wild
melodies
,
suddenly
stopped
,
and
Judith
set
down
the
glass
she
had
raised
to
her
lips
untested
.
<EOS>
What
could
it
mean
?
<EOS>
Neither
of
them
could
tell
.
<EOS>
It
seemed
like
strains
of
unearthly
music
,
mixed
with
shrieks
and
groans
as
of
tortured
spirits
,
accompanied
by
peals
of
such
laughter
as
might
be
supposed
to
proceed
,
from
demons
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
dead
are
burst
forth
from
their
tombs
,
"
cried
Chowles
,
in
a
quavering
voice
,
"
and
are
attended
by
a
legion
of
evil
spirits
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
would
seem
so
,
"
replied
Judith
,
rising
.
<EOS>
"
I
should
like
to
behold
the
sight
.
<EOS>
Come
with
me
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Not
for
the
world
!
"
rejoined
Chowles
,
shuddering
,
"
and
I
would
recommend
you
to
stay
where
you
are
.
<EOS>
You
may
behold
your
dead
husband
among
them
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Do
you
think
so
?
"
rejoined
Judith
,
halting
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
sure
of
it
,
"
cried
Chowles
,
eagerly
.
"
<EOS>
Stay
where
you
are
--
stay
where
you
are
.
"
 
<EOS>
As
he
spoke
,
there
was
another
peal
of
infernal
laughter
,
and
the
strains
of
music
grew
louder
each
moment
.
 
<EOS>
"
Come
what
may
,
I
will
see
what
it
is
,
"
said
Judith
,
emptying
her
glass
,
as
if
seeking
courage
from
the
draught
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Surely
,
"
she
added
,
in
a
taunting
tone
,
"
you
will
come
with
me
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
afraid
of
nothing
earthly
,
"
rejoined
<EOS>
Chowles--"but
<EOS>
I
do
not
like
to
face
beings
of
another
world
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Then
I
will
go
alone
,
"
rejoined
Judith
.
 
<EOS>
"
Nay
,
that
shall
never
be
,
"
replied
Chowles
,
tottering
after
her
.
 
<EOS>
As
they
opened
the
door
and
crossed
the
charnel
,
such
an
extraordinary
combination
of
sounds
burst
upon
their
ears
that
they
again
paused
,
and
looked
anxiously
at
each
other
.
<EOS>
Chowles
laid
his
hand
on
his
companion
's
arm
,
and
strove
to
detain
her
,
but
she
would
not
be
stayed
,
and
he
was
forced
to
proceed
.
<EOS>
Setting
down
the
lamp
on
the
stone
floor
,
Judith
passed
into
the
subterranean
church
,
where
she
beheld
a
sight
that
almost
petrified
her
.
<EOS>
In
the
midst
of
the
nave
,
which
was
illumined
by
a
blue
glimmering
light
,
whence
proceeding
it
was
impossible
to
determine
,
stood
a
number
of
grotesque
figures
,
apparelled
in
fantastic
garbs
,
and
each
attended
by
a
skeleton
.
<EOS>
Some
of
the
latter
grisly
shapes
were
playing
on
tambours
,
others
on
psalteries
,
others
on
rebecs
--
every
instrument
producing
the
strangest
sound
imaginable
.
<EOS>
Viewed
through
the
massive
pillars
,
beneath
that
dark
and
ponderous
roof
,
and
by
the
mystic
light
before
described
,
this
strange
company
had
a
supernatural
appearance
,
and
neither
Chowles
nor
Judith
doubted
for
a
moment
that
they
beheld
before
them
a
congregation
of
phantoms
.
<EOS>
An
irresistible
feeling
of
curiosity
prompted
them
to
advance
.
<EOS>
On
drawing
nearer
,
they
found
the
assemblage
comprehended
all
ranks
of
society
.
<EOS>
There
was
a
pope
in
his
tiara
and
pontifical
dress
;
a
cardinal
in
his
cap
and
robes
;
a
monarch
with
a
sceptre
in
his
hand
,
and
arrayed
in
the
habiliments
of
royalty
;
a
crowned
queen
;
a
bishop
wearing
his
mitre
,
and
carrying
his
crosier
;
an
abbot
,
likewise
in
his
mitre
,
and
bearing
a
crosier
;
a
duke
in
his
robes
of
state
;
a
grave
canon
of
the
church
;
a
knight
sheathed
in
armour
;
a
judge
,
an
advocate
,
and
a
magistrate
,
all
in
their
robes
;
a
mendicant
friar
and
a
nun
;
and
the
list
was
completed
by
a
physician
,
an
astrologer
,
a
miser
,
a
merchant
,
a
duchess
,
a
pedler
,
a
soldier
,
a
gamester
,
an
idiot
,
a
robber
,
a
blind
man
,
and
a
beggar
--
each
distinguishable
by
his
apparel
.
 
<EOS>
By
-
and
-
by
,
with
a
wild
and
gibbering
laugh
that
chilled
the
beholders
'
blood
,
one
of
the
tallest
and
grisliest
of
the
skeletons
sprang
forward
,
and
beating
his
drum
,
the
whole
ghostly
company
formed
,
two
and
two
,
into
a
line
--
a
skeleton
placing
itself
on
the
right
of
every
mortal
.
<EOS>
In
this
order
,
the
fantastic
procession
marched
between
the
pillars
,
the
unearthly
music
playing
all
the
while
,
and
disappeared
at
the
further
extremity
of
the
church
.
<EOS>
With
the
last
of
the
group
,
the
mysterious
light
vanished
,
and
Chowles
and
his
companion
were
left
in
profound
darkness
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
can
it
mean
?
<EOS>
"
cried
Judith
,
as
soon
as
she
recovered
her
speech
.
"
<EOS>
Are
they
human
,
or
spirits
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
Human
beings
do
n't
generally
amuse
themselves
in
this
way
,
"
returned
Chowles
.
"
<EOS>
But
hark!--I
still
hear
the
music.--They
are
above
--
in
Saint
Paul
's
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Then
I
will
join
them
,
"
said
Judith
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
resolved
to
see
the
end
of
it
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
leave
me
behind
,
"
returned
Chowles
,
following
her
.
<EOS>
"
I
would
rather
keep
company
with
Beelzebub
and
all
his
imps
than
be
alone
.
"
 
<EOS>
Both
were
too
well
acquainted
with
the
way
to
need
any
light
.
<EOS>
Ascending
the
broad
stone
steps
,
they
presently
emerged
into
the
cathedral
,
which
they
found
illumined
by
the
same
glimmering
light
as
the
lower
church
,
and
they
perceived
the
ghostly
assemblage
gathered
into
an
immense
ring
,
and
dancing
round
the
tall
skeleton
,
who
continued
beating
his
drum
,
and
uttering
a
strange
gibbering
sound
,
which
was
echoed
by
the
others
.
<EOS>
Each
moment
the
dancers
increased
the
swiftness
of
their
pace
,
until
at
last
it
grew
to
a
giddy
whirl
,
and
then
,
all
at
once
,
with
a
shriek
of
laughter
,
the
whole
company
fell
to
the
ground
.
 
<EOS>
Chowles
and
Judith
,
then
,
for
the
first
time
,
understood
,
from
the
confusion
that
ensued
,
and
the
exclamations
uttered
,
that
they
were
no
spirits
they
had
to
deal
with
,
but
beings
of
the
same
mould
as
themselves
.
<EOS>
Accordingly
,
they
approached
the
party
of
masquers
,
for
such
they
proved
,
and
found
on
inquiry
that
they
were
a
party
of
young
gallants
,
who
,
headed
by
the
Earl
of
Rochester
--
the
representative
of
the
tall
skeleton
--
had
determined
to
realize
the
Dance
of
Death
,
as
once
depicted
on
the
walls
of
an
ancient
cloister
at
the
north
of
the
cathedral
,
called
Pardon
-
churchyard
,
on
the
walls
of
which
,
says
Stowe
,
were
"
artificially
and
richly
painted
the
Dance
of
Macabre
,
or
Dance
of
Death
,
commonly
called
the
Dance
of
Paul
's
,
<EOS>
the
like
whereof
was
painted
about
Saint
Innocent
's
,
at
Paris
.
<EOS>
The
metres
,
or
poesy
of
this
dance
,
"
proceeds
the
same
authority
,
"
were
translated
out
of
Trench
into
English
by
John
Lydgate
,
monk
of
Bury
,
and
,
with
the
picture
of
Death
leading
all
estates
,
painted
about
the
cloister
,
at
the
special
request
and
expense
of
Jenkin
Carpenter
,
in
the
reign
of
Henry
the
Sixth
.
"
<EOS>
Pardon
-
churchyard
was
pulled
down
by
the
Protector
Somerset
,
in
the
reign
of
Edward
the
Sixth
,
and
the
materials
employed
in
the
erection
of
his
own
palace
in
the
Strand
.
<EOS>
It
was
the
discussion
of
these
singular
paintings
,
and
of
the
designs
on
the
same
subject
ascribed
to
Holbein
,
that
led
the
Earl
of
Rochester
and
his
companions
to
propose
the
fantastic
spectacle
above
described
.
<EOS>
With
the
disposition
which
this
reckless
nobleman
possessed
to
turn
the
most
solemn
and
appalling
subjects
to
jest
,
he
thought
no
season
so
fitting
for
such
an
entertainment
as
the
present
--
just
as
in
our
own
time
the
lively
Parisians
made
the
cholera
,
while
raging
in
their
city
,
the
subject
of
a
carnival
pastime
.
<EOS>
The
exhibition
witnessed
by
Chowles
and
Judith
was
a
rehearsal
of
the
masque
intended
to
be
represented
in
the
cathedral
on
the
following
night
.
 
<EOS>
Again
marshalling
his
band
,
the
Earl
of
Rochester
beat
his
drum
,
and
skipping
before
them
,
led
the
way
towards
the
south
door
of
the
cathedral
,
which
was
thrown
open
by
an
unseen
hand
,
and
the
procession
glided
through
it
like
a
troop
of
spectres
.
<EOS>
Chowles
,
whose
appearance
was
not
unlike
that
of
an
animated
skeleton
,
was
seized
with
a
strange
desire
to
join
in
what
was
going
forward
,
and
taking
off
his
doublet
,
and
baring
his
bony
arms
and
legs
,
he
followed
the
others
,
dancing
round
Judith
in
the
same
manner
that
the
other
skeletons
danced
round
their
partners
.
 
<EOS>
On
reaching
the
Convocation
House
,
a
door
was
opened
,
and
the
procession
entered
the
cloisters
;
and
here
Chowles
,
dragging
Judith
into
the
area
between
him
and
the
beautiful
structure
they
surrounded
,
began
a
dance
of
so
extraordinary
a
character
that
the
whole
troop
collected
round
to
witness
it
.
<EOS>
Rochester
beat
his
drum
,
and
the
other
representatives
of
mortality
who
were
provided
with
musical
instruments
struck
up
a
wild
kind
of
accompaniment
,
to
which
Chowles
executed
the
most
grotesque
flourishes
.
<EOS>
So
wildly
excited
did
he
become
,
and
such
extravagances
<EOS>
did
he
commit
,
that
even
Judith
stared
aghast
at
him
,
and
began
to
think
his
wits
were
fled
.
<EOS>
Now
he
whirled
round
her
--
now
sprang
high
into
the
air
--
now
twined
his
lean
arms
round
her
waist
--
now
peeped
over
one
shoulder
,
now
over
the
other
--
and
at
last
griped
her
neck
so
forcibly
,
that
he
might
perhaps
have
strangled
her
,
if
she
had
not
broken
from
him
,
and
dealt
him
a
severe
blow
that
brought
him
senseless
to
the
ground
.
<EOS>
On
recovering
,
he
found
himself
in
the
arched
entrance
of
a
large
octagonal
chamber
,
lighted
at
each
side
by
a
lofty
pointed
window
filled
with
stained
glass
.
<EOS>
Round
this
chamber
ran
a
wide
stone
bench
,
with
a
richly
-
carved
back
of
the
same
material
,
on
which
the
masquers
were
seated
,
and
opposite
the
entrance
was
a
raised
seat
,
ordinarily
allotted
to
the
dean
,
but
now
occupied
by
the
Earl
of
Rochester
.
<EOS>
A
circular
oak
table
stood
in
the
midst
of
the
chamber
,
covered
with
magnificent
silver
dishes
,
heaped
with
the
choicest
viands
,
which
were
handed
to
the
guests
