by
the
earl
's
servants
,
all
of
whom
represented
skeletons
,
and
it
had
a
strange
effect
,
to
behold
these
ghastly
objects
filling
the
cups
of
the
revellers
,
bending
obsequiously
before
some
blooming
dame
,
or
crowding
round
their
spectral
-
looking
lord
.
 
<EOS>
At
first
,
Chowles
was
so
confused
,
that
he
thought
he
must
have
awakened
in
another
world
,
but
by
degrees
he
called
to
mind
what
had
occurred
,
and
ascertained
from
Judith
that
he
was
in
the
Convocation
House
.
<EOS>
Getting
up
,
he
joined
the
train
of
grisly
attendants
,
and
acquitted
himself
so
well
that
the
earl
engaged
him
as
performer
in
the
masque
.
<EOS>
He
was
furthermore
informed
that
,
in
all
probability
,
the
king
himself
,
with
many
of
his
favourite
nobles
,
and
the
chief
court
beauties
,
would
be
present
to
witness
the
spectacle
.
 
<EOS>
The
banquet
over
,
word
was
brought
that
chairs
and
coaches
were
without
,
and
the
company
departed
,
leaving
behind
only
a
few
attendants
,
who
remained
to
put
matters
in
order
.
 
<EOS>
While
they
were
thus
occupied
,
Judith
,
who
had
fixed
her
greedy
eyes
upon
the
plate
,
observed
,
in
an
under
-
tone
,
to
Chowles
,
"
There
will
be
fine
plunder
for
us
.
<EOS>
We
must
manage
to
carry
off
all
that
plate
while
they
are
engaged
in
the
masque
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
must
do
it
yourself
,
then
,
"
returned
Chowles
,
in
the
same
<EOS>
tone--"for
<EOS>
I
shall
have
to
play
a
principal
part
in
the
entertainment
,
and
as
the
king
himself
will
be
present
,
I
can
not
give
up
such
an
opportunity
of
distinguishing
myself
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
can
have
no
share
in
the
prize
,
if
you
lend
no
assistance
,
"
replied
Judith
,
with
a
dissatisfied
look
.
 
<EOS>
"
Of
course
not
,
"
rejoined
Chowles
;
"
on
this
occasion
it
is
all
yours
.
<EOS>
The
Dance
of
Death
is
too
much
to
my
taste
to
be
given
up
.
"
 
<EOS>
Perceiving
they
were
noticed
,
Chowles
and
Judith
then
left
the
Convocation
House
,
and
returned
to
the
vault
in
Saint
Faith
's
,
nor
did
they
emerge
from
it
until
late
on
the
following
day
.
 
<EOS>
Some
rumour
of
the
masque
having
gone
abroad
,
towards
evening
a
crowd
,
chiefly
composed
of
the
most
worthless
order
of
society
,
collected
under
the
portico
at
the
western
entrance
,
and
the
great
doors
being
opened
by
Chowles
<EOS>
,
they
entered
the
cathedral
.
<EOS>
Thus
was
this
sacred
building
once
more
invaded
--
once
again
a
scene
of
noise
,
riot
,
and
confusion
--
its
vaulted
roofs
instead
of
echoing
the
voice
of
prayer
,
or
the
choral
hymn
,
resounded
with
loud
laughter
,
imprecations
,
and
licentious
discourse
.
<EOS>
This
disorder
,
however
,
was
kept
in
some
bounds
by
a
strong
body
of
the
royal
guard
,
who
soon
afterwards
arrived
,
and
stationing
themselves
in
parties
of
three
or
four
at
each
of
the
massive
columns
flanking
the
aisles
,
maintained
some
show
of
decorum
.
<EOS>
Besides
these
,
there
were
others
of
the
royal
attendants
,
bearing
torches
,
who
walked
from
place
to
place
,
and
compelled
all
loiterers
in
dark
corners
to
proceed
to
the
nave
.
 
<EOS>
A
little
before
midnight
,
the
great
doors
were
again
thrown
open
,
and
a
large
troop
of
richly
-
attired
personages
,
all
wearing
masks
,
were
admitted
.
<EOS>
For
a
short
time
they
paced
to
and
fro
between
its
shafted
pillars
gazing
at
the
spectators
grouped
around
,
and
evidently
,
from
their
jests
and
laughter
,
not
a
little
entertained
by
the
scene
.
<EOS>
As
the
clock
struck
twelve
,
however
,
all
sounds
were
hushed
,
and
the
courtly
party
stationed
themselves
on
the
steps
leading
to
the
choir
.
<EOS>
At
the
same
moment
,
also
,
the
torches
were
extinguished
,
and
the
whole
of
the
building
buried
in
profound
darkness
.
<EOS>
Presently
after
,
a
sound
was
heard
of
footsteps
approaching
the
nave
,
but
nothing
could
be
discerned
.
<EOS>
Expectation
was
kept
on
the
rack
for
some
minutes
,
during
which
many
a
stifled
cry
was
heard
from
those
whose
courage
failed
them
at
this
trying
juncture
.
<EOS>
All
at
once
,
a
blue
light
illumined
the
nave
,
and
partially
revealed
the
lofty
pillars
by
which
it
was
surrounded
.
<EOS>
By
this
light
the
whole
of
the
ghostly
company
could
be
seen
drawn
up
near
the
western
door
.
<EOS>
They
were
arranged
two
and
two
,
a
skeleton
standing
as
before
on
the
right
of
each
character
.
<EOS>
The
procession
next
marched
slowly
and
silently
towards
the
choir
,
and
drew
up
at
the
foot
of
the
steps
,
to
give
the
royal
party
an
opportunity
of
examining
them
.
<EOS>
After
pausing
there
for
a
few
minutes
,
Rochester
,
in
the
dress
of
the
larger
skeleton
,
started
off
,
and
,
beating
his
drum
,
was
followed
by
the
pope
and
his
attendant
skeleton
.
<EOS>
This
couple
having
danced
together
for
some
minutes
,
to
the
infinite
diversion
of
the
spectators
,
disappeared
behind
a
pillar
,
and
were
succeeded
by
the
monarch
and
a
second
skeleton
.
<EOS>
These
,
in
their
turn
,
gave
way
to
the
cardinal
and
his
companion
,
and
so
on
till
the
whole
of
the
masquers
had
exhibited
themselves
,
when
at
a
signal
from
the
earl
the
party
re
-
appeared
,
and
formed
a
ring
round
him
.
<EOS>
The
dance
was
executed
with
great
spirit
,
and
elicited
tumultuous
applause
from
all
the
beholders
.
<EOS>
The
earl
now
retired
,
and
Chowles
took
his
place
.
<EOS>
He
was
clothed
in
an
elastic
dress
painted
of
a
leaden
and
cadaverous
colour
,
which
fitted
closely
to
his
fleshless
figure
,
and
defined
all
his
angularities
.
<EOS>
He
carried
an
hour
-
glass
in
one
hand
and
a
dart
in
the
other
,
and
in
the
course
of
the
dance
kept
continually
pointing
the
latter
at
those
who
moved
around
him
.
<EOS>
His
feats
of
the
previous
evening
were
nothing
to
his
present
achievements
.
<EOS>
His
joints
creaked
,
and
his
eyes
flamed
like
burning
coals
.
<EOS>
As
he
continued
,
his
excitement
increased
.
<EOS>
He
bounded
higher
,
and
his
countenance
assumed
so
hideous
an
expression
,
that
those
near
him
recoiled
in
terror
,
crying
,
"
Death
himself
had
broke
loose
among
them
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
consternation
soon
became
general
.
<EOS>
The
masquers
fled
in
dismay
,
and
scampered
along
the
aisles
scarcely
knowing
whither
they
were
going
.
<EOS>
Delighted
with
the
alarm
he
occasioned
,
Chowles
chased
a
large
party
along
the
northern
aisle
,
and
was
pursuing
them
across
the
transept
upon
which
it
opened
,
when
he
was
arrested
in
his
turn
by
another
equally
formidable
figure
,
who
suddenly
placed
himself
in
his
path
.
 
<EOS>
"
Hold
!
"
exclaimed
Solomon
Eagle
--
<EOS>
for
it
was
the
enthusiast
--
in
a
voice
of
thunder
,
"
it
is
time
this
scandalous
exhibition
should
cease
.
<EOS>
Know
all
ye
who
make
a
mockery
of
death
,
that
his
power
will
be
speedily
and
fearfully
approved
upon
you
.
<EOS>
Thine
not
to
escape
the
vengeance
of
the
Great
Being
whose
temple
you
have
profaned
.
<EOS>
And
you
,
O
king
!
<EOS>
who
have
sanctioned
these
evil
doings
by
your
presence
,
and
who
by
your
own
dissolute
life
set
a
pernicious
example
to
all
your
subjects
,
know
that
your
city
shall
be
utterly
laid
waste
,
first
by
plague
and
then
by
fire
.
<EOS>
Tremble
!
<EOS>
my
warning
is
as
terrible
and
true
as
the
handwriting
on
the
wall
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Who
art
thou
who
holdest
this
language
towards
me
?
"
demanded
Charles
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
called
Solomon
Eagle
,
"
replied
the
enthusiast
,
"
and
am
charged
with
a
mission
from
on
high
to
warn
your
doomed
people
of
their
fate
.
<EOS>
Be
warned
yourself
,
sire
!
<EOS>
Your
end
will
be
sudden
.
<EOS>
You
will
be
snatched
away
in
the
midst
of
your
guilty
pleasure
,
and
with
little
time
for
repentance
.
<EOS>
Be
warned
,
I
say
again
.
"
 
<EOS>
With
this
he
turned
to
depart
.
 
<EOS>
"
Secure
the
knave
,
"
cried
Charles
,
angrily
.
<EOS>
"
He
shall
be
soundly
scourged
for
his
insolence
.
"
 
<EOS>
But
bursting
through
the
guard
,
Solomon
Eagle
ran
swiftly
up
the
choir
and
disappeared
,
nor
could
his
pursuers
discover
any
traces
of
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
Strange
!
"
exclaimed
the
king
,
when
he
was
told
of
the
enthusiast
's
escape
.
"
<EOS>
Let
us
go
to
supper
.
<EOS>
This
masque
has
given
me
the
vapours
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Pray
Heaven
it
have
not
given
us
the
plague
,
"
observed
the
fair
Stewart
,
who
stood
beside
him
,
taking
his
arm
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
to
be
hoped
not
,
"
rejoined
Charles
;
"
but
,
odds
fish
!
<EOS>
it
is
a
most
dismal
affair
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
so
,
in
more
ways
than
one
,
"
replied
Rochester
,
"
<EOS>
for
I
have
just
learnt
that
all
my
best
plate
has
been
carried
off
from
the
Convocation
House
.
<EOS>
I
shall
only
be
able
to
offer
your
majesty
and
your
fair
partner
a
sorry
supper
.
"
  
<EOS>
IV
.
 
<EOS>
THE
PLAGUE
-
PIT
.
 
<EOS>
On
being
made
acquainted
by
Leonard
,
who
helped
him
out
of
the
pest
-
cart
,
with
the
danger
he
had
run
,
the
piper
uttered
a
cry
of
terror
,
and
swooned
away
.
<EOS>
The
buriers
,
seeing
how
matters
stood
,
and
that
their
superstitious
fears
were
altogether
groundless
,
now
returned
,
and
one
of
them
,
producing
a
phial
of
vinegar
,
sprinkled
the
fainting
man
with
it
,
and
speedily
brought
him
to
himself
.
<EOS>
But
though
so
far
recovered
,
his
terror
had
by
no
means
abated
,
and
he
declared
his
firm
conviction
that
he
was
infected
by
the
pestilence
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
been
carried
towards
the
plague
-
pit
by
mistake
,
"
he
said
.
<EOS>
"
I
shall
soon
be
conveyed
thither
in
right
earnest
,
and
not
have
the
power
of
frightening
away
my
conductors
on
the
road
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Pooh
!
pooh
!
<EOS>
"
cried
one
of
the
buriers
,
jestingly
.
<EOS>
"
I
hope
you
will
often
ride
with
us
,
and
play
us
many
a
merry
tune
as
you
go
.
<EOS>
You
shall
always
be
welcome
to
a
seat
in
the
cart
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Be
of
good
cheer
,
"
added
Leonard
,
"
and
all
will
be
well
.
<EOS>
Come
with
me
to
an
apothecary
's
shop
,
and
I
will
procure
a
cordial
for
you
,
which
shall
speedily
dispel
your
qualms
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
The
piper
shook
his
head
,
and
replied
,
with
a
deep
groan
,
that
he
was
certain
all
was
over
with
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
However
,
I
will
not
reject
your
kindness
,
"
he
added
,
"
though
I
feel
I
am
past
the
help
of
medicine
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
With
this
,
he
whistled
to
Bell
,
who
was
skipping
about
Leonard
,
having
recognised
him
on
his
first
approach
,
and
they
proceeded
towards
the
second
postern
in
London
-
wall
,
between
Moorgate
and
Cripplegate
;
while
the
buriers
,
laughing
heartily
at
the
adventure
,
took
their
way
towards
the
plague
-
pit
,
and
discharged
their
dreadful
load
within
it
.
<EOS>
Arrived
in
Basinghall
-
street
,
and
looking
round
,
Leonard
soon
discovered
by
the
links
at
the
door
,
as
well
as
by
the
crowd
collected
before
it
--
for
day
and
night
the
apothecaries
'
dwellings
were
besieged
by
the
sick
--
the
shop
of
which
he
was
in
search
.
<EOS>
It
was
long
before
they
could
obtain
admittance
,
and
during
this
time
the
piper
said
he
felt
himself
getting
rapidly
worse
;
but
,
imagining
he
was
merely
labouring
under
the
effect
of
fright
,
Leonard
paid
little
attention
to
his
complaints
.
<EOS>
The
apothecary
,
however
,
no
sooner
set
eyes
upon
him
,
than
he
pronounced
him
infected
,
and
,
on
examination
,
it
proved
that
the
fatal
tokens
had
already
appeared
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
knew
it
was
so
,
"
cried
the
piper
.
<EOS>
"
Take
me
to
the
pest
-
house
--
take
me
to
the
pest
-
house
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
His
desire
had
better
be
complied
with
,
"
observed
the
apothecary
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He
is
able
to
walk
thither
now
,
but
I
will
not
answer
for
his
being
able
to
do
so
two
hours
hence
.
<EOS>
It
is
a
bad
case
,
"
he
added
in
an
under
-
tone
to
Leonard
.
 
<EOS>
Feeing
the
apothecary
,
Leonard
set
out
with
the
piper
,
and
passing
through
Cripplegate
,
they
entered
the
open
fields
.
<EOS>
Here
they
paused
for
a
moment
,
and
the
little
dog
ran
round
and
round
them
,
barking
gleefully
.
 
<EOS>
"
Poor
Bell
!
"
cried
the
piper
;
"
what
will
become
of
thee
when
I
am
gone
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
If
you
will
entrust
her
to
me
,
I
will
take
care
of
her
,
"
replied
Leonard
.
 
<EOS>
"
She
is
yours
,
"
rejoined
the
piper
,
in
a
voice
hoarse
with
emotion
.
"
<EOS>
Be
kind
to
her
for
my
sake
,
and
for
the
sake
of
her
unfortunate
mistress
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Since
you
have
alluded
to
your
daughter
,
"
returned
Leonard
,
"
I
must
tell
you
what
has
become
of
her
.
<EOS>
I
have
not
hitherto
mentioned
the
subject
,
fearing
it
might
distress
you
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Have
no
further
consideration
,
but
speak
out
,
"
rejoined
the
piper
.
"
<EOS>
Be
it
what
it
may
,
I
will
bear
it
like
a
man
.
"
 
<EOS>
Leonard
then
briefly
recounted
all
that
had
occurred
,
describing
Nizza
's
disguise
as
a
page
,
and
her
forcible
abduction
by
Parravicin
.
<EOS>
He
was
frequently
interrupted
by
the
groans
of
his
hearer
,
who
at
last
gave
vent
to
his
rage
and
anguish
in
words
.
 
<EOS>
"
Heaven
's
direst
curse
upon
her
ravisher
!
"
<EOS>
he
cried
.
<EOS>
"
May
he
endure
worse
misery
than
I
now
endure
.
<EOS>
She
is
lost
for
ever
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
She
may
yet
be
preserved
,
"
rejoined
Leonard
.
"
<EOS>
Doctor
Hodges
thinks
he
has
discovered
her
retreat
,
and
I
will
not
rest
till
I
find
her
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
No
--
<EOS>
no
,
you
will
never
find
her
,
"
replied
the
piper
,
bitterly
;
"
or
if
you
do
,
it
will
be
only
to
bewail
her
ruin
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
His
rage
then
gave
way
to
such
an
access
of
grief
,
that
,
letting
his
head
fall
on
Leonard
's
shoulder
,
he
wept
aloud
.
 
<EOS>
"
There
is
a
secret
connected
with
that
poor
girl
,
"
he
said
,
at
length
,
controlling
his
emotion
by
a
powerful
effort
,
"
which
must
now
go
to
the
grave
with
me
.
<EOS>
The
knowledge
of
it
would
only
add
to
her
distress
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
view
the
matter
too
unfavourably
,
"
replied
Leonard
;
"
and
if
the
secret
is
of
any
moment
,
I
entreat
you
to
confide
it
to
me
.
<EOS>
If
your
worst
apprehensions
should
prove
well
founded
,
I
promise
you
it
shall
never
be
revealed
to
her
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
On
that
condition
only
,
I
will
confide
it
to
you
,
"
replied
the
piper
;
"
but
not
now
--
not
now
--
to
-
morrow
morning
,
if
I
am
alive
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
may
be
out
of
your
power
then
,
"
returned
Leonard
,
"
<EOS>
For
your
daughter
's
sake
,
I
urge
you
not
to
delay
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
for
her
sake
<EOS>
I
am
silent
,
"
rejoined
the
piper
.
<EOS>
"
Come
along
--
come
along
"
he
added
,
hurrying
forward
.
<EOS>
"
Are
we
far
from
the
pest
-
house
?
<EOS>
My
strength
is
failing
me
.
"
 
<EOS>
On
arriving
at
their
destination
,
they
were
readily
admitted
to
the
asylum
;
but
a
slight
difficulty
arose
,
which
,
however
,
was
speedily
obviated
.
<EOS>
All
the
couches
were
filled
,
but
on
examining
them
it
was
found
that
one
of
the
sick
persons
had
just
been
released
from
his
sufferings
,
and
the
body
being
removed
,
the
piper
was
allowed
to
take
its
place
.
<EOS>
Leonard
remained
by
him
for
a
short
time
,
but
,
overpowered
by
the
pestilential
effluvia
,
and
the
sight
of
so
many
miserable
objects
,
he
was
compelled
to
seek
the
open
air
.
<EOS>
Returning
,
however
,
shortly
afterwards
,
he
found
the
piper
in
a
very
perturbed
state
.
<EOS>
On
hearing
Leonard
's
voice
he
appeared
greatly
relieved
,
and
,
taking
his
gown
from
beneath
his
pillow
,
gave
it
to
him
,
and
desired
him
to
unrip
a
part
of
the
garment
,
in
which
it
was
evident
something
was
sewn
.
<EOS>
The
apprentice
complied
,
and
a
small
packet
dropped
forth
.
 
<EOS>
"
Take
it
,
"
said
the
piper
;
"
and
if
I
die,--and
Nizza
should
happily
be
preserved
from
her
ravisher
,
give
it
her
.
<EOS>
But
not
otherwise
--
not
otherwise
.
<EOS>
Implore
her
to
forgive
me
--
to
pity
me
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Forgive
you
--
her
father
?
"
cried
Leonard
,
in
astonishment
.
 
<EOS>
"
That
packet
will
explain
all
,
"
replied
the
piper
in
a
troubled
tone
.
<EOS>
"
You
promised
to
take
charge
of
poor
Bell
,
"
he
added
,
drawing
forth
the
little
animal
,
who
had
crept
to
the
foot
of
the
bed
,
"
here
she
is
.
<EOS>
Farewell
!
<EOS>
my
faithful
friend
,
"
he
added
,
pressing
his
rough
lips
to
her
forehead
,
while
she
whined
piteously
,
as
if
beseeching
him
to
allow
her
to
remain
;
"
farewell
for
ever
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Not
for
ever
,
I
trust
,
"
replied
Leonard
,
taking
her
gently
from
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
And
now
you
had
better
go
,
"
said
the
piper
.
<EOS>
"
Return
,
if
you
can
,
to
-
morrow
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
will,--I
will
,
"
replied
Leonard
;
and
he
hurried
out
of
the
room
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
followed
to
the
door
by
the
young
chirurgeon
--
the
same
who
had
accompanied
Mr.
Bloundel
during
his
inspection
of
the
pest
-
house,--and
he
inquired
of
him
if
he
thought
the
piper
's
case
utterly
hopeless
.
 
<EOS>
"
Not
utterly
so
,
"
replied
the
young
man
.
<EOS>
"
I
shall
be
able
to
speak
more
positively
in
a
few
hours
.
<EOS>
At
present
,
I
think
,
with
care
and
attention
,
there
_
is
_
a
chance
of
his
recovery
.
"
 
<EOS>
Much
comforted
by
this
assurance
,
Leonard
departed
,
and
afraid
to
put
Bell
to
the
ground
lest
she
should
run
back
to
her
master
,
he
continued
to
carry
her
,
and
endeavoured
to
attach
her
to
him
by
caresses
and
endearments
.
<EOS>
The
little
animal
showed
her
sense
of
his
kindness
by
licking
his
hands
,
but
she
still
remained
inconsolable
,
and
ever
and
anon
struggled
to
get
free
.
<EOS>
Making
the
best
of
his
way
to
Wood
-
street
,
he
entered
the
hutch
,
and
placing
a
little
straw
in
one
corner
for
Bell
,
threw
himself
on
a
bench
and
dropped
asleep
.
<EOS>
At
six
o'clock
he
was
awakened
by
the
barking
of
the
dog
,
and
opening
the
door
beheld
Dallison
.
<EOS>
The
grocer
was
at
the
window
above
,
and
about
to
let
down
a
basket
of
provisions
to
them
.
<EOS>
To
Leonard
's
eager
inquiries
after
Amabel
,
Mr.
Bloundel
replied
by
a
melancholy
shake
of
the
head
,
and
soon
afterwards
withdrew
.
<EOS>
With
a
sad
heart
,
the
apprentice
then
broke
his
fast,--not
forgetting
at
the
same
time
the
wants
of
his
little
companion,--and
finding
he
was
not
required
by
his
master
,
he
proceeded
to
Doctor
Hodges
'
residence
.
<EOS>
He
was
fortunate
enough
to
find
the
friendly
physician
at
home
,
and
,
after
relating
to
him
what
had
occurred
,
committed
the
packet
to
his
custody
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
will
be
safer
in
your
keeping
than
mine
,
"
he
said
;
"
and
if
anything
should
happen
to
me
,
you
will
,
I
am
sure
,
observe
the
wishes
of
the
poor
piper
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Rely
upon
it
,
I
will
,
"
replied
Hodges
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
sorry
to
tell
you
I
have
been
misled
as
to
the
clue
I
fancied
I
had
obtained
to
Nizza
's
retreat
.
<EOS>
We
are
as
far
from
the
mark
as
ever
.
<EOS>
"
 
"
Might
not
the
real
name
of
the
villain
who
has
assumed
the
name
of
Sir
Paul
Parravicin
be
ascertained
from
the
Earl
of
Rochester
?
"
rejoined
Leonard
.
 
<EOS>
"
So
I
thought
,
"
replied
Hodges
;
"
and
I
made
the
attempt
yesterday
,
but
it
failed
.
<EOS>
I
was
at
Whitehall
,
and
finding
the
earl
in
the
king
's
presence
,
suddenly
asked
him
where
I
could
find
his
friend
Sir
Paul
Parravicin
.
<EOS>
He
looked
surprised
at
the
question
,
glanced
significantly
at
the
monarch
,
and
then
carelessly
answered
that
he
knew
no
such
person
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
A
strange
idea
crosses
me
,
"
cried
Leonard
.
<EOS>
"
Can
it
be
the
king
who
has
assumed
this
disguise
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
At
one
time
I
suspected
as
much
,
"
rejoined
Hodges
;
"
but
setting
aside
your
description
of
the
person
,
which
does
not
tally
with
that
of
Charles
,
I
am
satisfied
from
other
circumstances
it
is
not
so
.
<EOS>
After
all
,
I
should
not
wonder
if
poor
Bell
,
"
smoothing
her
long
silky
ears
as
she
lay
in
the
apprentice
's
arms
,
"
should
help
us
to
discover
her
mistress
.
<EOS>
And
now
,
"
he
added
,
"
I
shall
go
to
Wood
-
street
to
inquire
after
Amabel
,
and
will
then
accompany
you
to
the
pest
-
house
.
<EOS>
From
what
you
tell
me
the
young
chirurgeon
said
of
the
piper
,
I
do
not
despair
of
his
recovery
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Poor
as
his
chance
may
appear
,
it
is
better
,
I
fear
,
than
Amabel
's
,
"
sighed
the
apprentice
.
 
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
"
exclaimed
Hodges
,
in
a
sorrowful
tone
<EOS>
,
"
hers
is
slight
indeed
.
"
 
<EOS>
And
perceiving
that
the
apprentice
was
greatly
moved
,
he
waited
for
a
moment
till
he
had
recovered
himself
,
and
then
,
motioning
him
to
follow
him
,
they
quitted
the
house
together
.
 
<EOS>
On
reaching
Mr.
Bloundel
's
habitation
,
Leonard
pulled
the
cord
in
the
hutch
,
and
the
grocer
appeared
at
the
window
.
 
<EOS>
"
My
daughter
has
not
left
her
bed
this
morning
,
"
he
said
,
in
answer
to
the
doctor
's
inquiries
,
"
and
I
fear
she
is
much
worse
.
<EOS>
My
wife
is
with
her
.
<EOS>
It
would
be
a
great
satisfaction
to
me
if
you
would
see
her
again
.
"
 
<EOS>
After
some
little
hesitation
,
Hodges
assented
,
and
was
drawn
up
as
before
.
<EOS>
He
returned
in
about
half
an
hour
,
and
his
grave
countenance
convinced
Leonard
that
his
worst
anticipations
were
correct
.
<EOS>
He
therefore
forbore
to
question
him
,
and
they
walked
towards
Cripplegate
in
silence
.
 
<EOS>
On
emerging
into
the
fields
,
Hodges
observed
to
his
companion
,
"
It
is
strange
that
I
who
daily
witness
such
dreadful
suffering
should
be
pained
by
the
gradual
and
easy
decline
of
Amabel
.
<EOS>
But
so
it
is
.
<EOS>
Her
case
touches
me
more
than
the
worst
I
have
seen
of
the
plague
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
can
easily
account
for
the
feeling
,
"
groaned
Leonard
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
happy
to
say
I
have
prevailed
on
her
,
if
she
does
not
improve
in
a
short
time,--and
<EOS>
there
is
not
the
slightest
chance
of
it,--to
try
the
effect
of
a
removal
to
the
country
.
<EOS>
Her
father
also
consents
to
the
plan
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
glad
to
hear
it
,
"
replied
Leonard
.
"
<EOS>
But
whither
will
she
go
,
and
who
will
watch
over
her
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
That
is
not
yet
settled
,
"
rejoined
Hodges
.
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
!
that
I
might
be
permitted
to
undertake
the
office
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Leonard
,
passionately
.
 
<EOS>
"
Restrain
yourself
,
"
said
Hodges
,
in
a
tone
of
slight
rebuke
.
<EOS>
"
Fitting
attendance
will
be
found
,
if
needed
.
"
 
<EOS>
The
conversation
then
dropped
,
and
they
walked
briskly
forward
.
<EOS>
They
were
now
within
a
short
distance
of
the
pest
-
house
,
and
Leonard
,
hearing
footsteps
behind
him
,
turned
and
beheld
a
closed
litter
,
borne
by
two
stout
porters
,
and
evidently
containing
a
plague
-
patient
.
<EOS>
He
stepped
aside
to
let
it
pass
,
when
Bell
,
suddenly
pricking
her
ears
,
uttered
a
singular
cry
,
and
bursting
from
him
,
flew
after
the
litter
,
leaping
against
it
and
barking
joyfully
.
<EOS>
The
porters
,
who
were
proceeding
at
a
quick
pace
,
tried
to
drive
her
away
,
but
without
effect
,
and
she
continued
her
cries
until
they
reached
the
gates
of
the
pest
-
house
.
<EOS>
In
vain
Leonard
whistled
to
her
,
and
called
her
back
.
<EOS>
She
paid
no
attention
whatever
to
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
almost
begin
to
fear
,
"
said
Hodges
,
unable
to
repress
a
shudder
,
"
that
the
poor
animal
will
,
indeed
,
be
the
means
of
discovering
for
us
the
object
of
our
search
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
understand
what
you
mean
,
"
rejoined
Leonard
,
"
and
am
of
the
same
opinion
as
yourself
.
<EOS>
Heaven
grant
we
may
be
mistaken
!
"
 
<EOS>
And
as
he
spoke
,
he
ran
forward
,
and
,
followed
by
Hodges
,
reached
the
pest
-
house
just
as
the
litter
was
taken
into
it
.
 
<EOS>
"
Silence
that
accursed
dog
,
"
cried
one
of
the
porters
,
"
and
bid
a
nurse
attend
us
.
<EOS>
We
have
a
patient
for
the
women
's
ward
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Let
me
see
her
,
"
cried
Hodges
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
a
physician
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Readily
,
sir
,
"
replied
the
porter
.
<EOS>
"
It
is
almost
over
with
her
,
poor
soul
!
<EOS>
It
would
have
saved
time
and
trouble
to
take
her
to
the
plague
-
pit
at
once
.
<EOS>
She
can
not
last
many
hours
.
<EOS>
Curse
the
dog
!
<EOS>
Will
it
never
cease
howling
?
"
 
<EOS>
Leonard
here
seized
Bell
,
fearing
she
might
do
some
mischief
,
and
with
a
sad
foreboding
beheld
the
man
draw
back
the
curtains
of
the
litter
.
<EOS>
His
fears
proved
well
founded
.
<EOS>
There
,
stretched
upon
the
couch
,
with
her
dark
hair
unbound
,
and
flowing
in
wild
disorder
over
her
neck
,
lay
Nizza
Macascree
.
<EOS>
The
ghastly
paleness
of
her
face
could
not
,
however
,
entirely
rob
it
of
its
beauty
,
and
her
dark
eyes
were
glazed
and
lustreless
.
<EOS>
At
the
sight
of
her
mistress
,
poor
Bell
uttered
so
piteous
a
cry
,
that
Leonard
,
moved
by
compassion
,
placed
her
on
the
pillow
beside
her
,
and
the
sagacious
animal
did
not
attempt
to
approach
nearer
,
but
merely
licked
her
cheek
.
<EOS>
Roused
by
the
touch
,
Nizza
turned
to
see
what
was
near
her
,
and
recognising
the
animal
,
made
a
movement
to
strain
her
to
her
bosom
,
but
the
pain
she
endured
was
so
intense
that
she
sank
back
with
a
deep
groan
.
 
<EOS>
"
From
whom
did
you
receive
this
young
woman
?
"
<EOS>
demanded
Hodges
,
of
one
of
the
porters
.
 
<EOS>
"
She
was
brought
to
us
by
two
richly
-
attired
lacqueys
,
"
replied
the
man
,
"
in
this
very
litter
.
<EOS>
They
paid
us
to
carry
her
here
without
loss
of
time
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
have
an
idea
whose
servants
they
were
?
"
pursued
Hodges
.
 
<EOS>
"
Not
the
least
,
"
replied
the
fellow
;
"
but
I
should
judge
,
from
the
richness
of
their
dress
,
that
they
belonged
to
some
nobleman
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Did
they
belong
to
the
royal
household
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Leonard
.
 
<EOS>
"
No
,
no
,
"
rejoined
the
man
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
certain
as
to
that
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
The
poor
girl
shall
not
remain
here
,
"
observed
Hodges
,
to
the
apprentice
.
<EOS>
"
You
must
convey
her
to
my
residence
in
Great
Knightrider
-
street
,
"
he
added
,
to
the
porters
.
 
<EOS>
"
We
will
convey
her
wherever
you
please
,
"
replied
the
men
,
"
if
we
are
paid
for
our
trouble
.
"
 
<EOS>
And
they
were
about
to
close
the
curtains
,
when
Nizza
,
having
caught
sight
of
the
apprentice
,
slightly
raised
herself
,
and
cried
,
in
a
voice
of
the
utmost
anxiety
,
"
<EOS>
Is
that
you
,
Leonard
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
,
"
he
replied
,
approaching
her
.
 
<EOS>
"
Then
I
shall
die
happy
,
since
I
have
seen
you
once
more
,
"
she
said
.
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
do
not
stay
near
me
.
<EOS>
You
may
catch
the
infection
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Nizza
,
"
said
Leonard
,
disregarding
the
caution
,
and
breathing
the
words
in
her
ear
;
"
allay
my
fears
by
a
word
.
<EOS>
You
have
not
fallen
a
victim
to
the
villain
who
carried
you
away
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
not
,
Leonard
,
"
she
replied
,
solemnly
,
"
I
resisted
his
importunities
,
his
threats
,
his
violence
,
and
would
have
slain
myself
rather
than
have
yielded
to
him
.
<EOS>
The
plague
,
at
length
,
came
to
my
rescue
,
and
I
have
reason
to
be
grateful
to
it
;
for
it
has
not
only
delivered
me
from
him
,
but
has
brought
me
to
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
must
now
impose
silence
upon
you
,
"
interposed
Hodges
,
laying
his
finger
on
his
lips
;
"
further
conversation
will
be
hurtful
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
One
question
more
,
and
I
have
done
,
"
replied
Nizza
.
<EOS>
"
How
came
Bell
with
you
--
and
where
is
my
father
?
<EOS>
Nothing
has
happened
to
him
?
"
<EOS>
she
continued
,
observing
Leonard
's
countenance
change
.
"
<EOS>
Speak
!
<EOS>
do
not
keep
me
in
suspense
.
<EOS>
Your
silence
fills
me
with
apprehension
.
<EOS>
Speak
,
I
implore
you
.
<EOS>
He
is
dead
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
replied
Leonard
,
"
he
is
not
dead
--
but
he
is
an
inmate
of
this
place
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
"
exclaimed
Nizza
,
falling
back
senseless
upon
the
pillow
.
 
<EOS>
And
in
this
state
she
was
conveyed
with
the
greatest
expedition
to
the
doctor
's
residence
.
 
<EOS>
Leonard
only
tarried
to
visit
the
piper
,
whom
he
found
slightly
delirious
,
and
unable
to
hold
any
conversation
with
him
,
and
promising
to
return
in
the
evening
,
he
set
out
after
the
litter
.
<EOS>
Nizza
was
placed
in
the
best
apartment
of
the
doctor
's
house
,
and
attended
by
an
experienced
and
trustworthy
nurse
.
<EOS>
But
Hodges
positively
refused
to
let
Leonard
see
her
again
,
affirming
that
the
excitement
was
too
much
for
her
,
and
might
militate
against
the
chance
of
her
recovery
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
not
without
hopes
of
bringing
her
through
,
"
he
said
,
"
and
though
it
will
be
a
severe
struggle
,
yet
,
as
she
has
youth
and
a
good
constitution
on
her
side
,
I
do
not
despair
.
<EOS>
If
she
herself
would
second
me
,
I
should
be
yet
more
confident
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
How
mean
you
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Leonard
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
think
if
she
thought
life
worth
a
struggle
--
if
,
in
short
,
she
believed
you
would
return
her
attachment
,
she
would
rally
,
"
answered
Hodges
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
can
not
consent
to
deceive
her
thus
,
"
rejoined
Leonard
,
sadly
.
<EOS>
"
My
heart
is
fixed
elsewhere
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Your
heart
is
fixed
upon
one
who
will
soon
be
in
her
grave
,
"
replied
the
doctor
.
 
<EOS>
"
And
with
her
my
affections
will
be
buried
,
"
rejoined
Leonard
,
turning
away
to
hide
his
tears
.
 
<EOS>
So
well
was
the
doctor
's
solicitude
rewarded
,
that
three
days
after
Nizza
had
come
under
his
care
,
he
pronounced
her
out
of
danger
.
<EOS>
But
the
violence
of
the
attack
left
her
so
weak
and
exhausted
,
that
he
still
would
not
allow
an
interview
to
take
place
between
her
and
Leonard
.
<EOS>
During
all
this
time
Bell
never
left
her
side
,
and
her
presence
was
an
inexpressible
comfort
to
her
.
<EOS>
The
piper
,
too
,
was
slowly
recovering
,
and
Leonard
,
who
daily
visited
him
,
was
glad
to
learn
from
the
young
chirurgeon
that
he
would
be
able
to
leave
the
pest
-
house
shortly
.
<EOS>
Having
ascertained
from
Leonard
that
his
daughter
was
under
the
care
of
Doctor
Hodges
,
and
likely
to
do
well
,
the
piper
begged
so
earnestly
that
the
packet
might
not
be
delivered
to
her
,
that
,
after
some
consultation
with
Hodges
,
Leonard
restored
it
to
him
.
<EOS>
He
was
delighted
to
get
it
back
,
felt
it
carefully
over
to
ascertain
that
the
seals
were
unbroken
,
and
satisfied
that
all
was
safe
,
had
it
again
sewn
up
in
his
gown
,
which
he
placed
under
his
pillow
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
would
rather
disclose
the
secret
to
her
by
word
of
mouth
than
in
any
other
way
,
"
he
said
.
 
<EOS>
Leonard
felt
doubtful
whether
the
secret
would
now
be
disclosed
at
all
,
but
he
made
no
remark
.
 
<EOS>
Night
was
drawing
on
as
he
quitted
the
pest
-
house
,
and
he
determined
to
take
this
opportunity
of
visiting
the
great
plague
-
pit
,
which
lay
about
a
quarter
of
a
mile
distant
,
in
a
line
with
the
church
of
All
-
Hallows
-
in
-
the
-
Wall
,
and
he
accordingly
proceeded
in
that
direction
.
<EOS>
The
pit
which
he
was
about
to
visit
was
about
forty
feet
long
,
twenty
wide
,
and
the
like
number
deep
.
<EOS>
Into
this
tremendous
chasm
the
dead
were
promiscuously
thrown
,
without
regard
to
sex
or
condition
,
generally
stripped
of
their
clothing
,
and
covered
with
a
slight
layer
of
earth
and
quick
lime
.
 
<EOS>
The
sun
was
setting
as
Leonard
walked
towards
this
dismal
place
,
and
he
thought
he
had
never
witnessed
so
magnificent
a
sight
.
<EOS>
Indeed
,
it
was
remarked
that
at
this
fatal
season
the
sunsets
were
unusually
splendid
.
<EOS>
The
glorious
orb
sank
slowly
behind
Saint
Paul
's
,
which
formed
a
prominent
object
in
the
view
from
the
fields
,
and
threw
out
its
central
tower
,
its
massive
roof
,
and
the
two
lesser
towers
flanking
the
portico
,
into
strong
relief
.
<EOS>
Leonard
gazed
at
the
mighty
fabric
,
which
seemed
dilated
to
twice
its
size
by
this
light
,
and
wondered
whether
it
was
possible
that
it
could
ever
be
destroyed
,
as
predicted
by
Solomon
Eagle
.
 
<EOS>
Long
after
the
sun
had
set
,
the
sky
was
stained
with
crimson
,
and
the
grey
walls
of
the
city
were
tinged
with
rosy
radiance
.
<EOS>
The
heat
was
intense
,
and
Leonard
,
to
cool
himself
,
sat
down
in
the
thick
grass
--
for
,
though
the
crops
were
ready
for
the
scythe
,
no
mowers
could
be
found
--
and
,
gazing
upwards
,
strove
to
mount
in
spirit
from
the
tainted
earth
towards
heaven
.
<EOS>
After
a
while
he
arose
,
and
proceeded
towards
the
plague
-
pit
.
<EOS>
The
grass
was
trampled
down
near
it
,
and
there
were
marks
of
frequent
cart
-
wheels
upon
the
sod
.
<EOS>
Great
heaps
of
soil
,
thrown
out
of
the
excavation
,
lay
on
either
side
.
<EOS>
Holding
a
handkerchief
steeped
in
vinegar
to
his
face
,
Leonard
ventured
to
the
brink
of
the
pit
.
<EOS>
But
even
this
precaution
could
not
counteract
the
horrible
effluvia
arising
from
it
.
<EOS>
It
was
more
than
half
filled
with
dead
bodies
;
and
through
the
putrid
and
heaving
mass
many
disjointed
limbs
and
ghastly
faces
could
be
discerned
,
the
long
hair
of
women
and
the
tiny
arms
of
children
appearing
on
the
surface
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
horrible
sight
--
so
horrible
,
that
it
possessed
a
fascination
peculiar
to
itself
,
and
,
in
spite
of
his
loathing
,
Leonard
lingered
to
gaze
at
it
.
<EOS>
Strange
and
fantastic
thoughts
possessed
him
.
<EOS>
He
fancied
that
the
legs
and
arms
moved
--
that
the
eyes
of
some
of
the
corpses
opened
and
glared
at
him
--
and
that
the
whole
rotting
mass
was
endowed
with
animation
.
<EOS>
So
appalled
was
he
by
this
idea
that
he
turned
away
,
and
at
that
moment
beheld
a
vehicle
approaching
.
<EOS>
It
was
the
dead
-
cart
,
charged
with
a
heavy
load
to
increase
the
already
redundant
heap
.
 
<EOS>
The
same
inexplicable
and
irresistible
feelings
of
curiosity
that
induced
Leonard
to
continue
gazing
upon
the
loathly
objects
in
the
pit
,
now
prompted
him
to
stay
and
see
what
would
ensue
.
<EOS>
Two
persons
were
with
the
cart
,
and
one
of
them
,
to
Leonard
's
infinite
surprise
and
disgust
,
proved
to
be
Chowles
.
<EOS>
He
had
no
time
,
however
,
for
the
expression
of
any
sentiment
,
for
the
cart
halted
at
a
little
distance
from
him
,
when
its
conductors
,
turning
it
round
,
backed
it
towards
the
edge
of
the
pit
.
<EOS>
The
horse
was
then
taken
out
,
and
Chowles
calling
to
Leonard
,
the
latter
involuntarily
knelt
down
to
guide
its
descent
,
while
the
other
assistant
,
who
had
proceeded
to
the
further
side
of
the
chasm
,
threw
the
light
of
a
lantern
full
upon
the
grisly
load
,
which
was
thus
shot
into
the
gulf
below
.
 
<EOS>
Shovelling
a
sufficient
quantity
of
earth
and
lime
into
the
pit
to
cover
the
bodies
,
Chowles
and
his
companion
departed
,
leaving
Leonard
alone
.
<EOS>
He
continued
there
a
few
moments
longer
,
and
was
about
to
follow
them
,
when
a
prolonged
and
piercing
cry
smote
his
ear
;
and
,
looking
in
the
direction
of
the
sound
,
he
perceived
a
figure
running
with
great
swiftness
towards
the
pit
.
<EOS>
As
no
pursuers
appeared
,
Leonard
could
scarcely
doubt
that
this
was
one
of
the
distracted
persons
he
had
heard
of
,
who
,
in
the
frenzy
produced
by
the
intolerable
anguish
of
their
sores
,
would
often
rush
to
the
plague
-
pit
and
bury
themselves
,
and
he
therefore
resolved
,
if
possible
,
to
prevent
the
fatal
attempt
.
<EOS>
Accordingly
,
he
placed
himself
in
the
way
of
the
runner
,
and
endeavoured
,
with
outstretched
arms
,
to
stop
him
.
<EOS>
But
the
latter
dashed
him
aside
with
great
violence
,
and
hurrying
to
the
brink
of
the
pit
,
uttered
a
fearful
cry
,
and
exclaiming
,
<EOS>
"
She
is
here
!
<EOS>
she
is
here!--I
shall
find
her
amongst
them!"--flung
himself
into
the
abyss
.
 
<EOS>
As
soon
as
he
could
shake
off
the
horror
inspired
by
this
dreadful
action
,
Leonard
ran
to
the
pit
,
and
,
gazing
into
it
,
beheld
him
by
the
imperfect
light
struggling
in
the
horrible
mass
in
which
he
was
partially
immersed
.
<EOS>
The
frenzied
man
had
now
,
however
,
begun
to
repent
his
rashness
,
and
cried
out
for
aid
.
<EOS>
But
this
Leonard
found
it
impossible
to
afford
him
;
and
,
seeing
he
must
speedily
perish
if
left
to
himself
,
he
ran
after
the
dead
-
cart
,
and
overtaking
it
just
as
it
reached
Moor
-
gate
,
informed
Chowles
what
had
happened
,
and
begged
him
to
return
.
 
<EOS>
"
There
will
be
no
use
in
helping
him
out
,
"
rejoined
Chowles
,
in
a
tone
of
indifference
.
<EOS>
"
We
shall
have
to
take
him
back
in
a
couple
of
hours
.
<EOS>
No
,
no
--
let
him
remain
where
he
is
.
<EOS>
There
is
scarcely
a
night
that
some
crazy
being
does
not
destroy
himself
in
the
same
way
.
<EOS>
We
never
concern
ourselves
about
such
persons
except
to
strip
them
of
their
apparel
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Unfeeling
wretch
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Leonard
,
unable
to
restrain
his
indignation
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Give
me
your
fork
,
and
I
will
pull
him
out
myself
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
Instead
of
surrendering
the
implement
,
Chowles
flourished
it
over
his
head
with
the
intention
of
striking
the
apprentice
,
but
the
latter
nimbly
avoided
the
blow
,
and
snatching
it
from
his
grasp
,
ran
back
to
the
plague
-
pit
.
<EOS>
He
was
followed
by
Chowles
and
the
burier
,
who
threatened
him
with
loud
oaths
.
<EOS>
Regardless
of
their
menaces
,
Leonard
fixed
the
hook
in
the
dress
of
the
struggling
man
,
and
exerting
all
his
strength
,
drew
him
out
of
the
abyss
.
<EOS>
He
had
just
lodged
him
in
safety
on
the
brink
when
Chowles
and
his
companion
came
up
.
 
<EOS>
"
Keep
off
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Leonard
,
brandishing
his
fork
as
he
spoke
;
"
you
shall
neither
commit
robbery
nor
murder
here
.
<EOS>
If
you
will
assist
this
unfortunate
gentleman
,
I
have
no
doubt
you
will
be
well
rewarded
.
<EOS>
If
not
,
get
hence
,
or
advance
at
your
peril
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Well
,
"
returned
Chowles
,
who
began
to
fancy
something
might
be
made
of
the
matter
,
"
if
you
think
we
should
be
rewarded
,
we
would
convey
the
gentleman
back
to
his
own
home
<EOS>
provided
we
can
ascertain
where
it
is
.
<EOS>
But
I
am
afraid
he
may
die
on
the
way
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
In
that
case
you
can
apply
to
his
friends
,
"
rejoined
Leonard
.
<EOS>
"
He
must
not
be
abandoned
thus
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
First
,
let
us
know
who
he
is
,
"
returned
Chowles
.
<EOS>
"
Is
he
able
to
speak
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
know
not
,
"
answered
Leonard
.
<EOS>
"
Bring
the
lantern
this
way
,
and
let
us
examine
his
countenance
.
"
 
<EOS>
Chowles
complied
,
and
held
the
light
over
the
unfortunate
person
.
<EOS>
His
attire
was
rich
,
but
in
great
disorder
,
and
sullied
by
the
loathsome
mass
in
which
he
had
been
plunged
.
<EOS>
He
was
in
the
flower
of
youth
,
and
his
features
must
have
been
remarkable
for
their
grace
and
beauty
,
but
they
were
now
of
a
livid
hue
,
and
swollen
and
distorted
by
pain
.
<EOS>
Still
Leonard
recognised
them
.
 
<EOS>
"
Gracious
Heaven
!
"
<EOS>
he
exclaimed
.
<EOS>
"
It
is
Sir
Paul
Parravicin
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Sir
Paul
Parravicin
!
"
echoed
Chowles
.
<EOS>
"
By
all
that
's
wonderful
,
so
it
is
!
<EOS>
Here
is
a
lucky
chance
!
<EOS>
Bring
the
dead
-
cart
hither
,
Jonas
--
quick
,
quick
!
<EOS>
I
shall
put
him
under
the
care
of
Judith
Malmayns
.
"
 
<EOS>
And
the
burier
hurried
off
as
fast
as
his
legs
could
carry
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
Had
I
known
who
it
was
,
"
exclaimed
Leonard
,
gazing
with
abhorrence
at
the
miserable
object
before
him
,
"
I
would
have
left
him
to
die
the
death
he
so
richly
merits
!
"
 
<EOS>
A
deep
groan
broke
from
the
sufferer
.
 
<EOS>
"
Have
no
fear
,
Sir
Paul
,
"
said
Chowles
.
<EOS>
"
You
are
in
good
hands
.
<EOS>
Every
care
shall
be
taken
of
you
,
and
you
shall
be
cured
by
Judith
Malmayns
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
She
shall
not
come
near
me
,
"
rejoined
Parravicin
,
faintly
.
<EOS>
"
You
will
take
care
of
me
?
"
<EOS>
he
added
in
an
imploring
tone
,
to
Leonard
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
appeal
in
vain
to
me
,
"
rejoined
the
apprentice
,
sternly
.
<EOS>
"
You
are
justly
punished
for
your
treatment
of
Nizza
Macascree
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
--
I
am
,
"
groaned
Parravicin
,
"
but
she
will
be
speedily
avenged
.
<EOS>
I
shall
soon
join
her
in
that
pit
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
She
is
not
there
,
"
replied
Leonard
,
bitterly
,
"
She
is
fast
recovering
from
the
plague
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Is
she
not
dead
?
"
demanded
Parravicin
,
with
frightful
eagerness
.
<EOS>
"
I
was
told
she
was
thrown
into
that
horrible
chasm
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
were
deceived
,
"
replied
Leonard
.
<EOS>
"
She
was
taken
to
the
pest
-
house
by
your
orders
,
and
would
have
perished
if
she
had
not
found
a
friend
to
aid
her
.
<EOS>
She
is
now
out
of
danger
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Then
I
no
longer
desire
to
die
,
"
cried
Parravicin
,
desperately
.
<EOS>
"
I
will
live
--
live
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Do
not
delude
yourself
,
"
replied
Leonard
,
coldly
;
"
you
have
little
chance
of
recovery
,
and
should
employ
the
short
time
left
you
in
praying
to
Heaven
for
forgiveness
of
your
sins
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Tush
!
"
exclaimed
Parravicin
,
fiercely
<EOS>
,
"
I
shall
not
weary
Heaven
with
ineffectual
supplications
.
<EOS>
I
well
know
I
am
past
all
forgiveness
.
<EOS>
No
,
"
he
added
,
with
a
fearful
imprecation
,
"
since
Nizza
is
alive
,
I
will
not
die
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Right
,
Sir
Paul
,
right
,
"
rejoined
Chowles
<EOS>
;
"
put
a
bold
face
on
it
,
and
I
will
answer
for
it
you
will
get
over
the
attack
.
<EOS>
Have
no
fear
of
Judith
Malmayns
,
"
he
added
,
in
a
significant
tone
.
"
<EOS>
However
she
may
treat
others
,
she
will
cure
_
you
_
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
will
make
it
worth
her
while
to
do
so
,
"
rejoined
Parravicin
.
 
<EOS>
"
Here
is
the
cart
,
"
cried
Chowles
,
seeing
the
vehicle
approach
.
<EOS>
"
I
will
take
you
in
the
first
place
to
Saint
Paul
's
.
<EOS>
Judith
must
see
you
as
soon
as
possible
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Take
me
where
you
please
,
"
rejoined
Parravicin
,
faintly
;
"
and
remember
what
I
have
said
.
<EOS>
If
I
die
,
the
nurse
will
get
nothing
--
if
I
am
cured
,
she
shall
be
proportionately
rewarded
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
will
not
forget
it
,
"
replied
Chowles
.
<EOS>
And
with
the
help
of
Jonas
he
placed
the
knight
carefully
in
the
cart
.
<EOS>
"
You
need
not
trouble
yourself
further
about
him
,
"
he
added
to
Leonard
.
 
<EOS>
"
Before
be
quits
this
place
<EOS>
I
must
know
who
he
is
,
"
rejoined
the
latter
,
placing
himself
at
the
horse
's
head
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
know
his
name
as
well
as
I
do
,
"
replied
Chowles
.
 
<EOS>
"
Parravicin
is
not
his
real
name
,
"
rejoined
Leonard
.
 
<EOS>
"
Indeed
!
"
exclaimed
Chowles
,
"
this
is
news
to
me
.
<EOS>
But
no
matter
who
he
is
,
he
is
rich
enough
to
pay
well
.
<EOS>
So
stand
aside
,
and
let
us
go
.
<EOS>
We
have
no
time
to
waste
in
further
parleying
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
will
not
move
till
my
question
is
answered
,
"
replied
Leonard
.
 
<EOS>
"
We
will
see
to
that
,
"
said
Jonas
,
approaching
him
behind
,
and
dealing
him
so
severe
a
blow
on
the
head
that
he
stretched
him
senseless
on
the
ground
?
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Shall
we
throw
him
into
the
pit
?
"
<EOS>
he
added
to
Chowles
.
 
<EOS>
The
latter
hesitated
for
a
moment
,
and
then
said
,
"
No
,
no
,
it
is
not
worth
while
.
<EOS>
It
may
bring
us
into
trouble
.
<EOS>
We
have
no
time
to
lose
.
"
<EOS>
And
they
then
put
the
cart
in
motion
,
and
took
the
way
to
Saint
Paul
's
.
 
<EOS>
On
coming
to
himself
,
Leonard
had
some
difficulty
in
recalling
what
had
happened
;
and
when
the
whole
train
of
circumstances
rushed
upon
his
mind
,
he
congratulated
himself
that
he
had
escaped
further
injury
.
<EOS>
"
When
I
think
of
the
hands
I
have
been
placed
in
,
"
he
murmured
,
"
I
can
not
but
be
grateful
that
they
did
not
throw
me
into
the
pit
,
where
no
discovery
could
have
been
made
as
to
how
I
came
to
an
end
.
<EOS>
But
I
will
not
rest
till
I
have
ascertained
the
name
and
rank
of
Nizza
's
persecutor
.
<EOS>
I
have
no
doubt
they
have
taken
him
to
Saint
Paul
's
,
and
will
proceed
thither
at
once
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
With
this
view
,
he
hastened
towards
the
nearest
city
gate
,
and
passing
towards
it
,
shaped
his
course
towards
the
cathedral
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
fine
starlight
night
,
and
though
there
was
no
moon
,
the
myriad
lustres
glowing
in
the
deep
and
cloudless
vault
rendered
every
object
plainly
distinguishable
.
<EOS>
At
this
hour
,
little
restraint
was
placed
upon
the
sick
,
and
they
wandered
about
the
streets
uttering
dismal
cries
.
<EOS>
Some
would
fling
themselves
upon
bulks
or
steps
,
where
they
were
not
unfrequently
found
the
next
morning
bereft
of
life
.
<EOS>
Most
of
those
not
attacked
by
the
distemper
kept
close
house
;
but
there
were
some
few
reckless
beings
who
passed
the
night
in
the
wildest
revelry
,
braving
the
fate
awaiting
them
.
<EOS>
As
Leonard
passed
Saint
Michael
's
church
,
in
Basinghall
-
street
,
he
perceived
,
to
his
great
surprise
,
that
it
was
lighted
up
,
and
at
first
supposed
some
service
was
going
on
within
it
,
but
on
approaching
he
heard
strains
of
lively
and
most
irreverent
music
issuing
from
within
.
<EOS>
Pushing
open
the
door
,
he
entered
the
sacred
edifice
,
and
found
it
occupied
by
a
party
of
twenty
young
men
,
accompanied
by
a
like
number
of
females
,
some
of
whom
were
playing
at
dice
and
cards
,
some
drinking
,
<EOS>
others
singing
Bacchanalian
melodies
,
others
dancing
along
the
aisles
to
the
notes
of
a
theorbo
and
spinet
.
<EOS>
Leonard
was
so
inexpressibly
shocked
by
what
he
beheld
,
that
unable
to
contain
himself
<EOS>
he
mounted
the
steps
of
the
pulpit
,
and
called
to
them
in
a
loud
voice
to
desist
from
their
scandalous
conduct
,
and
no
longer
profane
the
house
of
God
.
<EOS>
But
they
treated
his
remonstrances
with
laughter
and
derision
,
and
some
of
the
party
forming
themselves
into
a
group
round
the
pulpit
,
entreated
him
to
preach
to
them
.
 
<EOS>
"
We
want
a
little
variety
,
"
said
one
of
the
group
,
a
good
-
looking
young
man
,
upon
whom
the
wine
had
evidently
made
some
impression--"we
are
tired
of
drinking
and
play
,
and
may
as
well
listen
to
a
sermon
,
especially
an
original
one
.
<EOS>
Hold
forth
to
us
,
I
say
.
<EOS>
"
 
"
I
would
,
hold
forth
till
daybreak
,
if
I
thought
it
would
produce
any
impression
,
"
returned
Leonard
.
<EOS>
"
But
I
perceive
you
are
too
hardened
to
be
aroused
to
repentance
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Repentance
!
"
cried
another
of
the
assemblage
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Do
you
know
whom
you
address
?
<EOS>
These
gentlemen
are
the
Brotherhood
of
Saint
Michael
,
and
I
am
the
principal
.
<EOS>
We
are
determined
to
enjoy
the
few
days
or
hours
we
may
have
left
--
that
is
all
.
<EOS>
We
are
not
afraid
of
the
future
,
and
are
resolved
to
make
the
most
of
the
present
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Ay
,
ay
,
"
cried
the
others
,
with
a
great
shout
of
laughter
,
which
,
however
,
was
interrupted
by
a
cry
of
anguish
from
one
of
the
party
.
 
<EOS>
"
There
is
another
person
seized
,
"
said
the
principal
;
"
take
him
away
,
brothers
.
<EOS>
This
is
owing
to
listening
to
a
sermon
.
<EOS>
Let
us
return
to
our
wine
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Will
you
not
accept
this
awful
warning
?
<EOS>
"
cried
Leonard
.
<EOS>
"
You
will
all
share
your
companion
's
fate
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
We
anticipate
nothing
else
,
"
returned
the
principal
;
"
and
are
therefore
resolved
to
banish
reflection
.
<EOS>
A
week
ago
,
the
Brotherhood
of
Saint
Michael
consisted
of
forty
persons
.
<EOS>
We
are
already
diminished
to
half
the
number
,
but
are
not
the
less
merry
on
that
account
.
<EOS>
On
the
contrary
,
we
are
more
jovial
than
ever
.
<EOS>
We
have
agreed
that
whoever
shall
be
seized
with
the
distemper
,
shall
be
instantly
conveyed
to
the
pest
-
house
,
so
that
the
hilarity
of
the
others
shall
not
be
interrupted
.
<EOS>
The
poor
fellow
who
has
just
been
attacked
has
left
behind
him
a
beautiful
mistress
.
<EOS>
She
is
yours
if
you
choose
to
join
us
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Ay
,
stop
with
us
,
"
cried
a
young
and
very
pretty
woman
,
taking
his
hand
and
drawing
him
towards
the
company
who
were
dancing
beneath
the
aisles
.
 
<EOS>
But
Leonard
disengaged
himself
,
and
hurried
away
amid
the
laughter
and
hootings
of
the
assemblage
.
<EOS>
The
streets
,
despite
their
desolate
appearance
,
were
preferable
to
the
spot
he
had
just
quitted
,
and
he
seemed
to
breathe
more
freely
when
he
got
to
a
little
distance
from
the
polluted
fane
.
<EOS>
He
had
now
entered
Wood
-
street
,
but
all
was
as
still
as
death
,
and
he
paused
to
gaze
up
at
his
master
's
window
,
but
there
was
no
one
at
it
.
<EOS>
Many
a
lover
,
unable
to
behold
the
object
of
his
affections
,
has
in
some
measure
satisfied
the
yearning
of
his
heart
by
gazing
at
her
dwelling
,
and
feeling
he
was
near
her
.
<EOS>
Many
a
sad
heart
has
been
cheered
by
beholding
a
light
at
a
window
,
or
a
shadow
on
its
closed
curtains
,
and
such
would
have
been
Leonard
's
feelings
if
he
had
not
been
depressed
by
the
thought
of
Amabel
's
precarious
state
of
health
.
 
<EOS>
While
thus
wrapt
in
mournful
thought
,
he
observed
three
figures
slowly
approaching
from
the
further
end
of
the
street
,
and
he
instinctively
withdrew
into
a
doorway
.
<EOS>
He
had
reason
to
congratulate
himself
upon
the
precaution
,
as
,
when
the
party
drew
nearer
,
he
recognised
,
with
a
pang
that
shot
to
his
heart
,
the
voice
of
Rochester
.
<EOS>
A
moment
's
observation
from
his
place
of
concealment
showed
him
that
the
earl
was
accompanied
by
Sir
George
Etherege
and
Pillichody
.
<EOS>
They
paused
within
a
short
distance
of
him
,
and
he
could
distinctly
hear
their
conversation
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
have
not
yet
told
us
why
you
brought
us
here
my
lord
,
"
said
Etherege
to
Rochester
,
after
the
latter
had
gazed
for
a
few
moments
in
silence
at
the
house
.
<EOS>
"
Are
you
resolved
to
make
another
attempt
to
carry
off
the
girl
--
and
failing
in
it
,
to
give
her
up
for
ever
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
have
guessed
my
purpose
precisely
,
"
returned
Rochester
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Doctor
Hodges
has
informed
a
friend
of
mine
that
the
pretty
Amabel
has
fallen
into
a
decline
.
<EOS>
The
poor
soul
is
,
doubtless
,
pining
for
me
;
and
it
would
be
the
height
of
inhumanity
to
let
her
perish
.
"
 
<EOS>
Leonard
ground
his
teeth
-
with
suppressed
rage
.
 
<EOS>
"
Then
you
mean
to
make
her
Countess
of
Rochester
,
after
all
,
"
laughed
Etherege
.
<EOS>
"
I
thought
you
had
determined
to
carry
off
Mistress
Mallett
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Old
Bowley
declares
he
will
send
me
to
the
Tower
if
I
do
,
"
replied
Rochester
;
"
and
though
his
threats
would
scarcely
deter
me
from
acting
as
I
think
proper
,
I
have
no
inclination
for
marriage
at
present
.
<EOS>
What
a
pity
,
Etherege
,
that
one
can
not
in
these
affairs
have
the
money
oneself
,
and
give
the
wife
to
one
's
friend
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
That
is
easily
accomplished
,
"
replied
Etherege
,
laughingly
;
"
especially
where
you
have
a
friend
so
devoted
as
myself
.
<EOS>
But
do
you
mean
to
carry
off
Amabel
to
-
night
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Ay
,
now
we
come
to
business
,
"
interposed
Pillichody
.
"
<EOS>
Bolts
and
barricadoes
!
<EOS>
your
lordship
has
only
to
say
the
word
,
and
I
will
break
into
the
house
,
and
bear
her
off
for
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Your
former
conduct
is
a
good
guarantee
for
your
present
success
,
truly
,
"
returned
Rochester
,
with
a
sneer
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
,
no
;
I
shall
postpone
my
design
for
the
present
.
<EOS>
I
have
ascertained
,
from
the
source
<EOS>
whence
<EOS>
I
obtained
information
of
Amabel
's
illness
,
that
she
is
to
be
removed
into
the
country
.
<EOS>
This
will
exactly
suit
my
purpose
,
and
put
her
completely
in
my
power
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Then
nothing
is
to
be
done
to
-
night
?
<EOS>
"
said
Pillichody
,
secretly
congratulating
himself
on
his
escape
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
By
my
sword
!
<EOS>
I
feel
equal
to
the
most
desperate
attempt
.
<EOS>
"
 
"
Your
courage
and
dexterity
must
be
reserved
for
some
more
favourable
occasion
,
"
replied
Rochester
.
 
<EOS>
"
If
not
to
carry
off
the
girl
,
I
must
again
inquire
why
your
lordship
has
come
hither
?
"
demanded
Etherege
.
 
<EOS>
"
To
be
frank
with
you
,
my
sole
motive
was
to
gaze
at
the
house
that
contains
her
,
"
replied
Rochester
,
in
a
voice
that
bespoke
his
sincerity
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
before
told
you
that
she
has
a
strong
hold
upon
my
heart
.
<EOS>
I
have
not
seen
her
for
some
weeks
,
and
during
that
time
have
endeavoured
to
obliterate
her
image
by
making
love
to
a
dozen
others
.
<EOS>
But
it
will
not
do
.
<EOS>
She
still
continues
absolute
mistress
of
my
affections
.
<EOS>
I
sometimes
think
,
if
I
can
obtain
her
in
no
other
way
,
I
shall
be
rash
enough
to
marry
her
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Pshaw
!
<EOS>
this
must
never
be
,
"
said
Etherege
.
 
<EOS>
"
Were
I
to
lose
her
altogether
,
I
should
be
inconsolable
,
"
cried
Rochester
.
 
<EOS>
"
As
inconsolable
as
I
am
for
the
rich
widow
of
Watling
-
street
,
who
died
a
fortnight
ago
of
the
plague
,
and
left
her
wealth
to
her
footman
,
"
replied
Pillichody
,
drawing
forth
his
handkerchief
and
applying
it
to
his
eyes--"oh
!
<EOS>
oh
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
Silence
,
fool
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Rochester
:
"
I
am
in
no
mood
for
buffoonery
.
<EOS>
If
you
shed
tears
for
any
one
,
it
should
be
for
your
master
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Truly
,
I
am
grieved
for
him
,
"
replied
Pillichody
;
"
but
I
object
to
the
term
'
master
.
'
<EOS>
Sir
Paul
Parravicin
,
as
he
chooses
to
be
called
,
is
my
patron
,
not
my
master
.
<EOS>
He
permits
me
a
very
close
familiarity
,
not
to
say
friendship
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Well
,
then
,
your
patron
,
"
rejoined
Rochester
,
scornfully
.
<EOS>
"
How
is
he
going
on
to
-
night
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
feared
to
tell
your
lordship
,
"
replied
Pillichody
,
"
lest
it
should
spoil
your
mirth
;
but
he
broke
out
of
his
chamber
a
few
hours
ago
,
and
has
not
been
discovered
since
.
<EOS>
Most
likely
,
he
will
be
found
in
the
plague
-
pit
or
the
Thames
in
the
morning
,
for
he
was
in
such
an
infuriated
state
,
that
it
is
the
opinion
of
his
attendants
he
would
certainly
destroy
himself
.
<EOS>
You
know
he
was
attacked
two
days
after
Nizza
Macascree
was
seized
by
the
pestilence
,
and
his
brain
has
been
running
upon
the
poor
girl
ever
since
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Alas
!
"
exclaimed
Rochester
,
"
it
is
a
sad
end
.
<EOS>
I
am
wearied
of
this
infected
city
,
and
shall
be
heartily
glad
to
quit
it
.
<EOS>
A
few
months
in
the
country
with
Amabel
will
be
enchanting
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
_
Apropos
_
of
melancholy
subjects
,
"
said
Etherege
,
"
<EOS>
your
masque
of
the
Dance
of
Death
has
caused
great
consternation
at
court
.
<EOS>
Mistress
Stewart
declares
she
can
not
get
that
strange
fellow
who
performed
such
fantastic
tricks
in
the
skeleton
-
dance
out
of
her
head
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
mean
Chowles
,
"
replied
the
earl
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He
is
a
singular
being
,
certainly
--
once
a
coffin
-
maker
,
and
now
,
I
believe
,
a
burier
of
the
dead
.
<EOS>
He
takes
up
his
abode
in
a
crypt
of
Saint
Faith
's
and
leads
an
incomprehensible
life
.
<EOS>
As
we
return
we
shall
pass
the
cathedral
,
and
can
see
whether
he
is
astir
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Readily
,
"
replied
Etherege
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Do
you
desire
to
tarry
here
longer
,
or
shall
we
proceed
before
you
,
while
you
indulge
your
tender
meditations
undisturbed
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Leave
me
,
"
replied
Rochester
;
"
I
shall
be
glad
to
be
alone
for
a
few
moments
.
"
 
<EOS>
Etherege
and
Pillichody
then
proceeded
slowly
towards
Cheapside
,
while
the
earl
remained
with
his
arms
folded
upon
his
breast
,
and
his
gaze
fixed
upon
the
house
.
<EOS>
Leonard
watched
him
with
intense
curiosity
,
and
had
great
difficulty
in
controlling
himself
.
<EOS>
Though
the
earl
was
armed
,
while
he
had
only
his
staff
,
he
could
have
easily
mastered
him
by
assailing
him
unawares
.
<EOS>
But
Leonard
's
generous
nature
revolted
at
the
unworthy
suggestion
,
and
he
resolved
,
if
he
attacked
him
at
all
,
to
give
him
time
to
stand
upon
his
guard
.
<EOS>
A
moment
's
reflection
,
however
,
satisfied
him
that
his
wisest
course
would
be
to
remain
concealed
.
<EOS>
He
was
now
in
possession
of
the
earl
's
plan
,
and
,
with
the
help
of
Doctor
Hodges
,
could
easily
defeat
it
;
whereas
if
he
appeared
,
it
would
be
evident
that
he
had
overheard
what
had
passed
,
and
some
other
scheme
,
to
which
he
could
not
be
privy
,
would
be
necessarily
adopted
.
<EOS>
Influenced
by
this
consideration
,
he
suffered
the
earl
to
depart
unmolested
,
and
when
he
had
got
to
some
distance
followed
him
.
<EOS>
Rochester
's
companions
were
waiting
for
him
in
Cheapside
,
and
,
joining
them
,
they
all
three
proceeded
towards
the
cathedral
.
<EOS>
They
entered
the
great
northern
door
;
and
Leonard
,
who
was
now
well
acquainted
with
all
the
approaches
,
passed
through
the
door
at
the
north
side
of
the
choir
,
to
which
he
had
been
directed
on
a
former
occasion
by
Solomon
Eagle
.
<EOS>
He
found
the
party
guided
by
the
old
verger
--
the
only
one
of
its
former
keepers
who
still
lingered
about
the
place
--
and
preparing
to
descend
to
Saint
Faith
's
.
<EOS>
Leonard
followed
as
near
as
he
could
without
exposing
himself
,
and
,
on
gaining
the
subterranean
church
,
easily
contrived
to
screen
himself
behind
the
ponderous
ranks
of
pillars
.
 
<EOS>
By
this
time
they
had
reached
the
door
of
the
charnel
It
was
closed
;
but
Rochester
knocked
against
it
,
and
Chowles
presently
appeared
.
<EOS>
He
seemed
greatly
surprised
at
seeing
the
earl
,
nor
was
the
latter
less
astonished
when
he
learnt
that
Parravicin
was
within
the
vault
.
<EOS>
He
desired
to
be
shown
to
his
friend
,
and
Chowles
ushered
him
into
the
crypt
.
<EOS>
Leonard
would
have
followed
them
;
but
as
Etherege
and
the
others
declined
entering
the
charnel
,
and
remained
at
the
door
,
he
could
not
do
so
.
 
<EOS>
Shortly
after
this
the
sick
man
was
brought
out
,
stretched
upon
a
pallet
,
borne
by
Chowles
and
Judith
;
and
the
party
proceeded
slowly
,
and
occasionally
relieving
each
other
,
to
the
great
western
entrance
,
where
a
coach
being
procured
by
Pillichody
,
Parravicin
was
placed
within
it
,
with
Judith
and
Chowles
;
and
orders
being
given
in
an
under
-
tone
to
the
driver
,
he
departed
.
<EOS>
The
others
then
proceeded
towards
Ludgate
,
while
Leonard
,
again
disappointed
,
retraced
his
steps
to
Wood
-
street
.
        
<EOS>
*
      
<EOS>
*
      
<EOS>
*
      
<EOS>
*
      
<EOS>
*
  
<EOS>
V.
 
HOW
SAINT
PATHOS
WAS
USED
AS
A
PEST
-
HOUSE
.
 
<EOS>
The
distemper
had
by
this
time
increased
to
such
a
frightful
extent
,
that
the
pest
-
houses
being
found
wholly
inadequate
to
contain
the
number
of
sick
persons
sent
to
them
,
it
was
resolved
by
the
civic
authorities
,
who
had
obtained
the
sanction
of
the
Dean
and
Chapter
of
Saint
Paul
's
for
that
purpose
,
to
convert
the
cathedral
into
a
receptacle
for
the
infected
.
<EOS>
Accordingly
,
a
meeting
was
held
in
the
Convocation
House
to
make
final
arrangements
.
<EOS>
It
was
attended
by
Sir
John
Lawrence
,
the
Lord
Mayor
;
by
Sir
George
Waterman
,
and
Sir
Charles
Doe
,
sheriffs
;
by
Doctor
Sheldon
,
Archbishop
of
Canterbury
;
by
the
Duke
of
Albemarle
,
the
Earl
of
Craven
,
and
,
a
few
other
zealous
and
humane
persons
.
<EOS>
Several
members
of
the
College
of
Physicians
were
likewise
present
,
and
,
amongst
others
,
Doctor
Hodges
;
and
the
expediency
of
the
measure
being
fully
agreed
upon
,
it
was
determined
to
carry
it
into
immediate
execution
.
 
<EOS>
The
cloisters
surrounding
the
Convocation
House
were
crowded
with
sick
persons
,
drawn
thither
by
the
rumour
of
what
was
going
forward
;
and
when
the
meeting
adjourned
to
the
cathedral
,
these
unfortunate
beings
followed
them
,
and
were
with
some
difficulty
kept
aloof
from
the
uninfected
by
the
attendants
.
<EOS>
A
very
earnest
and
touching
address
was
next
pronounced
by
the
archbishop
.
<EOS>
Calling
upon
his
hearers
to
look
upon
themselves
as
already
dead
to
the
world,--to
regard
the
present
visitation
as
a
just
punishment
of
their
sins
,
and
to
rejoice
that
their
sufferings
would
be
so
soon
terminated
,
when
,
if
they
sincerely
and
heartily
repented
,
they
would
at
once
be
transported
from
the
depths
of
wretchedness
and
misery
to
regions
of
unfading
bliss
;
he
concluded
by
stating
that
he
,
and
all
those
around
him
,
were
prepared
to
devote
themselves
,
without
regard
to
their
own
safety
,
to
the
preservation
of
their
fellow
-
citizens
,
and
that
they
would
leave
nothing
undone
to
stop
the
ravages
of
the
devouring
scourge
.
 
<EOS>
It
chanced
that
Leonard
Holt
was
present
on
this
occasion
,
and
as
he
listened
to
the
eloquent
discourse
of
the
archbishop
,
and
gazed
at
the
group
around
him
,
all
equally
zealous
in
the
good
cause
,
and
equally
regardless
of
themselves
,
he
could
not
but
indulge
a
hope
that
their
exertions
might
be
crowned
with
success
.
<EOS>
It
was
indeed
a
touching
sight
to
see
the
melancholy
congregation
to
whom
his
address
was
delivered
--
many
,
nay
most
of
whom
were
on
the
verge
of
dissolution;--and
<EOS>
Leonard
Holt
was
so
moved
by
the
almost
apostolic
fervour
of
the
prelate
,
<EOS>
that
,
but
for
the
thought
of
Amabel
,
he
might
have
followed
the
example
of
several
of
the
auditors
,
and
devoted
himself
altogether
to
the
service
of
the
sick
.
 
<EOS>
His
discourse
concluded
,
the
archbishop
and
most
of
his
companions
quitted
the
cathedral
.
<EOS>
Hodges
,
however
,
and
three
of
the
physicians
,
remained
behind
to
superintend
the
necessary
preparations
.
<EOS>
Shortly
after
,
a
large
number
of
pallets
were
brought
in
,
and
ranged
along
the
nave
and
aisles
at
short
distances
from
each
other
;
and
,
before
night
,
the
interior
of
the
structure
presented
the
complete
appearance
of
an
hospital
.
<EOS>
Acting
under
the
directions
of
Doctor
Hodges
,
Leonard
Holt
lent
his
assistance
in
arranging
the
pallets
,
in
covering
them
with
bedding
and
blankets
,
and
in
executing
any
other
service
required
of
him
.
<EOS>
A
sufficient
number
of
chirurgeons
and
nurses
were
then
sent
for
,
and
such
was
the
expedition
used
,
that
on
that
very
night
most
of
the
pallets
were
occupied
.
<EOS>
Thus
the
cathedral
underwent
another
afflicting
change
.
<EOS>
A
blight
had
come
over
it
,
mildewing
its
holy
walls
,
and
tainting
and
polluting
its
altars
.
<EOS>
Its
aisles
,
once
trodden
by
grave
and
reverend
ecclesiastics
,
and
subsequently
haunted
by
rufflers
,
bullies
,
and
other
worthless
characters
,
were
now
filled
with
miserable
wretches
,
stricken
with
a
loathsome
and
fatal
distemper
.
<EOS>
Its
chapels
and
shrines
formerly
adorned
with
rich
sculptures
and
costly
ornaments
,
but
stripped
of
them
at
times
when
they
were
looked
upon
as
idolatrous
and
profane
,
were
now
occupied
by
nurses
,
chirurgeons
,
and
their
attendants
;
while
every
niche
and
corner
was
filled
with
surgical
implements
,
phials
,
drugs
,
poultices
,
foul
rags
,
and
linen
.
 
<EOS>
In
less
than
a
week
after
it
had
been
converted
into
a
pest
-
house
,
the
cathedral
was
crowded
to
overflowing
.
<EOS>
Upwards
of
three
hundred
pallets
were
set
up
in
the
nave
,
in
the
aisles
,
in
the
transepts
,
and
in
the
choir
,
and
even
in
the
chapels
.
<EOS>
But
these
proving
insufficient
,
many
poor
wretches
who
were
brought
thither
were
placed
on
the
cold
flags
,
and
protected
only
by
a
single
blanket
.
<EOS>
At
night
the
scene
was
really
terrific
.
<EOS>
The
imperfect
light
borne
by
the
attendants
fell
on
the
couches
,
and
revealed
the
livid
countenances
of
their
occupants
;
while
the
vaulted
roof
rang
with
shrieks
and
groans
<EOS>
so
horrible
and
heart
-
piercing
as
to
be
scarcely
endured
,
except
by
those
whose
nerves
were
firmly
strung
,
or
had
become
blunted
by
their
constant
recurrence
.
<EOS>
At
such
times
,
too
,
some
unhappy
creature
,
frenzied
by
agony
,
would
burst
from
his
couch
,
and
rend
the
air
with
his
cries
,
until
overtaken
and
overpowered
by
his
attendants
.
<EOS>
On
one
occasion
,
it
happened
that
a
poor
wretch
,
who
had
been
thus
caught
,
broke
loose
a
second
time
,
and
darting
through
a
door
leading
to
the
stone
staircase
in
the
northern
transept
gained
the
ambulatory
,
and
being
closely
followed
,
to
escape
his
pursuers
,
sprang
through
one
of
the
arched
openings
,
and
falling
from
a
height
of
near
sixty
feet
,
was
dashed
in
pieces
on
the
flagged
floor
beneath
.
 
<EOS>
A
walk
through
this
mighty
lazar
-
house
would
have
furnished
a
wholesome
lesson
to
the
most
reckless
observer
.
<EOS>
It
seemed
to
contain
all
the
sick
of
the
city
.
<EOS>
And
yet
it
was
not
so
.
<EOS>
Hundreds
were
expiring
in
their
own
dwellings
,
and
the
other
pest
-
houses
continued
crowded
as
before
.
<EOS>
Still
,
as
a
far
greater
number
of
the
infected
were
here
congregated
,
and
could
be
seen
at
one
view
,
the
picture
was
incomparably
more
impressive
.
<EOS>
Every
part
of
the
cathedral
was
occupied
.
<EOS>
Those
who
could
not
find
room
inside
it
crouched
beneath
the
columns
of
the
portico
on
rugs
or
blankets
,
and
implored
the
chirurgeons
as
they
passed
to
attend
them
.
<EOS>
Want
of
room
also
drove
others
into
Saint
Faith
's
,
and
here
the
scene
was
,
if
possible
,
more
hideous
.
<EOS>
In
this
dismal
region
it
was
found
impossible
to
obtain
a
free
circulation
of
air
,
and
consequently
the
pestilential
effluvia
,
unable
to
escape
,
acquired
such
malignancy
,
that
it
was
almost
certain
destruction
to
inhale
it
.
<EOS>
After
a
time
,
few
of
the
nurses
and
attendants
would
venture
thither
;
and
to
take
a
patient
to
Saint
Faith
's
was
considered
tantamount
to
consigning
him
to
the
grave
.
 
<EOS>
Whether
Judith
Malmayns
had
succeeded
or
not
in
curing
Sir
Paul
Parravicin
,
it
is
not
our
present
purpose
to
relate
.
<EOS>
Soon
after
the
cathedral
was
converted
into
a
lazar
-
house
she
returned
thither
,
and
,
in
spite
of
the
opposition
of
Doctor
Hodges
,
was
appointed
one
of
the
nurses
.
<EOS>
It
must
not
be
supposed
that
her
appointment
was
the
result
of
any
ill
design
.
<EOS>
Such
was
the
difficulty
of
obtaining
attendance
,
that
little
choice
was
left
,
and
the
nurses
being
all
of
questionable
character
<EOS>
,
it
was
supposed
she
was
only
a
shade
worse
than
her
fellows
,
while
she
was
known
to
be
active
and
courageous
.
<EOS>
And
this
was
speedily
proved
;
for
when
Saint
Faith
's
was
deserted
by
the
others
,
she
remained
at
her
post
,
and
quitted
it
neither
night
nor
day
.
<EOS>
A
large
pit
was
digged
in
the
open
space
at
the
north
-
east
corner
of
the
cathedral
,
and
to
this
great
numbers
of
bodies
were
nightly
conveyed
by
Chowles
and
Jonas
.
<EOS>
But
it
was
soon
filled
,
and
they
were
compelled
to
resort
,
as
before
,
to
Finsbury
Fields
,
and
to
another
vast
pit
near
Aldgate
.
<EOS>
When
not
engaged
in
this
revolting
employment
,
Chowles
took
up
his
quarters
in
the
crypt
,
where
,
in
spite
of
his
propinquity
to
the
sick
,
he
indulged
himself
in
his
customary
revelry
.
<EOS>
He
and
Judith
had
amassed
,
in
one
way
or
other
,
a
vast
quantity
of
spoil
,
and
frequently
planned
how
they
would
spend
it
when
the
pestilence
ceased
.
<EOS>
Their
treasure
was
carefully
concealed
in
a
cell
in
one
of
the
secret
passages
with
which
they
were
acquainted
,
leading
from
Saint
Faith
's
to
the
upper
structure
.
 
<EOS>
One
night
,
on
his
return
from
Finsbury
Fields
,
as
Chowles
was
seated
in
the
crypt
,
with
a
pipe
in
his
mouth
,
and
a
half
-
finished
flask
of
wine
before
him
,
he
was
startled
by
the
sudden
entrance
of
Judith
,
who
,
rushing
up
to
him
,
seized
him
by
the
throat
,
and
almost
choked
him
before
he
could
extricate
himself
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
is
the
matter?--would
you
strangle
me
,
you
murderous
harridan
?
"
he
cried
.
 
<EOS>
"
Ay
,
that
I
would
,
"
replied
Judith
,
preparing
to
renew
the
attack
.
 
<EOS>
"
Stand
off
!
"
rejoined
Chowles
,
springing
back
,
and
snatching
up
a
spade
,
"
or
I
will
dash
out
your
brains
.
<EOS>
Are
you
mad
?
"
<EOS>
he
continued
,
gazing
fearfully
at
her
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
angry
enough
to
make
me
so
,
"
she
replied
,
shaking
her
clenched
fists
at
him
.
"
<EOS>
But
I
will
be
revenged
--
revenged
,
I
tell
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Revenged
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Chowles
,
in
astonishment--"for
what
!
<EOS>
What
have
I
done
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
do
well
to
affect
ignorance
,
"
rejoined
Judith
,
"
but
you
can
not
deceive
me
.
<EOS>
No
one
<EOS>
but
you
can
have
done
it
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Done
what
!
"
exclaimed
Chowles
,
in
increased
astonishment
.
"
<EOS>
Has
our
hoard
been
discovered
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
Ay
,
and
been
carried
off
--
by
you
--
you
!
"
<EOS>
screamed
Judith
,
with
a
look
worthy
of
a
fury
.
 
<EOS>
"
By
my
soul
,
you
are
wrong
,
"
cried
Chowles
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
never
touched
it,--never
even
approached
the
hiding
-
place
,
except
in
your
presence
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Liar
!
"
returned
Judith
,
"
the
whole
hoard
is
gone;--the
plunder
I
obtained
in
Newgate,--the
Earl
of
Rochester
's
plate,--all
the
rings
,
trinkets
,
and
rich
apparel
<EOS>
I
have
picked
up
since,--everything
<EOS>
is
gone;--and
who
<EOS>
but
you
can
be
the
robber
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
difficult
to
say
,
"
rejoined
Chowles
.
"
<EOS>
But
I
swear
to
you
,
you
suspect
me
wrongfully
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Restore
it
,
"
replied
Judith
,
"
or
tell
me
where
it
is
hidden
.
<EOS>
If
not
,
I
will
be
the
death
of
you
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
Let
us
go
to
the
hiding
-
place
,
"
replied
Chowles
,
whose
uneasiness
was
not
diminished
by
the
menace
.
<EOS>
"
You
may
be
mistaken
,
and
I
hope
you
are
.
"
 
<EOS>
Though
he
uttered
the
latter
part
of
his
speech
with
seeming
confidence
,
his
heart
misgave
him
.
<EOS>
To
conceal
his
trepidation
,
he
snatched
up
a
lamp
,
and
passing
through
the
secret
door
,
hurried
along
the
narrow
stone
passage
.
<EOS>
He
was
about
to
open
the
cell
,
when
he
perceived
near
it
the
tall
figure
of
the
enthusiast
.
 
<EOS>
"
There
is
the
robber
,
"
he
cried
to
Judith
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
found
him
.
<EOS>
It
is
Solomon
Eagle
.
<EOS>
Villain
!
<EOS>
you
have
purloined
our
hoard
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
done
so
,
"
replied
Solomon
Eagle
,
"
and
I
will
carry
off
all
other
spoil
you
may
obtain
.
<EOS>
Think
not
to
hide
it
from
me
.
<EOS>
I
can
watch
you
when
you
see
me
not
,
and
track
you
when
you
suppose
me
afar
off
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Indeed
!
"
exclaimed
Chowles
,
trembling
.
<EOS>
"
I
begin
to
think
he
is
possessed
of
supernatural
power
,
"
he
added
,
in
an
undertone
to
Judith
.
 
<EOS>
"
Go
on
,
"
pursued
Solomon
Eagle
,
"
continue
to
plunder
and
destroy
.
<EOS>
Pursue
your
guilty
career
,
and
see
what
reward
you
will
reap
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Restore
what
you
have
robbed
us
of
,
"
cried
Judith
in
a
menacing
tone
,
"
or
dread
the
consequences
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Woman
,
you
threaten
idly
,
"
returned
Solomon
Eagle
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Your
ill
-
gotten
treasure
is
gone
--
whither
,
you
will
never
know
.
<EOS>
Get
hence
!
"
<EOS>
he
added
,
in
a
terrible
tone
,
"
or
I
will
rid
the
earth
of
you
both
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
So
awed
were
they
by
his
voice
and
gestures
,
that
they
slunk
away
with
a
discomfited
air
,
and
returned
to
the
crypt
.
 
<EOS>
"
If
we
are
always
to
be
robbed
in
this
manner
,
"
observed
Chowles
,
"
we
had
better
shift
our
quarters
,
and
practise
elsewhere
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
He
shall
not
repeat
the
offence
with
impunity
,
"
returned
Judith
.
<EOS>
"
I
will
speedily
get
rid
of
him
.
"
 
"
Beware
!
"
cried
a
voice
,
which
they
recognised
as
that
of
Solomon
Eagle
,
though
whence
proceeding
they
could
not
precisely
determine
.
<EOS>
The
pair
looked
at
each
other
uneasily
,
but
neither
spoke
a
word
.
 
<EOS>
Meanwhile
,
Leonard
Holt
did
not
omit
to
pay
a
daily
visit
to
the
cathedral
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
painful
contemplation
,
and
yet
not
without
deep
interest
,
to
behold
the
constant
succession
of
patients
,
most
of
whom
were
swept
away
by
the
scourge
in
the
course
of
a
couple
of
days
,
or
even
in
a
shorter
period
.
<EOS>
Out
of
every
hundred
persons
attacked
,
five
did
not
recover
;
and
whether
the
virulence
of
the
distemper
increased
,
or
the
summer
heats
rendered
its
victims
more
easily
assailable
,
certain
it
is
they
were
carried
off
far
more
expeditiously
than
before
.
<EOS>
Doctor
Hodges
was
unremitting
in
his
attentions
,
but
his
zeal
and
anxiety
availed
nothing
.
<EOS>
He
had
to
contend
with
a
disease
over
which
medicine
exercised
little
control
.
 
<EOS>
One
morning
,
as
he
was
about
to
enter
the
cathedral
,
he
met
Leonard
beneath
the
portico
,
and
as
soon
as
the
latter
caught
sight
of
him
,
he
hurried
towards
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
been
in
search
of
you
,
"
he
said
,
"
and
was
about
to
proceed
to
your
residence
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Bloundel
wishes
to
see
you
immediately
.
<EOS>
Amabel
is
worse
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
will
go
with
you
at
once
,
"
replied
the
doctor
.
 
<EOS>
And
they
took
the
way
to
Wood
-
street
.
 
<EOS>
"
From
a
few
words
let
<EOS>
fall
by
my
master
,
I
imagine
he
intends
sending
Amabel
into
the
country
to
-
morrow
,
"
said
Leonard
,
as
they
proceeded
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
hope
so
,
"
replied
Hodges
.
"
<EOS>
He
has
already
delayed
it
too
long
.
<EOS>
You
will
be
glad
to
hear
that
Nizza
Macascree
is
quite
recovered
.
<EOS>
To
-
morrow
,
or
the
next
day
,
she
will
be
able
to
see
you
with
safety
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Heaven
knows
where
I
may
be
to
-
morrow
,
"
rejoined
Leonard
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Wherever
Amabel
goes
,
I
shall
not
be
far
off
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Faithful
to
the
last
!
"
exclaimed
Hodges
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
,
I
shall
not
oppose
you
.
<EOS>
We
must
take
care
the
Earl
of
Rochester
does
not
get
a
hint
of
our
proceeding
.
<EOS>
At
this
time
a
chance
meeting
(
were
it
nothing
more
)
might
prove
fatal
to
the
object
of
our
solicitude
.
"
 
<EOS>
Leonard
said
nothing
,
but
the
colour
fled
his
cheek
,
and
his
lips
slightly
quivered
.
<EOS>
In
a
few
seconds
more
they
reached
the
grocer
's
house
.
 
<EOS>
They
found
him
at
the
window
anxiously
expecting
them
;
and
Doctor
Hodges
,
being
drawn
up
in
the
same
way
as
before
,
was
conducted
to
Amabel
's
chamber
.
<EOS>
She
was
reclining
in
an
easy
-
chair
,
with
the
Bible
on
her
knee
;
and
though
she
was
much
wasted
away
,
she
looked
more
lovely
than
ever
.
<EOS>
A
slight
hectic
flush
increased
the
brilliancy
of
her
eyes
,
which
had
now
acquired
that
ominous
lustre
peculiar
to
persons
in
a
decline
.
<EOS>
There
were
other
distressing
symptoms
in
her
appearance
which
the
skilful
physician
well
knew
how
to
interpret
.
<EOS>
To
an
inexperienced
eye
,
however
,
she
would
have
appeared
charming
.
<EOS>
Nothing
could
exceed
the
delicacy
of
her
complexion
,
or
the
lovely
mould
of
her
features
,
which
,
though
they
had
lost
much
of
their
fulness
and
roundness
,
had
gained
in
expression
;
while
the
pencilled
brows
clearly
traced
upon
her
snowy
forehead
,
the
long
dark
eyelashes
shading
her
cheek
,
and
the
rich
satin
tresses
drooping
over
her
shoulders
,
completed
her
attractions
.
<EOS>
Her
mother
stood
by
her
side
,
and
not
far
from
her
sat
little
Christiana
,
amusing
herself
with
some
childish
toy
,
and
ever
and
anon
stealing
an
anxious
glance
at
her
sister
.
<EOS>
Taking
Amabel
's
arm
,
and
sighing
to
himself
to
think
how
thin
it
was
,
the
doctor
placed
his
finger
upon
her
pulse
.
<EOS>
Whatever
might
be
his
secret
opinion
,
he
thought
fit
to
assume
a
hopeful
manner
,
and
looking
smilingly
at
her
,
said
,
"
You
are
better
than
I
expected
,
but
your
departure
to
the
country
must
not
be
deferred
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Since
it
is
my
father
's
wish
that
I
should
do
so
,
"
replied
Amabel
,
gently
,
"
I
am
quite
willing
to
comply
.
<EOS>
But
I
feel
it
will
be
of
no
avail
,
and
I
would
rather
pass
the
rest
of
my
life
here
than
with
strangers
.
<EOS>
I
can
not
be
happier
than
I
am
now
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
not
,
"
replied
Hodges
;
"
but
a
few
weeks
spent
in
some
salubrious
spot
will
remove
all
apprehensions
as
to
your
health
.
<EOS>
You
will
find
your
strength
return
,
and
with
it
the
desire
of
life
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
My
life
is
in
the
hands
of
my
Maker
,
"
replied
Amabel
,
"
and
I
am
ready
to
resign
it
whenever
it
shall
be
required
of
me
.
<EOS>
At
the
same
time
,
however
anxious
I
may
be
to
quit
a
world
which
appears
a
blank
to
me
,
I
would
make
every
effort
,
for
the
sake
of
those
whose
happiness
is
dearer
to
me
than
my
own
,
to
purchase
a
complete
restoration
to
health
.
<EOS>
If
my
father
desires
me
to
try
a
removal
to
the
country
,
and
you
think
it
will
have
a
beneficial
effect
,
I
am
ready
to
go
.
<EOS>
But
do
not
urge
it
,
unless
you
think
there
is
a
chance
of
my
recovery
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
will
tell
you
frankly
,
"
replied
the
doctor
,
"
if
you
remain
here
,
you
have
not
many
weeks
to
live
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
But
if
I
go
,
will
you
promise
me
health
?
"
rejoined
Amabel
.
"
<EOS>
Do
not
deceive
me
.
<EOS>
Is
there
a
hope
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
Unquestionably
,
"
replied
the
doctor
.
<EOS>
"
Change
of
air
will
work
wonders
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
beseech
you
not
to
hesitate
--
for
my
sake
do
not
,
dearest
daughter
,
"
said
Mrs.
Bloundel
,
with
difficulty
repressing
tears
.
 
<EOS>
"
And
for
mine
,
"
added
her
father
,
more
firmly
,
yet
with
deep
emotion
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
already
expressed
my
readiness
to
accede
to
your
wishes
,
"
replied
Amabel
.
<EOS>
"
Whenever
you
have
made
arrangements
for
me
,
I
will
set
out
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
And
now
comes
the
question
--
where
is
she
to
go
?
"
remarked
Hodges
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
a
sister
,
who
lives
as
housekeeper
at
Lord
Craven
's
seat
,
Ashdown
Park
,
"
replied
Mr.
Bloundel
.
<EOS>
"
She
shall
go
thither
,
and
her
aunt
will
take
every
care
of
her
.
<EOS>
The
mansion
is
situated
amid
the
Berkshire
hills
,
and
the
air
is
the
purest
and
best
in
England
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Nothing
can
be
better
,
"
replied
Hodges
;
"
but
who
is
to
escort
her
thither
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
Leonard
Holt
,
"
replied
Mr.
Bloundel
.
<EOS>
"
He
will
gladly
undertake
the
office
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
No
doubt
,
"
rejoined
Hodges
;
"
but
can
not
you
go
yourself
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Impossible
!
"
returned
the
grocer
,
a
shade
passing
over
his
countenance
.
 
<EOS>
"
Neither
do
I
wish
it
,
"
observed
Amabel
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
content
to
be
under
the
safeguard
of
Leonard
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Amabel
,
"
said
her
father
,
"
you
know
not
what
I
shall
endure
in
thus
parting
with
you
.
<EOS>
I
would
give
all
I
possess
to
be
able
to
accompany
you
,
but
a
sense
of
duty
restrains
me
.
<EOS>
I
have
taken
the
resolution
to
remain
here
with
my
family
during
the
continuance
of
the
pestilence
,
and
I
must
abide
by
it
.
<EOS>
I
little
thought
how
severely
my
constancy
would
be
tried
.
<EOS>
But
hard
though
it
be
,
I
must
submit
I
shall
commit
you
,
therefore
,
to
the
care
of
an
all
-
merciful
Providence
,
who
will
not
fail
to
watch
over
and
protect
you
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Have
no
fear
for
me
,
father
,
"
replied
Amabel
;
"
and
do
not
weep
,
dear
mother
,
"
she
added
to
Mrs.
Bloundel
,
who
,
unable
to
restrain
her
grief
,
was
now
drowned
in
tears
;
"
I
shall
be
well
cared
for
.
<EOS>
If
we
meet
no
more
in
this
world
,
our
reunion
is
certain
in
that
to
come
.
<EOS>
I
have
given
you
much
pain
and
uneasiness
,
but
it
will
be
an
additional
grief
to
me
if
I
think
you
feel
further
anxiety
on
my
account
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
We
do
not
,
my
dear
child
,
"
replied
Mr.
Bloundel
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
well
assured
all
is
for
the
best
,
and
if
it
pleases
Heaven
to
spare
you
,
I
shall
rejoice
beyond
measure
in
your
return
.
<EOS>
If
not
,
I
shall
feel
a
firm
reliance
that
you
will
continue
in
the
same
happy
frame
,
as
at
present
,
to
the
last
,
and
that
we
shall
meet
above
,
where
there
will
be
no
further
separation
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
can
not
bear
to
part
with
her
,
"
cried
Mrs.
Bloundel
,
clasping
her
arms
round
her
daughter--"I
cannot
--
I
can
not
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
Restrain
yourself
,
Honora
,
"
said
her
husband
;
"
you
will
do
her
an
injury
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
She
must
not
be
over
excited
,
"
interposed
Hodges
,
in
a
low
tone
,
and
gently
drawing
the
afflicted
mother
away
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
sooner
,
"
he
added
to
Mr.
Bloundel
,
"
she
now
sets
out
the
better
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
feel
it
,
"
replied
the
grocer
.
<EOS>
"
She
shall
start
to
-
morrow
morning
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
will
undertake
to
procure
horses
,
"
replied
Hodges
,
"
and
Leonard
will
be
ready
at
any
moment
.
"
 
<EOS>
With
this
,
he
took
his
leave
,
and
descending
by
the
pulley
,
communicated
to
Leonard
what
had
occurred
.
 
<EOS>
In
spite
of
his
fears
on
her
account
,
the
prospect
of
again
beholding
Amabel
so
transported
the
apprentice
that
he
could
scarcely
attend
to
what
was
said
respecting
her
.
<EOS>
When
he
grew
calmer
,
it
was
arranged
that
all
should
be
in
readiness
at
an
early
hour
on
the
following
morning
;
that
a
couple
of
horses
should
be
provided
;
and
that
Amabel
should
be
let
down
fully
equipped
for
the
journey
.
<EOS>
This
settled
,
Leonard
,
at
the
doctor
's
request
,
accompanied
him
to
his
residence
.
 
<EOS>
They
were
scarcely
out
of
sight
,
when
a
man
,
who
had
been
concealed
behind
the
hutch
,
in
such
a
position
that
not
a
word
that
had
passed
escaped
him
,
issued
from
his
hiding
-
place
,
and
darting
down
the
first
alley
on
the
right
,
made
the
best
of
his
way
to
Whitehall
.
 
<EOS>
Up
to
this
time
,
Doctor
Hodges
had
not
judged
it
prudent
to
allow
a
meeting
between
Leonard
and
Nizza
Macascree
,
but
now
,
from
reasons
of
his
own
,
he
resolved
no
longer
to
delay
it
.
<EOS>
Accordingly
,
on
reaching
his
dwelling
,
he
took
the
apprentice
to
her
chamber
.
<EOS>
She
was
standing
in
a
pensive
attitude
,
near
a
window
which
looked
towards
the
river
,
and
as
she
turned
on
his
entrance
,
Leonard
perceived
that
her
eyes
were
filled
with
tears
.
<EOS>
Blushing
deeply
,
she
advanced
towards
him
,
and
greeted
him
with
all
the
warmth
of
her
affectionate
nature
.
<EOS>
She
had
quite
recovered
her
good
looks
,
and
Leonard
could
not
but
admit
that
,
had
he
seen
her
before
his
heart
