was
plighted
to
another
,
it
must
have
been
given
to
her
.
<EOS>
Comparisons
are
ungracious
,
and
tastes
differ
more
perhaps
as
to
beauty
than
on
any
other
point
;
but
if
Amabel
and
the
piper
's
daughter
had
been
placed
together
,
it
would
not
have
been
difficult
to
determine
to
which
of
the
two
the
palm
of
superior
loveliness
should
be
assigned
.
<EOS>
There
was
a
witchery
in
the
magnificent
black
eyes
of
the
latter
--
in
her
exquisitely
-
formed
mouth
and
pearly
teeth
--
in
her
clear
nut
-
brown
complexion
--
in
her
dusky
and
luxuriant
tresses
,
and
in
her
light
elastic
figure
,
with
which
more
perfect
but
less
piquant
charms
could
not
compete
.
<EOS>
Such
seemed
to
be
the
opinion
of
Doctor
Hodges
,
for
as
he
gazed
at
her
with
unaffected
admiration
<EOS>
,
he
exclaimed
,
as
if
to
himself--
<EOS>
"
I'faith
,
if
I
had
to
choose
between
the
two
,
I
know
which
it
would
be
.
"
 
<EOS>
This
exclamation
somewhat
disconcerted
the
parties
to
whom
it
referred
,
and
the
doctor
did
not
relieve
their
embarrassment
by
adding
,
"
Well
,
I
perceive
I
am
in
the
way
.
<EOS>
You
must
have
much
to
say
to
each
other
that
can
in
nowise
interest
me
.
<EOS>
Excuse
me
a
moment
,
while
I
see
that
the
horses
are
ordered
.
"
 
<EOS>
So
saying
,
and
disregarding
Leonard
's
expostulating
looks
,
he
hurried
out
of
the
room
,
and
shut
the
door
after
him
.
 
<EOS>
Hitherto
,
the
conversation
had
been
unrestrained
and
agreeable
on
both
sides
,
but
now
they
were
left
alone
together
,
neither
appeared
able
to
utter
a
word
.
<EOS>
Nizza
cast
her
eyes
timidly
on
the
ground
,
while
Leonard
caressed
little
Bell
,
who
had
been
vainly
endeavouring
by
her
gamesome
tricks
to
win
his
attention
.
 
<EOS>
"
Doctor
Hodges
spoke
of
ordering
horses
,
"
said
Nizza
,
at
length
breaking
silence
.
<EOS>
"
Are
you
going
on
a
journey
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
about
to
take
Amabel
to
Ashdown
Park
,
in
Berkshire
,
to
-
morrow
morning
,
"
replied
Leonard
.
<EOS>
"
She
is
dangerously
ill
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Of
the
plague
?
"
asked
Nizza
,
anxiously
.
 
<EOS>
"
Of
a
yet
worse
disorder
,
"
replied
Leonard
,
heaving
a
deep
sigh--"of
a
broken
heart
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Alas
!
<EOS>
I
pity
her
from
my
soul
!
"
<EOS>
replied
Nizza
,
in
a
tone
of
the
deepest
commiseration
.
<EOS>
"
Does
her
mother
go
with
her
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
replied
Leonard
,
"
I
alone
shall
attend
her
.
<EOS>
She
will
be
placed
under
the
care
of
a
near
female
relative
at
Ashdown
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Would
it
not
be
better,--would
<EOS>
it
not
be
safer
,
if
she
is
in
the
precarious
state
you
describe
,
that
some
one
of
her
own
sex
should
accompany
her
?
"
said
Nizza
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
should
greatly
prefer
it
,
"
rejoined
Leonard
,
"
and
<EOS>
so
I
am
sure
would
Amabel
.
<EOS>
But
where
is
such
a
person
to
be
found
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
will
go
with
you
,
if
you
desire
it
,
"
replied
Nizza
,
"
and
will
watch
over
her
,
and
tend
her
as
a
sister
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Are
you
equal
to
the
journey
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Leonard
,
somewhat
doubtfully
.
 
<EOS>
"
Fully
,
"
replied
Nizza
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
entirely
recovered
,
and
able
to
undergo
far
more
fatigues
than
an
invalid
like
Amabel
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
will
relieve
me
from
a
world
of
anxiety
if
this
can
be
accomplished
,
"
rejoined
Leonard
.
<EOS>
"
I
will
consult
Doctor
Hodges
on
the
subject
on
his
return
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
desire
to
consult
me
about
?
<EOS>
"
cried
the
physician
,
who
had
entered
the
room
unobserved
at
this
juncture
.
 
<EOS>
The
apprentice
stated
Nizza
's
proposal
to
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
entirely
approve
of
the
plan
,
"
observed
the
doctor
;
"
it
will
obviate
many
difficulties
.
<EOS>
I
have
just
received
a
message
from
Mr.
Bloundel
,
by
Dallison
,
the
porter
,
to
say
he
intends
sending
Blaize
with
you
.
<EOS>
I
will
therefore
provide
pillions
for
the
horses
,
so
that
the
whole
party
can
be
accommodated
.
"
 
<EOS>
He
then
sat
down
and
wrote
out
minute
instructions
for
Amabel
's
treatment
,
and
delivering
the
paper
to
Leonard
,
desired
him
to
give
it
to
the
housekeeper
at
Ashdown
Park
.
 
<EOS>
"
Heaven
only
knows
what
the
result
of
all
this
may
be
!
"
<EOS>
he
exclaimed
.
"
But
nothing
must
be
neglected
.
"
 
<EOS>
Leonard
promised
that
his
advice
should
be
scrupulously
attended
to
;
and
the
discourse
then
turning
to
Nizza
's
father
,
she
expressed
the
utmost
anxiety
to
see
him
before
she
set
out
.
 
<EOS>
Hodges
readily
assented
.
<EOS>
"
Your
father
has
been
discharged
as
cured
from
the
pest
-
house
,
"
he
said
,
"
and
is
lodged
at
a
cottage
,
kept
by
my
old
nurse
,
Dame
Lucas
,
just
without
the
walls
,
near
Moorgate
.
<EOS>
I
will
send
for
him
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
On
no
account
,
"
replied
Nizza
.
<EOS>
"
I
will
go
to
him
myself
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
As
you
please
,
"
returned
Hodges
.
<EOS>
"
Leonard
shall
accompany
you
.
<EOS>
You
will
easily
find
the
cottage
.
<EOS>
It
is
about
two
hundred
yards
beyond
the
gate
,
on
the
right
,
near
the
old
doghouses
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
know
the
spot
perfectly
,
"
rejoined
Leonard
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
would
recommend
you
to
put
on
a
mask
,
"
observed
the
doctor
to
Nizza
;
"
it
may
protect
you
from
molestation
.
<EOS>
I
will
find
you
one
below
.
"
 
<EOS>
Leading
the
way
to
a
lower
room
,
he
opened
a
drawer
,
and
,
producing
a
small
loo
mask
,
gave
it
her
.
<EOS>
The
youthful
pair
then
quitted
the
house
,
Nizza
taking
Bell
under
her
arm
,
as
she
intended
leaving
her
with
her
father
.
<EOS>
The
necessity
of
the
doctor
's
caution
was
speedily
manifested
,
for
as
they
crossed
Saint
Paul
's
churchyard
they
encountered
Pillichody
,
who
,
glancing
inquisitively
at
Nizza
,
seemed
disposed
to
push
his
inquiries
further
by
attempting
to
take
off
her
mask
;
but
the
fierce
look
of
the
apprentice
,
who
grasped
his
staff
in
a
menacing
manner
,
induced
him
to
abandon
his
purpose
.
<EOS>
He
,
however
,
followed
them
along
Cheapside
,
and
would
have
continued
the
pursuit
along
the
Old
Jewry
,
if
Leonard
had
not
come
to
a
halt
,
and
awaited
his
approach
.
<EOS>
He
then
took
to
his
heels
,
and
did
not
again
make
his
appearance
.
 
<EOS>
As
they
reached
the
open
fields
and
slackened
their
pace
,
Leonard
deemed
it
prudent
to
prepare
his
companion
for
her
interview
with
her
father
by
mentioning
the
circumstance
of
the
packet
,
and
the
important
secret
which
he
had
stated
he
had
to
disclose
to
her
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
can
not
tell
what
the
secret
can
relate
to
,
unless
it
is
to
my
mother
,
"
rejoined
Nizza
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
She
died
,
I
believe
,
when
I
was
an
infant
.
<EOS>
At
all
events
,
I
never
remember
seeing
her
,
and
I
have
remarked
that
my
father
is
averse
to
talking
about
her
.
<EOS>
But
I
will
now
question
him
.
<EOS>
I
have
reason
to
think
this
piece
of
gold
,
"
and
she
produced
the
amulet
,
"
is
in
some
way
or
other
connected
with
the
mystery
.
"
 
<EOS>
And
she
then
explained
to
Leonard
all
that
had
occurred
in
the
vault
when
the
coin
had
been
shown
to
Judith
Malmayns
,
describing
the
nurse
's
singular
look
and
her
father
's
subsequent
anger
.
 
<EOS>
By
this
time
,
they
had
entered
a
narrow
footpath
leading
across
the
fields
in
the
direction
of
a
little
nest
of
cottages
,
and
pursuing
it
,
they
came
to
a
garden
-
gate
.
<EOS>
Opening
it
,
they
beheld
the
piper
seated
beneath
a
little
porch
covered
with
eglantine
and
roses
.
<EOS>
He
was
playing
a
few
notes
on
his
pipe
,
but
stopped
on
hearing
their
approach
.
<EOS>
Bell
,
who
had
been
put
to
the
ground
by
Nizza
,
ran
barking
gleefully
towards
him
.
<EOS>
Uttering
a
joyful
exclamation
,
the
piper
stretched
out
his
arms
,
and
the
next
moment
enfolded
his
daughter
in
a
strict
embrace
.
<EOS>
Leonard
remained
at
the
gate
till
the
first
transports
of
their
meeting
were
over
,
and
then
advanced
slowly
towards
them
.
 
<EOS>
"
Whose
footsteps
are
those
?
"
inquired
the
piper
.
 
<EOS>
Nizza
explained
.
 
<EOS>
"
Ah
,
is
it
Leonard
Holt
?
"
<EOS>
exclaimed
the
piper
,
extending
his
hand
to
the
apprentice
.
<EOS>
"
You
are
heartily
welcome
,
"
he
added
;
"
and
I
am
glad
to
find
you
with
Nizza
.
<EOS>
It
is
no
secret
to
me
that
she
likes
you
.
<EOS>
She
has
been
an
excellent
daughter
,
and
will
make
an
excellent
wife
.
<EOS>
He
who
weds
her
will
obtain
a
greater
treasure
than
he
expects
.
<EOS>
"
 
"
Not
than
he
expects
,
"
said
Leonard
.
 
<EOS>
"
Ay
,
than
he
expects
,
"
reiterated
the
piper
.
<EOS>
"
You
will
one
day
find
out
that
I
speak
the
truth
.
"
 
<EOS>
Leonard
looked
at
Nizza
,
who
was
blushing
deeply
at
her
father
's
remark
.
<EOS>
She
understood
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
Father
,
"
she
said
,
"
I
understand
you
have
a
secret
of
importance
to
disclose
to
me
.
<EOS>
I
am
about
to
make
a
long
journey
to
-
morrow
,
and
may
not
return
for
some
time
.
<EOS>
At
this
uncertain
season
,
when
those
who
part
know
not
that
they
shall
meet
again
,
nothing
of
this
sort
ought
to
be
withheld
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
can
not
know
it
while
I
live
,
"
replied
the
piper
,
"
but
I
will
take
such
precautions
that
,
if
anything
happens
to
me
,
it
shall
be
certainly
revealed
to
you
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
satisfied
,
"
she
rejoined
,
"
and
will
only
ask
you
one
farther
question
,
and
I
beseech
you
to
answer
it
.
<EOS>
Does
this
amulet
refer
to
the
secret
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
does
,
"
replied
her
father
,
sullenly
;
"
and
now
let
the
subject
be
dropped
.
"
 
<EOS>
He
then
led
the
way
into
the
cottage
.
<EOS>
The
good
old
dame
who
kept
it
,
on
learning
who
they
were
,
and
that
they
were
sent
by
Doctor
Hodges
,
gave
them
a
hearty
welcome
,
and
placed
refreshments
before
them
.
<EOS>
Leonard
commented
upon
the
extreme
neatness
of
the
abode
and
its
healthful
situation
,
and
expressed
a
hope
that
it
might
not
be
visited
by
the
plague
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
trust
it
will
not
,
"
rejoined
the
old
woman
,
shaking
her
head
;
"
but
when
I
hear
the
doleful
bell
at
night
--
when
I
catch
a
glimpse
of
the
fatal
cart
--
or
look
towards
yon
dreadful
place
,
"
and
she
pointed
in
the
direction
of
the
plague
-
pit
,
which
lay
only
a
few
hundred
yards
to
the
west
of
her
habitation--"I
<EOS>
am
reminded
that
the
scourge
is
not
far
off
,
and
that
it
must
needs
reach
me
ere
long
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Have
no
fear
,
Dame
Lucas
,
"
said
the
piper
;
<EOS>
"
you
see
it
has
pleased
a
merciful
Providence
to
spare
the
lives
of
myself
,
my
child
,
and
this
young
man
,
and
if
you
should
be
attacked
,
the
same
benificent
Being
may
preserve
you
in
like
manner
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
The
Lord
's
will
be
done
!
"
<EOS>
rejoined
Dame
Lucas
.
<EOS>
"
I
know
I
shall
be
well
attended
to
by
Doctor
Hodges
.
<EOS>
I
nursed
him
when
he
was
an
infant
,
and
he
has
been
like
a
son
to
me
.
<EOS>
Bless
his
kind
heart
!
"
<EOS>
she
exclaimed
,
her
eyes
filling
with
tears
of
gratitude
,
"
there
is
not
his
like
in
London
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Always
excepting
my
master
,
"
observed
Leonard
,
with
a
smile
at
her
enthusiasm
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
except
no
one
,
"
rejoined
Dame
Lucas
.
<EOS>
"
A
worthier
man
never
lived
,
than
Doctor
Hodges
.
<EOS>
If
I
die
of
the
plague
,
"
she
continued
,
"
he
has
promised
not
to
let
me
be
thrown
into
that
horrible
pit
--
ough!--but
to
bury
me
in
my
garden
,
beneath
the
old
apple
-
tree
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
And
he
will
keep
his
word
,
dame
<EOS>
,
I
am
sure
,
"
replied
Leonard
.
<EOS>
"
I
would
recommend
you
,
however
,
as
the
best
antidote
against
the
plague
,
to
keep
yourself
constantly
employed
,
and
to
indulge
as
few
gloomy
notions
as
possible
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
seldom
melancholy
,
and
still
more
seldom
idle
,
"
replied
the
good
dame
.
"
<EOS>
But
despondency
will
steal
on
me
sometimes
,
especially
when
the
dead
-
cart
passes
and
I
think
what
it
contains
.
<EOS>
"
 
While
the
conversation
was
going
forward
,
Nizza
and
the
piper
withdrew
into
an
inner
room
,
where
they
remained
closeted
together
for
some
time
.
<EOS>
On
their
re
-
appearance
,
Nizza
said
she
was
ready
to
depart
,
and
taking
an
affectionate
farewell
of
her
father
,
and
committing
Bell
to
his
charge
,
she
quitted
the
cottage
with
the
apprentice
.
 
<EOS>
Evening
was
now
advancing
,
and
the
sun
was
setting
with
the
gorgeousness
already
described
as
peculiar
to
this
fatal
period
.
<EOS>
Filled
with
the
pleasing
melancholy
inspired
by
the
hour
,
they
walked
on
in
silence
.
<EOS>
They
had
not
proceeded
far
,
when
they
observed
a
man
crossing
the
field
with
a
bundle
in
his
arms
.
<EOS>
Suddenly
,
he
staggered
and
fell
.
<EOS>
Seeing
he
did
not
stir
,
and
guessing
what
was
the
matter
,
Leonard
ran
towards
him
to
offer
him
assistance
.
<EOS>
He
found
him
lying
in
the
grass
with
his
left
hand
fixed
against
his
heart
.
<EOS>
He
groaned
heavily
,
and
his
features
were
convulsed
with
pain
.
<EOS>
Near
him
lay
the
body
of
a
beautiful
little
girl
,
with
long
fair
hair
,
and
finely
-
formed
features
,
though
now
disfigured
by
purple
blotches
,
proclaiming
the
disorder
of
which
she
had
perished
.
<EOS>
She
was
apparently
about
ten
years
old
,
and
was
partially
covered
by
a
linen
cloth
.
<EOS>
The
man
,
whose
features
bore
a
marked
resemblance
to
those
of
the
child
,
was
evidently
from
his
attire
above
the
middle
rank
.
<EOS>
His
frame
was
athletic
,
and
as
he
was
scarcely
past
the
prime
of
life
,
the
irresistible
power
of
the
disease
,
which
could
in
one
instant
prostrate
strength
like
his
,
was
terribly
attested
.
 
<EOS>
"
Alas
!
<EOS>
"
he
cried
,
addressing
the
apprentice
,
"
I
was
about
to
convey
the
remains
of
my
poor
child
to
the
plague
-
pit
.
<EOS>
But
I
have
been
unable
to
accomplish
my
purpose
.
<EOS>
I
hoped
she
would
have
escaped
the
polluting
touch
of
those
loathly
attendants
on
the
dead
-
cart
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
She
_
shall
_
escape
it
,
"
replied
Leonard
;
"
if
you
wish
it
,
I
will
carry
her
to
the
pit
myself
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
The
blessing
of
a
dying
man
rest
on
your
head
,
"
cried
the
sufferer
;
"
your
charitable
action
will
not
pass
unrequited
.
"
 
<EOS>
With
this
,
despite
the
agony
he
endured
,
he
dragged
himself
to
his
child
,
kissed
her
cold
lips
,
smoothed
her
fair
tresses
,
and
covered
the
body
carefully
with
the
cloth
.
<EOS>
He
then
delivered
it
to
Leonard
,
who
received
it
tenderly
,
and
calling
to
Nizza
Macascree
,
who
had
witnessed
the
scene
at
a
little
distance
,
and
was
deeply
affected
by
it
,
to
await
his
return
,
ran
towards
the
plague
-
pit
.
<EOS>
Arrived
there
,
he
placed
his
little
burden
at
the
brink
of
the
excavation
,
and
,
kneeling
beside
it
,
uttered
a
short
prayer
inspired
by
the
occasion
.
<EOS>
He
then
tore
his
handkerchief
into
strips
,
and
tying
them
together
,
lowered
the
body
gently
down
.
<EOS>
Throwing
a
little
earth
over
it
,
he
hastened
to
the
sick
man
,
and
told
him
what
he
had
done
.
<EOS>
A
smile
of
satisfaction
illumined
the
sufferer
's
countenance
,
and
holding
out
his
hand
,
on
which
a
valuable
ring
glistened
,
he
said
,
"
Take
it
--
it
is
but
a
poor
reward
for
the
service
you
have
rendered
me;--nay
,
take
it
,
"
he
added
,
seeing
that
the
apprentice
hesitated
;
"
others
will
not
be
so
scrupulous
.
"
 
<EOS>
Unable
to
gainsay
the
remark
,
Leonard
took
the
ring
from
his
finger
and
placed
it
on
his
own
.
<EOS>
At
this
moment
,
the
sick
man
's
gaze
fell
upon
Nizza
,
who
stood
at
a
little
distance
from
him
.
<EOS>
He
started
,
and
made
an
effort
to
clear
his
vision
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
my
eyes
deceive
me
?
"
<EOS>
he
cried
,
"
or
is
a
female
standing
there
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
are
not
deceived
,
"
replied
Leonard
.
 
<EOS>
"
Let
her
come
near
me
,
in
Heaven
's
name
!
"
<EOS>
cried
the
sick
man
,
staring
at
her
as
if
his
eyes
would
start
from
their
sockets
.
<EOS>
"
Who
are
you
?
"
<EOS>
he
continued
,
as
Nizza
approached
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
called
Nizza
Macascree
,
and
am
the
daughter
of
a
poor
piper
,
"
she
replied
.
 
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
<EOS>
"
exclaimed
the
sick
man
,
with
a
look
of
deep
disappointment
.
<EOS>
"
The
resemblance
is
wonderful
!
<EOS>
And
yet
it
can
not
be
.
<EOS>
My
brain
is
bewildered
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Whom
does
she
resemble
?
"
<EOS>
asked
Leonard
,
eagerly
.
 
<EOS>
"
One
very
dear
to
me
,
"
replied
the
sick
man
,
with
an
expression
of
remorse
and
anguish
,
"
one
I
would
not
think
of
now
.
"
<EOS>
And
he
buried
his
face
in
the
grass
.
 
<EOS>
"
Is
there
aught
more
I
can
do
for
you
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Leonard
,
after
a
pause
.
 
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
replied
the
sick
man
;
"
I
have
done
with
the
world
.
<EOS>
With
that
child
,
the
last
tie
that
bound
me
to
it
was
snapped
.
<EOS>
I
now
only
wish
to
die
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Do
not
give
way
thus
,
"
replied
Leonard
;
"
a
short
time
ago
my
condition
was
as
apparently
hopeless
as
your
own
,
and
you
see
I
am
now
perfectly
recovered
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
had
something
to
live
for
--
something
to
love
,
"
groaned
the
sick
man
.
<EOS>
"
All
I
lived
for
,
all
I
loved
,
are
gone
.
<EOS>
"
 
"
Be
comforted
,
sir
,
"
said
Nizza
,
in
a
commiserating
tone
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Much
happiness
may
yet
be
in
store
for
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
That
voice
!
<EOS>
"
exclaimed
the
sick
man
,
with
a
look
denoting
the
approach
of
delirium
.
<EOS>
"
It
must
be
my
Isabella
.
<EOS>
Oh
!
forgive
me
!
<EOS>
sweet
injured
saint
;
forgive
me
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
Your
presence
evidently
distresses
him
,
"
said
Leonard
.
<EOS>
"
Let
us
hasten
for
assistance
.
<EOS>
Your
name
,
sir
?
"
<EOS>
he
added
,
to
the
sick
man
.
 
<EOS>
"
Why
should
you
seek
to
know
it
?
<EOS>
"
replied
the
other
.
"
<EOS>
No
tombstone
will
be
placed
over
the
plague
-
pit
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Not
a
moment
must
be
lost
if
you
would
save
him
,
"
cried
Nizza
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
are
right
,
"
replied
Leonard
.
<EOS>
"
Let
us
fly
to
the
nearest
apothecary
's
.
"
 
<EOS>
Accordingly
,
they
set
off
at
a
quick
pace
towards
Moorgate
.
<EOS>
Just
as
they
reached
it
,
they
heard
the
bell
ring
,
and
saw
the
dead
-
cart
approaching
.
<EOS>
Shrinking
back
while
it
passed
,
they
ran
on
till
they
came
to
an
apothecary
's
shop
,
where
Leonard
,
describing
the
state
of
the
sick
man
,
by
his
entreaties
induced
the
master
of
the
establishment
and
one
of
his
assistants
to
accompany
him
.
<EOS>
Leaving
Nizza
in
the
shop
,
he
then
retraced
his
steps
with
his
companions
.
<EOS>
The
sick
man
was
lying
where
he
had
left
him
,
but
perfectly
insensible
.
<EOS>
On
searching
his
pockets
,
a
purse
of
money
was
found
,
but
neither
letter
nor
tablet
to
tell
who
he
was
.
<EOS>
Leonard
offered
the
purse
to
the
apothecary
,
but
the
latter
declined
it
,
and
desired
his
assistant
,
who
had
brought
a
barrow
with
him
,
to
place
the
sick
man
within
it
,
and
convey
him
to
the
pest
-
house
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
will
be
better
cared
for
there
than
if
I
were
to
take
charge
of
him
,
"
he
observed
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
As
to
the
money
,
you
can
return
it
if
he
recovers
.
<EOS>
If
not
,
it
of
right
belongs
to
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
Seeing
that
remonstrance
would
be
useless
,
Leonard
did
not
attempt
it
,
and
while
the
assistant
wheeled
away
the
sick
man
,
he
returned
with
the
apothecary
to
his
dwelling
.
<EOS>
Thanking
him
for
his
kindness
,
he
then
hastened
with
Nizza
Macascree
to
Great
Knightrider
-
street
.
<EOS>
He
related
to
the
doctor
all
that
had
occurred
,
and
showed
him
the
ring
.
<EOS>
Hodges
listened
to
the
recital
with
great
attention
,
and
at
its
close
said
,
"
This
is
a
very
singular
affair
,
and
excites
my
curiosity
greatly
.
<EOS>
I
will
go
to
the
pest
-
house
and
see
the
sick
man
to
-
morrow
.
<EOS>
And
now
we
will
proceed
to
supper
;
and
then
you
had
better
retire
to
rest
,
for
you
will
have
to
be
astir
before
daybreak
.
<EOS>
All
is
in
readiness
for
the
journey
.
"
 
<EOS>
The
last
night
(
for
such
she
considered
it
)
spent
by
Amabel
in
her
father
's
dwelling
,
was
passed
in
the
kindliest
interchanges
of
affection
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Bloundel
had
much
ado
to
maintain
his
firmness
,
and
ever
and
anon
,
in
spite
of
his
efforts
,
his
labouring
bosom
and
faltering
tones
proclaimed
the
struggle
within
.
<EOS>
He
sat
beside
his
daughter
,
with
her
thin
fingers
clasped
in
his
,
and
spoke
to
her
on
every
consolatory
topic
that
suggested
itself
.
<EOS>
This
discourse
,
however
,
insensibly
took
a
serious
turn
,
and
the
grocer
became
fully
convinced
that
his
daughter
was
not
merely
reconciled
to
the
early
death
that
to
all
appearance
awaited
her
,
but
wishful
for
it
.
<EOS>
He
found
,
too
,
to
his
inexpressible
grief
,
that
the
sense
of
the
Earl
of
Rochester
's
treachery
,
combined
with
her
own
indiscretion
,
and
the
consequences
that
might
have
attended
it
,
had
sunk
deep
in
her
heart
,
and
produced
the
present
sad
result
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs.
Bloundel
,
it
will
scarcely
be
supposed
,
could
support
herself
so
well
as
her
husband
,
but
when
any
paroxysm
of
grief
approached
she
rushed
out
of
the
room
,
and
gave
vent
to
her
affliction
alone
.
<EOS>
All
the
rest
of
the
family
were
present
,
and
were
equally
distressed
.
<EOS>
But
what
most
strongly
affected
Amabel
was
a
simple
,
natural
remark
of
little
Christiana
,
who
,
fixing
her
tearful
gaze
on
her
,
entreated
her
"
to
come
back
soon
.
"
 
<EOS>
Weak
as
she
was
,
Amabel
took
the
child
upon
her
knee
,
and
said
to
her
,
"
I
am
going
a
long
journey
,
Christiana
,
and
,
perhaps
may
never
come
back
.
<EOS>
But
if
you
attend
to
what
your
father
says
to
you
,
if
you
never
omit
,
morning
and
evening
,
to
implore
the
blessing
of
Heaven
,
we
shall
meet
again
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
understand
what
you
mean
,
sister
,
"
said
Christiana
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
place
you
are
going
to
is
the
grave
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
have
guessed
rightly
,
Christiana
,
"
rejoined
Amabel
,
solemnly
.
<EOS>
"
Do
not
forget
my
last
words
to
you
,
and
when
you
are
grown
into
a
woman
,
think
upon
the
poor
sister
who
loved
you
tenderly
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
shall
always
think
of
you
,
"
said
Christiana
,
clasping
her
arms
round
her
sister
's
neck
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
I
wish
I
could
go
to
the
grave
instead
of
you
!
"
 
<EOS>
Amabel
pressed
her
to
her
bosom
,
and
in
a
broken
voice
murmured
a
blessing
over
her
.
 
<EOS>
Mr.
Bloundel
here
thought
it
necessary
to
interfere
,
and
,
taking
the
weeping
child
in
his
arms
,
carried
her
into
the
adjoining
apartment
.
 
<EOS>
Soon
after
this
,
the
household
were
summoned
to
prayers
,
and
as
the
grocer
poured
forth
an
address
to
Heaven
for
the
preservation
of
his
daughter
,
all
earnestly
joined
in
the
supplication
.
<EOS>
Their
devotions
ended
,
Amabel
took
leave
of
her
brothers
,
and
the
parting
might
have
been
painfully
prolonged
but
for
the
interposition
of
her
father
.
<EOS>
The
last
and
severest
trial
was
at
hand
.
<EOS>
She
had
now
to
part
from
her
mother
,
from
whom
,
except
on
the
occasion
of
her
flight
with
the
Earl
of
Rochester
,
she
had
never
yet
been
separated
.
<EOS>
She
had
now
to
part
with
her
,
in
all
probability
,
for
ever
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
heart
-
breaking
reflection
to
both
.
<EOS>
Knowing
it
would
only
renew
their
affliction
,
and
perhaps
unfit
Amabel
for
the
journey
,
Mr.
Bloundel
had
prevailed
upon
his
wife
not
to
see
her
in
the
morning
.
<EOS>
The
moment
had
,
therefore
,
arrived
when
they
were
to
bid
each
other
farewell
.
<EOS>
The
anguish
displayed
in
his
wife
's
countenance
was
too
much
for
the
grocer
,
and
he
covered
his
face
with
his
hands
.
<EOS>
He
heard
her
approach
Amabel
--
he
listened
to
their
mutual
sobs
--
to
their
last
embrace
.
<EOS>
It
was
succeeded
by
a
stifled
cry
,
and
uncovering
his
face
at
the
sound
,
he
sprang
to
his
feet
just
in
time
to
receive
his
swooning
wife
in
his
arms
.
  
<EOS>
VI
.
 
<EOS>
THE
DEPARTURE
.
 
<EOS>
It
struck
four
by
Saint
Paul
's
as
Doctor
Hodges
,
accompanied
by
Leonard
and
Nizza
Macascree
,
issued
from
his
dwelling
,
and
proceeded
towards
Wood
-
street
.
<EOS>
The
party
was
followed
by
a
man
leading
a
couple
of
horses
,
equipped
with
pillions
,
and
furnished
with
saddle
-
bags
,
partly
filled
with
the
scanty
luggage
which
the
apprentice
and
the
piper
's
daughter
took
with
them
.
<EOS>
A
slight
haze
,
indicative
of
the
intense
heat
about
to
follow
,
hung
round
the
lower
part
of
the
cathedral
,
but
its
topmost
pinnacles
glittered
in
the
beams
of
the
newly
-
risen
sun
.
<EOS>
As
Leonard
gazed
at
the
central
tower
,
he
descried
Solomon
Eagle
on
its
summit
,
and
pointed
him
out
to
Hodges
.
<EOS>
Motioning
the
apprentice
,
in
a
manner
that
could
not
be
misunderstood
,
to
halt
,
the
enthusiast
vanished
,
and
in
another
moment
appeared
upon
the
roof
,
and
descended
to
the
battlements
,
overlooking
the
spot
where
the
little
party
stood
.
<EOS>
This
was
at
the
northwest
corner
of
the
cathedral
,
at
a
short
distance
from
the
portico
.
<EOS>
The
enthusiast
had
a
small
sack
in
his
hand
,
and
calling
to
Nizza
Macascree
to
take
it
,
flung
it
to
the
ground
.
<EOS>
The
ringing
sound
which
it
made
on
its
fall
proved
that
it
contained
gold
or
silver
,
while
its
size
showed
that
the
amount
must
be
considerable
.
<EOS>
Nizza
looked
at
it
in
astonishment
,
but
did
not
offer
to
touch
it
.
 
<EOS>
"
Take
it
!
<EOS>
"
thundered
Solomon
Eagle
;
"
it
is
your
dowry
.
"
<EOS>
And
perceiving
she
hesitated
to
comply
with
the
injunction
,
he
shouted
to
Leonard
.
"
<EOS>
Give
it
her
.
<EOS>
I
have
no
use
for
gold
.
<EOS>
May
it
make
you
and
her
happy
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
know
not
where
he
can
have
obtained
this
money
,
"
observed
Hodges
;
"
but
I
am
sure
in
no
unlawful
manner
,
and
I
therefore
counsel
Nizza
to
accept
the
boon
.
<EOS>
It
may
be
of
the
greatest
use
to
her
at
some
future
time
.
"
 
<EOS>
His
scruples
being
thus
overcome
,
Leonard
took
the
sack
,
and
placed
it
in
one
of
the
saddle
-
bags
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
can
examine
it
at
your
leisure
,
"
remarked
Hodges
to
Nizza
.
<EOS>
"
We
have
no
more
time
to
lose
.
"
 
<EOS>
Solomon
Eagle
,
meanwhile
,
expressed
his
satisfaction
at
the
apprentice
's
compliance
by
his
gestures
,
and
,
waving
his
staff
round
his
head
,
pointed
towards
the
west
of
the
city
,
as
if
inquiring
whether
that
was
the
route
they
meant
to
take
.
<EOS>
Leonard
nodded
an
affirmative
;
and
,
the
enthusiast
spreading
out
his
arms
and
pronouncing
an
audible
benediction
over
them
,
they
resumed
their
course
.
<EOS>
The
streets
were
silent
and
deserted
,
except
by
the
watchmen
stationed
at
the
infected
dwellings
,
and
a
few
sick
persons
stretched
on
the
steps
of
some
of
the
better
habitations
.
<EOS>
In
order
to
avoid
coming
in
contact
with
these
miserable
creatures
,
the
party
,
with
the
exception
of
Doctor
Hodges
,
kept
in
the
middle
of
the
road
.
<EOS>
Attracted
by
the
piteous
exclamations
of
the
sufferers
,
Doctor
Hodges
,
ever
and
anon
,
humanely
paused
to
speak
to
them
;
and
he
promised
one
poor
woman
,
who
was
suckling
an
infant
,
to
visit
her
on
his
return
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
no
hopes
of
saving
her
,
"
he
observed
to
Leonard
,
"
but
I
may
preserve
her
child
.
<EOS>
There
is
an
establishment
in
Aldgate
for
infants
whose
mothers
have
died
of
the
plague
,
where
more
than
a
hundred
little
creatures
are
suckled
by
she
-
goats
,
and
it
is
wonderful
how
well
they
thrive
under
their
nurses
.
<EOS>
If
I
can
induce
this
poor
woman
to
part
with
her
child
,
I
will
send
it
thither
.
"
 
<EOS>
Just
then
,
their
attention
was
arrested
by
the
sudden
opening
of
a
casement
,
and
a
middle
-
aged
woman
,
wringing
her
hands
,
cried
,
with
a
look
of
unutterable
anguish
and
despair--"Pray
<EOS>
for
us
,
good
people
!
<EOS>
pray
for
us
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
We
_
do
_
pray
for
you
,
my
poor
soul
!
"
<EOS>
rejoined
Hodges
,
"
as
well
as
for
all
who
are
similarly
afflicted
.
<EOS>
What
sick
have
you
within
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
There
were
ten
yesterday
,
"
replied
the
woman
.
<EOS>
"
Two
have
died
in
the
night
--
my
husband
and
my
eldest
son
--
and
there
are
eight
others
whose
recovery
is
hopeless
.
<EOS>
Pray
for
us
!
<EOS>
As
you
hope
to
be
spared
yourselves
,
pray
for
us
!
"
<EOS>
And
,
with
a
lamentable
cry
,
she
closed
the
casement
.
 
<EOS>
Familiarized
as
all
who
heard
her
were
with
spectacles
of
horror
and
tales
of
woe
,
they
could
not
listen
to
this
sad
recital
,
nor
look
upon
her
distracted
countenance
,
without
the
deepest
commiseration
.
<EOS>
Other
sights
had
previously
affected
them
,
but
not
in
the
same
degree
.
<EOS>
Around
the
little
conduit
standing
in
front
of
the
Old
Change
,
at
the
western
extremity
of
Cheapside
,
were
three
lazars
laving
their
sores
in
the
water
;
while
,
in
the
short
space
between
this
spot
and
Wood
-
street
,
Leonard
counted
upwards
of
twenty
doors
marked
with
the
fatal
red
cross
,
and
bearing
upon
them
the
sad
inscription
,
"
Lord
have
mercy
upon
us
!
"
 
<EOS>
A
few
minutes
'
walking
brought
them
to
the
grocer
's
habitation
,
and
on
reaching
it
,
they
found
that
Blaize
had
already
descended
.
<EOS>
He
was
capering
about
the
street
with
joy
at
his
restoration
to
freedom
.
 
<EOS>
"
Mistress
Amabel
will
make
her
appearance
in
a
few
minutes
,
"
he
said
to
Leonard
.
<EOS>
"
Our
master
is
with
her
,
and
is
getting
all
ready
for
her
departure
.
<EOS>
I
have
not
come
unprovided
with
medicine
,
"
he
added
to
Doctor
Hodges
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
got
a
bottle
of
plague
-
water
in
one
pocket
,
and
a
phial
of
vinegar
in
the
other
.
<EOS>
Besides
these
,
I
have
a
small
pot
of
Mayerne
's
electuary
in
my
bag
,
another
of
the
grand
antipestilential
confection
,
and
a
fourth
of
the
infallible
antidote
which
I
bought
of
the
celebrated
Greek
physician
,
Doctor
Constantine
Rhodocanaceis
,
at
his
shop
near
the
Three
-
Kings
Inn
,
in
Southampton
-
buildings
.
<EOS>
I
dare
say
you
have
heard
of
him
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
_
have
_
heard
of
the
quack
,
"
replied
Hodges
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
His
end
was
a
just
retribution
for
the
tricks
he
practised
on
his
dupes
.
<EOS>
In
spite
of
his
infallible
antidote
,
he
was
carried
off
by
the
scourge
.
<EOS>
But
what
else
have
you
got
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
Only
a
few
trifles
,
"
replied
Blaize
,
with
a
chap
-
fallen
look
.
<EOS>
"
Patience
has
made
me
a
pomander
-
ball
composed
of
angelica
,
rue
,
zedoary
,
camphor
,
wax
,
and
laudanum
,
which
I
have
hung
round
my
neck
with
a
string
.
<EOS>
Then
I
have
got
a
good
-
sized
box
of
rufuses
,
and
have
swallowed
three
of
them
preparatory
to
the
journey
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
A
proper
precaution
,
"
observed
Hodges
,
with
a
smile
.
 
<EOS>
"
This
is
not
all
,
"
replied
Blaize
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
By
my
mother
's
advice
,
I
have
eaten
twenty
leaves
of
rue
,
two
roasted
figs
,
and
two
pickled
walnuts
for
breakfast
,
washing
them
down
with
an
ale
posset
,
with
pimpernel
seethed
in
it
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Indeed
!
"
exclaimed
Hodges
.
<EOS>
"
You
must
be
in
a
pretty
condition
for
a
journey
.
<EOS>
But
how
could
you
bear
to
part
with
your
mother
and
Patience
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
The
parting
from
Patience
<EOS>
_
was
_
heart
-
breaking
,
"
replied
Blaize
,
taking
out
his
handkerchief
,
and
applying
it
to
his
eyes
.
<EOS>
"
We
sat
up
half
the
night
together
,
and
I
felt
so
much
overcome
that
I
began
to
waver
in
my
resolution
of
departing
.
<EOS>
I
am
glad
I
did
not
give
way
now
,
"
he
added
,
in
a
more
sprightly
tone
.
"
<EOS>
Fresh
air
and
bright
sunshine
are
very
different
things
from
the
close
rooms
in
that
dark
house
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
must
not
forget
that
you
were
there
free
from
the
contagion
,
"
rejoined
Hodges
;
"
while
you
are
here
exposed
to
its
assaults
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
True
,
"
replied
Blaize
;
"
that
makes
a
vast
difference
.
<EOS>
I
almost
wish
I
was
back
again
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
too
late
to
think
of
returning
,
"
said
Hodges
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Mount
your
horse
,
and
I
will
assist
Nizza
into
the
pillion
.
"
 
<EOS>
By
the
time
that
Blaize
,
who
was
but
an
indifferent
horseman
,
had
got
into
the
saddle
,
and
Nizza
had
taken
her
place
behind
him
,
the
window
opened
,
and
Mr.
Bloundel
appeared
at
it
.
 
<EOS>
Amabel
had
only
retired
to
rest
for
a
few
hours
during
the
night
.
<EOS>
When
left
to
herself
in
her
chamber
,
she
continued
to
pray
till
exhaustion
compelled
her
to
seek
some
repose
.
<EOS>
Arising
about
two
o'clock
,
she
employed
herself
for
more
than
an
hour
in
further
devotion
,
and
then
took
a
last
survey
of
every
object
in
the
room
.
<EOS>
She
had
occupied
it
from
her
childhood
;
and
as
she
opened
drawer
after
drawer
,
and
cupboard
after
cupboard
,
and
examined
their
contents
,
each
article
recalled
some
circumstance
connected
with
the
past
,
and
brought
back
a
train
of
long
-
forgotten
emotions
.
<EOS>
While
she
was
thus
engaged
,
Patience
tapped
at
the
door
,
and
was
instantly
admitted
.
<EOS>
The
tenderhearted
kitchenmaid
assisted
her
to
dress
,
and
to
put
together
some
few
articles
omitted
to
be
packed
by
her
mother
.
<EOS>
During
this
employment
she
shed
abundance
of
tears
,
and
Amabel
's
efforts
to
console
her
only
made
matters
worse
.
<EOS>
Poor
Patience
was
forced
at
last
to
sit
down
,
and
indulge
a
hearty
fit
of
crying
,
after
which
she
felt
considerably
relieved
.
<EOS>
As
soon
as
she
was
sufficiently
recovered
to
be
able
to
speak
,
she
observed
to
Amabel
,
"
Pardon
what
I
am
about
to
say
to
you
,
my
dear
young
mistress
,
but
I
can
not
help
thinking
that
the
real
seat
of
your
disease
is
in
the
heart
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
A
slight
blush
overspread
Amabel
's
pale
features
,
but
she
made
no
answer
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
see
I
am
right
,
"
continued
Patience
,
"
and
<EOS>
indeed
I
have
long
suspected
it
.
<EOS>
Let
me
entreat
you
,
therefore
,
dear
young
lady
,
not
to
sacrifice
yourself
.
<EOS>
Only
say
the
word
,
and
I
will
find
means
of
making
your
retreat
known
to
the
Earl
of
Rochester
.
<EOS>
Blaize
is
devoted
to
you
,
and
will
do
anything
you
bid
him
.
<EOS>
I
can
not
wonder
you
fret
after
so
handsome
,
so
captivating
a
man
as
the
earl
,
especially
when
you
are
worried
to
death
to
marry
a
common
apprentice
like
Leonard
Holt
,
who
is
not
fit
to
hold
a
candle
to
your
noble
admirer
.
<EOS>
Ah
!
<EOS>
we
women
can
never
blind
ourselves
to
the
advantages
of
rank
and
appearance
.
<EOS>
We
are
too
good
judges
for
that
.
<EOS>
I
hope
you
will
soon
be
restored
to
your
lover
,
and
that
the
happiness
you
will
enjoy
will
make
amends
for
all
the
misery
you
have
endured
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Patience
,
"
said
Amabel
,
whose
cheek
,
as
the
other
spoke
,
had
returned
to
its
original
paleness--"Patience
,
"
she
said
,
gravely
,
but
kindly
,
"
I
have
suffered
you
to
proceed
too
far
without
interruption
,
and
must
correct
the
very
serious
error
into
which
you
have
fallen
.
<EOS>
I
am
so
far
from
pining
for
an
interview
with
the
Earl
of
Rochester
,
that
nothing
in
the
world
should
induce
me
to
see
him
again
.
<EOS>
I
have
loved
him
deeply
,
"
she
continued
in
a
tremulous
tone
;
"
nay
,
I
will
not
attempt
to
disguise
that
I
feel
strongly
towards
him
still
,
while
I
will
also
freely
confess
that
his
conduct
towards
me
has
so
preyed
upon
my
spirits
,
that
it
has
impaired
,
perhaps
destroyed
,
my
health
.
<EOS>
In
spite
of
this
,
I
can
not
sufficiently
rejoice
that
I
have
escaped
the
earl
's
snares
--
I
can
not
be
sufficiently
thankful
to
the
merciful
Being
who
,
while
he
has
thought
fit
to
chastise
me
,
has
preserved
me
from
utter
ruin
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Since
you
are
of
this
mind
,
"
returned
Patience
,
in
a
tone
of
incredulity
,
"
you
are
more
to
be
rejoiced
with
than
pitied
.
<EOS>
But
we
are
not
overheard
,
"
she
added
,
almost
in
a
whisper
,
and
glancing
towards
the
door
.
<EOS>
"
You
may
entirely
confide
in
me
.
<EOS>
The
time
is
arrived
when
you
can
escape
to
your
lover
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
No
more
of
this
,
"
rejoined
Amabel
,
severely
,
"
or
<EOS>
I
shall
command
you
to
leave
the
room
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
This
is
nothing
more
than
pique
,
"
thought
Patience
.
<EOS>
"
We
women
are
all
hypocrites
,
even
to
ourselves
.
<EOS>
I
will
serve
her
whether
she
will
or
not
.
<EOS>
She
_
shall
_
see
the
earl
.
<EOS>
I
hope
there
is
no
harm
in
wishing
you
may
be
happy
with
Leonard
Holt
,
"
she
added
aloud
.
"
<EOS>
_
He
_
will
make
you
a
capital
husband
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
That
subject
is
equally
disagreeable
--
equally
painful
to
me
,
"
said
Amabel
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
had
better
hold
my
tongue
altogether
,
"
rejoined
Patience
,
somewhat
pertly
.
<EOS>
"
Whatever
I
say
seems
to
be
wrong
.
<EOS>
It
wo
n't
prevent
me
from
doing
as
I
would
be
done
by
,
"
she
added
to
herself
.
 
<EOS>
Amabel
's
preparations
finished
,
she
dismissed
Patience
,
to
whom
she
gave
some
few
slight
remembrances
,
and
was
soon
afterwards
joined
by
her
father
.
<EOS>
They
passed
half
an
hour
together
,
as
on
the
former
night
,
in
serious
and
devout
conversation
,
after
which
Mr.
Bloundel
left
her
for
a
few
minutes
to
let
down
Blaize
.
<EOS>
On
his
return
he
tenderly
embraced
her
,
and
led
her
into
the
passage
.
<EOS>
They
had
not
advanced
many
steps
when
Mrs.
Bloundel
rushed
forth
to
meet
them
.
<EOS>
She
was
in
her
night
-
dress
,
and
seemed
overwhelmed
with
affliction
.
 
<EOS>
"
How
is
this
,
Honora
?
<EOS>
"
cried
her
husband
,
in
a
severe
tone
.
<EOS>
"
You
promised
me
you
would
see
Amabel
no
more
.
<EOS>
You
will
only
distress
her
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
could
not
let
her
go
thus
,
"
cried
Mrs.
Bloundel
.
<EOS>
"
I
was
listening
at
my
chamber
door
to
hear
her
depart
,
and
when
I
caught
the
sound
of
her
footsteps
,
I
could
no
longer
control
myself
.
"
<EOS>
So
saying
,
she
rushed
to
her
daughter
,
and
clasped
her
in
her
arms
.
 
<EOS>
Affectionately
returning
her
mother
's
embrace
,
Amabel
gave
her
hand
to
her
father
,
who
conducted
her
to
the
little
room
overlooking
the
street
.
<EOS>
Nothing
more
,
except
a
deep
and
passionate
look
,
was
exchanged
between
them
.
<EOS>
Both
repressed
their
emotion
,
and
though
the
heart
of
each
was
bursting
,
neither
shed
a
tear
.
<EOS>
At
that
moment
,
and
for
the
first
time
,
they
greatly
resembled
each
other
;
and
this
was
not
surprising
,
for
intense
emotion
,
whether
of
grief
or
joy
,
will
bring
out
lines
in
the
features
that
lie
hidden
at
other
times
.
<EOS>
Without
a
word
,
Mr.
Bloundel
busied
himself
in
arranging
the
pulley
;
and
calling
to
those
below
to
prepare
for
Amabel
's
descent
,
again
embraced
her
,
kissed
her
pale
brow
,
and
,
placing
her
carefully
in
the
basket
,
lowered
her
slowly
to
the
ground
.
<EOS>
She
was
received
in
safety
by
Leonard
,
who
carried
her
in
his
arms
,
and
placed
her
on
the
pillion
.
<EOS>
The
pulley
was
then
drawn
up
,
and
her
luggage
lowered
by
Mr.
Bloundel
,
and
placed
in
the
saddle
-
bags
by
the
apprentice
.
<EOS>
Every
one
saw
the
necessity
of
terminating
this
painful
scene
.
<EOS>
A
kindly
farewell
was
taken
of
Hodges
.
<EOS>
Amabel
waved
her
hand
to
her
father
,
when
at
this
moment
Patience
appeared
at
the
window
,
and
,
calling
to
Blaize
,
threw
a
little
package
tied
in
a
handkerchief
to
him
.
<EOS>
Doctor
Hodges
took
up
the
parcel
,
and
gave
it
to
the
porter
,
who
,
untying
the
handkerchief
,
glanced
at
a
note
it
enclosed
,
and
,
striking
his
horse
with
his
stick
,
dashed
off
towards
Cheapside
.
 
<EOS>
"
Pursue
him
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Amabel
to
Leonard
;
"
he
is
flying
to
the
Earl
of
Rochester
.
"
 
<EOS>
The
intimation
was
sufficient
for
the
apprentice
.
<EOS>
Urging
his
horse
into
a
quick
pace
,
he
came
up
with
the
fugitive
,
just
as
he
had
reached
Cheapside
.
<EOS>
Blaize
's
mad
career
had
been
checked
by
Nizza
Macascree
,
who
,
seizing
the
bridle
,
stopped
the
steed
.
<EOS>
Leonard
,
who
was
armed
with
a
heavy
riding
-
whip
,
applied
it
unsparingly
to
Blaize
's
shoulders
.
 
<EOS>
"
Entreat
him
to
hold
his
hand
,
dear
,
good
Mistress
Amabel
,
"
cried
the
porter
;
"
it
was
for
your
sake
alone
<EOS>
I
made
this
rash
attempt
.
<EOS>
Patience
told
me
you
were
dying
to
see
the
Earl
of
Rochester
,
and
made
me
promise
I
would
ride
to
Whitehall
to
acquaint
his
lordship
whither
you
were
going
.
<EOS>
Here
is
her
letter
which
I
was
about
to
deliver
.
"
<EOS>
And
as
he
spoke
,
he
handed
her
the
note
,
which
was
tied
with
a
piece
of
packthread
,
and
directed
in
strange
and
almost
illegible
characters
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
not
hurt
him
more
,
"
said
Amabel
;
"
he
was
not
aware
of
the
mischief
he
was
about
to
commit
.
<EOS>
And
learn
from
me
,
Blaize
,
that
,
so
far
from
desiring
to
see
the
Earl
of
Rochester
,
all
my
anxiety
is
to
avoid
him
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
If
I
had
known
that
,
"
returned
the
porter
,
"
I
would
not
have
stirred
a
step
.
<EOS>
But
Patience
assured
me
the
contrary
.
"
 
<EOS>
By
this
time
,
Doctor
Hodges
had
come
up
,
and
an
explanation
ensued
.
<EOS>
It
was
agreed
,
however
,
that
it
would
be
better
not
to
alarm
Mr.
Bloundel
,
but
to
attribute
the
porter
's
sudden
flight
to
mismanagement
of
his
steed
.
<EOS>
Accordingly
,
they
returned
to
the
residence
of
the
grocer
,
who
was
anxiously
looking
out
for
them
;
and
after
a
brief
delay
,
during
which
the
saddlebags
were
again
examined
and
secured
,
they
departed
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Bloundel
looked
wistfully
after
his
daughter
,
and
she
returned
his
gaze
as
long
as
her
blinding
eyes
would
permit
her
.
<EOS>
So
unwonted
was
the
sound
of
horses
'
feet
at
this
period
,
that
many
a
melancholy
face
appeared
at
the
window
to
gaze
at
them
as
they
rode
by
,
and
Nizza
Macascree
shuddered
as
she
witnessed
the
envious
glances
cast
after
them
by
these
poor
captives
.
<EOS>
As
to
Blaize
,
when
they
got
into
Cheapside
,
he
was
so
terrified
by
the
dismal
evidences
of
the
pestilence
that
met
him
at
every
turn
,
that
he
could
scarcely
keep
his
seat
,
and
it
was
not
until
he
had
drenched
himself
and
his
companion
with
vinegar
,
and
stuffed
his
mouth
with
myrrh
and
zedoary
,
that
he
felt
anything
like
composure
.
 
<EOS>
On
approaching
Newgate
Market
,
they
found
it
entirely
deserted
.
<EOS>
Most
of
the
stalls
were
removed
,
the
shops
closed
,
and
the
window
-
shutters
nailed
up
.
<EOS>
It
was
never
,
in
fact
,
used
at
all
,
except
by
a
few
countrymen
and
higglers
,
who
ventured
thither
on
certain
days
of
the
week
to
sell
fresh
eggs
,
butter
,
poultry
,
and
such
commodities
.
<EOS>
The
manner
of
sale
was
this
.
<EOS>
The
article
disposed
of
was
placed
on
a
flag
on
one
side
of
the
market
,
near
which
stood
a
pump
and
a
trough
of
water
.
<EOS>
The
vendor
then
retired
,
while
the
purchaser
approached
,
took
the
article
,
and
put
its
price
into
the
water
,
whence
it
was
removed
when
supposed
to
be
sufficiently
purified
.
 
<EOS>
As
the
party
passed
Grey
Friars
,
the
tramp
of
their
horses
was
mistaken
for
the
dead
-
cart
,
and
a
door
was
suddenly
opened
and
a
corpse
brought
forth
.
<EOS>
Leonard
would
have
avoided
the
spectacle
had
it
been
possible
,
but
they
were
now
too
close
to
Newgate
,
where
they
were
detained
for
a
few
minutes
at
the
gate
,
while
their
bills
of
health
were
examined
and
countersigned
by
the
officer
stationed
there
.
<EOS>
During
this
pause
Leonard
glanced
at
the
grated
windows
of
the
prison
,
the
debtors
'
side
of
which
fronted
the
street
.
<EOS>
But
not
a
single
face
was
to
be
seen
.
<EOS>
In
fact
,
as
has
already
been
stated
,
the
prison
was
shut
up
.
 
<EOS>
The
gate
was
now
opened
to
them
,
and
descending
Snow
Hill
<EOS>
they
entered
a
region
completely
devastated
by
the
pestilence
.
<EOS>
So
saddening
was
the
sight
,
that
Leonard
involuntarily
quickened
his
horse
's
pace
,
resolved
to
get
out
of
this
forlorn
district
as
speedily
as
possible
.
<EOS>
He
was
,
however
,
stopped
by
an
unexpected
and
fearful
impediment
.
<EOS>
When
within
a
short
distance
of
Holborn
Bridge
,
he
observed
on
the
further
side
of
it
a
large
black
vehicle
,
and
,
unable
to
make
out
what
it
was
,
though
a
fearful
suspicion
crossed
him
,
slackened
his
pace
.
<EOS>
A
nearer
approach
showed
him
that
it
was
the
pest
-
cart
,
filled
with
its
charnel
load
.
<EOS>
The
horse
was
in
the
shafts
,
and
was
standing
quite
still
.
<EOS>
Rising
in
his
stirrups
to
obtain
a
better
view
,
Leonard
perceived
that
the
driver
was
lying
on
the
ground
at
a
little
distance
from
the
cart
,
in
an
attitude
that
proclaimed
he
had
been
suddenly
seized
by
the
pestilence
,
and
had
probably
just
expired
.
 
<EOS>
Not
choosing
to
incur
the
risk
of
passing
this
contagious
load
,
Leonard
retraced
his
course
as
far
as
Holborn
Conduit
,
then
turning
into
Seacole
-
lane
,
and
making
the
best
of
his
way
to
Fleet
Bridge
,
crossed
it
,
and
entered
the
great
thoroughfare
with
which
it
communicated
.
<EOS>
He
had
not
proceeded
far
when
he
encountered
a
small
party
of
the
watch
,
to
whom
he
showed
his
certificate
,
and
recounted
the
fate
of
the
driver
of
the
dead
-
cart
.
<EOS>
At
Temple
Bar
he
was
again
obliged
to
exhibit
his
passports
;
and
while
there
detained
,
he
observed
three
other
horsemen
riding
towards
them
from
the
further
end
of
Fleet
-
street
.
 
<EOS>
Though
much
alarmed
by
the
sight
,
Leonard
did
not
communicate
his
apprehensions
to
his
companions
,
but
as
soon
as
the
guard
allowed
him
to
pass
,
called
out
to
Blaize
to
follow
him
,
and
urging
his
horse
to
a
quick
pace
,
dashed
up
Drury
-
lane
.
<EOS>
A
few
minutes
'
hard
riding
,
during
which
nothing
occurred
to
give
the
apprentice
further
uneasiness
,
brought
them
to
a
road
skirting
the
open
fields
,
in
which
a
pest
-
house
had
just
been
built
by
the
chivalrous
nobleman
whose
habitation
in
Berkshire
they
were
about
to
visit
.
<EOS>
With
a
courage
and
devotion
that
redound
more
to
his
honour
than
the
brilliant
qualities
that
won
him
so
high
<EOS>
a
reputation
in
the
court
and
in
the
field
<EOS>
,
Lord
Craven
not
merely
provided
the
present
receptacle
for
the
sick
,
but
remained
in
London
during
the
whole
continuance
of
the
dreadful
visitation
;
"
braving
,
"
says
Pennant
,
"
the
fury
of
the
pestilence
with
the
same
coolness
that
he
fought
the
battles
of
his
beloved
mistress
,
Elizabeth
,
titular
Queen
of
Bohemia
,
or
mounted
the
tremendous
breach
of
Creutznach
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
spot
where
this
asylum
was
built
,
and
which
is
the
present
site
of
Golden
-
square
,
retained
nearly
half
a
century
afterwards
,
the
name
of
the
Pest
-
house
Fields
.
<EOS>
Leonard
had
already
been
made
acquainted
by
Doctor
Hodges
with
the
earl
's
generous
devotion
to
the
public
welfare
,
and
warmly
commenting
upon
it
,
he
pointed
out
the
structure
to
Amabel
.
<EOS>
But
the
speed
at
which
she
was
borne
along
did
not
allow
her
time
to
bestow
more
than
a
hasty
glance
at
it
.
<EOS>
On
gaining
Hyde
-
park
Corner
,
the
apprentice
cast
a
look
backwards
,
and
his
apprehensions
were
revived
by
perceiving
the
three
horsemen
again
in
view
,
and
evidently
using
their
utmost
exertions
to
come
up
with
them
.
 
<EOS>
While
Leonard
was
hesitating
whether
he
should
make
known
their
danger
to
Amabel
,
he
perceived
Solomon
Eagle
dart
from
behind
a
wall
on
the
left
of
the
road
,
and
plant
himself
in
the
direct
course
of
their
pursuers
,
and
he
involuntarily
drew
in
the
rein
to
see
what
would
ensue
.
<EOS>
In
another
moment
,
the
horsemen
,
who
were
advancing
at
full
gallop
,
and
whom
Leonard
now
recognised
as
the
Earl
of
Rochester
,
Pillichody
,
and
Sir
Paul
Parravicin
,
had
approached
within
a
few
yards
of
the
enthusiast
,
and
threatened
to
ride
over
him
if
he
did
not
get
of
the
way
.
<EOS>
Seeing
,
however
,
that
he
did
not
offer
to
move
,
they
opened
on
either
side
of
him
,
and
were
passing
swiftly
by
,
when
,
with
infinite
dexterity
,
he
caught
hold
of
the
bridle
of
Rochester
's
steed
,
and
checking
him
,
seized
the
earl
by
the
leg
,
and
threw
him
to
the
ground
.
 
<EOS>
Sir
Paul
Parravicin
pulled
up
as
soon
as
he
could
,
and
,
drawing
his
sword
,
rode
back
to
assist
his
friend
,
and
punish
the
aggressor
;
but
the
enthusiast
,
nothing
daunted
,
met
him
in
full
career
,
and
suddenly
lifting
up
his
arms
,
uttered
a
loud
cry
,
which
so
startled
the
knight
's
high
-
spirited
horse
,
that
it
reared
and
flung
him
.
<EOS>
All
this
was
the
work
of
a
few
seconds
.
<EOS>
Pillichody
had
been
borne
forward
by
the
impetuosity
of
his
steed
to
within
a
short
distance
of
the
apprentice
,
and
seeing
the
fate
of
his
companions
,
and
not
liking
Leonard
's
menacing
gestures
,
he
chipped
spurs
into
his
horse
,
and
rode
up
Park
-
lane
.
 
<EOS>
Overjoyed
at
his
unexpected
deliverance
,
Leonard
,
whose
attention
had
been
completely
engrossed
by
what
was
passing
,
now
ventured
to
look
at
Amabel
,
and
became
greatly
alarmed
at
her
appearance
.
<EOS>
She
was
as
pale
as
death
,
except
a
small
scarlet
patch
on
either
cheek
,
which
contrasted
powerfully
with
the
death
-
like
hue
of
the
rest
of
her
countenance
.
<EOS>
Her
hands
convulsively
clasped
the
back
of
the
pillion
;
her
lips
were
slightly
apart
,
and
her
eyes
fixed
upon
the
prostrate
form
of
the
Earl
of
Rochester
.
<EOS>
On
finding
they
were
pursued
,
and
by
whom
,
her
first
impulse
had
been
to
fling
herself
from
the
pillion
,
and
to
seek
safety
by
flight
;
but
controlling
herself
,
she
awaited
the
result
with
forced
composure
,
and
was
now
sinking
from
the
exhaustion
of
the
effort
.
 
<EOS>
"
Thank
Heaven
!
<EOS>
we
are
safe
,
"
cried
the
apprentice
;
"
but
I
fear
the
shock
has
been
too
much
for
you
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
has
,
"
gasped
Amabel
,
falling
against
his
shoulder
.
<EOS>
"
Let
us
fly
--
<EOS>
oh
!
let
us
fly
.
"
 
<EOS>
Inexpressibly
shocked
and
alarmed
,
Leonard
twined
his
left
arm
round
her
waist
so
as
to
hold
her
on
the
steed
,
for
she
was
utterly
unable
to
support
herself
,
and
glancing
anxiously
at
Nizza
Macascree
,
struck
off
on
the
right
into
the
road
skirting
the
Park
,
and
in
the
direction
of
Tyburn
,
where
there
was
a
small
inn
,
at
which
he
hoped
to
procure
assistance
.
<EOS>
Before
reaching
this
place
,
he
was
beyond
description
relieved
to
find
that
Amabel
had
so
far
recovered
as
to
be
able
to
raise
her
head
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
deadly
faintness
is
passed
,
"
she
murmured
;
"
I
shall
be
better
soon
.
<EOS>
But
I
fear
I
am
too
weak
to
pursue
the
journey
at
present
.
"
 
<EOS>
Leonard
spurred
on
his
steed
,
and
in
another
instant
reached
Tyburn
,
and
drew
up
at
the
little
inn
.
<EOS>
But
no
assistance
could
be
obtained
there
.
<EOS>
The
house
was
closed
;
there
was
a
red
cross
on
the
door
;
and
a
watchman
,
stationed
in
front
of
it
,
informed
him
that
all
the
family
had
died
of
the
plague
except
the
landlord--"and
he
will
be
buried
beside
them
in
Paddington
churchyard
before
to
-
morrow
morning
,
"
added
the
man
;
"
for
his
nurse
tells
me
it
is
impossible
he
can
survive
many
hours
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
As
he
spoke
an
upper
window
was
opened
,
and
a
woman
,
thrusting
forth
her
head
,
cried
,
"
Poor
Master
Sandys
has
just
breathed
his
last
.
<EOS>
Come
in
,
Philip
,
and
help
me
to
prepare
the
body
for
the
dead
-
cart
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
will
be
with
you
in
a
minute
,
"
rejoined
the
watchman
.
<EOS>
"
You
may
possibly
procure
accommodation
at
the
Wheatsheaf
at
Paddington
,
"
he
added
to
Leonard
;
"
it
is
but
a
short
distance
up
the
road
.
"
 
<EOS>
Thanking
him
for
the
information
,
Leonard
took
the
course
indicated
.
<EOS>
He
had
not
proceeded
far
,
when
he
was
alarmed
by
hearing
a
piteous
cry
of
"
Stop
!
<EOS>
stop
!
"
<EOS>
proceeding
from
Blaize
;
and
,
halting
,
found
that
the
porter
had
been
so
greatly
terrified
by
the
watchman
's
account
of
the
frightful
mortality
in
the
poor
innkeeper
's
family
,
that
he
had
applied
to
his
phial
of
plague
-
water
,
and
in
pulling
it
put
had
dropped
his
box
of
rufuses
,
and
the
jar
of
anti
-
pestilential
confection
.
<EOS>
He
had
just
ascertained
his
loss
,
and
wished
to
go
back
,
but
this
Nizza
Macascree
would
not
permit
.
<EOS>
Enraged
at
the
delay
,
Leonard
peremptorily
ordered
the
porter
to
come
on
;
and
Blaize
,
casting
a
rueful
glance
at
his
treasures
,
which
he
perceived
at
a
little
distance
in
the
middle
of
the
road
,
was
compelled
to
obey
.
 
<EOS>
At
Paddington
,
another
disappointment
awaited
them
.
<EOS>
The
Wheatsheaf
was
occupied
by
two
large
families
,
who
were
flying
from
the
infected
city
,
and
no
accommodation
could
be
obtained
.
<EOS>
Leonard
looked
wistfully
at
Nizza
Macascree
,
as
if
to
ascertain
what
to
do
,
and
she
was
equally
perplexed
;
but
the
difficulty
was
relieved
by
Amabel
herself
,
who
said
she
felt
much
better
,
and
able
to
proceed
a
little
further
.
<EOS>
"
Do
not
return
to
London
,
"
she
continued
with
great
earnestness
.
<EOS>
"
I
would
rather
die
on
the
road
than
go
home
again
.
<EOS>
Some
cottage
will
receive
us
.
<EOS>
If
not
,
I
can
rest
for
a
short
time
in
the
fields
.
"
 
<EOS>
Thinking
it
best
to
comply
,
Leonard
proceeded
along
the
Harrow
-
road
.
<EOS>
Soon
after
crossing
Paddington
Green
,
he
overtook
a
little
train
of
fugitives
driving
a
cart
filled
with
children
,
and
laden
with
luggage
.
<EOS>
Further
on
,
as
he
surveyed
the
beautiful
meadows
,
stretching
out
on
either
side
of
him
,
he
perceived
a
line
of
small
tents
,
resembling
a
gipsy
encampment
,
pitched
at
a
certain
distance
from
each
other
,
and
evidently
occupied
by
families
who
had
fled
from
their
homes
from
fear
of
infection
.
<EOS>
This
gave
a
singular
character
to
the
prospect
.
<EOS>
But
there
were
other
and
far
more
painful
sights
on
the
road
,
which
could
not
fail
to
attract
attention
.
<EOS>
For
the
first
half
-
mile
,
almost
at
every
hundred
yards
might
be
seen
some
sick
man
,
who
,
unable
to
proceed
further
,
had
fallen
against
the
hedge
-
side
,
and
exhibited
his
sores
to
move
the
pity
of
the
passers
-
by
.
<EOS>
But
these
supplications
were
wholly
unheeded
.
<EOS>
Self
-
preservation
was
the
first
object
with
all
,
and
the
travellers
holding
handkerchiefs
steeped
in
vinegar
to
their
faces
,
and
averting
their
heads
,
passed
by
on
the
other
side
of
the
way
.
 
<EOS>
The
pestilence
,
it
may
be
remarked
,
had
visited
with
extraordinary
rigour
the
whole
of
the
higher
country
at
the
west
and
north
-
west
of
the
metropolis
.
<EOS>
The
charmingly
-
situated
,
and
,
at
other
seasons
,
healthful
villages
of
Hampstead
and
Highgate
,
suffered
severely
from
the
scourge
;
and
it
even
extended
its
ravages
as
far
as
Harrow
-
on
-
the
-
Hill
,
which
it
half
depopulated
.
<EOS>
This
will
account
for
the
circumstance
of
a
large
pest
-
house
being
erected
in
the
neighbourhood
of
Westbourne
Green
,
which
the
party
now
approached
.
<EOS>
Two
litters
were
seen
crossing
the
fields
in
the
direction
of
the
hospital
,
and
this
circumstance
called
Leonard
's
attention
to
it
.
<EOS>
Shudderingly
averting
his
gaze
,
he
quickened
his
pace
,
and
soon
reached
a
small
farmhouse
on
the
summit
of
the
hill
rising
from
Kensal
Green
.
<EOS>
Determined
to
seek
a
temporary
asylum
here
for
Amabel
,
he
opened
a
gate
,
and
,
riding
into
the
yard
,
fortunately
met
with
owner
of
the
house
,
a
worthy
farmer
,
named
Wingfield
,
to
whom
he
explained
her
situation
.
<EOS>
The
man
at
first
hesitated
,
but
,
on
receiving
Leonard
's
solemn
assurance
that
she
was
free
from
the
plague
,
consented
to
receive
the
whole
party
.
 
<EOS>
Assisting
Amabel
to
dismount
<EOS>
,
Wingfield
conveyed
her
in
his
arms
into
the
house
,
and
delivered
her
to
his
wife
,
bidding
her
take
care
of
her
.
<EOS>
The
injunction
was
scarcely
needed
.
<EOS>
The
good
dame
,
who
was
a
middle
-
aged
woman
,
with
pleasing
features
,
which
lost
none
of
their
interest
from
being
stamped
with
profound
melancholy
,
gazed
at
her
for
a
moment
fixedly
,
and
then
observed
in
an
under
-
tone
,
but
with
much
emotion
,
to
her
husband
,
"
Ah
!
<EOS>
Robert
,
how
much
this
sweet
creature
resembles
our
poor
Sarah
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
Hush
!
hush
!
<EOS>
dame
,
"
rejoined
her
husband
,
hastily
brushing
away
the
moisture
that
sprang
to
his
eyes
;
"
take
her
to
your
chamber
,
and
see
that
she
wants
nothing
.
<EOS>
There
is
another
young
woman
outside
,
whom
I
will
send
to
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
So
saying
,
he
returned
to
the
yard
.
<EOS>
Meantime
,
the
others
had
dismounted
,
and
Wingfield
,
bidding
Nizza
Macascree
go
in
,
led
the
way
to
the
barn
,
where
the
horses
were
tied
up
,
and
fodder
placed
before
them
.
<EOS>
This
done
,
he
conducted
his
guests
to
the
house
,
and
placing
cold
meat
,
bread
,
and
a
jug
of
ale
before
them
,
desired
them
to
fall
to
--
an
injunction
which
Blaize
,
notwithstanding
his
previous
repast
of
roasted
figs
and
pickled
walnuts
,
very
readily
complied
with
.
<EOS>
While
they
were
thus
employed
,
Dame
Wingfield
made
her
appearance
.
<EOS>
She
said
that
the
poor
creature
(
meaning
Amabel
)
was
too
ill
to
proceed
on
her
journey
that
day
,
and
begged
her
husband
to
allow
her
to
stop
till
the
next
morning
,
when
she
hoped
she
would
be
able
to
undertake
it
.
 
<EOS>
"
To
-
morrow
morning
,
say
you
dame
?
"
<EOS>
cried
Wingfield
;
"
she
may
stop
till
the
day
after
,
and
the
day
after
that
,
if
you
desire
it
,
or
she
wishes
it
.
<EOS>
Go
tell
her
so
.
"
 
<EOS>
And
as
his
wife
withdrew
,
well
pleased
at
having
obtained
her
request
,
Wingfield
addressed
himself
to
Leonard
,
and
inquired
the
cause
of
Amabel
's
illness
;
and
as
the
apprentice
saw
no
necessity
for
secresy
,
and
felt
exceedingly
grateful
for
the
kind
treatment
he
had
experienced
,
he
acquainted
him
with
the
chief
particulars
of
her
history
.
<EOS>
The
farmer
appeared
greatly
moved
by
the
recital
.
 
<EOS>
"
She
resembles
my
poor
Sarah
very
strongly
,
"
he
said
.
<EOS>
"
My
daughter
was
hurried
into
an
early
grave
by
a
villain
who
won
her
affections
and
betrayed
her
.
<EOS>
She
now
lies
in
Willesden
churchyard
,
but
her
seducer
is
one
of
the
chief
favourites
of
our
profligate
monarch
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Do
you
mean
the
Earl
of
Rochester
?
"
cried
Leonard
.
 
<EOS>
"
No
,
no
,
"
replied
the
farmer
,
whose
good
-
natured
countenance
had
assumed
a
stern
expression
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
villain
I
mean
is
worse
,
if
possible
,
than
the
earl
.
<EOS>
He
is
called
Sir
Paul
Parravicin
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Gracious
Heaven
!
<EOS>
"
exclaimed
Leonard
,
in
astonishment
;
"
what
a
strange
coincidence
is
this
!
"
 
<EOS>
And
he
then
proceeded
to
relate
to
Wingfield
the
persecution
which
Nizza
Macascree
had
endured
from
the
profligate
knight
The
farmer
listened
to
his
recital
with
breathless
interest
,
and
when
it
was
ended
arose
,
and
,
taking
a
hasty
turn
round
the
room
,
halted
at
the
table
and
struck
it
forcibly
with
his
clenched
hand
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
hope
that
man
will
never
cross
my
path
,
"
he
said
,
all
the
blood
mounting
to
his
face
,
and
his
eye
kindling
with
fury
.
<EOS>
"
As
God
shall
judge
me
,
I
will
kill
him
if
I
meet
him
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Then
I
hope
you
never
will
meet
him
,
"
observed
Leonard
.
"
<EOS>
He
has
injured
you
enough
already
,
without
putting
you
out
of
the
pale
of
Divine
mercy
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
These
rascals
have
done
us
all
an
injury
,
"
observed
Blaize
.
<EOS>
"
Patience
has
never
been
like
herself
since
Major
Pillichody
entered
my
master
's
dwelling
,
and
made
love
to
her
.
<EOS>
I
feel
quite
uneasy
to
think
how
the
little
hussy
will
go
on
during
my
absence
.
<EOS>
She
ca
n't
get
out
of
the
house
,
that
's
one
comfort
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
have
mentioned
another
wretch
,
who
was
constantly
with
Sir
Paul
,
"
cried
Wingfield
.
"
<EOS>
Perdition
seize
them
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
Ay
,
perdition
seize
them
!
"
echoed
Blaize
,
striking
the
table
in
his
turn--"especially
Major
Pillichody
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Did
you
ever
suspect
Sir
Paul
to
be
of
higher
rank
than
he
pretends
?
"
asked
Leonard
.
 
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
rejoined
Wingfield
;
"
what
motive
have
you
for
the
question
?
"
 
<EOS>
Leonard
then
told
him
of
the
inquiries
instituted
by
Doctor
Hodges
relative
to
Nizza
's
retreat
,
and
how
they
had
been
baffled
.
<EOS>
"
It
is
strange
,
"
he
continued
,
"
that
Nizza
herself
never
heard
the
real
name
of
her
persecutor
;
neither
can
she
tell
where
the
house
to
which
she
was
conveyed
,
when
in
a
fainting
condition
,
and
from
which
she
was
removed
when
attacked
with
the
plague
,
is
situated
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
strange
indeed
,
"
observed
the
farmer
,
musingly
.
 
<EOS>
Soon
after
this
,
Nizza
Macascree
made
her
appearance
,
and
informed
them
that
Amabel
had
fallen
into
a
tranquil
slumber
,
which
,
in
all
probability
,
would
completely
renovate
her
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
hope
it
will
,
"
said
Wingfield
.
<EOS>
"
But
I
shall
not
part
with
her
to
-
day
.
"
 
<EOS>
He
then
entered
into
conversation
with
Nizza
,
and
after
a
little
time
,
proposed
to
her
and
Leonard
to
walk
across
the
fields
with
him
to
Willesden
,
to
visit
his
daughter
's
grave
.
 
<EOS>
"
My
wife
will
take
charge
of
Amabel
,
"
he
said
;
"
you
may
safely
trust
her
in
her
hands
.
"
 
<EOS>
Leonard
could
raise
no
objection
,
except
the
possibility
that
the
Earl
of
Rochester
and
his
companions
might
discover
their
retreat
,
and
carry
off
Amabel
in
his
absence
;
but
,
after
a
little
reflection
,
considering
this
altogether
unlikely
,
he
assented
,
and
they
set
out
.
<EOS>
A
pleasant
walk
across
the
fields
brought
them
to
the
pretty
little
village
of
Willesden
and
its
old
and
beautiful
church
.
<EOS>
They
proceeded
to
the
grave
of
poor
Sarah
Wingfield
,
which
lay
at
the
east
of
the
church
,
beneath
one
of
the
tall
elms
,
and
Nizza
,
as
she
stood
by
the
rounded
sod
covering
the
remains
of
the
unfortunate
girl
,
could
not
restrain
her
tears
.
 
<EOS>
"
This
might
have
been
my
own
fate
,
"
she
said
.
<EOS>
"
What
an
escape
I
have
had
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
did
not
bring
you
here
to
read
you
a
lesson
,
"
said
Wingfield
,
in
a
tone
of
deep
emotion
,
"
but
because
you
,
who
know
the
temptation
to
which
the
poor
creature
who
lies
there
was
exposed
,
will
pity
her
.
<EOS>
Not
alone
did
remorse
for
her
conduct
prey
upon
her
spirits
--
not
alone
<EOS>
did
she
suffer
from
self
-
<EOS>
reproach,--but
<EOS>
the
scoffs
and
jeers
of
her
sex
,
who
never
forgive
an
erring
sister
,
broke
her
heart
.
<EOS>
She
is
now
,
however
,
beyond
the
reach
of
human
malice
,
and
,
I
trust
,
at
peace
.
"
 
<EOS>
As
he
said
this
,
he
walked
away
to
hide
his
emotion
,
and
presently
afterwards
rejoining
them
,
they
quitted
the
churchyard
together
.
 
<EOS>
As
they
recrossed
the
fields
,
Wingfield
observed
two
men
digging
a
hole
in
the
ground
,
and
,
guessing
their
object
,
paused
for
a
few
minutes
to
watch
them
.
<EOS>
Having
thrown
out
the
earth
to
the
depth
of
a
couple
of
feet
,
one
of
them
took
a
long
hooked
pole
,
and
attaching
it
to
the
body
of
a
victim
to
the
pestilence
,
who
had
wandered
into
the
fields
and
died
there
,
dragged
it
towards
the
pit
.
<EOS>
As
soon
as
the
corpse
was
pushed
into
its
narrow
receptacle
,
the
clay
was
shovelled
over
it
,
and
trodden
down
.
 
<EOS>
"
This
is
a
sad
mode
of
burial
for
a
Christian
,
"
observed
Wingfield
.
<EOS>
"
But
it
would
not
do
to
leave
an
infected
body
to
rot
in
the
fields
,
and
spread
the
contagion
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Such
a
grave
is
better
than
the
plague
-
pit
,
"
rejoined
Leonard
,
recalling
the
frightful
scenes
he
had
witnessed
there
.
 
<EOS>
On
reaching
Wingfield
's
dwelling
,
they
found
from
the
good
dame
,
that
Amabel
had
awakened
from
her
slumber
greatly
refreshed
;
but
she
gave
it
as
her
opinion
that
she
had
better
remain
undisturbed
.
<EOS>
Accordingly
,
no
one
went
into
the
room
to
her
except
Nizza
Macascree
.
<EOS>
A
substantial
dinner
was
provided
for
his
guests
by
the
hospitable
farmer
;
and
Blaize
,
who
had
been
for
some
time
confined
to
salt
provisions
at
his
master
's
house
,
did
ample
justice
to
the
fresh
meat
and
vegetables
.
 
<EOS>
The
meal
over
,
Leonard
,
who
felt
exceedingly
curious
to
learn
what
had
become
of
the
mysterious
stranger
whose
child
he
had
carried
to
the
plague
-
pit
,
and
who
had
appeared
so
strangely
interested
in
Nizza
Macascree
,
determined
to
walk
to
the
pest
-
house
in
Finsbury
Fields
and
inquire
after
him
.
<EOS>
On
communicating
his
intention
to
his
host
,
Wingfield
would
have
dissuaded
him
;
but
as
Leonard
affirmed
he
had
no
fear
of
infection
,
he
desisted
from
the
attempt
.
<EOS>
Just
as
the
apprentice
was
starting
,
Blaize
came
up
to
him
,
and
said,--"Leonard
,
I
have
a
great
curiosity
to
see
a
pest
-
house
,
and
should
like
to
go
with
you
,
if
you
will
let
me
.
"
 
<EOS>
The
apprentice
stared
at
him
in
astonishment
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
will
never
dare
to
enter
it
,
"
he
said
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
will
go
wherever
you
go
,
"
replied
the
porter
,
with
a
confidence
mainly
inspired
by
the
hospitable
farmer
's
strong
ale
.
 
<EOS>
"
We
shall
see
,
"
replied
Leonard
.
<EOS>
"
I
shall
keep
you
to
your
word
.
"
 
<EOS>
In
less
than
an
hour
they
reached
Marylebone
Fields
(
now
the
Regent
's
Park
)
,
and
,
crossing
them
,
entered
a
lane
,
running
in
pretty
nearly
the
same
direction
as
the
present
New
-
road
.
<EOS>
It
Drought
them
to
Clerkenwell
,
whence
they
proceeded
to
Finsbury
Fields
,
and
soon
came
in
sight
of
the
pest
-
house
.
<EOS>
When
Blaize
found
himself
so
near
this
dreaded
asylum
,
all
his
courage
vanished
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
would
certainly
enter
the
pest
-
house
with
you
,
"
he
said
to
Leonard
,
"
but
I
have
used
up
all
my
vinegar
,
and
you
know
I
lost
my
box
of
rufuses
and
the
pot
of
anti
-
pestilential
confection
this
morning
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
That
excuse
shall
not
serve
your
turn
,
"
replied
Leonard
.
<EOS>
"
You
can
get
plenty
of
vinegar
and
plague
medicine
in
the
pest
-
house
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
But
I
have
no
money
to
pay
for
them
,
"
rejoined
Blaize
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
will
lend
you
some
,
"
said
Leonard
,
placing
a
few
pieces
in
his
hand
.
<EOS>
"
Now
,
come
along
.
"
 
<EOS>
Blaize
would
fain
have
run
away
,
but
,
afraid
of
incurring
the
apprentice
's
anger
,
he
walked
tremblingly
after
him
.
<EOS>
They
entered
the
garden
-
gate
,
and
soon
reached
the
principal
door
,
which
,
as
usual
,
stood
open
.
<EOS>
Scarcely
able
to
support
himself
,
the
porter
tottered
into
the
large
room
;
but
as
he
cast
his
eyes
around
,
and
beheld
the
miserable
occupants
of
the
pallets
,
and
heard
their
cries
and
groans
,
he
was
so
scared
that
he
could
not
move
another
step
,
but
stood
like
one
transfixed
with
terror
.
<EOS>
Paying
little
attention
to
him
,
Leonard
walked
forward
,
and
at
the
further
extremity
of
the
chamber
found
the
young
chirurgeon
whom
he
had
formerly
seen
,
and
describing
the
stranger
,
inquired
where
he
was
placed
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
person
you
allude
to
has
been
removed
,
"
returned
the
chirurgeon
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Doctor
Hodges
visited
him
this
morning
,
and
had
him
conveyed
to
his
own
dwelling
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Was
he
sensible
at
the
time
?
"
asked
the
apprentice
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
think
not
,
"
replied
the
chirurgeon
;
"
but
the
doctor
appeared
to
recognise
in
him
an
old
friend
,
though
I
did
not
hear
him
mention
his
name
;
and
it
was
on
that
account
,
I
conclude
,
that
he
had
him
removed
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Is
he
likely
to
recover
?
"
asked
Leonard
,
whose
curiosity
was
aroused
by
what
he
heard
.
 
<EOS>
"
That
is
impossible
to
say
,
"
replied
the
young
man
.
"
<EOS>
But
he
can
not
be
in
better
hands
than
those
of
Doctor
Hodges
.
"
 
<EOS>
Leonard
perfectly
concurred
with
him
,
and
,
after
a
few
minutes
'
further
conversation
,
turned
to
depart
.
<EOS>
Not
seeing
Blaize
,
he
concluded
he
had
gone
forth
,
and
expected
to
find
him
in
the
garden
,
or
,
at
all
events
,
in
the
field
adjoining
.
<EOS>
But
he
was
nowhere
to
be
seen
.
<EOS>
While
wondering
what
had
become
of
him
,
Leonard
heard
a
loud
cry
,
in
the
voice
of
the
porter
,
issuing
from
the
barn
,
which
,
as
has
already
been
stated
,
had
been
converted
into
a
receptacle
for
the
sick
;
and
hurrying
thither
,
he
found
Blaize
in
the
hands
of
two
stout
assistants
,
who
had
stripped
him
of
his
clothes
,
and
were
tying
him
down
to
a
pallet
.
<EOS>
On
seeing
Leonard
,
Blaize
implored
him
to
deliver
him
from
the
hands
of
his
persecutors
;
and
the
apprentice
assuring
the
assistants
that
the
poor
fellow
was
perfectly
free
from
infection
,
they
liberated
him
.
 
<EOS>
It
appeared
,
on
inquiry
,
that
Blaize
had
fallen
against
one
of
the
pallets
in
a
state
almost
of
insensibility
,
and
the
two
assistants
,
chancing
to
pass
at
the
time
,
and
taking
him
for
a
plague
patient
,
had
conveyed
him
to
the
barn
.
<EOS>
On
reaching
it
,
he
recovered
,
and
besought
them
to
set
him
free
,
but
they
paid
no
attention
to
his
cries
,
and
proceeded
to
strip
him
,
and
bind
him
to
the
bed
,
as
before
related
.
 
<EOS>
Thus
released
,
the
porter
lost
no
time
in
dressing
himself
;
and
Leonard
,
to
allay
his
terrors
,
had
a
strong
dose
of
anti
-
pestilential
elixir
administered
to
him
.
<EOS>
After
which
,
having
procured
him
a
box
of
rufuses
,
and
a
phial
of
plague
-
water
,
Blaize
shook
off
his
apprehension
,
and
they
set
out
at
a
brisk
pace
for
Kensal
Green
.
  
<EOS>
VII
.
 
<EOS>
THE
JOURNEY
.
 
<EOS>
Blaize
was
destined
to
experience
a
second
fright
.
<EOS>
It
has
been
mentioned
that
the
infected
were
sometimes
seized
with
a
rabid
desire
of
communicating
the
disorder
to
such
as
had
not
been
attacked
by
it
;
and
as
the
pair
were
making
the
best
of
their
way
along
the
Harrow
-
road
,
a
poor
lazar
who
was
lying
against
the
hedge
-
side
,
and
had
vainly
implored
their
assistance
,
suddenly
started
up
,
and
with
furious
cries
and
gestures
made
towards
the
porter
.
<EOS>
Guessing
his
intention
,
Blaize
took
to
his
heels
,
and
,
folding
himself
closely
pressed
,
broke
through
the
hedge
on
the
right
,
and
speeded
across
the
field
.
<EOS>
In
spite
of
the
alarming
nature
of
the
occurrence
,
the
apprentice
could
not
help
laughing
at
the
unwonted
agility
displayed
by
the
fat
little
porter
,
who
ran
so
swiftly
that
it
appeared
probable
he
would
distance
his
pursuer
.
<EOS>
To
prevent
mischief
,
however
,
Leonard
set
off
after
him
,
and
was
fast
gaining
upon
the
lazar
,
whose
strength
was
evidently
failing
,
when
the
poor
wretch
uttered
a
loud
cry
,
and
fell
to
the
ground
.
<EOS>
On
coming
up
,
Leonard
found
him
lying
with
his
face
in
the
grass
,
and
convulsed
by
the
agonies
of
death
,
and
perceiving
that
all
was
over
,
hurried
after
the
porter
,
whom
he
found
seated
on
a
gate
,
at
the
further
end
of
the
field
,
solacing
himself
with
a
draught
of
plague
-
water
.
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
Leonard
!
<EOS>
"
groaned
the
latter
,
"
how
little
do
we
know
what
is
for
our
good
!
<EOS>
I
was
delighted
to
quit
my
master
's
house
this
morning
,
but
I
now
wish
with
,
all
my
heart
<EOS>
I
was
back
again
.
<EOS>
I
am
afraid
I
shall
die
of
the
plague
after
all
.
<EOS>
Pray
what
are
the
first
symptoms
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Pooh
!
<EOS>
pooh
!
<EOS>
do
n't
think
about
it
,
and
you
will
take
no
harm
,
"
rejoined
Leonard
.
<EOS>
"
Put
by
your
phial
,
and
let
us
make
the
best
of
our
way
to
Farmer
Wingfield
's
dwelling
.
"
 
<EOS>
Being
now
in
sight
of
the
farm
,
which
,
from
its
elevated
situation
,
could
be
distinguished
at
a
distance
of
two
miles
in
this
direction
,
they
easily
shaped
their
course
towards
it
across
the
fields
.
<EOS>
When
about
halfway
up
the
hill
,
Leonard
paused
to
look
behind
him
.
<EOS>
The
view
was
exquisite
,
and
it
was
precisely
the
hour
(
just
before
sunset
)
at
which
it
could
be
seen
to
the
greatest
advantage
.
<EOS>
On
the
right
,
his
gaze
wandered
to
the
beautiful
and
well
-
wooded
heights
of
Richmond
and
Wimbledon
,
beyond
which
he
could
trace
the
long
line
of
the
Surrey
hills
,
while
nearer
he
perceived
Notting
Hill
,
now
covered
with
habitations
,
but
then
a
verdant
knoll
,
crowned
by
a
few
trees
,
but
without
so
much
as
a
cottage
upon
it
.
<EOS>
On
the
left
stood
Hampstead
;
at
that
time
a
collection
of
pretty
cottages
,
but
wanting
its
present
chief
ornament
,
the
church
.
<EOS>
At
the
foot
of
the
hill
rich
meadows
,
bordered
with
fine
hedges
,
interspersed
with
well
-
grown
timber
,
spread
out
as
far
as
the
eye
could
reach
.
<EOS>
Nothing
destroyed
the
rural
character
of
the
prospect
;
nor
was
there
any
indication
of
the
neighbourhood
of
a
great
city
,
except
the
lofty
tower
and
massive
body
of
Saint
Paul
's
,
which
appeared
above
the
tops
of
the
intervening
trees
in
the
distance
.
 
<EOS>
As
on
former
occasions
,
when
contemplating
the
surrounding
country
from
the
summit
of
the
cathedral
,
Leonard
could
not
help
contrasting
the
beauty
of
the
scene
before
him
with
the
horrible
scourge
by
which
it
was
ravaged
.
<EOS>
Never
had
the
country
looked
so
beautiful
--
never
,
therefore
,
was
the
contrast
so
forcible
;
and
it
appeared
to
him
like
a
lovely
mask
hiding
the
hideous
and
ghastly
features
of
death
.
<EOS>
Tinged
by
the
sombre
hue
of
his
thoughts
,
the
whole
scene
changed
its
complexion
.
<EOS>
The
smiling
landscape
seemed
to
darken
,
and
the
cool
air
of
evening
to
become
hot
and
noisome
,
as
if
laden
with
the
deadly
exhalations
of
the
pestilence
.
<EOS>
Nor
did
the
workings
of
his
imagination
stop
here
.
<EOS>
He
fancied
even
at
this
distance
--
nearly
seven
miles
--
that
he
could
discern
Solomon
Eagle
on
the
summit
of
Saint
Paul
's
.
<EOS>
At
first
the
figure
looked
like
a
small
black
speck
;
but
it
gradually
dilated
,
until
it
became
twice
the
size
of
the
cathedral
,
upon
the
central
tower
of
which
its
feet
rested
,
while
its
arms
were
spread
abroad
over
the
city
.
<EOS>
In
its
right
hand
the
gigantic
figure
held
a
blazing
torch
,
and
in
the
left
a
phial
,
from
the
mouth
of
which
a
stream
of
dark
liquid
descended
.
<EOS>
So
vividly
did
this
phantasm
present
itself
to
Leonard
,
that
,
almost
convinced
of
its
reality
,
he
placed
his
hands
before
his
eyes
for
a
few
moments
,
and
,
on
withdrawing
them
,
was
glad
to
find
that
the
delusion
was
occasioned
by
a
black
cloud
over
the
cathedral
,
which
his
distempered
fancy
had
converted
into
the
colossal
figure
of
the
enthusiast
.
 
<EOS>
Blaize
,
who
had
taken
the
opportunity
of
his
companion
's
abstraction
to
sip
a
little
more
plague
-
water
,
now
approached
,
and
told
him
that
Wingfield
was
descending
the
hill
to
meet
them
.
<EOS>
Rousing
himself
,
Leonard
ran
towards
the
farmer
,
who
appeared
delighted
to
see
them
back
again
,
and
conducted
them
to
his
dwelling
.
<EOS>
Owing
to
the
tender
and
truly
maternal
attention
of
Dame
Wingfield
,
Amabel
was
so
much
better
that
she
was
able
to
join
the
party
at
supper
,
though
she
took
no
share
in
the
meal
.
<EOS>
Wingfield
listened
to
the
soft
tones
of
her
voice
as
she
conversed
with
his
wife
,
and
at
last
,
unable
to
control
his
emotion
,
laid
down
his
knife
and
fork
,
and
quitted
the
table
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
is
the
matter
with
your
husband
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Amabel
of
her
hostess
.
<EOS>
"
I
hope
he
is
not
unwell
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
!
no
,
"
replied
the
good
dame
;
"
your
voice
reminds
him
of
our
daughter
,
whose
history
I
have
related
to
you
--
that
is
all
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Alas
!
"
exclaimed
Amabel
,
with
a
sympathizing
look
,
"
I
will
be
silent
,
if
it
pains
him
to
hear
me
speak
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
On
no
account
,
"
rejoined
Dame
Wingfield
.
<EOS>
"
The
tears
he
has
shed
will
relieve
him
.
<EOS>
He
could
not
weep
when
poor
Sarah
died
,
and
I
feared
his
heart
would
break
.
<EOS>
Talk
to
him
as
you
have
talked
to
me
,
and
you
will
do
him
a
world
of
good
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
Shortly
afterwards
,
the
farmer
returned
to
the
table
,
and
the
meal
proceeded
to
its
close
without
further
interruption
.
<EOS>
As
soon
as
the
board
was
cleared
,
Wingfield
took
a
chair
by
Amabel
,
who
,
in
compliance
with
his
wife
's
request
,
spoke
to
him
about
his
daughter
,
and
in
terms
calculated
to
afford
him
consolation
.
<EOS>
Leonard
was
enraptured
by
her
discourse
,
and
put
so
little
constraint
upon
his
admiration
,
that
Nizza
Macascree
could
not
repress
a
pang
of
jealousy
.
<EOS>
As
to
Blaize
,
who
had
eaten
as
much
as
he
could
cram
,
and
emptied
a
large
jug
of
the
farmer
's
stout
ale
,
he
took
his
chair
to
a
corner
,
and
speedily
fell
asleep
;
his
hoarse
but
tranquil
breathing
proving
that
the
alarms
he
had
undergone
during
the
day
did
not
haunt
his
slumbers
.
<EOS>
Before
separating
for
the
night
,
Amabel
entreated
that
prayers
might
be
said
,
and
her
request
being
readily
granted
,
she
was
about
to
retire
with
Nizza
,
when
Wingfield
detained
them
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
been
thinking
that
I
might
offer
you
a
safe
asylum
here
,
"
he
said
.
<EOS>
"
If
you
like
it
,
you
shall
remain
with
us
till
your
health
is
fully
reinstated
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
thank
you
most
kindly
for
the
offer
,
"
returned
Amabel
,
gratefully
;
"
and
if
I
do
not
accept
it
,
it
is
neither
because
I
should
not
esteem
myself
safe
here
,
nor
because
I
am
unwilling
to
be
indebted
to
your
hospitality
,
but
that
I
have
been
specially
advised
,
as
my
last
chance
of
recovery
,
to
try
the
air
of
Berkshire
.
<EOS>
I
have
little
hope
myself
,
but
I
owe
it
to
those
who
love
me
to
make
the
experiment
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
If
such
is
the
case
,
"
returned
the
farmer
,
"
I
will
not
attempt
to
persuade
you
further
.
<EOS>
But
if
at
any
future
time
you
should
need
change
of
air
,
my
house
shall
be
entirely
at
your
service
.
"
 
<EOS>
Dame
Wingfield
warmly
seconded
her
husband
's
wish
,
and
,
with
renewed
thanks
,
Amabel
and
her
companion
withdrew
.
<EOS>
As
there
was
not
sufficient
room
for
their
accommodation
within
the
house
,
Leonard
and
the
porter
took
up
their
quarters
in
the
barn
,
and
,
throwing
themselves
upon
a
heap
of
straw
,
slept
soundly
till
three
o'clock
,
when
they
arose
and
began
to
prepare
for
their
journey
.
<EOS>
Wingfield
was
likewise
astir
,
and
,
after
assisting
them
to
feed
and
dress
their
horses
,
took
them
into
the
house
,
where
a
plentiful
breakfast
awaited
them
.
<EOS>
At
the
close
of
the
meal
,
Amabel
and
Nizza
,
who
had
breakfasted
in
their
own
room
,
made
their
appearance
.
<EOS>
All
being
in
readiness
for
their
departure
,
Dame
Wingfield
took
leave
of
her
guests
with
tears
in
her
eyes
,
and
the
honest
farmer
was
little
less
affected
.
<EOS>
Both
gazed
after
them
as
long
as
they
continued
in
sight
.
 
<EOS>
Having
ascertained
from
Wingfield
the
route
they
ought
to
pursue
,
Leonard
proceeded
about
a
quarter
of
a
mile
along
the
Harrow
-
road
,
and
then
turned
off
on
the
left
into
a
common
,
which
brought
them
to
Acton
,
from
whence
they
threaded
a
devious
lane
to
Brentford
.
<EOS>
Here
they
encountered
several
fugitives
from
the
great
city
,
and
,
as
they
approached
Hounslow
,
learned
from
other
wayfarers
that
a
band
of
highwaymen
,
by
whom
the
heath
was
infested
,
had
become
more
than
usually
daring
since
the
outbreak
of
the
pestilence
,
and
claimed
a
heavy
tax
from
all
travellers
.
<EOS>
This
was
bad
news
to
Leonard
,
who
became
apprehensive
for
the
safety
of
the
bag
of
gold
given
to
Nizza
by
the
enthusiast
,
and
he
would
have
taken
another
road
if
it
had
been
practicable
;
but
as
there
was
no
alternative
except
to
proceed
,
he
put
all
the
money
he
had
about
him
into
a
leathern
purse
,
trusting
that
the
highwaymen
,
if
they
attacked
them
,
would
be
content
with
this
booty
.
 
<EOS>
When
about
halfway
across
the
vast
heath
,
which
spread
around
them
,
in
a
wild
but
not
unpicturesque
expanse
,
for
many
miles
on
either
side
,
Leonard
perceived
a
band
of
horsemen
,
amounting
perhaps
to
a
dozen
,
galloping
towards
them
,
and
,
not
doubting
they
were
the
robbers
in
question
,
communicated
his
suspicions
to
his
companions
.
<EOS>
Neither
Amabel
nor
Nizza
Macascree
appeared
much
alarmed
,
but
Blaize
was
so
terrified
that
he
could
scarcely
keep
his
seat
,
and
was
with
difficulty
prevented
from
turning
his
horse
's
head
and
riding
off
in
the
opposite
direction
.
 
<EOS>
By
this
time
the
highwaymen
had
come
up
.
<EOS>
With
loud
oaths
,
two
of
their
number
held
pistols
to
the
heads
of
Leonard
and
Blaize
,
and
demanded
their
money
.
<EOS>
The
apprentice
replied
by
drawing
forth
his
purse
,
and
besought
the
fellow
to
whom
he
gave
it
not
to
maltreat
his
companion
.
<EOS>
The
man
rejoined
with
a
savage
imprecation
that
he
"
would
maltreat
them
both
if
they
did
not
instantly
dismount
and
let
him
search
the
saddle
-
bags
;
"
and
he
was
proceeding
to
drag
Amabel
from
the
saddle
,
when
Leonard
struck
him
a
violent
blow
with
his
heavy
riding
-
whip
,
which
brought
him
to
the
ground
.
<EOS>
He
was
up
again
,
however
,
in
an
instant
,
and
would
have
fired
his
pistol
at
the
apprentice
,
if
a
masked
individual
,
who
was
evidently
,
from
the
richness
of
his
attire
,
and
the
deference
paid
him
by
the
others
,
the
captain
of
the
band
,
had
not
interfered
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
are
rightly
served
,
Dick
Dosset
,
"
said
this
person
,
"
for
your
rudeness
to
a
lady
.
<EOS>
I
will
have
none
of
my
band
guilty
of
incivility
,
and
if
this
young
man
had
not
punished
you
,
I
would
have
done
so
myself
.
<EOS>
Pass
free
,
my
pretty
damsel
,
"
he
added
,
bowing
gallantly
to
Amabel
;
"
you
shall
not
be
further
molested
.
"
 
<EOS>
Meanwhile
,
Blaize
exhibited
the
contents
of
his
pockets
to
the
other
highwayman
,
who
having
opened
the
box
of
rufuses
and
smelt
at
the
phial
of
plague
-
water
,
returned
them
to
him
with
a
look
of
disgust
,
and
bade
him
follow
his
companions
.
<EOS>
As
Leonard
was
departing
,
the
captain
of
the
band
rode
after
him
,
and
inquired
whether
he
had
heard
at
what
hour
the
king
meant
to
leave
Whitehall
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
court
is
about
to
adjourn
to
Oxford
,
"
he
added
,
"
and
the
king
and
some
of
his
courtiers
will
cross
the
heath
to
-
day
,
when
I
purpose
to
levy
the
same
tax
from
his
majesty
that
I
do
from
his
subjects
.
"
 
<EOS>
