Leonard
replied
,
that
he
was
utterly
ignorant
of
the
king
's
movements
;
and
explaining
whence
he
came
,
the
captain
left
him
.
<EOS>
The
intelligence
he
had
thus
accidentally
obtained
was
far
from
satisfactory
to
the
apprentice
.
<EOS>
For
some
distance
,
their
road
would
be
the
same
as
that
about
to
be
taken
by
the
monarch
and
his
attendants
,
amongst
whom
it
was
not
improbable
Rochester
might
be
numbered
;
and
the
possibility
that
the
earl
might
overtake
them
and
discover
Amabel
filled
him
with
uneasiness
.
<EOS>
Concealing
his
alarm
,
however
,
he
urged
his
steed
to
a
quicker
pace
,
and
proceeded
briskly
on
his
way
,
glad
,
at
least
,
that
he
had
not
lost
Solomon
Eagle
's
gift
to
Nizza
.
<EOS>
Amabel
's
weakly
condition
compelled
them
to
rest
at
frequent
intervals
,
and
it
was
not
until
evening
was
drawing
in
that
they
descended
the
steep
hill
leading
to
the
beautiful
village
of
Henley
-
upon
-
Thames
,
where
they
proposed
to
halt
for
the
night
.
 
<EOS>
Crossing
the
bridge
,
they
found
a
considerable
number
of
the
inhabitants
assembled
in
the
main
street
and
in
the
market
-
place
,
in
expectation
of
the
king
's
passing
through
the
town
on
his
way
to
Oxford
,
intimation
of
his
approach
having
been
conveyed
by
avant
-
couriers
.
<EOS>
Leonard
proceeded
to
the
principal
inn
,
and
was
fortunate
enough
to
procure
accommodation
.
<EOS>
Having
conducted
Amabel
and
Nizza
to
their
room
,
he
was
repairing
to
the
stable
with
Blaize
to
see
after
their
steeds
,
when
a
loud
blowing
of
horns
was
heard
on
the
bridge
,
succeeded
by
the
tramp
of
horses
and
the
rattling
of
wheels
,
and
the
next
moment
four
valets
in
splendid
livery
rode
up
,
followed
by
a
magnificent
coach
.
<EOS>
The
shouts
of
the
assemblage
proclaimed
that
it
was
the
king
.
<EOS>
The
cavalcade
stopped
before
the
inn
,
from
the
yard
of
which
six
fine
horses
were
brought
and
attached
to
the
royal
carriage
,
in
place
of
others
which
were
removed
.
<EOS>
Charles
was
laughing
heartily
,
and
desired
his
attendants
,
who
were
neither
numerous
nor
well
-
armed
,
to
take
care
they
were
not
robbed
again
between
this
place
and
Oxford
;
"
Though
,
"
added
the
monarch
,
"
it
is
now
of
little
consequence
,
since
we
have
nothing
to
lose
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Is
it
possible
your
majesty
can
have
been
robbed
?
"
asked
the
landlord
,
who
stood
cap
in
hand
at
the
door
of
the
carriage
.
 
<EOS>
"
I'faith
,
man
,
it
_
is
_
possible
,
"
rejoined
the
king
.
<EOS>
"
We
were
stopped
on
Hounslow
Heath
by
a
band
of
highwaymen
,
who
carried
off
two
large
coffers
filled
with
gold
,
and
would
have
eased
us
of
our
swords
and
snuff
-
boxes
but
for
the
interposition
of
their
captain
,
who
,
as
we
live
,
is
one
of
the
politest
men
breathing
--
is
he
not
,
Rochester
?
"
 
<EOS>
Leonard
Holt
,
who
was
among
the
crowd
of
spectators
,
started
at
the
mention
of
this
name
,
and
he
trembled
as
the
earl
leaned
forward
in
answer
to
the
king
's
question
.
<EOS>
The
eyes
of
the
rivals
met
at
this
moment
,
for
both
were
within
a
few
yards
of
each
other
,
and
Rochester
,
whose
cheek
was
flushed
with
anger
,
solicited
the
king
's
permission
to
alight
,
but
Charles
,
affirming
it
was
getting
late
,
would
not
permit
him
,
and
as
the
horses
were
harnessed
,
and
the
drivers
mounted
,
he
ordered
them
to
proceed
without
delay
.
 
<EOS>
Inexpressibly
relieved
by
his
rival
's
departure
,
Leonard
returned
to
the
house
,
and
acquainted
Amabel
with
what
had
occurred
.
<EOS>
Quitting
Henley
betimes
on
the
following
morning
<EOS>
,
they
arrived
in
about
three
hours
at
Wallingford
,
where
they
halted
for
some
time
,
and
,
then
pursuing
their
journey
,
reached
Wantage
at
four
o'clock
,
where
they
tarried
for
an
hour
.
<EOS>
Up
to
this
hour
,
Leonard
had
doubted
the
possibility
of
reaching
their
destination
that
night
;
but
Amabel
assuring
him
<EOS>
she
felt
no
fatigue
,
he
determined
to
push
on
.
<EOS>
Accordingly
,
having
refreshed
their
steeds
,
they
set
forward
,
and
soon
began
to
mount
the
beautiful
downs
lying
on
the
west
of
this
ancient
town
.
 
<EOS>
Crossing
these
heights
,
whence
they
obtained
the
most
magnificent
and
extensive
views
of
the
surrounding
country
,
they
reached
in
about
three
-
quarters
of
an
hour
the
pretty
little
hamlet
of
Kingston
Lisle
.
<EOS>
Here
they
again
paused
at
a
small
inn
at
the
foot
of
a
lofty
hill
,
denominated
,
from
a
curious
relic
kept
there
,
the
Blowing
Stone
.
<EOS>
This
rocky
fragment
,
which
is
still
in
existence
,
is
perforated
by
a
number
of
holes
,
which
emit
,
if
blown
into
,
a
strange
bellowing
sound
.
<EOS>
Unaware
of
this
circumstance
,
Leonard
entered
the
house
with
the
others
,
and
had
just
seated
,
himself
,
when
they
were
,
astounded
by
a
strange
unearthly
roar
.
<EOS>
Rushing
forth
,
Leonard
found
Blaize
with
his
cheeks
puffed
out
and
his
mouth
applied
to
the
stone
,
into
which
he
was
blowing
with
all
his
force
,
and
producing
the
above
-
mentioned
extraordinary
noise
.
 
<EOS>
Shortly
after
this
,
the
party
quitted
the
Blowing
Stone
,
and
having
toiled
up
the
steep
sides
of
the
hill
,
they
were
amply
repaid
on
reaching
its
summit
by
one
of
the
finest
views
they
had
ever
beheld
.
<EOS>
In
fact
,
the
hill
on
which
they
stood
commanded
the
whole
of
the
extensive
and
beautiful
vale
of
the
White
Horse
,
which
was
spread
out
before
them
as
far
as
the
eye
could
reach
,
like
a
vast
panorama
,
disclosing
a
thousand
fields
covered
with
abundant
,
though
as
yet
immature
crops
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
goodly
prospect
,
and
seemed
to
promise
plenty
and
prosperity
to
the
country
.
<EOS>
Almost
beneath
them
stood
the
reverend
church
of
Uffington
overtopping
the
ancient
village
clustering
round
it
.
<EOS>
Numerous
other
towers
and
spires
could
be
seen
peeping
out
of
groves
of
trees
,
which
,
together
with
the
scattered
mansions
and
farmhouses
surrounded
by
granges
and
stacks
of
hay
and
beans
,
gave
interest
and
diversity
to
the
prospect
.
<EOS>
The
two
most
prominent
objects
in
the
view
were
the
wooded
heights
of
Farringdon
on
the
one
hand
,
and
those
of
Abingdon
on
the
other
.
 
<EOS>
Proceeding
along
the
old
Roman
road
,
still
distinctly
marked
out
,
and
running
along
the
ridge
of
this
beautiful
chain
of
hills
,
they
arrived
at
an
immense
Roman
encampment
,
vulgarly
called
Uffingham
Castle
,
occupying
the
crown
of
a
hill
.
<EOS>
A
shepherd
,
who
was
tending
a
flock
of
sheep
which
were
browsing
on
the
delicious
herbage
to
be
found
within
the
vast
circular
space
enclosed
by
the
inner
vallum
of
the
camp
,
explained
its
purpose
,
and
they
could
not
but
regard
it
with
interest
.
<EOS>
He
informed
them
that
they
were
in
the
neighbourhood
of
the
famous
White
Horse
,
a
figure
cut
out
of
the
turf
on
the
hillside
by
the
Saxons
,
and
visible
for
many
miles
.
<EOS>
Conducting
them
to
a
point
whence
they
could
survey
this
curious
work
,
their
guide
next
directed
them
to
Ashdown
Lodge
,
which
lay
,
he
told
them
,
at
about
four
miles
'
distance
.
<EOS>
They
had
wandered
a
little
out
of
their
course
,
but
he
accompanied
them
for
a
mile
,
until
they
came
in
sight
of
a
thick
grove
of
trees
clothing
a
beautiful
valley
,
above
which
could
be
seen
the
lofty
cupola
of
the
mansion
.
 
<EOS>
Cheered
by
the
sight
,
and
invigorated
by
the
fresh
breeze
blowing
in
this
healthful
region
,
they
pressed
forward
,
and
soon
drew
near
the
mansion
,
which
they
found
was
approached
by
four
noble
avenues
.
<EOS>
They
had
not
advanced
far
,
when
a
stalwart
personage
,
six
feet
two
high
,
and
proportionately
stoutly
made
,
issued
from
the
covert
.
<EOS>
He
had
a
gun
over
his
shoulder
and
was
attended
by
a
couple
of
fine
dogs
.
<EOS>
Telling
them
he
was
called
John
Lutcombe
,
and
was
the
Earl
of
Craven
's
gamekeeper
,
he
inquired
their
business
,
and
,
on
being
informed
of
it
,
changed
his
surly
manner
to
one
of
great
cordiality
,
and
informed
them
that
Mrs.
Buscot
--
such
was
the
name
of
Amabel
's
aunt
--
was
at
home
,
and
would
be
heartily
glad
to
see
them
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
often
heard
her
speak
of
her
brother
,
Mr.
Bloundel
,
"
he
said
,
"
and
am
well
aware
that
he
is
an
excellent
man
.
<EOS>
Poor
soul
!
<EOS>
she
has
been
very
uneasy
about
him
and
his
family
during
this
awful
dispensation
,
though
she
had
received
a
letter
to
say
that
he
was
about
to
close
his
house
,
and
hoped
,
under
the
blessing
of
Providence
,
to
escape
the
pestilence
.
<EOS>
His
daughter
will
be
welcome
,
and
she
can
not
come
to
a
healthier
spot
than
Ashdown
,
nor
to
a
better
nurse
than
Mrs.
Buscot
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
With
this
,
he
led
the
way
to
the
court
-
yard
,
and
,
entering
the
dwelling
,
presently
returned
with
a
middle
-
aged
woman
,
who
Amabel
instantly
knew
,
from
the
likeness
to
her
father
,
must
be
her
aunt
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Buscot
caught
her
in
her
arms
,
and
almost
smothered
her
with
kisses
.
<EOS>
As
soon
as
the
first
transports
of
surprise
and
joy
had
subsided
,
the
good
housekeeper
took
her
niece
and
Nizza
Macascree
into
the
house
,
and
desired
John
Lutcombe
to
attend
to
the
others
.
  
<EOS>
VIII
.
 
<EOS>
ASHDOWN
LODGE
.
 
<EOS>
Erected
by
Inigo
Jones
,
and
still
continuing
in
precisely
the
same
state
as
at
the
period
of
this
history
,
Ashdown
Lodge
is
a
large
square
edifice
,
built
in
the
formal
French
taste
of
the
seventeenth
century
,
with
immense
casements
,
giving
it
the
appearance
of
being
all
glass
,
a
high
roof
lighted
by
dormer
windows
,
terminated
at
each
angle
by
a
tall
and
not
very
ornamental
chimney
,
and
surmounted
by
a
lofty
and
lantern
-
like
belvedere
,
crowned
in
its
turn
by
a
glass
cupola
.
<EOS>
The
belvedere
opens
upon
a
square
gallery
defended
by
a
broad
balustrade
,
and
overlooking
the
umbrageous
masses
and
lovely
hills
around
it
.
<EOS>
The
house
,
as
has
been
stated
,
is
approached
by
four
noble
avenues
,
the
timber
constituting
which
,
is
,
of
course
,
much
finer
now
than
at
the
period
under
consideration
,
and
possesses
a
delightful
old
-
fashioned
garden
,
and
stately
terrace
.
<EOS>
The
rooms
are
lofty
but
small
,
and
there
is
a
magnificent
staircase
,
occupying
nearly
half
the
interior
of
the
building
.
<EOS>
Among
other
portraits
decorating
the
walls
,
is
one
of
Elizabeth
Stuart
,
daughter
of
James
the
First
,
and
Queen
of
Bohemia
,
for
whom
the
first
Earl
of
Craven
entertained
so
romantic
an
attachment
,
and
to
whom
he
was
supposed
to
be
privately
united
.
<EOS>
Nothing
can
be
more
secluded
than
the
situation
of
the
mansion
,
lying
as
it
does
in
the
midst
of
a
gentle
valley
,
surrounded
by
a
thick
wood
,
and
without
having
a
single
habitation
in
view
.
<EOS>
Its
chief
interest
,
however
,
must
always
be
derived
from
its
connection
with
the
memory
of
the
chivalrous
and
high
-
souled
nobleman
by
whom
it
was
erected
,
and
who
made
it
occasionally
his
retreat
after
the
death
of
his
presumed
royal
consort
,
which
occurred
about
four
years
previous
to
the
date
of
this
history
.
 
<EOS>
Amabel
was
delighted
with
her
new
abode
,
and
she
experienced
the
kindness
of
a
parent
from
her
aunt
,
with
whom
,
owing
to
circumstances
,
she
had
not
hitherto
been
personally
acquainted
,
having
only
seen
her
when
too
young
to
retain
any
recollection
of
the
event
.
<EOS>
The
widow
of
a
farmer
,
who
had
resided
on
Lord
Craven
's
estate
near
Kingston
Lisle
,
Mrs.
Buscot
,
after
her
husband
's
death
,
had
been
engaged
as
housekeeper
at
Ashdown
Lodge
,
and
had
filled
the
situation
for
many
years
to
the
entire
satisfaction
of
her
employer
.
<EOS>
She
was
two
or
three
years
older
than
her
brother
,
Mr.
Bloundel
;
but
the
perfect
health
she
enjoyed
,
and
which
she
attributed
to
the
salubrious
air
of
the
downs
,
combined
with
her
natural
cheerfulness
of
disposition
,
made
her
look
much
the
younger
of
the
two
.
<EOS>
Her
features
,
besides
their
kindly
and
benevolent
expression
,
were
extremely
pleasing
,
and
must
,
some
years
ago
,
have
been
beautiful
.
<EOS>
Even
now
,
what
with
her
fresh
complexion
,
her
white
teeth
,
and
plump
figure
,
she
made
no
slight
pretensions
to
comeliness
.
<EOS>
She
possessed
the
same
good
sense
and
integrity
of
character
as
her
brother
,
together
with
his
strong
religious
feeling
,
but
entirely
unaccompanied
by
austerity
.
 
<EOS>
Having
no
children
,
she
was
able
to
bestow
her
entire
affections
upon
Amabel
,
whose
sad
story
,
when
she
became
acquainted
with
it
,
painfully
affected
her
;
nor
was
she
less
concerned
at
her
precarious
state
of
health
.
<EOS>
For
the
first
day
or
two
after
their
arrival
,
Amabel
suffered
greatly
from
the
effects
of
the
journey
;
but
after
that
time
,
she
gained
strength
so
rapidly
,
that
Mrs.
Buscot
,
who
at
first
had
well
-
nigh
despaired
of
her
recovery
,
began
to
indulge
a
hope
.
<EOS>
The
gentle
sufferer
would
sit
throughout
the
day
with
her
aunt
and
Nizza
Macascree
in
the
gallery
near
the
belvedere
,
inhaling
the
pure
breeze
blowing
from
the
surrounding
hills
,
and
stirring
the
tree
-
tops
beneath
her
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
never
expected
so
much
happiness
,
"
she
observed
,
on
one
occasion
,
to
Mrs.
Buscot
,
"
and
begin
to
experience
the
truth
of
Doctor
Hodges
'
assertion
,
that
with
returning
health
,
the
desire
of
life
would
return
.
<EOS>
I
now
wish
to
live
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
heartily
glad
to
hear
you
say
so
,
"
replied
Mrs.
Buscot
,
"
and
hold
it
a
certain
sign
of
your
speedy
restoration
to
health
.
<EOS>
Before
you
have
been
a
month
with
me
,
I
expect
to
bring
back
the
roses
to
those
pale
cheeks
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
are
too
sanguine
<EOS>
,
I
fear
,
dear
aunt
,
"
rejoined
Amabel
,
"
but
the
change
that
has
taken
place
in
my
feelings
,
may
operate
beneficially
upon
my
constitution
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
No
doubt
of
it
,
my
dear
,
"
replied
Mrs.
Buscot
;
"
no
doubt
.
"
 
<EOS>
The
good
dame
felt
a
strong
inclination
at
this
moment
to
introduce
a
subject
very
near
her
heart
,
but
,
feeling
doubtful
as
to
its
reception
,
she
checked
herself
.
<EOS>
The
devoted
attachment
of
the
apprentice
to
her
niece
had
entirely
won
her
regard
,
and
she
fondly
hoped
she
would
be
able
to
wean
Amabel
from
all
thought
of
the
Earl
of
Rochester
,
and
induce
her
to
give
her
hand
to
her
faithful
lover
.
<EOS>
With
this
view
,
she
often
spoke
to
her
of
Leonard
--
of
his
devotion
and
constancy
,
his
good
looks
and
excellent
qualities
;
and
though
Amabel
assented
to
all
she
said
,
Mrs.
Buscot
was
sorry
to
perceive
that
the
impression
she
desired
was
not
produced
.
<EOS>
It
was
not
so
with
Nizza
Macascree
.
<EOS>
Whenever
Leonard
's
name
was
mentioned
,
her
eyes
sparkled
,
her
cheek
glowed
,
and
she
responded
so
warmly
to
all
that
was
said
in
his
praise
,
that
Mrs.
Buscot
soon
found
out
the
state
of
her
heart
.
<EOS>
The
discovery
occasioned
her
some
little
disquietude
,
for
the
worthy
creature
could
not
bear
the
idea
of
making
even
her
niece
happy
at
the
expense
of
another
.
 
<EOS>
As
to
the
object
of
all
this
tender
interest
,
he
felt
far
happier
than
he
had
done
for
some
time
.
<EOS>
He
saw
Amabel
every
day
,
and
noted
with
unspeakable
delight
the
gradual
improvement
which
appeared
to
be
taking
place
in
her
health
.
<EOS>
The
greater
part
of
his
time
,
however
,
was
not
passed
in
her
society
,
but
in
threading
the
intricacies
of
the
wood
,
or
in
rambling
over
the
neighbouring
downs
;
and
he
not
only
derived
pleasure
from
these
rambles
,
but
his
health
and
spirits
,
which
had
been
not
a
little
shaken
by
the
awful
scenes
he
had
recently
witnessed
,
were
materially
improved
.
<EOS>
Here
,
at
last
,
he
seemed
to
have
got
rid
of
the
grim
spectre
which
,
for
two
months
,
had
constantly
haunted
him
.
<EOS>
No
greater
contrast
can
be
conceived
than
his
present
quiet
life
offered
to
the
fearful
excitement
he
had
recently
undergone
.
<EOS>
For
hot
and
narrow
thoroughfares
reeking
with
pestilential
effluvia
,
resounding
with
frightful
shrieks
,
or
piteous
cries
,
and
bearing
on
every
side
marks
of
the
destructive
progress
of
the
scourge
--
for
these
terrible
sights
and
sounds
--
for
the
charnel
horrors
of
the
plague
-
pit
--
the
scarcely
less
revolting
scenes
at
the
pest
-
house
--
<EOS>
the
dismal
bell
announcing
the
dead
-
cart
--
the
doleful
cries
of
the
buriers
--
for
graves
surfeited
with
corruption
,
and
streets
filled
with
the
dying
and
the
dead
--
and
,
above
all
,
for
the
ever
-
haunting
expectation
that
a
like
fate
might
be
his
own,--he
had
exchanged
green
hills
,
fresh
breezes
,
spreading
views
,
the
song
of
the
lark
,
and
a
thousand
other
delights
,
and
assurances
of
health
and
contentment
.
<EOS>
Often
,
as
he
gazed
from
the
ridge
of
the
downs
into
the
wide
-
spread
vale
beneath
,
he
wondered
whether
the
destroying
angel
had
smitten
any
of
its
peaceful
habitations
,
and
breathed
a
prayer
for
their
preservation
!
 
<EOS>
But
the
satisfaction
he
derived
from
having
quitted
the
infected
city
was
trifling
compared
with
that
of
Blaize
,
whose
sole
anxiety
was
lest
he
should
be
sent
back
to
London
.
<EOS>
Seldom
straying
further
than
the
gates
of
the
mansion
,
though
often
invited
by
John
Lutcombe
to
accompany
him
to
some
of
the
neighbouring
villages
;
having
little
to
do
,
and
less
to
think
of
,
unless
to
calculate
how
much
he
could
consume
at
the
next
<EOS>
meal,--for
he
had
banished
all
idea
of
the
plague,--he
conceived
himself
at
the
summit
of
happiness
,
and
waxed
so
sleek
and
round
,
that
his
face
shone
like
a
full
moon
,
while
his
doublet
would
scarcely
meet
around
his
waist
.
 
<EOS>
One
day
,
about
a
fortnight
after
their
arrival
,
and
when
things
were
in
this
happy
state
,
Amabel
,
who
was
seated
as
usual
in
the
gallery
at
the
summit
of
the
house
,
observed
a
troop
of
horsemen
,
very
gallantly
equipped
,
appear
at
the
further
end
of
the
northern
avenue
.
<EOS>
An
inexpressible
terror
seized
her
,
and
she
would
have
fled
into
the
house
,
but
her
limbs
refused
their
office
.
 
<EOS>
"
Look
there
!
"
<EOS>
she
cried
to
Nizza
,
who
,
at
that
moment
,
presented
herself
at
the
glass
door
.
"
<EOS>
Look
there
!
"
<EOS>
she
said
,
pointing
to
the
cavalcade
;
"
what
I
dreaded
has
come
to
pass
.
<EOS>
The
Earl
of
Rochester
has
found
me
out
,
and
is
coming
hither
to
carry
me
off
.
<EOS>
But
I
will
die
rather
than
accompany
him
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
may
be
mistaken
,
"
replied
Nizza
,
expressing
a
hopefulness
,
which
her
looks
belied
;
"
it
may
be
the
Earl
of
Craven
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
give
me
new
life
,
"
rejoined
Amabel
;
"
but
no
--
no
--
my
aunt
has
told
me
that
the
good
earl
will
not
quit
the
city
during
the
continuance
of
the
plague
.
<EOS>
And
see
!
<EOS>
some
of
the
horsemen
have
distinguished
us
,
and
are
waving
their
hats
.
<EOS>
My
heart
tells
me
the
Earl
of
Rochester
is
amongst
them
.
<EOS>
Give
me
your
arm
,
Nizza
,
and
I
will
try
to
gain
some
place
of
concealment
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Ay
,
let
us
fly
,
"
replied
the
other
,
assisting
her
towards
the
door
;
"
I
am
in
equal
danger
with
yourself
,
for
Sir
Paul
Parravicin
is
doubtless
with
them
.
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
where
--
where
is
Leonard
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
He
must
be
below
,
"
cried
Amabel
"
<EOS>
But
he
could
not
aid
us
at
this
juncture
;
we
must
depend
upon
ourselves
.
"
 
<EOS>
Descending
a
short
staircase
,
they
entered
Amabel
's
chamber
,
and
fastening
the
door
,
awaited
with
breathless
anxiety
the
arrival
of
the
horsemen
.
<EOS>
Though
the
room
whither
they
had
retreated
was
in
the
upper
part
of
the
house
,
they
could
distinctly
hear
what
was
going
on
below
,
and
shortly
afterwards
the
sound
of
footsteps
on
the
stairs
,
blended
with
merry
voices
and
loud
laughter
--
<EOS>
amid
which
,
Amabel
could
distinguish
the
tones
of
the
Earl
of
Rochester
--
reached
them
.
 
<EOS>
While
both
were
palpitating
with
fright
,
the
handle
of
the
door
was
tried
,
and
a
voice
announced
that
the
apprentice
was
without
.
 
<EOS>
"
All
is
lost
!
"
<EOS>
he
cried
,
speaking
through
the
keyhole
;
"
the
king
is
here
,
and
is
accompanied
by
the
Earl
of
Rochester
and
other
profligates
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
The
king
!
"
exclaimed
Amabel
,
joyfully
;
"
then
I
am
no
longer
apprehensive
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
As
yet
,
no
inquiries
have
been
made
after
you
,
"
continued
Leonard
,
unconscious
of
the
effect
produced
by
his
intelligence
,
"
but
it
is
evident
<EOS>
they
know
you
are
here
.
<EOS>
Be
prepared
,
therefore
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
_
am
_
prepared
,
"
rejoined
Amabel
.
<EOS>
And
as
she
spoke
,
she
threw
open
the
door
and
admitted
Leonard
.
<EOS>
"
Do
not
stay
with
us
,
"
she
added
to
him
.
"
<EOS>
In
case
of
need
,
I
will
throw
myself
on
his
majesty
's
protection
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
will
avail
you
little
,
"
rejoined
Leonard
,
distrustfully
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
do
not
think
so
,
"
said
Amabel
,
confidently
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
faith
in
his
acknowledged
kindness
of
heart
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
you
are
right
,
"
returned
Leonard
.
"
<EOS>
Mrs.
Buscot
is
at
present
with
his
majesty
in
the
receiving
-
room
.
<EOS>
Will
you
not
make
fast
your
door
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
replied
Amabel
,
firmly
;
"
if
the
king
will
not
defend
me
,
I
will
defend
myself
.
"
 
<EOS>
Leonard
glanced
at
her
with
admiration
,
but
he
said
nothing
.
 
<EOS>
"
Is
Sir
Paul
Parravicin
here
?
"
asked
Nizza
Macascree
,
with
great
anxiety
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
not
seen
him
,
"
replied
Leonard
;
"
and
I
have
carefully
examined
the
countenances
of
all
the
king
's
attendants
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Heaven
be
praised
!
"
exclaimed
Nizza
.
 
<EOS>
At
this
juncture
,
Mrs.
Buscot
entered
the
room
.
<EOS>
Her
looks
bespoke
great
agitation
,
and
she
trembled
violently
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
have
no
doubt
heard
from
Leonard
that
the
king
and
his
courtiers
are
below
,
"
she
said
.
<EOS>
"
His
majesty
inquired
whether
you
were
here
,
and
I
did
not
dare
to
deceive
him
.
<EOS>
He
desires
to
see
you
,
and
has
sent
me
for
you
.
<EOS>
What
is
to
be
done
?
"
<EOS>
she
added
,
with
a
look
of
distraction
.
<EOS>
"
I
suppose
you
must
obey
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
There
is
no
alternative
,
"
replied
Amabel
;
"
I
will
obey
his
majesty
's
commands
as
soon
as
I
can
collect
myself
.
<EOS>
Take
back
that
answer
,
dear
aunt
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Has
Leonard
told
you
that
the
Earl
of
Rochester
is
here
?
"
pursued
Mrs.
Buscot
.
 
<EOS>
Amabel
replied
in
the
affirmative
.
 
<EOS>
"
God
grant
that
good
may
come
of
it
!
"
cried
Mrs.
Buscot
,
clasping
her
hands
together
,
as
she
quitted
the
room
;
"
but
I
am
sorely
afraid
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
A
half
-
suppressed
groan
from
the
apprentice
told
that
he
shared
in
her
apprehensions
.
 
<EOS>
"
Leave
us
,
Leonard
,
"
said
Amabel
;
"
I
would
prepare
myself
for
the
interview
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
The
apprentice
obeyed
,
and
closing
the
door
after
him
,
stationed
himself
at
the
foot
of
the
staircase
.
<EOS>
Left
alone
with
Nizza
,
Amabel
threw
herself
on
her
knees
,
and
besought
the
support
of
Heaven
on
this
trying
occasion
.
<EOS>
She
then
arose
,
and
giving
her
hand
to
Nizza
,
they
went
down
stairs
together
.
<EOS>
Leonard
followed
them
at
a
little
distance
,
and
with
a
beating
heart
.
<EOS>
Two
gentlemen
-
ushers
were
posted
,
at
the
door
of
the
chamber
occupied
by
the
king
.
<EOS>
Not
far
from
them
stood
Mrs.
Buscot
,
who
,
having
made
known
her
niece
to
the
officials
,
they
instantly
admitted
her
,
but
ordered
Nizza
to
remain
outside
.
 
<EOS>
On
entering
the
room
,
Amabel
at
once
discovered
the
king
.
<EOS>
He
was
habited
in
a
magnificent
riding
-
dress
and
was
seated
on
a
rich
fauteuil
,
around
which
were
grouped
a
dozen
gaily
-
attired
courtiers
.
<EOS>
Amongst
these
were
the
Earl
of
Rochester
and
Sir
George
Etherege
.
<EOS>
As
Amabel
advanced
,
glances
of
insolent
curiosity
were
directed
towards
her
,
and
Rochester
,
stepping
forward
,
offered
to
lead
her
to
the
king
.
<EOS>
She
,
however
,
declined
the
attention
.
<EOS>
Greatly
mortified
,
the
earl
would
have
seized
her
hand
;
but
there
was
so
much
dignity
in
her
deportment
,
so
much
coldness
in
her
looks
,
that
in
spite
of
his
effrontery
,
he
felt
abashed
.
<EOS>
Charles
smiled
at
his
favourite
's
rebuff
,
but
,
in
common
with
the
others
,
he
could
not
help
being
struck
by
Amabel
's
extraordinary
beauty
and
natural
dignity
,
and
he
observed
,
in
an
under
-
tone
,
to
Etherege
,
"
Is
it
possible
this
can
be
a
grocer
's
daughter
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
She
passes
for
such
,
my
liege
,
"
replied
Etherege
,
with
a
smile
.
<EOS>
"
But
I
can
not
swear
to
her
parentage
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Since
I
have
seen
her
,
I
do
not
wonder
at
Rochester
's
extravagant
passion
,
"
rejoined
the
monarch
.
"
<EOS>
But
,
odds
fish
!
<EOS>
she
seems
to
care
little
for
him
.
"
 
<EOS>
Having
approached
within
a
short
distance
of
the
king
,
Amabel
would
have
prostrated
herself
before
him
,
but
he
prevented
her
.
 
<EOS>
"
Nay
,
do
not
kneel
,
sweetheart
,
"
he
said
,
"
I
am
fully
satisfied
of
your
loyalty
,
and
never
exact
homage
from
one
of
your
sex
,
but
,
on
the
contrary
,
am
ever
ready
to
pay
it
.
<EOS>
I
have
heard
much
of
your
attractions
,
and
,
what
is
seldom
the
case
in
such
matters
,
find
they
have
not
been
overrated
.
<EOS>
The
brightest
of
our
court
beauties
can
not
compare
with
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
A
moment
ago
,
the
fair
Amabel
might
be
said
to
lack
bloom
,
"
observed
Etherege
;
"
but
your
majesty
's
praises
have
called
a
glowing
colour
to
her
cheek
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Would
you
deign
to
grant
me
a
moment
's
hearing
,
my
liege
?
"
said
Amabel
,
looking
steadfastly
at
the
king
.
 
<EOS>
"
Not
a
moment
's
hearing
merely
,
sweetheart
,
"
returned
Charles
;
"
but
an
hour
's
,
if
you
list
.
<EOS>
I
could
dwell
on
the
music
of
your
tones
for
ever
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
thank
your
majesty
for
your
condescension
,
"
she
replied
;
"
but
<EOS>
I
will
not
long
trespass
on
your
patience
.
<EOS>
What
I
have
to
say
concerns
the
Earl
of
Rochester
.
<EOS>
"
 
"
Stand
forward
,
my
lord
,
"
said
Charles
to
the
earl
,
"
and
let
us
hear
what
complaint
is
to
be
made
against
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
Rochester
advanced
,
and
threw
a
passionate
and
half
-
reproachful
glance
at
Amabel
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
may
be
improper
for
me
to
trouble
your
majesty
on
so
light
a
matter
,
"
said
Amabel
;
"
but
your
kindness
emboldens
me
to
speak
unreservedly
.
<EOS>
You
may
be
aware
that
this
nobleman
once
entertained
,
or
feigned
to
entertain
,
an
ardent
attachment
to
me
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
need
scarcely
assure
you
,
my
liege
,
"
interposed
Rochester
,
"
that
it
was
no
feigned
passion
.
<EOS>
And
it
is
needless
to
add
,
that
however
ardently
I
felt
towards
my
fair
accuser
then
,
my
passion
has
in
nowise
abated
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
should
wonder
if
it
had
,
"
rejoined
Charles
,
gallantly
.
<EOS>
"
I
will
not
contradict
you
,
my
lord
,
"
said
Amabel
;
"
it
_
is
<EOS>
_
possible
<EOS>
you
may
have
loved
me
,
though
I
find
it
difficult
to
reconcile
your
professions
of
regard
with
your
conduct
--
but
this
is
not
to
the
purpose
.
<EOS>
Whether
you
loved
me
or
not
,
I
loved
_
you_--deeply
and
devotedly
.
<EOS>
There
is
no
sacrifice
I
would
not
have
made
for
him
,
"
she
continued
,
turning
to
the
king
,
"
and
influenced
by
these
feelings
,
and
deluded
by
false
promises
,
I
forgot
my
duty
,
and
was
rash
enough
to
quit
my
home
with
him
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
All
this
I
have
heard
,
sweetheart
,
"
replied
Charles
.
<EOS>
"
There
is
nothing
very
remarkable
in
it
.
<EOS>
It
is
the
ordinary
course
of
such
affairs
.
<EOS>
I
am
happy
to
be
the
means
of
restoring
your
lover
to
you
,
and
,
in
fact
,
came
hither
for
that
very
purpose
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
mistake
me
,
my
liege
,
"
replied
Amabel
.
<EOS>
"
I
do
not
desire
to
have
him
restored
to
me
.
<EOS>
Fortunately
for
myself
,
I
have
succeeded
in
mastering
my
love
for
him
.
<EOS>
The
struggle
has
well
-
nigh
cost
me
my
life
--
<EOS>
but
I
_
have
_
conquered
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
yet
to
learn
,
sweetheart
,
"
observed
Charles
,
with
an
incredulous
look
,
"
that
woman
's
love
,
if
deeply
fixed
,
_
can
_
be
subdued
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
If
I
had
not
been
supported
by
religion
,
my
liege
,
I
could
_
not
_
have
subdued
it
,
"
rejoined
Amabel
"
Night
and
day
,
I
have
passed
in
supplicating
the
Great
Power
that
implanted
this
fatal
passion
in
my
breast
,
and
,
at
length
,
my
prayers
have
prevailed
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Aha
!
<EOS>
we
have
a
devotee
here
!
"
thought
Charles
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Am
I
to
understand
,
fair
saint
,
that
you
would
reject
the
earl
,
if
he
were
to
offer
you
his
hand
?
<EOS>
"
he
asked
.
 
<EOS>
"
Unquestionably
,
"
replied
Amabel
,
firmly
.
 
<EOS>
"
This
is
strange
,
"
muttered
Charles
.
<EOS>
"
The
girl
is
evidently
in
earnest
.
<EOS>
What
says
your
lordship
?
<EOS>
"
he
added
to
Rochester
.
 
<EOS>
"
That
she
shall
be
mine
,
whether
she
loves
me
or
not
,
"
replied
the
earl
.
<EOS>
"
My
pride
is
piqued
to
the
conquest
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
No
wonder!--the
resistless
Rochester
flouted
by
a
grocer
's
daughter
.
<EOS>
Ha
!
ha
!
"
observed
Charles
,
laughing
,
while
the
rest
of
the
courtiers
joined
in
his
merriment
.
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
!
sire
,
"
exclaimed
Amabel
,
throwing
herself
at
the
king
's
feet
,
and
bursting
into
tears
,
"
do
not
abandon
me
,
I
beseech
you
.
<EOS>
I
can
not
requite
the
earl
's
attachment
--
and
shall
die
if
he
continues
his
pursuit
.
<EOS>
Command
him
--
<EOS>
oh
!
command
him
to
desist
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
fear
you
have
not
dealt
fairly
with
me
,
sweetheart
,
"
said
the
king
.
<EOS>
"
There
is
a
well
-
favoured
youth
without
,
whom
the
earl
pointed
out
as
your
father
's
apprentice
.
<EOS>
Have
you
transferred
your
affections
to
him
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Your
majesty
has
solved
the
enigma
,
"
observed
Rochester
,
bitterly
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
wrong
me
,
my
lord
,
"
replied
Amabel
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Leonard
Holt
is
without
.
<EOS>
Let
him
be
brought
into
the
royal
presence
and
interrogated
;
and
if
he
will
affirm
that
I
have
given
him
the
slightest
encouragement
by
look
or
word
,
or
even
state
that
he
himself
indulges
a
hope
of
holding
a
place
in
my
regards
,
I
will
admit
there
is
some
foundation
for
the
charge
.
<EOS>
I
pray
your
majesty
to
send
for
him
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
needless
,
"
replied
Charles
,
coldly
.
<EOS>
"
I
do
not
doubt
your
assertion
.
<EOS>
But
you
will
do
the
earl
an
injustice
as
well
as
yourself
,
if
you
do
not
allow
him
a
fair
hearing
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
If
you
will
allow
me
five
minutes
alone
with
you
,
Amabel
,
or
will
take
a
single
turn
with
me
on
the
terrace
,
I
will
engage
to
remove
every
doubt
,
"
insinuated
Rochester
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
would
fail
to
do
so
,
my
lord
,
"
replied
Amabel
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
time
is
gone
by
when
those
accents
,
once
so
winning
in
my
ear
,
can
move
me
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
At
least
give
me
the
opportunity
,
"
implored
the
earl
.
 
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
replied
Amabel
,
decidedly
,
"
I
will
never
willingly
meet
you
more
;
for
though
I
am
firm
in
my
purpose
,
I
do
not
think
it
right
to
expose
myself
to
temptation
.
<EOS>
And
now
that
I
have
put
your
majesty
in
full
possession
of
my
sentiments
,
"
she
added
to
the
king
;
"
now
that
I
have
told
you
with
what
bitter
tears
<EOS>
I
have
striven
to
wash
out
my
error,--I
<EOS>
implore
you
to
extend
your
protecting
hand
towards
me
,
and
to
save
me
from
further
persecution
on
the
part
of
the
earl
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
shall
remain
at
this
place
to
-
night
,
"
returned
Charles
.
<EOS>
"
Take
till
to
-
morrow
to
consider
of
it
,
and
if
you
continue
in
the
same
mind
,
your
request
shall
be
granted
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
At
least
,
enjoin
the
earl
to
leave
me
unmolested
till
then
,
"
cried
Amabel
.
 
<EOS>
"
Hum
!
"
exclaimed
the
king
,
exchanging
a
look
with
Rochester
.
 
<EOS>
"
For
pity
,
sire
,
do
not
hesitate
,
"
cried
Amabel
,
in
a
tone
of
such
agony
that
the
good
-
natured
monarch
could
not
resist
it
.
 
<EOS>
"
Well
,
well
,
"
he
rejoined
;
"
it
shall
be
as
you
desire
.
<EOS>
Rochester
,
you
have
heard
our
promise
,
and
will
act
in
conformity
with
it
.
"
 
<EOS>
The
earl
bowed
carelessly
.
 
<EOS>
"
Nay
,
nay
,
my
lord
,
"
pursued
Charles
,
authoritatively
,
"
<EOS>
my
commands
_
shall
_
be
obeyed
,
and
if
you
purpose
otherwise
,
I
will
place
you
under
restraint
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Your
majesty
's
wishes
are
sufficient
restraint
,
"
rejoined
Rochester
;
"
I
am
all
obedience
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
well
,
"
replied
Charles
.
<EOS>
"
Are
you
satisfied
,
fair
damsel
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
Perfectly
,
"
replied
Amabel
.
<EOS>
And
making
a
profound
and
grateful
reverence
to
the
king
,
she
retired
.
 
<EOS>
Nizza
Macascree
met
her
at
the
door
,
and
it
was
fortunate
<EOS>
she
did
so
,
or
Amabel
,
whose
strength
began
to
fail
her
,
would
otherwise
have
fallen
.
<EOS>
While
she
was
thus
engaged
,
Charles
caught
sight
of
the
piper
's
daughter
,
and
being
greatly
struck
by
her
beauty
,
inquired
her
name
.
 
<EOS>
"
Odds
fish
!
"
<EOS>
he
exclaimed
,
when
informed
of
it
by
Rochester
,
"
a
piper
's
daughter
!
<EOS>
She
is
far
more
beautiful
than
your
mistress
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
If
I
procure
her
for
your
majesty
,
will
you
withdraw
your
interdiction
from
me
?
"
rejoined
the
earl
.
 
<EOS>
"
No
--
no
--
that
is
impossible
,
after
the
pledge
I
have
given
,
"
replied
Charles
.
<EOS>
"
But
you
must
bring
this
lovely
creature
to
me
anon
.
<EOS>
I
am
enchanted
with
her
,
and
do
not
regret
this
long
ride
,
since
it
has
brought
her
under
my
notice
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Your
majesty
's
wishes
shall
be
obeyed
,
"
said
Rochester
.
<EOS>
"
I
will
not
wait
till
to
-
morrow
for
an
interview
with
Amabel
,
"
he
added
to
himself
.
 
<EOS>
Supported
by
Nizza
Macascree
and
her
aunt
,
and
followed
by
Leonard
,
Amabel
contrived
to
reach
her
own
chamber
,
and
as
soon
as
she
was
sufficiently
recovered
from
the
agitation
she
had
experienced
,
detailed
to
them
all
that
had
passed
in
her
interview
with
the
king
.
<EOS>
While
the
party
were
consulting
together
as
to
the
course
to
be
pursued
in
this
emergency
,
the
tap
of
a
wand
was
heard
at
the
door
,
and
the
summons
being
answered
by
Mrs.
Buscot
,
she
found
one
of
the
ushers
without
,
who
informed
her
it
was
the
king
's
pleasure
that
no
one
should
leave
the
house
till
the
following
day
,
without
his
permission
.
 
<EOS>
"
To
insure
obedience
to
his
orders
,
"
continued
the
usher
,
"
his
majesty
requires
that
the
keys
of
the
stables
be
delivered
to
the
keeping
of
his
chief
page
,
Mr.
Chiffinch
,
who
has
orders
,
together
with
myself
,
to
keep
watch
during
the
night
.
"
 
<EOS>
So
saying
,
he
bowed
and
retired
,
while
Mrs.
Buscot
returned
with
this
new
and
alarming
piece
of
intelligence
to
the
others
.
 
<EOS>
"
Why
should
the
mandate
be
respected
?
"
<EOS>
cried
Leonard
,
indignantly
.
<EOS>
"
We
have
committed
no
crime
,
and
ought
not
to
be
detained
prisoners
.
<EOS>
Trust
to
me
,
and
I
will
find
some
means
of
eluding
their
vigilance
.
<EOS>
If
you
will
remain
here
to
-
morrow
,
"
he
added
to
Amabel
,
"
you
are
lost
.
<EOS>
"
 
"
Do
not
expect
any
rational
advice
from
me
,
my
dear
niece
,
"
observed
Mrs.
Buscot
,
"
for
I
am
fairly
bewildered
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Shall
I
not
forfeit
the
king
's
protection
by
disobeying
his
injunctions
?
"
replied
Amabel
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
safer
here
than
if
I
were
to
seek
a
new
asylum
,
which
would
be
speedily
discovered
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Heaven
grant
<EOS>
you
may
not
have
cause
to
repent
your
decision
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Leonard
,
despondingly
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
must
now
,
perforce
,
quit
you
,
my
dear
niece
,
"
said
Mrs.
Buscot
,
"
though
it
breaks
my
heart
to
do
so
.
<EOS>
His
majesty
's
arrival
has
thrown
everything
into
confusion
,
and
if
I
do
not
look
after
the
supper
,
which
is
commanded
at
an
early
hour
,
it
will
never
be
ready
.
<EOS>
As
it
is
,
there
will
be
nothing
fit
to
set
before
him
.
<EOS>
What
with
my
distress
about
you
,
and
my
anxiety
about
the
royal
repast
,
I
am
well
-
nigh
beside
myself
.
"
 
<EOS>
With
this
,
she
quitted
the
room
,
and
Amabel
signifying
to
Leonard
that
she
desired
to
be
left
alone
with
Nizza
Macascree
<EOS>
,
he
departed
at
the
same
time
.
 
<EOS>
As
Mrs.
Buscot
had
stated
,
the
utmost
confusion
prevailed
below
.
<EOS>
The
royal
purveyor
and
cook
,
who
formed
part
of
the
king
's
suite
,
were
busily
employed
in
the
kitchen
,
and
though
they
had
the
whole
household
at
their
command
,
they
made
rather
slow
progress
at
first
,
owing
to
the
want
of
materials
.
<EOS>
In
a
short
time
,
however
,
this
difficulty
was
remedied
.
<EOS>
Ducks
were
slaughtered
by
the
dozen
;
fowls
by
the
score
,
and
a
couple
of
fat
geese
shared
the
same
fate
.
<EOS>
The
store
ponds
were
visited
for
fish
by
John
Lutcombe
;
and
as
the
country
abounded
with
game
,
a
large
supply
of
pheasants
,
partridges
,
and
rabbits
was
speedily
procured
by
the
keeper
and
his
assistants
.
<EOS>
Amongst
others
,
Blaize
lent
a
helping
-
hand
in
this
devastation
of
the
poultry
-
yard
,
and
he
had
just
returned
to
the
kitchen
,
and
commenced
plucking
one
of
the
geese
,
when
he
was
aroused
by
a
slap
on
the
shoulder
,
and
looking
up
,
beheld
Pillichody
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
ho
!
<EOS>
my
little
Blaize
,
my
physic
-
taking
porter
,
"
cried
the
bully
;
"
how
wags
the
world
with
you
?
<EOS>
And
how
is
my
pretty
Patience
?
<EOS>
How
is
that
peerless
kitchen
-
maiden
?
<EOS>
By
the
god
of
love
!
<EOS>
I
am
dying
to
behold
her
again
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Patience
is
well
enough
,
for
aught
I
know
,
"
replied
Blaize
,
in
a
surly
tone
.
"
<EOS>
But
it
is
useless
for
you
to
think
of
her
.
<EOS>
She
is
betrothed
to
me
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
know
it
,
"
replied
Pillichody
;
"
but
do
not
suppose
you
are
the
sole
master
of
her
affections
.
<EOS>
The
little
charmer
has
too
good
taste
for
that
.
'
<EOS>
Blaize
,
'
said
she
to
me
,
'
will
do
very
well
for
a
husband
,
but
he
can
not
expect
me
to
continue
faithful
to
him
.
'
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Can
not
I
?
"
exclaimed
the
porter
reddening
.
<EOS>
"
Fiends
take
her
!
<EOS>
but
I
do
!
<EOS>
When
did
she
say
this
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
When
I
last
visited
your
master
's
house
,
"
replied
Pillichody
.
"
<EOS>
Sweet
soul
!
<EOS>
I
shall
never
forget
her
tender
looks
,
nor
the
kisses
she
allowed
me
to
snatch
from
her
honeyed
lips
when
your
back
was
turned
.
<EOS>
The
very
recollection
of
them
is
enchanting
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Zounds
and
fury
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Blaize
,
transported
with
rage
.
<EOS>
"
If
I
am
only
a
porter
,
while
you
pretend
to
be
a
major
,
I
will
let
you
see
I
am
the
better
man
of
the
two
.
"
<EOS>
And
taking
the
goose
by
the
neck
,
he
swung
it
round
his
head
like
a
flail
,
and
began
to
batter
Pillichody
about
the
face
with
it
.
 
<EOS>
"
S'death
!
"
cried
the
bully
,
endeavouring
to
draw
his
sword
,
"
if
you
do
not
instantly
desist
,
I
will
treat
you
like
that
accursed
bird
--
cut
your
throat
,
pluck
,
stuff
,
roast
,
and
eat
you
afterwards
.
"
<EOS>
He
was
,
however
,
so
confounded
by
the
attack
,
that
he
could
offer
no
resistance
,
and
in
retreating
,
caught
his
foot
against
the
leg
of
a
table
,
and
fell
backwards
on
the
floor
.
<EOS>
Being
now
completely
at
the
porter
's
mercy
,
and
seeing
that
the
latter
was
preparing
to
pursue
his
advantage
with
a
rolling
-
pin
which
he
had
snatched
from
the
dresser
,
he
besought
him
piteously
to
spare
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
Recant
all
you
have
said
,
"
cried
Blaize
,
brandishing
the
rolling
-
pin
over
him
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Confess
that
you
have
calumniated
Patience
.
<EOS>
Confess
that
she
rejected
your
advances
,
if
you
ever
dared
to
make
any
to
her
.
<EOS>
Confess
that
she
is
a
model
of
purity
and
constancy
.
<EOS>
Confess
all
this
,
villain
,
or
I
will
break
every
bone
in
your
body
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
do
confess
it
,
"
replied
Pillichody
,
abjectly
.
<EOS>
"
She
is
all
you
describe
.
<EOS>
She
never
allowed
me
greater
freedom
than
a
squeeze
of
the
hand
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
That
was
too
much
,
"
replied
the
porter
,
belabouring
him
with
the
rolling
-
pin
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Swear
that
you
will
never
attempt
such
a
liberty
again
,
or
I
will
pummel
you
to
death
.
<EOS>
Swear
it
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
swear
,
"
replied
Pillichody
.
 
<EOS>
"
Before
I
allow
you
to
rise
,
I
must
disarm
you
to
prevent
mischief
,
"
cried
Blaize
.
<EOS>
And
kneeling
down
upon
the
prostrate
bully
,
who
groaned
aloud
,
he
drew
his
long
blade
from
his
side
.
<EOS>
"
There
,
now
you
may
get
up
,
"
he
added
.
 
<EOS>
So
elated
was
Blaize
with
his
conquest
,
that
he
could
do
nothing
for
some
time
but
strut
up
and
down
the
kitchen
with
the
sword
over
his
shoulder
,
to
the
infinite
diversion
of
the
other
domestics
,
and
especially
of
John
Lutcombe
,
who
chanced
to
make
his
appearance
at
the
time
,
laden
with
a
fresh
supply
of
game
.
 
<EOS>
"
Why
,
Blaize
,
man
,
"
cried
the
keeper
,
approvingly
,
"
I
did
not
give
you
credit
for
half
so
much
spirit
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
No
man
's
courage
is
duly
appreciated
until
it
has
been
tried
,
"
rejoined
Blaize
.
<EOS>
"
I
would
combat
with
you
,
gigantic
John
,
if
Patience
's
fidelity
were
called
in
question
.
"
 
<EOS>
Pillichody
,
meanwhile
,
had
retired
with
a
discomfited
air
into
a
corner
,
where
he
seated
himself
on
a
stool
,
and
eyed
the
porter
askance
,
as
if
meditating
some
terrible
retaliation
.
<EOS>
Secretly
apprehensive
of
this
,
and
thinking
it
becoming
to
act
with
generosity
towards
his
foe
,
Blaize
marched
up
to
him
,
and
extended
his
hand
in
token
of
reconciliation
.
<EOS>
To
the
surprise
of
all
,
Pillichody
did
not
reject
his
overtures
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
a
great
regard
for
you
,
friend
Blaize
,
"
he
said
,
"
otherwise
I
should
never
rest
till
I
had
been
repaid
with
terrible
interest
for
the
indignities
I
have
endured
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Nay
,
heed
them
not
,
"
replied
Blaize
.
<EOS>
"
You
must
make
allowances
for
the
jealous
feelings
you
excited
.
<EOS>
I
love
Patience
better
than
my
life
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Since
you
put
it
in
that
light
,
"
rejoined
Pillichody
,
"
I
am
willing
to
overlook
the
offence
.
<EOS>
Snakes
and
scorpions
!
<EOS>
no
man
can
be
a
greater
martyr
to
jealousy
than
myself
.
<EOS>
I
killed
three
of
my
most
intimate
friends
for
merely
presuming
to
ogle
the
widow
of
Watling
-
street
,
who
would
have
been
mine
,
if
she
had
not
died
of
the
plague
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
talk
of
the
plague
,
I
beseech
you
,
"
replied
Blaize
,
with
a
shudder
.
<EOS>
"
It
is
a
subject
never
mentioned
here
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
sorry
I
alluded
to
it
,
then
,
"
<EOS>
rejoined
Pillichody
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Give
me
back
my
sword
.
<EOS>
Nay
,
fear
nothing
.
<EOS>
I
entirely
forgive
you
,
and
am
willing
to
drown
the
remembrance
of
our
quarrel
in
a
bottle
of
sack
.
"
 
<EOS>
Readily
assenting
to
the
proposition
,
Blaize
obtained
the
key
of
the
cellar
from
the
butler
,
and
adjourning
thither
with
Pillichody
,
they
seated
themselves
on
a
cask
with
a
bottle
of
sack
and
a
couple
of
large
glasses
on
a
stool
between
them
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
suppose
you
know
why
I
am
come
hither
?
"
observed
the
major
,
smacking
his
lips
after
his
second
bumper
.
 
<EOS>
"
Not
precisely
,
"
replied
Blaize
.
<EOS>
"
But
I
presume
your
visit
has
some
reference
to
Mistress
Amabel
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
A
shrewd
guess
,
"
rejoined
Pillichody
.
"
<EOS>
And
this
reminds
me
that
we
have
omitted
to
drink
her
health
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Her
better
health
,
"
returned
Blaize
,
emptying
his
glass
.
<EOS>
"
Heaven
be
praised
!
<EOS>
she
has
plucked
up
a
little
since
we
came
here
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
She
would
soon
be
herself
again
if
she
were
united
to
the
Earl
of
Rochester
,
"
said
Pillichody
.
 
<EOS>
"
There
you
are
wrong
,
"
replied
Blaize
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
She
declares
she
has
no
longer
any
regard
for
him
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Mere
caprice
,
believe
me
,
"
rejoined
Pillichody
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
She
loves
him
better
than
ever
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
may
be
so
,
"
returned
Blaize
;
"
for
Patience
,
who
ought
to
know
something
of
the
matter
,
assured
me
she
was
dying
for
the
earl
;
and
if
she
had
not
told
me
the
contrary
herself
,
I
should
not
have
believed
it
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Did
she
tell
you
so
in
the
presence
of
Leonard
?
"
asked
Pillichody
.
 
<EOS>
"
Why
,
now
I
bethink
me
,
he
_
was
_
present
,
"
replied
Blaize
,
involuntarily
putting
his
hand
to
his
shoulder
,
as
he
recalled
the
horsewhipping
he
had
received
on
that
occasion
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
knew
it
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Pillichody
.
<EOS>
"
She
is
afraid
to
confess
her
attachment
to
the
earl
.
<EOS>
Is
Leonard
as
much
devoted
to
her
as
ever
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
fancy
so
,
"
replied
Blaize
,
"
but
she
certainly
gives
_
him
_
no
encouragement
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Confirmation
!
"
exclaimed
Pillichody
.
"
<EOS>
But
fill
your
glass
.
<EOS>
We
will
drink
to
the
earl
's
speedy
union
with
Amabel
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Not
so
loud
,
"
cried
Blaize
,
looking
uneasily
round
the
cellar
.
<EOS>
"
I
should
not
like
Leonard
to
overhear
us
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Neither
should
I
,
"
returned
Pillichody
,
"
for
I
have
something
to
say
to
you
respecting
him
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
need
not
propose
any
more
plans
for
carrying
off
Amabel
,
"
cried
Blaize
,
"
<EOS>
for
I
wo
n't
take
any
part
in
them
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
no
such
intention
,
"
rejoined
Pillichody
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
truth
is
,
"
he
added
,
mysteriously
,
"
I
am
inclined
to
side
with
you
and
Leonard
.
<EOS>
But
as
we
have
finished
our
bottle
,
suppose
we
take
a
turn
in
the
court
-
yard
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
With
all
my
heart
,
"
replied
Blaize
.
 
<EOS>
Immediately
after
Amabel
's
departure
Charles
proceeded
with
his
courtiers
to
the
garden
,
and
continued
to
saunter
up
and
down
the
terrace
for
some
time
,
during
which
he
engaged
Rochester
in
conversation
,
so
as
to
give
him
no
pretext
for
absenting
himself
.
<EOS>
The
king
next
ascended
to
the
belvedere
,
and
having
surveyed
the
prospect
from
it
,
was
about
to
descend
when
he
caught
a
glimpse
of
Nizza
Macascree
on
the
great
staircase
,
and
instantly
flew
towards
her
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
must
have
a
word
with
you
,
sweetheart
,
"
he
cried
,
taking
her
hand
,
which
she
did
not
dare
to
withdraw
.
 
<EOS>
Ready
to
sink
with
confusion
,
Nizza
suffered
herself
to
be
led
towards
the
receiving
-
room
.
<EOS>
Motioning
to
the
courtiers
to
remain
without
,
Charles
entered
it
with
his
blushing
companion
,
and
after
putting
several
questions
to
her
,
which
she
answered
with
great
timidity
and
modesty
,
inquired
into
the
state
of
her
heart
.
 
<EOS>
"
Answer
me
frankly
,
"
he
said
.
<EOS>
"
Are
your
affections
engaged
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
Since
your
majesty
deigns
to
interest
yourself
so
much
about
me
,
"
replied
Nizza
,
"
I
will
use
no
disguise
.
<EOS>
They
are
.
"
 
"
<EOS>
To
whom
?
"
demanded
the
king
.
 
<EOS>
"
To
Leonard
Holt
,
"
was
the
answer
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
!
<EOS>
the
apprentice
who
brought
Amabel
hither
!
"
cried
the
king
.
<EOS>
"
Why
,
the
Earl
of
Rochester
seemed
to
intimate
that
he
was
in
love
with
Amabel
.
<EOS>
Is
it
so
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
can
not
deny
it
,
"
replied
Nizza
,
hanging
down
her
head
.
 
<EOS>
"
If
this
is
the
case
,
it
is
incumbent
on
me
to
provide
you
with
a
new
lover
,
"
replied
Charles
.
<EOS>
"
What
will
you
say
,
sweetheart
,
if
I
tell
you
,
you
have
made
a
royal
conquest
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
should
tremble
to
hear
it
,
"
replied
Nizza
.
<EOS>
"
But
your
majesty
is
jesting
with
me
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
On
my
soul
,
no
!
"
rejoined
the
king
,
passionately
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
never
seen
beauty
equal
to
yours
,
sweetheart
--
never
have
been
so
suddenly
,
so
completely
captivated
before
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
!
do
not
use
this
language
towards
me
,
my
liege
,
"
replied
Nizza
,
dropping
on
her
knee
before
him
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
unworthy
your
notice
.
<EOS>
My
heart
is
entirely
given
to
Leonard
Holt
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
will
speedily
forget
him
in
the
brilliant
destiny
which
awaits
you
,
child
,
"
returned
Charles
,
raising
her
.
"
<EOS>
Do
not
bestow
another
thought
on
the
senseless
dolt
who
can
prefer
Amabel
's
sickly
charms
to
your
piquant
attractions
.
<EOS>
By
Heaven
!
<EOS>
you
shall
be
mine
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Never
!
"
exclaimed
Nizza
,
extricating
herself
from
his
grasp
,
and
rushing
towards
the
door
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
fly
in
vain
,
"
cried
the
king
,
laughingly
pursuing
her
.
 
<EOS>
As
he
spoke
the
door
opened
,
and
Sir
Paul
Parravicin
entered
the
room
.
<EOS>
The
knight
started
on
seeing
how
matters
stood
,
and
the
king
looked
surprised
and
angry
.
<EOS>
Taking
advantage
of
their
embarrassment
,
Nizza
made
good
her
retreat
,
and
hurrying
to
Amabel
's
chamber
,
closed
and
bolted
the
door
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
is
the
matter
?
"
<EOS>
cried
Amabel
,
startled
by
her
agitated
appearance
.
 
<EOS>
"
Sir
Paul
Parravicin
is
here
,
"
replied
Nizza
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
seen
him
.
<EOS>
But
that
is
not
all
.
<EOS>
I
am
unlucky
enough
to
have
attracted
the
king
's
fancy
.
<EOS>
He
has
terrified
me
with
his
proposals
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Our
persecution
is
never
to
end
,
"
rejoined
Amabel
;
"
you
are
as
unfortunate
as
myself
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
And
there
is
no
possibility
of
escape
,
"
returned
Nizza
,
bursting
into
tears
;
we
are
snared
like
birds
in
the
nets
of
the
fowler
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
can
fly
with
Leonard
if
you
choose
,
"
replied
Amabel
.
 
<EOS>
"
And
leave
you
--
impossible
!
"
rejoined
Nizza
.
 
<EOS>
"
There
is
nothing
for
it
,
then
,
but
resignation
,
"
returned
Amabel
.
<EOS>
"
Let
us
put
a
firm
trust
in
Heaven
,
and
no
ill
can
befall
us
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
After
passing
several
hours
of
the
greatest
disquietude
,
they
were
about
to
retire
to
rest
,
when
Mrs.
Buscot
tapped
at
the
door
,
and
making
herself
known
,
was
instantly
admitted
.
 
<EOS>
"
Alas
!
<EOS>
"
she
cried
,
clasping
her
niece
round
the
neck
,
"
I
tremble
to
tell
you
what
I
have
heard
.
<EOS>
Despite
the
king
's
injunctions
,
the
wicked
Earl
of
Rochester
is
determined
to
see
you
before
morning
,
and
to
force
you
to
compliance
with
his
wishes
.
<EOS>
You
must
fly
as
soon
as
it
is
dark
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
But
how
am
I
to
fly
,
dear
aunt
?
"
rejoined
Amabel
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
You
yourself
know
that
the
keys
of
the
stable
are
taken
away
,
and
that
two
of
the
king
's
attendants
will
remain
on
the
watch
all
night
.
<EOS>
How
will
it
be
possible
to
elude
their
vigilance
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
Leave
Leonard
to
manage
it
,
"
replied
Mrs.
Buscot
.
<EOS>
"
Only
prepare
to
set
out
.
<EOS>
John
Lutcombe
will
guide
you
across
the
downs
to
Kingston
Lisle
,
where
good
Mrs.
Compton
will
take
care
of
you
,
and
when
the
danger
is
over
you
can
return
to
me
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
a
hazardous
expedient
,
"
rejoined
Amabel
,
"
and
I
would
rather
run
all
risks
,
and
remain
here
.
<EOS>
If
the
earl
should
resort
to
violence
,
I
can
appeal
to
the
king
for
protection
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
If
you
have
any
regard
for
me
,
fly
,
"
cried
Nizza
Macascree
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
lost
if
I
remain
here
till
to
-
morrow
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
For
_
your
_
sake
I
will
go
,
then
,
"
returned
Amabel
.
"
<EOS>
But
I
have
a
foreboding
that
I
am
running
into
the
teeth
of
danger
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
!
say
not
so
,
"
rejoined
Mrs.
Buscot
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
persuaded
it
is
for
the
best
.
<EOS>
I
must
leave
you
now
,
but
I
will
send
Leonard
to
you
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
needless
,
"
replied
Amabel
.
"
<EOS>
Let
him
come
to
us
at
the
proper
time
.
<EOS>
We
will
be
ready
.
"
 
<EOS>
To
explain
the
cause
of
Mrs.
Buscot
's
alarm
,
it
will
be
necessary
to
return
to
the
receiving
-
room
,
and
ascertain
what
occurred
after
Nizza
's
flight
.
<EOS>
Charles
,
who
at
first
had
been
greatly
annoyed
by
Parravicin
's
abrupt
entrance
,
speedily
recovered
his
temper
,
and
laughed
at
the
other
's
forced
apologies
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
find
I
have
a
rival
in
your
majesty
,
"
observed
the
knight
.
<EOS>
"
It
is
unlucky
for
me
that
you
have
encountered
Nizza
.
<EOS>
Her
charms
were
certain
to
inflame
you
.
<EOS>
But
when
I
tell
you
I
am
desperately
enamoured
of
her
,
I
am
persuaded
you
will
not
interfere
with
me
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
will
tell
you
what
I
will
do
,
"
replied
the
good
-
humoured
monarch
,
after
a
moment
's
reflection
.
<EOS>
"
I
remember
your
mentioning
that
you
once
played
with
a
Captain
Disbrowe
for
his
wife
,
and
won
her
from
him
.
<EOS>
We
will
play
for
this
girl
in
the
same
manner
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
But
your
majesty
is
a
far
more
skilful
player
than
Disbrowe
,
"
replied
Parravicin
,
reluctantly
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
matters
not
,
"
rejoined
the
monarch
;
"
the
chances
will
be
more
equal
--
or
rather
the
advantage
will
be
greatly
on
your
side
,
<EOS>
for
you
are
allowed
to
be
the
luckiest
and
best
player
at
my
court
.
<EOS>
If
I
win
,
she
is
mine
.
<EOS>
If
,
on
the
contrary
,
fortune
favours
you
,
I
resign
her
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Since
there
is
no
avoiding
it
,
I
accept
the
challenge
,
"
replied
Parravicin
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
decision
shall
not
be
delayed
an
instant
,
"
cried
Charles
,
"
<EOS>
What
,
ho!--dice!--dice
!
"
 
<EOS>
An
attendant
answering
the
summons
,
he
desired
that
the
other
courtiers
should
be
admitted
,
and
dice
brought
.
<EOS>
The
latter
order
could
not
be
so
easily
obeyed
,
there
being
no
such
articles
at
Ashdown
;
and
the
attendants
were
driven
to
their
wits
'
ends
,
when
Pillichody
chancing
to
overhear
what
was
going
forward
,
produced
a
box
and
dice
,
which
were
instantly
conveyed
to
the
king
,
and
the
play
commenced
.
<EOS>
Charles
,
to
his
inexpressible
delight
and
Parravicin
's
chagrin
,
came
off
the
winner
,
and
the
mortification
of
the
latter
was
increased
by
the
laughter
and
taunts
of
the
spectators
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
are
not
in
your
usual
luck
to
-
day
,
"
observed
Rochester
to
him
,
as
they
walked
aside
.
 
<EOS>
"
For
all
this
,
do
not
think
I
will
surrender
Nizza
,
"
replied
Parravicin
,
in
a
low
tone
,
"
I
love
her
too
well
for
that
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
can
not
blame
you
,
"
replied
Rochester
.
<EOS>
"
Step
this
way
,
"
he
added
,
drawing
him
to
the
further
end
of
the
room
.
<EOS>
"
It
is
my
intention
to
carry
off
Amabel
to
-
night
,
notwithstanding
old
Rowley
's
injunctions
to
the
contrary
,
and
I
propose
to
accomplish
my
purpose
in
the
following
manner
.
<EOS>
I
will
frighten
her
into
flying
with
Leonard
Holt
,
and
will
then
secretly
follow
her
.
<EOS>
Nizza
Macascree
is
sure
to
accompany
her
,
and
will
,
therefore
,
be
in
your
power
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
see
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Parravicin
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
A
capital
project
!
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Pillichody
has
contrived
to
ingratiate
himself
with
Blaize
,
"
pursued
the
earl
,
"
and
through
him
the
matter
can
be
easily
managed
.
<EOS>
The
keys
of
the
stables
,
which
are
now
intrusted
to
Chiffinch
,
shall
be
stolen
--
<EOS>
the
horses
set
free
--
and
the
two
damsels
caught
in
the
trap
prepared
for
them
,
while
the
only
person
blamed
in
the
matter
will
be
Leonard
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Bravo
!
"
exclaimed
Parravicin
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
impatient
for
the
scheme
to
be
put
into
execution
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
will
set
about
it
at
once
,
"
returned
Rochester
.
 
<EOS>
And
separating
from
Parravicin
,
he
formed
some
excuse
for
quitting
the
royal
presence
.
 
<EOS>
About
an
hour
afterwards
,
Pillichody
sought
out
Blaize
,
and
told
him
,
with
a
very
mysterious
air
,
that
he
had
something
to
confide
to
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
know
my
regard
for
the
Earl
of
Rochester
and
Sir
Paul
Parravicin
,
"
he
said
,
"
and
that
I
would
do
anything
an
honourable
man
ought
to
do
to
assist
them
.
<EOS>
But
there
are
certain
bounds
which
even
friendship
can
not
induce
me
to
pass
.
<EOS>
They
meditate
the
worst
designs
against
Amabel
and
Nizza
Macascree
,
and
intend
to
accomplish
their
base
purpose
before
daybreak
.
<EOS>
I
therefore
give
you
notice
,
that
you
may
acquaint
Leonard
Holt
with
the
dangerous
situation
of
the
poor
girls
,
and
contrive
their
escape
in
the
early
part
of
the
night
.
<EOS>
I
will
steal
the
keys
of
the
stable
for
you
from
Chiffinch
,
and
will
render
you
every
assistance
in
my
power
.
<EOS>
But
if
you
are
discovered
,
you
must
not
betray
me
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Not
for
the
world
!
"
replied
Blaize
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
sure
we
are
infinitely
obliged
to
you
.
<EOS>
It
is
a
horrible
design
,
and
must
be
prevented
.
<EOS>
I
wish
all
this
flying
and
escaping
was
over
.
<EOS>
I
desire
to
be
quiet
,
and
am
quite
sorry
to
leave
this
charming
place
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
There
is
no
alternative
now
,
"
rejoined
Pillichody
.
 
<EOS>
"
So
it
appears
,
"
groaned
Blaize
.
 
<EOS>
The
substance
of
Pillichody
's
communication
was
immediately
conveyed
to
Leonard
,
who
told
Blaize
to
acquaint
his
informer
that
he
should
have
two
pieces
of
gold
,
if
he
brought
them
the
keys
.
<EOS>
To
obtain
them
was
not
very
difficult
,
and
the
bully
was
aided
in
accomplishing
the
task
by
the
Earl
of
Rochester
in
the
following
manner
.
<EOS>
Chiffinch
was
an
inordinate
drinker
,
and
satisfied
he
could
turn
this
failing
to
account
,
the
earl
went
into
the
ball
where
he
was
stationed
,
and
after
a
little
conversation
,
called
for
a
flask
of
wine
.
<EOS>
It
was
brought
,
and
while
they
were
quaffing
bumpers
,
Pillichody
,
who
had
entered
unperceived
,
contrived
to
open
a
table
-
drawer
in
which
the
keys
were
placed
,
and
slip
them
noiselessly
into
his
doublet
.
<EOS>
He
then
stole
away
,
and
delivered
his
prize
to
Blaize
,
receiving
in
return
the
promised
reward
,
and
chuckling
to
himself
at
the
success
of
his
roguery
.
<EOS>
The
keys
were
conveyed
by
the
porter
to
Leonard
,
and
the
latter
handed
them
in
his
turn
to
John
Lutcombe
,
who
engaged
to
have
the
horses
at
the
lower
end
of
the
south
avenue
an
hour
before
midnight
.
  
<EOS>
IX
.
 
<EOS>
KINGSTON
LISLE
.
 
<EOS>
About
half
-
past
ten
,
and
when
it
was
supposed
that
the
king
and
his
courtiers
had
retired
to
rest
(
for
early
hours
were
kept
in
those
days
)
,
Mrs.
Buscot
and
Leonard
repaired
to
Amabel
's
chamber
.
<EOS>
The
good
housekeeper
noticed
with
great
uneasiness
that
her
niece
looked
excessively
pale
and
agitated
,
and
she
would
have
persuaded
her
to
abandon
all
idea
of
flight
,
if
she
had
not
feared
that
her
stay
might
be
attended
with
still
worse
consequences
.
 
<EOS>
Before
the
party
set
out
,
Mrs.
Buscot
crept
down
stairs
to
see
that
all
was
safe
,
and
returned
almost
instantly
,
with
the
very
satisfactory
intelligence
that
Chiffinch
was
snoring
in
a
chair
in
the
hall
,
and
that
the
usher
had
probably
retired
to
rest
,
as
he
was
nowhere
to
be
seen
.
<EOS>
Not
a
moment
,
therefore
,
was
to
be
lost
,
and
they
descended
the
great
staircase
as
noiselessly
as
possible
.
<EOS>
So
far
all
had
gone
well
;
but
on
gaining
the
hall
,
Amabel
's
strength
completely
deserted
her
,
and
if
Leonard
had
not
caught
her
in
his
arms
,
she
must
have
fallen
.
<EOS>
He
was
hurrying
forward
with
his
burden
towards
a
passage
on
the
right
,
when
Chiffinch
,
who
had
been
disturbed
by
the
noise
,
suddenly
started
to
his
feet
,
and
commanded
him
to
stop
.
<EOS>
At
this
moment
,
a
figure
enveloped
in
a
cloak
darted
from
behind
a
door
,
and
extinguishing
the
lamp
which
Chiffinch
had
taken
from
the
table
,
seized
him
with
a
powerful
grasp
.
<EOS>
All
was
now
buried
in
darkness
,
and
while
Leonard
Holt
was
hesitating
what
to
do
,
he
heard
a
voice
,
which
he
knew
to
be
that
of
Pillichody
,
whisper
in
his
ear
,
"
<EOS>
Come
with
me
--
I
will
secure
your
retreat
.
<EOS>
Quick
!
<EOS>
quick
!
"
 
<EOS>
Suffering
himself
to
be
drawn
along
,
and
closely
followed
by
Nizza
Macascree
and
Mrs.
Buscot
,
Leonard
crossed
the
dining
-
chamber
,
not
without
stumbling
against
some
of
the
furniture
by
the
way
,
and
through
an
open
window
into
the
court
,
where
he
found
Blaize
awaiting
him
.
<EOS>
Without
waiting
for
thanks
,
Pillichody
then
disappeared
,
and
Mrs.
Buscot
,
having
pointed
out
the
course
he
ought
to
pursue
,
bade
him
farewell
.
 
<EOS>
Hurrying
across
the
court
,
he
reached
the
south
avenue
,
but
had
not
proceeded
far
when
it
became
evident
,
from
the
lights
at
the
windows
,
as
well
as
from
the
shouts
and
other
noises
proceeding
from
the
court
,
that
their
flight
was
discovered
.
<EOS>
Encumbered
as
he
was
by
his
lovely
burden
,
Leonard
ran
on
so
swiftly
,
that
Nizza
Macascree
and
Blaize
could
scarcely
keep
up
with
him
.
<EOS>
They
found
John
Lutcombe
at
the
end
of
the
avenue
with
the
horses
,
and
mounting
them
,
set
off
along
the
downs
,
accompanied
by
the
keeper
,
who
acted
as
their
guide
.
<EOS>
Striking
off
on
the
right
,
they
came
to
a
spot
covered
over
with
immense
grey
stones
,
resembling
those
rocky
fragments
used
by
the
Druids
in
the
construction
of
a
cromlech
,
and
,
as
it
was
quite
dark
,
it
required
some
caution
in
passing
through
them
.
<EOS>
Guided
by
the
keeper
,
who
here
took
hold
of
the
bridle
of
his
horse
,
Leonard
threaded
the
pass
with
safety
;
but
Blaize
was
not
equally
fortunate
.
<EOS>
Alarmed
by
the
sounds
in
the
rear
,
and
not
attending
to
the
keeper
's
caution
,
he
urged
his
horse
on
,
and
the
animal
coming
in
contact
with
a
stone
,
stumbled
,
and
precipitated
him
and
Nizza
Macascree
to
the
ground
.
<EOS>
Luckily
,
neither
of
them
fell
against
the
stone
,
or
the
consequences
might
have
been
fatal
.
<EOS>
John
Lutcombe
instantly
flew
to
their
aid
,
but
before
he
reached
them
,
Nizza
Macascree
had
regained
her
feet
.
<EOS>
Blaize
,
however
,
who
was
considerably
shaken
and
bruised
by
the
fall
,
was
not
quite
so
expeditious
,
and
his
dilatoriness
so
provoked
the
keeper
,
that
,
seizing
him
in
his
arms
,
he
lifted
him
into
the
saddle
.
<EOS>
Just
as
Nizza
Macascree
was
placed
on
the
pillion
behind
him
,
the
tramp
of
horses
was
heard
rapidly
approaching
.
<EOS>
In
another
moment
their
pursuers
came
up
,
and
the
foremost
,
whose
tones
proclaimed
him
the
Earl
of
Rochester
,
commanded
them
to
stop
.
<EOS>
Inexpressibly
alarmed
,
Amabel
could
not
repress
a
scream
,
and
guided
by
the
sound
,
the
earl
dashed
to
her
side
,
and
seized
the
bridle
of
her
steed
.
 
<EOS>
A
short
struggle
took
place
between
him
and
Leonard
,
in
which
the
hitter
strove
to
break
away
;
but
the
earl
,
drawing
his
sword
,
held
it
to
his
throat
.
 
<EOS>
"
Deliver
up
your
mistress
instantly
,
"
he
cried
,
in
a
menacing
tone
,
"
or
you
are
a
dead
man
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
Leonard
returned
a
peremptory
refusal
.
 
<EOS>
"
Hold
!
"
exclaimed
Amabel
,
springing
from
the
horse
;
"
I
will
not
be
the
cause
of
bloodshed
.
<EOS>
I
implore
you
,
my
lord
,
to
desist
from
this
outrage
.
<EOS>
You
will
gain
nothing
by
it
but
my
death
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Let
him
touch
you
at
his
peril
,
"
cried
John
Lutcombe
,
rushing
towards
them
,
and
interposing
his
stalwart
person
between
her
and
the
earl
.
 
<EOS>
"
Stand
aside
,
dog
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Rochester
furiously
,
"
or
I
will
trample
you
beneath
my
horse
's
hoofs
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
must
first
get
near
me
to
do
it
,
"
rejoined
the
keeper
.
<EOS>
And
as
he
spoke
he
struck
the
horse
so
violent
a
blow
with
a
stout
oaken
cudgel
with
which
he
was
provided
,
that
the
animal
became
unmanageable
,
and
dashed
across
the
downs
to
some
distance
with
his
rider
.
 
<EOS>
Meanwhile
,
Parravicin
having
ridden
up
with
Pillichody
<EOS>
(
for
they
proved
to
be
the
earl
's
companions
)
assailed
Blaize
,
and
commanded
him
to
deliver
up
Nizza
Macascree
.
<EOS>
Scared
almost
out
of
his
senses
,
the
porter
would
have
instantly
complied
,
if
the
piper
's
daughter
had
not
kept
fast
hold
of
him
,
and
reproaching
him
with
his
cowardice
,
screamed
loudly
for
help
.
<EOS>
Heedless
of
her
cries
,
Parravicin
seized
her
,
and
strove
to
drag
her
from
the
horse
;
but
she
only
clung
the
closer
to
Blaize
,
and
the
other
,
expecting
every
moment
to
pay
another
visit
to
the
ground
,
added
his
vociferations
for
assistance
to
hers
.
 
<EOS>
"
Leave
go
your
hold
,
"
he
cried
,
to
Pillichody
,
who
had
seized
him
on
the
other
side
by
the
collar
.
"
<EOS>
Leave
go
,
I
say
,
or
you
will
rend
my
jerkin
asunder
.
<EOS>
What
are
you
doing
here
?
<EOS>
I
thought
you
were
to
help
us
to
escape
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
So
I
have
done
,
"
rejoined
Pillichody
,
bursting
into
a
loud
laugh
;
"
and
I
am
now
helping
to
catch
you
again
.
<EOS>
What
a
blind
buzzard
you
must
be
not
to
perceive
the
net
spread
for
you
!
<EOS>
Deliver
up
Nizza
Macascree
without
more
ado
,
or
,
by
all
the
fiends
,
I
will
pay
you
off
for
your
dastardly
assault
upon
me
this
morning
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
can
not
deliver
her
up
,
"
cried
Blaize
;
"
she
sticks
to
me
as
fast
as
a
burr
.
<EOS>
I
shall
be
torn
asunder
between
you
.
<EOS>
Help
!
<EOS>
help
!
"
 
<EOS>
Parravicin
,
having
dismounted
,
now
tore
away
Nizza
Macascree
,
and
was
just
about
to
transfer
her
to
his
own
steed
,
when
John
Lutcombe
,
having
driven
away
the
earl
in
the
manner
before
described
,
came
to
the
rescue
.
<EOS>
One
blow
from
his
cudgel
stretched
the
knight
on
the
sod
,
and
liberated
Nizza
Macascree
,
who
instantly
flew
to
her
preserver
.
<EOS>
Finding
how
matters
stood
,
and
that
he
was
likely
to
be
well
backed
,
Blaize
plucked
up
his
courage
,
and
grappled
with
Pillichody
.
<EOS>
In
the
struggle
they
both
tumbled
to
the
ground
.
<EOS>
The
keeper
rushed
towards
them
,
and
seizing
Pillichody
,
began
to
belabour
him
soundly
.
<EOS>
In
vain
the
bully
implored
mercy
.
<EOS>
He
underwent
a
severe
chastisement
,
and
Blaize
added
a
few
kicks
to
the
shower
of
blows
proceeding
from
the
keeper
,
crying
,
as
he
dealt
them
,
"
Who
is
the
buzzard
now
,
I
should
like
to
know
?
"
 
<EOS>
By
this
time
,
Parravicin
had
regained
his
legs
,
and
the
Earl
of
Rochester
having
forced
back
his
steed
,
both
drew
their
swords
,
and
,
burning
for
vengeance
,
prepared
to
renew
the
charge
.
<EOS>
The
affair
might
have
assumed
a
serious
aspect
,
if
it
had
not
chanced
that
at
this
juncture
lights
were
seen
hurrying
along
the
avenue
,
and
the
next
moment
,
a
large
party
issued
from
it
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
the
king
?
"
cried
Rochester
.
<EOS>
"
What
is
to
be
done
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
Our
prey
must
be
abandoned
,
"
rejoined
Parravicin
;
"
it
will
never
do
to
be
caught
here
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
With
this
he
sprang
upon
his
steed
,
and
disappeared
across
the
downs
with
the
earl
.
 
<EOS>
John
Lutcombe
,
on
perceiving
the
approach
of
the
torch
-
bearers
,
instantly
abandoned
Pillichody
,
and
assisting
Blaize
to
the
saddle
,
placed
Nizza
behind
him
.
<EOS>
Leonard
,
likewise
,
who
had
dismounted
to
support
Amabel
,
replaced
her
in
the
pillion
,
and
in
a
few
seconds
the
party
were
in
motion
.
<EOS>
Pillichody
,
who
was
the
only
person
now
left
,
did
not
care
to
wait
for
the
king
's
arrival
,
but
snatching
the
bridle
of
his
steed
,
which
was
quietly
grazing
at
a
little
distance
,
mounted
him
,
and
galloped
off
in
the
direction
which
he
fancied
had
been
taken
by
the
earl
and
his
companion
.
 
<EOS>
Guided
by
the
keeper
,
who
ran
beside
them
,
the
fugitives
proceeded
for
a
couple
of
miles
at
a
rapid
pace
over
the
downs
,
when
,
it
not
appearing
that
they
were
followed
,
John
Lutcombe
halted
for
a
moment
to
recover
breath
.
<EOS>
The
fresh
air
had
in
some
degree
revived
Amabel
,
and
the
circumstance
of
their
providential
deliverance
raised
the
spirits
of
the
whole
party
.
<EOS>
Soon
after
this
,
they
reached
the
ridge
of
the
downs
,
the
magnificent
view
from
which
was
completely
hidden
by
the
shades
of
night
,
and
,
tracking
the
old
Roman
road
for
about
a
mile
,
descended
the
steep
hill
in
the
direction
of
the
Blowing
Stone
.
<EOS>
Skirting
a
thick
grove
of
trees
,
they
presently
came
to
a
gate
,
which
the
keeper
opened
,
and
led
them
through
an
orchard
towards
what
appeared
to
be
in
the
gloom
a
moderately
-
sized
and
comfortable
habitation
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
owner
of
this
house
,
Mrs.
Compton
,
"
observed
John
Lutcombe
to
Amabel
,
"
is
a
widow
,
and
the
kindest
lady
in
Berkshire
.
<EOS>
A
message
has
been
sent
by
your
aunt
to
beg
her
to
afford
you
an
asylum
for
a
few
days
,
and
I
will
answer
for
it
you
will
be
hospitably
received
.
"
 
<EOS>
As
he
spoke
,
the
loud
barking
of
a
dog
was
heard
,
and
an
old
grey
-
headed
butler
was
seen
advancing
towards
them
with
a
lantern
in
his
hand
.
<EOS>
At
the
same
time
a
groom
issued
from
the
stable
on
the
right
,
accompanied
by
the
dog
in
question
,
and
,
hastening
towards
them
,
assisted
them
to
dismount
.
<EOS>
The
dog
seemed
to
recognise
the
keeper
,
and
leaped
upon
him
,
licked
his
hand
,
and
exhibited
other
symptoms
of
delight
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
,
Ringwood
,
"
cried
the
keeper
,
patting
his
head
,
"
dost
thou
know
thy
old
master
again
?
<EOS>
I
see
you
have
taken
good
care
of
him
,
Sam
,
"
he
added
to
the
groom
.
<EOS>
"
I
knew
I
was
placing
him
into
good
hands
when
I
gave
him
to
Mrs.
Compton
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Ay
,
ay
,
he
ca
n't
find
a
better
home
,
I
fancy
,
"
said
the
groom
.
 
<EOS>
"
Will
it
please
you
to
walk
this
way
,
ladies
?
<EOS>
"
interposed
the
butler
.
<EOS>
"
My
mistress
has
been
expecting
you
for
some
time
,
and
had
become
quite
uneasy
about
you
.
"
<EOS>
So
saying
,
he
led
the
way
through
a
garden
,
filled
with
the
odours
of
a
hundred
unseen
flowers
,
and
ushered
them
into
the
house
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs.
Compton
,
an
elderly
lady
,
of
very
pleasing
exterior
,
received
them
with
great
kindness
,
and
conducted
them
to
a
comfortable
apartment
,
surrounded
with
book
-
shelves
and
old
family
portraits
,
where
refreshments
were
spread
out
for
them
.
<EOS>
The
good
old
lady
seemed
particularly
interested
in
Amabel
,
and
pressed
her
,
but
in
vain
,
to
partake
of
the
refreshments
.
<EOS>
With
extreme
delicacy
,
she
refrained
from
inquiring
into
the
cause
of
their
visit
,
and
seeing
that
they
appeared
,
much
fatigued
,
rang
for
a
female
attendant
,
and
conducted
them
to
a
sleeping
-
chamber
,
where
she
took
leave
of
them
for
the
night
.
<EOS>
Amabel
was
delighted
with
her
kind
hostess
,
and
,
contrary
to
her
expectations
and
to
those
of
Nizza
Macascree
,
enjoyed
undisturbed
repose
.
<EOS>
She
awoke
in
the
morning
greatly
refreshed
,
and
,
after
attiring
herself
,
gazed
through
her
chamber
window
.
<EOS>
It
looked
upon
a
trim
and
beautiful
garden
,
with
a
green
and
mossy
plot
carved
out
into
quaintly
-
fashioned
beds
,
filled
with
the
choicest
flowers
,
and
surrounded
by
fine
timber
,
amid
which
a
tall
fir
-
tree
appeared
proudly
conspicuous
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Compton
,
who
,
it
appeared
,
always
arose
with
the
sun
,
was
busied
in
tending
her
flowers
,
and
as
Amabel
watched
her
interesting
pursuits
,
she
could
scarcely
help
envying
her
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
a
delightful
life
your
mistress
must
lead
,
"
she
observed
to
a
female
attendant
who
was
present
;
"
I
can
not
imagine
greater
happiness
than
hers
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
My
mistress
ought
to
be
happy
,
"
said
the
attendant
;
"
for
there
is
no
one
living
who
does
more
good
.
<EOS>
Not
a
cottage
nor
a
farm
-
house
in
the
neighbourhood
<EOS>
but
she
visits
to
inquire
whether
she
can
be
of
any
service
to
its
inmates
;
and
wherever
her
services
_
are
_
required
,
they
are
always
rendered
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Compton
's
name
will
never
be
forgotten
in
Kingston
Lisle
.
"
 
<EOS>
At
this
moment
,
Amabel
caught
sight
of
the
benevolent
countenance
of
the
good
old
lady
looking
up
at
the
window
,
and
a
kindly
greeting
passed
between
them
.
<EOS>
Ringwood
,
who
was
a
privileged
intruder
,
was
careering
round
the
garden
,
and
though
his
mistress
watched
his
gambols
round
her
favourite
flower
-
beds
with
some
anxiety
,
she
did
not
check
him
.
<EOS>
Amabel
and
Nizza
now
went
down
stairs
,
and
Mrs.
Compton
returning
from
the
garden
,
all
the
household
,
including
Leonard
and
Blaize
,
assembled
in
the
breakfast
-
room
for
morning
prayers
.
 
<EOS>
Breakfast
over
,
Mrs.
Compton
entered
into
conversation
with
Amabel
,
and
ascertained
all
the
particulars
of
her
history
.
<EOS>
She
was
greatly
interested
in
it
,
but
did
not
affect
to
conceal
the
anxiety
it
gave
her
.
 
<EOS>
"
Yours
is
really
a
very
dangerous
position
,
"
she
said
,
"
and
I
should
be
acting
unfairly
towards
you
if
I
told
you
otherwise
.
<EOS>
However
,
I
will
give
you
all
the
protection
in
my
power
,
and
I
trust
your
retreat
may
not
be
discovered
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
Mrs.
Compton
's
remark
did
not
tend
to
dispel
Amabel
's
uneasiness
,
and
both
she
and
Nizza
Macascree
passed
a
day
of
great
disquietude
.
 
<EOS>
In
the
mean
time
,
Leonard
and
Blaize
were
treated
with
great
hospitality
by
the
old
butler
in
the
servants
'
hall
;
and
though
the
former
was
not
without
apprehension
that
their
retreat
might
be
discovered
,
he
trusted
,
if
it
were
so
,
to
some
fortunate
chance
to
effect
their
escape
.
<EOS>
He
did
not
dare
to
confide
his
apprehensions
to
the
butler
,
nor
did
the
other
make
any
inquiries
;
but
it
being
understood
that
their
visit
was
to
be
secret
,
every
precaution
was
taken
to
keep
it
so
.
<EOS>
John
Lutcombe
had
tarried
no
longer
than
enabled
him
to
discuss
a
jug
of
ale
,
and
then
set
out
for
Ashdown
,
promising
to
return
on
the
following
day
;
but
he
had
not
yet
made
his
appearance
.
<EOS>
Evening
arrived
,
and
nothing
alarming
having
occurred
,
all
became
comparatively
easy
;
and
Mrs.
Compton
herself
,
who
had
looked
unusually
grave
throughout
the
day
,
now
recovered
her
wonted
cheerfulness
.
 
<EOS>
Their
satisfaction
,
however
,
was
not
long
afterwards
disturbed
by
the
arrival
of
a
large
train
of
horsemen
at
the
gate
,
and
a
stately
personage
alighted
,
and
walked
at
the
head
of
a
gallant
train
,
towards
the
house
.
<EOS>
At
the
sight
of
the
new
-
comers
,
whom
they
instantly
knew
were
the
king
and
his
suite
,
Amabel
and
Nizza
Macascree
flew
upstairs
,
and
shutting
themselves
in
their
chamber
,
awaited
the
result
in
the
utmost
trepidation
.
<EOS>
They
were
not
kept
long
in
suspense
.
<EOS>
Shortly
after
the
king
's
arrival
,
Mrs.
Compton
herself
knocked
at
the
door
,
and
in
a
tone
of
deep
commiseration
,
informed
Amabel
that
his
majesty
desired
to
see
her
.
 
<EOS>
Knowing
<EOS>
that
refusal
was
impossible
,
Amabel
complied
,
and
descended
to
a
room
looking
upon
the
garden
,
in
which
she
found
the
king
.
<EOS>
He
was
attended
only
by
Chiffinch
,
and
received
her
with
a
somewhat
severe
aspect
,
and
demanded
why
she
had
left
Ashdown
contrary
to
his
express
injunctions
?
 
<EOS>
Amabel
stated
her
motives
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
you
tell
me
is
by
no
means
satisfactory
,
"
rejoined
the
king
;
"
but
since
you
have
chosen
to
trust
to
yourself
,
you
can
no
longer
look
for
protection
from
me
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
beseech
your
majesty
to
consider
the
strait
into
which
I
was
driven
,
"
returned
Amabel
,
imploringly
.
 
<EOS>
"
Summon
the
Earl
of
Rochester
to
the
presence
,
"
said
the
king
,
turning
from
her
to
Chiffinch
.
 
<EOS>
"
In
pity
,
sire
,
"
cried
Amabel
,
throwing
herself
at
his
feet
.
 
<EOS>
"
Let
the
injunction
be
obeyed
,
"
rejoined
Charles
,
peremptorily
.
 
<EOS>
And
the
chief
page
departed
.
 
<EOS>
Amabel
instantly
arose
,
and
drew
herself
proudly
up
.
<EOS>
Soon
afterwards
,
Rochester
made
his
appearance
,
and
on
seeing
Amabel
,
a
flush
of
triumphant
joy
overspread
his
features
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
withdraw
my
interdiction
,
my
lord
,
"
said
the
king
to
him
.
<EOS>
"
You
are
at
liberty
to
renew
your
suit
to
this
girl
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Hear
me
,
Lord
Rochester
,
"
said
Amabel
,
addressing
the
earl
;
"
I
have
conquered
the
passion
I
once
felt
for
you
,
and
regard
you
only
as
one
who
has
sought
my
ruin
,
and
from
whom
I
have
fortunately
escaped
.
<EOS>
When
you
learn
from
my
own
lips
that
my
heart
is
dead
to
you
,
that
I
never
can
love
you
more
,
and
that
I
only
desire
to
be
freed
from
your
addresses
<EOS>
,
I
can
not
doubt
but
you
will
discontinue
them
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Your
declaration
only
inflames
me
the
more
,
lovely
Amabel
,
"
replied
the
earl
,
passionately
.
<EOS>
"
You
must
,
and
shall
be
mine
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Then
my
death
will
rest
at
your
door
,
"
she
rejoined
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
will
take
my
chance
of
that
,
"
rejoined
the
earl
,
carelessly
.
 
<EOS>
Amabel
then
quitted
the
king
's
presence
,
and
returned
to
her
own
chamber
,
where
she
found
Nizza
Macascree
in
a
state
of
indescribable
agitation
.
 
<EOS>
"
All
has
happened
that
I
anticipated
,
"
said
she
to
Nizza
Macascree
.
<EOS>
"
The
king
will
no
longer
protect
me
,
and
I
am
exposed
to
the
persecutions
of
the
Earl
of
Rochester
,
who
is
here
.
"
 
<EOS>
As
she
spoke
,
an
usher
entered
,
and
informed
Nizza
Macascree
that
the
king
commanded
her
presence
.
<EOS>
The
piper
's
daughter
looked
at
Amabel
with
a
glance
of
unutterable
anguish
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
fear
you
must
go
,
"
said
Amabel
,
"
but
Heaven
will
protect
you
!
"
 
<EOS>
They
then
tenderly
embraced
each
other
,
and
Nizza
Macascree
departed
with
the
usher
.
 
<EOS>
Some
time
having
elapsed
,
and
Nizza
not
returning
,
Amabel
became
seriously
uneasy
.
<EOS>
Hearing
a
noise
below
,
she
looked
forth
from
the
window
,
and
perceived
the
king
and
all
his
train
departing
.
<EOS>
A
terrible
foreboding
shot
through
her
heart
.
<EOS>
She
gazed
anxiously
after
them
,
but
could
not
perceive
Nizza
Macascree
.
<EOS>
Overcome
at
last
by
her
anxiety
,
she
rushed
down
stairs
,
and
had
just
reached
the
last
step
,
when
she
was
seized
by
two
persons
.
<EOS>
A
shawl
was
passed
over
her
head
,
and
she
was
forced
out
of
the
house
.
        
<EOS>
*
      
<EOS>
*
      
<EOS>
*
      
<EOS>
*
      
<EOS>
*
    
<EOS>
BOOK
THE
FOURTH
.
 
<EOS>
SEPTEMBER
,
1665
.
  
<EOS>
I.
 
<EOS>
THE
PLAGUE
<EOS>
AT
ITS
HEIGHT
.
 
<EOS>
Amabel
's
departure
for
Berkshire
caused
no
change
in
her
father
's
mode
of
life
.
<EOS>
Everything
proceeded
as
before
within
his
quiet
dwelling
;
and
,
except
that
the
family
were
diminished
in
number
,
all
appeared
the
same
.
<EOS>
It
is
true
they
wanted
the
interest
,
and
indeed
the
occupation
,
afforded
them
by
the
gentle
invalid
,
but
in
other
respects
,
no
difference
was
observable
.
<EOS>
Devotional
exercises
,
meals
,
the
various
duties
of
the
house
,
and
cheerful
discourse
,
filled
up
the
day
,
which
never
proved
wearisome
.
<EOS>
The
result
proved
the
correctness
of
Mr.
Bloundel
's
judgment
.
<EOS>
While
the
scourge
continued
weekly
to
extend
its
ravages
throughout
the
city
,
it
never
crossed
his
threshold
;
and
,
except
suffering
in
a
slight
degree
from
scorbutic
affections
,
occasioned
by
the
salt
meats
to
which
they
were
now
confined
,
and
for
which
the
lemon
and
lime
-
juice
,
provided
against
such
a
contingency
,
proved
an
efficacious
remedy
,
all
the
family
enjoyed
perfect
health
.
<EOS>
For
some
weeks
after
her
separation
from
her
daughter
,
Mrs.
Bloundel
continued
in
a
desponding
state
,
but
after
that
time
she
became
more
reconciled
to
the
deprivation
,
and
partially
recovered
her
spirits
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Bloundel
did
not
dare
to
indulge
a
hope
that
Amabel
would
ever
return
;
but
though
he
suffered
much
in
secret
,
he
never
allowed
his
grief
to
manifest
itself
.
<EOS>
The
circumstance
that
he
had
not
received
any
intelligence
of
her
did
not
weigh
much
with
him
,
because
the
difficulty
of
communication
became
greater
and
greater
,
as
each
week
the
scourge
increased
in
violence
,
and
he
was
inclined
to
take
no
news
as
good
news
.
<EOS>
It
was
not
so
in
the
present
case
,
but
of
this
he
was
happily
ignorant
.
 
<EOS>
In
this
way
,
a
month
passed
on
.
<EOS>
And
now
every
other
consideration
was
merged
in
the
alarm
occasioned
by
the
daily
increasing
fury
of
the
pestilence
.
<EOS>
Throughout
July
the
excessive
heat
of
the
weather
underwent
no
abatement
,
but
in
place
of
the
clear
atmosphere
that
had
prevailed
during
the
preceding
month
,
unwholesome
blights
filled
the
air
,
and
,
confining
the
pestilential
effluvia
,
spread
the
contagion
far
and
wide
with
extraordinary
rapidity
.
<EOS>
Not
only
was
the
city
suffocated
with
heat
,
but
filled
with
noisome
smells
,
arising
from
the
carcasses
with
which
the
close
alleys
and
other
out
-
of
-
the
-
way
places
were
crowded
,
and
which
were
so
far
decomposed
as
not
to
be
capable
of
removal
.
<EOS>
The
aspect
of
the
river
was
as
much
changed
as
that
of
the
city
.
<EOS>
Numbers
of
bodies
were
thrown
into
it
,
and
,
floating
up
with
the
tide
,
were
left
to
taint
the
air
on
its
banks
,
while
strange
,
ill
-
omened
fowl
,
attracted
thither
by
their
instinct
,
preyed
upon
them
.
<EOS>
Below
the
bridge
,
all
captains
of
ships
moored
in
the
Pool
,
or
off
Wapping
,
held
as
little
communication
as
possible
with
those
on
shore
,
and
only
received
fresh
provisions
with
the
greatest
precaution
.
<EOS>
As
the
plague
increased
,
most
of
these
removed
lower
down
the
river
,
and
many
of
them
put
out
entirely
to
sea
.
<EOS>
Above
the
bridge
,
most
of
the
wherries
and
other
smaller
craft
had
disappeared
,
their
owners
having
taken
them
up
the
river
,
and
moored
them
against
its
banks
at
different
spots
,
where
they
lived
in
them
under
tilts
.
<EOS>
Many
hundreds
of
persons
remained
upon
the
river
in
this
way
during
the
whole
continuance
of
the
visitation
.
 
<EOS>
August
had
now
arrived
,
but
the
distemper
knew
no
cessation
.
<EOS>
On
the
contrary
,
it
manifestly
increased
in
violence
and
malignity
.
<EOS>
The
deaths
rose
a
thousand
in
each
week
,
and
in
the
last
week
in
this
fatal
month
amounted
to
upwards
of
sixty
thousand
!
 
<EOS>
But
,
terrible
as
this
was
,
the
pestilence
had
not
yet
reached
its
height
.
<EOS>
Hopes
were
entertained
that
when
the
weather
became
cooler
,
its
fury
would
abate
;
but
these
