anticipations
were
fearfully
disappointed
.
<EOS>
The
bills
of
mortality
rose
the
first
week
in
September
to
seven
thousand
,
and
though
they
slightly
decreased
during
the
second
week
--
awakening
a
momentary
hope
--
on
the
third
they
advanced
to
twelve
thousand
!
<EOS>
In
less
than
ten
days
,
upwards
of
two
thousand
persons
perished
in
the
parish
of
Aldgate
alone
;
while
Whitechapel
suffered
equally
severely
.
<EOS>
Out
of
the
hundred
parishes
in
and
about
the
city
,
one
only
,
that
of
Saint
John
the
Evangelist
in
Watling
-
street
,
remained
uninfected
,
and
this
merely
because
there
was
scarcely
a
soul
left
within
it
,
the
greater
part
of
the
inhabitants
having
quitted
their
houses
,
and
fled
into
the
country
.
 
<EOS>
The
deepest
despair
now
seized
upon
all
the
survivors
.
<EOS>
Scarcely
a
family
but
had
lost
half
of
its
number
--
many
,
more
than
half
--
while
those
who
were
left
felt
assured
that
their
turn
would
speedily
arrive
.
<EOS>
Even
the
reckless
were
appalled
,
and
abandoned
their
evil
courses
.
<EOS>
Not
only
were
the
dead
lying
in
the
passages
and
alleys
,
but
even
in
the
main
thoroughfares
,
and
none
would
remove
them
.
<EOS>
The
awful
prediction
of
Solomon
Eagle
that
"
grass
would
grow
in
the
streets
,
and
that
the
living
should
not
be
able
to
bury
the
dead
,
"
had
come
to
pass
.
<EOS>
London
had
become
one
vast
lazar
-
house
,
and
seemed
in
a
fair
way
of
becoming
a
mighty
sepulchre
.
 
<EOS>
During
all
this
time
,
Saint
Paul
's
continued
to
be
used
as
a
pest
-
house
,
but
it
was
not
so
crowded
as
heretofore
,
because
,
as
not
one
in
fifty
of
the
infected
recovered
when
placed
under
medical
care
,
it
was
not
thought
worth
while
to
remove
them
from
their
own
abodes
.
<EOS>
The
number
of
attendants
,
too
,
had
diminished
.
<EOS>
Some
had
died
,
but
the
greater
part
had
abandoned
their
offices
from
a
fear
of
sharing
the
fate
of
their
patients
.
<EOS>
In
consequence
of
these
changes
,
Judith
Malmayns
had
been
advanced
to
the
post
of
chief
nurse
at
the
cathedral
.
<EOS>
Both
she
and
Chowles
had
been
attacked
by
the
plague
,
and
both
had
recovered
.
<EOS>
Judith
attended
the
coffin
-
maker
,
and
it
was
mainly
owing
to
her
that
he
got
through
the
attack
.
<EOS>
She
never
left
him
for
a
moment
,
and
would
never
suffer
any
one
to
approach
him
--
a
necessary
precaution
,
as
he
was
so
much
alarmed
by
his
situation
that
he
would
infallibly
have
made
some
awkward
revelations
.
<EOS>
When
Judith
,
in
her
turn
,
was
seized
,
Chowles
exhibited
no
such
consideration
for
her
,
and
scarcely
affected
to
conceal
his
disappointment
at
her
recovery
.
<EOS>
This
want
of
feeling
on
his
part
greatly
incensed
her
against
him
,
and
though
he
contrived
in
some
degree
to
appease
her
,
it
was
long
before
she
entirely
forgave
him
.
<EOS>
Far
from
being
amended
by
her
sufferings
,
she
seemed
to
have
grown
more
obdurate
,
and
instantly
commenced
a
fresh
career
of
crime
.
<EOS>
It
was
not
,
however
,
necessary
now
to
hasten
the
end
of
the
sick
.
<EOS>
The
distemper
had
acquired
such
force
and
malignity
that
it
did
its
work
quickly
enough
--
often
too
quickly
--
and
all
she
sought
was
to
obtain
possession
of
the
poor
patients
'
attire
,
or
any
valuables
they
might
possess
worth
appropriating
.
<EOS>
To
turn
to
the
brighter
side
of
the
picture
,
it
must
not
be
omitted
that
when
the
pestilence
was
at
its
height
,
and
no
offers
could
induce
the
timorous
to
venture
forth
,
or
render
assistance
to
the
sufferers
,
Sir
John
Lawrence
the
Lord
Mayor
,
the
Duke
of
Albermarle
,
the
Earl
of
Craven
,
and
the
Archbishop
of
Canterbury
,
devoted
themselves
to
the
care
of
the
infected
,
and
supplied
them
with
every
necessary
they
required
.
<EOS>
Among
the
physicians
,
no
one
deserves
more
honourable
mention
than
Doctor
Hodges
,
who
was
unremitting
in
his
attentions
to
the
sufferers
.
 
<EOS>
To
return
to
the
grocer
.
<EOS>
While
the
plague
was
thus
raging
around
him
,
and
while
every
house
in
Wood
-
street
except
one
or
two
,
from
which
the
inmates
had
fled
,
was
attacked
by
the
pestilence
,
he
and
his
family
had
remained
untouched
.
<EOS>
About
the
middle
of
August
,
he
experienced
a
great
alarm
.
<EOS>
His
second
son
,
Hubert
,
fell
sick
,
and
he
removed
him
to
one
of
the
upper
rooms
which
he
had
set
aside
as
an
hospital
,
and
attended
upon
him
himself
.
<EOS>
In
a
few
days
,
however
,
his
fears
were
removed
and
he
found
,
to
his
great
satisfaction
,
that
the
youth
had
not
been
attacked
by
the
plague
,
but
was
only
suffering
from
a
slight
fever
,
which
quickly
yielded
to
the
remedies
applied
.
<EOS>
About
the
same
time
,
too
,
he
lost
his
porter
,
Dallison
.
<EOS>
The
poor
fellow
did
not
make
his
appearance
as
usual
for
two
days
,
and
intelligence
of
his
fate
was
brought
on
the
following
day
by
his
wife
,
who
came
to
state
that
her
husband
was
dead
,
and
had
been
thrown
into
the
plague
-
pit
at
Aldgate
.
<EOS>
The
same
night
,
however
,
she
brought
another
man
,
named
Allestry
,
who
took
the
place
of
the
late
porter
,
and
acquainted
his
employer
with
the
deplorable
state
of
the
city
.
 
<EOS>
Two
days
afterwards
,
Allestry
himself
died
,
and
Mr.
Bloundel
had
no
one
to
replace
him
.
<EOS>
He
thus
lost
all
means
of
ascertaining
what
was
going
forward
;
but
the
deathlike
stillness
around
him
,
broken
only
by
the
hoarse
tolling
of
a
bell
,
by
a
wild
shriek
or
other
appalling
cry
,
proclaimed
too
surely
the
terrible
state
of
things
.
<EOS>
Sometimes
,
too
,
a
passenger
would
go
by
,
and
would
tell
him
the
dreadful
height
to
which
the
bills
of
mortality
had
risen
,
assuring
him
that
ere
another
month
had
expired
,
not
a
soul
would
be
left
alive
in
London
.
 
<EOS>
One
night
,
as
Solomon
Eagle
,
who
had
likewise
been
miraculously
preserved
,
pursued
his
course
through
the
streets
,
he
paused
before
Mr.
Roundel
's
house
,
and
looking
up
at
the
window
,
at
which
the
latter
had
chanced
to
be
stationed
,
cried
in
a
loud
voice
,
"
Be
of
good
cheer
.
<EOS>
You
have
served
God
faithfully
,
and
there
shall
no
evil
befall
<EOS>
you
,
neither
shall
the
plague
come
nigh
your
dwelling
.
"
<EOS>
And
raising
his
arms
,
as
if
invoking
a
blessing
upon
the
habitation
,
he
departed
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
now
the
second
week
in
September
,
and
as
yet
Mr.
Bloundel
had
received
no
tidings
of
his
daughter
.
<EOS>
At
any
other
season
he
would
have
been
seriously
uneasy
,
but
now
,
as
has
been
already
stated
,
all
private
grief
was
swallowed
up
in
the
horror
of
the
general
calamity
.
<EOS>
Satisfied
that
she
was
in
a
healthful
situation
,
and
that
her
chance
of
preservation
from
the
pestilence
was
better
than
that
of
any
other
member
of
his
family
,
he
turned
his
thoughts
entirely
to
them
.
<EOS>
Redoubling
his
precautions
,
he
tried
by
every
means
to
keep
up
the
failing
spirits
of
his
household
,
and
but
rarely
ventured
to
open
his
shutter
,
and
look
forth
on
the
external
world
.
 
<EOS>
On
the
tenth
of
September
,
which
was
afterwards
accounted
the
most
fatal
day
of
this
fatal
month
,
a
young
man
of
a
very
dejected
appearance
,
and
wearing
the
traces
of
severe
suffering
in
his
countenance
,
entered
the
west
end
of
London
,
and
took
his
way
slowly
towards
the
city
.
<EOS>
He
had
passed
Saint
Giles
's
without
seeing
a
single
living
creature
,
or
the
sign
of
one
in
any
of
the
houses
.
<EOS>
The
broad
thoroughfare
was
completely
grown
over
with
grass
,
and
the
habitations
had
the
most
melancholy
and
deserted
air
imaginable
.
<EOS>
Some
doors
and
windows
were
wide
open
,
discovering
rooms
with
goods
and
furniture
scattered
about
,
having
been
left
in
this
state
by
their
inmates
;
but
most
part
of
them
were
closely
fastened
up
.
 
<EOS>
As
he
proceeded
along
Holborn
,
the
ravages
of
the
scourge
were
yet
more
apparent
.
<EOS>
Every
house
,
on
either
side
of
the
way
,
had
a
red
cross
,
with
the
fatal
inscription
above
it
,
upon
the
door
.
<EOS>
Here
and
there
,
a
watchman
might
be
seen
,
looking
more
like
a
phantom
than
a
living
thing
.
<EOS>
Formerly
,
the
dead
were
conveyed
away
at
night
,
but
now
the
carts
went
about
in
the
daytime
.
<EOS>
On
reaching
Saint
Andrew
's
,
Holborn
,
several
persons
were
seen
wheeling
hand
-
barrows
filled
with
corpses
,
scarcely
covered
with
clothing
,
and
revealing
the
blue
and
white
stripes
of
the
pestilence
,
towards
a
cart
which
was
standing
near
the
church
gates
.
<EOS>
The
driver
of
the
vehicle
,
a
tall
,
cadaverous
-
looking
man
,
was
ringing
his
bell
,
and
jesting
with
another
person
,
whom
the
young
man
recognised
,
with
a
shudder
,
as
Chowles
.
<EOS>
The
coffin
-
maker
also
recognised
him
at
the
same
moment
,
and
called
to
him
,
but
the
other
paid
no
attention
to
the
summons
and
passed
on
.
 
<EOS>
Crossing
Holborn
Bridge
<EOS>
,
he
toiled
faintly
up
the
opposite
hill
,
for
he
was
evidently
suffering
from
extreme
debility
,
and
on
gaining
the
summit
was
obliged
to
support
himself
against
a
wall
for
a
few
minutes
,
before
he
could
proceed
.
<EOS>
The
same
frightful
evidences
of
the
ravages
of
the
pestilence
were
observable
here
,
as
elsewhere
.
<EOS>
The
houses
were
all
marked
with
the
fatal
cross
,
and
shut
up
.
<EOS>
Another
dead
-
cart
was
heard
rumbling
along
,
accompanied
by
the
harsh
cries
of
the
driver
,
and
the
doleful
ringing
of
the
bell
.
<EOS>
The
next
moment
the
loathly
vehicle
was
seen
coming
along
the
Old
Bailey
.
<EOS>
It
paused
before
a
house
,
from
which
four
bodies
were
brought
,
and
then
passed
on
towards
Smithfield
.
<EOS>
Watching
its
progress
with
fearful
curiosity
,
the
young
man
noted
how
often
it
paused
to
increase
its
load
.
<EOS>
His
thoughts
,
coloured
by
the
scene
,
were
of
the
saddest
and
dreariest
complexion
.
<EOS>
All
around
wore
the
aspect
of
death
.
<EOS>
The
few
figures
in
sight
seemed
staggering
towards
the
grave
,
and
the
houses
appeared
to
be
plague
-
stricken
like
the
inhabitants
.
<EOS>
The
heat
was
intolerably
oppressive
,
and
the
air
tainted
with
noisome
exhalations
.
<EOS>
Ever
and
anon
,
a
window
would
be
opened
,
and
a
ghastly
face
thrust
from
it
,
while
a
piercing
shriek
,
or
lamentable
cry
,
was
uttered
.
<EOS>
No
business
seemed
going
on
--
there
were
no
passengers
--
no
vehicles
in
the
streets
.
<EOS>
The
mighty
city
was
completely
laid
prostrate
.
 
<EOS>
After
a
short
rest
,
the
young
man
shaped
his
course
towards
Saint
Paul
's
,
and
on
reaching
its
western
precincts
,
gazed
for
some
time
at
the
reverend
structure
,
as
if
its
contemplation
called
up
many
and
painful
recollections
.
<EOS>
Tears
started
to
his
eyes
,
and
he
was
about
to
turn
away
,
when
he
perceived
the
figure
of
Solomon
Eagle
stationed
near
the
cross
at
the
western
extremity
of
the
roof
.
<EOS>
The
enthusiast
caught
sight
of
him
at
the
same
moment
,
and
motioned
him
to
come
nearer
.
<EOS>
"
What
has
happened
?
"
he
demanded
,
as
the
other
approached
the
steps
of
the
portico
.
 
<EOS>
The
young
man
shook
his
head
mournfully
.
<EOS>
"
It
is
a
sad
tale
,
"
he
said
,
"
and
can
not
be
told
now
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
can
conjecture
what
it
is
,
"
replied
Solomon
Eagle
.
<EOS>
"
But
come
to
the
small
door
near
the
northern
entrance
of
the
cathedral
at
midnight
.
<EOS>
I
will
meet
you
there
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
will
not
fail
,
"
replied
the
young
man
.
 
<EOS>
"
One
of
the
terrible
judgments
which
I
predicted
would
befall
this
devoted
city
has
come
to
pass
,
"
cried
Solomon
Eagle
.
<EOS>
"
Another
yet
remains
--
the
judgment
by
fire
--
and
if
its
surviving
inhabitants
repent
not
,
of
which
there
is
as
yet
no
sign
,
it
will
assuredly
follow
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Heaven
avert
it
!
<EOS>
"
groaned
the
other
,
turning
away
.
 
<EOS>
Proceeding
along
Cheapside
,
he
entered
Wood
-
street
,
and
took
his
way
towards
the
grocer
's
dwelling
.
<EOS>
When
at
a
little
distance
from
it
,
he
paused
,
and
some
minutes
elapsed
before
he
could
muster
strength
to
go
forward
.
<EOS>
Here
,
as
elsewhere
,
there
were
abundant
indications
of
the
havoc
occasioned
by
the
fell
disease
.
<EOS>
Not
far
from
the
grocer
's
shop
,
and
in
the
middle
of
the
street
,
lay
the
body
of
a
man
,
with
the
face
turned
upwards
,
while
crouching
in
an
angle
of
the
wall
sat
a
young
woman
watching
it
.
<EOS>
As
the
young
man
drew
nearer
,
he
recognised
in
the
dead
man
the
principal
of
the
Brotherhood
of
Saint
Michael
,
and
in
the
poor
mourner
one
of
his
profligate
female
associates
.
<EOS>
"
What
has
become
of
your
unhappy
companions
?
"
he
demanded
of
the
woman
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
last
of
them
lies
there
,
"
she
rejoined
mournfully
.
<EOS>
"
All
the
rest
died
long
ago
.
<EOS>
My
lover
was
true
to
his
vow
;
and
instead
of
deploring
their
fate
,
lived
with
me
and
three
other
women
in
mirth
and
revelry
till
yesterday
,
when
the
three
women
died
,
and
he
fell
sick
.
<EOS>
He
did
not
,
however
,
give
in
,
but
continued
carousing
until
an
hour
before
his
death
.
"
 
<EOS>
Too
much
shocked
to
make
any
reply
,
the
young
man
proceeded
towards
the
hutch
.
<EOS>
Beneath
a
doorway
,
at
a
little
distance
from
it
,
sat
a
watchman
with
a
halberd
on
his
shoulder
,
guarding
the
house
;
but
it
was
evident
he
would
be
of
little
further
use
.
<EOS>
His
face
was
covered
with
his
hands
,
and
his
groans
proclaimed
that
he
himself
was
attacked
by
the
pestilence
.
<EOS>
Entering
the
hutch
,
the
young
man
pulled
the
cord
of
the
bell
,
and
the
summons
was
soon
after
answered
by
the
grocer
,
who
appeared
at
the
window
.
<EOS>
"
What
,
Leonard
Holt
!
"
<EOS>
he
exclaimed
,
in
surprise
,
on
seeing
the
young
man--"is
it
<EOS>
you?--what
ails
you?--you
<EOS>
look
frightfully
ill
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
been
attacked
a
second
time
by
the
plague
,
"
replied
the
apprentice
,
"
and
am
only
just
recovered
from
it
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
What
of
my
child
?
"
cried
the
grocer
<EOS>
eagerly--"what
of
her
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Alas
!
alas
!
<EOS>
"
exclaimed
the
apprentice
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
not
keep
me
in
suspense
,
"
rejoined
the
grocer
.
<EOS>
"
Is
she
dead
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
No
,
not
dead
,
"
replied
the
apprentice
,
"
<EOS>
but--
<EOS>
"
 
"
But
what
?
"
ejaculated
the
grocer
.
"
<EOS>
In
Heaven
's
name
,
speak
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
These
letters
will
tell
you
all
,
"
replied
the
apprentice
,
producing
a
packet
.
<EOS>
"
I
had
prepared
them
to
send
to
you
in
case
of
my
death
.
<EOS>
I
am
not
equal
to
further
explanation
now
.
"
 
<EOS>
With
trembling
eagerness
the
grocer
lowered
the
rope
,
and
Leonard
having
tied
the
packet
to
it
,
it
was
instantly
drawn
up
.
<EOS>
Notwithstanding
his
anxiety
to
ascertain
the
fate
of
Amabel
,
Mr.
Bloundel
would
not
touch
the
packet
until
he
had
guarded
against
the
possibility
of
being
infected
by
it
.
<EOS>
Seizing
it
with
a
pair
of
tongs
,
he
plunged
it
into
a
pan
containing
a
strong
solution
of
vinegar
and
sulphur
,
which
he
had
always
in
readiness
in
the
chamber
,
and
when
thoroughly
saturated
,
laid
it
in
the
sun
to
dry
.
<EOS>
On
first
opening
the
shutter
to
answer
Leonard
's
summons
,
he
had
flashed
off
a
pistol
,
and
he
now
thought
to
expel
the
external
air
by
setting
fire
to
a
ball
composed
of
quick
brimstone
,
saltpetre
,
and
yellow
amber
,
which
being
placed
on
an
iron
plate
,
speedily
filled
the
room
with
a
thick
vapour
,
and
prevented
the
entrance
of
any
obnoxious
particles
.
<EOS>
These
precautions
taken
,
he
again
addressed
himself
,
while
the
packet
was
drying
,
to
Leonard
,
whom
he
found
gazing
anxiously
at
the
window
,
and
informed
him
that
all
his
family
had
hitherto
escaped
contagion
.
 
<EOS>
"
A
special
providence
must
have
watched
over
you
,
sir
,
"
replied
the
apprentice
,
"
and
I
believe
yours
is
the
only
family
in
the
whole
city
that
has
been
so
spared
.
<EOS>
I
have
reason
to
be
grateful
for
my
own
extraordinary
preservation
,
and
yet
I
would
rather
it
had
pleased
Heaven
to
take
me
away
than
leave
me
to
my
present
misery
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
keep
me
in
a
frightful
state
of
suspense
,
Leonard
,
"
rejoined
the
grocer
,
regarding
the
packet
wistfully
,
"
for
I
dare
not
open
your
letters
till
they
are
thoroughly
fumigated
.
<EOS>
You
assure
me
my
child
is
living
.
<EOS>
Has
she
been
attacked
by
the
plague
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Would
she
had
!
<EOS>
"
groaned
Leonard
.
 
<EOS>
"
Is
she
still
at
Ashdown
?
"
<EOS>
pursued
the
grocer
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ah
!
<EOS>
you
shake
your
head
.
<EOS>
I
see!--I
must
be
beside
myself
not
to
have
thought
of
it
before
.
<EOS>
She
is
in
the
power
of
the
Earl
of
Rochester
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
She
is
,
"
cried
Leonard
,
catching
at
the
angle
of
the
shed
for
support
.
 
<EOS>
"
And
I
am
here
!
"
<EOS>
exclaimed
Mr.
Bloundel
,
forgetting
his
caution
,
and
thrusting
himself
far
out
of
the
window
,
as
if
with
the
intention
of
letting
himself
down
by
the
rope--"I
am
here
,
when
I
ought
to
be
near
her
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
Calm
yourself
,
<EOS>
I
beseech
you
,
sir
,
"
cried
Leonard
;
"
a
moment
's
rashness
will
undo
all
you
have
done
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
True
!
"
replied
the
grocer
,
checking
himself
.
<EOS>
"
I
must
think
of
others
as
well
as
of
her
.
<EOS>
But
where
is
she
?
<EOS>
Hide
nothing
from
me
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
reason
to
believe
she
is
in
London
,
"
replied
the
apprentice
.
<EOS>
"
I
traced
her
hither
,
and
should
not
have
desisted
from
my
search
if
I
had
not
been
checked
by
the
plague
,
which
attacked
me
on
the
night
of
my
arrival
.
<EOS>
I
was
taken
to
the
pesthouse
near
Westbourne
Green
,
where
I
have
been
for
the
last
three
weeks
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
If
she
was
brought
to
London
,
as
you
state
,
"
rejoined
the
grocer
,
"
I
can
not
doubt
<EOS>
but
she
has
fallen
a
victim
to
the
scourge
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
may
be
,
"
replied
Leonard
,
moodily
,
"
and
I
would
almost
hope
it
is
so
.
<EOS>
When
you
peruse
my
letters
,
you
will
learn
that
she
was
carried
off
by
the
earl
from
the
residence
of
a
lady
at
Kingston
Lisle
,
whither
she
had
been
removed
for
safety
;
and
after
being
taken
from
place
to
place
,
was
at
last
conveyed
to
an
old
hall
in
the
neighbourhood
of
Oxford
,
where
she
was
concealed
for
nearly
a
month
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Answer
me
,
Leonard
,
"
cried
the
grocer
,
"
and
do
not
attempt
to
deceive
me
.
<EOS>
Has
she
preserved
her
honour
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
Up
to
the
time
of
quitting
Oxford
she
had
preserved
it
,
"
replied
the
apprentice
.
"
<EOS>
She
herself
assured
me
she
had
resisted
all
the
earl
's
importunities
,
and
would
die
rather
than
yield
to
him
.
<EOS>
But
I
will
tell
you
how
I
obtained
an
interview
with
her
.
<EOS>
After
a
long
search
,
I
discovered
the
place
of
her
concealment
,
the
old
hall
I
have
just
mentioned
,
and
climbed
in
the
night
,
and
at
the
hazard
of
my
life
,
to
the
window
of
the
chamber
where
she
was
confined
.
<EOS>
I
saw
and
spoke
with
her
;
and
having
arranged
a
plan
by
which
I
hoped
to
accomplish
her
deliverance
on
the
following
night
,
descended
.
<EOS>
Whether
our
brief
conference
was
overheard
,
and
communicated
to
the
earl
,
I
know
not
;
but
it
would
seem
so
,
for
he
secretly
departed
with
her
the
next
morning
,
taking
the
road
,
as
I
subsequently
learnt
,
to
London
.
<EOS>
I
instantly
started
in
pursuit
,
and
had
reached
Paddington
,
when
I
fell
ill
,
as
I
have
related
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
What
you
tell
me
in
some
measure
eases
my
mind
,
"
replied
Mr.
Bloundel
,
after
a
pause
;
"
for
I
feel
that
my
daughter
,
if
alive
,
will
be
able
to
resist
her
persecutor
.
<EOS>
What
has
become
of
your
companions
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Nizza
Macascree
has
met
with
the
same
fate
as
Amabel
,
"
replied
Leonard
.
<EOS>
"
She
was
unfortunate
enough
to
attract
the
king
's
attention
,
when
he
visited
Ashdown
Lodge
in
company
of
the
Earl
of
Rochester
,
and
was
conveyed
to
Oxford
,
where
the
court
is
now
held
,
and
must
speedily
have
fallen
a
victim
to
her
royal
lover
if
she
had
not
disappeared
,
having
been
carried
off
,
it
was
supposed
,
by
Sir
Paul
Parravicin
.
<EOS>
But
the
villain
was
frustrated
in
his
infamous
design
.
<EOS>
The
king
's
suspicion
falling
upon
him
,
he
was
instantly
arrested
;
and
though
he
denied
all
knowledge
of
Nizza
's
retreat
,
and
was
afterwards
liberated
,
his
movements
were
so
strictly
watched
,
that
he
had
no
opportunity
of
visiting
her
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
do
not
mention
Blaize
,
"
said
Mr.
Bloundel
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
ill
,
I
trust
,
has
befallen
him
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
grieve
to
say
he
has
been
attacked
by
the
distemper
he
so
much
dreaded
,
"
replied
Leonard
.
"
<EOS>
He
accompanied
me
to
London
,
but
quitted
me
when
I
fell
sick
,
and
took
refuge
with
a
farmer
named
Wingfield
,
residing
near
Kensal
Green
.
<EOS>
I
accidentally
met
Wingfield
this
morning
,
and
he
informed
me
that
Blaize
was
taken
ill
the
day
before
yesterday
,
and
removed
to
the
pest
-
house
in
Finsbury
Fields
.
<EOS>
I
will
go
thither
presently
,
and
see
what
has
become
of
him
.
<EOS>
Is
Doctor
Hodges
still
among
the
living
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
trust
so
,
"
replied
Mr.
Bloundel
,
"
though
I
have
not
seen
him
for
the
last
ten
days
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
He
then
disappeared
for
a
few
minutes
,
and
on
his
return
lowered
a
small
basket
containing
a
flask
of
canary
,
a
loaf
which
he
himself
had
baked
,
and
a
piece
of
cold
boiled
beef
.
<EOS>
The
apprentice
thankfully
received
the
provisions
,
and
retiring
to
the
hutch
,
began
to
discuss
them
,
fortifying
himself
with
a
copious
draught
of
canary
.
<EOS>
Having
concluded
his
repast
,
he
issued
forth
,
and
acquainting
Mr.
Bloundel
,
who
had
at
length
ventured
to
commence
reading
the
contents
of
the
packet
by
the
aid
of
powerful
glasses
,
that
he
was
about
to
proceed
to
Dr.
Hodges
's
residence
,
to
inquire
after
him
,
set
off
in
that
direction
.
 
<EOS>
Arrived
in
Great
Knightrider
-
street
,
he
was
greatly
shocked
at
finding
the
door
of
the
doctor
's
habitation
fastened
,
nor
could
he
make
any
one
hear
,
though
he
knocked
loudly
and
repeatedly
against
it
.
<EOS>
The
shutters
of
the
lower
windows
were
closed
,
and
the
place
looked
completely
deserted
.
<EOS>
All
the
adjoining
houses
were
shut
up
,
and
not
a
living
being
could
be
discerned
in
the
street
from
whom
information
could
be
obtained
relative
to
the
physician
.
<EOS>
Here
,
as
elsewhere
,
the
pavement
was
overgrown
with
grass
,
and
the
very
houses
had
a
strange
and
melancholy
look
,
as
if
sharing
in
the
general
desolation
.
<EOS>
On
looking
down
a
narrow
street
leading
to
the
river
,
Leonard
perceived
a
flock
of
poultry
scratching
among
the
staves
in
search
of
food
,
and
instinctively
calling
them
,
they
flew
towards
him
,
as
if
delighted
at
the
unwonted
sound
of
a
human
voice
.
<EOS>
These
,
and
a
half
-
starved
cat
,
were
the
only
things
living
that
he
could
perceive
.
<EOS>
At
the
further
end
of
the
street
he
caught
sight
of
the
river
,
speeding
in
its
course
towards
the
bridge
,
and
scarcely
knowing
whither
he
was
going
,
sauntered
to
its
edge
.
<EOS>
The
tide
had
just
turned
,
and
the
stream
was
sparkling
in
the
sunshine
,
but
no
craft
could
be
discovered
upon
its
bosom
;
and
except
a
few
barges
moored
to
its
sides
,
all
vestiges
of
the
numberless
vessels
with
which
it
was
once
crowded
were
gone
.
<EOS>
Its
quays
were
completely
deserted
.
<EOS>
Boxes
and
bales
of
goods
lay
untouched
on
the
wharves
;
the
cheering
cries
with
which
the
workmen
formerly
animated
their
labour
were
hushed
.
<EOS>
There
was
no
sound
of
creaking
cords
,
no
rattle
of
heavy
chains
--
none
of
the
busy
hum
ordinarily
attending
the
discharge
of
freight
from
a
vessel
,
or
the
packing
of
goods
and
stores
on
board
.
<EOS>
All
traffic
was
at
an
end
;
and
this
scene
,
usually
one
of
the
liveliest
possible
,
was
now
forlorn
and
desolate
.
<EOS>
On
the
opposite
shore
of
the
river
it
appeared
to
be
the
same
--
indeed
,
the
borough
of
Southwark
was
now
suffering
the
utmost
rigour
of
the
scourge
,
and
except
for
the
rows
of
houses
on
its
banks
,
and
the
noble
bridge
by
which
it
was
spanned
,
the
Thames
appeared
as
undisturbed
as
it
must
have
been
before
the
great
city
was
built
upon
its
banks
.
 
<EOS>
The
apprentice
viewed
this
scene
with
a
singular
kind
of
interest
.
<EOS>
He
had
become
so
accustomed
to
melancholy
sights
,
that
his
feelings
had
lost
their
acuteness
,
and
the
contemplation
of
the
deserted
buildings
and
neglected
wharves
around
him
harmonized
with
his
own
gloomy
thoughts
.
<EOS>
Pursuing
his
walk
along
the
side
of
the
river
,
he
was
checked
by
a
horrible
smell
,
and
looking
downward
,
he
perceived
a
carcass
in
the
last
stage
of
decomposition
lying
in
the
mud
.
<EOS>
It
had
been
washed
ashore
by
the
tide
,
and
a
large
bird
of
prey
was
contending
for
the
possession
of
it
with
a
legion
of
water
-
rats
.
<EOS>
Sickened
by
the
sight
,
he
turned
up
a
narrow
thoroughfare
near
Baynard
's
Castle
,
and
crossing
Thames
-
street
,
was
about
to
ascend
Addle
-
hill
,
when
he
perceived
a
man
wheeling
a
hand
-
barrow
,
containing
a
couple
of
corpses
,
in
the
direction
of
the
river
,
with
the
intention
,
doubtless
,
of
throwing
them
into
it
,
as
the
readiest
means
of
disposing
of
them
.
<EOS>
Both
bodies
were
stripped
of
their
clothing
,
and
the
blue
tint
of
the
nails
,
as
well
as
the
blotches
with
which
they
were
covered
,
left
no
doubt
as
to
the
disease
of
which
they
had
died
.
<EOS>
Averting
his
gaze
from
the
spectacle
,
Leonard
turned
off
on
the
right
along
Carter
-
lane
,
and
threading
a
short
passage
,
approached
the
southern
boundary
of
the
cathedral
;
and
proceeding
towards
the
great
door
opposite
him
,
passed
through
it
.
<EOS>
The
mighty
lazar
-
house
was
less
crowded
than
he
expected
to
find
it
,
but
its
terrible
condition
far
exceeded
his
worst
conceptions
.
<EOS>
Not
more
than
half
the
pallets
were
occupied
;
but
as
the
sick
were
in
a
great
measure
left
to
themselves
,
the
utmost
disorder
prevailed
.
<EOS>
A
troop
of
lazars
,
with
sheets
folded
around
them
,
glided
,
like
phantoms
,
along
Paul
's
Walk
,
and
mimicked
in
a
ghastly
manner
the
air
and
deportment
of
the
gallants
who
had
formerly
thronged
the
place
.
<EOS>
No
attempt
being
made
to
maintain
silence
,
the
noise
was
perfectly
stunning
;
some
of
the
sick
were
shrieking
--
<EOS>
some
laughing
in
a
wild
unearthly
manner
--
<EOS>
some
praying
--
some
uttering
loud
execrations
--
others
groaning
and
lamenting
.
<EOS>
The
holy
building
seemed
to
have
become
the
abode
of
evil
and
tormented
spirits
.
<EOS>
Many
dead
were
lying
in
the
beds
--
the
few
attendants
who
were
present
not
caring
to
remove
them
;
and
Leonard
had
little
doubt
,
that
before
another
sun
went
down
the
whole
of
the
ghastly
assemblage
before
him
would
share
their
fate
.
<EOS>
If
the
habitations
he
had
recently
gazed
upon
had
appeared
plague
-
stricken
,
the
sacred
structure
in
which
he
was
now
standing
seemed
yet
more
horribly
contaminated
.
<EOS>
Ill
-
kept
and
ill
-
ventilated
,
the
air
was
loaded
with
noxious
effluvia
,
while
the
various
abominations
that
met
the
eye
at
every
turn
would
have
been
sufficient
to
produce
the
distemper
in
any
one
who
had
come
in
contact
with
them
.
<EOS>
They
were
,
however
,
utterly
disregarded
by
the
miserable
sufferers
and
their
attendants
.
<EOS>
The
magnificent
painted
windows
were
dimmed
by
a
thick
clammy
steam
,
which
could
scarcely
be
washed
off
--
while
the
carved
oak
screens
,
the
sculptured
tombs
,
the
pillars
,
the
walls
,
and
the
flagged
floors
were
covered
with
impurities
.
 
<EOS>
Satisfied
with
a
brief
survey
of
this
frightful
scene
,
Leonard
turned
to
depart
,
and
was
passing
the
entrance
to
Saint
Faith
's
,
which
stood
open
,
when
he
caught
sight
of
Judith
standing
at
the
foot
of
the
broad
stone
steps
,
and
holding
a
lamp
in
her
hand
.
<EOS>
She
was
conversing
with
a
tall
richly
-
dressed
man
,
whose
features
he
fancied
he
had
seen
before
,
though
he
could
not
at
the
moment
call
them
to
mind
.
<EOS>
After
a
brief
conversation
,
they
moved
off
into
the
depths
of
the
vault
,
and
he
lost
eight
of
them
.
<EOS>
All
at
once
it
occurred
to
Leonard
that
Judith
's
companion
was
the
unfortunate
stranger
whose
child
he
had
interred
,
and
who
had
been
so
strangely
affected
at
the
sight
of
Nizza
Macascree
.
<EOS>
Determined
to
ascertain
the
point
,
he
hurried
down
the
steps
and
plunged
into
the
vault
.
<EOS>
It
was
buried
in
profound
darkness
,
and
he
had
not
proceeded
far
when
he
stumbled
over
something
lying
in
his
path
,
and
found
from
the
groan
that
followed
that
it
was
a
plague
-
patient
.
<EOS>
Before
he
could
regain
his
feet
,
the
unfortunate
sufferer
whom
he
had
thus
disturbed
implored
him
,
in
piteous
accents
,
which
,
with
a
shudder
,
he
recognised
as
those
of
Blaize
,
to
remove
him
.
<EOS>
Leonard
immediately
gave
the
poor
porter
to
understand
that
he
was
near
him
,
and
would
render
him
every
aid
in
his
power
.
 
<EOS>
"
Your
assistance
comes
too
late
,
Leonard
,
"
groaned
<EOS>
Blaize--"it
's
all
over
with
me
now
,
<EOS>
but
I
do
n't
like
to
breathe
my
last
in
this
dismal
vault
,
without
medicine
or
food
,
both
of
which
I
am
denied
by
that
infernal
hag
Mother
Malmayns
,
who
calls
herself
a
nurse
,
but
who
is
in
reality
a
robber
and
murderess
.
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
the
frightful
scenes
I
have
witnessed
since
I
have
been
brought
here
!
<EOS>
I
told
you
I
should
not
escape
the
plague
.
<EOS>
I
shall
die
of
it
<EOS>
--
I
am
sure
I
shall
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
thought
you
were
at
the
pest
-
house
in
Finsbury
Fields
,
"
said
Leonard
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
was
taken
there
,
"
replied
Blaize
;
"
but
the
place
was
full
,
and
they
would
not
admit
me
,
so
I
was
sent
to
Saint
Paul
's
,
where
there
was
plenty
of
room
.
<EOS>
Yesterday
I
did
pretty
well
,
for
I
was
in
the
great
ward
above
,
and
one
of
the
attendants
obeyed
my
directions
implicitly
,
and
I
am
certain
<EOS>
if
they
had
been
fully
carried
out
,
I
should
have
got
well
.
<EOS>
I
will
tell
you
what
I
did
.
<EOS>
As
soon
as
I
was
placed
on
a
pallet
,
and
covered
with
blankets
,
I
ordered
a
drink
to
be
prepared
of
the
inner
bark
of
an
ash
-
tree
,
green
walnuts
,
scabious
vervain
,
and
saffron
,
boiled
in
two
quarts
of
the
strongest
vinegar
.
<EOS>
Of
this
mixture
I
drank
plentifully
,
and
it
soon
produced
a
plentiful
perspiration
.
<EOS>
I
next
had
a
hen
--
a
live
one
,
of
course
--
stripped
of
the
feathers
,
and
brought
to
me
.
<EOS>
Its
bill
was
held
to
the
large
blotch
under
my
arm
,
and
kept
there
till
the
fowl
died
from
the
noxious
matter
it
drew
forth
.
<EOS>
I
next
repeated
the
experiment
with
a
pigeon
,
and
derived
the
greatest
benefit
from
it
.
<EOS>
The
tumour
had
nearly
subsided
,
and
if
I
had
been
properly
treated
afterwards
,
I
should
now
be
in
a
fair
way
of
recovery
.
<EOS>
But
instead
of
nice
strengthening
chicken
-
broth
,
flavoured
with
succory
and
marigolds
;
or
water
-
gruel
,
mixed
with
rosemary
and
winter
-
savory
;
or
a
panado
,
seasoned
with
verjuice
or
wood
-
sorrel
;
instead
of
swallowing
large
draughts
of
warm
beer
;
or
water
boiled
with
carduus
seeds
;
or
a
posset
drink
,
made
with
sorrel
,
bugloss
,
and
borage;--instead
of
these
remedies
,
or
any
other
,
I
was
carried
to
this
horrible
place
when
I
was
asleep
,
and
strapped
to
my
pallet
,
as
you
perceive
.
<EOS>
Unloose
me
,
if
you
can
do
nothing
else
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
That
I
will
readily
do
,
"
replied
Leonard
;
"
but
I
must
first
procure
a
light
.
<EOS>
"
With
this
,
he
groped
his
way
among
the
close
ranks
of
ponderous
pillars
,
but
though
he
proceeded
with
the
utmost
caution
,
he
could
not
avoid
coming
in
contact
with
the
beds
of
some
of
the
other
patients
,
and
disturbing
them
.
<EOS>
At
length
he
descried
a
glimmer
of
light
issuing
from
a
door
which
he
knew
to
be
that
of
the
vestry
,
and
which
was
standing
slightly
ajar
.
<EOS>
Opening
it
,
he
perceived
a
lamp
burning
on
the
table
,
and
without
stopping
to
look
around
him
,
seized
it
,
and
hurried
back
to
the
porter
.
<EOS>
Poor
Blaize
presented
a
lamentable
,
and
yet
grotesque
appearance
.
<EOS>
His
plump
person
was
greatly
reduced
in
bulk
,
and
his
round
cheeks
had
become
hollow
and
cadaverous
.
<EOS>
He
was
strapped
,
as
he
had
stated
,
to
the
pallet
,
which
in
its
turn
was
fastened
to
the
adjoining
pillar
.
<EOS>
A
blanket
was
tightly
swathed
around
him
,
and
a
large
cloth
was
bound
round
his
head
in
lieu
of
a
nightcap
.
<EOS>
Leonard
instantly
set
about
releasing
him
,
and
had
just
unfastened
the
straps
when
he
heard
footsteps
approaching
,
and
looking
up
,
perceived
the
stranger
and
Judith
Malmayns
advancing
towards
him
.
  
<EOS>
II
.
 
<EOS>
THE
SECOND
PLAGUE
-
PIT
.
 
<EOS>
Judith
,
being
a
little
in
advance
of
her
companion
,
took
Leonard
in
the
first
instance
for
a
chirurgeon
's
assistant
,
and
called
to
him
,
in
a
harsh
and
menacing
voice
,
to
let
her
charge
alone
.
<EOS>
On
drawing
near
,
however
,
she
perceived
her
mistake
,
and
recognising
the
apprentice
,
halted
with
a
disconcerted
look
.
<EOS>
By
this
time
,
the
stranger
had
come
up
,
and
remarking
her
embarrassment
,
inquired
the
cause
of
it
.
 
<EOS>
"
Look
there
,
"
cried
Judith
,
pointing
towards
the
apprentice
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yonder
stands
the
very
man
you
seek
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
What
!
<EOS>
Leonard
Holt
,
"
cried
the
other
,
in
astonishment
.
 
<EOS>
"
Ay
,
Leonard
Holt
,
"
rejoined
Judith
.
<EOS>
"
You
can
now
put
any
questions
to
him
you
think
proper
.
"
 
<EOS>
The
stranger
did
not
require
the
suggestion
to
be
repeated
,
but
instantly
hastened
to
the
apprentice
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Do
you
remember
me
?
"
<EOS>
he
asked
.
 
<EOS>
Leonard
answered
in
the
affirmative
.
<EOS>
"
I
owe
you
a
large
debt
of
obligation
,
"
continued
the
stranger
,
"
and
you
shall
not
find
me
slow
in
paying
it
.
<EOS>
But
let
it
pass
for
the
moment
.
<EOS>
Do
you
know
aught
of
Nizza
Macascree
?
<EOS>
I
know
she
was
taken
to
Oxford
by
the
king
,
and
subsequently
disappeared
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Then
you
know
as
much
as
I
do
of
her
,
sir
,
"
rejoined
Leonard
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
was
right
,
you
see
,
Mr.
Thirlby
,
"
interposed
Judith
,
with
a
malicious
grin
.
<EOS>
"
I
told
you
this
youth
would
be
utterly
ignorant
of
her
retreat
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
My
firm
conviction
is
,
that
she
is
in
the
power
of
Sir
Paul
Parravicin
,
"
observed
Leonard
.
"
<EOS>
But
it
is
impossible
to
say
where
she
is
concealed
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Then
my
last
hope
of
finding
her
has
fallen
to
the
ground
,
"
replied
Thirlby
,
with
a
look
of
great
distress
.
<EOS>
"
Ever
since
my
recovery
from
the
plague
,
I
have
been
in
search
of
her
.
<EOS>
I
traced
her
from
Ashdown
Park
to
Oxford
,
but
she
was
gone
before
my
arrival
at
the
latter
place
;
and
though
I
made
every
possible
inquiry
after
her
,
and
kept
strict
and
secret
watch
upon
the
villain
whom
I
suspected
,
as
you
do
,
of
carrying
her
off
,
I
could
gain
no
clue
to
her
retreat
.
<EOS>
Having
ascertained
,
however
,
that
you
were
seen
in
the
neighbourhood
of
Oxford
about
the
time
of
her
disappearance
,
I
had
persuaded
myself
you
must
have
aided
her
escape
.
<EOS>
But
now
,
"
he
added
,
with
a
groan
,
"
I
find
I
was
mistaken
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
were
so
,
"
replied
Leonard
,
mournfully
;
"
I
was
in
search
of
my
master
's
daughter
,
Amabel
,
who
was
carried
off
at
the
same
time
by
the
Earl
of
Rochester
,
and
my
anxiety
about
her
made
me
neglectful
of
Nizza
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
not
ignorant
of
your
devoted
attachment
to
her
,
"
remarked
the
stranger
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
will
never
find
Amabel
again
,
"
observed
Judith
,
bitterly
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
mean
you
woman
?
"
asked
Leonard
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
mean
what
I
say
,
"
rejoined
Judith
.
<EOS>
"
I
repeat
,
you
will
never
see
her
again
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
would
not
speak
thus
positively
without
some
motive
,
"
returned
Leonard
,
seizing
her
arm
.
<EOS>
"
Where
is
she
?
<EOS>
What
has
happened
to
her
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
That
you
shall
never
learn
from
me
,
"
returned
Judith
,
with
a
triumphant
glance
.
 
<EOS>
"
Speak
,
or
I
will
force
you
to
do
so
,
"
cried
Leonard
,
furiously
.
 
<EOS>
"
Force
me
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Judith
,
laughing
derisively
;
"
you
know
not
whom
you
threaten
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
But
_
I
_
do
,
"
interposed
Thirlby
.
"
<EOS>
This
young
man
_
shall
_
have
an
answer
to
this
question
,
"
he
continued
,
addressing
her
in
an
authoritative
tone
.
<EOS>
"
Do
you
know
anything
of
the
girl
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
replied
Judith
;
"
I
was
merely
jesting
with
him
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Shame
on
you
,
to
trifle
with
his
feelings
thus
,
"
rejoined
Thirlby
.
<EOS>
"
Step
with
me
this
way
,
young
man
,
I
wish
to
speak
with
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Do
not
leave
me
here
,
Leonard
,
"
cried
Blaize
,
"
or
I
shall
die
before
you
come
back
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
no
intention
of
leaving
you
,
"
rejoined
Leonard
.
<EOS>
"
Are
you
aware
whether
Doctor
Hodges
is
still
alive
,
sir
?
"
<EOS>
he
added
to
Thirlby
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
just
been
to
his
residence
in
Great
Knight
-
rider
-
street
,
and
found
it
shut
up
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
He
has
removed
to
Watling
-
street
,
"
replied
the
other
;
"
but
I
have
not
seen
him
since
my
return
to
London
.
<EOS>
If
you
wish
it
,
I
will
go
to
his
house
at
once
,
and
send
him
to
look
after
your
poor
friend
.
"
 
<EOS>
Leonard
was
about
to
return
thanks
for
the
offer
,
when
the
design
was
frustrated
by
Blaize
himself
,
who
was
so
terrified
by
Judith
's
looks
,
that
he
could
pay
no
attention
to
what
was
going
forward
;
and
fearing
,
notwithstanding
Leonard
's
assurance
to
the
contrary
,
that
he
should
be
left
behind
,
he
started
to
his
feet
,
and
wrapping
the
blanket
about
him
,
ran
up
the
steps
leading
to
the
cathedral
.
<EOS>
Leonard
and
Thirlby
followed
,
and
seeing
him
dart
into
the
southern
aisle
,
would
have
pursued
him
along
it
,
but
were
afraid
of
coming
in
contact
with
the
many
sick
persons
by
whom
it
was
thronged
.
<EOS>
They
contented
themselves
,
therefore
,
with
watching
his
course
,
and
were
not
a
little
surprised
and
alarmed
to
find
the
whole
troop
of
lazars
set
off
after
him
,
making
the
sacred
walls
ring
with
their
cries
.
<EOS>
Frightened
by
the
clamour
,
Blaize
redoubled
his
speed
,
and
,
with
this
ghastly
train
at
his
heels
,
crossed
the
lower
part
of
the
mid
-
aisle
,
and
darting
through
the
pillars
,
took
refuge
within
Bishop
Kempe
's
Chapel
,
the
door
of
which
stood
open
,
and
which
he
instantly
closed
after
him
.
<EOS>
Judith
,
who
had
followed
the
party
from
the
subterranean
church
,
laughed
heartily
at
the
chase
of
the
poor
porter
,
and
uttered
an
exclamation
of
regret
at
its
sudden
conclusion
.
<EOS>
Leonard
,
however
,
being
apprehensive
of
mischief
from
the
crowd
of
sick
persons
collected
before
the
door
,
some
of
whom
were
knocking
against
it
and
trying
to
force
it
open
,
addressed
himself
to
a
couple
of
the
attendants
,
and
prevailed
on
them
to
accompany
him
to
the
chapel
.
<EOS>
The
assemblage
was
speedily
dispersed
,
and
Blaize
hearing
Leonard
's
voice
,
instantly
opened
the
door
and
admitted
him
;
and
,
as
soon
as
his
fears
were
allayed
,
he
was
placed
on
a
pallet
within
the
chapel
,
and
wrapped
up
in
blankets
,
while
such
remedies
as
were
deemed
proper
were
administered
to
him
.
<EOS>
Committing
him
to
the
care
of
the
attendants
,
and
promising
to
reward
them
well
for
their
trouble
,
Leonard
told
Blaize
he
should
go
and
bring
Doctor
Hodges
to
him
.
<EOS>
Accordingly
,
he
departed
,
and
finding
Thirlby
waiting
for
him
at
the
south
door
,
they
went
forth
together
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
almost
afraid
of
leaving
the
poor
fellow
,
"
said
Leonard
,
hesitating
as
he
was
about
to
descends
the
steps
.
"
<EOS>
Judith
Malmayns
is
so
cunning
and
unscrupulous
,
that
she
may
find
some
means
of
doing
him
an
injury
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Have
no
fear
,
"
replied
Thirlby
;
"
she
has
promised
me
not
to
molest
him
further
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
appear
to
have
a
strange
influence
over
her
,
then
,
"
observed
Leonard
.
<EOS>
"
May
I
ask
how
you
have
attained
it
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
No
matter
,
"
replied
the
other
.
<EOS>
"
It
must
suffice
that
I
am
willing
to
exercise
it
in
your
behalf
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
And
you
are
not
disposed
to
tell
me
the
nature
of
the
interest
you
feel
in
Nizza
Macascree
?
"
pursued
Leonard
.
 
<EOS>
"
Not
as
yet
,
"
replied
Thirlby
,
with
a
look
and
tone
calculated
to
put
a
stop
to
further
inquiries
.
 
<EOS>
Passing
through
Saint
Austin
's
Gate
,
they
approached
Watling
-
street
,
at
the
corner
of
which
stood
the
house
where
Doctor
Hodges
had
taken
up
his
temporary
abode
,
that
he
might
visit
the
sick
in
the
cathedral
with
greater
convenience
,
and
be
more
readily
summoned
whenever
his
attendance
might
be
required
.
<EOS>
Thirlby
's
knock
at
the
door
was
answered
,
to
Leonard
's
great
satisfaction
,
by
the
old
porter
,
who
was
equally
delighted
to
see
him
.
 
<EOS>
It
did
not
escape
Leonard
that
the
porter
treated
the
stranger
with
great
respect
,
and
he
inferred
from
this
that
he
was
a
person
of
some
consideration
,
as
indeed
his
deportment
bespoke
him
.
<EOS>
The
old
man
informed
them
that
his
master
had
been
summoned
on
a
case
of
urgency
early
in
the
morning
,
and
had
not
yet
returned
,
neither
was
he
aware
whither
he
was
gone
.
<EOS>
He
promised
,
however
,
to
acquaint
him
with
Blaize
's
condition
immediately
on
his
return--"and
<EOS>
I
need
not
assure
you
,
"
he
added
to
Leonard
,
"
that
he
will
instantly
go
to
him
.
"
<EOS>
Thirlby
then
inquired
of
the
porter
whether
Mike
Macascree
,
the
blind
piper
,
was
still
at
Dame
Lucas
's
cottage
,
in
Finsbury
Fields
,
and
was
answered
in
the
affirmative
by
the
old
man
,
who
added
,
however
,
in
a
voice
of
much
emotion
,
that
the
good
dame
herself
was
no
more
.
 
<EOS>
"
She
died
about
a
fortnight
ago
of
the
plague
,
"
he
said
,
"
and
is
buried
where
she
desired
to
be
,
beneath
an
old
apple
-
tree
in
her
garden
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Alas
!
"
exclaimed
Leonard
,
brushing
away
a
tear
,
"
her
own
foreboding
is
too
truly
realised
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
about
to
visit
the
old
piper
,
"
observed
Thirlby
to
the
apprentice
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Will
you
go
with
me
?
"
 
<EOS>
The
other
readily
acquiesced
,
only
stipulating
that
they
should
call
in
Wood
-
street
on
the
way
,
that
he
might
inquire
whether
his
master
wanted
him
.
<EOS>
Thirlby
agreeing
to
this
,
and
the
old
porter
repeating
his
assurance
that
Leonard
might
make
himself
quite
easy
as
to
Blaize
,
for
he
would
send
his
master
to
him
the
instant
he
returned
,
they
set
out
.
<EOS>
On
reaching
Wood
-
street
the
apprentice
gave
the
customary
signal
,
and
the
grocer
answering
it
,
he
informed
him
of
his
unexpected
meeting
with
Blaize
,
and
of
the
state
in
which
he
had
left
him
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Bloundel
was
much
distressed
by
the
intelligence
,
and
telling
Leonard
that
he
should
not
require
him
again
that
night
,
besought
him
to
observe
the
utmost
caution
.
<EOS>
This
the
apprentice
promised
,
and
joining
Thirlby
,
who
had
walked
forward
to
a
little
distance
,
they
struck
into
a
narrow
street
on
the
right
,
and
proceeding
along
Aldermanbury
,
soon
arrived
at
the
first
postern
in
the
city
walls
beyond
Cripplegate
.
 
<EOS>
Hitherto
,
Thirlby
had
maintained
a
profound
silence
,
and
appeared
lost
in
melancholy
reflection
.
<EOS>
Except
now
and
then
casting
a
commiserating
glance
at
the
wretched
objects
they
encountered
on
the
road
,
he
kept
his
eyes
steadily
fixed
upon
the
ground
,
and
walked
at
a
brisky
pace
,
as
if
desirous
of
getting
out
of
the
city
as
quickly
as
possible
.
<EOS>
Notwithstanding
his
weakness
,
Leonard
managed
to
keep
up
with
him
,
and
his
curiosity
being
greatly
aroused
by
what
had
just
occurred
,
he
began
to
study
his
appearance
and
features
attentively
.
<EOS>
Thirlby
was
full
six
feet
in
height
,
and
possessed
a
powerful
and
well
-
proportioned
figure
,
and
would
have
been
considered
extremely
handsome
but
for
a
certain
sinister
expression
about
the
eyes
,
which
were
large
and
dark
,
but
lighted
by
a
fierce
and
peculiar
fire
.
<EOS>
His
complexion
was
dark
,
and
his
countenance
still
bore
the
impress
of
the
dreadful
disease
from
which
he
had
recently
recovered
.
<EOS>
A
gloomy
shade
sat
about
his
brow
,
and
it
seemed
to
Leonard
as
if
he
had
been
led
by
his
passions
into
the
commission
of
crimes
of
which
he
had
afterwards
bitterly
repented
.
<EOS>
His
deportment
was
proud
and
commanding
,
and
though
he
exhibited
no
haughtiness
towards
the
apprentice
,
but
,
on
the
contrary
,
treated
him
with
great
familiarity
,
it
was
plain
<EOS>
he
did
so
merely
from
a
sense
of
gratitude
.
<EOS>
His
age
was
under
forty
,
and
his
habiliments
were
rich
,
though
of
a
sombre
colour
.
 
<EOS>
Passing
through
the
postern
,
which
stood
wide
open
,
the
watchman
having
disappeared
,
they
entered
a
narrow
lane
,
skirted
by
a
few
detached
houses
,
all
of
which
were
shut
up
,
and
marked
by
the
fatal
cross
.
<EOS>
As
they
passed
one
of
these
habitations
,
they
were
arrested
by
loud
and
continued
shrieks
of
the
most
heart
-
rending
nature
,
and
questioning
a
watchman
who
stood
at
an
adjoining
door
,
as
to
the
cause
of
them
,
he
said
they
proceeded
from
a
poor
lady
who
had
just
lost
the
last
of
her
family
by
the
plague
.
 
<EOS>
"
Her
husband
and
all
her
children
,
except
one
daughter
,
died
last
week
,
"
said
the
man
,
"
and
though
she
seemed
deeply
afflicted
,
yet
she
bore
her
loss
with
resignation
.
<EOS>
Yesterday
,
her
daughter
was
taken
ill
,
and
she
died
about
two
hours
ago
,
since
when
the
poor
mother
has
done
nothing
but
shriek
in
the
way
you
hear
.
<EOS>
Poor
soul
!
<EOS>
she
will
die
of
grief
,
as
many
have
done
before
her
at
this
awful
time
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Something
must
be
done
to
pacify
her
,
"
returned
Thirlby
,
in
a
voice
of
much
emotion,--"she
must
be
removed
from
her
child
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Where
can
she
be
removed
to
?
"
rejoined
the
watchman
.
<EOS>
"
Who
will
receive
her
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
At
all
events
,
we
can
remove
the
object
that
occasions
her
affliction
,
"
rejoined
Thirlby
.
<EOS>
"
My
heart
bleeds
for
her
.
<EOS>
I
never
heard
shrieks
so
dreadful
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
The
dead
-
cart
will
pass
by
in
an
hour
,
"
said
the
watchman
;
"
and
then
the
body
can
be
taken
away
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
An
hour
will
be
too
late
,
"
rejoined
Thirlby
.
<EOS>
"
If
she
continues
in
this
frantic
state
,
she
will
be
dead
before
that
time
.
<EOS>
You
have
a
hand
-
barrow
there
.
<EOS>
Take
the
body
to
the
plague
-
pit
at
once
,
and
I
will
reward
you
for
your
trouble
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
We
shall
find
some
difficulty
in
getting
into
the
house
,
"
said
the
watchman
,
who
evidently
felt
some
repugnance
to
the
task
.
 
<EOS>
"
Not
so
,
"
replied
Thirlby
.
<EOS>
And
pushing
forcibly
against
the
door
,
he
burst
it
open
,
and
,
directed
by
the
cries
,
entered
a
room
on
the
right
.
<EOS>
The
watchman
's
statement
proved
correct
.
<EOS>
Stretched
upon
a
bed
in
one
corner
lay
the
body
of
a
beautiful
girl
,
while
the
poor
mother
was
bending
over
it
in
a
state
bordering
on
distraction
.
<EOS>
On
seeing
Thirlby
,
she
fled
to
the
further
end
of
the
room
,
but
did
not
desist
from
her
cries
.
<EOS>
In
fact
,
she
was
unable
to
do
so
,
being
under
the
dominion
of
the
wildest
hysterical
passion
.
<EOS>
In
vain
Thirlby
endeavoured
to
make
her
comprehend
by
signs
the
nature
of
his
errand
.
<EOS>
Waving
him
off
,
she
continued
shrieking
more
loudly
than
ever
.
<EOS>
Half
-
stunned
by
the
cries
,
and
greatly
agitated
by
the
sight
of
the
child
,
whose
appearance
reminded
him
of
his
own
daughter
,
Thirlby
motioned
the
watchman
,
who
had
followed
him
into
the
room
,
to
bring
away
the
body
,
and
rushed
forth
.
<EOS>
His
injunctions
were
obeyed
.
<EOS>
The
remains
of
the
unfortunate
girl
were
wrapped
in
a
sheet
,
and
deposited
in
the
hand
-
barrow
.
<EOS>
The
miserable
mother
followed
the
watchman
to
the
door
,
but
did
not
attempt
to
interfere
with
him
,
and
having
seen
the
body
of
her
child
disposed
of
in
the
manner
above
described
,
turned
back
.
<EOS>
The
next
moment
,
a
heavy
sound
proclaimed
that
she
had
fallen
to
the
ground
,
and
her
shrieks
were
hushed
.
<EOS>
Thirlby
and
Leonard
exchanged
sad
and
significant
looks
,
but
neither
of
them
went
back
to
see
what
had
happened
to
her
.
<EOS>
The
watchman
shook
his
head
,
and
setting
the
barrow
in
motion
,
proceeded
along
a
narrow
footpath
across
the
fields
.
<EOS>
Remarking
that
he
did
not
take
the
direct
road
to
the
plague
-
pit
,
Leonard
called
to
him
,
and
pointed
out
the
corner
in
which
it
lay
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
know
where
the
old
plague
-
pit
is
,
as
well
as
you
,
"
replied
the
watchman
,
"
but
it
has
been
filled
these
three
weeks
.
<EOS>
The
new
pit
lies
in
this
direction
.
"
<EOS>
So
saying
,
he
pursued
his
course
,
and
they
presently
entered
a
field
,
in
the
middle
of
which
lay
the
plague
-
pit
,
as
was
evident
from
the
immense
mound
of
clay
thrown
out
of
the
excavation
.
 
<EOS>
"
That
pit
is
neither
so
deep
nor
so
wide
as
the
old
one
,
"
said
the
watchman
,
"
and
if
the
plague
goes
on
at
this
rate
,
they
will
soon
have
to
dig
another
--
that
is
,
if
any
one
should
be
left
alive
to
undertake
the
job
.
"
 
<EOS>
And
chuckling
as
if
he
had
said
a
good
thing
,
he
impelled
his
barrow
forward
more
quickly
.
<EOS>
A
few
seconds
brought
them
near
the
horrible
chasm
.
<EOS>
It
was
more
than
half
full
,
and
in
all
respects
resembled
the
other
pit
,
except
that
it
was
somewhat
smaller
.
<EOS>
There
was
the
same
heaving
and
putrefying
mass,--the
same
ghastly
objects
of
every
kind,--the
grey
-
headed
old
man
,
the
dark
-
haired
maiden
,
the
tender
infant,--all
huddled
together
.
<EOS>
Wheeling
the
barrow
to
the
edge
of
the
pit
,
the
watchman
cast
his
load
into
it
;
and
without
even
tarrying
to
throw
a
handful
of
soil
over
it
,
turned
back
,
and
rejoined
Thirlby
,
who
had
halted
at
some
distance
from
the
excavation
.
<EOS>
While
the
latter
was
searching
for
his
purse
to
reward
the
watchman
,
they
heard
wild
shrieks
in
the
adjoining
field
,
and
the
next
moment
perceived
the
wretched
mother
running
towards
them
.
<EOS>
Guessing
her
purpose
from
his
former
experience
,
Leonard
called
to
the
others
to
stop
her
,
and
stretching
out
his
arms
,
placed
himself
in
her
path
.
<EOS>
But
all
their
efforts
were
in
vain
.
<EOS>
She
darted
past
them
,
and
though
Leonard
caught
hold
of
her
,
she
broke
from
him
,
and
leaving
a
fragment
of
her
dress
in
his
grasp
,
flung
herself
into
the
chasm
.
 
<EOS>
Well
knowing
that
all
help
was
vain
,
Thirlby
placed
a
few
pieces
of
money
in
the
watchman
's
hand
,
and
hurried
away
.
<EOS>
He
was
followed
by
Leonard
,
who
was
equally
eager
to
quit
the
spot
.
<EOS>
It
so
chanced
that
the
path
they
had
taken
led
them
near
the
site
of
the
old
plague
-
pit
,
and
Leonard
pointed
it
out
to
his
companion
.
<EOS>
The
latter
stopped
for
a
moment
,
and
then
,
without
saying
a
word
,
ran
quickly
towards
it
.
<EOS>
On
reaching
the
spot
,
they
found
that
the
pit
was
completely
filled
up
.
<EOS>
The
vast
cake
of
clay
with
which
it
was
covered
had
swollen
and
cracked
in
an
extraordinary
manner
,
and
emitted
such
a
horrible
effluvium
that
they
both
instantly
retreated
.
 
<EOS>
"
And
that
is
the
grave
of
my
poor
child
,
"
cried
Thirlby
,
halting
,
and
bursting
into
a
passionate
flood
of
tears
.
<EOS>
"
It
would
have
been
a
fitting
resting
-
place
for
a
guilty
wretch
like
me
;
but
for
her
it
is
horrible
.
"
 
<EOS>
Allowing
time
for
the
violence
of
his
grief
to
subside
,
Leonard
addressed
a
few
words
of
consolation
to
him
,
and
then
tried
to
turn
the
current
of
his
thoughts
by
introducing
a
different
subject
.
<EOS>
With
this
view
,
he
proceeded
to
detail
the
piper
's
mysterious
conduct
as
to
the
packet
,
and
concluded
by
mentioning
the
piece
of
gold
which
Nizza
wore
as
an
amulet
,
and
which
she
fancied
must
have
some
connection
with
her
early
history
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
heard
of
the
packet
and
amulet
from
Doctor
Hodges
,
"
said
Thirlby
,
"
and
should
have
visited
the
piper
on
my
recovery
from
the
plague
,
but
I
was
all
impatience
to
behold
Nizza
,
and
could
not
brook
an
instant
's
delay
.
<EOS>
But
you
know
his
cottage
.
<EOS>
We
can
not
be
far
from
it
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Yonder
<EOS>
it
is
,
"
replied
Leonard
,
pointing
to
the
little
habitation
,
which
lay
at
a
field
's
distance
from
them--"and
<EOS>
we
are
certain
to
meet
with
him
,
for
I
hear
the
notes
of
his
pipe
.
"
 
<EOS>
Nor
was
he
deceived
,
for
as
they
crossed
the
field
,
and
approached
the
cottage
,
<EOS>
the
sounds
of
a
melancholy
air
played
on
the
pipe
became
each
instant
more
distinct
.
<EOS>
Before
entering
the
gate
,
they
paused
for
a
moment
to
listen
to
the
music
,
and
Leonard
could
not
help
contrasting
the
present
neglected
appearance
of
the
garden
with
the
neatness
it
exhibited
when
he
last
saw
it
.
<EOS>
It
was
overgrown
with
weeds
,
while
the
drooping
flowers
seemed
to
bemoan
the
loss
of
their
mistress
.
<EOS>
Leonard
's
gaze
involuntarily
wandered
in
search
of
the
old
apple
-
tree
,
and
he
presently
discovered
it
.
<EOS>
It
was
loaded
with
fruit
,
and
the
rounded
sod
beneath
it
proclaimed
the
grave
of
the
ill
-
fated
Dame
Lucas
.
 
<EOS>
Satisfied
with
this
survey
,
Leonard
opened
the
gate
,
but
had
no
sooner
set
foot
in
the
garden
than
the
loud
barking
of
a
dog
was
heard
,
and
Bell
rushed
forth
.
<EOS>
Leonard
instantly
called
to
her
,
and
on
hearing
his
voice
,
the
little
animal
instantly
changed
her
angry
tones
to
a
gladsome
whine
,
and
,
skipping
towards
him
,
fawned
at
his
feet
.
<EOS>
While
he
stooped
to
caress
her
,
the
piper
,
who
had
been
alarmed
by
the
barking
,
appeared
at
the
door
,
and
called
out
to
know
who
was
there
?
<EOS>
At
the
sight
of
him
,
Thirlby
,
who
was
close
behind
Leonard
,
uttered
a
cry
of
surprise
,
and
exclaiming
,
"
It
is
he
!
"
<EOS>
rushed
towards
him
.
 
<EOS>
The
cry
of
recognition
uttered
by
the
stranger
caused
the
piper
to
start
as
if
he
had
received
a
sudden
and
violent
shock
.
<EOS>
The
ruddy
tint
instantly
deserted
his
cheek
,
and
was
succeeded
by
a
deadly
paleness
;
his
limbs
trembled
,
and
he
bent
forward
with
a
countenance
of
the
utmost
anxiety
,
as
if
awaiting
a
confirmation
of
his
fears
.
<EOS>
When
within
a
couple
of
yards
of
him
,
Thirlby
paused
,
and
having
narrowly
scrutinized
his
features
,
as
if
to
satisfy
himself
he
was
not
mistaken
,
again
exclaimed
,
though
in
a
lower
and
deeper
tone
than
before
,
"
It
is
he
!
"
<EOS>
and
seizing
his
arm
,
pushed
him
into
the
house
,
banging
the
door
to
after
him
in
such
a
manner
as
to
leave
no
doubt
in
the
apprentice
's
mind
that
his
presence
was
not
desired
.
<EOS>
Accordingly
,
though
extremely
anxious
to
hear
what
passed
between
them
,
certain
their
conversation
must
relate
to
Nizza
Macascree
,
Leonard
did
not
attempt
to
follow
,
but
,
accompanied
by
Bell
,
who
continued
to
gambol
round
him
,
directed
his
steps
towards
the
grave
of
Dame
Lucas
.
<EOS>
Here
he
endeavoured
to
beguile
the
time
in
meditation
,
but
in
spite
of
his
efforts
to
turn
his
thoughts
into
a
different
channel
,
they
perpetually
recurred
to
what
he
supposed
to
be
taking
place
inside
the
house
.
<EOS>
The
extraordinary
effect
produced
by
Nizza
Macascree
on
Thirlby
--
the
resemblance
he
had
discovered
between
her
and
some
person
dear
to
him
--
the
anxiety
he
appeared
to
feel
for
her
,
as
evinced
by
his
recent
search
for
her
--
the
mysterious
connection
which
clearly
subsisted
between
him
and
the
piper
--
all
these
circumstances
convinced
Leonard
that
Thirlby
was
,
or
imagined
himself
,
connected
by
ties
of
the
closest
relationship
with
the
supposed
piper
's
daughter
.
 
<EOS>
Leonard
had
never
been
able
to
discern
the
slightest
resemblance
either
in
manner
or
feature
,
or
in
those
indescribably
slight
personal
peculiarities
that
constitute
a
family
likeness
,
between
Nizza
and
her
reputed
father
--
neither
could
he
now
recall
any
particular
resemblance
between
her
and
Thirlby
;
still
he
could
not
help
thinking
her
beauty
and
high
-
bred
<EOS>
looks
savoured
more
of
the
latter
than
the
former
.
<EOS>
He
came
,
therefore
,
to
the
conclusion
that
she
must
be
the
offspring
of
some
early
and
unfortunate
attachment
on
the
part
of
Thirlby
,
whose
remorse
might
naturally
be
the
consequence
of
his
culpable
conduct
at
that
time
.
<EOS>
His
sole
perplexity
was
the
piper
's
connection
with
the
affair
;
but
he
got
over
this
difficulty
by
supposing
that
Nizza
's
mother
,
whoever
she
was
,
must
have
committed
her
to
Macascree
's
care
when
an
infant
,
probably
with
strict
injunctions
,
which
circumstances
might
render
necessary
,
to
conceal
her
even
from
her
father
.
<EOS>
Such
was
Leonard
's
solution
of
the
mystery
;
and
feeling
convinced
that
he
had
made
himself
master
of
the
stranger
's
secret
,
he
resolved
to
give
him
to
understand
as
much
as
soon
as
he
beheld
him
again
.
 
<EOS>
More
than
half
an
hour
having
elapsed
,
and
Thirlby
not
coming
forth
,
Leonard
began
to
think
sufficient
time
had
been
allowed
him
for
private
conference
with
the
piper
,
and
he
therefore
walked
towards
the
door
,
and
coughing
to
announce
his
approach
,
raised
the
latch
and
entered
the
house
.
<EOS>
He
found
the
pair
seated
close
together
,
and
conversing
in
a
low
and
earnest
tone
.
<EOS>
The
piper
had
completely
recovered
from
his
alarm
,
and
seemed
perfectly
at
ease
with
his
companion
,
while
all
traces
of
anger
had
disappeared
from
the
countenance
of
the
other
.
<EOS>
Before
them
on
the
table
lay
several
letters
,
taken
from
a
packet
,
the
cover
of
which
Leonard
recognised
as
the
one
that
had
been
formerly
intrusted
to
him
.
<EOS>
Amidst
them
was
the
miniature
of
a
lady
--
at
least
,
it
appeared
so
to
Leonard
,
in
the
hasty
glance
he
caught
of
it
;
but
he
could
not
be
quite
sure
;
for
on
seeing
him
,
Thirlby
closed
the
case
,
and
placing
his
hand
on
the
piper
's
mouth
,
to
check
his
further
speech
,
arose
.
 
<EOS>
"
Forgive
my
rudeness
,
"
he
said
to
the
apprentice
;
"
<EOS>
but
I
have
been
so
deeply
interested
in
what
I
have
just
heard
,
that
I
quite
forgot
you
were
waiting
without
.
<EOS>
I
shall
remain
here
some
hours
longer
,
but
will
not
detain
you
,
especially
as
I
am
unable
to
admit
you
to
our
conference
.
<EOS>
I
will
meet
you
at
Doctor
Hodges
's
in
the
evening
,
and
shall
have
much
to
say
to
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
can
anticipate
some
part
of
your
communication
,
"
replied
Leonard
.
<EOS>
"
You
will
tell
me
you
have
a
daughter
still
living
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
are
inquisitive
,
young
man
,
"
rejoined
Thirlby
,
sternly
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
do
me
wrong
,
sir
,
"
replied
Leonard
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
no
curiosity
as
regards
yourself
;
and
if
I
had
,
would
never
lower
myself
in
my
own
estimation
to
gratify
it
.
<EOS>
Feeling
a
strong
interest
in
Nizza
Macascree
,
I
am
naturally
anxious
to
know
whether
my
suspicion
that
a
near
relationship
subsists
between
yourself
and
her
is
correct
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
can
not
enter
into
further
explanation
now
,
"
returned
Thirlby
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Meet
me
at
Doctor
Hodges
's
this
evening
,
and
you
shall
know
more
.
<EOS>
And
now
farewell
.
<EOS>
I
am
in
the
midst
of
a
deeply
-
interesting
conversation
,
which
your
presence
interrupts
.
<EOS>
Do
not
think
me
rude
--
do
not
think
me
ungrateful
.
<EOS>
My
anxiety
must
plead
my
excuse
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
None
is
necessary
,
sir
,
"
replied
Leonard
.
<EOS>
"
I
will
no
longer
place
any
restraint
upon
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
So
saying
,
and
taking
care
not
to
let
Bell
out
,
he
passed
through
the
door
,
and
closed
it
after
him
.
<EOS>
Having
walked
to
some
distance
across
the
fields
,
musing
on
what
had
just
occurred
,
and
scarcely
conscious
whither
<EOS>
he
was
going
,
he
threw
himself
down
on
the
grass
,
and
fell
asleep
.
<EOS>
He
awoke
after
some
time
much
refreshed
,
and
finding
he
was
considerably
nearer
Bishopsgate
than
any
other
entrance
into
the
city
,
determined
to
make
for
it
.
<EOS>
A
few
minutes
brought
him
to
a
row
of
houses
without
the
walls
,
none
of
which
appeared
to
have
escaped
infection
,
and
passing
them
,
he
entered
the
city
gate
.
<EOS>
As
he
proceeded
along
the
once
-
crowded
but
now
utterly
-
deserted
thoroughfare
that
opened
upon
him
,
he
could
scarcely
believe
he
was
in
a
spot
which
had
once
been
the
busiest
of
the
busy
haunts
of
men
--
so
silent
,
<EOS>
so
desolate
did
it
appear
!
<EOS>
On
reaching
Cornhill
,
he
found
it
equally
deserted
.
<EOS>
The
Exchange
was
closed
,
and
as
Leonard
looked
at
its
barred
gates
,
a
saddening
train
of
reflection
passed
through
his
mind
.
<EOS>
His
head
declined
upon
his
breast
,
and
he
continued
lost
in
a
mournful
reverie
until
he
was
roused
by
a
hand
laid
upon
his
shoulder
,
and
starting
--
for
such
a
salutation
at
this
season
was
alarming
--
he
looked
round
,
and
beheld
Solomon
Eagle
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
are
looking
upon
that
structure
,
"
said
the
enthusiast
,
"
and
are
thinking
how
much
it
is
changed
.
<EOS>
Men
who
possess
boundless
riches
imagine
their
power
above
that
of
their
Maker
,
and
suppose
they
may
neglect
and
defy
him
.
<EOS>
But
they
are
mistaken
.
<EOS>
Where
are
now
the
wealthy
merchants
who
used
to
haunt
those
courts
and
chambers?--why
<EOS>
do
they
not
come
here
as
of
old?--why
<EOS>
do
they
not
buy
and
sell
,
and
send
their
messengers
and
ships
to
the
farthest
parts
of
the
world
?
<EOS>
Because
the
Lord
hath
smitten
them
and
driven
them
forth--'From
the
least
of
them
even
to
the
greatest
of
them
,
'
as
the
prophet
Jeremiah
saith
,
'
every
one
has
been
given
to
covetousness
.
'
<EOS>
The
balances
of
deceit
have
been
in
their
hands
.
<EOS>
They
have
cozened
their
neighbours
,
and
greedily
gained
from
them
,
and
will
find
it
true
what
the
prophet
Ezekiel
hath
written
,
that
'
the
Lord
will
pour
out
his
indignation
upon
them
,
and
consume
them
with
the
fire
of
his
wrath
.
'
<EOS>
Yea
,
I
tell
you
,
unless
they
turn
from
their
evil
ways
--
unless
they
cast
aside
the
golden
idol
they
now
worship
,
and
set
up
the
Holy
One
of
Israel
in
its
stead
,
a
fire
will
be
sent
to
consume
them
,
and
that
pile
which
they
have
erected
as
a
temple
to
their
god
shall
be
burnt
to
the
ground
.
"
 
<EOS>
Leonard
's
heart
was
too
full
to
make
any
answer
,
and
the
enthusiast
,
after
a
brief
pause
,
again
addressed
him
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Have
you
seen
Doctor
Hodges
pass
this
way
?
<EOS>
I
am
in
search
of
him
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
On
what
account
?
"
asked
Leonard
anxiously
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
His
advice
,
I
trust
,
is
not
needed
on
behalf
of
any
one
in
whom
I
am
interested
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
No
matter
,
"
replied
Solomon
Eagle
,
in
a
sombre
tone
;
"
have
you
seen
him
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
not
,
"
rejoined
the
apprentice
;
"
but
he
is
probably
at
Saint
Paul
's
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
just
left
the
cathedral
,
and
was
told
he
had
proceeded
to
some
house
near
Cornhill
,
"
rejoined
the
enthusiast
.
 
<EOS>
"
If
you
have
been
there
,
you
can
perhaps
tell
me
how
my
master
's
porter
,
Blaize
Shotterel
,
is
getting
on
,
"
said
Leonard
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
can
,
"
replied
the
enthusiast
.
<EOS>
"
I
heard
one
of
the
chirurgeons
say
that
Doctor
Hodges
had
pronounced
him
in
a
fair
way
of
recovery
.
<EOS>
But
I
must
either
find
the
doctor
or
go
elsewhere
.
<EOS>
Farewell
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
will
go
with
you
in
search
of
him
,
"
said
Leonard
.
 
<EOS>
"
No
,
no
;
you
must
not
--
shall
not
,
"
cried
Solomon
Eagle
.
 
<EOS>
"
Wherefore
not
?
"
asked
the
apprentice
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
not
question
me
,
but
leave
me
,
"
rejoined
the
enthusiast
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
you
know
aught
of
Amabel
--
of
her
retreat
?
"
<EOS>
persisted
Leonard
,
who
had
a
strange
misgiving
that
the
enthusiast
's
errand
in
some
way
referred
to
her
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
do
,
"
replied
Solomon
Eagle
,
gloomily
;
"
but
I
again
advise
you
not
to
press
me
further
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Answer
me
one
question
at
least
,
"
cried
Leonard
.
<EOS>
"
Is
she
with
the
Earl
of
Rochester
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
She
is
,
"
replied
Solomon
Eagle
;
"
but
I
shall
allay
your
fears
in
that
respect
when
I
tell
you
she
is
sick
of
the
plague
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
Leonard
heard
nothing
more
,
for
,
uttering
a
wild
shriek
,
he
fell
to
the
ground
insensible
.
<EOS>
He
was
aroused
to
consciousness
by
a
sudden
sense
of
strangulation
,
and
opening
his
eyes
,
beheld
two
dark
figures
bending
over
him
,
one
of
whom
was
kneeling
on
his
chest
.
<EOS>
A
glance
showed
him
that
this
person
was
Chowles
;
and
instantly
comprehending
what
was
the
matter
,
and
aware
that
the
coffin
-
maker
was
stripping
him
previously
to
throwing
him
into
the
dead
-
cart
,
which
was
standing
hard
by
,
he
cried
aloud
,
and
struggled
desperately
to
set
himself
free
.
<EOS>
Little
opposition
was
offered
;
for
,
on
hearing
the
cry
,
Chowles
quitted
his
hold
,
and
retreating
to
a
short
distance
,
exclaimed
,
with
a
look
of
surprise
,
"
Why
,
the
fellow
is
not
dead
,
after
all
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
neither
dead
,
nor
likely
to
die
,
as
you
shall
find
to
your
cost
,
rascal
,
if
you
do
not
restore
me
the
clothes
you
have
robbed
me
of
,
"
cried
Leonard
,
furiously
.
<EOS>
And
chancing
to
perceive
a
fork
,
dropped
by
Chowles
in
his
hasty
retreat
,
he
snatched
it
up
,
and
,
brandishing
it
over
his
head
,
advanced
towards
him
.
<EOS>
Thus
threatened
,
Chowles
tossed
him
a
rich
suit
of
livery
.
 
<EOS>
"
These
are
not
mine
,
"
said
the
apprentice
,
gazing
at
the
habiliments
.
 
<EOS>
"
They
are
better
than
your
own
,
"
replied
Chowles
,
"
and
therefore
you
ought
to
be
glad
of
the
exchange
.
<EOS>
But
give
me
them
back
again
.
<EOS>
I
have
no
intention
of
making
you
a
present
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
This
is
the
livery
of
the
Earl
of
Rochester
,
"
cried
Leonard
.
 
<EOS>
"
To
be
sure
it
is
,
"
replied
Chowles
,
with
a
ghastly
smile
.
<EOS>
"
One
of
his
servants
is
just
dead
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Where
is
the
profligate
noble
?
"
cried
Leonard
,
eagerly
.
 
<EOS>
"
There
is
the
person
who
owned
these
clothes
,
"
replied
Chowles
,
pointing
to
the
dead
-
cart
.
<EOS>
"
You
had
better
ask
him
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Where
is
the
Earl
of
Rochester
,
I
say
,
villain
?
"
<EOS>
cried
Leonard
,
menacingly
.
 
<EOS>
"
How
should
I
know
?
"
rejoined
Chowles
.
<EOS>
"
Here
are
your
clothes
,
"
he
added
,
pushing
them
towards
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
will
have
an
answer
,
"
cried
Leonard
.
 
<EOS>
"
Not
from
me
,
"
replied
Chowles
.
<EOS>
And
hastily
snatching
up
the
livery
,
he
put
the
cart
in
motion
,
and
proceeded
on
his
road
.
<EOS>
Leonard
would
have
followed
him
,
but
the
state
of
his
attire
did
not
permit
him
to
do
so
.
<EOS>
Having
dressed
himself
,
he
hastened
to
the
cathedral
,
where
he
soon
found
the
attendant
who
had
charge
of
Blaize
.
 
<EOS>
"
Doctor
Hodges
has
been
with
him
,
"
said
the
man
,
in
reply
to
his
inquiries
after
the
porter
,
"
and
has
good
hopes
of
him
.
<EOS>
But
the
patient
is
not
entirely
satisfied
with
the
treatment
he
has
received
,
and
wishes
to
try
some
remedies
of
his
own
.
<EOS>
Were
his
request
granted
,
all
would
soon
be
over
with
him
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
That
I
am
sure
of
,
"
replied
Leonard
.
"
<EOS>
But
let
us
go
to
him
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
must
not
heed
his
complaints
,
"
returned
the
attendant
.
<EOS>
"
I
assure
you
he
is
doing
as
well
as
possible
;
but
he
is
so
dreadfully
frightened
at
a
trifling
operation
which
Doctor
Hodges
finds
it
necessary
to
perform
upon
him
,
that
we
have
been
obliged
to
fasten
him
to
the
bed
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Indeed
!
"
exclaimed
Leonard
,
suspiciously
.
"
<EOS>
Has
Judith
Malmayns
had
no
hand
in
this
arrangement
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Judith
Malmayns
has
been
absent
during
the
whole
of
the
afternoon
,
"
said
the
man
,
"
and
another
nurse
has
taken
her
place
in
Saint
Faith
's
.
<EOS>
She
has
never
been
near
Blaize
since
I
have
had
charge
of
him
.
"
 
<EOS>
By
this
time
they
had
reached
the
pallet
in
which
the
porter
was
laid
.
<EOS>
His
eyes
and
a
small
portion
of
his
snub
-
nose
were
alone
visible
,
his
head
being
still
enveloped
by
the
linen
cloth
,
while
his
mouth
was
covered
by
blankets
.
<EOS>
He
looked
so
anxiously
at
the
apprentice
,
that
the
latter
removed
the
covering
from
his
mouth
,
and
enabled
him
to
speak
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
glad
to
find
you
are
getting
on
so
well
,
"
said
Leonard
,
in
a
cheerful
tone
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Doctor
Hodges
has
been
with
you
,
I
understand
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
He
has
,
"
groaned
Blaize
;
"
but
he
has
done
me
no
good
--
<EOS>
none
<EOS>
whatever
.
<EOS>
I
could
doctor
myself
much
better
,
if
I
might
be
allowed
;
for
I
know
every
remedy
that
has
been
prescribed
for
the
plague
;
but
he
would
adopt
none
that
I
mentioned
to
him
.
<EOS>
I
wanted
him
to
place
a
hot
loaf
,
fresh
from
the
oven
,
to
the
tumour
,
to
draw
it
;
but
he
would
not
consent
.
<EOS>
Then
I
asked
for
a
cataplasm
,
composed
of
radish
-
roots
,
mustard
-
seed
,
onions
and
garlic
roasted
,
mithridate
,
salt
,
and
soot
from
a
chimney
where
wood
only
has
been
burnt
.
<EOS>
This
he
liked
no
better
than
the
first
.
<EOS>
Next
,
I
begged
for
an
ale
posset
with
pimpernel
soaked
in
it
,
assuring
him
that
by
frequently
drinking
such
a
mixture
,
Secretary
Naunton
drew
the
infection
from
his
very
heart
.
<EOS>
But
the
doctor
would
have
none
of
it
,
and
seemed
to
doubt
the
fact
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
What
did
he
do
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Leonard
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
applied
oil
of
St.
John
's
wort
to
the
tumour
,
"
replied
Blaize
,
with
a
dismal
groan
,
and
said
,
"
if
the
scar
did
not
fall
off
,
he
must
cauterize
it
.
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
I
shall
never
be
able
to
bear
the
pain
of
the
operation
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Recollect
your
life
is
at
stake
,
"
rejoined
Leonard
.
<EOS>
"
You
must
either
submit
to
it
or
die
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
know
I
must
,
"
replied
Blaize
,
with
a
prolonged
groan
;
"
but
it
is
a
terrible
alternative
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
will
not
find
the
operation
so
painful
as
you
imagine
,
"
rejoined
Leonard
;
"
and
you
know
I
speak
from
personal
experience
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
give
me
great
comfort
,
"
said
Blaize
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
so
you
really
think
I
shall
get
better
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
no
doubt
of
it
,
if
you
keep
up
your
spirits
,
"
replied
Leonard
.
<EOS>
"
The
worst
is
evidently
over
.
<EOS>
Behave
like
a
man
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
will
try
to
do
so
,
"
rejoined
Blaize
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
been
told
that
if
a
circle
is
drawn
with
a
blue
sapphire
round
a
plague
-
blotch
,
it
will
fall
off
.
<EOS>
Could
n't
we
just
try
the
experiment
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
will
not
do
to
rely
upon
it
,
"
observed
the
attendant
,
with
a
smile
.
<EOS>
"
You
will
find
a
small
knob
of
red
-
hot
iron
,
which
we
call
the
'
button
,
'
much
more
efficacious
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
dear
!
<EOS>
oh
dear
!
"
<EOS>
exclaimed
Blaize
,
"
I
already
feel
that
dreadful
button
burning
into
my
flesh
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
On
the
contrary
,
you
wo
n't
feel
it
at
all
,
"
replied
the
attendant
.
<EOS>
"
The
iron
only
touches
the
point
of
the
tumour
,
in
which
there
is
no
sensibility
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
In
that
case
,
I
do
n't
care
how
soon
the
operation
is
performed
,
"
replied
Blaize
.
 
<EOS>
"
Doctor
Hodges
will
choose
his
own
time
for
it
,
"
said
the
attendant
.
<EOS>
"
In
the
mean
time
,
here
is
a
cup
of
barley
-
broth
for
you
.
<EOS>
You
will
find
it
do
you
good
.
"
 
<EOS>
While
the
man
applied
the
cup
to
the
poor
porter
's
lips
--
for
he
would
not
unloose
the
straps
,
for
fear
of
mischief
--
Leonard
,
who
was
sickened
by
the
terrible
scene
around
him
,
took
his
departure
,
and
quitted
the
cathedral
by
the
great
western
entrance
.
<EOS>
Seating
himself
on
one
of
the
great
blocks
of
stone
left
there
by
the
workmen
employed
in
repairing
the
cathedral
,
but
who
had
long
since
abandoned
their
task
,
he
thought
over
all
that
had
recently
occurred
.
<EOS>
Raising
his
eyes
at
length
,
he
looked
toward
the
cathedral
.
<EOS>
The
oblique
rays
of
the
sun
had
quitted
the
columns
of
the
portico
,
which
looked
cold
and
grey
,
while
the
roof
and
towers
were
glittering
in
light
.
<EOS>
In
ten
minutes
more
,
only
the
summit
of
the
central
tower
caught
the
last
reflection
of
the
declining
orb
.
<EOS>
Leonard
watched
the
rosy
gleam
till
it
disappeared
,
and
then
steadfastly
regarded
the
reverend
pile
as
its
hue
changed
from
grey
to
black
,
until
at
length
each
pinnacle
and
buttress
,
each
battlement
and
tower
,
was
lost
in
one
vast
indistinct
mass
.
<EOS>
Night
had
fallen
upon
the
city
--
a
night
destined
to
be
more
fatal
than
any
that
had
preceded
it
;
and
yet
it
was
so
calm
,
so
beautiful
,
so
clear
,
that
it
was
scarcely
possible
to
imagine
that
it
was
unhealthy
.
<EOS>
The
destroying
angel
was
,
however
,
fearfully
at
work
.
<EOS>
Hundreds
were
falling
beneath
his
touch
;
and
as
Leonard
wondered
how
many
miserable
wretches
were
at
that
moment
released
from
suffering
,
it
crossed
him
like
an
icy
chill
,
that
among
the
number
might
be
Amabel
.
<EOS>
So
forcibly
was
he
impressed
by
this
idea
,
that
he
fell
on
his
knees
and
prayed
aloud
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
aroused
by
hearing
the
ringing
of
a
bell
,
which
announced
the
approach
of
the
dead
-
cart
,
and
presently
afterwards
the
gloomy
vehicle
approached
from
Ludgate
-
hill
,
and
moved
slowly
towards
the
portico
of
the
cathedral
,
where
it
halted
.
<EOS>
A
great
number
of
the
dead
were
placed
within
it
,
and
the
driver
,
ringing
his
bell
,
proceeded
in
the
direction
of
Cheapside
.
<EOS>
A
very
heavy
dew
had
fallen
;
for
as
Leonard
put
his
hand
to
his
clothes
,
they
felt
damp
,
and
his
long
hair
was
filled
with
moisture
.
<EOS>
Reproaching
himself
with
having
needlessly
exposed
himself
to
risk
,
he
was
about
to
walk
away
,
when
he
heard
footsteps
at
a
little
distance
,
and
looking
in
the
direction
of
the
sound
,
perceived
the
tall
figure
of
Thirlby
.
<EOS>
Calling
to
him
,
the
other
,
who
appeared
to
be
in
haste
,
halted
for
a
moment
,
and
telling
the
apprentice
he
was
going
to
Doctor
Hodges
's
,
desired
him
to
accompany
him
thither
,
and
went
on
.
        
<EOS>
*
      
<EOS>
*
      
<EOS>
*
      
<EOS>
*
      
<EOS>
*
  
III
.
 
<EOS>
THE
HOUSE
IN
NICHOLAS
-
LANE
.
 
<EOS>
On
reaching
Watling
-
street
,
Leonard
and
his
companion
found
Doctor
Hodges
was
from
home
.
<EOS>
This
did
not
much
surprise
the
apprentice
,
after
the
information
he
had
received
from
Solomon
Eagle
,
but
Thirlby
was
greatly
disappointed
,
and
eagerly
questioned
the
porter
as
to
the
probable
time
of
his
master
's
return
.
<EOS>
The
man
replied
that
it
was
quite
uncertain
,
adding
,
"
He
has
been
in
since
you
were
last
here
,
and
has
seen
Blaize
.
<EOS>
He
had
not
been
gone
to
the
cathedral
many
minutes
when
a
gentleman
arrived
,
desiring
his
instant
attendance
upon
a
young
woman
who
was
sick
of
the
plague
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Did
you
hear
her
name
?
"
asked
Leonard
and
Thirlby
,
in
a
breath
.
 
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
replied
the
porter
,
"
<EOS>
neither
did
I
obtain
any
information
respecting
her
from
the
gentleman
,
who
appeared
in
great
distress
.
<EOS>
But
I
observed
that
my
master
,
on
his
return
,
looked
much
surprised
at
seeing
him
,
and
treated
him
with
a
sort
of
cold
respect
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Was
the
gentleman
young
or
old
?
"
demanded
Leonard
,
hastily
.
 
<EOS>
"
As
far
as
I
noticed
,
"
replied
the
porter
,
"
for
he
kept
his
face
covered
with
a
handkerchief
<EOS>
,
I
should
say
he
was
young
--
very
young
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
are
sure
it
was
not
Lord
Rochester
?
"
pursued
Leonard
.
 
<EOS>
"
How
should
I
be
sure
of
it
,
"
rejoined
the
porter
,
"
since
I
have
never
seen
his
lordship
that
I
am
aware
of
?
<EOS>
But
I
will
tell
you
all
that
happened
,
and
you
can
judge
for
yourselves
.
<EOS>
My
master
,
as
I
have
just
said
,
on
seeing
the
stranger
,
looked
surprised
and
angry
,
and
bowing
gravely
,
conducted
him
to
his
study
,
taking
care
to
close
the
door
after
him
.
<EOS>
I
did
not
,
of
course
,
hear
what
passed
,
but
the
interview
was
brief
enough
,
and
the
gentleman
,
issuing
forth
,
said
,
as
he
quitted
the
room
,
'
You
will
not
fail
to
come
?
'
<EOS>
To
which
my
master
replied
,
'
Certainly
not
,
on
the
terms
I
have
mentioned
.
'
<EOS>
With
this
,
the
gentleman
hurried
out
of
the
house
.
<EOS>
Shortly
afterwards
the
doctor
came
out
,
and
said
to
me
,
'
I
am
going
to
attend
a
young
woman
who
is
sick
of
the
plague
,
and
may
be
absent
for
some
time
.
<EOS>
If
Mr.
Thirlby
or
Leonard
Holt
should
call
,
detain
them
till
my
return
.
'
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
My
heart
tells
me
that
the
young
woman
he
is
gone
to
visit
is
no
other
than
Amabel
,
"
said
Leonard
Holt
,
sorrowfully
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
suspect
it
is
Nizza
Macascree
,
"
cried
Thirlby
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Which
way
did
your
master
take
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
did
not
observe
,
"
replied
the
porter
,
"
but
he
told
me
he
should
cross
London
Bridge
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
will
go
into
Southwark
in
quest
of
him
,
"
said
Thirlby
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Every
moment
is
of
consequence
now
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
had
better
stay
where
you
are
,
"
replied
the
old
porter
.
<EOS>
"
It
is
the
surest
way
to
meet
with
him
.
"
 
<EOS>
Thirlby
,
however
,
was
too
full
of
anxiety
to
listen
to
reason
,
and
his
impatience
producing
a
corresponding
effect
upon
Leonard
,
though
from
a
different
motive
,
they
set
forth
together
.
<EOS>
"
If
I
fail
to
find
him
,
you
may
expect
me
back
ere
long
,
"
were
Thirlby
's
last
words
to
the
porter
.
<EOS>
Hurrying
along
Watling
-
street
,
and
taking
the
first
turning
on
the
right
,
he
descended
to
Thames
-
street
,
and
made
the
best
of
his
way
towards
the
bridge
.
<EOS>
Leonard
followed
him
closely
,
and
they
pursued
their
rapid
course
in
silence
.
<EOS>
By
the
time
they
reached
the
north
gate
of
the
bridge
,
Leonard
found
his
strength
failing
him
,
and
halting
at
one
of
the
openings
between
the
tall
houses
overlooking
the
river
,
where
there
was
a
wooden
bench
for
the
accommodation
of
passengers
,
he
sank
upon
it
,
and
begged
Thirlby
to
go
on
,
saying
he
would
return
to
Watling
-
street
as
soon
as
he
recovered
from
his
exhaustion
.
<EOS>
Thirlby
did
not
attempt
to
dissuade
him
from
his
purpose
,
but
instantly
disappeared
.
 
<EOS>
The
night
,
it
has
before
been
remarked
,
was
singularly
beautiful
.
<EOS>
It
was
almost
as
light
as
day
,
for
the
full
harvest
moon
(
alas
!
<EOS>
there
was
no
harvest
for
it
to
smile
upon
!
)
<EOS>
having
just
risen
,
revealed
every
object
with
perfect
distinctness
.
<EOS>
The
bench
on
which
Leonard
was
seated
lay
on
the
right
side
of
the
bridge
,
and
commanded
a
magnificent
reach
of
the
river
,
that
flowed
beneath
like
a
sheet
of
molten
silver
.
<EOS>
The
apprentice
gazed
along
its
banks
,
and
noticed
the
tall
spectral
-
looking
houses
on
the
right
,
until
his
eye
finally
settled
on
the
massive
fabric
of
Saint
Paul
's
,
the
roof
and
towers
of
which
rose
high
above
the
lesser
structures
.
<EOS>
His
meditations
were
suddenly
interrupted
by
the
opening
of
a
window
in
the
house
near
him
,
while
a
loud
splash
in
the
water
told
that
a
body
had
been
thrown
into
it
.
<EOS>
He
turned
away
with
a
shudder
,
and
at
the
same
moment
perceived
a
watchman
,
with
a
halberd
upon
his
shoulder
,
advancing
slowly
towards
him
from
the
Southwark
side
of
the
bridge
.
<EOS>
Pausing
as
he
drew
near
the
apprentice
,
the
watchman
compassionately
inquired
whether
he
was
sick
,
and
being
answered
in
the
negative
,
was
about
to
pass
on
,
when
Leonard
,
fancying
he
recognised
his
voice
,
stopped
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
We
have
met
somewhere
before
,
friend
,
"
he
said
,
"
though
where
,
or
under
what
circumstances
,
I
can
not
at
this
moment
call
to
mind
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Not
unlikely
,
"
returned
the
other
,
roughly
,
"
but
the
chances
are
against
our
meeting
again
.
"
 
<EOS>
Leonard
heaved
a
sigh
at
this
remark
.
<EOS>
"
I
now
recollect
where
I
met
you
,
friend
,
"
he
remarked
.
<EOS>
"
It
was
at
Saint
Paul
's
,
when
I
was
in
search
of
my
master
's
daughter
,
who
had
been
carried
off
by
the
Earl
of
Rochester
.
<EOS>
But
you
were
then
in
the
garb
of
a
smith
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
recollect
the
circumstance
,
too
,
now
you
remind
me
of
it
,
"
replied
the
other
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Your
name
is
Leonard
Holt
as
surely
as
mine
is
Robert
Rainbird
.
<EOS>
I
recollect
,
also
,
that
you
offended
me
about
a
dog
belonging
to
the
piper
's
pretty
daughter
,
Nizza
Macascree
,
which
I
was
about
to
destroy
in
obedience
to
the
Lord
Mayor
's
commands
.
<EOS>
However
,
I
bear
no
malice
,
and
if
I
did
,
this
is
not
a
time
to
rip
up
old
quarrels
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
are
right
,
friend
,
"
returned
Leonard
.
<EOS>
"
The
few
of
us
left
ought
to
be
in
charity
with
each
other
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Truly
,
ought
we
,
"
rejoined
Rainbird
.
<EOS>
"
For
my
own
part
,
I
have
seen
so
much
misery
within
the
last
few
weeks
,
that
my
disposition
is
wholly
changed
.
<EOS>
I
was
obliged
to
abandon
my
old
occupation
of
a
smith
,
because
my
master
died
of
the
plague
,
and
there
was
no
one
else
to
employ
me
.
<EOS>
I
have
therefore
served
as
a
watchman
,
and
in
twenty
days
have
stood
at
the
doors
of
more
than
twenty
houses
.
<EOS>
It
would
freeze
your
blood
were
I
to
relate
the
scenes
I
have
witnessed
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
might
have
done
formerly
,
"
replied
Leonard
;
"
but
my
feelings
are
as
much
changed
as
your
own
.
<EOS>
I
have
had
the
plague
twice
myself
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Then
,
indeed
,
you
_
can
_
speak
,
"
replied
Rainbird
.
"
<EOS>
Thank
God
,
