I
have
hitherto
escaped
it
!
<EOS>
Ah
!
<EOS>
these
are
terrible
times
--
terrible
times
!
<EOS>
The
worst
that
ever
London
knew
.
<EOS>
Although
I
have
been
hitherto
miraculously
preserved
myself
,
I
am
firmly
persuaded
no
one
will
escape
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
almost
inclined
to
agree
with
you
,
"
replied
Leonard
.
 
<EOS>
"
For
the
last
week
the
distemper
has
raged
fearfully
--
fearfully
,
indeed
,
"
said
Rainbird
;
"
but
yesterday
and
to
-
day
have
far
exceeded
all
that
have
gone
before
.
<EOS>
The
distempered
have
died
quicker
than
cattle
of
the
murrain
.
<EOS>
I
visited
upwards
of
a
hundred
houses
in
the
Borough
this
morning
,
and
only
found
ten
persons
alive
;
and
out
of
those
ten
,
not
one
,
I
will
venture
to
say
,
is
alive
now
.
<EOS>
It
will
,
in
truth
,
be
a
mercy
if
they
are
gone
.
<EOS>
There
were
distracted
mothers
raving
over
their
children,--a
young
husband
lamenting
his
wife,--two
little
children
weeping
over
their
dead
parents
,
with
none
to
attend
them
,
none
to
feed
them,--an
old
man
mourning
over
his
son
cut
off
in
his
prime
.
<EOS>
In
short
,
misery
and
distress
in
their
worst
form,--the
streets
ringing
with
shrieks
and
groans
,
and
the
numbers
of
dead
so
great
that
it
was
impossible
to
carry
them
off
.
<EOS>
You
remember
Solomon
Eagle
's
prophecy
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Perfectly
,
"
replied
Leonard
;
"
and
I
lament
to
see
its
fulfilment
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
'
The
streets
shall
be
covered
with
grass
,
and
the
living
shall
not
be
able
to
bury
their
dead,'--so
<EOS>
it
ran
,
"
said
Rainbird
.
<EOS>
"
And
it
has
come
to
pass
.
<EOS>
Not
a
carriage
of
any
description
,
save
the
dead
-
cart
,
is
to
be
seen
in
the
broadest
streets
of
London
,
which
are
now
as
green
as
the
fields
without
her
walls
,
and
as
silent
as
the
grave
itself
.
<EOS>
Terrible
times
,
as
I
said
before
--
terrible
times
!
<EOS>
The
dead
are
rotting
in
heaps
in
the
courts
,
in
the
alleys
,
in
the
very
houses
,
and
no
one
to
remove
them
.
<EOS>
What
will
be
the
end
of
it
all
?
<EOS>
What
will
become
of
this
great
city
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
not
difficult
to
foresee
what
will
become
of
it
,
"
replied
Leonard
,
"
unless
it
pleases
the
Lord
to
stay
his
vengeful
arm
.
<EOS>
And
something
whispers
in
my
ear
that
we
are
now
at
the
worst
.
<EOS>
The
scourge
can
not
exceed
its
present
violence
without
working
our
ruin
;
and
deeply
as
we
have
sinned
,
little
as
we
repent
,
I
can
not
bring
myself
to
believe
that
God
will
sweep
his
people
entirely
from
the
face
of
the
earth
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
dare
not
hope
otherwise
,
"
rejoined
Rainbird
,
"
though
I
would
fain
do
so
.
<EOS>
I
discern
no
symptoms
of
abatement
of
the
distemper
,
but
,
on
the
contrary
,
an
evident
increase
of
malignity
,
and
such
is
the
opinion
of
all
I
have
spoken
with
on
the
subject
.
<EOS>
Chowles
told
me
he
buried
two
hundred
more
yesterday
than
he
had
ever
done
before
,
and
yet
he
did
not
carry
a
third
of
the
dead
to
the
plague
-
pit
.
<EOS>
He
is
a
strange
fellow
that
Chowles
.
<EOS>
But
for
his
passion
for
his
horrible
calling
there
is
no
necessity
for
him
to
follow
it
,
for
he
is
now
one
of
the
richest
men
in
London
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
He
must
have
amassed
his
riches
by
robbery
,
then
,
"
remarked
Leonard
.
 
<EOS>
"
True
,
"
returned
Rainbird
.
"
<EOS>
He
helps
himself
without
scruple
to
the
clothes
,
goods
,
and
other
property
,
of
all
who
die
of
the
pestilence
;
and
after
ransacking
their
houses
,
conveys
his
plunder
in
the
dead
-
cart
to
his
own
dwelling
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
In
Saint
Paul
's
?
"
asked
Leonard
.
 
<EOS>
"
No
--
a
large
house
in
Nicholas
-
lane
,
once
belonging
to
a
wealthy
merchant
,
who
perished
,
with
his
family
,
of
the
plague
,
"
replied
Rainbird
.
"
<EOS>
He
has
filled
it
from
cellar
to
garret
with
the
spoil
he
has
obtained
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
And
how
has
he
preserved
it
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
the
apprentice
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
plague
has
preserved
it
for
him
,
"
replied
Rainbird
.
<EOS>
"
The
few
authorities
who
now
act
have
,
perhaps
,
no
knowledge
of
his
proceedings
;
or
if
they
have
,
have
not
cared
to
interfere
,
awaiting
a
more
favourable
season
,
if
it
should
ever
arrive
,
to
dispossess
him
of
his
hoard
,
and
punish
him
for
his
delinquencies
;
while
,
in
the
mean
time
,
they
are
glad
,
on
any
terms
,
to
avail
themselves
of
his
services
as
a
burier
.
<EOS>
Other
people
do
not
care
to
meddle
with
him
,
and
the
most
daring
robber
would
be
afraid
to
touch
infected
money
or
clothes
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
If
you
are
going
towards
Nicholas
-
lane
,
"
said
Leonard
,
as
if
struck
with
a
sudden
idea
,
"
and
will
point
out
to
me
the
house
in
question
,
you
will
do
me
a
favour
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
Rainbird
nodded
assent
,
and
they
walked
on
together
towards
Fish
-
street
-
hill
.
<EOS>
Ascending
it
,
and
turning
off
on
the
right
,
they
entered
Great
Eastcheap
,
but
had
not
proceeded
far
when
they
were
obliged
to
turn
back
,
the
street
being
literally
choked
up
with
a
pile
of
carcasses
deposited
there
by
the
burier
's
assistants
.
<EOS>
Shaping
their
course
along
Gracechurch
-
street
,
they
turned
off
into
Lombard
-
street
,
and
as
Leonard
gazed
at
the
goldsmiths
'
houses
on
either
side
,
which
were
all
shut
up
,
with
the
fatal
red
cross
on
the
doors
,
he
could
not
help
remarking
to
his
companion
,
"
The
plague
has
not
spared
any
of
these
on
account
of
their
riches
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
True
,
"
replied
the
other
;
"
and
of
the
thousands
who
used
formerly
to
throng
this
street
not
one
is
left
.
<EOS>
Wo
to
London!--wo!--wo
!
"
 
<EOS>
Leonard
echoed
the
sentiment
,
and
fell
into
a
melancholy
train
of
reflection
.
<EOS>
It
has
been
more
than
once
remarked
that
the
particular
day
now
under
consideration
was
the
one
in
which
the
plague
exercised
its
fiercest
dominion
over
the
city
;
and
though
at
first
its
decline
was
as
imperceptible
as
the
gradual
diminution
of
the
day
after
the
longest
has
passed
,
yet
still
the
alteration
began
.
<EOS>
On
that
day
,
as
if
death
had
known
that
his
power
was
to
be
speedily
arrested
,
he
sharpened
his
fellest
arrows
,
and
discharged
them
with
unerring
aim
.
<EOS>
To
pursue
the
course
of
the
destroyer
from
house
to
house
--
to
show
with
what
unrelenting
fury
he
assailed
his
victims
--
to
describe
their
sufferings
--
to
number
the
dead
left
within
their
beds
,
thrown
into
the
streets
,
or
conveyed
to
the
plague
-
pits
--
would
be
to
present
a
narrative
as
painful
as
revolting
.
<EOS>
On
this
terrible
night
it
was
as
hot
as
if
it
had
been
the
middle
of
June
.
<EOS>
No
air
was
stirring
,
and
the
silence
was
so
profound
,
that
a
slight
noise
was
audible
at
a
great
distance
.
<EOS>
Hushed
in
the
seemingly
placid
repose
lay
the
great
city
,
while
hundreds
of
its
inhabitants
were
groaning
in
agony
,
or
breathing
their
last
sigh
.
 
<EOS>
On
reaching
the
upper
end
of
Nicholas
-
lane
,
Rainbird
stood
still
for
a
moment
,
and
pointed
out
a
large
house
on
the
right
,
just
below
the
old
church
dedicated
to
the
saint
from
which
the
thoroughfare
took
its
name
.
<EOS>
They
were
about
to
proceed
towards
it
,
when
the
smith
again
paused
,
and
called
Leonard
's
attention
to
two
figures
quickly
advancing
from
the
lower
end
of
the
street
.
<EOS>
As
the
apprentice
and
his
companion
stood
in
the
shade
,
they
could
not
be
seen
,
while
the
two
persons
,
being
in
the
moonlight
,
were
fully
revealed
.
<EOS>
One
of
them
,
it
was
easy
to
perceive
,
was
Chowles
.
<EOS>
He
stopped
before
the
door
of
his
dwelling
and
unfastened
it
,
and
while
he
was
thus
occupied
,
the
other
person
turned
his
face
so
as
to
catch
the
full
radiance
of
the
moon
,
disclosing
the
features
of
Sir
Paul
Parravicin
.
<EOS>
Before
Leonard
recovered
from
the
surprise
into
which
he
was
thrown
by
this
unexpected
discovery
,
they
had
entered
the
house
.
 
<EOS>
He
then
hurried
forward
,
but
,
to
his
great
disappointment
,
found
the
door
locked
.
<EOS>
Anxious
to
get
into
the
house
without
alarming
those
who
had
preceded
him
,
he
glanced
at
the
windows
;
but
the
shutters
were
closed
and
strongly
barred
.
<EOS>
While
hesitating
what
to
do
,
Rainbird
came
up
,
and
guessing
his
wishes
,
told
him
there
was
a
door
at
the
back
of
the
house
by
which
he
might
probably
gain
admittance
.
<EOS>
Accordingly
they
hastened
down
a
passage
skirting
the
churchyard
,
which
brought
them
to
a
narrow
alley
lying
between
Nicholas
-
lane
and
Abchurch
-
lane
.
<EOS>
Tracking
it
for
about
twenty
yards
,
Rainbird
paused
before
a
small
yard
-
door
,
and
trying
the
latch
,
found
it
yielded
to
his
touch
.
 
<EOS>
Crossing
the
yard
,
they
came
to
another
door
.
<EOS>
It
was
locked
,
and
though
they
could
have
easily
burst
it
open
,
they
preferred
having
recourse
to
an
adjoining
window
,
the
shutter
of
which
,
being
carelessly
fastened
,
was
removed
without
noise
or
difficulty
.
<EOS>
In
another
moment
they
gained
a
small
dark
room
on
the
ground
-
floor
,
whence
they
issued
into
a
passage
,
<EOS>
where
,
to
their
great
joy
,
they
found
a
lighted
lantern
placed
on
a
chair
.
<EOS>
Leonard
hastily
possessed
himself
of
it
,
and
was
about
to
enter
a
room
on
the
left
when
his
companion
arrested
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
Before
we
proceed
further
,
"
he
said
in
a
low
voice
,
"
I
must
know
what
you
are
about
to
do
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
My
purpose
will
be
explained
in
a
word
,
"
replied
the
apprentice
in
the
same
tone
.
<EOS>
"
I
suspect
that
Nizza
Macascree
is
confined
here
by
Sir
Paul
Parravicin
and
Chowles
,
and
if
it
turns
out
I
am
right
in
my
conjecture
,
I
propose
to
liberate
her
.
<EOS>
Will
you
help
me
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
Humph
!
"
<EOS>
exclaimed
Rainbird
,
"
I
do
n't
much
fancy
the
job
.
<EOS>
However
,
since
I
am
here
,
I
'll
not
go
back
.
<EOS>
I
am
curious
to
see
the
coffin
-
maker
's
hoards
.
<EOS>
Look
at
yon
heap
of
clothes
.
<EOS>
There
are
velvet
doublets
and
silken
hose
enow
to
furnish
wardrobes
for
a
dozen
court
gallants
.
<EOS>
And
yet
,
rich
as
the
stuffs
are
,
I
would
not
put
the
best
of
them
on
for
all
the
wealth
of
London
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Nor
I
,
"
replied
Leonard
.
<EOS>
"
I
shall
make
free
,
however
,
with
a
sword
,
"
he
added
,
selecting
one
from
the
heap
.
<EOS>
"
I
may
need
a
weapon
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
require
nothing
more
than
my
halberd
,
"
observed
the
smith
;
"
and
I
would
advise
you
to
throw
away
that
velvet
scabbard
;
it
is
a
certain
harbour
for
infection
.
"
 
<EOS>
Leonard
did
not
neglect
the
caution
,
and
pushing
open
the
door
,
they
entered
a
large
room
which
resembled
an
upholsterer
's
shop
,
being
literally
crammed
with
chairs
,
tables
,
cabinets
,
moveable
cupboards
,
bedsteads
,
curtains
,
and
hangings
,
all
of
the
richest
description
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
I
heard
is
true
,
"
observed
Rainbird
,
gazing
around
in
astonishment
.
<EOS>
"
Chowles
must
have
carried
off
every
thing
he
could
lay
hands
upon
.
<EOS>
What
can
he
do
with
all
that
furniture
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
What
the
miser
does
with
his
store
,
"
replied
Leonard
:
"
<EOS>
feast
his
eyes
with
it
,
but
never
use
it
.
"
 
<EOS>
They
then
proceeded
to
the
next
room
.
<EOS>
It
was
crowded
with
books
,
looking
-
glasses
,
and
pictures
;
many
of
them
originally
of
great
value
,
but
greatly
damaged
by
the
careless
manner
in
which
they
were
piled
one
upon
another
.
<EOS>
A
third
apartment
was
filled
with
flasks
of
wine
,
with
casks
probably
containing
spirits
,
and
boxes
,
the
contents
of
which
they
did
not
pause
to
examine
.
<EOS>
A
fourth
contained
male
and
female
habiliments
,
spread
out
like
the
dresses
in
a
theatrical
wardrobe
.
<EOS>
Most
of
these
garments
were
of
the
gayest
and
costliest
description
,
and
of
the
latest
fashion
,
and
Leonard
sighed
as
he
looked
upon
them
,
and
thought
of
the
fate
of
those
they
had
so
lately
adorned
.
 
<EOS>
"
There
is
contagion
enough
in
those
clothes
to
infect
a
whole
city
,
"
said
Rainbird
,
who
regarded
them
with
different
feelings
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
half
a
mind
to
set
fire
to
them
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
were
a
good
deed
to
do
so
,
"
returned
Leonard
;
"
but
it
must
not
be
done
now
.
<EOS>
Let
us
go
upstairs
.
<EOS>
These
are
the
only
rooms
below
.
"
 
<EOS>
Accordingly
,
they
ascended
the
staircase
,
and
entered
chamber
after
chamber
,
all
of
which
were
as
full
of
spoil
as
those
they
had
just
visited
;
but
they
could
find
no
one
,
nor
was
there
any
symptom
that
the
house
was
tenanted
.
<EOS>
They
next
stood
still
within
the
gallery
,
and
listened
intently
for
some
sound
to
reveal
those
they
sought
,
but
all
was
still
and
silent
as
the
grave
.
 
<EOS>
"
We
can
not
be
mistaken
,
"
observed
Leonard
.
<EOS>
"
It
is
clear
this
house
is
the
receptacle
for
Chowles
's
plunder
.
<EOS>
Besides
,
we
should
not
have
found
the
lantern
burning
if
they
had
gone
forth
again
.
<EOS>
No
,
no
;
they
must
be
hidden
somewhere
,
and
I
will
not
quit
the
place
till
I
find
them
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Their
search
,
however
,
was
fruitless
.
<EOS>
They
mounted
to
the
garrets
,
opened
every
door
,
and
glanced
into
every
corner
.
<EOS>
Still
,
no
one
was
to
be
seen
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
begin
to
think
Nizza
can
not
be
here
,
"
said
the
apprentice
;
"
but
I
am
resolved
not
to
depart
without
questioning
Chowles
on
the
subject
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
must
find
him
first
,
"
rejoined
Rainbird
.
<EOS>
"
If
he
is
anywhere
,
he
must
be
in
the
cellar
,
for
we
have
been
into
every
room
in
this
part
of
the
house
.
<EOS>
For
my
own
part
,
I
think
you
had
better
abandon
the
search
altogether
.
<EOS>
No
good
will
come
of
it
.
"
 
<EOS>
Leonard
,
however
,
was
not
to
be
dissuaded
,
and
they
went
downstairs
.
<EOS>
A
short
flight
of
stone
steps
brought
them
to
a
spacious
kitchen
,
but
it
was
quite
empty
,
and
seemed
to
have
been
long
disused
.
<EOS>
They
then
peeped
into
the
scullery
adjoining
,
and
were
about
to
retrace
their
steps
,
when
Rainbird
plucked
Leonard
's
sleeve
to
call
attention
to
a
gleam
of
light
issuing
from
a
door
which
stood
partly
ajar
,
in
a
long
narrow
passage
leading
apparently
to
the
cellars
.
 
<EOS>
"
They
are
there
,
"
he
said
,
in
a
whisper
.
 
<EOS>
"
So
I
see
,
"
replied
Leonard
,
in
the
same
tone
.
<EOS>
And
raising
his
finger
to
his
lips
in
token
of
silence
,
he
stole
forward
on
the
points
of
his
feet
and
cautiously
opened
the
door
.
 
<EOS>
At
the
further
end
of
the
cellar
--
for
such
it
was
--
knelt
Chowles
,
examining
with
greedy
eyes
the
contents
of
a
large
chest
,
which
,
from
the
hasty
glance
that
Leonard
caught
of
it
,
appeared
to
be
filled
with
gold
and
silver
plate
.
<EOS>
A
link
stuck
against
the
wall
threw
a
strong
light
over
the
scene
,
and
showed
that
the
coffin
-
maker
was
alone
.
<EOS>
As
Leonard
advanced
,
the
sound
of
his
footsteps
caught
Chowles
's
ear
,
and
uttering
a
cry
of
surprise
and
alarm
,
he
let
fall
the
lid
of
the
chest
,
and
sprang
to
his
feet
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
want
?
<EOS>
"
he
cried
,
looking
uneasily
round
,
as
if
in
search
of
some
weapon
.
"
<EOS>
Are
you
come
to
rob
me
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
replied
Leonard
;
<EOS>
"
neither
are
we
come
to
reclaim
the
plunder
you
have
taken
from
others
.
<EOS>
We
are
come
in
search
of
Nizza
Macascree
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Then
you
have
come
on
a
fool
's
errand
,
"
replied
Chowles
,
regaining
his
courage
,
"
<EOS>
for
she
is
not
here
.
<EOS>
I
know
nothing
of
her
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
That
is
false
,
"
replied
Leonard
.
<EOS>
"
You
have
just
conducted
Sir
Paul
Parravicin
to
her
.
"
 
<EOS>
This
assertion
on
the
part
of
the
apprentice
,
which
he
thought
himself
justified
under
the
circumstances
in
making
,
produced
a
strong
effect
on
Chowles
.
<EOS>
He
appeared
startled
and
confounded
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
What
right
have
you
to
play
the
spy
upon
me
thus
?
<EOS>
"
he
faltered
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
right
that
every
honest
man
possesses
to
check
the
designs
of
the
wicked
,
"
replied
Leonard
.
<EOS>
"
You
admit
she
is
here
.
<EOS>
Lead
me
to
her
hiding
-
place
without
more
ado
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
If
you
know
where
it
is
,
"
rejoined
Chowles
,
who
now
perceived
the
trick
that
had
been
practised
upon
him
<EOS>
,
"
you
will
not
want
me
to
conduct
you
to
it
.
<EOS>
Neither
Nizza
nor
Sir
Paul
Parravicin
are
here
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
That
is
false
,
prevaricating
scoundrel
,
"
cried
Leonard
.
<EOS>
"
My
companion
and
I
saw
you
enter
the
house
with
your
profligate
employer
.
<EOS>
And
as
we
gained
admittance
a
few
minutes
after
you
,
it
is
certain
no
one
can
have
left
it
.
<EOS>
Lead
me
to
Nizza
's
retreat
instantly
,
or
I
will
cut
your
throat
.
"
<EOS>
And
seizing
Chowles
by
the
collar
,
he
held
the
point
of
his
sword
to
his
breast
.
 
<EOS>
"
Use
no
violence
,
"
cried
Chowles
,
struggling
to
free
himself
,
"
and
I
will
take
you
wherever
you
please
.
<EOS>
This
way
--
this
way
.
<EOS>
"
And
he
motioned
as
if
he
would
take
them
upstairs
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
not
think
to
mislead
me
,
villain
,
"
cried
Leonard
,
tightening
his
grasp
.
<EOS>
"
We
have
searched
every
room
in
the
upper
part
of
the
house
,
and
though
we
have
discovered
the
whole
of
your
ill
-
gotten
hoards
,
we
have
found
nothing
else
.
<EOS>
No
one
is
there
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Well
,
then
,
"
rejoined
Chowles
,
<EOS>
"
since
the
truth
must
out
,
Sir
Paul
is
in
the
next
house
.
<EOS>
But
it
is
his
own
abode
.
<EOS>
I
have
nothing
to
do
with
it
,
<EOS>
nothing
whatever
.
<EOS>
He
is
accountable
for
his
own
actions
,
and
you
will
be
accountable
to
_
him
<EOS>
_
if
you
intrude
upon
his
privacy
.
<EOS>
Release
me
,
and
I
swear
to
conduct
you
to
him
.
<EOS>
But
you
will
take
the
consequences
of
your
rashness
upon
yourself
.
<EOS>
I
only
go
upon
compulsion
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
ready
to
take
any
consequences
,
"
replied
Leonard
,
resolutely
.
 
<EOS>
"
Come
along
,
then
,
"
said
Chowles
,
pointing
down
the
passage
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
mean
us
no
mischief
?
"
<EOS>
cried
Leonard
,
suspiciously
.
<EOS>
"
If
you
do
,
the
attempt
will
cost
you
your
life
.
"
 
<EOS>
Chowles
made
no
answer
,
but
moved
along
the
passage
as
quickly
as
Leonard
,
who
kept
fast
hold
of
him
and
walked
by
his
side
,
would
permit
.
<EOS>
Presently
they
reached
a
door
,
which
neither
the
apprentice
nor
Rainbird
had
observed
before
,
and
which
admitted
them
into
an
extensive
vault
,
with
a
short
staircase
at
the
further
end
,
communicating
with
a
passage
that
Leonard
did
not
require
to
be
informed
was
in
another
house
.
 
<EOS>
Here
Chowles
paused
.
<EOS>
"
I
think
it
right
to
warn
you
you
are
running
into
a
danger
from
which
ere
long
you
will
be
glad
to
draw
back
,
young
man
,
"
he
said
,
to
the
apprentice
.
"
<EOS>
As
a
friend
,
I
advise
you
to
proceed
no
further
in
the
matter
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Waste
no
more
time
in
talking
,
"
cried
Leonard
,
fiercely
,
and
forcing
him
forward
as
he
spoke
,
<EOS>
"
where
is
Nizza
?
<EOS>
Lead
me
to
her
without
an
instant
's
delay
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
A
wilful
man
must
have
his
way
,
"
returned
Chowles
,
hurrying
up
the
main
staircase
.
<EOS>
"
It
is
not
my
fault
if
any
harm
befalls
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
They
had
just
gained
the
landing
when
a
door
on
the
right
was
suddenly
thrown
open
,
and
Sir
Paul
Parravicin
stood
before
them
.
<EOS>
He
looked
surprised
and
startled
at
the
sight
of
the
apprentice
,
and
angrily
demanded
his
business
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
come
for
Nizza
Macascree
,
"
replied
Leonard
,
"
whom
you
and
Chowles
have
detained
against
her
will
.
"
 
<EOS>
Parravicin
glanced
sternly
and
inquiringly
at
the
coffin
-
maker
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
protested
to
him
that
she
is
not
here
,
Sir
Paul
,
"
said
the
latter
,
"
but
he
will
not
believe
me
,
and
has
compelled
me
,
by
threats
of
taking
my
life
,
to
bring
him
and
his
companion
to
you
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Then
take
them
back
again
,
"
rejoined
Parravicin
,
turning
haughtily
upon
his
heel
.
 
<EOS>
"
That
answer
will
not
suffice
,
Sir
Paul
,
"
cried
Leonard--"I
will
not
depart
without
her
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
How
!
"
exclaimed
the
knight
,
drawing
his
sword
.
<EOS>
"
Do
you
dare
to
intrude
upon
my
presence
?
<EOS>
Begone
!
<EOS>
or
I
will
punish
your
presumption
.
"
<EOS>
And
he
prepared
to
attack
the
apprentice
.
 
<EOS>
"
Advance
a
footstep
,
"
rejoined
Leonard
,
who
had
never
relinquished
his
grasp
of
Chowles
,
"
and
I
pass
my
sword
through
this
man
's
body
.
<EOS>
Speak
,
villain
,
"
he
continued
,
in
a
tone
so
formidable
that
the
coffin
-
maker
shook
with
apprehension--"is
she
here
or
not
?
"
<EOS>
Chowles
gazed
from
him
to
the
knight
,
whose
deportment
was
equally
menacing
and
appeared
bewildered
with
terror
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
needless
,
"
said
Leonard
,
"
<EOS>
your
looks
answer
for
you
.
<EOS>
She
_
is
_
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
yes
,
I
confess
she
is
,
"
replied
Chowles
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
hear
what
he
says
,
Sir
Paul
,
"
remarked
Leonard
.
 
<EOS>
"
His
fears
would
make
him
assert
anything
,
"
rejoined
Parravicin
,
disdainfully
.
<EOS>
"
If
you
do
not
depart
instantly
,
I
will
drive
you
forth
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Sir
Paul
Parravicin
,
"
rejoined
Leonard
,
in
an
authoritative
tone
,
"
I
command
you
in
the
king
's
name
,
to
deliver
up
this
girl
.
"
 
<EOS>
Parravicin
laughed
scornfully
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
king
has
no
authority
here
,
"
he
said
.
 
<EOS>
"
Pardon
me
,
Sir
Paul
,
"
rejoined
Chowles
,
who
began
to
be
seriously
alarmed
at
his
own
situation
,
and
eagerly
grasped
at
the
opportunity
that
offered
of
extricating
himself
from
it--"pardon
me
.
<EOS>
If
it
is
the
king
's
pleasure
she
should
be
removed
,
it
materially
alters
the
case
,
and
I
can
be
no
party
to
her
detention
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Both
you
and
your
employer
will
incur
his
majesty
's
severest
displeasure
,
by
detaining
her
after
this
notice
,
"
remarked
Leonard
.
 
<EOS>
"
Before
I
listen
to
the
young
man
's
request
,
let
him
declare
that
it
is
his
intention
to
deliver
her
up
to
the
king
,
"
rejoined
Parravicin
,
coldly
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
my
intention
to
deliver
her
up
to
one
who
has
the
best
right
to
take
charge
of
her
,
"
returned
Leonard
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
mean
her
father
,
"
sneered
Parravicin
.
 
<EOS>
"
Ay
,
but
not
the
person
you
suppose
to
be
her
father
,
"
replied
Leonard
.
"
<EOS>
An
important
discovery
has
been
made
respecting
her
parentage
.
<EOS>
"
 
"
Indeed
!
"
exclaimed
Parravicin
,
with
a
look
of
surprise
.
<EOS>
"
Who
has
the
honour
to
be
her
father
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
A
gentleman
named
Thirlby
,
"
replied
Leonard
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Parravicin
,
starting
,
and
turning
pale
.
<EOS>
"
Did
you
say
Thirlby
?
"
 
<EOS>
The
apprentice
reiterated
his
assertion
.
<EOS>
Parravicin
uttered
a
deep
groan
,
and
pressed
his
hand
forcibly
against
his
brow
for
some
moments
,
during
which
the
apprentice
watched
him
narrowly
.
<EOS>
He
then
controlled
himself
by
a
powerful
effort
,
and
returned
his
sword
to
its
scabbard
.
 
<EOS>
"
Come
into
this
room
,
young
man
<EOS>
,
"
he
said
to
the
apprentice
,
"
and
let
your
companion
remain
outside
with
Chowles
.
<EOS>
Fear
nothing
.
<EOS>
I
intend
you
no
injury
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
do
not
distrust
you
,
"
replied
Leonard
,
"
and
if
I
did
,
should
have
no
apprehension
.
"
<EOS>
And
motioning
Rainbird
to
remain
where
he
was
,
he
entered
the
room
with
the
knight
,
who
instantly
closed
the
door
.
 
<EOS>
Parravicin
's
first
proceeding
was
to
question
him
as
to
his
reasons
for
supposing
Nizza
to
be
Thirlby
's
daughter
,
and
clearly
perceiving
the
deep
interest
his
interrogator
took
in
the
matter
,
and
the
favourable
change
that
,
from
some
unknown
cause
,
had
been
wrought
in
his
sentiments
,
the
apprentice
did
not
think
fit
to
hide
anything
from
him
.
<EOS>
Parravicin
's
agitation
increased
as
he
listened
to
the
recital
;
and
at
last
,
overcome
by
emotion
,
he
sank
into
a
chair
,
and
covered
his
face
with
his
hands
.
<EOS>
Recovering
himself
in
a
short
time
,
he
arose
,
and
began
to
pace
the
chamber
to
and
fro
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
I
have
told
you
seems
to
have
disturbed
you
,
Sir
Paul
,
"
remarked
Leonard
.
<EOS>
"
May
I
ask
the
cause
of
your
agitation
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
No
,
man
,
you
may
not
,
"
replied
Parravicin
,
angrily
.
<EOS>
And
then
suddenly
checking
himself
,
he
added
,
with
forced
calmness
,
"
<EOS>
And
so
you
parted
with
Mr.
Thirlby
on
London
Bridge
,
and
you
think
he
will
return
to
Doctor
Hodges
's
residence
in
Watling
-
street
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
sure
of
it
,
"
replied
Leonard
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
must
see
him
without
delay
,
"
rejoined
Parravicin
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
will
take
you
to
him
,
"
remarked
Leonard
;
"
but
first
I
must
see
Nizza
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
Parravicin
walked
to
a
table
,
on
which
stood
a
small
silver
bell
,
and
ringing
it
,
the
summons
was
immediately
answered
by
an
old
woman
.
<EOS>
He
was
about
to
deliver
a
message
to
her
,
when
the
disturbed
expression
of
her
countenance
struck
him
,
and
he
hastily
inquired
the
cause
of
it
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
must
not
see
the
young
lady
to
-
night
,
Sir
Paul
,
"
said
the
old
woman
.
 
<EOS>
"
Why
not
?
"
demanded
the
knight
,
hastily
.
<EOS>
"
Why
not
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
Because
--
but
you
frighten
me
so
that
I
dare
not
speak
,
"
was
the
answer
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
will
frighten
you
still
more
if
you
keep
me
in
this
state
of
suspense
,
"
rejoined
Parravicin
,
furiously
.
<EOS>
"
Is
she
ill
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
fear
she
has
got
the
plague
,
"
returned
the
old
woman
.
<EOS>
"
Now
you
can
see
her
if
you
think
proper
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
_
I
_
will
see
her
,
"
said
Leonard
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
no
fear
of
infection
.
"
 
<EOS>
The
old
woman
looked
hard
at
Parravicin
,
as
if
awaiting
his
orders
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
yes
,
you
can
take
him
to
her
room
,
"
said
the
knight
,
who
seemed
completely
overpowered
by
the
intelligence
,
"
if
he
chooses
to
go
thither
.
<EOS>
But
why
do
you
suppose
it
is
the
plague
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
One
can
not
well
be
deceived
in
a
seizure
of
that
kind
,
"
replied
the
old
woman
,
shaking
her
head
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
thought
the
disorder
never
attacked
the
same
person
twice
,
"
said
Parravicin
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
myself
am
an
instance
to
the
contrary
,
"
replied
Leonard
.
 
<EOS>
"
And
,
as
you
have
twice
recovered
,
there
may
be
a
chance
for
Nizza
,
"
said
Parravicin
.
<EOS>
"
This
old
woman
will
take
you
to
her
.
<EOS>
I
will
hasten
to
Doctor
Hodges
's
residence
,
and
if
I
should
fail
in
meeting
him
,
will
not
rest
till
I
procure
assistance
elsewhere
.
<EOS>
Do
not
leave
her
till
I
return
.
"
 
<EOS>
Leonard
readily
gave
a
promise
to
the
desired
effect
,
and
accompanying
him
to
the
door
,
told
Rainbird
what
had
happened
.
<EOS>
The
latter
agreed
to
wait
below
to
render
any
assistance
that
might
be
required
,
and
went
downstairs
with
Parravicin
and
Chowles
.
<EOS>
The
two
latter
instantly
quitted
the
house
together
,
and
hastened
to
Watling
-
street
.
 
<EOS>
With
a
beating
heart
,
Leonard
then
followed
the
old
woman
to
Nizza
's
chamber
.
<EOS>
They
had
to
pass
through
a
small
anteroom
,
the
door
of
which
was
carefully
locked
.
<EOS>
The
suite
of
apartments
occupied
by
the
captive
girl
were
exquisitely
and
luxuriously
furnished
,
and
formed
a
striking
contrast
to
the
rest
of
the
house
.
<EOS>
The
air
was
loaded
with
perfumes
;
choice
pictures
adorned
the
walls
;
and
the
tables
were
covered
with
books
and
china
ornaments
.
<EOS>
The
windows
,
however
,
were
strictly
barred
,
and
every
precaution
appeared
to
be
taken
to
prevent
an
attempt
at
escape
.
<EOS>
Leonard
cast
an
anxious
look
round
as
he
entered
the
anteroom
,
and
its
luxurious
air
filled
him
with
anxiety
.
<EOS>
His
conductress
,
however
,
did
not
allow
him
time
for
reflection
,
but
led
him
into
another
room
,
still
more
richly
furnished
than
the
first
,
and
lighted
by
a
large

,
that
shed

warm

around

.
<EOS>
An
old
dwarfed
African
,
in
a
fantastic
dress
,
and
with
a
large
scimetar
stuck
in

,
stepped
forward
on
their
approach
,
and
shook
his
head
significantly
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
is
dumb
,
"
said
the
old
woman
,
"
but
his
gestures
are
easy
to
be
understood
.
<EOS>
He
means
that
Nizza
is
worse
.
"
 
<EOS>
Leonard
heaved
a
deep
sigh
.
<EOS>
Passing
into
a
third
room
,
they
perceived
the
poor
girl
stretched
on
a
couch
placed
in
a
recess
at
one
side
.
<EOS>
She
heard
their

,
and
without
raising

,
or

,
said
,
in
a
weak

<EOS>
voice--"Tell
your
master
<EOS>
I
will
see
him
no
more
.
<EOS>
The
plague
has
again
attacked
me
,
and
I
am
glad
of
it
,
for
it
will
deliver
me
from
him
.
<EOS>
It
will
be
useless
to
offer
me
any
remedies
,
for
I
will
not
take
them
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
not
Sir
Paul
Parravicin
,
"
replied

old
woman
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
brought
a

,
with
whose

I
am

,
to
see
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Then
you
have
done
very
wrong
,
"
replied
Nizza
.
<EOS>
"
I
will
see
no
one
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Not
even
me
,
Nizza
?
<EOS>
"
asked
Leonard
,

.
<EOS>
The
poor
girl
started
at
the
sound

his
voice
,
and
raising

on

,

.
<EOS>
As

that
her

did

,

uttered

,
and

,

.
 
<EOS>
Leonard
and

girl
's

,
and
restoratives
being
applied
,
she

and
fixed

.
<EOS>
Before

,

--
an

--
and

,
proceeded
to

,
as

,
the

.
<EOS>
Nizza
listened

with

,
and
though

acute

,
uttered

,
but

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
must
now

all

,
"
she

,

.
<EOS>
"
I

king
,

--
I

arts
,
the

,

--

I

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"

"

,
"

who

,

,

.
<EOS>
I

;
and

.
<EOS>
Thinking

,
I

,

,

,
where

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
see
the
device
,
"

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
,

--
why
did

?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
What
could
I
do
?
"

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
To
stay
was
as

as
to
fly
,
and
might

.
<EOS>
At
all

,
I
had
no

.
<EOS>
My

opened
the
gate
,
and
called
to
some

without
.
<EOS>
It
was
profoundly
dark
;
but
I
could
perceive
a
carriage
,

,
at
a

.
<EOS>
Alarmed

,
I
whispered
my

to

,
and
would

;
but
she
laid

,
and
detained

.
<EOS>
The
next

I
felt
a
rude

upon
my

.
<EOS>
Before
I
could
cry
out
,
a

was
placed

so

as

;
and
I
was
forced
into

by

,
who
seated

on

side

,

to

.
<EOS>
The
carriage
was

driven

at
a

.
<EOS>
For
some
miles
it
pursued
the
high
road
,
and
then
struck
into
a
lane
,
where
,

,

.
<EOS>
But

,

,
and

.
<EOS>
No

the
others

,
and
the
door
being
forced

without

,

.
<EOS>
One

kept

,
while
the

lent

to

to

to

.
<EOS>
It
proved
,

,
to
be

,
that

;
and
,

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
Having

,

an

,
and
passed

,

.
<EOS>
Our

;

,

the
old

you

,

,

.
<EOS>
Some

,

Mrs.
Carteret
who

,

,

<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Still
,

?
"

.
 
<EOS>
"

,

,
"

.
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>

"
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

<EOS>
I

,

<EOS>

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

,
'
It

.
'
<EOS>

,

,

.
<EOS>
Yesterday
,

Paul

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
But

.
<EOS>

?
"
 
<EOS>
"
She

,

,
"

<EOS>
"
Alas

"

,

"
 
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

<EOS>
"

Lisle

"
 
"

?
<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
Ever

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
The

,

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

?
"
 
<EOS>
"

,

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
"

"
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Have

,

?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You

,
"

<EOS>
"

;

.
<EOS>
Thirlby

.
<EOS>
Have

<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Never
,
"

.
<EOS>
"
It

.
<EOS>
I

for

the
piper
,
who

.
<EOS>
But

.
<EOS>
Tell

.
"
 
<EOS>
As

,

Paul
Parravicin

.
<EOS>
The

,

,

,

,

,
"
At
last
<EOS>
I
have

--

!
<EOS>
my
child
!
"
<EOS>
The

an
address
was
materially
lessened
by
what
Leonard
had
just
told
her
;
and
,
after
earnestly
regarding
the
stranger
for
some
time
,
she
exclaimed
,
in
a
gentle
voice
,
"
My
father
!
"
 
<EOS>
Thirlby
sprang
to
his
feet
,
and
would
have
folded
her
in
his
arms
,
if
Doctor
Hodges
,
who
by
this
time
had
reached
the
couch
,
had
not
prevented
him
.
"
<EOS>
Touch
her
not
,
or
you
destroy
yourself
,
"
he
cried
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
care
not
if
I
do
,
"
rejoined
Thirlby
.
<EOS>
"
The
gratification
would
be
cheaply
purchased
at
the
price
of
my
life
;
and
if
I
could
preserve
hers
by
the
sacrifice
,
I
would
gladly
make
it
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
No
more
of
this
,
"
cried
Hodges
,
impatiently
,
"
or
you
will
defeat
any
attempt
I
may
make
to
cure
her
.
<EOS>
You
had
better
not
remain
here
.
<EOS>
Your
presence
agitates
her
.
"
 
<EOS>
Gazing
wistfully
at
his
daughter
,
and
scarcely
able
to
tear
himself
away
,
Thirlby
yielded
at
last
to
the
doctor
's
advice
,
and
quitted
the
room
.
<EOS>
He
was
followed
by
Leonard
,
who
received
a
hint
to
the
same
effect
.
<EOS>
On
reaching
the
adjoining
room
,
they
found
Sir
Paul
Parravicin
walking
to
and
fro
in
an
agitated
manner
.
<EOS>
He
immediately
came
up
to
Thirlby
,
and
,
in
an
anxious
but
deferential
tone
,
inquired
how
he
had
found
Nizza
?
<EOS>
The
latter
shook
his
head
,
and
,
sternly
declining
any
further
conversation
,
passed
on
with
the
apprentice
to
an
outer
room
.
<EOS>
He
then
flung
himself
into
a
chair
,
and
appeared
lost
in
deep
and
bitter
reflection
.
<EOS>
Leonard
was
unwilling
to
disturb
him
;
but
at
last
his
own
anxieties
compelled
him
to
break
silence
.
 
<EOS>
"
Can
you
tell
me
aught
of
Amabel
?
"
<EOS>
he
asked
.
 
<EOS>
"
Alas
!
<EOS>
no
,
"
replied
Thirlby
,
rousing
himself
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
had
no
time
to
inquire
about
her
,
as
you
shall
hear
.
<EOS>
After
leaving
you
on
the
bridge
,
I
went
into
Southwark
,
and
hurrying
through
all
the
principal
streets
,
inquired
from
every
watchman
I
met
whether
he
had
seen
any
person
answering
to
Doctor
Hodges
's
description
,
but
could
hear
nothing
of
him
.
<EOS>
At
last
I
gave
up
the
quest
,
and
,
retracing
my
steps
,
was
proceeding
along
Cannon
-
street
,
when
I
descried
a
person
a
little
in
advance
of
me
,
whom
I
thought
must
be
the
doctor
,
and
,
calling
out
to
him
,
found
I
was
not
mistaken
.
<EOS>
I
had
just
reached
him
,
when
two
other
persons
turned
the
corner
of
Nicholas
-
lane
.
<EOS>
On
seeing
us
,
one
of
them
ran
up
to
the
doctor
,
exclaiming
,
'
By
Heaven
,
the
very
person
I
want
!
'
<EOS>
It
was
Sir
Paul
Parravicin
;
and
he
instantly
explained
his
errand
.
<EOS>
Imagine
the
feelings
with
which
I
heard
his
account
of
the
illness
of
my
daughter
.
<EOS>
Imagine
,
also
,
the
horror
I
must
have
experienced
in
recognising
in
her
persecutor
my--
"
 
<EOS>
The
sentence
was
not
completed
,
for
at
that
moment
the
door
was
opened
by
Sir
Paul
Parravicin
,
who
,
advancing
towards
Thirlby
,
begged
,
in
the
same
deferential
tone
as
before
,
to
have
a
few
words
with
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
might
well
refuse
you
,
"
replied
Thirlby
,
sternly
,
"
but
it
is
necessary
we
should
have
some
explanation
of
what
has
occurred
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
,
"
rejoined
Parravicin
,
"
and
,
therefore
,
I
have
sought
you
.
"
<EOS>
Thirlby
arose
,
and
accompanied
the
knight
into
the
outer
room
,
closing
the
door
after
him
.
<EOS>
More
than
a
quarter
of
an
hour
--
it
seemed
an
age
to
Leonard
--
elapsed
,
and
still
no
one
came
.
<EOS>
Listening
intently
,
he
heard
voices
in
the
next
room
.
<EOS>
They
were
loud
and
angry
,
as
if
in
quarrel
.
<EOS>
Then
all
was
quiet
,
and
at
last
Thirlby
reappeared
,
and
took
his
seat
beside
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
Have
you
seen
Doctor
Hodges
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
the
apprentice
,
eagerly
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
,
"
replied
<EOS>
Thirlby--"and
he
speaks
favourably
of
my
poor
child
.
<EOS>
He
has
administered
all
needful
remedies
,
but
as
it
is
necessary
to
watch
their
effect
,
he
will
remain
with
her
some
time
longer
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
And
,
meanwhile
,
I
shall
know
nothing
of
Amabel
,
"
cried
Leonard
,
in
a
tone
of
bitter
disappointment
.
 
<EOS>
"
Your
anxiety
is
natural
,
"
returned
Thirlby
,
"
but
you
may
rest
satisfied
,
if
Doctor
Hodges
has
seen
her
,
he
has
done
all
that
human
aid
can
effect
.
<EOS>
But
as
you
must
perforce
wait
his
coming
forth
,
I
will
endeavour
to
beguile
the
tedious
interval
by
relating
to
you
so
much
of
my
history
as
refers
to
Nizza
Macascree
.
"
 
<EOS>
After
a
brief
pause
,
he
commenced
.
<EOS>
"
You
must
know
,
then
,
that
in
my
youth
I
became
desperately
enamoured
of
a
lady
named
Isabella
Morley
.
<EOS>
She
was
most
beautiful
--
but
I
need
not
enlarge
upon
her
attractions
,
since
you
have
beheld
her
very
image
in
Nizza
.
<EOS>
When
I
first
met
her
she
was
attached
to
another
,
but
I
soon
rid
myself
of
my
rival
.
<EOS>
I
quarrelled
with
him
,
and
slew
him
in
a
duel
.
<EOS>
After
a
long
and
urgent
suit
,
for
the
successful
issue
of
which
I
was
mainly
indebted
to
my
rank
and
wealth
,
which
gave
great
influence
with
her
parents
,
Isabella
became
mine
.
<EOS>
But
I
soon
found
out
she
did
not
love
me
.
<EOS>
In
consequence
of
this
discovery
,
I
became
madly
jealous
,
and
embittered
her
life
and
my
own
by
constant
,
and
,
now
I
know
too
well
,
groundless
suspicions
.
<EOS>
She
had
borne
me
a
son
,
and
in
the
excess
of
my
jealous
fury
,
fancying
the
child
was
not
my
own
,
I
threatened
to
put
it
to
death
.
<EOS>
This
violence
led
to
the
unhappy
result
I
am
about
to
relate
.
<EOS>
Another
child
was
born
,
a
daughter
--
need
I
say
Nizza
,
or
to
give
her
her
proper
name
,
Isabella
,
for
she
was
so
christened
after
her
mother
--
and
<EOS>
one
night
--
one
luckless
night,--maddened
by
some
causeless
doubt
,
I
snatched
the
innocent
babe
from
her
mother
's
arms
,
and
if
I
had
not
been
prevented
by
the
attendants
,
who
rushed
into
the
room
on
hearing
their
mistress
's
shrieks
,
should
have
destroyed
her
.
<EOS>
After
awhile
,
I
became
pacified
,
and
on
reviewing
my
conduct
more
calmly
on
the
morrow
,
bitterly
reproached
myself
,
and
hastened
to
express
my
penitence
to
my
wife
.
'
<EOS>
You
will
never
have
an
opportunity
of
repeating
your
violence
,
'
she
said
;
'
the
object
of
your
cruel
and
unfounded
suspicions
is
gone
.
<EOS>
'--'Gone
!
<EOS>
'
<EOS>
I
exclaimed
;
'
whither
?
'
<EOS>
And
as
I
spoke
I
looked
around
the
chamber
.
<EOS>
But
the
babe
was
nowhere
to
be
seen
.
<EOS>
In
answer
to
my
inquiries
,
my
wife
admitted
that
she
had
caused
her
to
be
removed
to
a
place
of
safety
,
but
refused
,
even
on
my
most
urgent
entreaties
,
accompanied
by
promises
of
amended
conduct
,
to
tell
me
where
.
<EOS>
I
next
interrogated
the
servants
,
but
they
professed
entire
ignorance
of
the
matter
.
<EOS>
For
three
whole
days
I
made
ineffectual
search
for
the
child
,
and
offered
large
rewards
to
any
one
who
would
bring
her
to
me
.
<EOS>
But
they
failed
to
produce
her
;
and
repairing
to
my
wife
's
chamber
,
I
threatened
her
with
the
most
terrible
consequences
if
she
persisted
in
her
vindictive
project
.
<EOS>
She
defied
me
,
and
,
transported
with
rage
<EOS>
,
I
passed
my
sword
through
her
body
,
exclaiming
as
I
dealt
the
murderous
blow
,
'
You
have
sent
the
brat
to
her
father
--
to
your
lover
,
madam
.
'
<EOS>
Horror
and
remorse
seized
me
the
moment
I
had
committed
the
ruthless
act
,
and
I
should
have
turned
my
sword
against
myself
,
if
I
had
not
been
stayed
by
the
cry
of
my
poor
victim
,
who
implored
me
to
hold
my
hand
.
'
<EOS>
Do
not
add
crime
to
crime
,
'
she
cried
;
'
you
have
done
me
grievous
wrong
.
<EOS>
I
have
not
,
indeed
,
loved
you
,
because
my
affections
were
not
under
my
control
,
but
I
have
been
ever
true
to
you
,
and
this
I
declare
with
my
latest
breath
.
<EOS>
I
freely
forgive
you
,
and
pray
God
to
turn
your
heart
.
'
<EOS>
And
with
these
words
she
expired
.
<EOS>
I
was
roused
from
the
stupefaction
into
which
I
was
thrown
by
the
appearance
of
the
servants
.
<EOS>
Heaping
execrations
upon
me
,
they
strove
to
seize
me
;
but
I
broke
through
them
,
and
gained
a
garden
at
the
back
of
my
mansion
,
which
was
situated
on
the
bank
of
the
Thames
,
not
far
from
Chelsea
.
<EOS>
This
garden
ran
down
to
the
river
side
,
and
was
defended
by
a
low
wall
,
which
I
leapt
,
and
plunged
into
the
stream
.
<EOS>
A
boat
was
instantly
sent
in
pursuit
of
me
,
and
a
number
of
persons
ran
along
the
banks
,
all
eager
for
my
capture
.
<EOS>
But
being
an
excellent
swimmer
,
I
tried
to
elude
them
,
and
as
I
never
appeared
again
,
it
was
supposed
I
was
drowned
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
And
Nizza
,
or
as
I
ought
now
to
call
her
,
Isabella
,
was
confided
,
I
suppose
,
to
the
piper
?
"
inquired
Leonard
.
 
<EOS>
"
She
was
confided
to
his
helpmate
,
"
replied
Thirlby
,
"
who
had
been
nurse
to
my
wife
.
<EOS>
Mike
Macascree
was
one
of
my
father
's
servants
,
and
was
in
his
younger
days
a
merry
,
worthless
fellow
.
<EOS>
The
heavy
calamity
under
which
he
now
labours
had
not
then
befallen
him
.
<EOS>
On
taking
charge
of
my
daughter
,
his
wife
received
certain
papers
substantiating
the
child
's
origin
,
together
with
a
miniature
,
and
a
small
golden
amulet
.
<EOS>
The
papers
and
miniature
were
delivered
by
her
on
her
death
-
bed
to
the
piper
,
who
showed
them
to
me
to
-
night
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
And
the
amulet
I
myself
have
seen
,
"
remarked
Leonard
.
 
<EOS>
"
To
resume
my
own
history
,
"
said
Thirlby--"after
<EOS>
the
dreadful
catastrophe
I
have
related
,
I
remained
concealed
in
London
for
some
months
,
and
was
glad
to
find
the
report
of
my
death
generally
believed
.
<EOS>
I
then
passed
over
into
Holland
,
where
I
resided
for
several
years
,
in
the
course
of
which
time
I
married
the
widow
of
a
rich
merchant
,
who
died
soon
after
our
union
,
leaving
me
one
child
.
"
<EOS>
And
he
covered
his
face
with
his
hands
to
hide
his
emotion
.
<EOS>
After
awhile
he
proceeded
:
 
"
Having
passed
many
years
,
as
peacefully
as
one
whose
conscience
was
so
heavily
burdened
as
mine
could
hope
to
pass
them
,
in
Amsterdam
,
I
last
summer
brought
my
daughter
,
around
whom
my
affections
were
closely
twined
,
to
London
,
and
took
up
my
abode
in
the
eastern
environs
of
the
city
.
<EOS>
There
again
I
was
happy
--
<EOS>
too
happy!--until
at
last
the
plague
came
.
<EOS>
But
why
should
I
relate
the
rest
of
my
sad
story
?
<EOS>
"
he
added
,
in
a
voice
suffocated
with
emotion--"you
know
it
as
well
as
I
do
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
said
you
had
a
son
,
"
observed
Leonard
,
after
a
pause--"Is
he
yet
living
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
He
is
,
"
replied
Thirlby
,
a
shade
passing
over
his
countenance
.
"
<EOS>
On
my
return
to
England
I
communicated
to
him
through
Judith
Malmayns
,
who
is
my
foster
-
sister
,
that
I
was
still
alive
,
telling
him
the
name
I
had
adopted
,
and
adding
,
I
should
never
disturb
him
in
the
possession
of
his
title
and
estates
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Title
!
"
exclaimed
Leonard
.
 
<EOS>
"
Ay
,
title
!
<EOS>
"
echoed
Thirlby
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
title
I
once
bore
was
that
of
Lord
Argentine
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
glad
to
hear
it
,
"
said
Leonard
,
"
for
I
began
to
fear
Sir
Paul
Parravicin
was
your
son
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Sir
Paul
Parravicin
,
or
,
rather
,
the
Lord
Argentine
,
for
such
is
his
rightful
title
,
_
is
_
my
son
,
"
returned
Thirlby
;
"
and
I
lament
to
own
<EOS>
I
am
his
father
.
<EOS>
When
among
his
worthless
associates,--nay
,
even
with
the
king
--
he
drops
the
higher
title
,
and
assumes
that
by
which
you
have
known
him
;
and
it
is
well
he
does
so
,
for
his
actions
are
sufficient
to
tarnish
a
far
nobler
name
than
that
he
bears
.
<EOS>
Owing
to
this
disguise
I
knew
not
he
was
the
person
who
carried
off
my
daughter
.
<EOS>
But
,
thank
Heaven
,
another
and
fouler
crime
has
been
spared
us
.
<EOS>
All
these
things
have
been
strangely
explained
to
me
to
-
night
.
<EOS>
And
thus
,
you
see
,
young
man
,
the
poor
piper
's
daughter
turns
out
to
be
the
Lady
Isabella
Argentine
.
<EOS>
"
Before
an
answer
could
be
returned
,
the
door
was
opened
by
Hodges
,
and
both
starting
to
their
feet
,
hurried
towards
him
.
  
<EOS>
IV
.
 
<EOS>
THE
TRIALS
OF
AMABEL
.
 
<EOS>
It
will
now
be
necessary
to
return
to
the
period
of
Amabel
's
abduction
from
Kingston
Lisle
.
<EOS>
The
shawl
thrown
over
her
head
prevented
her
cries
from
being
heard
;
and
,
notwithstanding
her
struggles
,
she
was
placed
on
horseback
before
a
powerful
man
,
who
galloped
off
with
her
along
the
Wantage
-
road
.
<EOS>
After
proceeding
at
a
rapid
pace
for
about
two
miles
,
her
conductor
came
to
a
halt
,
and
she
could
distinguish
the
sound
of
other
horsemen
approaching
.
<EOS>
At
first
she
hoped
it
might
prove
a
rescue
;
but
she
was
quickly
undeceived
.
<EOS>
The
shawl
was
removed
,
and
she
beheld
the
Earl
of
Rochester
,
accompanied
by
Pillichody
,
and
some
half
-
dozen
mounted
attendants
.
<EOS>
The
earl
would
have
transferred
her
to
his
own
steed
,
but
she
offered
such
determined
resistance
to
the
arrangement
,
that
he
was
compelled
to
content
himself
with
riding
by
her
aide
.
<EOS>
All
his
efforts
to
engage
her
in
conversation
were
equally
unsuccessful
.
<EOS>
She
made
no
reply
to
his
remarks
,
but
averted
her
gaze
from
him
;
and
,
whenever
he
approached
,
shrank
from
him
with
abhorrence
.
<EOS>
The
earl
,
however
,
was
not
easily
repulsed
,
but
continued
his
attentions
and
discourse
,
as
if
both
had
been
favourably
received
.
 
<EOS>
In
this
way
they
proceeded
for
some
miles
,
one
of
the
earl
's
attendants
,
who
was
well
acquainted
with
the
country
,
being
in
fact
a
native
of
it
,
serving
as
their
guide
.
<EOS>
They
had
quitted
the
Wantage
-
road
,
and
leaving
that
ancient
town
,
renowned
as
the
birthplace
of
the
great
Alfred
,
on
the
right
,
had
taken
the
direction
of
Abingdon
and
Oxford
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
lovely
evening
,
and
their
course
led
them
through
many
charming
places
.
<EOS>
But
the
dreariest
waste
would
have
been
as
agreeable
as
the
richest
prospect
to
Amabel
.
<EOS>
She
noted
neither
the
broad
meadows
,
yet
white
from
the
scythe
,
nor
the
cornfields
waving
with
their
deep
and
abundant
,
though
yet
immature
crops
;
nor
did
she
cast
even
a
passing
glance
at
any
one
of
those
green
spots
which
every
lane
offers
,
and
upon
which
the
eye
of
the
traveller
ordinarily
delights
to
linger
.
<EOS>
She
rode
beneath
a
natural
avenue
of
trees
,
whose
branches
met
overhead
like
the
arches
of
a
cathedral
,
and
was
scarcely
conscious
of
their
pleasant
shade
.
<EOS>
She
heard
neither
the
song
of
the
wooing
thrush
,
nor
the
cry
of
the
startled
blackbird
,
nor
the
evening
hymn
of
the
soaring
lark
.
<EOS>
Alike
to
her
was
the
gorse
-
covered
common
,
along
which
they
swiftly
speeded
,
and
the
steep
hill
-
side
up
which
they
more
swiftly
mounted
.
<EOS>
She
breathed
not
the
delicious
fragrance
of
the
new
-
mown
hay
,
nor
listened
to
the
distant
lowing
herds
,
the
bleating
sheep
,
or
the
cawing
rooks
.
<EOS>
She
thought
of
nothing
but
her
perilous
situation,--heard
nothing
but
the
voice
of
Rochester,--felt
nothing
but
the
terror
inspired
by
his
presence
.
 
<EOS>
As
the
earl
did
not
desire
to
pass
through
any
village
,
if
he
could
help
it
,
his
guide
led
him
along
the
most
unfrequented
roads
;
but
in
spite
of
his
caution
,
an
interruption
occurred
which
had
nearly
resulted
in
Amabel
's
deliverance
.
<EOS>
While
threading
a
narrow
lane
,
they
came
suddenly
upon
a
troop
of
haymakers
,
in
a
field
on
the
right
,
who
,
up
to
that
moment
,
had
been
hidden
from
view
by
the
high
hedges
.
<EOS>
On
seeing
them
,
Amabel
screamed
loudly
for
assistance
,
and
was
instantly
answered
by
their
shouts
.
<EOS>
Rochester
ordered
his
men
to
gallop
forward
,
but
the
road
winding
round
the
meadow
,
the
haymakers
were
enabled
to
take
a
shorter
cut
and
intercept
them
.
<EOS>
Leaping
the
hedge
,
a
stout
fellow
rushed
towards
Amabel
's
conductor
,
and
seized
the
bridle
of
his
steed
.
<EOS>
He
was
followed
by
two
others
,
who
would
have
instantly
liberated
the
captive
girl
,
if
the
earl
had
not
,
with
great
presence
of
mind
,
cried
out
,
"
Touch
her
not
,
as
you
value
your
lives
!
<EOS>
She
is
ill
of
the
plague
!
"
 
<EOS>
At
this
formidable
announcement
,
which
operated
like
magic
upon
Amabel
's
defenders
,
and
made
them
fall
back
more
quickly
than
the
weapons
of
the
earl
's
attendants
could
have
done
,
they
retreated
,
and
communicating
their
fears
to
their
comrades
,
who
were
breaking
through
the
hedge
in
all
directions
,
and
hurrying
to
their
aid
,
the
whole
band
took
to
their
heels
,
and
,
regardless
of
Amabel
's
continued
shrieks
,
never
stopped
till
they
supposed
themselves
out
of
the
reach
of
infection
.
<EOS>
The
earl
was
thus
at
liberty
to
pursue
his
way
unmolested
,
and
laughing
heartily
at
the
success
of
his
stratagem
,
and
at
the
consternation
he
had
created
among
the
haymakers
,
pressed
forward
.
 
<EOS>
Nothing
further
occurred
till
,
in
crossing
the
little
river
Ock
,
near
Lyford
,
the
horse
ridden
by
Amabel
's
conductor
missed
its
footing
,
and
precipitated
them
both
into
the
water
.
<EOS>
No
ill
consequences
followed
the
accident
.
<EOS>
Throwing
himself
into
the
shallow
stream
,
Rochester
seized
Amabel
,
and
placed
her
beside
him
on
his
own
steed
.
<EOS>
A
deathly
paleness
overspread
her
countenance
,
and
a
convulsion
shook
her
frame
as
she
was
thus
brought
into
contact
with
the
earl
,
who
,
fearing
the
immersion
might
prove
dangerous
in
her
present
delicate
state
of
health
,
quickened
his
pace
to
procure
assistance
.
<EOS>
Before
he
had
proceeded
a
hundred
yards
,
Amabel
fainted
.
<EOS>
Gazing
at
her
with
admiration
,
and
pressing
her
inanimate
frame
to
his
breast
,
Rochester
imprinted
a
passionate
kiss
on
her
cheek
.
 
<EOS>
"
By
my
soul
!
"
he
mentally
ejaculated
,
"
I
never
thought
I
could
be
so
desperately
enamoured
.
<EOS>
I
would
not
part
with
her
for
the
crown
of
these
realms
.
"
 
<EOS>
While
considering
whither
he
should
take
her
,
and
much
alarmed
at
her
situation
,
the
man
who
acted
as
guide
came
to
his
relief
.
<EOS>
Halting
till
the
earl
came
up
,
he
said
,
"
If
you
want
assistance
for
the
young
lady
,
my
lord
,
I
can
take
you
to
a
good
country
<EOS>
inn
,
not
far
from
this
,
where
she
will
be
well
attended
to
,
and
where
,
as
it
is
kept
by
my
father
,
I
can
answer
that
no
questions
will
be
asked
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Precisely
what
I
wish
,
Sherborne
,
"
replied
Rochester
.
<EOS>
"
We
will
halt
there
for
the
night
.
<EOS>
Ride
on
as
fast
as
you
can
.
"
 
<EOS>
Sherborne
struck
spurs
into
his
steed
,
and
passing
Kingston
Bagpuze
,
reached
the
high
road
between
Abingdon
and
Faringdon
,
at
the
corner
of
which
stood
the
inn
in
question,--a
good
-
sized
habitation
,
with
large
stables
and
a
barn
attached
to
it
.
<EOS>
Here
he
halted
,
and
calling
out
in
a
loud
and
authoritative
voice
,
the
landlord
instantly
answered
the
summons
;
and
,
on
being
informed
by
his
son
of
the
rank
of
his
guest
,
doffed
his
cap
,
and
hastened
to
assist
the
earl
to
dismount
.
<EOS>
But
Rochester
declined
his
services
,
and
bidding
him
summon
his
wife
,
she
shortly
afterwards
made
her
appearance
in
the
shape
of
a
stout
middle
-
aged
dame
.
<EOS>
Committing
Amabel
to
her
care
,
the
earl
then
alighted
,
and
followed
them
into
the
house
.
 
<EOS>
The
Plough
,
for
so
the
inn
was
denominated
,
was
thrown
into
the
utmost
confusion
by
the
arrival
of
the
earl
and
his
suite
.
<EOS>
All
the
ordinary
frequenters
of
the
inn
were
ejected
,
while
the
best
parlour
was
instantly
prepared
for
the
accommodation
of
his
lordship
and
Pillichody
.
<EOS>
But
Rochester
was
far
more
anxious
for
Amabel
than
himself
,
and
could
not
rest
for
a
moment
till
assured
by
Dame
Sherborne
that
she
was
restored
to
sensibility
,
and
about
to
retire
to
rest
.
<EOS>
He
then
became
easy
,
and
sat
down
to
supper
with
Pillichody
.
<EOS>
So
elated
was
he
by
his
success
,
that
,
yielding
to
his
natural
inclination
for
hard
drinking
,
he
continued
to
revel
so
freely
and
so
long
with
his
follower
<EOS>
,
that
daybreak
found
them
over
their
wine
,
the
one
toasting
the
grocer
's
daughter
,
and
the
other
Patience
,
when
they
both
staggered
off
to
bed
.
 
<EOS>
A
couple
of
hours
sufficed
Rochester
to
sleep
off
the
effects
of
his
carouse
.
<EOS>
At
six
o'clock
he
arose
,
and
ordered
his
attendants
to
prepare
to
set
out
without
delay
.
<EOS>
When
all
was
ready
,
he
sent
for
Amabel
,
but
she
refused
to
come
downstairs
,
and
finding
his
repeated
messages
of
no
avail
,
he
rushed
into
her
room
,
and
bore
her
,
shrieking
to
his
steed
.
 
<EOS>
In
an
hour
after
this
,
they
arrived
at
an
old
hall
,
belonging
to
the
earl
,
in
the
neighbourhood
of
Oxford
.
<EOS>
Amabel
was
entrusted
to
the
care
of
a
female
attendant
,
named
Prudence
,
and
towards
evening
,
Rochester
,
who
was
burning
with
impatience
for
an
interview
,
learnt
,
to
his
infinite
disappointment
,
that
she
was
so
seriously
unwell
,
that
if
he
forced
himself
into
her
presence
,
her
life
might
be
placed
in
jeopardy
.
<EOS>
She
continued
in
the
same
state
for
several
days
,
at
the
end
of
which
time
,
the
chirurgeon
who
attended
her
,
and
who
was
a
creature
of
the
earl
's
,
pronounced
her
out
of
danger
.
<EOS>
Rochester
then
sent
her
word
by
Prudence
that
he
must
see
her
in
the
course
of
that
day
,
and
a
few
hours
after
the
delivery
of
the
message
,
he
sought
her
room
.
<EOS>
She
was
much
enfeebled
by
illness
,
but
received
him
with
great
self
-
possession
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
can
not
believe
,
my
lord
,
"
she
said
,
"
that
you
desire
to
destroy
me
,
and
when
I
assure
you
--
solemnly
assure
you
,
that
if
you
continue
to
persecute
me
thus
,
my
death
,
will
be
the
consequence
<EOS>
,
I
am
persuaded
you
will
desist
,
and
suffer
me
to
depart
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Amabel
,
"
rejoined
the
earl
,
passionately
,
"
is
it
possible
you
can
be
so
changed
towards
me
?
<EOS>
Nothing
now
interferes
to
prevent
our
union
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Except
my
own
determination
to
the
contrary
,
my
lord
,
"
she
replied
.
<EOS>
"
I
can
never
be
yours
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Wherefore
not
?
<EOS>
"
asked
the
earl
,
half
angrily
,
half
reproachfully
.
 
<EOS>
"
Because
I
know
and
feel
that
I
should
condemn
myself
to
wretchedness
,
"
she
replied
.
<EOS>
"
Because
--
for
since
your
lordship
will
force
the
truth
from
me
,
I
must
speak
out
--
I
have
learnt
to
regard
your
character
in
its
true
light,--and
because
my
heart
is
wedded
to
heaven
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Pshaw
!
"
exclaimed
the
earl
,
contemptuously
;
"
you
have
been
listening
so
long
to
your
saintly
father
's
discourses
,
that
you
fancy
them
applicable
to
yourself
.
<EOS>
But
you
are
mistaken
in
me
,
"
he
added
,
altering
his
tone
;
"
I
see
where
the
main
difficulty
lies
.
<EOS>
You
think
I
am
about
to
delude
you
,
as
before
,
into
a
mock
marriage
.
<EOS>
But
I
swear
to
you
you
are
mistaken
.
<EOS>
I
love
you
so
well
that
I
would
risk
my
temporal
and
eternal
happiness
for
you
.
<EOS>
It
will
rejoice
me
to
raise
you
to
my
own
rank
--
to
place
you
among
the
radiant
beauties
of
our
sovereign
's
court
,
the
brightest
of
whom
you
will
outshine
,
and
to
devote
my
whole
life
to
your
happiness
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
too
late
,
"
sighed
Amabel
.
 
<EOS>
"
Why
too
late
?
"
cried
the
earl
,
imploringly
.
<EOS>
"
We
have
gone
through
severe
trials
,
it
is
true
.
<EOS>
I
have
been
constantly
baffled
in
my
pursuit
of
you
,
but
disappointment
has
only
made
me
love
you
more
devotedly
.
<EOS>
Why
too
late
?
<EOS>
What
is
to
prevent
our
nuptials
from
taking
place
to
-
day
--
to
-
morrow
--
when
you
will
?
<EOS>
The
king
himself
shall
be
present
at
the
ceremony
,
and
shall
give
you
away
.
<EOS>
Will
this
satisfy
your
scruples
.
<EOS>
I
know
I
have
offended
you
.
<EOS>
I
know
I
deserve
your
anger
.
<EOS>
But
the
love
that
prompted
me
to
act
thus
,
must
also
plead
my
pardon
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Strengthen
me
!
"
<EOS>
she
murmured
,
looking
supplicatingly
upwards
.
"
<EOS>
Strengthen
me
,
for
my
trial
is
very
severe
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Be
not
deceived
,
Amabel
,
"
continued
Rochester
,
yet
more
ardently
;
"
that
you
love
me
<EOS>
I
am
well
assured
,
however
strongly
you
may
at
this
moment
persuade
yourself
to
the
contrary
.
<EOS>
Be
not
governed
by
your
father
's
strait
-
laced
and
puritanical
opinions
.
<EOS>
Men
,
such
as
he
is
,
can
not
judge
of
fiery
natures
like
mine
.
<EOS>
I
myself
have
had
to
conquer
a
stubborn
and
rebellious
spirit,--the
demon
pride
.
<EOS>
But
I
have
conquered
.
<EOS>
Love
has
achieved
the
victory,--love
for
you
.
<EOS>
I
offer
you
my
heart
,
my
hand
,
my
title
.
<EOS>
A
haughty
noble
makes
this
offer
to
a
grocer
's
daughter
.
<EOS>
Can
you
--
will
you
refuse
me
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
can
and
do
,
my
lord
,
"
she
replied
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
achieved
a
yet
harder
victory
.
<EOS>
With
me
,
principle
has
conquered
love
.
<EOS>
I
no
longer
respect
you
,
no
longer
love
you
--
and
,
therefore
,
can
not
we
d
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Rash
and
obstinate
girl
,
"
cried
the
earl
,
unable
to
conceal
his
mortification
;
"
you
will
bitterly
repent
your
inconsiderate
conduct
.
<EOS>
I
offer
you
devotion
such
as
no
other
person
could
offer
you
,
and
rank
such
as
no
other
is
likely
to
offer
you
.
<EOS>
You
are
now
in
my
power
,
and
you
_
shall
_
be
mine,--in
<EOS>
what
way
rests
with
yourself
.
<EOS>
You
shall
have
a
week
to
consider
the
matter
.
<EOS>
At
the
end
of
that
time
,
I
will
again
renew
my
proposal
.
<EOS>
If
you
accept
it
,
well
and
good
.
<EOS>
If
not
,
you
know
the
alternative
.
"
<EOS>
And
without
waiting
for
a
reply
,
he
quitted
the
room
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
as
good
as
his
word
.
<EOS>
During
the
whole
of
the
week
allowed
Amabel
for
consideration
,
he
never
intruded
upon
her
,
nor
was
his
name
at
any
time
mentioned
by
her
attendants
.
<EOS>
If
she
had
been
,
indeed
,
Countess
of
Rochester
,
she
could
not
have
been
treated
with
greater
respect
than
was
shown
her
.
<EOS>
The
apartment
allotted
her
opened
upon
a
large
garden
,
surrounded
by
high
walls
,
and
she
walked
within
it
daily
.
<EOS>
Her
serenity
of
mind
remained
undisturbed
;
her
health
visibly
improved
;
and
,
what
was
yet
more
surprising
,
she
entirely
recovered
her
beauty
.
<EOS>
The
whole
of
her
time
not
devoted
to
exercise
,
was
spent
in
reading
,
or
in
prayer
.
<EOS>
On
the
appointed
day
,
Rochester
presented
himself
.
<EOS>
She
received
him
with
the
most
perfect
composure
,
and
with
a
bland
look
,
from
which
he
augured
favourably
.
<EOS>
He
waved
his
hand
to
the
attendants
,
and
they
were
alone
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
came
for
your
answer
,
Amabel
,
"
he
said
;
"
but
I
scarcely
require
it
,
being
convinced
from
your
looks
that
I
have
nothing
to
fear
.
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
why
did
you
not
abridge
this
tedious
interval
?
<EOS>
Why
not
inform
me
you
had
altered
your
mind
?
<EOS>
But
I
will
not
reproach
you
.
<EOS>
I
am
too
happy
to
complain
of
the
delay
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
must
undeceive
you
,
my
lord
,
"
returned
Amabel
,
gravely
.
"
<EOS>
No
change
has
taken
place
in
my
feelings
.
<EOS>
I
still
adhere
to
the
resolution
I
had
come
to
when
we
last
parted
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
How
!
"
exclaimed
the
earl
,
his
countenance
darkening
,
and
the
evil
look
which
Amabel
had
before
noticed
taking
possession
of
it
.
"
<EOS>
One
moment
lured
on
,
and
next
rebuffed
.
<EOS>
But
no
--
no
!
"
<EOS>
he
added
,
constraining
himself
,
"
you
can
not
mean
it
.
<EOS>
It
is
not
in
woman
's
nature
to
act
thus
.
<EOS>
You
have
loved
me
--
you
love
me
still
.
<EOS>
Make
me
happy
--
make
yourself
happy
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
My
lord
,
"
she
replied
,
"
strange
and
unnatural
as
my
conduct
may
appear
,
you
will
find
it
consistent
.
<EOS>
You
have
lost
the
sway
you
had
once
over
me
,
and
,
for
the
reasons
I
have
already
given
you
,
I
can
never
be
yours
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
recall
your
words
,
Amabel
,
"
he
cried
,
in
the
most
moving
tones
he
could
command
;
"
if
you
have
no
regard
for
me
--
at
least
have
compassion
.
<EOS>
I
will
quit
the
court
if
you
desire
it
;
will
abandon
title
,
rank
,
wealth
;
and
live
in
the
humblest
station
with
you
.
<EOS>
You
know
not
what
I
am
capable
of
when
under
the
dominion
of
passion
.
<EOS>
I
am
capable
of
the
darkest
crimes
,
or
of
the
brightest
virtues
.
<EOS>
The
woman
who
has
a
man
's
heart
in
her
power
may
mould
it
to
her
own
purposes
,
be
they
good
or
ill
.
<EOS>
Reject
me
,
and
you
drive
me
to
despair
,
and
plunge
me
into
guilt
.
<EOS>
Accept
me
,
and
you
may
lead
me
into
any
course
,
you
please
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Were
I
assured
of
this--
"
cried
Amabel
.
 
<EOS>
"
Rest
assured
of
it
,
"
returned
the
earl
,
passionately
.
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
yield
to
impulses
of
natural
affection
,
and
do
not
suffer
a
cold
and
calculating
creed
to
chill
your
better
feelings
.
<EOS>
How
many
a
warm
and
loving
heart
has
been
so
frozen
!
<EOS>
Do
not
let
yours
be
one
of
them
.
<EOS>
Be
mine
!
<EOS>
be
mine
!
"
 
<EOS>
Amabel
looked
at
him
earnestly
for
a
moment
;
while
he
,
assured
that
he
had
gained
his
point
,
could
not
conceal
a
slightly
triumphant
smile
.
 
<EOS>
"
Now
,
your
answer
!
"
<EOS>
he
cried
.
<EOS>
"
My
life
hangs
upon
it
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
still
unmoved
,
"
she
replied
,
coldly
,
and
firmly
.
 
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
<EOS>
"
exclaimed
the
earl
with
a
terrible
imprecation
,
and
starting
to
his
feet
.
<EOS>
"
You
refuse
me
.
<EOS>
Be
it
so
.
<EOS>
But
think
not
that
you
shall
escape
me
.
<EOS>
No
,
you
are
in
my
power
,
and
I
will
use
it
.
<EOS>
You
shall
be
mine
and
without
the
priest
's
interference
.
<EOS>
I
will
not
degrade
myself
by
an
alliance
with
one
so
lowly
born
.
<EOS>
The
strongest
love
is
nearest
allied
to
hatred
,
and
mine
has
become
hatred
--
bitter
hatred
.
<EOS>
You
shall
be
mine
,
I
tell
you
,
and
when
I
am
indifferent
to
you
,
I
will
cast
you
off
.
<EOS>
Then
,
when
you
are
neglected
,
despised
,
shunned
,
you
will
regret
--
deeply
but
unavailingly
--
your
rejection
of
my
proposals
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
No
,
my
lord
,
I
shall
never
regret
it
,
"
replied
Amabel
,
"
and
I
can
not
sufficiently
rejoice
that
I
did
not
yield
to
the
momentary
weakness
that
inclined
me
to
accept
them
.
<EOS>
I
thank
you
for
the
insight
you
have
afforded
me
into
your
character
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
have
formed
an
erroneous
opinion
of
me
,
Amabel
,
"
cried
the
earl
,
seeing
his
error
,
and
trying
to
correct
it
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
well
nigh
distracted
by
conflicting
emotions
.
<EOS>
Oh
,
forgive
my
violence
--
forget
it
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Readily
,
"
she
replied
;
"
but
think
not
I
attach
the
least
credit
to
your
professions
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Away
,
then
,
with
further
disguise
,
"
returned
the
earl
,
relapsing
into
his
furious
mood
,
"
and
recognise
in
me
the
person
I
am
--
or
,
rather
the
person
you
would
have
me
be
.
<EOS>
You
say
you
are
immovable
.
<EOS>
So
am
I
;
nor
will
I
further
delay
my
purpose
.
"
 
<EOS>
Amabel
,
who
had
watched
him
uneasily
during
this
speech
,
retreated
a
step
,
and
taking
a
small
dagger
from
a
handkerchief
in
which
she
kept
it
concealed
,
placed
its
point
against
her
breast
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
well
know
whom
I
have
to
deal
with
,
my
lord
,
"
she
said
,
"
and
am
,
therefore
,
provided
against
the
last
extremity
.
<EOS>
Attempt
to
touch
me
,
and
I
plunge
this
dagger
into
my
heart
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Your
sense
of
religion
will
not
allow
you
to
commit
so
desperate
a
deed
,
"
replied
the
earl
,
derisively
.
 
<EOS>
"
My
blood
be
upon
your
head
,
my
lord
,
<EOS>
"
she
rejoined
;
"
for
it
is
your
hand
that
strikes
the
blow
,
and
not
my
own
.
<EOS>
My
honour
is
dearer
to
me
than
life
,
and
I
will
unhesitatingly
sacrifice
the
one
to
preserve
the
other
.
<EOS>
I
have
no
fear
but
that
the
action
,
wrongful
though
it
be
,
will
be
forgiven
me
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Hold
!
"
<EOS>
exclaimed
the
earl
,
seeing
from
her
determined
look
and
manner
that
she
would
unquestionably
execute
her
purpose
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
no
desire
to
drive
you
to
destruction
.
<EOS>
Think
over
what
I
have
said
to
you
,
and
we
will
renew
the
subject
tomorrow
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Renew
it
when
you
please
,
my
lord
,
my
answer
will
still
be
the
same
,
"
she
replied
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
but
one
refuge
from
you
--
the
grave
--
and
thither
,
if
need
be
,
I
will
fly
.
"
<EOS>
And
as
she
spoke
,
she
moved
slowly
towards
the
adjoining
chamber
,
the
door
of
which
she
fastened
after
her
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
thought
I
had
some
experience
of
her
sex
,
"
said
Rochester
to
himself
,
"
<EOS>
but
I
find
I
was
mistaken
.
<EOS>
To
-
morrow
's
mood
,
however
,
may
be
unlike
to
-
day
's
.
<EOS>
At
all
events
,
I
must
take
my
measures
differently
.
"
        
<EOS>
*
      
<EOS>
*
      
<EOS>
*
      
<EOS>
*
      
<EOS>
*
  
<EOS>
V.
 
<EOS>
THE
MARRIAGE
AND
ITS
CONSEQUENCES
.
 
<EOS>
Unwilling
to
believe
he
had
become
an
object
of
aversion
to
Amabel
,
Rochester
renewed
his
solicitations
on
the
following
day
,
and
calling
into
play
his
utmost
fascination
of
manner
,
endeavoured
to
remove
any
ill
impression
produced
by
his
previous
violence
.
<EOS>
She
was
proof
,
however
,
against
his
arts
;
and
though
he
never
lost
his
mastery
over
himself
,
he
had
some
difficulty
in
concealing
his
chagrin
at
the
result
of
the
interview
.
<EOS>
He
now
began
to
adopt
a
different
course
,
and
entering
into
long
discussions
with
Amabel
,
strove
by
every
effort
of
wit
and
ridicule
,
to
shake
and
subvert
her
moral
and
religious
principles
.
<EOS>
But
here
again
he
failed
;
and
once
more
shifting
his
ground
,
affected
to
be
convinced
by
her
arguments
.
<EOS>
He
entirely
altered
his
demeanour
,
and
though
Amabel
could
not
put
much
faith
in
the
change
,
it
was
a
subject
of
real
rejoicing
to
her
.
<EOS>
Though
scarcely
conscious
of
it
herself
,
he
sensibly
won
upon
her
regards
,
and
she
passed
many
hours
of
each
day
in
his
society
without
finding
it
irksome
.
<EOS>
Seeing
the
advantage
he
had
gained
,
and
well
aware
that
he
should
lose
it
by
the
slightest
indiscretion
,
Rochester
acted
with
the
greatest
caution
.
<EOS>
The
more
at
ease
she
felt
with
him
,
the
more
deferential
did
he
become
;
and
before
she
was
conscious
of
her
danger
,
the
poor
girl
was
once
more
on
the
brink
of
the
precipice
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
about
this
time
that
Leonard
Holt
,
as
has
been
previously
intimated
,
discovered
her
retreat
,
and
contrived
,
by
clambering
up
a
pear
-
tree
which
was
nailed
against
the
wall
of
the
house
,
to
reach
her
chamber
-
window
.
<EOS>
Having
received
her
assurance
that
she
had
resisted
all
Rochester
's
importunities
,
the
apprentice
promised
to
return
on
the
following
night
with
means
to
affect
her
liberation
,
and
departed
.
<EOS>
Fully
persuaded
that
she
could
now
repose
confidence
in
the
earl
,
Amabel
acquainted
him
,
the
next
morning
,
with
Leonard
's
visit
,
adding
that
he
would
now
have
an
opportunity
of
proving
the
sincerity
of
his
professions
by
delivering
her
up
to
her
friends
.
 
<EOS>
"
Since
you
desire
it
,
"
replied
the
earl
,
who
heard
her
with
an
unmoved
countenance
,
though
internally
torn
with
passion
,
"
I
will
convey
you
to
your
father
myself
.
<EOS>
I
had
hoped
,
"
he
added
with
a
sigh
,
"
that
we
should
never
part
again
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
fear
I
have
been
mistaken
in
you
,
my
lord
,
"
rejoined
Amabel
,
half
-
repenting
her
frankness
.
 
<EOS>
"
Not
so
,
"
he
replied
.
<EOS>
"
I
will
do
anything
you
require
,
except
deliver
you
to
this
hateful
apprentice
.
<EOS>
If
it
is
your
pleasure
,
I
repeat
,
I
will
take
you
back
to
your
father
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Promise
me
this
,
my
lord
,
and
I
shall
be
quite
easy
,
"
cried
Amabel
,
joyfully
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
do
promise
it
,
"
he
returned
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
oh
!
<EOS>
why
not
stay
with
me
,
and
complete
the
good
work
you
have
begun
?
"
 
<EOS>
Amabel
averted
her
head
,
and
Rochester
sighing
deeply
,
quitted
the
room
.
<EOS>
An
attendant
shortly
afterwards
came
to
inform
her
that
the
earl
intended
to
start
for
London
without
delay
,
and
begged
her
to
prepare
for
the
journey
.
<EOS>
In
an
hour
's
time
,
a
carriage
drove
to
the
door
,
and
Rochester
having
placed
her
and
Prudence
in
it
,
mounted
his
horse
,
and
set
forth
.
<EOS>
Late
on
the
second
day
they
arrived
in
London
,
and
passing
through
the
silent
and
deserted
streets
,
the
aspect
of
which
struck
terror
into
all
the
party
,
shaped
their
course
towards
the
city
.
<EOS>
Presently
they
reached
Ludgate
,
but
instead
of
proceeding
to
Wood
-
street
,
the
carriage
turned
off
on
the
right
,
and
traversing
Thames
-
street
,
crossed
London
Bridge
.
<EOS>
Amabel
could
obtain
no
explanation
of
this
change
from
Prudence
;
and
her
uneasiness
was
not
diminished
when
the
vehicle
,
which
was
driven
down
a
narrow
street
on
the
left
immediately
after
quitting
the
bridge
,
stopped
at
the
entrance
of
a
large
court
-
yard
.
<EOS>
Rochester
,
who
had
already
dismounted
,
assisted
her
to
alight
,
and
in
answer
to
her
hasty
inquiries
why
he
had
brought
her
thither
,
told
her
he
thought
it
better
to
defer
taking
her
to
her
father
till
the
morrow
.
<EOS>
Obliged
to
be
content
with
this
excuse
,
she
was
led
into
the
house
,
severely
reproaching
herself
for
her
indiscretion
.
<EOS>
Nothing
,
however
,
occurred
to
alarm
her
that
night
.
<EOS>
The
earl
was
even
more
deferential
than
before
,
and
assuring
her
he
would
fulfil
his
promise
in
the
morning
,
confided
her
to
Prudence
.
 
<EOS>
The
house
whither
she
had
been
brought
was
large
and
old
-
fashioned
.
<EOS>
The
rooms
had
once
been
magnificently
fitted
up
,
but
the
hangings
and
furniture
were
much
faded
,
and
had
a
gloomy
and
neglected
air
.
<EOS>
This
was
especially
observable
in
the
sleeping
-
chamber
appointed
for
her
reception
.
<EOS>
It
was
large
and
lofty
,
panelled
with
black
and
shining
oak
,
with
a
highly
-
polished
floor
of
the
same
material
,
and
was
filled
with
cumbrous
chests
and
cabinets
,
and
antique
high
-
backed
chairs
.
<EOS>
But
the
most
noticeable
object
was
a
large
state
-
bed
,
with
a
heavy
square
canopy
,
covered
,
with
the
richest
damask
,
woven
with
gold
,
and
hung
with
curtains
of
the
same
stuff
,
though
now
decayed
and
tarnished
.
<EOS>
A
chill
crept
over
Amabel
as
she
gazed
around
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
can
not
help
thinking
,
"
she
observed
to
Prudence
,
"
that
I
shall
breathe
my
last
in
this
room
,
and
in
that
bed
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
hope
not
,
madam
,
"
returned
the
attendant
,
unable
to
repress
a
shudder
.
 
<EOS>
Nothing
more
was
said
,
and
Amabel
retired
to
rest
.
<EOS>
But
not
being
able
to
sleep
,
and
having
vainly
tried
to
compose
herself
,
she
arose
and
opened
the
window
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
serene
and
beautiful
night
,
and
she
could
see
the
smooth
river
sparkling
in
the
starlight
,
and
flowing
at
a
hundred
yards
'
distance
at
the
foot
of
the
garden
.
<EOS>
Beyond
,
she
could
indistinctly
perceive
the
outline
of
the
mighty
city
,
while
nearer
,
on
the
left
,
lay
the
bridge
.
<EOS>
Solemnly
across
the
water
came
the
sound
of
innumerable
bells
,
tolling
for
those
who
had
died
of
the
plague
,
and
were
now
being
borne
to
their
last
home
.
<EOS>
While
listening
to
these
sad
sounds
,
another
,
but
more
doleful
and
appalling
noise
,
caught
her
ears
.
<EOS>
It
was
the
rumbling
of
cart
-
wheels
in
the
adjoining
street
,
accompanied
by
the
ringing
of
a
hand
-
bell
,
while
a
hoarse
-
voice
cried
,
"
Bring
out
your
dead
!
<EOS>
bring
out
your
dead
!
"
<EOS>
On
hearing
this
cry
,
she
closed
the
window
and
retired
.
<EOS>
Morning
broke
before
sleep
visited
her
weary
eyelids
,
and
then
,
overcome
by
fatigue
,
she
dropped
into
a
slumber
,
from
which
she
did
not
awake
until
the
day
was
far
advanced
.
<EOS>
She
found
Prudence
sitting
by
her
bedside
,
and
alarmed
by
the
expression
of
her
countenance
,
anxiously
inquired
what
was
the
matter
?
 
<EOS>
"
Alas
!
madam
,
"
replied
the
attendant
,
"
the
earl
has
been
taken
suddenly
ill
.
<EOS>
He
set
out
for
Wood
-
street
the
first
thing
this
morning
,
and
has
seen
your
father
,
who
refuses
to
receive
you
.
<EOS>
On
his
return
,
he
complained
of
a
slight
sickness
,
which
has
gradually
increased
in
violence
,
and
there
can
be
little
doubt
it
is
the
plague
.
<EOS>
Advice
has
been
sent
for
.
<EOS>
He
prays
you
not
to
disturb
yourself
on
his
account
,
but
to
consider
yourself
sole
mistress
of
this
house
,
whatever
may
befall
him
.
"
 
<EOS>
Amabel
passed
a
miserably
anxious
day
.
<EOS>
A
fresh
interest
had
been
awakened
in
her
heart
in
behalf
of
the
earl
,
and
the
precarious
state
in
which
she
conceived
him
placed
did
not
tend
to
diminish
it
.
<EOS>
She
made
many
inquiries
after
him
,
and
learned
that
he
was
worse
,
while
the
fearful
nature
of
the
attack
could
not
be
questioned
.
<EOS>
On
the
following
day
Prudence
reported
that
the
distemper
had
made
such
rapid
and
terrible
progress
,
that
his
recovery
was
considered
almost
hopeless
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
raves
continually
of
you
,
madam
,
"
said
the
attendant
,
"
and
<EOS>
I
have
no
doubt
he
will
expire
with
your
name
on
his
lips
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
Amabel
was
moved
to
tears
by
the
information
,
and
withdrawing
into
a
corner
of
the
room
,
prayed
fervently
for
the
supposed
sufferer
.
<EOS>
Prudence
gazed
at
her
earnestly
and
compassionately
,
and
muttering
something
to
herself
,
quitted
the
room
.
<EOS>
The
next
day
was
the
critical
one
(
so
it
was
said
)
for
the
earl
,
and
Amabel
awaited
,
in
tearful
anxiety
,
the
moment
that
was
to
decide
his
fate
.
<EOS>
It
came
,
and
he
was
pronounced
out
of
danger
.
<EOS>
When
the
news
was
brought
the
anxious
girl
,
she
fainted
.
 
<EOS>
A
week
passed
,
and
the
earl
,
continued
to
improve
,
and
all
danger
of
infection
--
if
any
such
existed
--
being
at
an
end
,
he
sent
a
message
to
Amabel
,
beseeching
her
to
grant
him
an
interview
in
his
own
room
.
<EOS>
She
willingly
assented
,
and
,
following
the
attendant
,
found
him
stretched
upon
a
couch
.
<EOS>
In
spite
of
his
paleness
and
apparent
debility
,
however
,
his
good
looks
were
but
little
impaired
,
and
his
attire
,
though
negligent
,
was
studiously
arranged
for
effect
.
<EOS>
On
Amabel
's
appearance
he
made
an
effort
to
rise
,
but
she
hastened
to
prevent
him
.
<EOS>
After
thanking
her
for
her
kind
inquiries
,
he
entered
into
a
long
conversation
with
her
,
in
the
course
of
which
he
displayed
sentiments
so
exactly
coinciding
with
her
own
,
that
the
good
opinion
she
had
already
begun
to
entertain
for
him
was
soon
heightened
into
the
liveliest
interest
.
<EOS>
They
parted
,
to
meet
again
on
the
following
day
--
and
on
the
day
following
that
.
<EOS>
The
bloom
returned
to
the
earl
's
countenance
,
and
he
looked
handsomer
than
ever
.
<EOS>
A
week
thus
passed
,
and
at
the
end
of
it
,
he
said--"To
-
morrow
I
shall
be
well
enough
to
venture
forth
again
,
and
my
first
business
shall
be
to
proceed
to
your
father
,
and
see
whether
he
is
now
able
to
receive
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
The
plague
has
not
yet
abated
,
my
lord
,
"
she
observed
,
blushingly
.
 
<EOS>
"
True
,
"
he
replied
,
looking
passionately
at
her
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
,
forgive
me
,
Amabel
,
"
he
added
,
taking
her
hand
,
which
she
did
not
attempt
to
withdraw
.
"
<EOS>
Forgive
me
,
if
I
am
wrong
.
<EOS>
But
I
now
think
your
feelings
are
altered
towards
me
,
and
that
I
may
venture
to
hope
you
will
be
mine
?
"
 
<EOS>
Amabel
's
bosom
heaved
with
emotion
.
<EOS>
She
tried
to
speak
,
but
could
not
.
<EOS>
Her
head
declined
upon
his
shoulder
,
and
her
tears
flowed
fast
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
answered
,
"
he
cried
,
scarcely
able
to
contain
his
rapture
,
and
straining
her
to
his
bosom
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
know
not
whether
I
am
doing
rightly
,
"
she
murmured
,
gazing
at
him
through
her
tears
,
"
but
I
believe
you
mean
me
truly
.
<EOS>
God
forgive
you
if
you
do
not
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Have
no
more
doubts
,
"
cried
the
earl
.
<EOS>
"
You
have
wrought
an
entire
change
in
me
.
<EOS>
Our
union
shall
not
be
delayed
an
hour
.
<EOS>
It
shall
take
place
in
Saint
Saviour
's
to
-
night
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Not
to
-
night
,
"
cried
Amabel
,
trembling
at
his
eagerness--"to
-
morrow
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
To
-
night
,
to
-
night
!
"
reiterated
the
earl
,
victoriously
.
<EOS>
And
he
rushed
out
of
the
room
.
 
<EOS>
Amabel
was
no
sooner
left
to
herself
than
she
repented
what
she
had
done
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
I
fear
I
have
made
a
false
step
,
"
she
mused
;
"
but
it
is
now
too
late
to
retreat
,
and
I
will
hope
for
the
best
.
<EOS>
He
can
not
mean
to
deceive
me
.
"
 
<EOS>
Her
meditations
were
interrupted
by
the
entrance
of
Prudence
,
who
came
towards
her
with
a
face
full
of
glee
.
<EOS>
"
My
lord
has
informed
me
of
the
good
news
,
"
she
said
.
<EOS>
"
You
are
to
be
wedded
to
him
to
-
day
.
<EOS>
I
have
expected
it
all
along
,
but
it
is
somewhat
sudden
at
last
.
<EOS>
He
is
gone
in
search
of
the
priest
,
and
in
the
mean
time
has
ordered
me
to
attire
you
for
the
ceremony
.
<EOS>
I
have
several
rich
dresses
for
your
ladyship
--
for
so
I
must
now
call
you
--
to
choose
from
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
The
simplest
will
suit
me
best
,
"
replied
Amabel
,
"
and
do
not
call
me
ladyship
till
I
have
a
right
to
that
title
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
That
will
be
so
soon
that
I
am
sure
there
can
be
no
harm
in
using
it
now
,
"
returned
Prudence
.
<EOS>
"
But
pray
let
me
show
you
the
dresses
.
"
 
<EOS>
Amabel
suffered
herself
to
be
led
into
another
room
,
where
she
saw
several
sumptuous
female
habiliments
,
and
selecting
the
least
showy
of
them
,
was
soon
arrayed
in
it
by
the
officious
attendant
.
<EOS>
More
than
two
hours
elapsed
before
Rochester
returned
,
when
he
entered
Amabel
's
chamber
,
accompanied
by
Sir
George
Etherege
and
Pillichody
.
<EOS>
A
feeling
of
misgiving
crossed
Amabel
,
as
she
beheld
his
companions
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
had
some
difficulty
in
finding
a
clergyman
,
"
said
the
earl
,
"
for
the
rector
of
Saint
Saviour
's
has
fled
from
the
plague
.
<EOS>
His
curate
,
however
,
will
officiate
for
him
,
and
is
now
in
the
church
.
"
 
<EOS>
Amabel
fixed
a
searching
look
upon
him
.
<EOS>
"
Why
are
these
gentlemen
here
?
<EOS>
"
she
asked
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
brought
them
with
me
,
"
rejoined
Rochester
,
"
because
,
as
they
were
aware
of
the
injury
I
once
intended
you
,
I
wish
them
to
be
present
at
its
reparation
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
satisfied
,
"
she
replied
.
 
<EOS>
Taking
her
hand
,
the
earl
then
led
her
to
a
carriage
,
which
conveyed
them
to
Saint
Saviour
's
.
<EOS>
Just
as
they
alighted
,
the
dead
-
cart
passed
,
and
several
bodies
were
brought
towards
it
.
<EOS>
Eager
to
withdraw
her
attention
from
the
spectacle
,
Rochester
hurried
her
into
the
old
and
beautiful
church
.
<EOS>
In
another
moment
they
were
joined
by
Etherege
and
Pillichody
,
and
they
proceeded
to
the
altar
,
where
the
priest
,
a
young
man
,
was
standing
.
<EOS>
The
ceremony
was
then
performed
,
and
the
earl
led
his
bride
back
to
the
carriage
.
<EOS>
On
their
return
they
had
to
undergo
another
ill
-
omened
interruption
.
<EOS>
The
dead
-
cart
was
stationed
near
the
gateway
,
and
some
delay
occurred
before
it
could
be
moved
forward
.
 
<EOS>
Amabel
,
however
,
suffered
no
further
misgiving
to
take
possession
of
her
.
<EOS>
Deeming
herself
wedded
to
the
earl
,
she
put
no
constraint
on
her
affection
for
him
,
and
her
happiness
,
though
short
-
lived
,
was
deep
and
full
.
<EOS>
A
month
passed
away
like
a
dream
of
delight
.
<EOS>
Nothing
occurred
in
the
slightest
degree
to
mar
her
felicity
.
<EOS>
Rochester
seemed
only
to
live
for
her
--
to
think
only
of
her
.
<EOS>
At
the
end
of
this
time
,
some
indifference
began
to
manifest
itself
in
his
deportment
to
her
,
and
he
evinced
a
disposition
to
return
to
the
court
and
to
its
pleasures
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
thought
you
had
for
ever
abandoned
them
,
my
dear
lord
,
"
said
Amabel
,
reproachfully
.
 
<EOS>
"
For
awhile
I
have
,
"
he
replied
,
carelessly
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
must
leave
me
,
if
you
return
to
them
,
"
she
rejoined
.
 
<EOS>
"
If
I
must
,
I
must
,
"
said
the
earl
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
can
not
mean
this
,
my
lord
,
"
she
cried
,
bursting
into
tears
.
<EOS>
"
You
can
not
be
so
changed
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
never
changed
since
you
first
knew
me
,
"
replied
Rochester
.
 
<EOS>
"
Impossible
!
"
<EOS>
she
cried
,
in
a
tone
of
anguish
;
"
you
have
not
the
faults
--
the
vices
,
you
once
had
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
know
not
what
you
call
faults
and
vices
,
madam
,
"
replied
the
earl
sharply
,
"
but
I
have
the
same
qualities
as
heretofore
.
 
<EOS>
"
Am
I
to
understand
,
then
,
"
cried
Amabel
,
a
fearful
suspicion
of
the
truth
breaking
upon
her
,
"
that
you
never
sincerely
repented
your
former
actions
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
are
to
understand
it
,
"
replied
Rochester
.
 
<EOS>
"
And
you
deceived
me
when
you
affirmed
the
contrary
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
deceived
you
,
"
he
replied
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
begin
to
suspect
,
"
she
cried
,
with
a
look
of
horror
and
doubt
,
"
that
the
attack
of
the
plague
was
feigned
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
are
not
far
wide
of
the
truth
,
"
was
the
reply
.
 
<EOS>
"
And
our
marriage
?
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
she
cried--"our
marriage
?
<EOS>
Was
that
feigned
likewise
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
was
,
"
replied
Rochester
,
calmly
.
 
<EOS>
Amabel
looked
at
him
fixedly
for
a
few
minutes
,
as
if
she
could
not
credit
his
assertion
,
and
then
receiving
no
contradiction
,
uttered
a
wild
scream
,
and
rushed
out
of
the
room
.
<EOS>
Rochester
followed
,
and
saw
her
dart
with
lightning
swiftness
across
the
court
-
yard
.
<EOS>
On
gaining
the
street
,
he
perceived
her
flying
figure
already
at
some
distance
;
and
greatly
alarmed
,
started
in
pursuit
.
<EOS>
The
unfortunate
girl
was
not
allowed
to
proceed
far
.
<EOS>
Two
persons
who
were
approaching
,
and
who
proved
to
be
Etherege
and
Pillichody
,
caught
hold
of
her
,
and
detained
her
till
Rochester
came
up
.
<EOS>
When
the
latter
attempted
to
touch
her
,
she
uttered
such
fearful
shrieks
,
that
Etherege
entreated
him
to
desist
.
<EOS>
With
some
difficulty
she
was
taken
back
to
the
house
.
<EOS>
But
it
was
evident
that
the
shock
had
unsettled
her
reason
.
<EOS>
She
alternately
uttered
wild
,
piercing
screams
,
or
broke
into
hysterical
laughter
.
<EOS>
The
earl
's
presence
so
much
increased
her
frenzy
,
that
he
gladly
withdrew
.
 
<EOS>
"
This
is
a
melancholy
business
,
my
lord
,
"
observed
Etherege
,
as
they
quitted
the
room
together
,
"
and
I
am
sorry
for
my
share
in
it
.
<EOS>
We
have
both
much
to
answer
for
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Do
you
think
her
life
in
danger
?
"
rejoined
Rochester
.
