<EOS>
"
It
would
be
well
if
it
were
so
,
"
returned
the
other
;
"
<EOS>
but
I
fear
she
will
live
to
be
a
perpetual
memento
to
you
of
the
crime
you
have
committed
.
"
 
<EOS>
Amabel
's
delirium
produced
a
high
fever
,
which
continued
for
three
days
.
<EOS>
Her
screams
were
at
times
so
dreadful
,
that
her
betrayer
shut
himself
up
in
the
furthest
part
of
the
house
,
that
he
might
not
hear
them
.
<EOS>
When
at
last
she
sank
into
a
sleep
like
that
of
death
,
produced
by
powerful
opiates
,
he
stole
into
the
room
,
and
gazed
at
her
with
feelings
which
those
who
watched
his
countenance
did
not
envy
.
<EOS>
It
was
hoped
by
the
chirurgeon
in
attendance
,
that
when
the
violence
of
the
fever
abated
,
Amabel
's
reason
would
be
restored
.
<EOS>
But
it
was
not
so
.
<EOS>
Her
faculties
were
completely
shaken
,
and
the
cause
of
her
affliction
being
effaced
from
her
memory
,
she
now
spoke
of
the
Earl
of
Rochester
with
her
former
affection
.
 
<EOS>
Her
betrayer
once
ventured
into
her
presence
,
but
he
did
not
repeat
the
visit
.
<EOS>
Her
looks
and
her
tenderness
were
more
than
even
_
<EOS>
his
_
firmness
could
bear
,
and
he
hurried
away
to
hide
his
emotion
from
the
attendants
.
<EOS>
Several
days
passed
on
,
and
as
no
improvement
took
place
,
the
earl
,
who
began
to
find
the
stings
of
conscience
too
sharp
for
further
endurance
,
resolved
to
try
to
deaden
the
pangs
by
again
plunging
into
the
dissipation
of
the
court
.
<EOS>
Prudence
had
been
seized
by
the
plague
,
and
removed
to
the
pest
-
house
,
and
not
knowing
to
whom
to
entrust
Amabel
,
it
at
last
occurred
to
him
that
Judith
Malmayns
would
be
a
fitting
person
,
and
he
accordingly
sent
for
her
from
Saint
Paul
's
,
and
communicated
his
wishes
to
her
,
offering
her
a
considerable
reward
for
the
service
.
<EOS>
Judith
readily
undertook
the
office
,
and
the
earl
delayed
his
departure
for
two
days
,
to
see
how
all
went
on
;
and
finding
the
arrangements
,
to
all
appearances
,
answer
perfectly
,
he
departed
with
Etherege
and
Pillichody
.
 
<EOS>
Ever
since
the
communication
of
the
fatal
truth
had
been
made
to
her
by
the
earl
,
his
unfortunate
victim
had
occupied
the
large
oak
-
panelled
chamber
,
on
entering
which
so
sad
a
presentiment
had
seized
her
;
and
she
had
never
quitted
the
bed
where
she
thought
she
would
breathe
her
last
.
<EOS>
On
the
night
of
Rochester
's
departure
she
made
many
inquiries
concerning
him
from
Judith
Malmayns
,
who
was
seated
in
an
old
broad
-
cushioned
,
velvet
-
covered
chair
,
beside
her
,
and
was
told
that
the
king
required
his
attendance
at
Oxford
,
but
that
he
would
soon
return
.
<EOS>
At
this
answer
the
tears
gathered
thickly
in
Amabel
's
dark
eyelashes
,
and
she
remained
silent
.
<EOS>
By
-
and
-
by
she
resumed
the
conversation
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
you
know
,
nurse
,
"
she
said
,
with
a
look
of
extreme
anxiety
,
"
I
have
forgotten
my
prayers
.
<EOS>
Repeat
them
to
me
,
and
I
will
say
them
after
you
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
My
memory
is
as
bad
as
your
ladyship
's
,
"
replied
Judith
,
contemptuously
.
<EOS>
"
It
is
so
long
since
I
said
mine
,
that
I
have
quite
forgotten
them
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
That
is
wrong
in
you
,
"
returned
Amabel
,
"
very
wrong
.
<EOS>
When
I
lived
with
my
dear
father
,
we
had
prayers
morning
and
evening
,
and
I
was
never
so
happy
as
then
.
<EOS>
I
feel
it
would
do
me
good
if
I
could
pray
as
I
used
to
do
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Well
,
well
,
all
in
good
time
,
"
replied
Judith
.
<EOS>
"
As
soon
as
you
are
better
,
you
shall
go
back
to
your
father
,
and
then
you
can
do
as
you
please
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
No
,
no
,
I
can
not
go
back
to
him
,
"
returned
Amabel
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
the
Earl
of
Rochester
's
wife
--
his
wedded
wife
.
<EOS>
Am
I
not
Countess
of
Rochester
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
To
be
sure
you
are
,
"
replied
Judith--"to
be
sure
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
sometimes
think
otherwise
,
"
rejoined
Amabel
,
mournfully
.
 
<EOS>
"
And
so
my
dear
lord
is
gone
to
Oxford
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
He
is
,
"
returned
Judith
,
"
but
he
will
be
back
soon
.
<EOS>
And
now
,
"
she
added
,
with
some
impatience
,
"
you
have
talked
quite
long
enough
.
<EOS>
You
must
take
your
composing
draught
,
and
go
to
sleep
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
With
this
she
arose
,
and
stepping
to
the
table
which
stood
by
the
side
of
the
bed
,
filled
a
wine
-
glass
with
the
contents
of
a
silver
flagon
,
and
gave
it
to
her
.
<EOS>
Amabel
drank
the
mixture
,
and
complaining
of
its
nauseous
taste
,
Judith
handed
her
a
plate
of
fruit
from
the
table
to
remove
it
.
<EOS>
Soon
after
this
she
dropped
asleep
,
when
the
nurse
arose
,
and
taking
a
light
from
the
table
,
cautiously
possessed
herself
of
a
bunch
of
keys
which
were
placed
in
a
small
pocket
over
Amabel
's
head
,
and
proceeded
to
unlock
a
large
chest
that
stood
near
the
foot
of
the
bed
.
<EOS>
She
found
it
filled
with
valuables
--
with
chains
of
gold
,
necklaces
of
precious
stones
,
loops
of
pearl
,
diamond
crosses
,
and
other
ornaments
.
<EOS>
Besides
these
,
there
were
shawls
and
stuffs
of
the
richest
description
.
<EOS>
While
contemplating
these
treasures
,
and
considering
how
she
should
carry
them
off
without
alarming
the
household
,
she
was
startled
by
a
profound
sigh
;
and
looking
towards
the
bed
,
perceived
to
her
great
alarm
,
that
Amabel
had
opened
her
eyes
,
and
was
watching
her
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
are
you
doing
there
,
nurse
?
<EOS>
"
she
cried
.
 
<EOS>
"
Only
looking
at
these
pretty
things
,
your
ladyship
,
"
replied
Judith
,
in
an
embarrassed
tone
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
hope
you
are
not
going
to
steal
them
?
"
said
Amabel
.
 
<EOS>
"
Steal
them
?
"
<EOS>
echoed
Judith
,
alarmed
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
,
no
!
<EOS>
What
should
make
your
ladyship
think
so
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
,
"
said
Amabel
;
"
but
put
them
by
,
and
bring
the
keys
to
me
.
"
 
<EOS>
Judith
feigned
compliance
,
but
long
before
she
had
restored
the
things
to
the
chest
,
Amabel
had
again
fallen
asleep
.
<EOS>
Apprised
by
her
tranquil
breathing
of
this
circumstance
,
Judith
arose
;
and
shading
the
candle
with
her
hand
,
crept
noiselessly
towards
the
bed
.
<EOS>
Dark
thoughts
crossed
her
as
she
gazed
at
the
unfortunate
sleeper
;
and
moving
with
the
utmost
caution
,
she
set
the
light
on
the
table
behind
the
curtains
,
and
had
just
grasped
the
pillow
,
with
the
intention
of
plucking
it
from
under
Amabel
's
head
,
and
of
smothering
her
with
it
,
when
she
felt
herself
restrained
by
a
powerful
grasp
,
and
turning
in
utmost
alarm
,
beheld
the
Earl
of
Rochester
.
  
<EOS>
VI
.
 
<EOS>
THE
CERTIFICATE
.
 
<EOS>
"
Wretch
!
"
cried
the
earl
.
"
<EOS>
An
instinctive
dread
that
you
would
do
your
poor
charge
some
injury
brought
me
back
,
and
I
thank
Heaven
I
have
arrived
in
time
to
prevent
your
atrocious
purpose
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Your
lordship
would
have
acted
more
discreetly
in
staying
away
,
"
replied
Judith
,
recovering
her
resolution
;
"
and
I
would
recommend
you
not
to
meddle
in
the
matter
,
but
to
leave
it
to
me
.
<EOS>
No
suspicion
shall
alight
on
you
,
nor
shall
it
even
be
known
that
her
end
was
hastened
.
<EOS>
Leave
the
house
as
secretly
as
you
came
,
and
proceed
on
your
journey
with
a
light
heart
.
<EOS>
She
will
never
trouble
you
further
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
What
!
"
exclaimed
Rochester
,
who
was
struck
dumb
for
the
moment
by
surprise
and
indignation
,
"
do
you
imagine
I
would
listen
to
such
a
proposal
?
<EOS>
Do
you
think
I
would
sanction
her
murder
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
sure
you
would
,
if
you
knew
as
much
as
I
do
,
"
replied
Judith
,
calmly
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Hear
me
,
my
lord
,
"
she
continued
,
drawing
him
to
a
little
distance
from
the
bed
,
and
speaking
in
a
deep
low
tone
.
<EOS>
"
You
can
not
marry
Mistress
Mallet
while
this
girl
lives
.
"
 
<EOS>
Rochester
looked
sternly
and
inquiringly
at
her
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
You
think
your
marriage
was
feigned
,
"
pursued
Judith
;
"
<EOS>
that
he
was
no
priest
who
performed
the
ceremony
;
and
that
no
other
witnesses
were
present
except
Sir
George
Etherege
and
Pillichody
.
<EOS>
But
you
are
mistaken
.
<EOS>
I
and
Chowles
were
present
;
and
he
who
officiated
_
was
_
a
priest
.
<EOS>
The
marriage
was
a
lawful
one
;
and
yon
sleeping
girl
,
who
,
but
for
your
ill
-
timed
interference
,
would
,
ere
this
,
have
breathed
her
last
,
is
to
all
intents
and
purposes
Countess
of
Rochester
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
A
lie
!
"
cried
the
earl
,
furiously
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
will
soon
prove
it
to
be
truth
,
"
rejoined
Judith
.
"
<EOS>
Your
retainer
and
unscrupulous
agent
,
Major
Pillichody
,
applied
to
Chowles
to
find
some
one
to
personate
a
clergyman
in
a
mock
marriage
,
which
your
lordship
wished
to
have
performed
,
and
promised
a
handsome
reward
for
the
service
.
<EOS>
Chowles
mentioned
the
subject
to
me
,
and
we
speedily
contrived
a
plan
to
outwit
your
lordship
,
and
turn
the
affair
to
our
advantage
.
"
 
<EOS>
The
earl
uttered
an
ejaculation
of
rage
.
 
<EOS>
"
Being
acquainted
with
one
of
the
minor
canons
of
Saint
Paul
's
,
a
worthy
and
pious
young
man
,
named
Vincent
,
"
pursued
Judith
,
utterly
unmoved
by
Rochester
's
anger
,
"
who
resided
hard
by
the
cathedral
,
we
hastened
to
him
,
and
acquainted
him
with
the
design
,
representing
ourselves
as
anxious
to
serve
the
poor
girl
,
and
defeat
your
lordship
's
wicked
design
--
for
such
we
termed
it
.
<EOS>
With
a
little
persuasion
,
Mr.
Vincent
consented
to
the
scheme
.
<EOS>
Pillichody
was
easily
duped
by
Chowles
's
statement
,
and
the
ceremony
was
fully
performed
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
The
whole
story
is
a
fabrication
,
"
cried
the
earl
,
with
affected
incredulity
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
a
certificate
of
the
marriage
,
"
replied
Judith
,
"
signed
by
Mr.
Vincent
,
and
attested
by
Chowles
and
myself
.
<EOS>
If
ever
woman
was
wedded
to
man
,
Amabel
is
wedded
to
your
lordship
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
If
this
is
the
case
,
why
seek
to
destroy
her
?
"
demanded
the
earl
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Her
life
must
be
of
more
consequence
to
you
than
her
removal
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
will
deal
frankly
with
you
,
"
replied
Judith
.
"
<EOS>
She
discovered
me
in
the
act
of
emptying
that
chest
,
and
an
irresistible
impulse
prompted
me
to
make
away
with
her
.
<EOS>
But
your
lordship
is
in
the
right
.
<EOS>
Her
life
_
is
_
valuable
to
me
,
and
she
_
shall
_
live
.
<EOS>
But
,
I
repeat
,
you
can
not
marry
the
rich
heiress
,
Mistress
Mallet
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Temptress
!
"
cried
the
earl
,
"
you
put
frightful
thoughts
into
my
head
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Go
your
ways
,
"
replied
Judith
,
"
and
think
no
more
about
her
.
<EOS>
All
shall
be
done
that
you
require
.
<EOS>
I
claim
as
my
reward
the
contents
of
that
chest
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Your
reward
shall
be
the
gallows
,
"
rejoined
the
earl
,
indignantly
.
<EOS>
"
I
reject
your
proposal
at
once
.
<EOS>
Begone
,
wretch
!
<EOS>
or
I
shall
forget
you
are
a
woman
,
and
sacrifice
you
to
my
fury
.
<EOS>
Begone
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
As
your
lordship
pleases
,
"
she
replied
;
"
but
first
,
the
Countess
of
Rochester
shall
be
made
acquainted
with
her
rights
.
"
<EOS>
So
saying
,
she
broke
from
him
,
and
rushed
to
the
bed
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
are
you
about
to
do
?
"
he
cried
.
 
<EOS>
"
Waken
her
,
"
rejoined
Judith
,
slightly
shaking
the
sleeper
.
 
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
"
exclaimed
Amabel
,
opening
her
eyes
,
and
gazing
at
her
with
a
terrified
and
bewildered
look
.
 
<EOS>
"
His
lordship
is
returned
,
"
said
Judith
.
 
<EOS>
"
Indeed
!
"
exclaimed
Amabel
,
raising
herself
in
the
bed
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Where
is
he?--Ah
,
I
see
him.--Come
to
me
,
my
dear
lord
,
"
she
added
,
stretching
out
her
arms
to
him
,
"
Come
to
me
.
"
 
<EOS>
But
evil
thoughts
kept
Rochester
motionless
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
come
to
me
,
my
lord
,
"
cried
Amabel
,
in
a
troubled
tone
,
"
or
I
shall
begin
to
think
what
I
have
dreamed
is
true
,
and
that
I
am
not
wedded
to
you
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
_
was
_
merely
a
dream
,
your
ladyship
,
"
observed
Judith
.
<EOS>
"
I
will
bear
witness
you
are
wedded
to
his
lordship
,
<EOS>
for
I
was
present
at
the
ceremony
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
did
not
see
you
,
"
remarked
Amabel
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
was
there
,
nevertheless
,
"
replied
Judith
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
sorry
to
hear
it
,
"
replied
Amabel
.
 
<EOS>
"
Your
ladyship
would
rejoice
if
you
knew
all
,
"
returned
Judith
,
significantly
.
 
<EOS>
"
Why
so
?
<EOS>
"
inquired
the
other
,
curiously
.
 
<EOS>
"
Because
the
clergyman
who
married
you
is
dead
of
the
plague
,
"
was
the
answer
;
"
and
it
may
chance
in
these
terrible
times
that
the
two
gentlemen
who
were
present
at
the
ceremony
may
die
of
the
same
distemper
,
and
then
there
will
be
no
one
left
but
me
and
another
person
to
prove
that
your
marriage
was
lawful
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
But
its
lawfulness
will
never
be
questioned
,
my
dear
lord
,
will
it
?
"
asked
Amabel
,
looking
beseechingly
at
Rochester
.
 
<EOS>
"
Never
,
"
replied
Judith
,
producing
a
small
piece
of
parchment
,
"
while
I
hold
this
certificate
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Give
me
that
document
,
"
said
the
earl
,
in
an
undertone
,
to
her
.
 
<EOS>
Judith
directed
her
eyes
towards
the
chest
.
<EOS>
"
It
is
yours
,
"
said
the
earl
,
in
the
same
tone
as
before
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
are
you
whispering
,
my
lord
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Amabel
,
uneasily
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
merely
telling
her
to
remove
that
chest
,
sweetheart
,
"
he
replied
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
not
send
it
away
,
"
cried
Amabel
.
<EOS>
"
It
contains
all
the
ornaments
and
trinkets
you
have
given
me
.
<EOS>
Do
you
know
,
"
she
added
in
a
whisper
,
"
I
caught
her
looking
into
it
just
now
,
and
I
suspect
she
was
about
to
steal
something
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Pshaw
!
"
cried
the
earl
,
"
she
acted
by
my
directions
.
<EOS>
Take
the
chest
away
,
"
he
added
to
Judith
.
 
<EOS>
"
Has
your
lordship
no
further
orders
?
<EOS>
"
she
rejoined
,
significantly
.
 
<EOS>
"
None
whatever
,
"
he
replied
,
with
a
frown
.
 
<EOS>
"
Before
you
go
,
give
me
the
certificate
,
"
cried
Amabel
.
<EOS>
"
I
must
have
it
.
"
 
<EOS>
Judith
pretended
not
to
hear
her
.
"
<EOS>
Give
it
her
,
"
whispered
the
earl
,
"
I
will
remove
it
when
she
falls
asleep
.
"
 
<EOS>
Nodding
acquiescence
<EOS>
,
Judith
took
the
parchment
from
her
bosom
,
and
returned
with
it
to
the
bed
.
<EOS>
While
this
was
passing
,
the
earl
walked
towards
the
chest
,
and
cast
his
eye
over
such
of
its
contents
as
were
scattered
upon
the
floor
.
<EOS>
Judith
watched
him
carefully
,
and
when
his
back
was
turned
,
drew
a
small
lancet
,
and
affecting
to
arrange
her
dress
,
slightly
punctured
Amabel
's
neck
.
<EOS>
The
pain
was
trifling
,
but
the
poor
girl
uttered
a
cry
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
is
the
matter
?
<EOS>
"
cried
the
earl
,
turning
suddenly
round
.
 
<EOS>
"
Nothing
--
nothing
,
"
replied
Judith
;
"
a
pin
in
my
sleeve
pricked
her
as
I
was
fastening
her
cap
,
that
was
all
.
<EOS>
Her
death
is
certain
,
"
she
added
to
herself
,
"
she
is
inoculated
with
the
plague
-
venom
.
"
 
<EOS>
She
then
went
to
the
chest
,
and
replacing
everything
within
it
,
removed
it
,
by
the
help
of
the
Earl
of
Rochester
,
into
the
adjoining
room
.
<EOS>
"
I
will
send
for
it
at
midnight
,
"
she
said
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
shall
be
delivered
to
your
messenger
,
"
rejoined
the
earl
;
"
but
you
will
answer
for
Chowles
's
secrecy
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
will
,
"
returned
Judith
,
with
a
meaning
smile
.
<EOS>
"
But
you
may
take
my
word
for
it
you
will
not
be
troubled
long
with
your
wife
.
<EOS>
If
I
have
any
judgment
respecting
the
plague
,
she
is
already
infected
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Indeed
!
"
cried
Rochester--"then--
<EOS>
"
but
he
checked
himself
,
and
added
,
"
I
do
not
believe
it
.
<EOS>
Begone
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
He
_
<EOS>
does
_
believe
it
for
all
that
,
"
muttered
Judith
,
as
he
slunk
away
.
 
<EOS>
Rochester
returned
to
Amabel
,
and
sat
by
her
until
she
fell
asleep
,
when
he
took
the
parchment
from
beneath
the
pillow
where
she
had
placed
it
.
<EOS>
Examining
it
,
he
found
it
,
as
Judith
had
stated
,
a
certificate
of
his
marriage
,
signed
by
Mark
Vincent
,
the
clergyman
who
had
officiated
,
and
duly
attested
.
<EOS>
Having
carefully
perused
it
,
he
held
it
towards
the
taper
,
with
the
intention
of
destroying
it
.
<EOS>
As
he
was
about
to
perpetrate
this
unworthy
action
,
he
looked
towards
the
bed
.
<EOS>
The
soft
sweet
smile
that
played
upon
the
sleeper
's
features
,
turned
him
from
his
purpose
.
<EOS>
Placing
the
parchment
in
his
doublet
,
he
left
the
room
,
and
summoning
a
female
attendant
,
alleged
some
reason
for
his
unexpected
return
,
and
ordered
her
to
watch
by
the
bedside
of
her
mistress
.
<EOS>
Giving
some
further
directions
,
he
threw
himself
upon
a
couch
and
sought
a
few
hours
'
repose
.
<EOS>
At
daybreak
,
he
repaired
to
Amabel
's
chamber
,
and
finding
her
wrapped
in
a
peaceful
slumber
,
he
commended
her
to
the
attendant
,
and
departed
.
 
<EOS>
On
awaking
,
Amabel
complained
of
an
uneasy
sensation
on
her
neck
,
and
the
attendant
examining
the
spot
,
found
,
to
her
great
alarm
,
a
small
red
pustule
.
<EOS>
Without
making
a
single
observation
,
she
left
the
room
,
and
despatched
a
messenger
after
the
Earl
of
Rochester
to
acquaint
him
that
the
countess
was
attacked
by
the
plague
.
<EOS>
Such
was
the
terror
inspired
by
this
dread
disorder
,
that
the
moment
it
was
known
that
Amabel
was
attacked
by
it
,
the
whole
household
,
except
an
old
woman
,
fled
.
<EOS>
This
old
woman
,
whose
name
was
Batley
,
and
who
acted
as
the
earl
's
housekeeper
,
took
upon
herself
the
office
of
nurse
.
<EOS>
Before
evening
,
the
poor
sufferer
,
who
had
endured
great
agony
during
the
whole
of
the
day
,
became
so
much
worse
,
that
Mrs.
Batley
ran
out
in
search
of
assistance
.
<EOS>
She
met
with
a
watchman
,
who
told
her
that
a
famous
apothecary
,
from
Clerkenwell
,
named
Sibbald
,
who
was
celebrated
for
the
cures
he
had
effected
,
had
just
entered
a
neighbouring
house
,
and
offered
to
await
his
coming
forth
,
and
send
him
to
her
.
<EOS>
Thanking
him
,
Mrs.
Batley
returned
to
the
house
,
and
presently
afterwards
,
Sibbald
made
his
appearance
.
<EOS>
His
looks
and
person
had
become
even
more
repulsive
than
formerly
.
<EOS>
He
desired
to
be
led
to
the
patient
,
and
on
seeing
her
,
shook
his
head
.
<EOS>
He
examined
the
pustule
,
which
had
greatly
increased
in
size
,
and
turning
away
,
muttered
,
"
I
can
do
nothing
for
her
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
At
least
make
the
attempt
,
"
implored
Mrs.
Batley
.
<EOS>
"
She
is
the
Countess
of
Rochester
.
<EOS>
You
shall
be
well
rewarded
--
and
if
you
cure
her
,
the
earl
will
make
your
fortune
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
If
his
lordship
would
change
stations
with
me
,
I
could
not
cure
her
,
"
replied
Sibbald
.
<EOS>
"
Let
me
look
at
her
again
,
"
he
added
,
examining
the
pustule
.
<EOS>
"
There
is
a
strange
appearance
about
this
tumour
.
<EOS>
Has
Judith
Malmayns
attended
her
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
She
was
here
yesterday
,
"
replied
Mrs.
Batley
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
thought
so
,
"
he
muttered
.
<EOS>
"
I
repeat
it
is
all
over
with
her
.
"
<EOS>
And
he
turned
to
depart
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
not
leave
her
thus
,
in
pity
do
not
!
"
cried
the
old
woman
,
detaining
him
.
"
<EOS>
Make
some
effort
to
save
her
.
<EOS>
My
lord
loves
her
to
distraction
,
and
will
abundantly
reward
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
All
I
can
do
is
to
give
her
something
to
allay
the
pain
,
"
returned
Sibbald
.
<EOS>
And
drawing
a
small
phial
from
his
doublet
,
he
poured
its
contents
into
a
glass
,
and
administered
it
to
the
patient
.
 
<EOS>
"
That
will
throw
her
into
a
slumber
,
"
he
said
,
"
and
when
she
wakes
,
she
will
be
without
pain
.
<EOS>
But
her
end
will
be
not
far
off
.
"
 
<EOS>
Mrs.
Batley
took
a
purse
from
a
drawer
in
one
of
the
cabinets
,
and
gave
it
to
the
apothecary
,
who
bowed
and
retired
.
<EOS>
As
he
had
foretold
,
Amabel
fell
into
a
heavy
lethargy
,
which
continued
during
the
whole
of
the
night
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Batley
,
who
had
never
left
her
,
noticed
that
an
extraordinary
and
fearful
change
had
taken
place
in
her
countenance
,
and
she
could
not
doubt
that
the
apothecary
's
prediction
would
be
realized
.
<EOS>
The
tumour
had
increased
in
size
,
and
was
surrounded
by
a
dusky
brown
circle
,
which
she
knew
to
be
a
bad
sign
.
<EOS>
The
sufferer
's
eyes
,
when
she
opened
them
,
and
gazed
around
,
had
a
dim
and
glazed
look
.
<EOS>
But
she
was
perfectly
calm
and
composed
,
and
,
as
had
been
prognosticated
,
free
from
pain
.
<EOS>
She
had
,
also
,
fully
regained
her
faculties
,
and
seemed
quite
aware
of
her
dangerous
situation
.
 
<EOS>
But
the
return
of
reason
brought
with
it
no
solace
.
<EOS>
On
the
contrary
,
the
earl
's
treachery
rushed
upon
her
recollection
,
and
gave
her
infinitely
more
anguish
than
the
bodily
pain
she
had
recently
endured
.
<EOS>
She
bedewed
the
pillow
with
her
tears
,
and
fervently
prayed
for
forgiveness
for
her
involuntary
fault
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Batley
was
deeply
moved
by
her
affliction
,
and
offered
her
every
consolation
in
her
power
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
would
the
plague
had
selected
me
for
a
victim
instead
of
your
ladyship
,
"
she
said
.
<EOS>
"
It
is
hard
to
leave
the
world
at
your
age
,
possessed
of
beauty
,
honours
,
and
wealth
.
<EOS>
At
mine
,
it
would
not
signify
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
mistake
the
cause
of
my
grief
,
"
returned
Amabel
;
"
I
do
not
lament
that
my
hour
is
at
hand
,
but--
"
and
her
emotion
so
overpowered
her
that
she
could
not
proceed
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
not
disturb
yourself
further
,
dear
lady
,
"
rejoined
the
old
woman
.
<EOS>
"
Let
the
worst
happen
,
I
am
sure
you
are
well
prepared
to
meet
your
Maker
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
once
was
,
"
replied
Amabel
in
a
voice
of
despair
,
"
but
now
--
<EOS>
Oh
,
Heaven
forgive
me
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
Shall
I
fetch
some
holy
minister
to
pray
beside
you
,
my
lady
?
"
said
Mrs.
Batley
;
"
one
to
whom
you
can
pour
forth
the
sorrows
of
your
heart
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Do
so
!
<EOS>
oh
,
do
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Amabel
,
"
and
do
not
call
me
lady
.
<EOS>
I
am
not
worthy
to
be
placed
in
the
same
rank
as
yourself
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Her
wits
are
clean
gone
,
"
muttered
Mrs.
Batley
,
looking
at
her
compassionately
.
 
<EOS>
"
Heed
me
not
,
"
cried
Amabel
;
"
but
if
you
have
any
pity
for
the
unfortunate
,
do
as
you
have
promised
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
will
--
I
will
,
"
said
Mrs.
Batley
,
departing
.
 
<EOS>
Half
an
hour
,
which
scarcely
seemed
a
moment
to
the
poor
sufferer
,
who
was
employed
in
fervent
prayer
,
elapsed
before
Mrs.
Batley
returned
.
<EOS>
She
was
accompanied
by
a
tall
man
,
whom
Amabel
recognised
as
Solomon
Eagle
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
not
been
able
to
find
a
clergyman
,
"
said
the
old
woman
,
"
but
I
have
brought
a
devout
man
who
is
willing
to
pray
with
you
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
"
exclaimed
the
enthusiast
,
starting
as
he
beheld
Amabel
.
"
<EOS>
Can
it
be
Mr.
Bloundel
's
daughter
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
,
"
returned
Amabel
with
a
groan
.
"
<EOS>
Leave
us
,
my
good
woman
,
"
she
added
to
Mrs.
Batley
,
"
I
have
something
to
impart
to
Solomon
Eagle
which
is
for
his
ear
alone
.
"
<EOS>
The
old
woman
instantly
retired
,
and
Amabel
briefly
related
her
hapless
story
to
the
enthusiast
.
 
<EOS>
"
May
I
hope
for
forgiveness
?
"
<EOS>
she
inquired
,
as
she
concluded
.
 
<EOS>
"
Assuredly
,
"
replied
Solomon
Eagle
,
"
assuredly
!
<EOS>
You
have
not
erred
wilfully
,
but
through
ignorance
,
and
therefore
have
committed
no
offence
.
<EOS>
_
<EOS>
You
_
will
be
forgiven
--
but
woe
to
your
deceiver
,
here
and
hereafter
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
'
say
not
so
,
"
she
cried
.
"
<EOS>
May
Heaven
pardon
him
as
I
do
.
<EOS>
While
I
have
strength
left
I
will
pray
for
him
.
"
<EOS>
And
she
poured
forth
her
supplications
for
the
earl
in
terms
so
earnest
and
pathetic
,
that
the
tears
flowed
down
Solomon
Eagle
's
rough
cheek
.
<EOS>
At
this
juncture
,
hasty
steps
were
heard
in
the
adjoining
passage
,
and
the
door
opening
,
admitted
the
Earl
of
Rochester
,
who
rushed
towards
the
bed
.
 
<EOS>
"
Back
!
"
cried
Solomon
Eagle
,
pushing
him
forcibly
aside
.
"
<EOS>
Back
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
here
?
"
<EOS>
cried
Rochester
,
fiercely
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
watching
over
the
death
-
bed
of
your
victim
,
"
returned
Solomon
Eagle
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Retire
,
my
lord
.
<EOS>
You
disturb
her
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
no
,
"
returned
Amabel
,
meekly
.
<EOS>
"
Let
him
come
near
me
.
"
<EOS>
And
as
Solomon
Eagle
drew
a
little
aside
,
and
allowed
the
earl
to
approach
,
she
added
,
"
With
my
latest
breath
I
forgive
you
,
my
lord
,
for
the
wrong
you
have
done
me
,
and
bless
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
The
earl
tried
to
speak
,
but
his
voice
was
suffocated
by
emotion
.
<EOS>
As
soon
as
he
could
find
words
,
he
said
,
"
Your
goodness
completely
overpowers
me
,
dearest
Amabel
.
<EOS>
Heaven
is
my
witness
,
that
even
now
I
would
make
you
all
the
reparation
in
my
power
were
it
needful
.
<EOS>
But
it
is
not
so
.
<EOS>
The
wrong
I
intended
you
was
never
committed
.
<EOS>
I
myself
was
deceived
.
<EOS>
I
intended
a
feigned
marriage
,
but
it
was
rightfully
performed
.
<EOS>
Time
will
not
allow
me
to
enter
into
further
particulars
of
the
unhappy
transaction
,
but
you
may
credit
my
assertion
when
I
tell
you
you
are
indeed
my
wife
,
and
Countess
of
Rochester
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
If
I
thought
so
,
I
should
die
happy
,
"
replied
Amabel
.
 
<EOS>
"
Behold
this
proof
!
"
said
Rochester
,
producing
the
certificate
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
can
not
read
it
,
"
replied
Amabel
.
<EOS>
"
But
you
could
not
have
the
heart
to
deceive
me
now
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
will
read
it
,
and
you
well
know
_
<EOS>
I
_
would
not
deceive
you
,
"
cried
Solomon
Eagle
,
casting
his
eye
over
<EOS>
it--"His
<EOS>
lordship
has
avouched
the
truth
,
"
he
continued
.
<EOS>
"
It
is
a
certificate
of
your
marriage
with
him
,
duly
signed
and
attested
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
God
be
thanked
,
"
ejaculated
Amabel
,
fervently
.
<EOS>
"
God
be
thanked
!
<EOS>
You
have
been
spared
that
guilt
,
and
I
shall
die
content
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
trust
your
life
will
long
be
spared
,
"
rejoined
the
earl
.
<EOS>
Amabel
shook
her
head
.
 
<EOS>
"
There
is
but
one
man
in
this
city
who
could
save
her
,
"
whispered
Solomon
Eagle
,
and
I
doubt
even
his
power
to
do
so
.
'
 
<EOS>
"
Who
do
you
mean
?
"
cried
Rochester
,
eagerly
.
 
<EOS>
"
Doctor
Hodges
,
"
replied
the
enthusiast
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
know
him
well
,
"
cried
the
earl
.
<EOS>
"
I
will
fly
to
him
instantly
.
<EOS>
Remain
with
her
till
I
return
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
My
lord
--
my
dear
lord
,
"
interposed
Amabel
,
faintly
,
"
you
trouble
yourself
needlessly
.
<EOS>
I
am
past
all
human
aid
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Do
not
despair
,
"
replied
the
earl
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Many
years
of
happiness
are
,
I
trust
,
in
store
for
us
.
<EOS>
Do
not
detain
me
.
<EOS>
I
go
to
save
you
.
<EOS>
Farewell
for
a
short
time
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Farewell
,
for
ever
,
my
lord
,
"
she
said
,
gently
pressing
his
hand
.
<EOS>
"
We
shall
not
meet
again
.
<EOS>
Your
name
will
be
coupled
with
my
latest
breath
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
shall
be
completely
unmanned
if
I
stay
here
a
moment
longer
,
"
cried
the
earl
,
breaking
from
her
,
and
rushing
out
of
the
room
.
 
<EOS>
As
soon
as
he
was
gone
,
Amabel
addressed
herself
once
more
to
prayer
with
Solomon
Eagle
,
and
in
this
way
an
hour
passed
by
.
<EOS>
The
earl
not
returning
at
the
end
of
that
time
,
Solomon
Eagle
became
extremely
uneasy
,
every
moment
being
of
the
utmost
consequence
,
and
summoning
Mrs.
Batley
,
committed
the
patient
to
her
care
,
and
set
off
in
search
of
Hodges
.
<EOS>
He
hastened
to
the
doctor
's
house
--
<EOS>
he
was
absent
--
to
Saint
Paul's
--
he
was
not
there
,
but
he
learnt
that
a
person
answering
to
the
earl
's
description
had
been
making
similar
inquiries
after
him
.
 
<EOS>
At
last
,
one
of
the
chirurgeon
's
assistants
told
him
that
he
thought
the
doctor
was
gone
towards
Cornhill
,
and
hoping
,
accidentally
,
to
meet
with
him
,
the
enthusiast
set
off
in
that
direction
.
<EOS>
While
passing
near
the
Exchange
,
he
encountered
Leonard
,
as
before
related
,
but
did
not
think
fit
to
acquaint
him
with
more
than
Amabel
's
dangerous
situation
;
and
he
had
reason
to
regret
making
the
communication
at
all
,
on
finding
its
effect
upon
the
poor
youth
.
<EOS>
There
was
,
however
,
no
help
for
it
,
and
placing
him
in
what
appeared
a
situation
of
safety
,
he
left
him
.
 
<EOS>
Rochester
,
meanwhile
,
had
been
equally
unsuccessful
in
his
search
for
Hodges
.
<EOS>
Hurrying
first
in
one
direction
and
then
in
another
,
at
the
suggestion
of
the
chirurgeon
's
assistant
,
he
at
last
repaired
to
the
doctor
's
residence
,
determined
to
await
his
return
.
<EOS>
In
half
an
hour
he
came
,
and
received
the
earl
,
as
the
old
porter
stated
to
Thirlby
and
Leonard
,
with
angry
astonishment
.
<EOS>
As
soon
as
they
were
alone
,
the
earl
told
him
all
that
had
occurred
,
and
besought
him
to
accompany
him
to
the
poor
sufferer
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
will
go
to
her
,
"
said
Hodges
,
who
had
listened
to
the
recital
with
mixed
feelings
of
sorrow
and
indignation
,
"
on
one
condition
--
and
one
only
--
namely
,
that
your
lordship
does
not
see
her
again
without
my
permission
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Why
do
you
impose
this
restriction
upon
,
me
sir
?
'
<EOS>
demanded
Rochester
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
do
not
think
it
necessary
to
give
my
reasons
,
my
lord
,
"
returned
Hodges
;
"
but
I
will
only
go
upon
such
terms
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Then
I
must
perforce
submit
,
"
replied
the
earl
;
"
<EOS>
but
I
entreat
you
to
set
forth
-
without
a
moment
's
delay
,
or
you
will
be
too
late
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
will
follow
you
instantly
,
"
rejoined
Hodges
.
<EOS>
"
Your
lordship
can
wait
for
me
at
the
Southwark
side
of
the
bridge
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He
then
opened
the
door
,
reiterating
the
terms
upon
which
alone
he
would
attend
,
and
the
earl
departed
.
 
<EOS>
Shortly
afterwards
he
set
out
,
and
making
the
best
of
his
way
,
found
Rochester
at
the
appointed
place
.
<EOS>
The
latter
conducted
him
to
the
entrance
of
the
habitation
,
and
indicating
a
spot
where
he
would
remain
till
his
return
,
left
him
.
<EOS>
Hodges
soon
found
his
way
to
the
chamber
of
the
sufferer
,
and
at
once
perceived
that
all
human
aid
was
vain
.
<EOS>
She
exhibited
much
pleasure
at
seeing
him
,
and
looked
round
,
as
if
in
search
of
the
earl
.
<EOS>
Guessing
her
meaning
,
the
physician
,
who
now
began
to
regret
the
interdiction
he
had
placed
upon
him
,
told
her
that
he
was
the
cause
of
his
absence
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
well
,
"
she
murmured--"well
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
She
then
made
some
inquiries
after
her
relatives
,
and
receiving
a
satisfactory
answer
,
said
,
"
I
am
glad
you
are
come
.
<EOS>
You
will
be
able
to
tell
my
father
how
I
died
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
will
be
a
great
comfort
to
him
to
learn
the
tranquil
frame
in
which
I
have
found
you
,
"
replied
Hodges
.
 
<EOS>
"
How
long
have
I
to
live
?
<EOS>
"
asked
Amabel
,
somewhat
quickly
.
<EOS>
"
Do
not
deceive
me
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
had
better
make
your
preparations
without
delay
,
"
returned
Hodges
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
understand
,
"
she
replied
;
and
joining
her
hands
upon
her
breast
,
she
began
to
murmur
a
prayer
.
 
<EOS>
Hodges
,
who
up
to
this
moment
had
had
some
difficulty
in
repressing
his
emotion
,
withdrew
to
a
short
distance
to
hide
his
fast
-
falling
tears
.
<EOS>
He
was
roused
shortly
after
,
by
a
sudden
and
startling
cry
from
the
old
woman
.
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
sir
,
she
is
going
!
<EOS>
she
is
going
!
"
<EOS>
ejaculated
Mrs.
Batley
.
<EOS>
He
found
the
exclamation
true
.
<EOS>
The
eyes
of
the
dying
girl
were
closed
.
<EOS>
There
was
a
slight
quiver
of
the
lips
,
as
if
she
murmured
some
name
--
probably
Rochester's
--
and
then
all
was
over
.
 
<EOS>
Hodges
gazed
at
her
sorrowfully
for
some
time
.
<EOS>
He
then
roused
himself
,
and
giving
some
necessary
directions
to
the
old
woman
respecting
the
body
,
quitted
the
house
.
<EOS>
Not
finding
the
earl
at
the
place
he
had
appointed
to
meet
him
,
after
waiting
for
a
short
time
,
he
proceeded
,
towards
his
own
house
.
<EOS>
On
the
way
he
was
net
by
Thirlby
and
Parravicin
,
as
previously
related
,
and
conducted
to
the
house
in
Nicholas
-
lane
.
<EOS>
It
will
not
be
necessary
to
recapitulate
what
subsequently
occurred
.
<EOS>
We
shall
,
therefore
,
proceed
to
the
point
of
time
when
he
quitted
his
new
patient
,
and
entered
the
room
where
Thirlby
and
Leonard
were
waiting
for
him
.
<EOS>
Both
,
as
has
been
stated
,
rushed
towards
him
,
and
the
former
eagerly
asked
his
opinion
respecting
his
daughter
.
 
<EOS>
"
My
opinion
is
positive
,
"
replied
Hodges
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
With
care
,
she
will
undoubtedly
recover
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Heaven
be
thanked
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Thirlby
,
dropping
on
his
knees
.
 
<EOS>
"
And
now
,
one
word
to
me
,
sir
,
"
cried
Leonard
.
<EOS>
"
What
of
Amabel
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
Alas
!
"
exclaimed
the
doctor
,
"
her
troubles
are
ended
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Dead
!
"
shrieked
Leonard
.
 
<EOS>
"
Ay
,
dead
!
"
repeated
the
doctor
.
"
<EOS>
She
died
of
the
plague
to
-
night
.
"
 
<EOS>
He
then
proceeded
to
detail
briefly
all
that
had
occurred
.
<EOS>
Leonard
listened
like
one
stupefied
,
till
he
brought
his
recital
to
a
close
,
and
then
asking
where
the
house
in
which
she
had
died
was
situated
,
rushed
out
of
the
room
,
and
made
his
way
,
he
knew
not
<EOS>
how
,
into
the
street
.
<EOS>
His
brain
seemed
on
fire
,
and
he
ran
so
quickly
that
his
feet
appeared
scarcely
to
touch
the
ground
.
<EOS>
A
few
seconds
brought
him
to
London
Bridge
.
<EOS>
He
crossed
it
,
and
turning
down
the
street
on
the
left
,
had
nearly
reached
the
house
to
which
he
had
been
directed
,
when
his
career
was
suddenly
checked
.
<EOS>
The
gate
of
the
court
-
yard
was
opened
,
and
two
men
,
evidently
,
from
their
apparel
,
buriers
of
the
dead
,
issued
from
it
.
<EOS>
They
carried
a
long
narrow
board
between
them
,
with
a
body
wrapped
in
a
white
sheet
placed
upon
it
.
<EOS>
A
freezing
horror
rooted
Leonard
to
the
spot
where
he
stood
.
<EOS>
He
could
neither
move
nor
utter
a
cry
.
 
<EOS>
The
men
proceeded
with
their
burden
towards
the
adjoining
habitation
,
which
was
marked
with
a
fatal
red
cross
and
inscription
.
<EOS>
Before
it
stood
the
dead
-
cart
,
partly
filled
with
corpses
.
<EOS>
The
foremost
burier
carried
a
lantern
,
but
he
held
it
so
low
that
its
light
did
not
fall
upon
his
burden
.
<EOS>
Leonard
,
however
,
did
not
require
to
see
the
body
to
know
whose
it
was
.
<EOS>
The
moon
was
at
its
full
,
and
shed
a
ghastly
light
over
the
group
,
and
a
large
bat
wheeled
in
narrow
circles
round
the
dead
-
cart
.
 
<EOS>
On
reaching
the
door
of
the
house
,
the
burier
set
down
the
lantern
near
the
body
of
a
young
man
which
had
just
been
thrust
forth
.
<EOS>
At
the
same
moment
,
Chowles
,
with
a
lantern
in
his
hand
,
stepped
out
upon
the
threshold
.
<EOS>
"
Who
have
you
got
,
Jonas
?
"
he
asked
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
know
not
,
"
replied
the
hindmost
burier
.
<EOS>
"
We
entered
yon
large
house
,
the
door
of
which
stood
open
,
and
in
one
of
the
rooms
found
,
an
old
woman
in
a
fainting
state
,
and
the
body
of
this
young
girl
,
wrapped
in
a
sheet
,
and
ready
for
the
cart
.
<EOS>
So
we
clapped
it
on
the
board
,
and
brought
it
away
with
us
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
did
right
,
"
replied
Chowles
.
<EOS>
"
I
wonder
whose
body
it
is
.
"
 
<EOS>
As
he
spoke
,
he
held
up
his
lantern
,
and
unfastening
it
,
threw
the
light
full
upon
the
face
.
<EOS>
The
features
were
pale
as
marble
;
calm
in
their
expression
,
and
like
those
of
one
wrapped
in
placid
slumber
.
<EOS>
The
long
fair
hair
hung
over
the
side
of
the
board
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
sad
and
touching
sight
.
 
<EOS>
"
Why
,
as
I
am
a
living
man
,
it
is
the
grocer
's
daughter
,
Amabel,--somewhile
Countess
of
Rochester
!
"
exclaimed
Chowles
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
,
it
is
!
"
<EOS>
cried
the
earl
,
suddenly
rushing
from
behind
a
building
where
he
had
hitherto
remained
concealed
.
<EOS>
"
Whither
are
you
about
to
take
her
?
<EOS>
Set
her
down
--
set
her
down
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Hinder
them
not
,
my
lord
,
"
vociferated
another
person
,
also
appearing
on
the
scene
with
equal
suddenness
.
<EOS>
"
Place
her
in
the
cart
,
"
cried
Solomon
Eagle
--
for
he
<EOS>
it
was
--
to
the
bearers
.
<EOS>
"
This
is
a
just
punishment
upon
you
,
my
lord
,
"
he
added
to
Rochester
,
as
his
injunctions
were
obeyed--"oppose
them
not
in
their
duty
.
"
 
<EOS>
It
was
not
in
the
earl
's
power
to
do
so
.
<EOS>
Like
Leonard
,
he
was
transfixed
with
horror
.
<EOS>
The
other
bodies
were
soon
placed
in
the
cart
,
and
it
was
put
in
motion
.
<EOS>
At
this
juncture
,
the
apprentice
's
suspended
faculties
were
for
an
instant
--
and
an
instant
only
--
restored
to
him
.
<EOS>
He
uttered
a
piercing
cry
,
and
staggering
forward
,
fell
senseless
on
the
ground
.
    
<EOS>
BOOK
THE
FIFTH
.
 
<EOS>
DECEMBER
,
1665
.
  
<EOS>
I.
 
<EOS>
THE
DECLINE
OF
THE
PLAGUE
.
 
<EOS>
More
than
two
months
must
be
passed
over
in
silence
.
<EOS>
During
that
time
,
the
pestilence
had
so
greatly
abated
as
no
longer
to
occasion
alarm
to
those
who
had
escaped
its
ravages
.
<EOS>
It
has
been
mentioned
that
the
distemper
arrived
at
its
height
about
the
10th
of
September
,
and
though
for
the
two
following
weeks
the
decline
was
scarcely
perceptible
,
yet
it
had
already
commenced
.
<EOS>
On
the
last
week
in
that
fatal
month
,
when
all
hope
had
been
abandoned
,
the
bills
of
mortality
suddenly
decreased
in
number
to
one
thousand
eight
hundred
and
thirty
-
four
.
<EOS>
And
this
fortunate
change
could
not
be
attributed
to
the
want
of
materials
to
act
upon
,
for
the
sick
continued
as
numerous
as
before
,
while
the
deaths
were
less
frequent
.
<EOS>
In
the
next
week
there
was
a
further
decrease
of
six
hundred
;
in
the
next
after
that
of
six
hundred
;
and
so
on
till
the
end
of
October
,
when
,
the
cold
weather
setting
in
,
the
amount
was
reduced
to
nearly
one
thousand
.
 
<EOS>
At
first
,
when
the
distemper
began
to
lose
somewhat
of
its
malignancy
,
a
few
scared
individuals
appeared
in
the
streets
,
but
carefully
shunned
each
other
.
<EOS>
In
a
few
days
,
however
,
considerable
numbers
joined
them
,
and
for
the
first
time
for
nearly
three
months
there
was
something
like
life
abroad
.
<EOS>
It
is
astonishing
how
soon
hope
and
confidence
are
revived
.
<EOS>
Now
that
it
could
no
longer
be
doubted
that
the
plague
was
on
the
decline
,
it
seemed
as
if
a
miracle
had
been
performed
in
favour
of
the
city
.
<EOS>
Houses
were
opened
--
shopkeepers
resumed
their
business
--
and
it
was
a
marvel
to
every
one
that
so
many
persons
were
left
alive
.
<EOS>
Dejection
and
despair
of
the
darkest
kind
were
succeeded
by
frenzied
delight
,
and
no
bound
was
put
to
the
public
satisfaction
.
<EOS>
Strangers
stopped
each
other
in
the
streets
,
and
conversed
together
like
old
friends
.
<EOS>
The
bells
,
that
had
grown
hoarse
with
tolling
funerals
,
were
now
cracked
with
joyous
peals
.
<EOS>
The
general
joy
extended
even
to
the
sick
,
and
many
,
buoyed
up
by
hope
,
recovered
,
when
in
the
former
season
of
despondency
they
would
inevitably
have
perished
.
<EOS>
All
fear
of
the
plague
seemed
to
vanish
with
the
flying
disorder
.
<EOS>
Those
who
were
scarcely
out
of
danger
joined
in
the
throng
,
and
it
was
no
uncommon
sight
to
see
men
with
bandages
round
their
necks
,
or
supported
by
staves
and
crutches
,
shaking
hands
with
their
friends
,
and
even
embracing
them
.
 
<EOS>
The
consequence
of
this
incautious
conduct
may
be
easily
foreseen
.
<EOS>
The
plague
had
received
too
severe
a
check
to
burst
forth
anew
;
but
it
spread
further
than
it
otherwise
would
have
done
,
and
attacked
many
persons
,
who
but
for
their
own
imprudence
would
have
escaped
.
<EOS>
Amongst
others
,
a
barber
in
Saint
Martin's
-
le
-
Grand
,
who
had
fled
into
the
country
in
August
,
returned
to
his
shop
in
the
middle
of
October
,
and
,
catching
the
disorder
from
one
of
his
customers
,
perished
with
the
whole
of
his
family
.
 
<EOS>
But
these
,
and
several
other
equally
fatal
instances
,
produced
no
effect
on
the
multitude
.
<EOS>
Fully
persuaded
that
the
virulence
of
the
disorder
was
exhausted
--
as
,
indeed
,
appeared
to
be
the
case
--
they
gave
free
scope
to
their
satisfaction
,
which
was
greater
than
was
ever
experienced
by
the
inhabitants
of
a
besieged
city
reduced
by
famine
to
the
last
strait
of
despair
,
and
suddenly
restored
to
freedom
and
plenty
.
<EOS>
The
more
pious
part
of
the
community
thronged
to
the
churches
,
from
which
they
had
been
so
long
absent
,
and
returned
thanks
for
their
unexpected
deliverance
.
<EOS>
Others
,
who
had
been
terrified
into
seriousness
and
devotion
,
speedily
forgot
their
former
terrors
,
and
resumed
their
old
habits
.
<EOS>
Profaneness
and
debauchery
again
prevailed
,
and
the
taverns
were
as
well
filled
as
the
churches
.
<EOS>
Solomon
Eagle
continued
his
midnight
courses
through
the
streets
;
but
he
could
no
longer
find
an
audience
as
before
.
<EOS>
Those
who
listened
to
him
only
laughed
at
his
denunciations
of
a
new
judgment
,
and
told
him
his
preachings
and
prophesyings
were
now
completely
out
of
date
.
 
<EOS>
By
this
time
numbers
of
those
who
had
quitted
London
having
returned
to
it
,
the
streets
began
to
resume
their
wonted
appearance
.
<EOS>
The
utmost
care
was
taken
by
the
authorities
to
cleanse
and
purify
the
houses
,
in
order
to
remove
all
chance
of
keeping
alive
the
infection
.
<EOS>
Every
room
in
every
habitation
where
a
person
had
died
of
the
plague
--
and
there
were
few
that
had
escaped
the
visitation
--
was
ordered
to
be
whitewashed
,
and
the
strongest
fumigations
were
employed
to
remove
the
pestilential
effluvia
.
<EOS>
Brimstone
,
resin
,
and
pitch
were
burnt
in
the
houses
of
the
poor
;
benjamin
,
myrrh
,
and
other
more
expensive
perfumes
in
those
of
the
rich
;
while
vast
quantities
of
powder
were
consumed
in
creating
blasts
to
carry
off
the
foul
air
.
<EOS>
Large
and
constant
fires
were
kept
in
all
the
houses
,
and
several
were
burnt
down
in
consequence
of
the
negligence
of
their
owners
.
 
<EOS>
All
goods
,
clothes
,
and
bedding
,
capable
of
harbouring
infection
,
were
condemned
to
be
publicly
burned
,
and
vast
bonfires
were
lighted
in
Finsbury
Fields
and
elsewhere
,
into
which
many
hundred
cart
-
loads
of
such
articles
were
thrown
.
<EOS>
The
whole
of
Chowles
's
hoard
,
except
the
plate
,
which
he
managed
,
with
Judith
's
aid
,
to
carry
off
and
conceal
in
certain
hiding
-
places
in
the
vaults
of
Saint
Faith
's
,
was
taken
from
the
house
in
Nicholas
-
lane
,
and
cast
into
the
fire
.
 
<EOS>
The
cathedral
was
one
of
the
first
places
ordered
to
be
purified
.
<EOS>
The
pallets
of
the
sick
were
removed
and
burned
,
and
all
the
stains
and
impurities
with
which
its
floor
and
columns
were
polluted
were
cleansed
.
<EOS>
Nothing
was
left
untried
to
free
it
from
infection
.
<EOS>
It
was
washed
throughout
with
vinegar
,
fumigated
with
the
strongest
scents
,
and
several
large
barrels
of
pitch
were
set
fire
to
in
the
aisles
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
shall
undergo
another
species
of
purification
,
"
said
Solomon
Eagle
,
who
was
present
during
these
proceedings
;
"
one
that
shall
search
every
nook
within
it
--
shall
embrace
all
those
columns
,
and
pierce
every
crack
and
crevice
in
those
sculptured
ornaments
;
and
then
,
and
not
till
then
,
will
it
be
thoroughly
cleansed
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
During
all
this
time
the
grocer
had
not
opened
his
dwelling
.
<EOS>
The
wisdom
of
this
plan
was
now
made
fully
apparent
.
<EOS>
The
plague
was
declining
fast
,
and
not
an
inmate
of
his
house
had
been
attacked
by
it
.
<EOS>
Soon
after
the
melancholy
occurrence
,
he
had
been
informed
by
Doctor
Hodges
of
Amabel
's
death
;
but
the
humane
physician
concealed
from
him
the
painful
circumstances
under
which
it
occurred
.
<EOS>
It
required
all
Mr.
Bloundel
's
fortitude
to
support
him
under
the
shock
of
this
intelligence
,
and
he
did
not
communicate
the
afflicting
tidings
to
his
wife
until
he
had
prepared
her
for
their
reception
.
<EOS>
But
she
bore
them
better
than
he
had
anticipated
;
and
though
she
mourned
her
daughter
deeply
and
truly
,
she
appeared
completely
resigned
to
the
loss
.
<EOS>
Sorrow
pervaded
the
whole
household
for
some
weeks
;
and
the
grocer
,
who
never
relaxed
his
system
,
shrouded
his
sufferings
under
the
appearance
of
additional
austerity
of
manner
.
<EOS>
It
would
have
been
a
great
consolation
to
him
to
see
Leonard
Holt
;
but
the
apprentice
had
disappeared
;
and
even
Doctor
Hodges
could
give
no
account
of
him
.
 
<EOS>
One
night
,
in
the
middle
of
November
,
Mr.
Bloundel
signified
to
his
wife
his
intention
of
going
forth
,
early
on
the
following
morning
,
to
satisfy
himself
that
the
plague
was
really
abating
.
<EOS>
Accordingly
,
after
he
had
finished
his
devotions
,
and
broken
his
fast
,
he
put
his
design
into
execution
.
<EOS>
His
first
act
,
after
locking
the
door
behind
him
,
which
he
did
as
a
measure
of
precaution
,
was
to
fall
on
his
knees
and
offer
up
prayers
to
Heaven
for
his
signal
preservation
.
<EOS>
He
then
arose
,
and
,
stepping
into
the
middle
of
the
street
,
gazed
at
the
habitation
which
had
formed
his
prison
and
refuge
for
nearly
six
months
.
<EOS>
There
it
was
,
with
its
shutters
closed
and
barred
--
a
secure
asylum
,
with
all
alive
within
it
,
while
every
other
dwelling
in
the
street
was
desolate
.
 
<EOS>
The
grocer
's
sensations
were
novel
and
extraordinary
.
<EOS>
His
first
impulse
was
to
enjoy
his
newly
-
recovered
freedom
,
and
to
put
himself
into
active
motion
.
<EOS>
But
he
checked
the
feeling
as
sinful
,
and
proceeded
along
the
street
at
a
slow
pace
.
<EOS>
He
did
not
meet
a
single
person
,
until
he
reached
Cheapside
,
where
he
found
matters
completely
changed
.
<EOS>
Several
shops
were
already
opened
,
and
there
were
a
few
carts
and
other
vehicles
tracking
their
way
through
the
broad
and
yet
grass
-
grown
street
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
clear
,
frosty
morning
,
and
there
was
a
healthful
feel
in
the
bracing
atmosphere
that
produced
an
exhilarating
effect
on
the
spirits
.
<EOS>
The
grocer
pursued
his
course
through
the
middle
of
the
street
,
carefully
avoiding
all
contact
with
such
persons
as
he
encountered
,
though
he
cordially
returned
their
greetings
,
and
wandered
on
,
scarcely
knowing
whither
he
was
going
,
but
deeply
interested
in
all
he
beheld
.
 
<EOS>
The
aspect
of
the
city
was
indeed
most
curious
.
<EOS>
The
houses
were
for
the
most
part
unoccupied
--
the
streets
overgrown
with
grass
--
while
every
object
,
animate
and
inanimate
,
bore
some
marks
of
the
recent
visitation
.
<EOS>
Still
,
all
looked
hopeful
,
and
the
grocer
could
not
doubt
that
the
worst
was
past
.
<EOS>
The
different
demeanour
of
the
various
individuals
he
met
struck
him
.
<EOS>
Now
he
passed
a
young
man
whistling
cheerily
,
who
saluted
him
,
and
said
,
"
I
have
lost
my
sweetheart
by
the
plague
,
but
I
shall
soon
get
another
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
next
was
a
grave
man
,
who
muttered
,
"
I
have
lost
all
,
"
and
walked
pensively
on
.
<EOS>
Then
came
others
in
different
moods
;
but
all
concurred
in
thinking
that
the
plague
was
at
an
end
;
and
the
grocer
derived
additional
confirmation
of
the
fact
from
meeting
numerous
carts
and
other
vehicles
bringing
families
back
to
their
houses
from
the
country
.
 
<EOS>
After
roaming
about
for
several
hours
,
and
pondering
on
all
he
saw
,
he
found
himself
before
the
great
western
entrance
of
Saint
Paul
's
.
<EOS>
It
chanced
to
be
the
morning
on
which
the
pallets
and
bedding
were
brought
forth
,
and
he
watched
the
proceeding
at
a
distance
.
<EOS>
All
had
been
removed
,
and
he
was
about
to
depart
,
when
he
perceived
a
person
seated
on
a
block
of
stone
,
not
far
from
him
,
whom
he
instantly
recognised
.
<EOS>
"
Leonard
,
"
he
cried--"Leonard
Holt
,
is
it
you
?
"
 
<EOS>
Thus
addressed
,
and
in
these
familiar
tones
,
the
apprentice
looked
up
,
and
Mr.
Bloundel
started
at
the
change
that
had
taken
place
in
him
.
<EOS>
Profound
grief
was
written
in
every
line
of
his
thin
and
haggard
countenance
;
his
eyes
were
hollow
,
and
had
the
most
melancholy
expression
imaginable
;
and
his
flesh
was
wasted
away
from
the
bone
.
<EOS>
He
looked
the
very
image
of
hopeless
affliction
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
sorry
to
find
you
in
this
state
,
Leonard
,
"
said
the
grocer
,
in
a
tone
of
deep
commiseration
;
"
but
I
am
well
aware
of
the
cause
.
<EOS>
I
myself
have
suffered
severely
;
but
I
deem
it
my
duty
to
control
my
affliction
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
_
would
_
control
it
,
if
it
were
possible
,
Mr.
Bloundel
,
"
replied
Leonard
.
"
<EOS>
But
hope
is
dead
in
my
breast
.
<EOS>
I
shall
never
be
happy
again
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
trust
otherwise
,
"
replied
the
grocer
,
kindly
.
"
<EOS>
Your
trials
have
been
very
great
,
and
so
were
those
of
the
poor
creature
we
both
of
us
deplore
.
<EOS>
But
she
is
at
peace
,
and
therefore
we
need
not
lament
her
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Alas
!
"
exclaimed
Leonard
,
mournfully
,
"
I
am
now
only
anxious
to
rejoin
her
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
selfish
,
if
not
sinful
,
to
grieve
in
this
way
,
"
rejoined
Mr.
Bloundel
,
somewhat
sternly
.
<EOS>
"
You
must
bear
your
sorrows
like
a
man
.
<EOS>
Come
home
with
me
.
<EOS>
I
will
be
a
father
to
you
.
<EOS>
Nay
,
do
not
hesitate
.
<EOS>
I
will
have
no
refusal
.
"
 
<EOS>
So
saying
,
he
took
Leonard
's
arm
,
and
led
him
in
the
direction
of
Wood
-
street
.
<EOS>
Nothing
passed
between
them
on
the
way
,
nor
did
Leonard
evince
any
further
emotion
until
he
entered
the
door
of
the
grocer
's
dwelling
,
when
he
uttered
a
deep
groan
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Bloundel
was
greatly
affected
at
seeing
him
,
as
were
the
rest
of
the
family
,
and
abundance
of
tears
were
shed
by
all
,
except
Mr.
Bloundel
,
who
maintained
his
customary
stoical
demeanour
throughout
the
meeting
.
 
<EOS>
Satisfied
that
the
pestilence
had
not
declined
sufficiently
to
warrant
him
in
opening
his
house
,
the
grocer
determined
to
await
the
result
of
a
few
weeks
.
<EOS>
Indeed
,
that
very
night
,
he
had
reason
to
think
he
had
defeated
his
plans
by
precipitancy
.
<EOS>
While
sitting
after
prayers
with
his
family
,
he
was
seized
with
a
sudden
shivering
and
sickness
,
which
he
could
not
doubt
were
the
precursors
of
the
plague
.
<EOS>
He
was
greatly
alarmed
,
but
did
not
lose
his
command
over
himself
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
been
most
imprudent
,
"
he
said
,
"
in
thus
exposing
myself
to
infection
.
<EOS>
I
have
symptoms
of
the
plague
about
me
,
and
will
instantly
repair
to
one
of
the
upper
rooms
which
I
have
laid
aside
as
an
hospital
,
in
case
of
any
emergency
like
the
present
.
<EOS>
None
of
you
must
attend
me
.
<EOS>
Leonard
will
fetch
Doctor
Hodges
and
a
nurse
.
<EOS>
I
shall
then
do
very
well
.
<EOS>
Farewell
,
dear
wife
and
children
!
<EOS>
God
bless
you
all
,
and
watch
over
you
.
<EOS>
Remember
me
in
your
prayers
.
"
<EOS>
So
saying
,
he
arose
and
walked
towards
the
door
.
<EOS>
His
wife
and
eldest
son
would
have
assisted
him
,
but
he
motioned
them
away
.
 
<EOS>
"
Let
me
go
with
you
,
sir
,
"
cried
Leonard
,
who
had
arisen
with
the
others
;
"
I
will
nurse
you
;
my
life
is
of
little
consequence
,
and
I
can
not
be
more
satisfactorily
employed
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
The
grocer
reluctantly
assented
,
and
the
apprentice
assisted
him
upstairs
,
and
helped
to
place
him
in
bed
.
<EOS>
No
plague
-
token
could
be
found
about
his
person
,
but
as
the
same
alarming
symptoms
still
continued
,
Leonard
administered
such
remedies
as
he
thought
needful
,
and
then
went
in
search
of
Doctor
Hodges
.
 
<EOS>
On
reaching
Watling
-
street
,
he
found
Doctor
Hodges
about
to
retire
to
rest
.
<EOS>
The
worthy
physician
was
greatly
distressed
by
the
apprentice
's
account
of
his
master
's
illness
;
but
was
somewhat
reassured
when
the
symptoms
were
more
minutely
described
to
him
.
<EOS>
While
preparing
certain
medicines
,
and
arming
himself
with
his
surgical
implements
,
he
questioned
Leonard
as
to
the
cause
of
his
long
disappearance
.
"
<EOS>
Having
seen
nothing
of
you
,
"
he
said
,
"
since
the
fatal
night
when
our
poor
Amabel
's
sorrows
were
ended
,
I
began
to
feel
very
apprehensive
on
your
account
.
<EOS>
Where
have
you
been
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
shall
hear
,
"
replied
Leonard
,
"
though
the
relation
will
be
like
opening
my
wounds
afresh
.
<EOS>
On
recovering
from
the
terrible
shock
I
had
received
,
I
found
myself
stretched
upon
a
bed
in
a
house
whither
<EOS>
I
had
been
conveyed
by
Rainbird
the
watchman
,
who
had
discovered
me
lying
in
a
state
of
insensibility
in
the
street
.
<EOS>
For
nearly
a
week
I
continued
delirious
,
and
should
,
probably
,
have
lost
my
senses
altogether
but
for
the
attentions
of
the
watchman
.
<EOS>
As
soon
as
I
was
able
to
move
,
I
wandered
to
the
lesser
plague
-
pit
,
in
Finsbury
Fields
,
you
will
guess
with
what
intent
.
<EOS>
My
heart
seemed
breaking
,
and
I
thought
I
should
pour
forth
my
very
soul
in
grief
,
as
I
gazed
into
that
dreadful
gulf
,
and
thought
she
was
there
interred
.
<EOS>
Still
my
tears
were
a
relief
.
<EOS>
Every
evening
,
for
a
month
,
I
went
to
that
sad
spot
,
and
remained
there
till
daybreak
admonished
me
to
return
to
Rainbird
's
dwelling
.
<EOS>
At
last
,
he
was
seized
by
the
distemper
;
but
though
I
nursed
him
,
voluntarily
exposing
myself
to
infection
,
and
praying
to
be
carried
off
,
I
remained
untouched
.
<EOS>
Poor
Rainbird
died
;
and
having
seen
his
body
thrown
into
the
pit
,
I
set
off
into
Berkshire
,
and
after
three
days
'
toilsome
travel
on
foot
,
reached
Ashdown
Park
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
melancholy
pleasure
to
behold
the
abode
where
she
I
had
loved
passed
her
last
few
days
of
happiness
,
and
where
I
had
been
near
her
.
<EOS>
Her
aunt
,
good
Mrs.
Buscot
,
though
overwhelmed
by
affliction
at
the
sad
tidings
I
brought
her
,
received
me
with
the
utmost
kindness
,
and
tried
to
console
me
.
<EOS>
My
sorrow
,
however
,
was
too
deeply
seated
to
be
removed
.
<EOS>
Wandering
over
the
downs
,
I
visited
Mrs.
Compton
at
Kingston
Lisle
,
from
whose
house
Amabel
was
carried
off
by
the
perfidious
earl
.
<EOS>
She
,
also
,
received
me
with
kindness
,
and
strove
,
like
Mrs.
Buscot
,
to
comfort
me
,
and
,
like
her
,
ineffectually
.
<EOS>
Finding
my
strength
declining
,
and
persuaded
that
my
days
were
drawing
to
a
close
,
I
retraced
my
steps
to
London
,
hoping
to
find
a
final
resting
-
place
near
her
I
had
loved
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
are
,
indeed
,
faithful
to
the
grave
,
Leonard
,
"
said
the
physician
,
brushing
away
a
tear
;
"
and
I
never
heard
or
read
of
affection
stronger
than
yours
.
<EOS>
Sorrow
is
a
great
purifier
,
and
you
will
come
out
all
the
better
for
your
trial
.
<EOS>
You
are
yet
young
,
and
though
you
never
can
love
as
you
_
have
_
loved
,
a
second
time
,
your
heart
is
not
utterly
seared
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Utterly
,
sir
,
"
echoed
Leonard
,
"
utterly
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
think
so
,
now
,
"
rejoined
the
physician
.
<EOS>
"
But
you
will
find
it
otherwise
hereafter
.
<EOS>
I
can
tell
you
of
one
person
who
has
suffered
almost
as
much
from
your
absence
as
you
have
done
for
the
loss
of
Amabel
.
<EOS>
The
Lady
Isabella
Argentine
has
made
constant
inquiries
after
you
;
and
though
I
should
be
the
last
person
to
try
to
rouse
you
from
your
present
state
of
despondency
,
by
awakening
hopes
of
alliance
with
the
sister
of
a
proud
noble
,
yet
it
may
afford
you
consolation
to
know
that
she
still
cherishes
the
warmest
regard
for
you
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
grateful
to
her
,
"
replied
Leonard
,
sadly
,
but
without
exhibiting
any
other
emotion
.
<EOS>
"
She
was
dear
to
Amabel
,
and
therefore
will
be
ever
dear
to
me
.
<EOS>
I
would
fain
know
,
"
he
added
,
his
brow
suddenly
contracting
,
and
his
lip
quivering
,
"
what
has
become
of
the
Earl
of
Rochester
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
He
has
married
a
wealthy
heiress
,
the
fair
Mistress
Mallet
,
"
replied
Hodges
.
 
<EOS>
"
Married
,
and
so
soon
!
"
cried
Leonard
.
"
<EOS>
And
he
has
quite
forgotten
his
victim
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Apparently
so
,
"
replied
the
doctor
,
with
an
expression
of
disgust
.
 
<EOS>
"
And
it
was
for
one
who
so
lightly
regarded
her
that
she
sacrificed
herself
,
"
groaned
Leonard
,
his
head
dropping
upon
his
breast
.
 
<EOS>
"
Come
,
"
cried
Hodges
,
taking
his
arm
,
and
leading
him
out
of
the
room
;
"
we
must
go
and
look
after
your
master
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
With
this
,
they
made
the
best
of
their
way
to
Wood
-
street
.
<EOS>
Arrived
at
the
grocer
's
house
,
they
went
upstairs
,
and
Hodges
immediately
pronounced
Mr.
Bloundel
to
be
suffering
from
a
slight
feverish
attack
,
which
a
sudorific
powder
would
remove
.
<EOS>
Having
administered
the
remedy
,
he
descended
to
the
lower
room
to
allay
the
fears
of
the
family
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Bloundel
received
the
happy
tidings
with
tears
of
joy
,
and
the
doctor
remained
a
short
time
to
condole
with
her
on
the
loss
she
had
sustained
.
<EOS>
The
good
dame
wept
bitterly
on
hearing
the
whole
particulars
,
with
which
she
had
been
hitherto
unacquainted
,
attending
her
daughter
's
untimely
death
,
but
she
soon
regained
her
composure
.
<EOS>
They
then
spoke
of
Leonard
,
who
had
remained
above
with
his
master,--of
his
blighted
hopes
,
and
seemingly
incurable
affliction
.
 
<EOS>
"
His
is
true
love
,
indeed
,
doctor
,
"
sighed
Mrs.
Bloundel
.
<EOS>
"
Pity
it
is
that
it
could
not
be
requited
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
know
not
how
it
is
,
"
rejoined
Hodges
,
"
and
will
not
question
the
decrees
of
our
All
-
Wise
Ruler
,
but
the
strongest
affection
seldom
,
if
ever
,
meets
a
return
.
<EOS>
Leonard
himself
was
insensible
to
the
devotion
of
one
,
of
whom
I
may
say
,
without
disparagement
to
our
poor
Amabel
,
that
she
was
,
in
my
opinion
,
her
superior
in
beauty
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
And
does
this
person
love
him
still
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Mrs.
Bloundel
,
eagerly
.
<EOS>
"
I
ask
,
because
I
regard
him
as
a
son
,
and
earnestly
desire
to
restore
him
to
happiness
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Alas
!
"
exclaimed
Hodges
<EOS>
,
"
there
are
obstacles
in
the
way
that
can
not
be
removed
.
<EOS>
We
must
endeavour
to
cure
him
of
his
grief
in
some
other
way
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
The
conversation
then
dropped
,
and
Hodges
took
his

,
promising
to
return
on
the
morrow
,
and
assuring

Bloundel
that

about
her

.
<EOS>
And
so
it
proved
.
<EOS>
The
powders
removed
all
the
grocer
's
feverish
symptoms
,
and
when
Doctor
Hodges
made
his

the
next

,
he
found
him
dressed
,
and
ready

downstairs
.
<EOS>
Having
received
the
physician
's
congratulations
on
his
entire
recovery
,
Mr.
Bloundel
inquired
from
him
when
he
thought
he
might
with
entire
safety
open
his
shop
.
<EOS>
Hodges
considered
for
a
moment
,
and
then
replied
,
"
I
do
not
see
any
great
risk
in
doing

now
,
but
I

you
to
defer

for
a

.
<EOS>
I
would
,
also
,
recommend
you
to
take
the
whole

for
a

into
the
country
.
<EOS>
Pure
air
and
change
of
scene
are

necessary
after

long

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Farmer
Wingfield
,
of

-

,
who

us
on

way
down
to
Ashdown

,
will
,
I

,
receive

,
"
observed
Leonard
.
 
<EOS>
"
If

,
you
can
not

,
"
rejoined

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
will

,
"
returned

Bloundel
.
<EOS>
And
leading

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
My

,
you

,

,
"

Bloundel
.
 
<EOS>
"
Heaven

,

!
"
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"
But

till
all

is
at

end
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Rest
assured
I
will
not
,
"
he

.
<EOS>
Soon

,

Hodges
took

,

had

the
street

,
when

,

he

of
Blaize
.
 
<EOS>
"
Make

easy
about

,
child
,
"
replied
the
doctor
;
"
I
am
pretty

he
is
safe

.
<EOS>
He
has
had
the
plague
,

;
but
he

's
cured
.
 
<EOS>
"
O
then
I
_
shall
_

,
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Poor

,

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

,
"

.
"
<EOS>
And

.
 
<EOS>
For

.
<EOS>
But

;
and
here

was
of

.
<EOS>
They
often

of
Amabel
,
and
Mr.
Bloundel
strove
,
by
every

he
was
master

,
to

under

.
<EOS>
He
so
far

that
Leonard
's
health
improved
,
though

a

secret

.
<EOS>
Things
were
in
this

,
when
one

a

the

,
and

.
<EOS>
After

,

,

she
might

into

,

.
<EOS>
Patience

to

,

of
Blaize
,

.
<EOS>

,

,
discovering

.
 
<EOS>
"
What

,

?
<EOS>
"

,
in

,

.
<EOS>
"
What

?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
have

news
of
Blaize
,
"

.
<EOS>
"
But

you
look
.
<EOS>
By
the

Venus
!
<EOS>
your

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Never

,

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
Where

?
<EOS>
Why

?
"
 
<EOS>
"
Alas
!
"

,

"
he

.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Could

!
"
<EOS>
half

.
<EOS>
"
Why

?
"
 
<EOS>
"
Do
not

,
"

,

.
"
<EOS>
He

,

.
<EOS>
The

,
that
,
by

!
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
"
 
"
Do

"

"
I

.
"
 
"
Nonsense
!
"

.
<EOS>
"
I

I

.
<EOS>
By

!
<EOS>
I

.
"
<EOS>
And

,

;
and
,

,

a

.
<EOS>
As

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
The

,

.
 
<EOS>
"

,
"

.
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Then

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
<EOS>

<EOS>

"

<EOS>
"

.

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

.

<EOS>

<EOS>

"
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
oh

<EOS>

<EOS>

"

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"
I

<EOS>
"
I

<EOS>
"
Blaize

<EOS>
"

,

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>

"

<EOS>

"
 
<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"

"
 
<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>
"
I

"
 
<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

"

.
<EOS>
It

he

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
Ah
,

,
I

,
"

,
"
and

,

,

.
<EOS>
I
_
have
_

,

,

a

it

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
heard

your

from
Leonard
Holt
,
"

Bloundel
.
<EOS>
"
But

Paul
's
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
In

,

,
"

;
"
sometimes

-

,

.
<EOS>
I
only

London
yesterday
,
and

,
whom
I

to
go

,

I

,
in
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
We

,
"
observed

Bloundel
,
"

.
<EOS>
You

.
"
 
<EOS>
Blaize
obeyed
,
and
was
received
by
old
Josyna
with
a
scream
of
delight
.
<EOS>
Having
embraced
him
,
and
sobbed
over
him
,
she
ran
for
a

of

,
and
poured
its
contents
down
his

so

as
nearly
to
choke

.
<EOS>
She
then
spread
abundance
of
eatables
before

,
and
after
he
had

and

full
,

a

plague
medicine
which

.
 
<EOS>
"
No
,
thank

,
mother
,
"
replied
Blaize
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
had

_
that
_
.
<EOS>
But
if
there
should

a
box
of

amongst

store
,
you
can
bring
it
,
as
I
think

might
