.
"
 
<EOS>
Three
days
after
this
event
,
the
apprentice
was
sent
forth
to
ascertain
the
precise
state
of
the
city
,
as
,
if
all
proved
favourable
,
the
grocer
proposed
to
open
his
house
on
the
following
day
.
<EOS>
Leonard
set
out
betimes
,
and
was
speedily
convinced
that
all
danger
was
at
an
end
.
<EOS>
A
severe
frost
had
set
in
,
and
had
completely
purified
the
air
.
<EOS>
For
the
last
few
days
there
had
been
no
deaths
of
the
plague
,
and
but
little
mortality
of
any
kind
.
<EOS>
Leonard
traversed
several
of
the
main
streets
,
and
some
narrow
thoroughfares
,
and
found
evidences
of
restored
health
and
confidence
everywhere
.
<EOS>
It
is
true
there
were
many
houses
,
in
which
whole
families
had
been
swept
off
,
still
left
untenanted
.
<EOS>
But
these
were
only
memorials
of
the
past
calamity
,
and
could
not
be
referred
to
any
existing
danger
.
<EOS>
Before
returning
to
Wood
-
street
,
an
irresistible
impulse
led
him
to
Finsbury
Fields
.
<EOS>
He
passed
through
the
postern
east
of
Cripplegate
,
and
shaped
his
way
towards
the
lesser
plague
-
pit
.
<EOS>
The
sun
,
which
had
been
bright
all
the
morning
,
was
now
partially
obscured
;
the
air
had
grown
thick
,
and
a
little
snow
fell
.
<EOS>
The
ground
was
blackened
and
bound
by
the
hard
frost
,
and
the
stiffened
grass
felt
crisp
beneath
his
feet
.
<EOS>
Insensible
to
all
external
circumstances
,
he
hurried
forward
,
taking
the
most
direct
course
,
and
leaping
every
impediment
in
his
path
.
<EOS>
Having
crossed
several
fields
,
he
at
length
stood
before
a
swollen
heap
of
clay
,
round
which
a
wooden
railing
was
placed
.
<EOS>
Springing
over
the
enclosure
,
and
uttering
a
wild
cry
that
evinced
the
uncontrollable
anguish
of
his
breast
,
he
flung
himself
upon
the
mound
.
<EOS>
He
remained
for
some
time
in
the
deepest
affliction
,
and
was
at
last
roused
by
.
<EOS>
a
hand
laid
upon
his
shoulder
,
and
,
raising
himself
,
beheld
Thirlby
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
thought
it
must
be
you
,
"
said
the
new
comer
,
in
accents
of
the
deepest
commiseration
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
been
visiting
yonder
plague
-
pit
for
the
same
melancholy
purpose
as
yourself,--to
mourn
over
my
lost
child
.
<EOS>
I
have
been
in
search
of
you
,
and
have
much
to
say
to
you
.
<EOS>
Will
you
meet
me
in
this
place
at
midnight
tomorrow
?
<EOS>
"
Leonard
signified
his
assent
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
in
danger
,
"
pursued
Thirlby
,
"
for
,
by
some
means
,
the
secret
of
my
existence
has
been
made
known
,
and
the
officers
of
justice
are
in
pursuit
of
me
.
<EOS>
I
suspect
that
Judith
Malmayns
is
my
betrayer
.
<EOS>
You
will
not
fail
me
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
will
not
,
"
returned
Leonard
.
<EOS>
Upon
this
,
Thirlby
hurried
away
,
and
leaping
a
hedge
,
disappeared
from
view
.
 
<EOS>
Leonard
slowly
and
sorrowfully
returned
to
Wood
-
street
.
<EOS>
On
arriving
there
,
he
assured
his
master
that
he
might
with
entire
safety
open
his
house
,
as
he
proposed
,
on
the
morrow
;
and
Doctor
Hodges
,
who
visited
the
grocer
the
same
evening
,
confirmed
the
opinion
.
<EOS>
Early
,
therefore
,
the
next
morning
,
Mr.
Bloundel
summoned
his
family
to
prayers
;
and
after
pouring
forth
his
supplications
with
peculiar
fervour
and
solemnity
,
he
went
,
accompanied
by
them
all
,
and
threw
open
the
street
-
door
.
<EOS>
Again
,
kneeling
down
at
the
threshold
,
he
prayed
fervently
,
as
before
.
<EOS>
He
then
proceeded
to
remove
the
bars
and
shutters
from
the
windows
.
<EOS>
The
transition
from
gloom
and
darkness
to
bright
daylight
was
almost
overpowering
.
<EOS>
For
the
first
time
for
six
months
,
the
imprisoned
family
looked
forth
on
the
external
world
,
and
were
dazzled
and
bewildered
by
the
sight
.
<EOS>
The
grocer
himself
,
despite
his
sober
judgment
,
could
scarcely
believe
he
had
not
been
in
a
trance
during
the
whole
period
.
<EOS>
The
shop
was
scarcely
opened
before
it
was
filled
with
customers
,
and
Leonard
and
Stephen
were
instantly
employed
.
<EOS>
But
the
grocer
would
sell
nothing
.
<EOS>
To
those
who
asked
for
any
article
he
possessed
,
he
presented
them
with
it
,
but
would
receive
no
payment
.
 
<EOS>
He
next
dispatched
Blaize
to
bring
together
all
the
poor
he
could
find
,
and
distributed
among
them
the
remainder
of
his
store
--
his
casks
of
flour
,
his
salted
meat
,
his
cheeses
,
his
biscuits
,
his
wine
--
in
short
,
all
that
was
left
.
 
<EOS>
"
This
I
give
,
"
he
said
,
"
as
a
thanksgiving
to
the
Lord
,
and
as
a
humble
testimony
of
gratitude
for
my
signal
deliverance
.
"
  
<EOS>
II
.
 
<EOS>
THE
MIDNIGHT
MEETING
.
 
<EOS>
The
first
day
of
his
deliverance
being
spent
by
the
grocer
in
the
praiseworthy
manner
before
related
,
he
laid
his
head
upon
his
pillow
with
a
feeling
of
satisfaction
such
as
he
had
not
for
months
experienced
.
<EOS>
A
very
remarkable
dream
occurred
to
him
that
night
,
and
its
recollection
afterwards
afforded
him
the
greatest
consolation
.
<EOS>
While
thinking
of
Amabel
,
and
of
the
delight
her
presence
would
have
afforded
him
,
slumber
stole
upon
him
,
and
his
dreams
were
naturally
influenced
by
his
previous
meditations
.
<EOS>
It
appeared
to
him
that
he
was
alone
within
his
house
,
and
while
visiting
one
of
the
upper
rooms
,
which
had
formerly
been
appropriated
to
his
lost
daughter
,
he
noticed
a
small
door
in
the
wall
that
had
never
before
attracted
his
attention
.
<EOS>
He
immediately
pushed
against
it
,
and
yielding
to
the
touch
,
it
admitted
him
to
an
apartment
with
which
he
seemed
acquainted
,
though
he
could
not
recall
the
time
when
he
had
seen
it
.
<EOS>
It
was
large
and
gloomy
,
panelled
with
dark
and
lustrous
oak
,
and
filled
with
rich
but
decayed
furniture
.
<EOS>
At
the
further
end
stood
a
large
antique
bed
,
hung
round
with
tarnished
brocade
curtains
.
<EOS>
The
grocer
shuddered
at
the
sight
,
for
he
remembered
to
have
heard
Doctor
Hodges
assert
,
that
in
such
a
bed
,
and
in
such
a
room
as
this
,
his
daughter
had
breathed
her
last
.
<EOS>
Some
one
appeared
to
be
within
the
bed
,
and
rushing
forward
with
a
throbbing
heart
,
and
a
foreboding
of
what
was
to
follow
,
he
beheld
the
form
of
Amabel
.
<EOS>
Yes
,
there
she
was
,
with
features
like
those
she
wore
on
earth
,
but
clothed
with
such
celestial
beauty
,
and
bearing
the
impress
of
such
serene
happiness
,
that
the
grocer
felt
awe
-
struck
as
he
gazed
at
her
!
 
<EOS>
"
Approach
,
my
father
,
"
said
the
visionary
form
,
in
a
voice
so
musical
that
it
thrilled
through
his
frame--"approach
,
and
let
what
you
now
hear
be
for
ever
graven
upon
your
heart
.
<EOS>
Do
not
lament
me
more
,
but
rather
rejoice
that
I
am
removed
from
trouble
,
and
in
the
enjoyment
of
supreme
felicity
.
<EOS>
Such
a
state
you
will
yourself
attain
.
<EOS>
You
have
run
the
good
race
,
and
will
assuredly
reap
your
reward
.
<EOS>
Comfort
<EOS>
my
dear
mother
,
my
brothers
,
my
little
sister
,
with
the
assurance
of
what
I
tell
you
,
and
bid
them
dry
their
tears
.
<EOS>
I
can
now
read
the
secrets
of
all
hearts
,
and
know
how
true
was
Leonard
Holt
's
love
for
me
,
and
how
deep
and
sincere
is
his
present
sorrow
.
<EOS>
But
I
am
not
permitted
to
appear
to
him
as
I
now
appear
to
you
.
<EOS>
Often
have
I
heard
him
invoke
me
in
accents
of
the
wildest
despair
,
and
have
floated
past
him
on
the
midnight
breeze
,
but
could
neither
impart
consolation
to
him
nor
make
him
sensible
of
my
presence
,
because
his
grief
was
sinful
.
<EOS>
Bid
him
be
comforted
.
<EOS>
Bid
him
put
a
due
control
upon
his
feelings
.
<EOS>
Bid
him
open
his
heart
anew
,
and
he
shall
yet
be
happy
,
yet
love
again
,
and
have
his
love
requited
.
<EOS>
Farewell
,
dear
father
!
"
 
<EOS>
And
with
these
words
the
curtains
of
the
bed
closed
.
<EOS>
The
grocer
stretched
out
his
arm
to
draw
them
aside
,
and
in
the
effort
awoke
.
<EOS>
He
slept
no
more
that
night
,
but
dwelt
with
unutterable
delight
on
the
words
he
had
heard
.
<EOS>
On
rising
,
his
first
object
was
to
seek
out
Leonard
,
and
to
relate
his
vision
to
him
.
<EOS>
The
apprentice
listened
in
speechless
wonder
,
and
remained
for
some
time
lost
in
reflection
.
 
<EOS>
"
From
any
other
person
than
yourself
,
sir
,
"
he
said
,
at
length
,
"
I
might
have
doubted
this
singular
story
,
but
coming
from
you
,
I
attach
implicit
credence
to
it
.
<EOS>
I
_
<EOS>
will
_
obey
your
sainted
daughter
's
injunctions
;
<EOS>
I
_
will
<EOS>
_
struggle
against
the
grief
that
overwhelms
me
,
and
will
try
to
hope
that
her
words
may
be
fulfilled
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
will
do
wisely
,
"
rejoined
Mr.
Bloundel
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
After
breakfast
we
will
walk
together
to
the
farmhouse
you
spoke
of
at
Kensal
Green
,
and
if
its
owner
should
prove
willing
to
receive
my
family
for
a
few
weeks
,
I
will
remove
them
thither
at
once
.
"
 
<EOS>
Leonard
applauded
his
master
's
resolution
,
expressing
his
firm
conviction
that
Farmer
Wingfield
would
readily
accede
to
the
proposal
,
and
the
rest
of
the
family
having
by
this
time
assembled
,
they
sat
down
to
breakfast
.
<EOS>
As
soon
as
the
meal
was
over
,
Mr.
Bloundel
intrusted
the
care
of
the
shop
to
Stephen
and
Blaize
,
and
accompanied
by
Leonard
,
set
forth
.
<EOS>
On
the
way
to
the
west
end
of
the
town
,
the
grocer
met
one
or
two
of
his
old
friends
,
and
they
welcomed
each
other
like
men
risen
from
the
grave
.
<EOS>
Their
course
took
them
through
Saint
Giles
's
,
where
the
plague
had
raged
with
the
greatest
severity
,
and
where
many
houses
were
still
without
tenants
.
 
<EOS>
"
If
all
had
acted
as
I
have
done
,
"
sighed
the
grocer
,
as
he
gazed
at
these
desolate
habitations
,
"
<EOS>
how
many
lives
,
under
God
's
providence
,
would
have
been
saved
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
In
my
opinion
,
sir
,
"
replied
Leonard
,
"
you
owe
your
preservation
as
much
to
your
piety
as
to
your
prudence
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
placed
my
trust
on
high
,
"
rejoined
the
grocer
,
"
and
have
not
been
forsaken
.
<EOS>
And
yet
many
evil
doers
have
escaped
;
amongst
others--
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
know
whom
you
mean
,
sir
,
"
interrupted
Leonard
,
with
some
fierceness
,
"
but
a
day
of
retribution
will
arrive
for
him
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
No
more
of
this
,
"
rejoined
the
grocer
,
severely
.
"
<EOS>
Remember
the
solemn
injunction
you
have
received
.
"
 
<EOS>
At
this
moment
they
observed
a
horseman
,
richly
attired
,
and
followed
by
a
couple
of
attendants
,
riding
rapidly
towards
them
.
<EOS>
Both
instantly
recognised
him
.
<EOS>
The
apprentice
's
cheek
and
brow
flushed
with
anger
,
and
Mr.
Bloundel
had
much
ado
to
control
his
emotion
.
<EOS>
It
was
the
Earl
of
Rochester
,
and
on
seeing
them
he
instantly
dismounted
,
and
flinging
his
bridle
to
one
of
the
attendants
,
advanced
towards
them
.
<EOS>
Noticing
the
fury
that
gleamed
in
Leonard
's
eyes
,
and
apprehending
some
violence
on
his
part
,
the
grocer
laid
his
hand
,
upon
his
arm
,
and
sternly
enjoined
him
to
calm
himself
.
 
<EOS>
By
this
time
,
the
earl
had
reached
them
.
"
<EOS>
Mr.
Bloundel
,
"
he
said
,
in
a
tone
of
much
emotion
,
and
with
a
look
that
seemed
to
bespeak
contrition
.
<EOS>
"
I
heard
that
you
had
opened
your
house
yesterday
,
and
was
about
to
call
upon
you
.
<EOS>
I
have
a
few
words
to
say
to
you
on
a
subject
painful
to
both
of
us
,
but
doubly
painful
to
me
--
your
daughter
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
must
decline
to
hear
them
,
my
lord
,
"
replied
the
grocer
,
coldly
;
"
nor
shall
you
ever
cross
my
threshold
again
with
my
consent
.
<EOS>
My
poor
child
is
now
at
peace
.
<EOS>
You
can
do
her
no
further
injury
,
and
must
settle
your
own
account
with
your
Maker
.
<EOS>
"
 
"
Do
not
refuse
me
your
forgiveness
,
"
implored
the
earl
.
<EOS>
"
I
will
make
every
reparation
in
my
power
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
_
can
_
make
none
,
"
replied
the
grocer
,
repelling
him
;
"
and
as
to
my
forgiveness
,
I
neither
refuse
it
nor
accord
it
.
<EOS>
I
pray
your
lordship
to
let
me
pass
.
<EOS>
The
sole
favour
I
ask
of
you
is
to
come
near
me
no
more
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
obey
you
,
"
replied
the
earl
.
<EOS>
"
Stay
,
"
he
added
to
Leonard
,
who
stood
by
,
regarding
him
with
a
look
of
deadly
animosity
.
<EOS>
"
I
would
give
you
a
piece
of
caution
.
<EOS>
Your
life
is
in
danger
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
can
easily
guess
from
whom
,
"
replied
the
apprentice
,
scornfully
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
mistake
,
"
rejoined
Rochester
;
"
you
have
nothing
to
apprehend
from
me
.
<EOS>
You
have
promised
to
meet
some
one
to
-
night
,
"
he
added
,
in
so
low
a
tone
as
to
be
inaudible
to
the
grocer
.
"
<EOS>
Do
not
go
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Your
lordship
's
warning
will
not
deter
me
,
"
rejoined
the
apprentice
.
 
<EOS>
"
As
you
will
,
"
rejoined
Rochester
,
turning
away
.
<EOS>
And
springing
upon
his
horse
,
and
striking
his
spurs
into
his
side
,
he
dashed
off
,
while
Leonard
and
the
grocer
took
the
opposite
direction
.
<EOS>
In
less
than
half
an
hour
they
reached
the
little
village
of
Paddington
,
then
consisting
of
a
few
houses
,
but
now
one
of
the
most
populous
and
important
parishes
of
the
metropolis
,
and
speedily
gained
the
open
country
.
<EOS>
Even
at
this
dreary
season
the
country
had
charms
,
which
Mr.
Bloundel
,
after
his
long
confinement
,
could
fully
appreciate
.
<EOS>
His
eye
roamed
over
the
wide
prospect
;
and
the
leafless
trees
,
the
bare
hedges
,
and
the
frost
-
bound
fields
seemed
pleasant
in
his
sight
.
 
<EOS>
He
quickened
his
pace
,
and
being
wholly
indifferent
to
the
cold
,
greatly
enjoyed
the
exercise
.
<EOS>
Leonard
pointed
out
to
him
the
spots
where
the
fugitives
from
the
plague
had
pitched
their
tents
,
and
also
the
pest
-
house
near
Westbourne
Green
,
where
he
himself
had
been
received
during
his
second
attack
of
the
distemper
,
and
which
was
now
altogether
abandoned
.
 
<EOS>
Soon
after
this
,
they
mounted
the
hill
beyond
Kensal
Green
,
and
approached
the
farmhouse
.
<EOS>
Leonard
descried
Wingfield
near
one
of
the
barns
,
and
hailing
him
,
he
immediately
came
forward
.
<EOS>
On
being
informed
of
Mr.
Bloundel
's
desire
,
he
at
once
assented
,
and
taking
them
into
the
house
,
mentioned
the
matter
to
his
dame
,
who
was
quite
of
the
same
opinion
as
himself
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
only
difference
between
us
<EOS>
,
"
he
said
to
Mr.
Bloundel
,
"
is
as
to
the
payment
you
propose
.
<EOS>
Now
I
will
take
none
--
not
a
farthing
.
<EOS>
Come
when
you
please
,
bring
whom
you
please
,
and
stay
as
long
as
you
please
.
<EOS>
But
do
n't
offer
me
anything
if
you
would
not
offend
me
.
<EOS>
Recollect
,
"
he
added
,
the
moisture
forcing
itself
into
his
eyes
,
and
his
strong
clear
voice
becoming
husky
with
emotion
,
"
that
I
loved
your
daughter
for
her
resemblance
to
my
poor
child
.
<EOS>
She
,
too
,
is
gone
.
<EOS>
I
do
this
for
her
sake
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
Mr.
Bloundel
shook
the
worthy
man
warmly
by
the
hand
,
but
he
made
no
further
objection
,
resolved
in
his
own
mind
to
find
some
other
means
of
requiting
his
hospitality
.
<EOS>
It
was
then
agreed
that
the
grocer
should
bring
his
family
on
the
following
day
,
and
remain
there
for
a
month
;
and
every
other
arrangement
being
made
,
and
a
hearty
meal
partaken
of
,
he
cordially
thanked
his
host
,
and
returned
with
Leonard
to
Wood
-
street
.
 
<EOS>
In
spite
of
his
efforts
to
resist
the
impression
produced
by
the
earl
's
warning
,
Leonard
could
not
banish
it
from
his
mind
;
and
though
he
did
not
for
a
moment
think
of
abandoning
his
purpose
,
he
resolved
to
attend
the
meeting
armed
.
<EOS>
He
told
Mr.
Bloundel
he
should
go
out
that
night
,
but
did
not
state
his
object
,
and
the
grocer
did
not
inquire
it
.
<EOS>
Blaize
sat
up
with
him
,
and
displayed
much
anxiety
to
know
whither
he
was
going
,
but
,
as
may
be
supposed
,
his
curiosity
was
not
gratified
.
<EOS>
As
the
clock
struck
eleven
,
Leonard
thrust
a
sword
into
his
girdle
,
and
arming
himself
furthermore
with
his
staff
,
proceeded
towards
the
door
,
and
bade
Blaize
lock
it
after
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
shall
probably
be
back
in
a
couple
of
hours
,
"
he
said
,
as
he
went
forth
.
<EOS>
"
You
must
sit
up
for
me
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
wonder
where
he
is
going
!
"
<EOS>
thought
Blaize
,
"
From
his
gloomy
looks
,
and
the
weapon
he
has
taken
with
him
,
I
should
judge
he
is
about
to
murder
some
one
--
perhaps
the
Earl
of
Rochester
.
<EOS>
It
must
be
prevented
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
With
this
view
,
though
perhaps
rather
more
influenced
by
curiosity
than
any
better
feeling
,
the
porter
waited
a
few
seconds
to
allow
the
apprentice
to
get
out
of
sight
,
and
then
locking
the
door
outside
,
put
the
key
in
his
pocket
,
and
followed
him
.
<EOS>
The
night
was
profoundly
dark
,
but
he
had
noticed
the
direction
taken
by
Leonard
,
and
running
noiselessly
along
the
street
,
soon
perceived
him
a
little
in
advance
.
<EOS>
Regulating
his
pace
by
that
of
the
apprentice
,
and
keeping
about
fifty
yards
behind
him
,
he
tracked
his
course
along
several
streets
,
until
he
saw
him
pass
through
the
second
postern
in
the
city
wall
,
near
Moorgate
.
 
<EOS>
Here
he
debated
with
himself
whether
to
proceed
further
or
turn
back
;
but
at
length
,
curiosity
got
the
best
of
his
fears
,
and
he
went
on
.
<EOS>
A
few
steps
brought
him
into
the
open
fields
,
and
fancying
he
saw
Leonard
at
a
little
distance
before
him
,
he
hurried
on
in
that
direction
.
<EOS>
But
he
soon
found
he
had
been
deceived
by
the
stump
of
a
tree
,
and
began
to
fear
he
must
have
taken
the
wrong
course
.
<EOS>
He
looked
around
in
vain
for
some
object
to
guide
him
.
<EOS>
The
darkness
was
so
profound
that
he
could
see
nothing
,
and
he
set
off
again
at
random
,
and
not
without
much
self
-
reproach
and
misgiving
.
<EOS>
At
last
,
he
reached
a
hedge
,
and
continued
to
skirt
it
,
until
he
perceived
through
the
bushes
the
light
of
a
lantern
in
the
adjoining
field
.
<EOS>
He
immediately
called
out
,
but
at
the
cry
the
light
disappeared
.
<EOS>
This
did
not
prevent
him
from
making
towards
the
spot
where
he
had
seen
it
;
but
he
had
not
proceeded
far
when
he
was
forcibly
seized
by
some
unseen
person
,
thrown
on
the
ground
,
and
a
drawn
sword
--
for
he
felt
the
point
--
placed
at
his
throat
.
 
<EOS>
"
Utter
a
cry
,
and
it
is
your
last
,
"
cried
a
stern
voice
.
<EOS>
"
Where
is
he
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
Who
--
who
?
"
demanded
Blaize
,
half
dead
with
terror
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
whom
you
appointed
to
meet
,
"
replied
the
unknown
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
appointed
to
meet
no
one
,
"
rejoined
Blaize
.
 
<EOS>
"
Liar
!
"
exclaimed
the
other
;
"
if
you
do
not
instantly
lead
me
to
him
,
I
will
cut
your
throat
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
will
lead
you
wherever
you
please
,
if
you
will
only
let
me
get
up
,
"
rejoined
Blaize
,
with
difficulty
repressing
a
cry
.
 
<EOS>
"
By
the
daughters
of
Nox
and
Acheron
!
"
exclaimed
a
voice
which
sounded
like
music
in
the
porter
's
ears
,
"
I
think
you
are
mistaken
in
your
man
,
my
lord
.
<EOS>
It
does
not
sound
like
the
apprentice
's
voice
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
_
not
_
the
apprentice
's
voice
,
good
Major
Pillichody
,
"
rejoined
the
porter
.
<EOS>
"
It
is
mine
,
your
friend
--
Blaize
's
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Blaize
!
"
exclaimed
Pillichody
,
unmasking
a
dark
lantern
,
and
revealing
the
terror
-
stricken
countenance
of
the
porter
;
"
so
it
is
.
<EOS>
In
the
devil
's
name
,
what
are
you
doing
here
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
The
devil
himself
,
who
put
it
into
my
head
to
come
,
only
knows
,
"
replied
Blaize
;
"
but
I
followed
Leonard
Holt
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Which
way
did
he
take
?
<EOS>
"
asked
the
person
who
had
assailed
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
can
not
exactly
say
,
"
replied
Blaize
,
"
but
he
seemed
to
go
straight
into
the
fields
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
He
is
no
doubt
gone
to
the
plague
-
pit
,
"
replied
the
other
.
<EOS>
"
You
are
now
at
liberty
,
"
he
added
to
Blaize
,
"
and
I
counsel
you
to
make
the
best
of
your
way
home
.
<EOS>
Say
nothing
to
your
master
of
what
has
occurred
.
<EOS>
The
city
walls
lie
in
that
direction
.
"
 
<EOS>
Overjoyed
to
be
released
,
Blaize
ran
off
as
fast
as
his
legs
could
carry
him
,
and
never
stopped
till
he
reached
Moorgate
.
<EOS>
Meanwhile
,
Leonard
had
reached
the
place
of
meeting
.
<EOS>
As
he
stood
by
the
rail
surrounding
the
plague
-
pit
,
he
thought
of
Mr.
Bloundel
's
singular
dream
,
and
almost
hoping
to
be
similarly
favoured
,
flung
himself
on
his
knees
,
and
besought
Amabel
,
if
it
were
possible
,
to
appear
to
him
.
<EOS>
But
his
entreaties
produced
no
result
.
<EOS>
The
chill
blast
whistled
past
him
,
and
,
mindful
of
what
had
been
told
him
,
he
was
fain
to
interpret
this
into
an
answer
to
his
request
.
<EOS>
The
night
was
bitterly
cold
,
and
Leonard
,
whose
limbs
were
almost
stiffened
by
long
kneeling
,
walked
round
and
round
the
enclosure
at
a
quick
pace
to
put
his
blood
into
circulation
.
<EOS>
As
the
hour
of
midnight
was
tolled
forth
by
the
neighbouring
churches
,
he
heard
footsteps
,
and
could
just
detect
a
figure
advancing
towards
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
Are
you
there
?
"
was
asked
in
the
voice
of
Thirlby
.
<EOS>
Leonard
replied
in
the
affirmative
,
and
the
other
instantly
joined
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
Have
you
mentioned
our
meeting
to
any
one
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Leonard
.
<EOS>
"
I
ask
,
because
I
was
warned
by
the
Earl
of
Rochester
not
to
attend
it
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Strange
!
"
exclaimed
Thirlby
,
musingly
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
However
,
do
not
let
us
waste
time
.
<EOS>
I
am
about
to
leave
London
,
perhaps
this
country
--
for
ever
.
<EOS>
But
I
could
not
depart
without
an
interview
with
you
.
<EOS>
You
are
aware
of
my
strong
attachment
to
my
poor
lost
child
.
<EOS>
My
daughter
Isabella
now
supplies
her
place
in
my
heart
.
<EOS>
She
is
the
only
being
I
love
on
earth
,
for
my
son
has
alienated
himself
from
my
affections
.
<EOS>
All
I
desire
is
to
see
her
happy
.
<EOS>
This
,
I
find
,
can
only
be
accomplished
in
one
way
.
"
 
<EOS>
Here
he
paused
for
a
moment
,
but
as
Leonard
made
no
remark
,
he
proceeded
.
<EOS>
"
Why
should
I
hesitate
to
declare
it
,
"
he
said
,
"
since
it
was
for
that
object
I
brought
you
hither
?
<EOS>
She
loves
you
--
devotedly
loves
you
--
and
if
her
wishes
were
opposed
,
I
should
tremble
for
the
consequences
.
<EOS>
Now
listen
to
me
.
<EOS>
Situated
as
you
are
,
you
never
can
we
d
her
.
<EOS>
I
will
,
however
,
point
out
a
means
by
which
you
can
raise
yourself
to
distinction
in
a
short
time
,
and
so
entitle
yourself
to
claim
her
hand
.
<EOS>
I
will
supply
you
with
money
--
more
than
you
can
require
--
will
place
you
at
court
--
near
the
king
's
person
--
and
if
you
act
under
my
direction
,
your
rise
is
certain
.
<EOS>
I
have
extorted
a
promise
to
this
effect
from
my
own
son
.
<EOS>
I
told
him
my
object
,
and
that
if
he
did
not
make
your
fortune
,
I
could
ruin
him
by
revealing
myself
.
<EOS>
I
may
,
perhaps
,
pay
the
penalty
of
my
crime
on
the
scaffold
;
but
I
may
also
escape
.
<EOS>
In
the
latter
case
,
my
reappearance
would
be
fatal
to
him
.
<EOS>
He
has
consented
to
cooperate
with
me
,
to
watch
over
your
fortunes
,
and
,
as
soon
as
you
have
attained
sufficient
eminence
,
to
bestow
his
sister
upon
you
.
<EOS>
Now
do
you
understand
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
do
,
"
replied
Leonard
;
"
and
I
understand
also
against
whom
the
Earl
of
Rochester
warned
me
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
And
you
consent
,
"
demanded
Thirlby
.
 
<EOS>
Leonard
,
was
about
to
answer
,
when
he
felt
a
light
and
trembling
hand
placed
upon
his
own
.
<EOS>
"
Do
not
answer
inconsiderately
,
Leonard
,
"
said
a
low
,
sweet
voice
,
which
he
recognised
as
that
of
the
Lady
Isabella
;
"
I
am
here
to
receive
your
determination
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
glad
of
it
,
"
replied
the
apprentice
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
deep
devotion
you
have
displayed
towards
me
deserves
to
be
requited
.
<EOS>
I
will
strive
to
render
myself
worthy
of
you
,
and
I
feel
that
by
so
doing
<EOS>
I
shall
best
fulfil
the
injunctions
of
her
who
lies
beside
us
.
<EOS>
Henceforth
,
Lady
Isabella
,
I
wholly
devote
myself
to
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
A
murmur
of
delight
escaped
her
.
<EOS>
"
My
blessings
on
you
both
!
"
exclaimed
her
father
.
"
<EOS>
Give
me
your
hand
,
Isabella
,
"
he
added
,
taking
it
and
placing
it
in
that
of
the
apprentice
.
"
<EOS>
Here
,
beside
the
grave
of
her
whom
you
both
loved
,
I
affiance
you
.
<EOS>
Pursue
the
course
I
point
out
to
you
,
Leonard
,
and
she
will
soon
be
yours
.
"
 
<EOS>
As
he
spoke
,
the
light
of
a
lantern
was
suddenly
thrown
upon
them
,
disclosing
two
persons
who
had
noiselessly
approached
.
<EOS>
They
were
Lord
Argentine
and
Pillichody
.
<EOS>
"
You
affirm
more
than
you
have
warrant
for
,
my
lord
,
"
said
the
former
.
<EOS>
"
I
will
never
consent
to
this
ill
-
assorted
and
dishonourable
union
;
and
,
so
far
from
permitting
it
,
will
oppose
it
to
the
utmost
of
my
power
.
<EOS>
If
this
presumptuous
apprentice
dares
to
raise
his
views
towards
my
sister
,
let
him
look
to
himself
.
<EOS>
Your
safety
lies
in
instant
flight
.
<EOS>
The
officers
are
in
search
of
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
They
shall
find
me
,
"
replied
Thirlby
,
sternly
.
 
<EOS>
"
As
you
please
,
"
rejoined
Argentine
.
<EOS>
"
Come
with
me
,
Isabella
,
"
he
added
to
his
sister
.
<EOS>
But
she
flew
with
a
cry
towards
Leonard
.
 
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
"
exclaimed
her
brother
,
drawing
his
sword
.
<EOS>
"
Do
you
dare
to
detain
,
her
?
<EOS>
Deliver
her
to
me
,
villain
,
instantly
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
Not
when
thus
menaced
,
my
lord
,
"
rejoined
Leonard
,
likewise
drawing
his
sword
,
and
standing
upon
the
defensive
.
 
<EOS>
"
Then
look
to
yourself
,
"
replied
Argentine
,
assaulting
him
.
 
<EOS>
Isabella
uttered
a
wild
shriek
,
and
Thirlby
tried
to
rush
between
them
.
<EOS>
But
before
they
could
be
separated
,
Lord
Argentine
's
fury
had
exposed
him
to
his
adversary
,
whose
sword
passed
through
his
body
.
<EOS>
He
fell
to
the
ground
,
weltering
in
his
blood
.
<EOS>
While
Leonard
stood
stupefied
and
confounded
at
what
had
occurred
,
and
Isabella
,
uttering
a
loud
cry
,
threw
herself
upon
the
body
and
tried
to
stanch
the
wound
--
two
men
,
with
halberds
in
their
hands
rushed
forward
,
and
seizing
Thirlby
,
cried
,
"
We
arrest
you
as
a
murderer
!
"
 
<EOS>
Thirlby
,
who
seemed
utterly
overcome
by
surprise
and
horror
,
offered
no
Resistance
.
<EOS>
At
this
juncture
Leonard
felt
his
arm
seized
by
a
bystander
--
he
did
not
know
whom
--
and
scarcely
conscious
of
what
was
taking
place
,
suffered
himself
to
be
dragged
from
the
scene
.
    
<EOS>
BOOK
THE
SIXTH
.
 
<EOS>
SEPTEMBER
,
1666
.
  
<EOS>
I.
 
<EOS>
THE
FIRE
-
HALL
.
 
<EOS>
About
nine
o'clock
on
the
night
of
Saturday
,
the
second
of
September
,
1666
-
-and
rather
more
than
nine
months
after
the
incidents
last
related,--three
men
took
their
way
from
Smithfield
to
Islington
.
<EOS>
They
proceeded
at
a
swift
pace
and
in
silence
,
until
,
having
mounted
the
steep
hill
on
which
the
suburb
in
question
is
situated
,
they
halted
at
a
short
distance
from
the
high
walls
surrounding
the
great
water
-
works
formed
by
the
New
-
River
-
head
.
<EOS>
The
night
was
dark
,
but
free
from
cloud
,
in
consequence
of
a
strong
easterly
wind
which
prevailed
at
the
time
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
dark
in
London
now
,
"
observed
one
of
the
three
persons
to
his
companions
as
he
cast
his
eye
in
the
direction
of
the
great
city
,
that
lay
buried
in
gloom
beneath
them
;
"
but
there
will
be
light
enough
soon
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
A
second
dawn
,
and
brighter
than
the
first
,
shall
arise
upon
it
<EOS>
,
"
replied
one
of
his
companions
,
a
tall
,
gaunt
man
,
whose
sole
covering
was
a
sheepskin
,
girded
round
his
loins
.
<EOS>
"
Such
a
flame
shall
be
kindled
within
it
,
as
hath
not
been
seen
since
showers
of
brimstone
and
fire
descended
upon
the
sinful
cities
of
the
plain
.
'
<EOS>
The
Lord
shall
come
with
flames
of
fire
,
'
"
he
added
,
pointing
his
long
staff
towards
the
city
.
"
<EOS>
'
He
shall
make
them
like
a
fiery
oven
,
in
the
time
of
his
wrath
.
<EOS>
They
shall
be
utterly
consumed
.
'
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Amen
!
<EOS>
"
exclaimed
the
third
person
,
who
stood
near
him
,
in
a
deep
voice
,
and
with
something
of
a
foreign
accent
.
 
<EOS>
"
Not
so
loud
,
friends
,
"
rejoined
the
first
speaker
.
<EOS>
"
Let
us
set
about
the
task
.
<EOS>
I
will
ascertain
that
no
one
is
on
the
watch
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
With
this
he
moved
towards
the
water
-
works
,
and
skirting
the
circular
walls
,
to
satisfy
himself
that
all
was
secure
,
he
returned
to
his
companions
,
and
they
proceeded
to
the
principal
entrance
to
the
place
.
<EOS>
Noiselessly
unlocking
the
gates
,
the
leader
of
the
party
admitted
the
others
into
an
open
space
of
some
extent
,
in
the
midst
of
which
was
a
large
reservoir
of
water
.
<EOS>
He
then
gave
each
of
them
a
small
key
,
and
bidding
them
use
despatch
,
they
began
to
turn
the
cocks
of
the
leaden
pipes
connected
with
the
reservoir
,
while
he
hastened
to
the
further
end
of
the
inclosure
,
and
employed
himself
in
a
similar
manner
.
<EOS>
In
this
way
,
and
in
less
than
a
quarter
of
an
hour
,
the
whole
of
the
cocks
were
stopped
.
 
<EOS>
"
And
now
give
me
the
keys
,
"
said
the
leader
.
 
<EOS>
Taking
them
as
they
were
offered
,
he
added
his
own
to
the
number
,
and
flung
them
as
far
as
he
could
into
the
reservoir
,
laughing
slightly
as
the
noise
of
the
splash
occasioned
by
their
fall
into
the
water
reached
the
ears
.
 
<EOS>
"
They
will
not
be
found
till
this
pool
is
drained
,
"
he
observed
to
his
companions
.
"
<EOS>
And
now
let
us
go
.
<EOS>
Our
business
here
is
done
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Stay
yet
a
moment
,
"
cried
Solomon
Eagle
,
who
was
standing
at
the
brink
of
the
reservoir
,
with
his
eyes
fixed
upon
it
.
<EOS>
"
Stay
!
"
<EOS>
he
cried
,
arresting
him
.
"
<EOS>
A
vision
rises
before
me
.
<EOS>
I
see
in
this
watery
mirror
a
representation
of
the
burning
city
.
<EOS>
And
what
are
those
fearful
forms
that
feed
the
flames
?
<EOS>
Fiends
,
in
our
likeness
--
fiends
!
<EOS>
And
see
how
wide
and
far
the
conflagration
spreads
.
<EOS>
The
whole
city
is
swallowed
up
by
an
earthquake
.
<EOS>
It
sinks
to
the
bottomless
pit
--
down
--
down
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
No
more
of
this
,
"
cried
the
leader
,
impatiently
.
<EOS>
"
Come
along
.
"
<EOS>
And
,
followed
by
the
others
,
he
rushed
to
the
gates
,
and
locking
them
after
him
,
flung
the
key
away
.
 
<EOS>
"
A
hundred
pounds
were
paid
to
the
servant
of
the
chief
officer
of
the
works
to
bring
those
keys
to
me
,
"
he
said
,
"
and
he
executed
his
commission
faithfully
and
well
.
<EOS>
Water
will
be
vainly
sought
for
to
quench
the
conflagration
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
like
not
the
vision
I
have
just
beheld
,
"
said
Solomon
Eagle
,
in
a
troubled
tone
.
<EOS>
"
It
seems
to
portend
mischief
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Think
of
it
no
more
,
"
rejoined
the
leader
,
"
or
regard
it
as
it
was
--
a
phantom
created
by
your
overheated
imagination
.
<EOS>
Yon
city
has
sinned
so
deeply
,
that
it
is
the
will
of
Heaven
it
should
be
destroyed
;
and
it
has
been
put
into
our
hearts
by
the
Supreme
Power
to
undertake
the
terrible
task
.
<EOS>
We
are
the
chosen
instruments
of
the
divine
displeasure
.
<EOS>
Everything
favours
the
design
--
the
long
-
continued
dry
weather
--
the
strong
easterly
wind
,
which
will
bear
the
flames
into
the
heart
of
the
city
--
the
want
of
water
,
occasioned
by
the
stopping
of
these
pipes
,
the
emptying
of
the
various
aqueducts
,
and
the
destruction
of
the
Thames
water
-
tower
,
which
we
have
accomplished
.
<EOS>
Everything
favours
it
,
I
say
,
and
proves
that
the
hand
of
Heaven
directs
us
.
<EOS>
Yes
,
London
shall
fall
!
<EOS>
We
have
received
our
commission
from
on
high
,
and
must
execute
it
,
regardless
of
the
consequences
.
<EOS>
For
my
own
part
,
I
feel
as
little
compunction
to
the
task
,
as
the
thunderbolt
launched
from
on
high
does
for
the
tree
it
shivers
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Philip
Grant
has
uttered
my
sentiments
exactly
,
"
said
the
man
who
,
it
has
been
mentioned
,
spoke
with
a
slight
foreign
accent
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
neither
misgiving
nor
compunction
.
<EOS>
You
appear
to
have
forgotten
your
own
denunciations
,
brother
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Not
so
,
Brother
Hubert
,
"
rejoined
the
enthusiast
,
"
and
I
now
recognise
in
the
vision
a
delusion
of
the
Evil
One
to
turn
me
from
my
holy
purpose
.
<EOS>
But
it
has
failed
.
<EOS>
The
impious
and
impenitent
city
is
doomed
,
and
nothing
can
save
it
.
<EOS>
And
yet
I
would
fain
see
it
once
more
as
I
beheld
it
this
morn
when
day
arose
upon
it
for
the
last
time
,
from
the
summit
of
Saint
Paul
's
.
<EOS>
It
looked
so
beautiful
that
my
heart
smote
me
,
and
tears
started
to
my
eyes
,
to
think
that
those
goodly
habitations
,
those
towers
,
temples
,
halls
,
and
palaces
,
should
so
soon
be
levelled
with
the
dust
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Hear
what
the
prophet
saith
,
"
rejoined
Hubert
.
"
<EOS>
'
Thou
hast
defiled
thy
sanctuaries
by
the
multitude
of
thine
iniquities
,
by
the
iniquity
of
thy
traffic
.
<EOS>
Therefore
will
I
bring
forth
a
fire
from
the
midst
of
thee
,
and
will
bring
thee
to
ashes
upon
the
earth
,
in
the
sight
of
all
those
that
behold
thee
.
'
"
 
<EOS>
Solomon
Eagle
flung
himself
upon
his
knees
,
and
his
example
was
imitated
by
the
others
.
<EOS>
Having
recited
a
prayer
in
a
low
deep
tone
,
he
arose
,
and
stretching
out
his
arms
,
solemnly
denounced
the
city
.
<EOS>
As
he
pronounced
the
words
,
a
red
and
fiery
star
shot
from
the
dark
vault
of
the
sky
,
and
seemed
to
fall
in
the
midst
of
the
city
.
 
<EOS>
"
Did
you
not
see
that
sign
?
"
<EOS>
cried
Grant
,
eagerly
.
<EOS>
"
It
heralds
us
to
our
task
.
"
 
<EOS>
So
saying
,
he
ran
swiftly
down
the
hill
,
and
,
followed
by
the
others
,
did
not
slacken
his
pace
till
they
reached
the
city
.
<EOS>
They
then
shaped
their
course
more
slowly
towards
Saint
Paul
's
,
and
having
gained
the
precincts
of
the
cathedral
,
Solomon
Eagle
,
who
now
assumed
the
place
of
leader
,
conducted
them
to
a
small
door
on
the
left
of
the
great
northern
entrance
,
and
unlocking
it
,
ushered
them
into
a
narrow
passage
behind
the
rich
carved
work
of
the
choir
.
<EOS>
Traversing
it
,
they
crossed
the
mid
aisle
,
and
soon
reached
the
steps
leading
to
Saint
Faith
's
.
<EOS>
It
was
profoundly
dark
,
but
they
were
all
well
acquainted
with
the
road
,
and
did
not
miss
their
footing
.
<EOS>
It
required
,
however
,
some
caution
to
thread
the
ranks
of
the
mighty
pillars
filling
the
subterranean
church
.
<EOS>
But
at
last
this
was
accomplished
,
and
they
entered
the
vault
beyond
the
charnel
,
where
they
found
Chowles
and
Judith
Malmayns
.
<EOS>
The
former
was
wrapped
in
a
long
black
cloak
,
and
was
pacing
to
and
fro
within
the
narrow
chamber
.
<EOS>
When
Solomon
Eagle
appeared
,
he
sprang
towards
him
,
and
regarding
him
inquiringly
,
cried
,
"
Have
you
done
it?--have
<EOS>
you
done
it
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
The
enthusiast
replied
in
the
affirmative
.
<EOS>
"
Heaven
be
praised
!
"
exclaimed
Chowles
.
<EOS>
And
he
skipped
about
with
the
wildest
expressions
of
delight
.
<EOS>
A
gleam
of
satisfaction
,
too
,
darted
from
Judith
's
savage
eyes
.
<EOS>
She
had
neither
risen
nor
altered
her
position
on
the
arrival
of
the
party
,
but
she
now
got
up
,
and
addressed
the
enthusiast
.
<EOS>
A
small
iron
lamp
,
suspended
by
a
chain
from
the
vaulted
roof
,
lighted
the
chamber
.
<EOS>
The
most
noticeable
figure
amidst
the
group
was
that
of
Solomon
Eagle
,
who
,
with
his
blazing
eyes
,
long
jet
-
black
locks
,
giant
frame
,
and
tawny
skin
,
looked
like
a
supernatural
being
.
<EOS>
Near
him
stood
the
person
designated
as
Robert
Hubert
.
<EOS>
He
was
a
young
man
,
and
appeared
to
have
lived
a
life
of
great
austerity
.
<EOS>
His
features
were
thin
;
his
large
black
eyes
set
in
deep
caverns
;
his
limbs
seemed
almost
destitute
of
flesh
;
and
his
looks
wild
and
uncertain
,
like
those
of
an
insane
person
.
<EOS>
His
tattered
and
threadbare
garb
resembled
that
of
a
French
ecclesiastic
.
<EOS>
The
third
person
,
who
went
by
the
name
of
Philip
Grant
,
had
a
powerful
frame
,
though
somewhat
bent
,
and
a
haughty
deportment
and
look
,
greatly
at
variance
with
his
miserable
attire
and
haggard
looks
.
<EOS>
His
beard
was
long
and
grizzled
,
and
his
features
,
though
sharpened
by
care
,
retained
some
traces
of
a
noble
expression
.
<EOS>
A
few
minutes
having
passed
in
conversation
,
Grant
observed
to
the
enthusiast
,
"
I
must
now
leave
you
for
a
short
time
.
<EOS>
Give
me
the
key
that
I
may
let
myself
out
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
are
not
going
to
betray
us
?
"
<EOS>
cried
Chowles
,
suspiciously
.
 
<EOS>
"
Why
should
I
betray
you
?
"
<EOS>
rejoined
Grant
,
sternly
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
too
anxious
for
the
event
to
disclose
it
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
True
,
true
,
"
replied
Chowles
.
 
<EOS>
"
_
<EOS>
I
_
do
not
mistrust
you
,
brother
,
"
observed
Solomon
Eagle
,
giving
him
the
key
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
know
whither
you
are
going
,
"
observed
Judith
Malmayns
.
<EOS>
"
You
are
about
to
warn
Mr.
Bloundel
and
his
partner
--
apprentice
no
longer
--
Leonard
Holt
,
of
the
approaching
conflagration
.
<EOS>
But
your
care
will
be
thrown
away
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Does
she
speak
the
truth
,
brother
?
<EOS>
"
demanded
Hubert
,
raising
his
eyes
from
the
Bible
which
he
was
reading
in
the
corner
of
the
vault
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
will
do
nothing
to
endanger
the
design
,
"
rejoined
Grant
;
"
of
that
rest
assured
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
With
this
,
he
strode
forth
,
traversed
Saint
Faith
's
,
and
,
notwithstanding
the
gloom
,
reached
,
without
difficulty
,
the
little
door
by
which
he
had
entered
the
cathedral
.
<EOS>
Issuing
from
it
,
he
took
the
way
,
as
Judith
had
surmised
,
to
Wood
-
street
,
and
pausing
before
the
grocer
's
door
,
knocked
against
it
.
<EOS>
The
summons
was
presently
answered
by
Blaize
;
and
to
Grant
's
inquiries
whether
his
master
was
within
,
he
replied
,
"
Which
of
my
masters
did
you
mean
?
<EOS>
I
have
two
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
The
younger
,
"
replied
Grant
,
"
Leonard
Holt
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
So
far
you
are
fortunate
,
"
rejoined
Blaize
.
"
<EOS>
Mr.
Bloundel
has
retired
to
rest
,
but
Mr.
Holt
is
still
downstairs
.
<EOS>
Pray
what
may
be
your
business
with
him
at
this
hour
?
<EOS>
It
should
be
important
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
important
,
"
rejoined
Grant
,
"
and
does
not
admit
of
a
moment
's
delay
.
<EOS>
Tell
him
so
.
"
 
<EOS>
Eyeing
the
stranger
with
a
look
of
suspicion
,
the
porter
was
about
to
enter
into
a
parley
with
him
,
when
Leonard
himself
cut
it
short
,
and
learning
the
nature
of
the
application
,
desired
Grant
to
follow
him
into
the
adjoining
room
.
<EOS>
The
nine
months
which
had
passed
over
Leonard
's
head
since
he
was
last
brought
under
notice
,
had
wrought
a
material
change
in
his
appearance
.
<EOS>
He
had
a
grave
and
thoughtful
air
,
somewhat
inclining
to
melancholy
,
but
in
other
respects
he
was
greatly
improved
.
<EOS>
His
health
was
completely
restored
,
and
the
thoughtful
expression
added
character
to
his
handsome
physiognomy
,
and
harmonised
well
with
his
manly
and
determined
bearing
.
<EOS>
He
was
habited
plainly
,
but
with
some
degree
of
taste
.
<EOS>
As
Judith
Malmayns
had
intimated
,
he
was
now
Mr.
Bloundel
's
partner
,
and
his
whole
appearance
denoted
his
improved
circumstances
.
<EOS>
The
alteration
did
not
escape
the
notice
of
the
stranger
,
who
regarded
him
with
much
curiosity
,
and
closed
the
door
behind
him
as
he
entered
the
room
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
are
looking
much
better
than
when
we
last
met
,
Leonard
Holt
,
"
he
said
,
in
tones
that
made
his
hearer
start
,
"
and
I
am
glad
to
perceive
it
.
<EOS>
Prosperity
seems
to
attend
your
path
,
and
you
deserve
it
;
whereas
misery
and
every
other
ill
--
and
I
deserve
them
--
dog
mine
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
did
not
recognise
you
at
first
,
Mr.
Thirlby
,
"
replied
Leonard
;
"
for
,
in
truth
,
you
are
much
changed
.
<EOS>
But
you
desire
to
speak
with
me
on
a
matter
of
importance
.
<EOS>
Can
I
aid
you
?
<EOS>
You
may
need
money
.
<EOS>
Here
is
my
purse
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
do
not
want
it
,
"
replied
the
other
,
scornfully
rejecting
the
offer
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
a
proposal
to
make
to
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
shall
be
glad
to
hear
it
,
"
replied
Leonard
.
"
<EOS>
But
first
tell
me
how
you
effected
your
escape
after
your
arrest
on
that
disastrous
night
when
,
in
self
-
defence
,
and
unintentionally
,
I
wounded
your
son
,
Lord
Argentine
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Would
you
had
killed
him
!
"
<EOS>
cried
the
other
,
fiercely
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
lost
all
feelings
of
a
father
for
him
.
<EOS>
He
<EOS>
it
was
who
contrived
my
arrest
,
and
he
would
have
gladly
seen
me
borne
to
the
scaffold
,
certain
it
would
have
freed
him
from
me
for
ever
.
<EOS>
I
was
hurried
away
by
the
officers
from
the
scene
of
strife
,
and
conveyed
to
the
Tun
at
Cornhill
,
which
you
know
has
been
converted
into
a
round
-
house
,
and
where
I
was
locked
up
for
the
night
.
<EOS>
But
while
I
was
lying
on
the
floor
of
my
prison
,
driven
well
-
nigh
frantic
by
what
had
occurred
,
there
were
two
persons
without
labouring
to
effect
my
deliverance
--
nor
did
they
labour
in
vain
.
<EOS>
These
were
Chowles
and
Judith
,
my
foster
-
sister
,
and
whom
,
you
may
remember
,
I
suspected
--
and
most
unfairly
--
of
intending
my
betrayal
.
<EOS>
By
means
of
a
heavy
bribe
,
they
prevailed
on
one
of
the
officers
to
connive
at
my
escape
.
<EOS>
An
iron
bar
was
removed
from
the
window
of
my
prison
,
and
I
got
through
the
aperture
.
<EOS>
Judith
concealed
me
for
some
days
in
the
vaults
of
Saint
Faith
's
,
after
which
I
fled
into
the
country
,
where
I
wandered
about
for
several
months
,
under
the
name
of
Philip
Grant
.
<EOS>
Having
learnt
that
my
son
though
severely
hurt
by
you
,
had
recovered
from
his
wound
,
and
that
his
sister
,
the
Lady
Isabella
,
had
accompanied
him
to
his
seat
in
Staffordshire
,
I
proceeded
thither
,
and
saw
her
,
unknown
to
him
.
<EOS>
I
found
her
heart
still
true
to
you
.
<EOS>
She
told
me
you
had
disappeared
immediately
after
the
termination
of
the
conflict
,
and
had
not
been
heard
of
till
her
brother
was
out
of
danger
,
when
you
returned
to
Wood
-
street
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
The
information
was
correct
,
"
replied
Leonard
.
<EOS>
"
I
was
dragged
away
by
a
person
whom
I
did
not
recognise
at
the
time
,
but
who
proved
to
be
the
Earl
of
Rochester
.
<EOS>
He
conducted
me
to
a
place
of
safety
,
thrust
a
purse
into
my
hand
,
and
left
me
.
<EOS>
As
soon
as
I
could
do
so
with
safety
,
I
returned
to
my
master
's
house
.
<EOS>
But
how
long
have
you
been
in
London
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
Nearly
a
month
,
"
replied
Grant
.
"
<EOS>
And
now
let
me
ask
you
one
question
.
<EOS>
Do
you
ever
think
of
Isabella
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Often
,
very
often
,
"
replied
Leonard
.
<EOS>
"
But
as
I
dare
not
indulge
the
hope
of
a
union
with
her
,
I
have
striven
to
banish
her
image
from
my
mind
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
She
can
not
forget
_
<EOS>
you
_
,
Leonard
,
"
rejoined
Grant
.
"
<EOS>
And
now
to
my
proposal
.
<EOS>
I
have
another
plan
for
your
aggrandisement
that
can
not
fail
.
<EOS>
I
am
in
possession
of
a
monstrous
design
,
the
revelation
of
which
will
procure
you
whatever
you
desire
.
<EOS>
Ask
a
title
from
the
king
,
and
he
will
give
it
;
and
when
in
possession
of
that
title
,
demand
the
hand
of
the
Lady
Isabella
,
and
her
proud
brother
will
not
refuse
you
.
<EOS>
Call
in
your
porter
--
seize
me
.
<EOS>
I
will
offer
a
feigned
resistance
.
<EOS>
Convey
me
before
the
king
.
<EOS>
Make
your
own
terms
with
him
.
<EOS>
He
will
accede
to
them
.
<EOS>
Will
you
do
it
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
replied
Leonard
,
"
I
will
not
purchase
the
daughter
at
the
price
of
the
father
's
life
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Heed
me
not
,
"
replied
Grant
,
supplicatingly
,
"
I
am
wholly

to
life
.
<EOS>
And
what
matters

whether
I
am

to
the

or

?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
plead
in
vain
,
"
returned
Leonard
,
firmly
.
 
<EOS>
"
Reflect
,
"

Grant
,
in

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
A
word

you
will
not
only

,

city
from

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Save
the
city
!
"
exclaimed
Leonard
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
What
mean
you
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
Swear

with
my
request
,
and
you
shall
know
.
<EOS>
But
not
otherwise
,
"
replied
Grant
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
cannot
--
I
can
not
,
"
rejoined
Leonard
;
"
and
unfortunately
you
have
said
too
much
for
your
own

.
<EOS>
I
must
,
though
most

,

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Hear
me
,
Leonard
,
and
consider

you
do
,
"
cried
Grant
,
planting

before

door
.
<EOS>
"
I
love
you
next
to
my
daughter
,
and
chiefly
because
she
loves
you
.
<EOS>
I
have
told
you
I
have
a
design
to
discover
,
to
which
I
am
a
party
--
a
hellish
,
horrible
design
--
which
threatens
this
whole
city
with
destruction
.
<EOS>
It
is
your
duty
,
having
told
you
thus
much
,
to
arrest
me
,
and
I
will
offer
no
resistance
.
<EOS>
Will
you
not
turn
this
to
your
advantage
?
<EOS>
Will
you
not
make
a
bargain
with
the
king
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
said
I
will
not
,
"
rejoined
Leonard
.
 
<EOS>
"
Then
be
warned
by
me
,
"
rejoined
Grant
.
"
<EOS>
Arouse
your
partner
.
<EOS>
Pack
up
all
your
goods
and
make
preparations
for
instant
flight
,
for
the
danger
will
invade
you
before
you
are
aware
of
it
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Is
it
fire
?
"
demanded
Leonard
,
upon
whose
mind
the
denunciations
of
Solomon
Eagle
now
rushed
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
will
see
,
"
replied
Grant
,
with
a

.
<EOS>
"
You
will
repent
your
determination
when
it
is
too
late
.
<EOS>
Farewell
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Hold
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Leonard
,
advancing
towards
him
,
and
trying
to
lay
hands
upon
him
<EOS>
,
"
I
arrest
you
in
the
king
's
name
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Off
!
"
exclaimed
Grant
,
dashing
him
forcibly
backwards
.
<EOS>
And
striking
down
Blaize
,
who
tried
to
stop
him
in
the
passage
,
he
threw
open
the
street
-
door
,
and
disappeared
.
<EOS>
Fearful
of
pursuit
,
Grant
took
a
circuitous
route
to
Saint
Paul
's
,
and
it
was
full
half
an
hour
after
the
interview
above
related
before
he
reached
the
cathedral
.
<EOS>
Just
as
he
passed
through
the
small
door
,
the
clock
tolled
forth
the
hour
of
midnight
,
and
when
he
gained
the
mid
aisle
,
he
heard
footsteps
approaching
,
and
encountered
his
friends
.
 
<EOS>
"
We
had
given
you
up
,
"
said
Chowles
,
"
and
fearing
you
intended
us
some
treachery
,
were
about
to
do
the
job
without
you
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
been
unavoidably
detained
,
"
replied
Grant
.
<EOS>
"
Let
us
about
it
at
once
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
got
the
fire
-
balls
with
me
,
"
observed
Hubert
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
well
,
"
returned
Grant
.
 
<EOS>
Quitting
the
cathedral
,
they
proceeded
to
Thames
-
street
,
and
tracking
it
to
Fish
-
street
-
hill
,
struck
off
on
the
right
into
an
alley
that
brought
them
to
Pudding
-
lane
.
 
<EOS>
"
This
is
the
house
,
"
said
Chowles
,
halting
before
a
two
-
storied
wooden
habitation
,
over
the
door
of
which
was
suspended
the
sign
of
the
"
Wheat
Sheaf
,
with
the
name
THOMAS
FARRYNER
,
BAKER
,
inscribed
beneath
it
.
 
<EOS>
"
And
here
,
"
said
Hubert
,
"
shall
begin
the
great
fire
of
London
.
"
 
<EOS>
As
he
said
this
,
he
gave
a
fire
-
ball
to
Solomon
Eagle
,
who
lighted
the
fuze
at
Chowles
's
lantern
.
<EOS>
The
enthusiast
then
approached
a
window
of
the
baker
's
shop
,
and
breaking
a
small
pane
of
glass
within
it
,
threw
the
fire
-
ball
into
the
room
.
<EOS>
It
alighted
upon
a
heap
of
chips
and
fagots
lying
near
a
large
stack
of
wood
used
for
the
oven
,
and
in
a
few
minutes
the
whole
pile
had
caught
and
burst
into
a
flame
,
which
,
quickly
mounting
to
the
ceiling
,
set
fire
to
the
old
,
dry
,
half
-
decayed
timber
that
composed
it
.
  
<EOS>
II
.
 
<EOS>
THE
FIRST
NIGHT
OF
THE
FIRE
.
 
<EOS>
Having
seen
the
stack
of
wood
kindled
,
and
the
flames
attack
the
building
in
such
a
manner
as
to
leave
no
doubt
they
would
destroy
it
,
the
incendiaries
separated
,
previously
agreeing
to
meet
together
in
half
an
hour
at
the
foot
of
London
Bridge
;
and
while
the
others
started
off
in
different
directions
,
Chowles
and
Judith
retreated
to
a
neighbouring
alley
commanding
a
view
of
the
burning
habitation
.
 
<EOS>
"
At
last
the
great
design
is
executed
,
"
observed
Chowles
,
rubbing
his
hands
gleefully
.
"
<EOS>
The
fire
burns
right
merrily
,
and
will
not
soon
be
extinguished
.
<EOS>
Who
would
have
thought
we
should
have
found
such
famous
assistants
as
the
two
madmen
,
Solomon
Eagle
and
Robert
Hubert
--
and
your
scarcely
less
mad
foster
-
brother
,
Philip
Grant
?
<EOS>
I
can
understand
the
motives
that
influenced
the
two
first
to
the
deed
,
but
not
those
of
the
other
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Nor
I
,
"
replied
Judith
,
"
unless
he
wishes
in
some
way
or
other
to
benefit
Leonard
Holt
by
it
.
<EOS>
For
my
part
,
I
shall
enjoy
this
fire
quite
as
much
on
its
own
account
as
for
the
plunder
it
will
bring
us
.
<EOS>
I
should
like
to
see
every
house
in
this
great
city
destroyed
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
are
in
a
fair
way
of
obtaining
your
wish
,
"
replied
Chowles
;
"
but
provided
I
have
the
sacking
of
them
<EOS>
,
I
do
n't
care
how
many
are
saved
.
<EOS>
Not
but
that
such
a
fire
will
be
a
grand
sight
,
which
I
should
be
sorry
to
miss
.
<EOS>
You
forget
,
too
,
that
if
Saint
Paul
's
should
be
burnt
down
,
we
shall
lose
our
hoards
.
<EOS>
However
,
there
's
no
chance
of
that
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Not
much
,
"
replied
Judith
,
interrupting
him
.
"
<EOS>
But
see
!
<EOS>
the
baker
has
at
last
discovered
that
his
dwelling
is
on
fire
.
<EOS>
He
bursts
open
the
window
,
and
,
as
I
live
,
is
about
to
throw
himself
out
of
it
.
"
 
<EOS>
As
she
spoke
,
one
of
the
upper
windows
in
the
burning
habitation
was
burst
open
,
and
a
poor
terrified
wretch
appeared
at
it
in
his
night
-
dress
,
vociferating
in
tones
of
the
wildest
alarm
,
"
Fire
!
<EOS>
fire!--help
!
<EOS>
help
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
Shall
we
go
forward
?
"
said
Chowles
.
<EOS>
Judith
hesitated
for
a
moment
,
and
then
assenting
,
they
hurried
towards
the
spot
.
 
<EOS>
"
Can
we
give
you
any
help
,
friend
?
"
cried
Chowles
.
 
<EOS>
"
Take
care
of
this
,
"
rejoined
the
baker
,
flinging
a
bag
of
money
to
the
ground
,
"
and
I
will
endeavour
to
let
down
my
wife
and
children
.
<EOS>
The
staircase
is
on
fire
,
and
we
are
almost
stifled
with
smoke
.
<EOS>
God
help
us
!
"
<EOS>
And
the
exclamation
was
followed
by
fearful
shrieks
from
within
,
followed
by
the
appearance
of
a
woman
,
holding
two
little
children
in
her
arms
,
at
the
window
.
 
<EOS>
"
This
must
be
money
,
"
said
Judith
,
utterly
heedless
of
the
fearful
scene
occurring
above
,
and
taking
up
the
bag
and
chinking
it
;
"
silver
,
by
the
sound
.
<EOS>
Shall
we
make
off
with
it
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
No
,
no
,
"
replied
Chowles
,
"
we
must
not
run
any
risk
for
such
a
paltry
booty
.
<EOS>
Let
us
bide
our
time
.
"
 
<EOS>
At
this
juncture
,
the
baker
,
who
had
disappeared
for
a
few
seconds
from
the
window
,
again
presented
himself
at
it
,
and
,
with
some
difficulty
,
forced
a
feather
bed
through
it
,
which
was
instantly
placed
by
Chowles
in
such
a
position
beneath
,
as
to
break
the
fall
of
the
descending
parties
.
<EOS>
Tying
a
couple
of
sheets
together
,
and
fastening
one
end
round
his
wife
's
waist
,
the
baker
lowered
her
and
the
children
to
the
ground
.
<EOS>
They
alighted
in
safety
;
but
just
as
he
was
about
to
follow
their
example
,
the
floor
of
the
room
gave
way
,
and
though
he
succeeded
in
springing
through
the
window
,
he
missed
the
feather
bed
,
and
broke
his
leg
in
the
fall
.
<EOS>
He
was
picked
up
by
Chowles
and
Judith
,
and
placed
upon
the
bed
in
a
state
of
insensibility
,
and
was
soon
afterwards
conveyed
with
his
family
to
the
house
of
a
neighbour
.
 
<EOS>
Meanwhile
,
the
fire
had
spread
to
the
houses
on
either
side
of
the
unfortunate
man
's
habitation
,
and
both
of
them
being
built
entirely
of
wood
,
they
were
almost
instantly
in
flames
.
<EOS>
The
alarm
too
had
become
general
;
the
inhabitants
of
the
adjoining
houses
were
filled
with
indescribable
terror
,
and
the
narrow
street
was
speedily
crowded
with
persons
of
both
sexes
,
who
had
rushed
from
their
beds
to
ascertain
the
extent
of
the
danger
.
<EOS>
All
was
terror
and
confusion
.
<EOS>
The
fire
-
bells
of
Saint
Margaret
's
,
Saint
George
's
,
and
Saint
Andrew
's
,
in
Botolph
-
lane
,
began
to
toll
,
and
shouts
were
heard
on
every
side
,
proving
that
the
whole
neighbourhood
was
roused
.
 
<EOS>
To
add
to
the
general
distress
,
a
report
was
raised
that
a
house
in
Fish
-
street
-
hill
was
on
fire
,
and
it
was
soon
found
to
be
true
,
as
an
immense
volume
of
flames
burst
forth
in
that
quarter
.
<EOS>
While
the
rest
of
the
spectators
,
distracted
by
this
calamity
,
and
hardly
knowing
what
to
do
,
hurried
in
the
direction
of
the
new
fire
,
Chowles
and
Judith
eyed
each
other
askance
,
and
the
former
whispered
to
his
companion
,
"
This
is
another
piece
of
Hubert
's
handiwork
.
"
 
<EOS>
The
two
wretches
now
thought
it
time
to
bestir
themselves
.
<EOS>
So
much
confusion
prevailed
,
that
they
were
wholly
unobserved
,
and
under
the
plea
of
rendering
assistance
,
they
entered
houses
and
carried
off
whatever
excited
their
cupidity
,
or
was
sufficiently
portable
.
<EOS>
No
wealthy
house
had
been
attacked
as
yet
,
and
therefore
their
spoil
was
but
trifling
.
<EOS>
The
poor
baker
seemed
to
be
the
bearer
of
ill
-
luck
,
for
he
had
not
been
many
minutes
in
his
new
asylum
before
it
likewise
caught
fire
.
<EOS>
Another
house
,
too
,
in
Fish
-
street
-
hill
,
and
lower
down
than
the
first
,
was
observed
to
be
burning
,
and
as
this
was
out
of
the
current
of
the
wind
,
and
consequently
could
not
have
been
occasioned
by
the
showers
of
sparks
that
marked
its
course
,
a
cry
was
instantly
raised
that
incendiaries
were
abroad
,
and
several
suspicious
-
looking
persons
were
seized
in
consequence
.
 
<EOS>
Meantime
no
efforts
had
been
made
to
stop
the
progress
of
the
original
conflagration
in
Pudding
-
lane
,
which
continued
to
rage
with
the
greatest
fury
,
spreading
from
house
to
house
with
astonishing
rapidity
.
<EOS>
All
the
buildings
in
this
neighbourhood
being
old
,
and
of
wood
,
which
was
as
dry
as
tinder
,
a
spark
alighting
upon
them
would
have
sufficed
to
set
them
on
fire
.
<EOS>
It
may
be
conceived
,
therefore
,
what
must
have
been
the
effect
of
a
vast
volume
of
flame
,
fanned
by
a
powerful
wind
.
<EOS>
House
after
house
caught
,
as
if
constructed
of
touchwood
,
and
the
fire
roared
and
raged
to
such
a
degree
,
that
those
who
stood
by
were
too
much
terrified
to
render
any
effectual
assistance
.
<EOS>
Indeed
,
the
sole
thought
that
now
seemed
to
influence
all
<EOS>
was
the
preservation
of
a
portion
of
their
property
.
<EOS>
No
one
regarded
his
neighbour
,
or
the
safety
of
the
city
.
<EOS>
The
narrow
street
was
instantly
filled
with
goods
and
furniture
of
all
kinds
,
thrown
out
of
the
windows
or
pushed
out
of
the
doors
;
but
such
was
the
fierceness
of
the
fire
,
and
the
extraordinary
rapidity
with
which
it
advanced
,
that
the
very
articles
attempted
to
be
saved
were
seized
by
it
,
and
thus
formed
a
means
of
conveying
it
to
the
opposite
houses
.
 
<EOS>
In
this
way
a
number
of
persons
were
inclosed
for
a
short
time
between
two
fires
,
and
seemed
in
imminent
danger
of
being
burned
to
death
.
<EOS>
The
perilous
nature
of
their
situation
was
,
moreover
,
increased
by
a
sudden
and
violent
gust
of
wind
,
which
,
blowing
the
flames
right
across
the
street
,
seemed
to
envelop
all
within
them
.
<EOS>
The
shrieks
that
burst
from
the
poor
creatures
thus
involved
were
most
appalling
.
<EOS>
Fortunately
,
they
sustained
no
greater
damage
than
was
occasioned
by
the
fright
and
a
slight
scorching
,
for
the
next
moment
the
wind
shifted
,
and
,
sweeping
back
the
flames
,
they
were
enabled
to
effect
their
retreat
.
<EOS>
Chowles
and
Judith
were
among
the
sufferers
,
and
in
the
alarm
of
the
moment
lost
all
the
booty
they
had
obtained
.
 
<EOS>
Soon
after
this
the
whole
street
was
on
fire
.
<EOS>
All
idea
of
preserving
their
property
was
therefore
abandoned
by
the
inhabitants
,
and
they
thought
only
of
saving
themselves
.
<EOS>
Hundreds
of
half
-
naked
persons
of
both
sexes
rushed
towards
Thames
-
street
in
search
of
a
place
of
refuge
.
<EOS>
The
scene
was
wholly
without
parallel
for
terror
.
<EOS>
Many
fires
had
occurred
in
London
,
but
none
that
raged
with
such
fierceness
as
the
present
conflagration
,
or
promised
to
be
so
generally
destructive
.
<EOS>
It
gathered
strength
and
fury
each
moment
,
now
rising
high
into
the
air
in
a
towering
sheet
of
flame
,
now
shooting
forward
like
an
enormous
dragon
vomiting
streams
of
fire
upon
its
foes
.
<EOS>
All
at
once
the
flames
changed
colour
,
and
were
partially
obscured
by
a
thick
black
smoke
.
<EOS>
A
large
warehouse
filled
with
resin
,
tar
,
and
other
combustible
matters
,
had
caught
fire
,
and
the
dense
vapour
proceeded
from
the
burning
pitch
.
<EOS>
But
it
cleared
off
in
a
few
minutes
,
and
the
flames
burnt
more
brightly
and
fiercely
than
ever
.
 
<EOS>
Up
to
this
time
,
none
of
the
civic
authorities
having
arrived
,
several
persons
set
off
to
give
information
of
the
calamity
to
the
lord
mayor
(
Sir
Thomas
Bludworth
)
,
and
the
other
magistrates
.
<EOS>
A
small
party
of
the
watch
were
on
the
spot
,
but
they
were
unable
to
render
any
effectual
assistance
.
<EOS>
As
the
conflagration
advanced
,
those
occupying
houses
in
its
track
quitted
them
,
and
left
their
goods
a
prey
to
the
numerous
plunderers
,
who
were
now
gathered
together
pursuing
their
vocation
like
unhallowed
beings
amid
the
raging
element
.
<EOS>
The
whole
presented
a
scene
of
the
wildest
alarm
,
confusion
,
and
license
.
<EOS>
Vociferations
,
oaths
,
shrieks
,
and
outcries
of
every
description
stunned
the
ear
.
<EOS>
Night
was
turned
into
day
.
<EOS>
The
awful
roaring
of
the
flames
was
ever
and
anon
broken
by
the
thundering
fall
of
some
heavy
roof
.
<EOS>
Flakes
of
fire
were
scattered
far
and
wide
by
the
driving
wind
,
carrying
destruction
wherever
they
alighted
,
and
spreading
the
conflagration
on
all
sides
,
till
it
seemed
like
a
vast
wedge
of
fire
driven
into
the
heart
of
the
city
.
<EOS>
And
thus
it
went
on
,
swallowing
up
all
before
it
,
like
an
insatiate
monster
,
and
roaring
for
very
joy
.
<EOS>
Meanwhile
,
the
incendiaries
had
met
,
as
concerted
,
near
the
foot
of
the
bridge
,
and
all
except
Philip
Grant
seemed
to
rejoice
in
the
progress
of
the
conflagration
.
<EOS>
Chowles
made
some
comment
upon
his
moody
looks
and
silence
,
and
whispered
in
his
ear
,
<EOS>
"
You
have
now
an
opportunity
of
retrieving
your
fortune
,
and
may
make
yourself
richer
than
your
son
.
<EOS>
Take
my
advice
,
and
do
not
let
it
pass
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Away
,
tempter
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Grant--"I
have
lighted
a
fire
within
my
breast
which
never
will
be
quenched
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Poh
,
poh
!
"
rejoined
Judith
;
"
do
not
turn
faint
-
hearted
now
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
The
fire
rages
fiercely
,
"
cried
Solomon
Eagle
,
gazing
at
the
vast
sheet
of
flame
overtopping
the
buildings
near
them
,
"
but
we
must
keep
it
alive
.
<EOS>
Take
the
remainder
of
the
fire
-
balls
,
Hubert
,
and
cast
them
into
some
of
the
old
houses
in
Crooked
-
lane
.
"
 
<EOS>
Hubert
prepared
to
obey
.
<EOS>
"
I
will
go
with
you
,
and
point
out
the
best
spots
,
"
said
Chowles
.
<EOS>
"
Our
next
place
of
rendezvous
must
be
the
vaults
beneath
Saint
Faith
's
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Agreed
!
"
exclaimed
the
others
.
<EOS>
And
they
again
separated
,
Hubert
and
Chowles
to
kindle
fresh
fires
,
and
Grant
to
watch
the
conflagration
at
a
distance
.
<EOS>
As
to
Solomon
Eagle
,
he
rushed
towards
the
scene
of
destruction
,
and
forcing
himself
into
the
midst
of
the
crowd
,
mounted
a
post
,
crying
in
a
loud
voice
:
 
<EOS>
"
I
told
you
a
second
judgment
would
come
upon
you
on
account
of
your
iniquities
,
and
you
now
find
that
I
avouched
the
truth
.
<EOS>
The
Lord
himself
hath
come
to
preach
to
you
,
as
he
did
in
the
fiery
mount
of
Sinai
,
and
a
terrible
exhortation
it
shall
be
,
and
one
ye
shall
not
easily
forget
.
<EOS>
This
fire
shall
not
be
quenched
till
the
whole
city
is
laid
prostrate
.
<EOS>
Ye
doubted
my
words
when
I
told
you
of
the
plague
;
ye
laughed
at
me
and
scoffed
me
;
but
ye
became
believers
in
the
end
,
and
now
conviction
is
forced
upon
you
a
second
time
.
<EOS>
You
will
vainly
attempt
to
save
your
dwellings
.
<EOS>
It
is
the
Lord
's
will
they
should
be
destroyed
,
and
man
's
efforts
to
avert
the
judgment
will
be
ineffectual
!
"
 
<EOS>
While
the
majority
listened
to
him
with
fear
and
trembling
,
and
regarded
him
as
a
prophet
,
a
few
took
the
opposite
view
of
the
question
,
and
coupling
his
appearance
with
the
sudden
outbreak
of
the
fire
,
were
disposed
to
regard
him
as
an
incendiary
.
<EOS>
They
therefore
cried
out--"He
has
set
fire
to
our
houses
.
<EOS>
Down
with
him
!
<EOS>
down
with
him
!
"
 
<EOS>
Other
voices
joined
in
the
outcry
,
and
an
attempt
was
made
to
carry
the
menace
into
effect
;
but
a
strong
party
rallied
round
the
enthusiast
,
who
derided
the
attempts
of
his
opponents
.
<EOS>
Planting
himself
on
the
steps
of
Saint
Margaret
's
Church
,
he
continued
to
pour
forth
exhortations
to
the
crowd
,
until
he
was
driven
into
the
interior
of
the
pile
by
the
fast
-
approaching
flames
.
<EOS>
The
whole
body
of
the
church
was
filled
with
poor
wretches
who
had
sought
refuge
within
it
,
having
brought
with
them
such
of
their
goods
as
they
were
able
to
carry
off
.
<EOS>
But
it
soon
became
evident
that
the
sacred
structure
would
be
destroyed
,
and
their
screams
and
cries
on
quitting
it
were
truly
heartrending
.
<EOS>
Solomon
Eagle
was
the
last
to
go
forth
,
and
he
delayed
his
departure
till
the
flames
burst
through
the
windows
.
<EOS>
Another
great
storehouse
of
oil
,
tar
,
cordage
,
hemp
,
flax
,
and
other
highly
inflammable
articles
,
adjoining
the
church
,
had
caught
fire
,
and
the
flames
speedily
reached
the
sacred
fabric
.
<EOS>
The
glass
within
the
windows
was
shivered
;
the
stone
bars
split
asunder
;
and
the
seats
and
other
woodwork
withinside
catching
fire
,
the
flames
ascended
to
the
roof
,
and
kindled
its
massive
rafters
.
 
<EOS>
Great
efforts
were
now
made
to
check
the
fire
.
<EOS>
A
few
of
the
cumbrous
and
unmanageable
engines
of
the
day
were
brought
to
the
spot
,
but
no
water
could
be
obtained
.
<EOS>
All
the
aqueducts
,
pipes
,
and
sluices
were
dry
,
and
the
Thames
water
-
tower
was
found
to
be
out
of
order
,
and
the
pipes
connected
with
it
empty
.
<EOS>
To
add
to
the
calamity
,
the
tide
was
out
,
and
it
was
not
only
difficult
,
but
dangerous
,
to
obtain
water
from
the
river
.
<EOS>
The
scanty
supply
served
rather
to
increase
than
check
the
flames
.
<EOS>
All
sorts
of
rumours
prevailed
among
the
crowd
.
<EOS>
It
could
no
longer
be
doubted
that
the
fire
,
which
kept
continually
breaking
out
in
fresh
places
,
was
the
work
of
incendiaries
,
and
it
was
now
supposed
that
it
must
have
been
caused
by
the
French
or
the
Dutch
,
with
both
of
which
nations
the
country
was
then
at
war
,
and
the
most
fearful
anticipations
that
it
was
only
the
prelude
of
a
sudden
invasion
were
entertained
.
<EOS>
Some
conjectured
it
might
be
the
work
of
the
Papists
;
and
it
chancing
that
a
professor
of
that
religion
was
discovered
among
the
mob
,
he
was
with
difficulty
rescued
from
their
fury
by
the
watch
,
and
conveyed
to
Newgate
.
<EOS>
Other
persons
,
who
were
likewise
suspected
of
being
incendiaries
,
were
conveyed
with
him
.
 
<EOS>
This
,
though
it
satisfied
the
multitude
,
did
not
check
the
progress
of
the
fire
,
nor
put
a
stop
to
the
terror
and
tumult
that
prevailed
.
<EOS>
Every
moment
a
fresh
family
were
turned
into
the
street
,
and
by
their
cries
added
to
the
confusion
.
<EOS>
The
plunderers
had
formed
themselves
into
bands
,
pillaging
everything
they
could
lay
hands
on
--
carrying
off
boxes
,
goods
,
and
coffers
,
breaking
into
cellars
,
broaching
casks
of
spirits
and
ale
,
and
emptying
flasks
of
wine
.
<EOS>
Hundreds
of
persons
who
did
not
join
in
the
pillage
made
free
with
the
contents
of
the
cellars
,
and
a
large
portion
of
the
concourse
was
soon
in
a
state
of
intoxication
.
 
<EOS>
Thus
,
wild
laughter
and
exclamations
of
frenzied
mirth
were
heard
amid
the
wailings
of
women
and
the
piteous
cries
of
children
.
<EOS>
It
was
indeed
dreadful
to
see
the
old
and
bed
-
ridden
forced
into
the
street
to
seek
a
home
where
they
could
;
nor
yet
less
dreadful
to
behold
others
roused
from
a
bed
of
sickness
at
dead
of
night
,
and
by
such
a
fearful
summons
.
<EOS>
Still
,
fanned
by
the
wind
,
and
fed
by
a
thousand
combustible
matters
,
the
fire
pressed
fearfully
on
,
devouring
all
before
it
,
and
increasing
in
fury
and
power
each
instant
;
while
the
drunken
mob
laughed
,
roared
,
shouted
,
and
rejoiced
beside
it
,
as
if
in
emulation
of
the
raging
flames
.
 
<EOS>
To
proceed
for
a
moment
to
Wood
Street
.
<EOS>
When
Philip
Grant
quitted
Leonard
in
the
manner
before
related
,
the
latter
followed
him
to
the
door
,
and
saw
him
disappear
in
the
gloom
.
<EOS>
But
he
did
not
attempt
pursuit
,
because
he
could
not
persuade
himself
that
any
danger
was
really
to
be
apprehended
.
<EOS>
He
thought
it
,
however
,
advisable
to
consult
with
Mr.
Bloundel
on
the
subject
,
and
accordingly
proceeded
to
his
room
and
roused
him
.
 
<EOS>
After
hearing
what
had
occurred
,
the
grocer
looked
very
grave
,
and
said
,
"
I
am
not
disposed
to
treat
this
matter
so
lightly
as
you
do
,
Leonard
.
<EOS>
I
fear
this
unhappy
man
has
some
desperate
design
in
view
.
<EOS>
What
it
is
<EOS>
I
cannot
--
dare
not
--
<EOS>
conjecture
.
<EOS>
But
I
confess
I
am
full
of
apprehension
.
<EOS>
I
shall
not
retire
to
rest
to
-
night
,
but
shall
hold
myself
in
readiness
to
act
in
whatever
way
may
be
necessary
,
You
had
better
go
forth
,
and
if
anything
occurs
,
give
notice
to
the
proper
authorities
.
<EOS>
We
have
not
now
such
a
lord
mayor
as
we
had
during
the
season
of
the
plague
.
<EOS>
The
firm
and
courageous
Sir
John
Lawrence
is
but
ill
succeeded
by
the
weak
and
vacillating
Sir
Thomas
Bludworth
.
<EOS>
Still
,
the
latter
may
be
equal
to
this
emergency
,
and
if
anything
happens
,
you
must
apply
to
him
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
will
follow
your
advice
implicitly
,
"
rejoined
Leonard
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
At
the
same
time
,
I
think
there
is
nothing
to
apprehend
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
better
to
err
on
the
safe
side
,
"
observed
the
grocer
;
"
you
can
not
then
reproach
yourself
with
want
of
caution
.
"
 
<EOS>
Shortly
after
this
,
Leonard
sallied
forth
,
and
having
determined
what
course
to
pursue
in
the
first
instance
,
proceeded
to
Saint
Paul
's
.
<EOS>
He
found
every
door
in
the
sacred
structure
fast
closed
.
<EOS>
Not
satisfied
with
this
,
he
knocked
at
the
great
northern
entrance
till
the
summons
was
answered
by
a
verger
,
and
stating
his
object
,
demanded
to
be
admitted
,
and
to
search
the
cathedral
,
as
well
as
Saint
Faith
's
.
<EOS>
The
verger
offered
no
objection
,
and
having
examined
the
old
building
throughout
,
without
discovering
any
traces
of
the
person
he
was
in
quest
of
,
Leonard
quitted
it
.
 
<EOS>
More
than
ever
convinced
that
he
was
right
in
his
supposition
,
and
that
no
danger
was
to
be
apprehended
,
he
was
about
to
return
home
,
when
the
idea
occurred
to
him
that
he
might
perhaps
find
Grant
at
the
plague
-
pit
in
Finsbury
Fields
,
and
he
accordingly
shaped
his
course
thither
.
<EOS>
A
long
period
had
elapsed
since
he
had
last
visited
the
melancholy
spot
,
and
it
was
not
without
much
painful
emotion
that
he
drew
near
the
vast
mound
covering
the
victims
of
the
pestilence
.
<EOS>
But
Grant
was
not
there
,
and
though
he
paced
round
and
round
the
dreary
inclosure
for
some
time
,
no
one
came
.
<EOS>
He
then
proceeded
to
the
lesser
plague
-
pit
,
and
kneeling
beside
the
grave
of
Amabel
,
bedewed
it
with
his
tears
.
 
<EOS>
As
he
arose
,
with
the
intention
of
returning
to
Wood
Street
,
he
observed
an
extraordinary
light
in
the
sky
a
little
to
the
left
,
evidently
produced
by
the
reflection
of
a
great
fire
in
that
direction
.
<EOS>
On
beholding
this
light
,
he
said
to
himself
,
"
Mr.
Bloundel
was
right
.
<EOS>
This
is
the
danger
with
which
the
city
is
threatened
.
<EOS>
It
is
now
too
late
to
avert
it
.
"
<EOS>
Determined
,
however
,
to
ascertain
the
extent
of
the
calamity
without
an
instant
's
loss
of
time
,
he
set
off
at
a
swift
pace
,
and
in
less
than
half
an
hour
reached
Fish
Street
Hill
,
and
stood
beside
the
conflagration
.
<EOS>
It
was
then
nearly
three
o'clock
,
and
a
vast
chasm
of
blackening
ruins
proclaimed
the
devastation
that
had
been
committed
.
<EOS>
Just
as
he
arrived
,
the
roof
of
Saint
Margaret
's
fell
in
with
a
tremendous
crash
,
and
for
a
few
minutes
the
fire
was
subdued
.
<EOS>
It
then
arose
with
greater
fury
than
ever
;
burst
out
on
both
sides
of
the
sacred
structure
,
and
caught
the
line
of
houses
leading
towards
London
Bridge
.
<EOS>
The
first
house
was
that
of
a
vintner
;
and
the
lower
part
of
the
premises
--
the
cellars
and
vaults
--
were
filled
with
wine
and
spirits
.
<EOS>
These
instantly
blazed
up
,
and
burnt
with
such
intensity
that
the
adjoining
habitation
was
presently
in
flames
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
know
who
hath
done
all
this
!
"
exclaimed
Leonard
,
half
involuntarily
,
as
he
gazed
on
the
work
of
destruction
.
 
<EOS>
"
Indeed
!
"
exclaimed
a
bystander
,
gazing
at
him
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Who
is
it?--the
Dutchman
or
the
Frenchman
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
Neither
,
"
replied
Leonard
,
who
at
that
moment
discovered
Grant
among
the
group
opposite
him
.
"
<EOS>
Yonder
stands
the
incendiary
!
"
  
<EOS>
III
.
 
<EOS>
PROGRESS
OF
THE
FIRE
.
 
<EOS>
Instantly
surrounded
and
seized
by
the
mob
,
Grant
offered
no
resistance
,
but
demanded
to
be
led
with
his
accuser
before
a
magistrate
.
<EOS>
Almost
as
the
words
were
uttered
,
a
cry
was
raised
that
the
lord
mayor
and
the
sheriffs
were
coming
along
East
-
cheap
,
and
the
prisoner
and
Leonard
were
immediately
hurried
off
in
that
direction
.
<EOS>
They
met
the
civic
authorities
at
the
corner
of
Saint
Clement's
-
lane
;
but
instead
of
paying
any
attention
to
them
,
the
lord
mayor
,
who
appeared
to
be
in
a
state
of
great
agitation
and
excitement
,
ordered
the
javelin
-
men
,
by
whom
he
was
attended
,
to
push
the
mob
aside
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
will
not
delay
your
worship
an
instant
,
"
cried
Leonard
;
"
but
this
dreadful
fire
is
the
work
of
incendiaries
,
of
whom
that
man
,
"
pointing
to
Grant
,
"
is
the
principal
.
<EOS>
I
pray
your
worship
to
question
him
.
<EOS>
He
may
have
important
revelations
to
make
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Eh
,
what
?
"
cried
the
lord
mayor
,
addressing
Grant
.
<EOS>
"
Is
it
true
you
are
an
incendiary
?
<EOS>
Who
are
your
accomplices
?
<EOS>
Where
are
they
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
none
,
"
replied
Grant
,
boldly--"I
deny
the
charge
altogether
.
<EOS>
Let
my
accuser
prove
it
if
he
can
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
hear
what
he
says
,
young
man
,
"
said
the
mayor
.
<EOS>
"
Did
you
see
him
set
fire
to
any
house
?
<EOS>
Did
you
find
any
fire
-
balls
on
his
person
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
did
not
,
"
replied
Leonard
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
searched
him
,
your
worship
,
"
cried
Chowles
,
who
was
among
the
bystanders
,
"
the
moment
he
was
seized
,
and
found
nothing
upon
him
.
<EOS>
It
is
a
false
and
malicious
charge
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
looks
like
it
,
I
must
say
,
"
<EOS>
replied
the
mayor
.
<EOS>
"
On
what
grounds
do
you
accuse
him
?
"
<EOS>
he
added
,
angrily
,
to
Leonard
.
 
<EOS>
"
On
these
,
"
replied
Leonard
.
"
<EOS>
He
came
to
me
three
hours
ago
,
and
confessed
that
he
had
a
desperate
design
against
the
safety
of
the
city
,
and
made
certain
proposals
to
me
,
to
which
I
would
not
listen
.
<EOS>
This
is
not
the
season
for
a
full
explanation
of
the
matter
.
<EOS>
But
I
pray
your
worship
,
as
you
value
the
welfare
of
the
city
,
to
have
him
secured
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
There
can
be
no
harm
in
that
,
"
replied
the
lord
mayor
.
<EOS>
"
His
appearance
is
decidedly
against
him
.
<EOS>
Let
him
be
taken
care
of
till
the
morrow
,
when
I
will
examine
further
into
the
matter
.
<EOS>
Your
name
and
place
of
abode
,
young
man
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
called
Leonard
Holt
,
and
my
business
is
that
of
a
grocer
,
in
Wood
-
street
,
"
was
the
reply
.
 
<EOS>
"
Enough
,
"
rejoined
the
mayor
.
<EOS>
"
Take
away
the
prisoner
.
<EOS>
I
will
hear
nothing
further
now
.
<EOS>
Lord
!
<EOS>
Lord
!
<EOS>
how
the
fire
rages
,
to
be
sure
.
<EOS>
We
shall
have
the
whole
city
burnt
down
,
if
we
do
not
take
care
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
That
we
shall
,
indeed
,
"
replied
Sir
Robert
Viner
,
one
of
the
sheriffs
,
"
unless
the
most
prompt
and
decisive
measures
are
immediately
adopted
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
What
would
you
recommend
?
"
cried
the
lord
mayor
,
despairingly
.
<EOS>
Sir
Robert
looked
perplexed
by
the
question
.
 
<EOS>
"
If
I
might
offer
an
opinion
,
"
interposed
Leonard
,
"
I
would
advise
your
worship
to
pull
down
all
the
houses
in
the
way
of
the
fire
,
as
the
only
means
of
checking
it
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Pull
down
the
houses
!
"
cried
the
lord
mayor
.
<EOS>
"
Who
ever
heard
of
such
an
idea
?
<EOS>
Why
,
that
would
be
worse
than
the
fire
.
<EOS>
No
,
no
;
that
will
never
do
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
The
young
man
is
in
the
right
,
"
observed
Sir
Joseph
Sheldon
,
the
other
sheriff
.
 
<EOS>
"
Well
,
well
--
we
shall
see
,
"
replied
the
mayor
.
<EOS>
"
But
we
are
losing
time
here
.
<EOS>
Forward
!
<EOS>
forward
!
"
 
<EOS>
And
while
Grant
was
borne
off
to
Newgate
by
a
guard
of
javelin
-
men
,
the
lord
mayor
and
his
company
proceeded
to
Fish
-
street
-
hill
,
where
the
whole
conflagration
burst
upon
them
.
<EOS>
The
moment
the
lord
mayor
appeared
,
he
was
beset
on
all
sides
by
hundreds
of
families
soliciting
his
protection
.
<EOS>
Others
came
to
give
him
the
alarming
intelligence
that
a
very
scanty
supply
of
water
only
could
be
obtained
,
and
that
already
two
engines
had
been
destroyed
,
while
the
firemen
who
worked
them
had
narrowly
escaped
with
life
.
<EOS>
Others
again
pressed
him
for
instructions
how
to
act
--
some
suggesting
one
plan
--
some
another,--and
being
of
a
weak
and
irresolute
character
,
and
utterly
unequal
to
a
fearful
emergency
like
the
present
,
he
was
completely
bewildered
.
<EOS>
Bidding
the
houseless
families
take
refuge
in
the
churches
,
he
ordered
certain
officers
to
attend
them
,
and
affecting
to
doubt
the
statement
of
those
who
affirmed
there
was
no
water
,
advised
them
to
go
to
the
river
,
where
they
would
find
plenty
.
<EOS>
In
vain
they
assured
him
the
tide
was
out
,
the
Thames
water
-
tower
empty
,
the
pipes
and
conduits
dry
.
<EOS>
He
would
not
believe
anything
of
the
sort
,
but
upbraiding
his
informants
with
neglect
,
bade
them
try
again
.
<EOS>
As
to
instructions
,
he
could
give
none
.
 
<EOS>
At
last
,
a
reluctant
assent
being
wrung
from
him
by
Sir
Joseph
Sheldon
,
that
a
house
should
be
pulled
down
,
as
suggested
by
Leonard
<EOS>
,
preparations
were
instantly
made
for
putting
the
design
into
execution
.
<EOS>
The
house
selected
was
about
four
doors
from
the
top
of
Fish
-
street
-
hill
,
and
belonged
to
a
birdcage
-
maker
.
<EOS>
But
they
encountered
an
unexpected
opposition
.
<EOS>
Having
ascertained
their
purpose
,
the
owner
fastened
his
doors
,
and
refused
to
admit
them
.
<EOS>
He
harangued
the
mob
from
one
of
the
upper
windows
,
and
producing
a
pistol
,
threatened
to
fire
upon
them
if
they
attempted
to
gain
a
forcible
entrance
.
<EOS>
The
officers
,
however
,
having
received
their
orders
,
were
not
to
be
intimidated
,
and
commenced
breaking
down
the
door
.
<EOS>
The
birdcage
-
maker
then
fired
,
but
without
effect
;
and
before
he
had
time
to
reload
,
the
door
had
yielded
to
the
combined
efforts
of
the
multitude
,
who
were
greatly
enraged
at
his
strange
conduct
.
<EOS>
They
rushed
upstairs
,
but
finding
he
had
locked
himself
in
the
room
,
left
him
there
,
supposing
him
secure
,
and
commenced
the
work
of
demolition
.
<EOS>
More
than
a
hundred
men
were
engaged
in
the
task
;
but
though
they
used
the
utmost
exertion
,
they
had
little
more
than
unroofed
the
building
,
when
a
cry
was
raised
by
those
in
the
street
that
the
house
was
on
fire
.
<EOS>
Alarmed
by
the
shout
,
they
descended
,
and
found
the
report
true
.
<EOS>
Flames
were
issuing
from
the
room
lately
occupied
by
the
birdcage
-
maker
.
<EOS>
The
wretch
had
set
fire
to
his
dwelling
,
and
then
made
his
escape
with
his
family
by
a
back
staircase
.
<EOS>
Thus
defeated
,
the
workmen
,
with
bitter
imprecations
on
the
fugitive
,
withdrew
,
and
Leonard
,
who
had
lent
his
best
assistance
to
the
task
,
repaired
to
the
lord
mayor
.
<EOS>
He
found
him
in
greater
consternation
than
ever
.
 
<EOS>
"
We
must
go
further
off
,
if
we
would
do
any
good
,
"
said
Leonard
;
"
and
as
the
present
plan
is
evidently
too
slow
,
we
must
have
recourse
to
gunpowder
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Gunpowder
!
"
exclaimed
the
lord
mayor
.
<EOS>
"
Would
you
blow
up
the
city
,
like
a
second
Guy
Fawkes
?
<EOS>
I
begin
to
suspect
you
are
one
of
the
incendiaries
yourself
,
young
man
.
<EOS>
Lord
,
Lord
!
<EOS>
what
will
become
of
us
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
If
your
worship
disapproves
of
my
suggestion
,
at
least
give
orders
what
is
to
be
done
,
"
rejoined
Leonard
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
done
all
I
can
,
"
replied
the
mayor
.
<EOS>
"
Who
are
you
that
talk
to
me
thus
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
told
your
worship
I
am
a
simple
tradesman
,
"
replied
Leonard
.
"
<EOS>
But
I
have
the
welfare
of
the
city
at
heart
,
and
I
can
not
stand
by
and
see
it
burnt
to
the
ground
without
an
effort
to
save
it
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Well
,
well
,
I
dare
say
you
mean
very
well
,
young
man
,
"
rejoined
the
lord
mayor
,
somewhat
pacified
.
"
<EOS>
But
do
n't
you
perceive
it
's
impossible
to
stop
such
a
fire
as
this
without
water
,
or
engines
.
<EOS>
I
'm
sure
I
would
willingly
lay
down
my
life
to
preserve
the
city
.
<EOS>
But
what
can
I
do?--what
can
any
man
do
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Much
may
be
done
if
there
is
resolution
to
attempt
it
,
"
returned
Leonard
.
<EOS>
"
I
would
recommend
your
worship
to
proceed
,
in
the
first
place
,
to
the
wharves
on
the
banks
of
the
Thames
,
and
cause
the
removal
of
the
wood
,
coal
,
and
other
combustible
matter
with
which
they
are
crowded
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Well
thought
of
,
"
cried
the
lord
mayor
.
<EOS>
"
I
will
go
thither
at
once
.
<EOS>
Do
you
stay
here
.
<EOS>
Your
advice
will
be
useful
.
<EOS>
I
will
examine
you
touching
the
incendiary
to
-
morrow
--
that
is
,
if
we
are
any
of
us
left
alive
,
which
I
do
n't
expect
.
<EOS>
Lord
,
Lord
!
<EOS>
what
will
become
of
us
?
"
<EOS>
And
with
many
similar
ejaculations
,
he
hurried
off
with
the
sheriffs
,
and
the
greater
part
of
his
attendants
,
and
taking
his
way
down
Saint
Michael's
-
lane
,
soon
reached
the
river
-
side
.
 
<EOS>
By
this
time
,
the
fire
had
approached
the
summit
of
Fish
-
street
-
hill
,
and
here
the
overhanging
stories
of
the
houses
coming
so
close
together
as
almost
to
meet
at
the
top
,
the
flames
speedily
caught
the
other
side
,
and
spread
the
conflagration
in
that
direction
.
<EOS>
Two
other
houses
were
likewise
discovered
to
be
on
fire
in
Crooked
-
lane
,
and
in
an
incredibly
short
space
the
whole
dense
mass
of
habitations
lying
at
the
west
side
of
Fish
-
street
-
hill
,
and
between
Crooked
-
lane
and
Eastcheap
,
were
in
flames
,
and
threatening
the
venerable
church
of
Saint
Michael
,
which
stood
in
the
midst
of
them
,
with
instant
destruction
.
<EOS>
To
the
astonishment
of
all
who
witnessed
it
,
the
conflagration
seemed
to
proceed
as
rapidly
against
the
wind
,
as
with
it
,
and
to
be
approaching
Thames
-
street
,
both
by
Pudding
-
lane
and
Saint
Michael's
-
lane
.
<EOS>
A
large
stable
,
filled
with
straw
and
hay
,
at
the
back
of
the
Star
Inn
,
in
Little
Eastcheap
,
caught
fire
,
and
carrying
the
conflagration
eastward
,
had
already
conveyed
it
as
far
as
Botolph
-
lane
.
 
<EOS>
It
chanced
that
a
poor
Catholic
priest
,
travelling
from
Douay
to
England
,
had
landed
that
night
,
and
taken
up
his
quarters
at
the
hotel
above
mentioned
.
<EOS>
The
landlord
,
who
had
been
roused
by
the
cries
of
fire
,
and
alarmed
by
the
rumours
of
incendiaries
,
immediately
called
to
mind
his
guest
,
and
dragging
him
from
his
room
,
thrust
him
,
half
-
naked
,
into
the
street
.
<EOS>
Announcing
his
conviction
that
the
poor
priest
was
an
incendiary
to
the
mob
without
,
they
seized
him
,
and
in
spite
of
his
protestations
and
explanations
,
which
,
being
uttered
in
a
foreign
tongue
,
they
could
not
comprehend
,
they
were
about
to
exercise
summary
punishment
upon
him
,
by
hanging
him
to
the
sign
-
post
before
the
landlord
's
door
,
when
they
were
diverted
from
their
dreadful
purpose
by
Solomon
Eagle
,
who
prevailed
upon
them
to
carry
him
to
Newgate
.
 
<EOS>
The
conflagration
had
now
assumed
so
terrific
a
character
that
it
appalled
even
the
stoutest
spectator
.
<EOS>
It
has
been
mentioned
,
that
for
many
weeks
previous
to
the
direful
calamity
,
the
weather
had
been
remarkably
dry
and
warm
,
a
circumstance
which
had
prepared
the
old
wooden
houses
,
abounding
in
this
part
of
the
city
,
for
almost
instantaneous
ignition
.
<EOS>
Added
to
this
,
if
the
incendiaries
themselves
had
deposited
combustible
materials
at
certain
spots
to
extend
the
conflagration
,
they
could
not
have
selected
better
places
than
accident
had
arranged
.
<EOS>
All
sorts
of
inflammable
goods
were
contained
in
the
shops
and
ware
-
houses,--oil
,
hemp
,
flax
,
pitch
,
tar
,
cordage
,
sugar
,
wine
,
and
spirits
;
and
when
any
magazine
of
this
sort
caught
fire
,
it
spread
the
conflagration
with
tenfold
rapidity
.
 
<EOS>
The
heat
of
the
flames
had
now
become
almost
insufferable
,
and
the
sparks
and
flakes
of
fire
fell
so
fast
and
thick
,
that
the
spectators
were
