I
charged
you
to
do
this
.
<EOS>
It
will
enable
you
to
act
as
I
have
directed
.
<EOS>
Promise
me
you
will
go
.
<EOS>
Promise
me
you
will
fulfil
my
injunctions
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
do
,
"
replied
Leonard
.
 
<EOS>
"
Enough
,
"
rejoined
Argentine
.
<EOS>
"
May
you
be
happy
with
Isabella
.
"
<EOS>
And
removing
his
hand
from
his
side
,
a
copious
effusion
of
blood
followed
,
and
,
sinking
backwards
,
he
expired
.
  
<EOS>
VII
.
 
<EOS>
THE
BURNING
OF
SAINT
PAUL'S.
 
<EOS>
Several
other
persons
having
by
this
time
come
up
,
the
body
of
Lord
Argentine
was
conveyed
to
Bishop
Kempe
's
Chapel
,
and
left
there
till
a
fitting
season
should
arrive
for
its
removal
.
<EOS>
Confounded
by
the
tragical
event
that
had
taken
place
,
Leonard
remained
with
his
eyes
fixed
upon
the
blood
-
stained
pavement
,
until
he
was
roused
by
an
arm
which
gently
drew
him
away
,
while
the
voice
of
the
Earl
of
Rochester
breathed
in
his
ear
,
"
This
is
a
sad
occurrence
,
Leonard
;
and
yet
it
is
most
fortunate
for
you
,
<EOS>
for
it
removes
the
only
obstacle
to
your
union
with
the
Lady
Isabella
.
<EOS>
You
see
how
fleeting
life
is
,
and
how
easily
we
may
be
deprived
of
it
.
<EOS>
I
tried
to
reason
Lord
Argentine
into
calmness
;
but
nothing
would
satisfy
him
except
my
blood
;
and
there
he
lies
,
though
not
by
my
hand
.
<EOS>
Let
his
fate
be
a
lesson
to
us
,
and
teach
us
to
live
in
charity
with
each
other
.
<EOS>
I
have
wronged
you
--
deeply
wronged
you
;
but
I
will
make
all
the
atonement
in
my
power
,
and
let
me
think
I
am
forgiven
.
"
 
<EOS>
The
blood
rushed
tumultuously
to
Leonard
's
heart
as
he
listened
to
what
the
earl
said
,
but
overcoming
his
feelings
of
aversion
by
a
powerful
effort
,
he
took
the
proffered
hand
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
do
forgive
you
my
lord
,
"
he
said
.
 
<EOS>
"
Those
words
have
removed
a
heavy
weight
from
my
soul
,
"
replied
Rochester
;
"
and
if
death
should
trip
up
my
heels
as
suddenly
as
he
did
his
who
perished
on
this
spot
,
I
shall
be
better
prepared
to
meet
him
.
<EOS>
And
now
let
me
advise
you
to
repair
to
Newgate
without
delay
,
and
see
the
wretched
man
,
and
obtain
the
document
from
him
.
<EOS>
The
fire
will
reach
the
gaol
ere
long
,
and
the
prisoners
must
of
necessity
be
removed
.
<EOS>
Amid
the
confusion
his
escape
might
be
easily
accomplished
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Recollect
,
my
lord
,
that
the
direful
conflagration
now
prevailing
without
is
owing
to
him
,
"
replied
Leonard
.
<EOS>
"
I
will
never
be
accessory
to
his
escape
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
And
yet
his
death
by
the
public
executioner
,
"
urged
Rochester
.
<EOS>
"
Think
of
its
effect
on
his
daughter
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Justice
must
take
its
course
,
"
rejoined
Leonard
.
<EOS>
"
I
would
not
aid
him
to
escape
if
he
were
my
own
father
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
In
that
case
,
nothing
more
is
to
be
said
,
"
replied
Rochester
.
<EOS>
"
But
at
all
events
,
see
him
as
quickly
as
you
can
.
<EOS>
I
would
accompany
you
,
but
my
duty
detains
me
here
.
<EOS>
When
you
return
from
your
errand
you
will
find
me
at
my
post
near
the
entrance
of
the
churchyard
in
front
of
Saint
Michael
's
le
Quern
;
that
is
,
if
I
am
not
beaten
from
it
.
<EOS>
Having
seen
the
father
,
your
next
business
must
be
to
seek
out
the
daughter
,
and
remove
her
from
this
dangerous
neighbourhood
.
<EOS>
You
have
heard
where
she
is
to
be
found
.
"
 
<EOS>
Upon
this
they
separated
,
Leonard
and
his
companions
quitting
the
cathedral
by
the
great
western
entrance
,
and
proceeding
towards
Paul's
-
alley
,
and
the
earl
betaking
himself
to
the
north
-
east
corner
of
the
churchyard
.
<EOS>
The
former
got
as
far
as
Ivy
-
lane
,
but
found
it
wholly
impassable
,
in
consequence
of
the
goods
and
furniture
with
which
it
was
blocked
up
.
<EOS>
They
were
,
therefore
,
obliged
to
return
to
the
precincts
of
the
cathedral
,
where
Blaize
,
who
was
greatly
terrified
by
what
he
had
seen
,
expressed
his
determination
of
quitting
them
,
and
hurried
back
to
the
sacred
pile
.
<EOS>
Leonard
and
the
farmer
next
essayed
to
get
up
Ave
Maria
-
lane
;
but
,
finding
that
also
impassable
,
they
made
for
Ludgate
,
and
,
after
a
long
delay
and
severe
struggle
,
got
through
the
portal
.
<EOS>
The
Old
Bailey
was
entirely
filled
with
persons
removing
their
goods
;
and
they
were
here
informed
,
to
their
great
dismay
,
that
the
conflagration
had
already
reached
Newgate
Market
,
which
was
burning
with
the
greatest
fury
,
and
was
at
that
moment
seizing
upon
the
gaol
.
<EOS>
No
one
,
however
,
in
answer
to
Leonard
's
inquiries
,
could
tell
him
what
had
become
of
the
prisoners
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
suppose
they
have
left
them
to
burn
,
"
observed
a
bystander
,
who
heard
the
question
with
a
malicious
look
;
"
and
it
is
the
best
way
of
getting
rid
of
them
.
<EOS>
"
Paying
no
attention
to
the
remark
,
nor
to
the
brutal
laugh
accompanying
it
,
Leonard
,
assisted
by
Wingfield
,
fought
his
way
through
the
crowd
till
he
reached
the
prison
.
<EOS>
The
flames
were
bursting
through
its
grated
windows
,
and
both
wings
,
as
well
as
the
massive
gate
connecting
them
,
were
on
fire
.
<EOS>
Regardless
of
the
risk
he
ran
,
Leonard
forced
his
way
to
the
lodge
-
door
,
where
two
turnkeys
were
standing
,
removing
their
goods
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
has
become
of
the
prisoners
?
"
he
asked
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
debtors
are
set
free
,
"
replied
the
turnkey
addressed
,
"
and
all
but
one
or
two
of
the
common
felons
are
removed
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
And
where
are
those
poor
creatures
?
"
<EOS>
cried
Leonard
,
horror
-
stricken
.
 
<EOS>
"
In
the
Stone
Hold
,
"
replied
the
turnkey
.
 
<EOS>
"
And
have
you
left
them
to
perish
there
?
"
demanded
Leonard
.
 
<EOS>
"
We
could
n't
help
it
,
"
rejoined
the
turnkey
.
<EOS>
"
It
would
have
been
risking
our
lives
to
venture
near
them
.
<EOS>
One
is
a
murderer
,
taken
in
the
fact
;
and
the
other
is
quite
as
bad
,
for
he
set
the
city
on
fire
;
so
its
right
and
fair
he
should
perish
by
his
own
contrivance
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Where
does
the
Stone
Hold
lie
?
"
<EOS>
cried
Leonard
,
in
a
tone
that
startled
the
turnkey
.
<EOS>
"
I
must
get
these
prisoners
out
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
ca
n't
<EOS>
,
I
tell
you
,
"
rejoined
the
turnkey
,
doggedly
.
<EOS>
"
They
're
burnt
to
a
cinder
by
this
time
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Give
me
your
keys
,
and
show
me
the
way
to
the
cell
,
"
cried
Leonard
,
authoritatively
.
<EOS>
"
I
will
at
least
attempt
to
save
them
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Well
,
if
you
're
determined
to
put
an
end
to
yourself
,
you
may
try
,
"
replied
the
turnkey
;
"
but
I
've
warned
you
as
to
what
you
may
expect
.
<EOS>
This
way
,
"
he
added
,
opening
a
door
,
from
which
a
thick
volume
of
smoke
issued
;
"
if
any
of
'em
's
alive
,
you
'll
soon
know
by
the
cries
.
"
<EOS>
And
,
as
if
in
answer
to
his
remark
,
a
most
terrific
shriek
at
that
moment
burst
on
their
ears
.
 
<EOS>
"
Here
are
the
keys
,
"
cried
the
turnkey
,
delivering
them
to
Leonard
.
<EOS>
"
You
are
not
going
too
?
"
<EOS>
he
added
,
as
Wingfield
pushed
past
him
.
"
<EOS>
A
couple
of
madmen
!
<EOS>
I
should
n't
wonder
if
they
were
incendiaries
.
"
 
<EOS>
Directed
by
the
cries
,
Leonard
pressed
forward
through
the
blinding
and
stifling
smoke
.
<EOS>
After
proceeding
about
twenty
yards
,
he
arrived
at
a
cross
passage
where
the
smoke
was
not
quite
so
dense
,
as
it
found
an
escape
through
a
small
grated
aperture
in
the
wall
.
<EOS>
And
here
a
horrible
sight
was
presented
to
him
.
<EOS>
At
the
further
extremity
of
this
passage
was
a
small
cell
,
from
which
the
cries
he
had
heard
issued
.
<EOS>
Not
far
from
it
the
stone
roof
had
fallen
in
,
and
from
the
chasm
<EOS>
thus
caused
the
flames
were
pouring
into
the
passage
.
<EOS>
Regardless
of
the
risk
he
ran
,
Leonard
dashed
forward
,
and
reaching
the
cell
,
beheld
Grant
,
still
living
,
but
in
such
a
dreadful
state
,
that
it
was
evident
his
sufferings
must
soon
be
ended
.
<EOS>
His
hair
and
beard
were
singed
close
to
his
head
and
face
,
and
his
flesh
was
blistered
,
blackened
,
and
scorched
to
the
bone
.
<EOS>
On
seeing
Leonard
,
he
uttered
a
hoarse
cry
,
and
attempted
to
speak
,
but
the
words
rattled
in
his
throat
.
<EOS>
He
then
staggered
forward
,
and
,
to
Leonard
's
inexpressible
horror
,
thrust
his
arms
through
the
bars
of
the
cage
,
which
were
literally
red
-
hot
.
<EOS>
Seeing
he
had
something
in
one
hand
,
though
he
could
not
unclose
his
fingers
,
Leonard
took
it
from
him
,
and
the
wretched
man
fell
backwards
.
<EOS>
At
this
moment
a
loud
crack
was
heard
in
the
wall
behind
.
<EOS>
Several
ponderous
stones
dropped
from
their
places
,
admitting
a
volume
of
flame
that
filled
the
whole
cell
,
and
disclosing
another
body
on
the
floor
,
near
which
lay
that
of
Grant
.
<EOS>
Horrified
by
the
spectacle
,
Leonard
staggered
off
,
and
,
catching
Wingfield
's
arm
,
sought
to
retrace
his
steps
.
<EOS>
This
was
no
easy
matter
,
the
smoke
being
so
dense
,
that
they
could
not
see
a
foot
before
them
,
and
was
obliged
to
feel
their
way
along
the
wall
.
<EOS>
On
arriving
at
the
cross
passage
,
Wingfield
would
fain
have
turned
off
to
the
right
,
but
Leonard
drew
him
forcibly
in
the
opposite
direction
;
and
most
fortunate
was
it
that
he
did
so
,
or
the
worthy
farmer
would
inevitably
have
perished
.
<EOS>
At
last
they
reached
the
lodge
,
and
sank
down
on
a
bench
from
exhaustion
.
 
<EOS>
"
So
,
my
masters
,
"
observed
the
turnkey
,
with
a
grim
smile
,
"
you
were
not
able
to
rescue
them
,
I
perceive
?
"
<EOS>
But
receiving
no
answer
,
he
added
,
"
<EOS>
Well
,
and
what
did
you
see
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
A
sight
that
would
have
moved
even
your
stony
heart
to
compassion
,
"
returned
Leonard
,
getting
up
and
quitting
the
lodge
.
<EOS>
Followed
by
Wingfield
,
and
scarcely
knowing
where
he
was
going
,
he
forced
his
way
through
the
crowd
,
and
dashing
down
Snow
-
hill
,
did
not
stop
till
he
reached
Holborn
Conduit
,
<EOS>
where
,
seizing
a
leathern
bucket
,
he
filled
it
with
water
,
and
plunged
his
head
into
it
.
<EOS>
Refreshed
by
the
immersion
,
he
now
glanced
at
the
document
committed
to
him
by
Grant
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
piece
of
parchment
,
and
showed
by
its
shrivelled
and
scorched
appearance
the
agony
which
its
late
possessor
must
have
endured
,
Leonard
did
not
open
it
,
but
thrust
it
with
a
shudder
into
his
doublet
.
 
<EOS>
Meditating
on
the
strange
and
terrible
events
that
had
just
occurred
,
Leonard
's
thoughts
involuntarily
wandered
to
the
Lady
Isabella
,
whose
image
appeared
to
him
like
a
bright
star
shining
on
troubled
waters
,
and
for
the
first
time
venturing
to
indulge
in
a
hope
that
she
might
indeed
be
his
,
he
determined
immediately
to
proceed
in
search
of
her
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
now
high
noon
,
but
the
mid
-
day
sun
was
scarcely
visible
,
or
not
visible
at
all
;
as
it
struggled
through
the
masses
of
yellow
vapour
it
looked
red
as
blood
.
<EOS>
Bands
of
workmen
were
demolishing
houses
on
the
western
side
of
Fleet
Ditch
,
and
casting
the
rubbish
into
the
muddy
sluice
before
them
,
by
which
means
it
was
confidently
but
vainly
hoped
that
the
progress
of
the
fire
would
be
checked
.
<EOS>
Shaping
their
course
along
the
opposite
side
of
the
ditch
,
and
crossing
to
Fleet
Bridge
,
Leonard
and
his
companion
passed
through
Salisbury
-
court
to
Whitefriars
,
and
taking
a
boat
,
directed
the
waterman
to
land
them
at
Puddle
Dock
.
<EOS>
The
river
was
still
covered
with
craft
of
every
description
laden
with
goods
,
and
Baynard
's
Castle
,
an
embattled
stone
structure
of
great
strength
and
solidity
,
built
at
the
beginning
of
the
fifteenth
century
on
the
site
of
another
castle
as
old
as
the
Conquest
,
being
now
wrapped
in
flames
from
foundation
to
turret
,
offered
a
magnificent
spectacle
.
<EOS>
From
this
point
the
four
ascents
leading
to
the
cathedral
,
namely
,
Addle
-
hill
,
Saint
Bennet's
-
hill
,
Saint
Peter's
-
hill
,
and
Lambert
-
hill
,
with
all
their
throng
of
habitations
,
were
burning
--
the
black
lines
of
ruined
walls
standing
in
bold
relief
against
the
white
sheet
of
flame
.
<EOS>
Billows
of
fire
rolled
upwards
every
moment
towards
Saint
Paul
's
,
and
threatened
it
with
destruction
.
 
<EOS>
Landing
at
the
appointed
place
<EOS>
Leonard
and
his
companion
ascended
Saint
Andrew's
-
hill
,
and
,
proceeding
along
Carter
-
lane
,
soon
gained
the
precincts
of
the
cathedral
.
<EOS>
Here
the
whole
mass
of
habitations
on
the
summit
of
Saint
Bennet's
-
hill
extending
from
the
eastern
,
end
of
Carter
-
lane
to
Distaff
-
lane
,
was
on
fire
,
and
the
flames
were
dashed
by
the
fierce
wind
against
the
south
-
east
corner
of
the
cathedral
.
<EOS>
A
large
crowd
was
collected
at
this
point
,
and
great
efforts
were
made
to
save
the
venerable
pile
,
but
Leonard
saw
that
its
destruction
was
inevitable
.
<EOS>
Forcing
a
way
through
the
throng
with
his
companion
,
they
reached
Doctor
Hodges
's
residence
at
the
corner
of
Watling
-
street
,
and
Leonard
,
without
waiting
to
knock
,
tried
the
door
,
which
yielded
to
his
touch
.
<EOS>
The
habitation
was
empty
,
and
from
the
various
articles
scattered
about
it
was
evident
its
inmates
must
have
fled
with
the
greatest
precipitation
.
<EOS>
Alarmed
at
this
discovery
,
Leonard
rushed
forth
with
Wingfield
,
and
sought
to
ascertain
from
the
crowd
without
whither
Doctor
Hodges
was
gone
,
but
could
learn
nothing
more
than
that
he
had
departed
with
his
whole
household
a
few
hours
before
.
<EOS>
At
last
it
occurred
to
him
that
he
might
obtain
some
information
from
the
Earl
of
Rochester
,
and
he
was
about
to
cross
to
the
other
side
of
the
churchyard
,
when
he
was
arrested
by
a
simultaneous
cry
of
horror
from
the
assemblage
.
<EOS>
Looking
upwards
,
for
there
he
saw
the
general
gaze
directed
,
he
perceived
that
the
scaffolding
around
the
roof
and
tower
of
the
cathedral
had
kindled
,
and
was
enveloping
the
whole
upper
part
of
the
fabric
in
a
network
of
fire
.
<EOS>
Flames
were
likewise
bursting
from
the
belfry
,
and
from
the
lofty
pointed
windows
below
it
,
flickering
and
playing
round
the
hoary
buttresses
,
and
disturbing
the
numerous
jackdaws
that
built
in
their
timeworn
crevices
,
and
now
flew
screaming
forth
.
<EOS>
As
Leonard
gazed
at
the
summit
of
the
tower
,
be
discerned
through
the
circling
eddies
of
smoke
that
enveloped
it
the
figure
of
Solomon
Eagle
standing
on
the
top
of
the
battlements
and
waving
his
staff
,
and
almost
fancied
he
could
hear
his
voice
.
<EOS>
After
remaining
in
this
perilous
situation
for
some
minutes
,
as
if
to
raise
anxiety
for
his
safety
to
the
highest
pitch
,
the
enthusiast
sprang
upon
a
portion
of
the
scaffolding
that
was
only
partly
consumed
,
and
descended
from
pole
to
pole
,
regardless
whether
burning
or
not
,
with
marvellous
swiftness
,
and
apparently
without
injury
.
<EOS>
Alighting
on
the
roof
,
he
speeded
to
the
eastern
extremity
of
the
fane
,
and
there
commenced
his
exhortations
to
the
crowd
below
.
 
<EOS>
It
now
became
evident
also
,
from
the
strange
roaring
noise
proceeding
from
the
tower
,
that
the
flames
were
descending
the
spiral
staircase
,
and
forcing
their
way
through
some
secret
doors
or
passages
to
the
roof
.
<EOS>
Determined
to
take
one
last
survey
of
the
interior
of
the
cathedral
before
its
destruction
,
which
he
now
saw
was
inevitable
,
Leonard
motioned
to
Wingfield
,
and
forcing
his
way
through
the
crowd
,
which
was
now
considerably
thinned
,
entered
the
southern
door
.
<EOS>
He
had
scarcely
gained
the
middle
of
the
transept
when
the
door
opened
behind
him
,
and
two
persons
,
whom
,
even
in
the
brief
glimpse
he
caught
of
them
,
he
knew
to
be
Chowles
and
Judith
,
darted
towards
the
steps
leading
to
Saint
Faith
's
.
<EOS>
They
appeared
to
be
carrying
a
large
chest
,
but
Leonard
was
too
much
interested
in
what
was
occurring
to
pay
much
attention
to
them
.
<EOS>
There
were
but
few
persons
besides
himself
and
his
companion
within
the
cathedral
,
and
these
few
were
chiefly
booksellers
'
porters
,
who
were
hurrying
out
of
Saint
Faith
's
in
the
utmost
trepidation
.
<EOS>
By
-
and
-
by
,
these
were
gone
,
and
they
were
alone
--
alone
within
that
vast
structure
,
and
at
such
a
moment
.
<EOS>
Their
situation
,
though
perilous
,
was
one
that
awakened
thrilling
and
sublime
emotions
.
<EOS>
The
cries
of
the
multitude
,
coupled
with
the
roaring
of
the
conflagration
,
resounded
from
without
,
while
the
fierce
glare
of
the
flames
lighted
up
the
painted
windows
at
the
head
of
the
choir
with
unwonted
splendour
.
<EOS>
Overhead
was
heard
a
hollow
rumbling
noise
like
that
of
distant
thunder
,
which
continued
for
a
short
time
,
while
fluid
streams
of
smoke
crept
through
the
mighty
rafters
of
the
roof
,
and
gradually
filled
the
whole
interior
of
the
fabric
with
vapour
.
<EOS>
Suddenly
a
tremendous
cracking
was
heard
,
as
if
the
whole
pile
were
tumbling
in
pieces
.
<EOS>
So
appalling
was
this
sound
,
that
Leonard
and
his
companion
would
have
fled
,
but
they
were
completely
transfixed
by
terror
.
 
<EOS>
While
they
were
in
this
state
,
the
flames
,
which
had
long
been
burning
in
secret
,
burst
through
the
roof
at
the
other
end
of
the
choir
,
and
instantaneously
spread
over
its
whole
expanse
.
<EOS>
At
this
juncture
,
a
cry
of
wild
exultation
was
heard
in
the
great
northern
gallery
,
and
looking
up
,
Leonard
beheld
Solomon
Eagle
,
hurrying
with
lightning
swiftness
around
it
,
and
shouting
in
tones
of
exultation
,
"
My
words
have
come
to
pass
--
it
burns
--
it
burns
--
and
will
be
utterly
consumed
!
"
 
<EOS>
The
vociferations
of
the
enthusiast
were
answered
by
a
piercing
cry
from
below
,
proceeding
from
Blaize
,
who
at
that
moment
rushed
from
the
entrance
of
Saint
Faith
's
.
<EOS>
On
seeing
the
porter
,
Leonard
shouted
to
him
,
and
the
poor
fellow
hurried
towards
him
.
<EOS>
At
this
juncture
,
a
strange
hissing
sound
was
heard
,
as
if
a
heavy
shower
of
rain
were
descending
upon
the
roof
,
and
through
the
yawning
gap
over
the
choir
there
poured
a
stream
of
molten
lead
of
silvery
brightness
.
<EOS>
Nothing
can
be
conceived
more
beautiful
than
this
shining
yet
terrible
cascade
,
which
descended
with
momentarily
increasing
fury
,
sparkling
,
flashing
,
hissing
,
and
consuming
all
before
it
.
<EOS>
All
the
elaborately
carved
woodwork
and
stalls
upon
which
it
fell
were
presently
in
flames
.
<EOS>
Leonard
and
his
companions
now
turned
to
fly
,
but
they
had
scarcely
moved
a
few
paces
when
another
fiery
cascade
burst
through
the
roof
near
the
great
western
entrance
,
for
which
they
were
making
,
flooding
the
aisles
and
plashing
against
the
massive
columns
.
<EOS>
At
the
same
moment
,
too
,
a
third
stream
began
to
fall
over
the
northern
transept
,
not
far
from
where
Blaize
stood
,
and
a
few
drops
of
the
burning
metal
reaching
him
,
caused
him
to
utter
the
most
fearful
outcries
.
<EOS>
Seriously
alarmed
,
Leonard
and
Wingfield
now
rushed
to
one
of
the
monuments
in
the
northern
aisle
,
and
hastily
clambering
it
,
reached
a
window
,
which
they
burst
open
.
<EOS>
Blaize
followed
them
,
but
not
without
receiving
a
few
accidental
plashes
from
the
fiery
torrents
,
which
elicited
from
him
the
most
astounding
yells
.
<EOS>
Having
helped
him
to
climb
the
monument
,
Leonard
pushed
him
through
the
window
after
Wingfield
,
and
then
cast
his
eye
round
the
building
before
he
himself
descended
.
<EOS>
The
sight
was
magnificent
in
the
extreme
.
<EOS>
Prom
the
flaming
roof
<EOS>
three
silvery
cascades
descended
.
<EOS>
The
choir
was
in
flame
,
and
a
glowing
stream
like
lava
was
spreading
over
the
floor
,
and
slowly
trickling
down
the
steps
leading
to
the
body
of
the
church
.
<EOS>
The
transepts
and
the
greater
part
of
the
nave
were
similarly
flooded
.
<EOS>
Above
the
roar
of
the
flames
and
the
hissing
plash
of
the
descending
torrents
,
was
heard
the
wild
laughter
of
Solomon
Eagle
.
<EOS>
Perceiving
him
in
one
of
the
arcades
of
the
southern
gallery
,
Leonard
shouted
to
him
to
descend
,
and
make
good
his
escape
while
there
was
yet
time
,
adding
that
in
a
few
moments
it
would
be
too
late
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
shall
never
quit
it
more
,
"
rejoined
the
enthusiast
,
in
a
voice
of
thunder
,
"
but
shall
perish
with
the
fire
I
have
kindled
.
<EOS>
No
monarch
on
earth
ever
lighted
a
nobler
funeral
pyre
.
"
 
<EOS>
And
as
Leonard
passed
through
the
window
,
he
disappeared
along
the
gallery
.
<EOS>
Breaking
through
the
crowd
collected
round
Wingfield
and
Blaize
,
and
calling
to
them
to
follow
him
,
Leonard
made
his
way
to
the
north
-
east
of
the
churchyard
,
where
he
found
a
large
assemblage
of
persons
,
in
the
midst
of
which
were
the
king
,
the
Duke
of
York
,
Rochester
,
Arlington
,
and
many
others
.
<EOS>
As
Leonard
advanced
,
Charles
discerned
him
amid
the
crowd
,
and
motioned
him
to
come
forward
.
<EOS>
A
passage
was
then
cleared
,
for
him
,
through
which
Wingfield
and
Blaize
,
who
kept
close
beside
him
,
were
permitted
to
pass
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
glad
to
find
no
harm
has
happened
to
you
,
friend
,
"
said
Charles
,
as
he
approached
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Rochester
informed
me
you
were
gone
to
Newgate
,
and
as
the
gaol
had
been
burnt
down
,
I
feared
you
might
have
met
with
the
same
mishap
.
<EOS>
I
now
regret
that
I
did
not
adopt
your
plan
,
but
it
may
not
be
yet
too
late
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
not
too
late
to
save
a
portion
of
your
city
,
sire
,
"
replied
Leonard
;
"
but
,
alas
!
<EOS>
how
much
is
gone
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
so
,
"
replied
the
king
,
mournfully
.
 
<EOS>
Further
conversation
was
here
interrupted
by
the
sudden
breaking
out
of
the
fire
from
the
magnificent
rose
window
of
the
cathedral
,
the
effect
of
which
,
being
extraordinarily
fine
,
attracted
the
monarch
's
attention
.
<EOS>
By
this
time
Solomon
Eagle
had
again
ascended
the
roof
,
and
making
his
way
to
the
eastern
extremity
,
clasped
the
great
stone
cross
that
terminated
it
with
his
left
hand
,
while
with
his
right
he
menaced
the
king
and
his
party
,
uttering
denunciations
that
were
lost
in
the
terrible
roar
prevailing
around
him
.
<EOS>
The
flames
now
raged
with
a
fierceness
wholly
inconceivable
,
considering
the
material
they
had
to
work
upon
.
<EOS>
The
molten
lead
poured
down
in
torrents
,
and
not
merely
flooded
the
whole
interior
of
the
fabric
,
but
ran
down
in
a
wide
and
boiling
stream
almost
as
far
as
the
Thames
,
consuming
everything
in
its
way
,
and
rendering
the
very
pavements
red
-
hot
.
<EOS>
Every
stone
,
spout
,
and
gutter
in
the
sacred
pile
,
of
which
there
were
some
hundreds
,
added
to
this
fatal
shower
,
and
scattered
destruction
far
and
wide
;
nor
will
this
be
wondered
at
when
it
is
considered
that
the
quantity
of
lead
thus
melted
covered
a
space
of
no
less
than
six
acres
.
<EOS>
Having
burned
with
incredible
fury
and
fierceness
for
some
time
,
the
whole
roof
of
the
sacred
structure
fell
in
at
once
,
and
with
a
crash
heard
at
an
amazing
distance
.
<EOS>
After
an
instant
's
pause
,
the
flames
burst
forth
from
every
window
in
the
fabric
,
producing
such
an
intensity
of
heat
,
that
the
stone
pinnacles
,
transom
beams
,
and
mullions
split
and
cracked
with
a
sound
like
volleys
of
artillery
,
shivering
and
flying
in
every
direction
.
<EOS>
The
whole
interior
of
the
pile
was
now
one
vast
sheet
of
flame
,
which
soared
upwards
,
and
consumed
even
the
very
stones
.
<EOS>
Not
a
vestige
of
the
reverend
structure
was
left
untouched
--
its
bells
--
its
plate
--
its
woodwork
--
its
monuments
--
its
mighty
pillars
--
its
galleries
--
its
chapels
--
all
,
all
were
destroyed
.
<EOS>
The
fire
raged
throughout
all
that
night
and
the
next
day
,
till
it
had
consumed
all
but
the
mere
shell
,
and
rendered
the
venerable
cathedral--"one
of
the
most
ancient
pieces
of
piety
in
the
Christian
world"--to
use
the
words
of
Evelyn
,
a
heap
of
ruin
and
ashes
.
  
<EOS>
VIII
.
 
<EOS>
HOW
LEONARD
RESCUED
THE
LADY
ISABELLA
.
 
<EOS>
The
course
of
events
having
been
somewhat
anticipated
in
the
last
chapter
,
it
will
now
be
necessary
to
return
to
an
earlier
stage
in
the
destruction
of
the
cathedral
,
namely
,
soon
after
the
furious
bursting
forth
of
the
flames
from
the
great
eastern
windows
.
<EOS>
While
Leonard
,
in
common
with
the
rest
of
the
assemblage
,
was
gazing
at
this
magnificent
spectacle
,
he
heard
a
loud
cry
of
distress
behind
him
,
and
turning
at
the
sound
,
beheld
Doctor
Hodges
rush
forth
from
an
adjoining
house
,
the
upper
part
of
which
was
on
fire
,
almost
in
a
state
of
distraction
.
<EOS>
An
elderly
man
and
woman
,
and
two
or
three
female
servants
,
all
of
whom
were
crying
as
loud
as
himself
,
followed
him
.
<EOS>
But
their
screams
fell
on
indifferent
ears
,
for
the
crowd
had
become
by
this
time
too
much
accustomed
to
such
appeals
to
pay
any
particular
attention
to
them
.
<EOS>
Leonard
,
however
,
instantly
rushed
towards
the
doctor
,
and
anxiously
inquired
what
was
the
matter
;
the
latter
was
so
bewildered
that
he
did
not
recognise
the
voice
of
the
speaker
,
but
gazing
up
at
the
house
with
an
indescribable
anguish
,
cried
,
"
Merciful
God
!
<EOS>
the
flames
have
by
this
time
reached
her
room
--
she
will
be
burned
--
horror
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
Who
will
be
burned
?
"
<EOS>
cried
Leonard
,
seizing
his
arm
,
and
gazing
at
him
with
a
look
of
apprehension
and
anguish
equal
to
his
own--"Not
the
Lady
Isabella
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
Isabella
,
"
replied
Hodges
,
regarding
the
speaker
,
and
for
the
first
time
perceiving
by
whom
he
was
addressed
.
<EOS>
"
Not
a
moment
is
to
be
lost
if
you
would
save
her
from
a
terrible
death
.
<EOS>
She
was
left
in
a
fainting
state
in
one
of
the
upper
rooms
by
a
female
attendant
,
who
deserted
her
mistress
to
save
herself
.
<EOS>
The
staircase
is
on
fire
,
or
I
myself
would
have
saved
her
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
A
ladder
!
<EOS>
a
ladder
!
"
cried
Leonard
.
 
<EOS>
"
Here
is
one
,
"
cried
Wingfield
,
pointing
to
one
propped
against
an
adjoining
house
.
<EOS>
And
in
another
moment
,
by
the
combined
efforts
of
the
crowd
,
the
ladder
was
brought
and
placed
against
the
burning
building
.
 
<EOS>
"
Which
is
the
window
?
<EOS>
"
cried
Leonard
.
 
<EOS>
"
That
on
the
right
,
on
the
second
floor
,
"
replied
Hodges
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Gracious
Heaven
!
<EOS>
the
flames
are
bursting
from
it
.
"
 
<EOS>
But
Leonard
's
foot
was
now
on
the
ladder
,
and
rushing
up
with
inconceivable
swiftness
,
he
plunged
through
the
window
regardless
of
the
flame
.
<EOS>
All
those
who
witnessed
this
daring
deed
,
regarded
his
destruction
as
certain
,
and
even
Hodges
gave
him
up
for
lost
.
<EOS>
But
the
next
moment
he
appeared
at
the
window
,
bearing
the
fainting
female
form
in
his
arms
,
and
with
extraordinary
dexterity
obtaining
a
firm
footing
and
hold
of
the
ladder
,
descended
in
safety
.
<EOS>
The
shout
that
burst
from
such
part
of
the
assemblage
as
had
witnessed
this
achievement
,
and
its
successful
termination
,
attracted
the
king
's
attention
,
and
he
inquired
the
cause
of
the
clamour
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
will
ascertain
it
for
your
majesty
,
"
replied
Rochester
,
and
proceeding
to
the
group
,
he
learnt
,
to
his
great
satisfaction
,
what
had
occurred
.
<EOS>
Having
gained
this
intelligence
,
he
flew
back
to
the
king
,
and
briefly
explained
the
situation
of
the
parties
.
<EOS>
Doctor
Hodges
,
it
appeared
,
had
just
removed
to
the
house
in
question
,
which
belonged
to
one
of
his
patients
,
as
a
temporary
asylum
,
and
the
Lady
Isabella
had
accompanied
him
.
<EOS>
She
was
in
the
upper
part
of
the
house
when
the
fire
broke
out
,
and
was
so
much
terrified
that
she
swooned
away
,
in
which
condition
her
attendant
left
her
;
nor
was
the
latter
so
much
to
blame
as
might
appear
,
for
the
stairs
were
burning
at
the
time
,
and
a
moment
's
delay
would
have
endangered
her
own
safety
.
 
<EOS>
"
Fate
,
indeed
,
seems
to
have
brought
these
young
persons
together
,
"
replied
Charles
,
as
he
listened
to
Rochester
's
recital
,
who
took
this
opportunity
of
acquainting
him
with
Lord
Argentine
's
dying
injunctions
,
"
and
it
would
be
a
pity
to
separate
them
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
sure
your
majesty
has
no
such
intention
,
"
said
Rochester
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
will
see
,
"
rejoined
the
monarch
.
<EOS>
And
,
as
he
spoke
,
he
turned
his
horse
's
head
,
and
moved
towards
the
spot
where
Leonard
was
kneeling
beside
Isabella
,
and
supporting
her
.
<EOS>
Some
restoratives
having
been
applied
by
Doctor
Hodges
,
she
had
regained
her
sensibility
,
and
was
murmuring
her
thanks
to
her
deliverer
.
 
<EOS>
"
She
has
not
lost
her
beauty
,
I
perceive
,
"
cried
Charles
,
gazing
at
her
with
admiration
,
and
feeling
something
of
his
former
passion
revive
within
his
breast
.
 
<EOS>
"
Your
majesty
,
I
trust
,
will
not
mar
their
happiness
,
"
said
Rochester
,
noticing
the
monarch
's
libertine
look
with
uneasiness
.
<EOS>
"
Remember
,
you
owe
your
life
to
that
young
man
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
And
I
will
pay
the
debt
royally
,
"
replied
Charles
;
"
I
will
give
him
permission
to
marry
her
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Your
majesty
's
permission
is
scarcely
needed
,
"
muttered
Rochester
.
 
<EOS>
"
There
you
are
wrong
,
my
lord
,
"
replied
the
king
.
<EOS>
"
She
is
now
my
ward
,
and
I
can
dispose
of
her
in
marriage
as
I
please
;
nor
will
I
so
dispose
of
her
except
to
her
equal
in
rank
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
discern
your
majesty
's
gracious
intentions
,
"
replied
Rochester
,
gratefully
inclining
his
head
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
almost
forget
my
deliverer
's
name
,
"
whispered
Charles
,
with
a
smile
,
"
but
it
is
of
no
consequence
,
since
he
will
so
speedily
change
it
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
His
name
is
Leonard
Holt
,
"
replied
Rochester
,
in
the
same
tone
.
 
<EOS>
"
Ah!--true
,
"
returned
the
king
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
What
ho
!
<EOS>
good
Master
Leonard
Holt
,
"
he
added
,
addressing
the
young
man
,
"
commit
the
Lady
Isabella
Argentine
to
the
care
of
our
worthy
friend
Doctor
Hodges
for
a
moment
,
and
stand
up
before
me
.
"
<EOS>
His
injunctions
being
complied
with
,
he
continued
,
"
The
Lady
Isabella
Argentine
<EOS>
and
I
owe
our
lives
to
you
,
and
we
must
both
evince
our
gratitude
--
<EOS>
she
by
devoting
that
life
,
which
,
if
I
am
not
misinformed
,
she
will
be
right
willing
to
do
,
to
you
,
and
I
by
putting
you
in
a
position
to
unite
yourself
to
her
.
<EOS>
The
title
of
Argentine
has
been
this
day
extinguished
by
most
unhappy
circumstances
;
I
therefore
confer
the
title
on
you
,
and
here
in
this
presence
create
you
Baron
Argentine
,
of
Argentine
,
in
Staffordshire
.
<EOS>
Your
patent
shall
be
made
out
with
all
convenient
despatch
,
and
with
it
you
shall
receive
the
hand
of
the
sole
representative
of
that
ancient
and
noble
house
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Your
majesty
overwhelms
me
,
"
replied
Leonard
,
falling
on
his
knee
and
pressing
the
king
's
hand
,
which
was
kindly
extended
towards
him
,
to
his
lips
.
<EOS>
"
I
can
scarcely
persuade
myself
I
am
not
in
a
dream
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
will
soon
awaken
to
the
sense
of
the
joyful
reality
,
"
returned
the
king
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Have
I
not
now
discharged
my
debt
?
"
<EOS>
he
added
to
Rochester
.
 
<EOS>
"
Right
royally
,
indeed
,
my
liege
,
"
replied
the
earl
,
in
a
tone
of
unaffected
emotion
.
<EOS>
"
My
lord
,
"
he
added
,
grasping
Leonard
's
hand
,
"
I
sincerely
congratulate
you
on
your
newly
-
acquired
dignities
,
nor
less
in
the
happiness
that
awaits
you
there
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
If
I
do
not
answer
you
fittingly
,
my
lord
,
"
replied
the
new
-
made
peer
,
"
it
is
not
because
I
do
not
feel
your
kindness
.
<EOS>
But
my
brain
reels
.
<EOS>
Pray
Heaven
<EOS>
my
senses
may
not
desert
me
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
must
not
forget
the
document
you
obtained
this
morning
,
my
lord
,
"
replied
Rochester
,
endeavouring
to
divert
his
thoughts
into
a
new
channel
.
<EOS>
"
The
proper
moment
for
consulting
it
may
have
arrived
.
"
 
<EOS>
Lord
Argentine
,
for
we
shall
henceforth
give
him
his
title
,
thrust
his
hand
into
his
doublet
,
and
drew
forth
the
parchment
.
<EOS>
He
opened
it
,
and
endeavoured
to
read
it
,
but
a
mist
swam
before
his
eyes
.
 
<EOS>
"
Let
me
look
at
it
,
"
said
Rochester
,
taking
it
from
him
.
<EOS>
"
It
is
a
deed
of
gift
,
"
he
said
,
after
glancing
at
it
for
a
moment
,
"
from
the
late
Lord
Argentine
--
I
mean
the
elder
baron
--
of
a
large
estate
in
Yorkshire
,
which
he
possessed
in
right
of
his
wife
,
to
you
,
my
lord
,
here
described
as
Leonard
Holt
,
provided
you
shall
marry
the
Lady
Isabella
Argentine
.
<EOS>
Another
piece
of
good
fortune
.
<EOS>
Again
and
again
,
I
congratulate
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
And
now
,
"
said
Charles
,
"
other
and
less
pleasing
matters
claim
our
attention
.
<EOS>
Let
the
Lady
Isabella
be
removed
,
under
the
charge
of
Doctor
Hodges
,
to
Whitehall
,
where
apartments
shall
be
provided
for
her
at
once
,
together
with
fitting
attendants
,
and
where
she
can
remain
till
this
terrible
conflagration
is
<EOS>
over
which
,
I
trust
,
soon
will
be
,
when
I
will
no
longer
delay
her
happiness
,
but
give
her
away
in
person
.
<EOS>
Chiffinch
,
"
he
added
to
the
chief
page
,
"
see
all
this
is
carried
into
effect
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
will
,
my
liege
,
and
right
willingly
,
"
replied
Chiffinch
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
would
send
you
with
her
,
my
lord
,
"
pursued
Charles
to
Argentine
,
"
<EOS>
but
I
have
other
duties
for
you
to
fulfil
.
<EOS>
The
plan
you
proposed
of
demolishing
the
houses
with
gunpowder
shall
be
immediately
put
into
operation
,
under
your
own
superintendence
.
"
 
<EOS>
A
chair
was
now
brought
,
and
the
Lady
Isabella
,
after
a
tender
parting
with
her
lover
,
being
placed
within
it
,
she
was
thus
transported
,
under
the
charge
of
Hodges
and
Chiffinch
,
to
Whitehall
,
where
she
arrived
in
safety
,
though
not
without
having
sustained
some
hindrance
and
inconvenience
.
 
<EOS>
She
had
not
been
gone
many
minutes
,
when
the
conflagration
of
the
cathedral
assumed
its
most
terrific
character
;
the
whole
of
the
mighty
roof
falling
in
,
and
the
flames
soaring
upwards
,
as
before
related
.
<EOS>
Up
to
this
time
,
Solomon
Eagle
had
maintained
his
position
at
the
eastern
end
of
the
roof
,
and
still
grasped
the
stone
cross
.
<EOS>
His
situation
now
attracted
universal
attention
,
for
it
was
evident
he
must
speedily
perish
.
 
<EOS>
"
Poor
wretch
!
"
exclaimed
the
king
,
shuddering
,
"
I
fear
there
is
no
way
of
saving
him
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
None
,
whatever
my
liege
,
"
replied
Rochester
,
"
nor
do
I
believe
he
would
consent
to
it
if
there
were
.
<EOS>
But
he
is
again
menacing
your
majesty
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
As
Rochester
spoke
,
Solomon
Eagle
shook
his
arm
menacingly
at
the
royal
party
,
raising
it
aloft
,
as
if
invoking
the
vengeance
of
Heaven
.
<EOS>
He
then
knelt
down
upon
the
sloping
ridge
of
the
roof
,
as
if
in
prayer
,
and
his
figure
,
thus
seen
relieved
against
the
mighty
sheet
of
flame
,
might
have
been
taken
for
an
image
of
Saint
John
the
Baptist
carved
in
stone
.
<EOS>
Not
an
eye
in
the
vast
crowd
below
but
was
fixed
on
him
.
<EOS>
In
a
few
moments
he
rose
again
,
and
tossing
his
arms
aloft
,
and
shrieking
,
in
a
voice
distinctly
heard
above
the
awful
roar
around
him
,
the
single
word
"
_
Resurgam
!
<EOS>
_
"
flung
himself
headlong
into
the
flaming
abyss
.
<EOS>
A
simultaneous
cry
of
horror
rose
from
the
whole
assemblage
on
beholding
this
desperate
action
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
last
exclamation
of
the
poor
wretch
may
apply
to
the
cathedral
,
as
well
as
to
himself
,
"
remarked
the
monarch
,
to
a
middle
-
aged
personage
,
with
a
pleasing
and
highly
intellectual
countenance
,
standing
near
him
:
"
for
the
old
building
shall
rise
again
,
like
a
phoenix
from
its
fires
,
with
renewed
beauty
,
and
under
your
superintendence
,
Doctor
Christopher
Wren
.
"
 
<EOS>
The
great
architect
bowed
.
<EOS>
"
I
can
not
hope
to
erect
such
another
structure
,
"
he
said
,
modestly
;
"
but
I
will
endeavour
to
design
an
edifice
that
shall
not
disgrace
your
majesty
's
city
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
must
build
me
another
city
at
the
same
time
,
Doctor
Wren
,
"
sighed
the
king
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ah
!
"
<EOS>
he
added
,
"
is
not
that
Mr.
Lilly
,
the
almanac
-
maker
,
whom
I
see
among
the
crowd
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
,
"
replied
Rochester
.
 
<EOS>
"
Bid
him
come
to
me
,
"
replied
the
king
.
<EOS>
And
the
order
being
obeyed
,
he
said
to
the
astrologer
,
"
Well
,
Mr.
Lilly
,
your
second
prediction
has
come
to
pass
.
<EOS>
We
have
had
the
Plague
,
and
now
we
have
the
Fire
.
<EOS>
You
may
thank
my
clemency
that
I
do
not
order
you
to
be
cast
into
the
flames
,
like
the
poor
wretch
who
has
just
perished
before
our
eyes
,
as
a
wizard
and
professor
of
the
black
art
.
<EOS>
How
did
you
obtain
information
of
these
fatal
events
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
By
a
careful
study
of
the
heavenly
bodies
,
sire
,
"
replied
Lilly
,
"
and
by
long
and
patient
calculations
,
which
,
if
your
majesty
or
any
of
your
attendants
had
had
leisure
or
inclination
to
make
,
would
have
afforded
you
the
same
information
.
<EOS>
_
<EOS>
I
_
make
no
pretence
to
the
gift
of
prophecy
,
but
this
calamity
was
predicted
in
the
last
century
.
<EOS>
"
 
"
<EOS>
Indeed
!
<EOS>
by
whom
?
"
asked
the
king
.
 
<EOS>
"
By
Michael
Nostradamus
,
"
replied
Lilly
;
"
his
prediction
runs
thus:--
   
'
<EOS>
La
sang
du
juste
à
Londres
fera
faute
,
     
Bruslez
par
feu
,
le
vingt
et
trois
,
les
Six
;
   
<EOS>
La
Dame
antique
cherra
de
place
haute
,
     
De
même
secte
plusieurs
seront
occis
.
<EOS>
'[1
]
 
<EOS>
And
thus
I
venture
to
explain
it
.
<EOS>
The
'
blood
of
the
just
'
refers
to
the
impious
and
execrable
murder
of
your
majesty
's
royal
father
of
blessed
memory
.
'
<EOS>
Three
-
and
-
twenty
and
six
'
gives
the
exact
year
of
the
calamity
;
and
it
may
likewise
give
us
,
as
will
be
seen
by
computation
hereafter
,
the
amount
of
habitations
to
be
destroyed
.
<EOS>
The
'
Ancient
Dame
'
undoubtedly
refers
to
the
venerable
pile
now
burning
before
us
,
which
,
as
it
stands
in
the
most
eminent
spot
in
the
city
,
clearly
'
falls
from
its
high
place
.
'
<EOS>
The
expression
'
of
the
same
sect
'
refers
not
to
men
,
but
churches
,
of
which
a
large
number
<EOS>
,
I
grieve
to
say
it
,
are
already
destroyed
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
[
Footnote
1
:
   
<EOS>
'
The
blood
of
the
just
shall
be
wanting
in
London
,
     
Burnt
by
fire
of
three
-
and
-
twenty
,
the
Six
;
   
<EOS>
The
ancient
Dame
shall
fall
from
her
high
place
,
     
Of
the
same
sect
many
shall
be
killed
.
'
]
 
<EOS>
"
The
prophecy
is
a
singular
one
,
"
remarked
Charles
,
musingly
"
and
you
have
given
it
a
plausible
interpretation
.
<EOS>
"
And
for
some
moments
he
appeared
lost
in
reflection
.
<EOS>
Suddenly
rousing
himself
,
he
took
forth
his
tablets
,
and
hastily
tracing
a
few
lines
upon
a
leaf
,
tore
it
out
,
and
delivered
it
with
his
signet
-
ring
to
Lord
Argentine
.
<EOS>
"
Take
this
,
my
lord
,
"
he
said
,
"
to
Lord
Craven
.
<EOS>
You
will
find
him
at
his
post
in
Tower
-
street
.
<EOS>
A
band
of
my
attendants
shall
go
with
you
.
<EOS>
Embark
at
the
nearest
stairs
you
can
--
<EOS>
those
at
Blackfriars
I
should
conceive
the
most
accessible
.
<EOS>
Bid
the
men
row
for
their
lives
.
<EOS>
As
soon
as
you
join
Lord
Craven
,
commence
operations
.
<EOS>
The
Tower
must
be
preserved
at
all
hazards
.
<EOS>
Mark
me!--at
all
hazards
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
understand
your
majesty
,
"
replied
Argentine--"your
commands
shall
be
implicitly
obeyed
.
<EOS>
And
if
the
conflagration
has
not
gone
too
far
,
I
will
answer
with
my
life
that
I
preserve
the
fortress
.
"
<EOS>
And
he
departed
on
his
mission
.
  
<EOS>
IX
.
 
<EOS>
WHAT
BEFEL
CHOWLES
AND
JUDITH
IN
THE
VAULTS
OF
SAINT
FAITH'S.
 
<EOS>
Having
now
seen
what
occurred
outside
Saint
Paul
's
,
we
shall
proceed
to
the
vaults
beneath
it
.
<EOS>
Chowles
and
Judith
,
it
has
been
mentioned
,
were
descried
by
Leonard
,
just
before
the
outbreak
of
the
fire
,
stealing
into
Saint
Faith
's
,
and
carrying
a
heavy
chest
between
them
.
<EOS>
This
chest
contained
some
of
the
altar
-
plate
,
which
they
had
pillaged
from
the
Convocation
House
.
<EOS>
As
they
traversed
the
aisles
of
Saint
Faith
's
,
which
were
now
filled
with
books
and
paper
,
they
could
distinctly
hear
the
raging
of
the
fire
without
,
and
Judith
,
who
was
far
less
intimidated
than
her
companion
,
observed
,
"
Let
it
roar
on
.
<EOS>
It
can
not
injure
us
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
not
so
sure
of
that
,
"
replied
Chowles
,
doubtfully
,
"
<EOS>
I
wish
we
had
taken
our
hoards
elsewhere
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
There
is
no
use
in
wishing
that
now
,
"
rejoined
Judith
.
"
<EOS>
And
it
would
have
been
wholly
impossible
to
get
them
out
of
the
city
.
<EOS>
But
have
no
fear
.
<EOS>
The
fire
,
I
tell
you
,
can
not
reach
us
.
<EOS>
It
could
as
soon
burn
into
the
solid
earth
as
into
this
place
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
comforts
me
to
hear
you
say
so
,
"
replied
Chowles
.
"
<EOS>
And
when
I
think
of
those
mighty
stone
floors
above
us
,
I
feel
we
are
quite
safe
.
<EOS>
No
,
no
,
it
can
never
make
its
way
through
them
.
"
 
<EOS>
Thus
discoursing
,
they
reached
the
charnel
at
the
further
end
of
the
church
,
where
Chowles
struck
a
light
,
and
producing
a
flask
of
strong
waters
,
took
a
copious
draught
himself
and
handed
the
flask
to
Judith
,
who
imitated
his
example
.
<EOS>
Their
courage
being
thus
stimulated
,
they
opened
the
chest
,
and
Chowles
was
so
enraptured
with
its
glittering
contents
that
he
commenced
capering
round
the
vault
.
<EOS>
Recalled
to
quietude
by
a
stern
reproof
from
Judith
,
he
opened
a
secret
door
in
the
wall
,
and
pushed
the
chest
into
a
narrow
passage
beyond
it
.
<EOS>
Fearful
of
being
discovered
in
their
retreat
,
they
took
a
basket
of
provisions
and
liquor
with
them
,
and
then
closed
the
door
.
<EOS>
For
some
time
,
they
proceeded
along
the
passage
,
pushing
the
chest
before
them
,
until
they
came
to
a
descent
of
a
few
steps
,
which
brought
them
to
a
large
vault
,
half
-
filled
with
bags
of
gold
,
chests
of
plate
,
caskets
,
and
other
plunder
.
<EOS>
At
the
further
end
of
this
vault
was
a
strong
wooden
door
.
<EOS>
Pushing
the
chest
into
the
middle
of
the
chamber
,
Chowles
seated
himself
upon
it
,
and
opening
the
basket
of
provisions
,
took
out
the
bottle
of
spirits
,
and
again
had
recourse
to
it
.
 
<EOS>
"
How
comfortable
and
secure
we
feel
in
this
quiet
place
,
"
he
said
;
"
while
all
above
us
is
burning
.
<EOS>
I
declare
I
feel
quite
merry
,
ha
!
ha
!
"
<EOS>
And
he
forced
a
harsh
and
discordant
laugh
.
 
<EOS>
"
Give
me
the
bottle
,
"
rejoined
Judith
,
sternly
,
"
and
do
n't
grin
like
a
death
's
head
.
<EOS>
I
do
n't
like
to
see
the
frightful
face
you
make
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
's
the
first
time
you
ever
thought
my
face
frightful
,
"
replied
Chowles
,
"
and
I
begin
to
think
you
are
afraid
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Afraid
!
"
echoed
Judith
,
forcing
a
derisive
laugh
in
her
turn
;
"
afraid
--
of
what
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
Nay
,
I
do
n't
know
,
"
replied
Chowles
;
"
only
I
feel
a
little
uncomfortable
.
<EOS>
What
if
we
should
not
be
able
to
breathe
here
?
<EOS>
The
very
idea
gives
me
a
tightness
across
the
chest
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Silence
!
"
cried
Judith
,
with
a
fierceness
that
effectually
insured
obedience
to
her
command
.
 
<EOS>
Chowles
again
had
recourse
to
the
bottle
,
and
deriving
a
false
courage
from
it
,
as
before
,
commenced
skipping
about
the
chamber
in
his
usual
fantastical
manner
.
<EOS>
Judith
,
did
not
attempt
to
check
him
,
but
remained
with
her
chin
resting
upon
her
hand
gazing
at
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
you
remember
the
Dance
of
Death
,
Judith
?
"
he
cried
,
executing
some
of
the
wildest
flourishes
he
had
then
performed
,
"
and
how
I
surprised
the
Earl
of
Rochester
and
his
crew
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
do
,
"
replied
Judith
,
sternly
,
"
and
I
hope
we
may
not
soon
have
to
perform
that
dance
together
in
reality
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
was
a
merry
night
,
"
rejoined
Chowles
,
who
did
not
hear
what
she
said
,
"
a
right
merry
night
--
and
so
to
-
night
shall
be
,
in
spite
of
what
is
occurring
overhead
.
<EOS>
Ha
!
ha
!
"
<EOS>
And
he
took
another
long
pull
at
the
flask
.
<EOS>
"
I
breathe
freely
now
.
"
<EOS>
And
he
continued
his
wild
flourishes
until
he
was
completely
exhausted
.
<EOS>
He
then
sat
down
by
Judith
,
and
would
have
twined
his
bony
arms
round
her
neck
,
but
she
roughly
repulsed
him
.
 
<EOS>
With
a
growl
of
displeasure
,
he
then
proceeded
to
open
and
examine
the
various
bags
,
chests
,
and
caskets
piled
upon
the
floor
,
and
the
sight
of
their
contents
so
excited
Judith
,
that
shaking
off
her
misgivings
,
she
joined
him
,
and
they
continued
opening
case
after
case
,
glutting
their
greedy
eyes
,
until
Chowles
became
aware
that
the
vault
was
filled
with
smoke
.
<EOS>
As
soon
as
he
perceived
this
,
he
started
to
his
feet
in
terror
.
 
<EOS>
"
We
are
lost
--
we
shall
be
suffocated
!
"
<EOS>
he
cried
!
<EOS>
Judith
likewise
arose
,
and
her
looks
showed
that
she
shared
in
his
apprehensions
.
 
<EOS>
"
We
must
not
stay
here
,
"
cried
Chowles
;
"
and
yet
,
"
he
added
,
with
an
agonised
look
at
the
rich
store
before
him
,
"
the
treasure
!
<EOS>
the
treasure
!
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Ay
,
let
us
,
at
least
,
take
something
with
us
,
"
rejoined
Judith
,
snatching
up
two
or
three
of
the
most
valuable
caskets
.
 
<EOS>
While
Chowles
gazed
at
the
heap
before
him
,
hesitating
what
to
select
,
the
smoke
grew
so
dense
around
them
,
that
Judith
seized
his
arm
,
and
dragged
him
away
.
<EOS>
"
I
come
--
I
come
!
"
<EOS>
he
cried
,
snatching
up
a
bag
of
gold
.
 
<EOS>
They
then
threaded
the
narrow
passage
,
Judith
leading
the
way
and
bearing
the
light
.
<EOS>
The
smoke
grew
thicker
and
thicker
as
they
advanced
;
but
regardless
of
this
,
they
hurried
to
the
secret
door
leading
to
the
charnel
.
<EOS>
Judith
touched
the
spring
,
but
as
she
did
so
,
a
sheet
of
flame
burst
in
and
drove
her
back
.
<EOS>
Chowles
dashed
passed
her
,
and
with
great
presence
of
mind
shut
the
door
,
excluding
the
flame
.
<EOS>
They
then
hastily
retraced
their
steps
,
feeling
that
not
a
moment
was
to
be
lost
if
they
would
escape
.
<EOS>
The
air
in
the
vault
,
thickened
by
the
smoke
,
had
become
so
hot
that
they
could
scarcely
breathe
;
added
to
which
,
to
increase
their
terror
,
they
heard
the
most
awful
cracking
of
the
walls
overhead
,
as
if
the
whole
fabric
were
breaking
asunder
to
its
foundation
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
cathedral
is
tumbling
upon
us
!
<EOS>
We
shall
be
buried
alive
!
"
<EOS>
exclaimed
Chowles
,
as
he
listened
with
indescribable
terror
to
the
noise
overhead
!
 
<EOS>
"
I
owe
my
death
to
you
,
wretch
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Judith
,
fiercely
.
<EOS>
"
You
persuaded
me
to
come
hither
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Chowles
.
<EOS>
"
It
is
a
lie
!
<EOS>
You
were
the
person
who
proposed
it
.
<EOS>
But
for
you
I
should
have
left
our
hoards
here
,
and
come
for
them
after
the
fire
was
over
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
you
who
lie
!
"
<EOS>
returned
Judith
,
with
increased
fury
,
"
that
was
my
proposal
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Hold
your
tongue
,
you
she
-
devil
,
"
cried
Chowles
,
"
it
is
you
who
have
brought
me
into
this
strait
--
and
if
you
do
not
cease
taunting
me
,
I
will
silence
you
for
ever
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Coward
and
fool
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Judith
,
"
I
will
at
least
have
the
satisfaction
of
seeing
you
die
before
me
.
"
 
<EOS>
And
as
she
spoke
,
she
rushed
towards
him
,
and
a
desperate
struggle
commenced
.
<EOS>
And
thus
while
the
walls
were
cracking
overhead
,
threatening
them
with
instant
destruction
,
the
two
wretches
continued
their
strife
,
uttering
the
most
horrible
blasphemies
and
execrations
.
<EOS>
Judith
,
being
the
stronger
of
the
two
,
had
the
advantage
,
and
she
had
seized
her
opponent
by
the
throat
with
the
intention
of
strangling
him
,
when
a
most
terrific
crash
was
heard
causing
her
to
loose
her
gripe
.
<EOS>
The
air
instantly
became
as
hot
as
the
breath
of
a
furnace
,
and
both
started
to
their
feet
.
<EOS>
"
What
has
happened
?
"
gasped
Chowles
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
know
not
,
"
replied
Judith
,
"
and
I
dare
not
look
down
the
passage
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Then
I
will
,
"
replied
Chowles
,
and
he
advanced
a
few
paces
up
it
,
and
then
hastily
returned
,
shrieking
,
"
it
is
filled
with
boiling
lead
,
and
the
stream
is
flowing
towards
us
.
"
 
<EOS>
Scarcely
able
to
credit
the
extent
of
the
danger
,
Judith
gazed
down
the
passage
,
and
there
beheld
a
glowing
silvery
stream
trickling
slowly
onwards
.
<EOS>
She
saw
too
well
,
that
if
they
could
not
effect
their
retreat
instantly
,
their
fate
was
sealed
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
door
of
the
vault
!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
she
cried
,
pointing
towards
it
,
"
where
is
the
key
?
<EOS>
where
is
the
key
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
not
got
it
,
"
replied
Chowles
,
distractedly
,
"
I
can
not
tell
where
to
find
it
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Then
we
are
lost
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Judith
,
with
a
terrible
execration
.
 
<EOS>
"
Not
so
,
"
replied
Chowles
,
<EOS>
snatching
up
a
pickaxe
,
"
if
I
can
not
unlock
the
door
,
I
can
break
it
open
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
With
this
,
he
commenced
furiously
striking
against
it
,
while
Judith
,
who
was
completely
horror
-
stricken
,
and
filled
with
the
conviction
that
her
last
moments
were
at
hand
,
fell
on
her
knees
beside
him
,
and
gazing
down
the
passage
,
along
which
she
could
see
the
stream
of
molten
lead
,
now
nearly
a
foot
in
depth
,
gradually
advancing
,
and
hissing
as
it
came
,
shrieked
to
Chowles
to
increase
his
exertions
.
<EOS>
He
needed
no
incitement
to
do
so
,
but
nerved
by
fear
,
continued
to
deal
blow
after
blow
against
the
door
,
until
at
last
he
effected
a
small
breach
just
above
the
lock
.
<EOS>
But
this
only
showed
him
how
vain
were
his
hopes
,
for
a
stream
of
fire
and
smoke
poured
through
the
aperture
.
<EOS>
Notwithstanding
this
,
he
continued
his
exertions
,
Judith
shrieking
all
the
time
,
until
the
lock
at
last
yielded
.
<EOS>
He
then
threw
open
the
door
,
but
finding
the
whole
passage
involved
in
flame
,
was
obliged
to
close
it
.
<EOS>
Judith
had
now
risen
,
and
their
looks
at
each
other
at
this
fearful
moment
were
terrible
in
the
extreme
.
<EOS>
Retreating
to
either
side
of
the
cell
,
they
glared
at
each
other
like
wild
beasts
.
<EOS>
Suddenly
,
Judith
casting
her
eyes
to
the
entrance
of
the
vault
,
uttered
a
yell
of
terror
,
that
caused
her
companion
to
look
in
that
direction
,
and
he
perceived
that
the
stream
of
molten
lead
had
gained
it
,
and
was
descending
the
steps
.
<EOS>
He
made
a
rush
towards
the
door
at
the
same
time
with
Judith
,
and
another
struggle
ensued
,
in
which
he
succeeded
in
dashing
her
upon
the
floor
.
<EOS>
He
again
opened
the
door
,
but
was
again
driven
backwards
by
the
terrific
flame
,
and
perceived
that
the
fiery
current
had
reached
Judith
,
who
was
writhing
and
shrieking
in
its
embrace
.
<EOS>
Before
Chowles
could
again
stir
,
it
was
upon
him
.
<EOS>
With
a
yell
of
anguish
,
he
fell
forward
,
and
was
instantly
stifled
in
the
glowing
torrent
,
which
in
a
short
time
flooded
the
whole
chamber
,
burying
the
two
partners
in
iniquity
,
and
the
whole
of
their
ill
-
gotten
gains
,
in
its
burning
waves
.
  
<EOS>
X.
 
CONCLUSION
.
 
<EOS>
Lord
Argentine
proceeded
,
as
directed
by
the
king
,
to
the
eastern
end
of
Tower
-
street
,
where
he
found
Lord
Craven
,
and
having
delivered
him
the
king
's
missive
,
and
shown
him
the
signet
,
they
proceeded
to
the
western
side
of
the
Tower
Dock
,
and
having
procured
a
sufficient
number
of
miners
and
engineers
,
together
with
a
supply
of
powder
from
the
fortress
,
commenced
undermining
the
whole
of
the
row
of
habitations
called
Tower
-
bank
,
on
the
edge
of
the
dock
,
having
first
,
it
is
scarcely
necessary
to
state
,
taken
care
to
clear
them
of
their
inhabitants
.
<EOS>
The
powder
deposited
,
the
trains
were
fired
,
and
the
buildings
blown
into
the
air
.
<EOS>
At
this
time
the
whole
of
the
western
side
of
the
Tower
Moat
was
covered
with
low
wooden
houses
and
sheds
,
and
,
mindful
of
the
king
's
instructions
,
Lord
Argentine
suggested
to
Lord
Craven
that
they
should
be
destroyed
.
<EOS>
The
latter
acquiescing
,
they
proceeded
to
their
task
,
and
in
a
short
time
the
whole
of
the
buildings
of
whatever
description
,
from
the
bulwark
-
gate
to
the
city
postern
,
at
the
north
of
the
Tower
,
and
nearly
opposite
the
Bowyer
Tower
,
were
destroyed
.
<EOS>
Long
before
this
was
accomplished
they
were
joined
by
the
Duke
of
York
,
who
lent
his
utmost
assistance
to
the
task
,
and
when
night
came
on
,
a
clear
space
of
at
least
a
hundred
yards
in
depth
,
had
been
formed
between
the
ancient
fortress
and
the
danger
with
which
it
was
threatened
.
 
<EOS>
Meantime
the
conflagration
continued
to
rage
with
unabated
fury
.
<EOS>
It
burnt
throughout
the
whole
of
Monday
night
,
and
having
destroyed
Saint
Paul
's
,
as
before
related
,
poured
down
Ludgate
-
hill
,
consuming
all
in
its
way
,
and
,
crossing
Fleet
Bridge
,
commenced
its
ravages
upon
the
great
thoroughfare
adjoining
it
.
<EOS>
On
Tuesday
an
immense
tract
was
on
fire
.
<EOS>
All
Fleet
-
street
,
as
far
as
the
Inner
Temple
,
Ludgate
-
hill
,
and
the
whole
of
the
city
eastwards
,
along
the
banks
of
the
Thames
,
up
to
the
Tower
Dock
,
where
the
devastation
was
checked
by
the
vast
gap
of
houses
demolished
,
were
in
flames
.
<EOS>
From
thence
the
boundary
of
the
fire
extended
to
the
end
of
Mark
-
lane
,
Lime
-
street
,
and
Leadenhall
,
the
strong
walls
of
which
resisted
its
fury
.
<EOS>
Ascending
again
by
the
Standard
on
Cornhill
,
Threadneedle
-
street
,
and
Austin
Friars
,
it
embraced
Drapers
'
Hall
,
and
the
whole
mass
of
buildings
to
the
west
of
Throgmorton
-
street
.
<EOS>
It
next
proceeded
to
the
then
new
buildings
behind
Saint
Margaret
's
,
Lothbury
,
and
so
on
westward
to
the
upper
end
of
Cateaton
-
street
,
whence
it
spread
to
the
second
postern
in
London
Wall
,
and
destroying
the
ramparts
and
suburbs
as
far
as
Cripplegate
,
consumed
Little
Wood
-
street
,
Mungwell
-
street
,
and
the
whole
of
the
city
wall
on
the
west
as
far
as
Aldersgate
.
<EOS>
Passing
a
little
to
the
north
of
Saint
Sepulchre
's
,
which
it
destroyed
,
it
crossed
Holborn
Bridge
,
and
ascending
Saint
Andrew's
-
hill
,
passed
the
end
of
Shoe
-
lane
,
and
so
on
to
the
end
of
Fetter
-
lane
.
<EOS>
The
whole
of
the
buildings
contained
within
this
boundary
were
now
on
fire
,
and
burning
with
terrific
fury
.
<EOS>
And
so
they
continued
till
the
middle
of
Wednesday
,
when
the
wind
abating
,
and
an
immense
quantity
of
houses
being
demolished
according
to
Lord
Argentine
's
plan
,
the
conflagration
was
got
under
;
and
though
it
broke
out
in
several
places
after
that
time
,
little
mischief
was
done
,
and
it
may
be
said
to
have
ceased
on
the
middle
of
that
day
.
 
<EOS>
On
Saturday
morning
in
that
week
,
soon
after
daybreak
,
a
young
man
,
plainly
yet
richly
attired
in
the
habiliments
then
worn
by
persons
of
high
rank
,
took
his
way
over
the
smouldering
heaps
of
rubbish
,
and
along
the
ranks
of
ruined
and
blackened
walls
denoting
the
habitations
that
had
once
constituted
Fleet
-
street
.
<EOS>
It
was
with
no
little
risk
,
and
some
difficulty
,
that
he
could
force
his
way
,
now
clambering
over
heaps
of
smouldering
ashes
,
now
passing
by
some
toppling
wall
,
which
fell
with
a
terrific
crash
after
he
had
just
passed
it
--
now
creeping
under
an
immense
pile
of
blackened
rafters
;
but
he
at
length
reached
Fleet
Bridge
,
where
he
paused
to
gaze
at
the
scene
of
devastation
around
him
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
indeed
a
melancholy
sight
,
and
drew
tears
to
his
eyes
.
<EOS>
The
ravages
of
the
fire
were
almost
inconceivable
.
<EOS>
Great
beams
were
burnt
to
charcoal
--
stones
calcined
,
and
as
white
as
snow
,
and
such
walls
and
towers
as
were
left
standing
were
so
damaged
that
their
instant
fall
was
to
be
expected
.
<EOS>
The
very
water
in
the
wells
and
fountains
was
boiling
,
and
even
the
muddy
Fleet
sent
forth
a
hot
steam
.
<EOS>
The
fire
still
lingered
in
the
lower
parts
of
many
habitations
,
especially
where
wine
,
spirits
,
or
inflammable
goods
had
been
kept
;
and
these
"
voragos
of
subterranean
cellars
,
"
<EOS>
as
Evelyn
terms
them
,
still
emitted
flames
,
together
with
a
prodigious
smoke
and
stench
.
<EOS>
Undismayed
by
the
dangers
of
the
path
he
had
to
traverse
,
the
young
man
ascended
Ludgate
-
hill
,
still
encountering
the
same
devastation
,
and
passing
through
the
ruined
gateway
,
the
end
of
which
remained
perfect
,
approached
what
had
once
been
Saint
Paul
's
Cathedral
.
<EOS>
Mounting
a
heap
of
rubbish
at
the
end
of
Ludgate
street
,
he
gazed
at
the
mighty
ruin
,
which
looked
more
like
the
remains
of
a
city
than
those
of
a
single
edifice
.
 
<EOS>
The
solid
walls
and
buttresses
were
split
and
rent
asunder
;
enormous
stones
were
splintered
and
calcined
by
the
heat
;
and
vast
flakes
having
scaled
from
off
the
pillars
,
gave
them
a
hoary
and
almost
ghostly
appearance
.
<EOS>
Its
enormous
extent
was
now
for
the
first
time
clearly
seen
,
and
,
strange
to
say
it
looked
twice
as
large
in
ruins
as
when
entire
.
<EOS>
The
central
tower
was
still
standing
,
but
chipped
,
broken
,
and
calcined
,
like
the
rest
of
the
structure
,
by
the
vehement
heat
of
the
flames
.
<EOS>
Part
of
the
roof
,
in
its
fall
,
broke
through
the
solid
floor
of
the
choir
,
which
was
of
immense
thickness
,
into
Saint
Faith
's
,
and
destroyed
the
magazine
of
books
and
paper
deposited
there
by
the
booksellers
.
<EOS>
The
portico
,
erected
by
Inigo
Jones
,
and
which
found
so
much
favour
in
Evelyn
's
eyes
,
that
he
describes
it
as
"
comparable
to
any
in
Europe
,
"
and
particularly
deplores
its
loss
,
shared
the
fate
of
the
rest
of
the
building
--
<EOS>
the
only
part
left
uninjured
being
the
architrave
,
the
inscription
on
which
was
undefaced
.
 
<EOS>
Having
satiated
himself
with
this
sad
but
striking
prospect
,
the
young
man
,
with
some
toil
and
trouble
,
crossed
the
churchyard
,
and
gained
Cheapside
,
where
a
yet
more
terrific
scene
of
devastation
than
that
which
he
had
previously
witnessed
burst
upon
him
.
<EOS>
On
the
right
of
London
Bridge
,
which
he
could
discern
through
the
chasms
of
the
houses
,
and
almost
to
the
Tower
,
were
nothing
but
ruins
,
while
a
similar
waste
lay
on
the
left
.
<EOS>
Such
was
the
terrible
change
that
had
been
wrought
in
the
aspect
of
the
ruined
city
,
that
if
the
young
man
had
not
had
some
marks
to
guide
him
,
he
would
not
have
known
where
he
was
.
<EOS>
The
tower
and
ruined
walls
of
Saint
Peter
's
Church
pointed
out
to
him
the
entrance
to
Wood
-
street
,
and
,
entering
it
,
he
traversed
it
with
considerable
difficulty
--
for
the
narrow
thoroughfares
were
much
fuller
of
rubbish
,
and
much
less
freed
from
smoke
and
fiery
vapour
,
than
the
wider
--
until
he
reached
a
part
of
it
with
which
he
had
once
been
well
acquainted
.
<EOS>
But
,
alas
!
<EOS>
how
changed
was
that
familiar
spot
.
<EOS>
The
house
he
sought
was
a
mere
heap
of
ruins
.
<EOS>
While
gazing
at
them
,
he
heard
a
voice
behind
him
,
and
turning
,
beheld
Mr.
Bloundel
and
his
son
Stephen
,
forcing
their
way
through
what
had
once
been
Maiden
-
lane
.
<EOS>
A
warm
greeting
passed
between
them
,
and
Mr.
Bloundel
gazed
for
some
time
in
silence
upon
the
wreck
of
his
dwelling
.
<EOS>
Tears
forced
themselves
into
his
eyes
,
and
his
companions
were
no
less
moved
.
<EOS>
As
he
turned
to
depart
,
he
observed
to
the
young
man
with
some
severity
:
 
<EOS>
"
How
is
it
,
Leonard
,
that
I
see
you
in
this
gay
apparel
?
<EOS>
Surely
,
the
present
is
not
a
fitting
season
for
such
idle
display
.
"
 
<EOS>
Lord
Argentine
,
for
such
it
was
,
now
explained
to
the
wonder
-
stricken
grocer
all
that
had
occurred
to
him
,
adding
that
he
had
intended
coming
to
him
that
very
day
,
if
he
had
not
been
thus
anticipated
,
to
give
him
the
present
explanation
.
 
<EOS>
"
And
where
are
Farmer
Wingfield
and
Blaize
?
"
asked
Mr.
Bloundel
.
<EOS>
"
We
have
been
extremely
uneasy
at
your
prolonged
absence
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
They
are
both
at
the
palace
,
"
replied
Lord
Argentine
,
"
and
have
both
been
laid
up
with
slight
injuries
received
during
the
conflagration
;
but
I
believe
--
nay
,
I
am
sure
--
they
will
get
out
to
-
day
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
That
is
well
,
"
replied
Mr.
Bloundel
;
"
and
now
let
me
congratulate
you
,
Leonard
--
that
is
,
my
lord
--
how
strange
such
a
title
sounds!--on
your
new
dignity
.
 
<EOS>
"
And
accept
my
congratulations
,
too
,
my
lord
,
"
said
Stephen
.
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
!
do
not
style
me
thus
,
"
said
Argentine
.
<EOS>
"
With
you
,
at
least
,
let
me
be
ever
Leonard
Holt
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
are
still
my
old
apprentice
<EOS>
,
I
see
,
"
cried
the
grocer
,
warmly
grasping
his
hand
.
 
<EOS>
"
And
such
I
shall
ever
continue
in
feeling
,
"
returned
the
other
,
cordially
returning
the
pressure
.
 
<EOS>
Three
days
after
this
,
Lord
Argentine
was
united
to
the
Lady
<EOS>
Isabella.--the
king
,
as
he
had
promised
,
giving
away
the
bride
.
<EOS>
The
Earl
of
Rochester
was
present
,
together
with
the
grocer
and
his
wife
,
and
the
whole
of
their
family
.
<EOS>
Another
marriage
also
took
place
on
the
same
day
between
Blaize
and
Patience
.
<EOS>
Both
unions
,
it
is
satisfactory
to
be
able
to
state
,
were
extremely
happy
,
though
it
would
be
uncandid
not
to
mention
,
that
in
the
latter
case
,
to
use
a
homely
but
expressive
phrase
,
"
the
grey
mare
proved
the
better
horse
.
<EOS>
"
Blaize
,
however
,
was
exceedingly
content
under
his
government
.
<EOS>
He
settled
at
Willesden
with
his
wife
,
where
they
lived
to
a
good
old
age
,
and
where
some
of
his
descendants
may
still
be
found
.
 
<EOS>
Mr.
Bloundel
sustained
only
a
trifling
loss
by
the
fire
.
<EOS>
Another
house
was
erected
on
the
site
of
the
old
habitation
,
where
he
carried
on
his
business
as
respectably
and
as
profitably
as
before
,
until
,
in
the
course
of
nature
,
he
was
gathered
to
his
fathers
,
and
succeeded
by
his
son
Stephen
,
leaving
an
unblemished
character
behind
him
as
a
legacy
to
his
family
.
<EOS>
Nor
was
it
his
only
legacy
,
in
a
worldly
sense
,
for
his
time
had
not
been
misspent
,
and
he
had
well
-
husbanded
his
money
.
<EOS>
All
his
family
turned
out
well
,
and
were
successful
in
the
world
.
<EOS>
Stephen
rose
to
the
highest
civic
dignities
,
and
the
younger
obtained
great
distinction
.
<EOS>
Their
daughter
Christiana
became
Lady
Argentine
,
being
wedded
to
the
eldest
son
of
the
baron
and
baroness
.
 
<EOS>
Mike
Macascree
,
the
piper
,
and
Bell
,
found
a
happy
asylum
with
the
same
noble
family
.
 
<EOS>
As
to
Lord
and
Lady
Argentine
,
theirs
was
a
life
of
uninterrupted
happiness
.
<EOS>
Devotedly
attached
to
her
lord
,
the
Lady
Isabella
seemed
only
to
live
for
him
,
and
he
well
repaid
her
affection
.
<EOS>
By
sedulously
cultivating
his
talents
and
powers
,
which
were
considerable
,
he
was
enabled
to
reflect
credit
upon
the
high
rank
to
which
it
had
pleased
a
grateful
sovereign
to
elevate
him
.
<EOS>
He
lived
to
see
the
new
cathedral
completed
by
Sir
Christopher
Wren
,
and
often
visited
it
with
feelings
of
admiration
,
but
never
with
the
same
sentiments
of
veneration
and
awe
that
he
had
experienced
when
,
in
times
long
gone
by
,
he
had
repaired
to
OLD
SAINT
PAUL'S.
   
<EOS>
THE
END
.
